text:
[1969-08-15 14:00:00] Rocky path | I saw a bus coming toward me. It was a mild, cloudy day in August 1969, and I was walking along the outermost trail of the southern islands. Around me were gardens, rocky outcrops, and fields; the path rose and fell along steep slopes, sometimes shielded by dense woods on both sides, sometimes opening up to reveal the sea.
[1969-08-15 14:00:30] Rocky path | I watched the vehicle cross a bridge, driving down the narrow fjord with its right turn signal blinking before finally stopping. The bus belonged to Aucity Shipping Company, painted in two shades of brown.
[1969-08-15 14:01:00] Rocky path | I saw the door open and a small family step out.
[1969-08-15 14:01:05] Rocky path | I noticed the father was a tall, thin man wearing a white shirt and light-colored polyester trousers, carrying two suitcases in his hands.
[1969-08-15 14:01:10] Rocky path | I saw the mother wearing a beige coat, her long hair covered by a pale blue headscarf, one hand pushing a stroller and the other holding a little boy’s hand.
[1969-08-15 14:01:20] Rocky path | I saw the bus continue forward, kicking up a large cloud of gray exhaust on the road. I heard the father say: 'We still have a way to go.'
[1969-08-15 14:01:30] Rocky path | I saw the mother look down at the boy, and he nodded. I heard the mother say: 'Are you okay, Henrik Inge?'
[1969-08-15 14:01:35] Rocky path | I heard him say: 'I'm fine.'
[1969-08-15 14:01:40] Rocky path | I noticed he was about four and a half years old, with hair so light it was almost white, and skin tanned brown from the long summer sun.
[1969-08-15 14:01:45] Rocky path | I saw his younger brother, the infant not yet eight months old, lying in the stroller gazing at the sky. I thought that at this moment, he neither knew where he was nor where he was going.
[1969-08-15 14:02:00] slope path | I watched as they began slowly walking up the slope path.
[1969-08-15 14:02:10] gravel road | Before me lay a gravel road scattered with stones. On both sides stretched open fields, and about five hundred meters ahead was a forest of low trees, seemingly stunted by years of sea winds, extending all the way to the pebble beach.
[1969-08-15 14:02:30] gravel road | I saw a newly built house standing to the right; otherwise, no other buildings were visible around.
[1969-08-15 14:03:00] gravel road | I watched the baby gradually close its eyes and fall asleep amid the gentle rocking. A sharp creaking sound from the carriage’s large spring frame rang in my ears.
[1969-08-15 14:03:15] gravel road | I saw my father put down a box he was carrying and wipe sweat from his forehead. His closely cropped dark hair and thick black beard stood out distinctly.
[1969-08-15 14:03:20] gravel road | I heard him say, "What a stifling hot day."
[1969-08-15 14:03:25] gravel road | I heard her reply, "Yes, but it might be cooler further toward the sea."
[1969-08-15 14:03:30] gravel road | I saw him pick up the box again. I heard him say, "Let's hope so."
[1969-08-15 14:04:00] Rocky | I knew this was an ordinary family. They had just moved here from Bærum, where they had lived for five years. As far as I knew, Rocky was having a house built for them, and during the interim, they were renting an old house outside the former Høver barracks.
[1969-08-15 14:04:10] Rocky | I learned that while in Bærum, he studied English and Leivik during the day and worked night shifts; meanwhile, she attended nursing school at Ullenvold Hospital. I knew he had secured a teaching position, and she worked as a nurse at a care facility.
[1969-08-15 14:04:20] Vesfjord / West Leivik | As far as I know, they met at seventeen and married at twenty. I learned that his relatives did not attend the wedding in West Leivik. Looking at the photo, at his smile surrounded by solitude, I realize he didn't fully belong to her social circle.
[1969-08-15 14:04:30] Rocky | I think, now they are twenty-four, and life lies ahead of them. They have their own jobs, house, and child—the future belongs entirely to them.
[1969-08-15 14:04:35] Rocky | I wonder in my heart—wasn’t it so?
[1969-08-15 14:04:40] Leivik | I know they were both born in 1944. I understand the 1950s was a period of rebuilding, when various social systems began developing, and this generation was finding their place in an emerging society.
[1969-08-15 14:04:50] Outer Sogn South Berlevåg / Jølster | As far as I know, her father came from a farm in South Berlevåg, and her grandfather from a small island overseas. I learned her mother came from a farm in Jølster, where her family's presence can be traced back to the sixteenth century.
[1969-08-15 14:05:00] Vesfjord / Aust-Agder | I know his relatives belonged to a higher social class and had received higher education. From what I’ve heard, his mother came from Aust-Agder, and her father was a sea captain. She followed her husband to Vesfjord—a common way of life at the time.
[1969-08-15 14:05:10] Leivik | I learned that during the 1950s and 60s, a transformation known as the 'spirit of the age' took place—children of fishermen and workers began pursuing higher education, becoming teachers or psychologists, and settling far from their families.
[1969-08-15 14:05:20] Leivik | I understand that the spirit of the age affected everyone differently. I imagine for that young mother, spending her whole life on the farm must have seemed absurd—she must have strongly desired to leave and have a life entirely her own.
[1969-08-15 14:05:30] Leivik / United States | I know there was no tradition of leaving home in her family; the only one who went far away was her father’s brother Magnus, who emigrated to the United States due to poverty. Yet I find that, like many families across the country, her siblings held a firm belief in leaving their hometown.
[1969-08-15 14:05:40] South of Leivik | I understand his situation was completely different—his family expected him to pursue better education, not to marry a farmer’s daughter and settle in a southern residential area.
[1969-08-15 14:06:00] on the way to the new house | I watched them walking down the path to their new home. Father dragged a heavy crate filled with sixties clothing, mother pushed a lace-decorated baby stroller, and eldest son Henrik Inge happily darted between them, brimming with hope for the future.
[1969-08-15 14:07:00] rental housing area | I watched them pass through the woods and enter this rental housing area. I noticed a gas repair station on the right, and to the left, a large red military barracks surrounded by gravel; beyond it lay a dense pine forest.
[1969-08-15 14:08:00] Rocky Church / Meld Island | About one kilometer to the east, I could see the elevated stone church. The area around it was dotted with exotic flowers, and fossils were buried among the pebble beaches. I knew that Rocky Church was built in 1150. As far as I knew, Meld Island bore witness to the region’s glorious trading history. I learned that Rocky was the first place in the country where potatoes were planted, and Stone Age weapons lay hidden beneath the meadows.
[1969-08-15 14:09:00] rental housing area | I watched this moving family slowly cross the open land. I noticed that the marks left on this land weren’t ancient ones, but traces from World War II.
[1969-08-15 14:09:30] rental housing area | I knew this area had been occupied by Oswick forces during the war. I understood there were low brick bunkers standing in the woods, artillery emplacements once stood at the highest cliff points, and even a small airfield existed here.
[1969-08-15 14:10:00] red house | I saw a detached house painted red with white window frames. I smelled the scent of the forest and sea salt, and could hear the rhythmic sound of waves from hundreds of meters away.
[1969-08-15 14:11:00] red house | I saw father put down the crate and find the key to unlock the door. Inside, I saw a hallway, kitchen, living room with a wood stove, and three bedrooms.
[1969-08-15 14:11:30] red house | I noticed the walls of the house lacked insulation, and the kitchen appliances were basic. There was no telephone, dishwasher, washing machine, or television.
[1969-08-15 14:12:00] red house | I saw father carry the crate into the bedroom, Henrik Inge running back and forth between the windows looking out, and mother parking the stroller on the stone steps outside the door. I heard father say: "We’re here."
locations: on the way to the new house

text:
[1969-12-15 10:00:00] Hofver House | I learned that winter’s snow was several meters deep. From photographs, I saw Henrik Inge pushing me in the stroller, standing on short skis and smiling at the camera.
[1970-01-15 10:00:00] Hofe House interior | I saw him smiling at me in the photograph, or myself standing alone by the crib. I remember the first sound I ever made was 'Ao-wu,' calling for him.
[1970-06-15 10:00:00] Hofe House | I heard he was the only one who could understand what I said. I also knew he had gone door to door asking if there were any children for me to play with—Grandmother often delighted in telling this story.
[1970-07-15 10:00:00] Tibaken Construction Area | I knew the neighbors here came from all over the country. Families like the Magnuses, Presbakkmos, and Kanestroms lived here with their children. By now, I began to lose track of their parents and occupations.
[1970-07-15 10:00:10] Tibaken Construction Area | I knew the names of a group of kids like Bent and Erik Jens. As far as I knew, most were around my age, and five of them later became my classmates.
[1970-07-15 10:00:20] Tibaken Construction Area | I knew we moved here in the summer of 1970, when most of the houses were still under construction.
[1970-07-15 10:00:30] Tibaken Construction Area | The sharp, piercing alarm before each blast and the tremor through the floor afterward were the most ordinary experiences of my childhood. That trembling always gave me a peculiar sensation, as if the end of the world had arrived.
[1970-07-15 10:01:00] Construction Site | My friends and I gathered around the excavated cavern, peering deep into it. Before my eyes were various gashes in the earth—beneath lay yellow sand, black mud, and gray clay, often covered at the bottom with murky standing water. I found that these excavated gashes held a special attraction for me and the children growing up with me.
[1970-07-15 10:01:10] Construction Site | Above the pit, I saw the yellow excavator resembling a long-necked bird, the headlights of the truck like eyes, and the radiator grille like an open mouth.
[1970-07-15 10:01:20] Construction Site | I saw the massive tire tracks left by bulldozers on the ground, as wide as our palms.
[1970-07-15 10:01:30] Construction Site | If I was lucky, I would take away the tangled wires near the blast hole. I believed those wires were valuable things, useful both in trading and practical use.
[1970-07-15 10:01:40] construction site | I noticed tall cable spools scattered around, about my height, along with wooden drums and smooth brownish-red plastic pipes nearly as thick as my forearm. Piles of concrete pipes and precast concrete wells looked rugged yet beautiful, their height just right for us to climb.
[1970-07-15 10:01:50] construction site | I saw old tires fastened into long strips, meant for people to use during explosions. Stacks of wooden telephone poles, soaked in preservative, had turned green. Nearby were boxes of explosives and a shelter where workers ate.
[1970-07-15 10:02:00] construction site | I saw the workers laboring, and my friends and I kept a respectful distance, watching them intently.
[1970-07-15 10:03:00] construction site | When the workers were away, I climbed into the excavation pit, jumped onto the wheels of a dump trailer, walked along the pipes testing my balance. I poked around, peered through windows into the sheds, climbed into concrete wells, and tried pushing the cable spools. I collected scraps of wire, plastic handles, and leads, stuffing them all into my pockets.
[1970-07-15 10:04:00] construction site | I watched the workers in orange coveralls or baggy blue work pants, noticing how they'd pull combs from their pockets to comb their hair.
[1970-07-15 10:05:00] construction site | I saw them tuck their helmets under their arms, moving through the roar of machinery. In the afternoon, I witnessed the magical moment: they emerged from the work shed, changed into ordinary clothes, got into their cars, and drove off like regular people. I felt that moment was almost incomprehensible.
[1970-07-15 10:06:00] construction site | I remained wide awake, closely observing the movements of the other workers.
[1970-07-15 10:07:00] beside a telephone pole | I noticed workers from the telecommunications company appearing nearby, and the news quickly spread among the children. I saw a car parked there and an engineer standing by. I thought his climbing shoes for scaling poles were absolutely amazing!
[1970-07-15 10:07:10] beside a telephone pole | I observed him putting on the shoes, strapping a tool bag around his waist, securing the safety clip to the pole, then beginning his ascent with slow, confident motions. Those climbing movements seemed extremely complex and incomprehensible to me.
[1970-07-15 10:07:30] beside a telephone pole | I saw him straighten his back and swiftly climb to the top without any apparent effort. I wondered how this could be possible? He didn't seem under any strain at all.
[1970-07-15 10:08:00] beside the utility pole | I stared wide-eyed at him as he worked on the utility pole.
[1970-07-15 10:09:00] beside the utility pole | I saw him climb down quickly from above, moving with ease and effortlessness. I thought that with those shoes and that curved metal rod, there was nothing he couldn't do climbing up and down the pole. I realized I didn't need to worry about him at all.
[1970-07-15 10:10:00] storm drain opening | I saw the workers at the storm drain park their vehicle by the roadside. I noticed they put on tall boots reaching up to their waists, used iron rods to pry open the heavy circular iron cover, and then climbed down through the opening. I found that some of these drain openings were beside sidewalks, others situated high up on concrete structures.
[1970-07-15 10:10:30] storm drain opening | I watched as their feet, thighs, torsos, and finally heads disappeared one by one into the opening. I wondered silently in my mind: What exactly is down there? Is it a tunnel?
[1970-07-15 10:11:00] storm drain opening | I heard them call out for us to stay away as they climbed down to work. I realized this was something nobody knew. I felt that no one dared to go and ask them.
[1970-08-15 10:00:00] Hoff house steps | I know I once fell from the outdoor steps, so frightened I couldn't catch my breath. As far as I know, Mom rushed me to the neighbor's house, holding me tightly in her arms. I learned she thought it was an epileptic seizure, but actually it was nothing at all.
[1971-05-15 10:00:00] the mountain peak | I know Dad loved teaching and was a talented psychologist. I’ve seen photos of him leading students up to the mountain peak; in those early seventies images, he looked very young and happy.
[1971-05-15 10:00:10] the mountain peak | From the photos, I saw them wearing hand-knitted sweaters, loose pants, and rubber boots. I know that was the typical style of the era, their hair fluffy and soft, falling over their cheeks.
[1971-05-15 10:00:20] the mountain peak | I once heard Mom say that perhaps this was the happiest time in Dad’s life.
[1972-10-15 10:00:00] Vesfjord balcony | I saw the photo at Grandma’s. It showed Henrik Inge and me in knitted sweaters, together on the balcony. I saw Grandma’s face pressed close to mine under the clear blue autumn sky. I know I must have been only two or three years old in that picture.
[1973-06-15 14:00:00] wooden bridge in sparse woods | I stood on the wooden bridge at the center of the sparse woods, watching the rushing stream flow beneath me. I bounced up and down, making the bridge sway and wobble, and couldn't help but burst into laughter. I felt the green and white water gushing below me. I know that back then, my thoughts were all about meaningless little things.
[1973-06-15 14:00:10] wooden bridge in sparse woods | I saw my neighbor Nils Lidar standing beside me, bouncing up and down too, laughing heartily. I know he was standing right beside me at that moment.

[1973-08-15 10:00:00] Mjøndalen crossroads | I sat in the back seat as the car stopped at the crossroads. I saw Dad turn around. I heard Dad say, 'We've arrived in Mjøndalen.' I heard them tell me we were going to a match. I know it was to watch a game by Stato club, but I can't remember exactly which one.
[1973-09-15 10:00:00] hillside outside the house | I climbed the hillside outside the house, pushing the large yellow-and-red plastic freight wagon. I remember the delight this wagon once brought me. I felt an immense joy connected with wealth, luck, and happiness.
[1973-10-15 20:00:00] bedroom | I heard Henrik Inge say from the upper bunk, 'I'm a fox, and now I'm going to catch you.' I know I was so afraid of foxes. I remember screaming in fear when he said that.
[1973-10-15 20:00:10] bedroom | I saw him lean down from the upper bunk and reach out to grab me. I shouted at him, 'No, you're not a fox.' I heard him say, 'Yes, I am.'
[1973-10-15 20:01:00] bedroom | I heard myself ask him, 'Henrik Inge, are you scared now?'
[1973-10-15 20:01:10] bedroom | I heard him reply, 'No, why should I be scared? There's nothing to be afraid of here.' I realized he was right, marveled inwardly, and my heart grew calm.
[1974-05-15 15:00:00] slope below Helen Ster's house | I saw it come charging down the slope after me. When I saw it drawing closer, I immediately froze in place. I knew Trude had loosened its collar because she was wearing high heels. I'd heard that one should act indifferent when facing a wild animal, so I followed that advice.
[1974-05-15 15:00:10] slope below Helen Ster's house | I saw the dog open its mouth and bite down hard on my arm. I realized freezing still had been no help at all. I knew the wound was just beside my wrist joint.
[1974-05-15 15:00:30] Below Helen Ster's house | I saw Trude rush over and grab the collar, pulling it back with all her strength. I kept walking quickly forward, crying. I knew it was finally pulled back.
[1974-06-15 10:00:00] Tibaken construction area | I knew we were free before school started. As far as I knew, there were only two exceptions.
[1974-06-15 10:00:10] Main road | I knew the first forbidden area was the main road from the bridge all the way to the gas station.
[1974-06-15 10:00:20] Lakeside | I heard adults emphasize: "Never go to the lake alone!" I knew the second forbidden area was the lakeside.
[1974-06-15 10:01:00] Lakeside meadow | I sat on the hillside beside the meadow, gazing at the lake. I heard someone say: Down below, beneath the steep cliff, lives the water spirit—it will catch children. I remember sometimes we played football on that little meadow.
[1974-06-15 10:01:10] Lakeside meadow | I heard my friends talking: "Who said that?" "Mom and Dad." "Right here?" "Yes."
[1974-06-15 10:01:20] Yttervika cliff | I stared down at the gray water below. I saw the dark, rippling water of Yttervika. I thought: It really looks like it might be true—I felt as if something truly was down there beneath the surface.
[1974-06-15 10:01:30] Yttervika cliff | I heard one of my friends ask: "Only here? Then we can go somewhere else, like Tyena?"
[1974-06-15 10:01:40] Yttervika cliff | I heard someone reply: "Or Little Hawaii? There are different water spirits there. They're dangerous—they drag children into the water and drown them."
[1974-06-15 10:01:50] Yttervika cliff | I heard a worried voice from a companion: "Could it come up here?" I also heard the negative answer: "I don't think so—it's too far."
[1974-09-15 20:00:00] new room | I miss him. Even though he used to scare me often, I still feel lonely now that I have to sleep alone in my own room.
[1974-09-15 20:00:10] new room | I look at this new room. I think it's nice here, but it's still not as good as when we were together, sleeping on the top bunk.
[1975-01-15 10:00:00] outside Beck's house | I see stacks of firewood placed under a tarp outside Beck's house. In winter, I also see them stored beneath an overturned wooden boat.
[1975-05-01 10:00:00] home | I see Dad hand me a knife during the ceremony. I use it to cut, whittle, and play with other kids. I hear Dad say they're proud of me. I know that at first all the children had knives except me. I notice the boy in the knife sheath is wearing a skirt. I hide my disappointment about this 'girl's' knife deep inside. I think as long as no one sees the details of the sheath, it will be fine—and eventually, my affection for the knife wins out.
[1975-05-15 10:00:00] Tibaken | I think by the time I was seven, I was no longer afraid of foxes. But I realize that the space left behind was immediately filled with new fears.
[1975-05-15 10:00:00] school | I know that in spring we went to school, met our homeroom teacher, and drew pictures. But I realize it was completely different from the very first day of school. I silently reflect: the first day of school isn't just symbolic—it's real.
[1975-05-15 10:01:00] in front of the TV | I pass by the television in the morning. I see the TV is on, and on the screen a headless person is walking up the stairs.
[1975-05-15 10:01:10] room | I scream and dash into the room. I frantically search for Mom or my brother. Though the sun shines brightly outside and birds are singing, it brings me no comfort. I think I am utterly helpless on my own. I feel the image of the headless man chasing me, even in broad daylight. I realize my heart is pounding violently and fear surging through my nerves.
[1975-05-15 14:00:00] construction site | Toya Moen and I carve wooden swords. We hold them and wander through the construction site, sneaking behind two girls pushing toy baby carriages. We repeatedly slash at their canvas hoods, making them scream. Later, we keep watching them closely. I hear them say they’re going to tell on us. I think we are pirates, and they are pirate ships. I realize we begin to feel afraid ourselves.
[1975-05-15 16:00:00] the woods atop the hill | I see them walking toward my house and the Moens’ house. Frightened, we climb up the hill and slip deep into the woods at the summit, going all the way to the cliff’s edge. I know this is a place Toya Moen and I have never been to before. After analyzing the situation, I feel terrified and decide to flee from home. I think we can spend the night here and keep going tomorrow.
[1975-05-15 19:00:00] cliff edge | I sat with Toya Moen at the cliff edge for about half an hour, and in the end I followed him back. I saw the sun hanging low behind me, and everything bathed in golden light under its rays. I wanted to persuade him to stay, but he insisted on going home for dinner, and I was afraid of the dark, too scared to remain outside alone.
[1975-05-15 20:00:00] home | I saw my father waiting for me in the garden; he grabbed my arm, dragged me upstairs, locked me in my room, and took away my knife. I sat inside watching Toya Moen playing outside. I heard my father say while looking at the hole in the sheath: "Look at this sheath—it's completely ruined." I thought they didn't understand the difference between a knife and a sword at all. I damaged the sheath only to hide the pattern on it. I realized that after getting a slap, Toya Moen was fine—he didn't care at all.
[1975-06-15 10:00:00] Kanestrøm hill | I noticed that the Kanestrøms had a golden retriever named Alex, with gentle eyes and a friendly posture. Even though he looked as tame as a sheep, I still felt deeply afraid inside.
[1975-06-15 10:00:00] Beck's house | I knew their two older sisters, who were in middle school, used to take care of us. I learned that their younger brother Helen Ster wore strange clothes and showed no interest in the things we cared about.
[1975-06-15 10:00:00] Tibaken | I remembered my father once showed me a detective magazine whose cover featured a skeleton. I saw that skull turned around, staring at me with hollow red eyes, and I began fearing it might suddenly appear before me without warning.
[1975-06-15 10:00:10] Kanestrøm hill | When I appeared on the hill, ready to press the doorbell, I immediately froze in place. I heard the dog emit a powerful, deep, and loud bark - nothing like a friendly sound.
[1975-06-15 10:00:10] Beck's house | I learned that he built a real boat when he was twelve. I knew he wasn't one of us—we were separated by a great distance.
[1975-06-15 10:00:20] Kanestrøm hill | If no one was around, I would try greeting it by saying: "Hey, Alex, I'm not afraid, you know. Not afraid at all."

[1975-06-15 10:00:20] Beck's house | I knew his father once dreamed of living alone in the woods. I understood that when the first construction machine parked beside their home, he must have felt deeply disappointed.
[1975-06-15 10:00:30] Kanestrøm hill | I pretended to walk past casually, and when it opened its mouth to snarl, I bent down and patted it briefly on the side. I could feel my heart pounding violently in my chest, and my entire body went weak from fear.
[1975-06-15 10:00:40] up the slope to the Kanestrom house | I saw Dalson running up from the gravel path, or coming out through the front door. I heard Dalson shout, "Stop barking, Alex!"
[1975-06-15 10:00:45] up the slope to the Kanestrom house | I heard him say, "Grete Lundnes is afraid of dogs barking, you fool."
[1975-06-15 10:00:50] up the slope to the Kanestrom house | I watched Dalson staring at me with a stiff smile. I retorted, "I'm not afraid." I realized his smile meant I didn't need to try acting brave.
[1975-06-15 10:01:00] on the road | So we set off together.
[1975-06-15 10:01:00] bathroom | I heard the sharp, grating sound from the pipes when the hot water tap in the bathroom was turned on, followed by violent banging. Those sharp, grating sounds filled me with intense fear and unease.
[1975-06-15 10:01:10] bathroom | I knew the others in the house would always run cold water first to draw out the hot water gradually and avoid the noise.
[1975-06-15 10:01:20] bathroom | I tried to turn off the tap as quickly as possible and ran out. I heard that piercing, grating noise and rapid pounding penetrating through the entire wall. I felt as if something beneath was going mad; I was completely seized by fear.
[1975-06-15 10:01:30] bathroom | In the morning, I either used cold water or continued with the lukewarm water left by Henrik Inge. I knew the water wasn't clean, but at least it was gentle.
[1975-06-15 10:02:00] various places around Rocky | We wandered everywhere—into the woods, to Ytterfjord, the dry dock, Rocky Bridge, Old Tibaken, the shipbuilding factory, up the hills, to Lake Tjenna, the supermarket, or the gas station.
[1975-06-15 10:03:00] the road near our homes | If we didn’t go far, we’d run along the road near our houses, gather outside someone’s doorway, sit on stone steps, or climb up into the thick cherry trees.
[1975-07-15 10:00:00] Childhood Lane | I saw the coarse gravel on Childhood Lane, which under the summer sun almost appeared blue.
[1975-07-15 10:00:00] Spunes Beach | I preferred to stay near Spunes Beach, wading in the water, going as deep as I wanted. I knew that on good weather days we often parked the car at the old shooting range and walked down to the rocky area below—it was our usual spot.
[1975-07-15 10:00:10] North Hill Loop / Deer Path | I walked along the gravel road, following the brown fence, through a low ditch between North Hill Loop and Deer Path. I saw various cars from the seventies parked along the driveway—Citroëns, Fords, Volvos. That ditch ran through the entire area.
[1975-07-15 10:00:20] Hill leading to the woods | I saw the dark, fertile hillsides rising on both sides of the road toward the woods, where slender green shoots were bursting vigorously out of the soil. I noticed how these thin stems would multiply wildly over the next year, until they covered the entire hillside.
[1975-07-15 10:00:30] Hill leading to the woods | I saw young trees, foxgloves, and ferns blurring the once-clear boundary between the road and the forest.
[1975-07-15 10:00:40] Sidewalk stone curb | I saw tiny streams flowing down the narrow stone curbs of the sidewalk when it rained.
[1975-07-15 10:01:00] Badger Road | I saw a small marsh beside the path leading to the supermarket, shaded by birch trees. Olson’s house stood at the highest point of the slope known as 'Badger Road'.
[1975-07-15 10:01:10] Helen Ster and Trude's house | I saw that the first house on the left belonged to Helen Ster and Trude—the plot of land more like a stony field. Every time I passed this house, I always felt terrified.
[1975-07-15 10:01:20] Helen Ster and Trude's house | I knew Helen Ster might throw things at children passing by, and I remembered they had an Oswick sheepdog. I realized why I felt afraid, silently cursing that creature as a damned beast.
[1975-07-15 10:01:30] Helen Ster and Trude's house | I saw it tethered to the balcony or driveway, pacing within the length of its rope, barking furiously at passersby. I saw its lean body, yellowish eyes that looked sickly, and heard its constant growling near my ears.
[1975-07-15 10:05:00] beside the rock | I saw small pools of water gathered by the rock, their bottoms covered with barnacles and kelp. When waves struck the rock, water surged up to my neck, and the thunderous sound of water hitting stone filled my ears. I felt how the steep rocky walls around me amplified the sounds, making it seem as if I were inside a deep cave.
[1975-07-15 10:06:00] beside the rock | I stood there trembling, gasping for breath. I heard the hissing sound of seawater retreating. I felt terrified—suddenly my breathing became labored, and that sound filled me with fear and unease.
[1975-07-15 10:10:00] shore | I lay on an inflated swimming raft, floating along the shore, gently moving my hands through the water. I felt the soaked plastic clinging to my skin, my back scorched by the blazing sun, and splashes of water all around.
[1975-07-15 10:15:00] shore | I scanned the water with my eyes, looking for fish or crabs, following distant moving boats. I smelled the salty freshness of the sea and saw the kelp on the rocks swaying slowly like waves.
[1975-07-15 14:00:00] outside the bay | I saw a huge white ferry appear on the horizon, docking between the reefs outside the bay. I saw many children come swimming as the ferry passed by. I knew children from the southwest side of the island would be drawn here by the powerful waves churned up by the ship’s wake.
[1975-07-15 14:30:00] at sea | I was paddling on my raft when suddenly a wave hurled me into the air, then threw me back into the water.
[1975-07-15 14:30:20] underwater/at sea | I sank like a stone about three meters down, flailing wildly with arms and legs, crying out for help. I accidentally swallowed several mouthfuls of seawater. I felt extreme panic—thankfully Dad saw everything.
[1975-07-15 14:31:00] land | Dad dove into the water and pulled me up, dragging me back onto land. I spat out some water, then followed everyone home. I felt a chill running through my body.
[1975-07-15 15:00:00] home | I climbed up the hill to tell Karl Larsdal everything that had happened. I realized the world is some kind of solid, impenetrable surface. I suppose I’ve always known this fact, but only now truly felt that we are walking upon a surface.
[1975-07-15 15:10:00] seaside | I sat on a towel beside Henrik Inge, watching the distant lighthouse and the moving ships. I saw the pale blue sea, smooth as a mirror, and the white lighthouse at the horizon standing clearly against the azure sky. Despite the drowning incident, I still looked forward to these trips to the seaside, finding the view truly delightful.
[1975-07-15 15:20:00] seaside | I drank juice and ate biscuits, my eyes following Dad as he walked to the edge of the hilltop and jumped into the two-meter-deep seawater. I saw him emerge from the water, shaking his head to shake off the droplets. I heard the noisy splashing of water. I saw Dad’s brown skin and well-developed muscles.
[1975-07-15 15:30:00] in the sea | I watched Dad swim further out to sea, his body rising and falling in the water. I noticed his strokes were heavy and slow, and a rare joy appeared in his eyes.
locations: up the slope to the Kanestrom house

text:
[1975-07-15 15:40:00] a pit by the seaside | I saw two pits on the rocks—one filled with broad seaweed, deep enough to reveal spiral markings; the other shallower, full of extremely salty, warm water covered with tiny insects and sickly algae. I found this natural scenery between the rocks incredibly beautiful.
[1975-07-15 16:00:00] by the water | I followed Dad to the water’s edge, standing in about half a meter of water. I saw him swim to the reef four or five meters from shore, then turn around and look at me. I heard Dad shout: “Now swim over to me.” I saw smooth blades of seaweed floating on the water surface.
[1975-07-15 16:00:10] by the water | I looked down at the bottom and noticed the reef faintly visible in the depths. I shouted loudly: “The water is too deep!” I realized the water there might be three meters deep.
[1975-07-15 16:00:20] by the water | I heard Dad say: “I’m right here, Grete Lundnes. If you sink, would I not save you? Swim—start now. Dive into the water, move your arms.” I sensed his firm belief that I could do it—if only I tried, I would learn how to swim.
[1975-07-15 16:01:00] by the water | I squatted down in the water. I saw the seabed shimmering with a faint green glow deep below. I hesitated inwardly: Could I really float and move forward on this water?
[1975-07-15 16:01:10] by the water | I screamed desperately: “I can’t!” I felt my heart pounding violently in my chest from fear.
[1975-07-15 16:01:20] by the water | I heard Dad shout back: “You can! It’s not hard!” But I still insisted: “I can’t!”
[1975-07-15 16:02:00] by the water | I watched him sigh, then swim back toward me. I heard him say: “OK, I’ll swim beside you. I can support your belly from underneath so you won’t sink!”
[1975-07-15 16:02:10] by the water | I started crying, repeating over and over that I couldn't do it. I sobbed to him, "I can't." I thought I really couldn't—why didn't he understand that?
[1975-07-15 16:02:20] by the water | I felt as if my head, chest, arms, legs, even my fingers and toes, were all filled with deep water. I was completely surrounded by the sensation of deep water, and I desperately wished I could cast this feeling aside and stop thinking about it.
[1975-07-15 16:05:00] on shore | I saw Dad walk up onto the shore with a stern face, heading toward where we had left our things, and when he came back, he was holding my life jacket. I noticed that Dad’s smiling face from earlier was gone.
[1975-07-15 16:06:00] by the water | I saw Dad throw the life jacket to me. He swam out again and turned around to face me. I put on the life jacket. I heard him say, "There, put this on. Now you won’t be able to sink even if you try. Start swimming! Swim to me!" Even though I had the life jacket on, I knew deep down it wouldn’t help—it wouldn’t change anything.
[1975-07-15 16:07:00] by the water | I crouched down and stretched my arms forward beneath the water. I heard Dad encouraging me: "Yes, that's right!" I felt cool water rushing against my swim trunks.
[1975-07-15 16:07:10] by the water | I thought all I needed to do was lean forward, dive into the sea, and take a few strokes—but I just couldn't do it. I realized that no matter what, I would never be able to move forward through this deep water.
[1975-07-15 16:08:00] by the water | I felt tears running down my cheeks. I heard Dad shout loudly, "Come on, now—right now, kid! We can't spend all day on this!"
[1975-07-15 16:08:10] by the water | I shouted back as hard as I could, "I can't do it! Can you hear me?"
[1975-07-15 16:08:20] by the water | I stared into his eyes; his expression turned ugly. I heard him ask me furiously, "Are you determined to defy me?" I saw his face stiffen and realized he had become utterly enraged.
[1975-07-15 16:08:30] by the water | I couldn't stop sobbing, and I felt my arms trembling violently. I whispered, "No."
[1975-07-15 16:09:00] by the water | I saw him swim back, grab my arm tightly, and try to pull me into the water. I twisted my body desperately toward the land. I heard him command: "Come here." I shouted in refusal: "I won't!"
[1975-07-15 16:10:00] by the water | I saw him let go of my arm and sigh deeply. I heard him say resignedly: "Alright then, we know now."
[1975-07-15 16:15:00] on shore | I watched him walk over to where our things were. I took off my life jacket and followed, stopping a few meters behind him. I saw him rub his face, underarms, and thighs with a towel, then put on his shirt, buttoning it as he looked out ahead. Before me lay the remarkably calm sea.
[1975-07-15 16:20:00] on shore | I watched him pull on his socks and slip his feet into his shoes. Without turning around, he asked me: "What are you still waiting for?" I noticed he was wearing brown leather shoes without laces, which didn’t match at all with his socks and swimming trunks.
[1975-07-15 16:25:00] on the way back to the car | I pulled my T-shirt over my head and put on my running shoes, tying the laces. I saw Dad pack the empty juice bottles and orange peels into the cooler bag, sling it over his shoulder, and walk off with a damp towel clutched in his other hand. He didn’t say a word on the way back to the car. The light blue Lars Palmas T-shirt I was wearing had been a gift from my grandparents.
[1975-07-15 16:30:00] parking lot | I watched him open the trunk, put the cooler bag inside, and take my life jacket. I was still holding a wet towel in my hand, but he ignored it. I realized he clearly hadn’t thought about my towel, and I certainly wouldn’t bother him with something so trivial at this moment.
[1975-07-15 16:31:00] inside the car | I got into the car and, to avoid drawing attention, pressed my palms flat against the seat beneath my thighs, tucking my hands as far in as possible. Although the car was parked in the shade, the black seats were scorching hot. I felt sharp stings on my thighs. For a moment I hesitated about placing the wet towel underneath, but I guessed he would surely notice.
[1975-07-15 16:35:00] inside the car | I sat in the slowly moving car, feeling the bumps in the road. I saw green branches and bushes brush across the roof. The car was driving across an open gravel field called the Shooting Range, scattered with large stones and deep holes. Now and then, I heard small thuds as branches tapped against the roof.
[1975-07-15 16:40:00] inside the car | I quickly glanced at his face in the rearview mirror—he showed no expression. My palms still burned with pain. It suddenly occurred to me that Dad was also sitting only in his swim shorts on the hot seat, yet he managed to give no sign that his thighs were being stung.
[1975-07-15 16:50:00] main road | I felt the car accelerate sharply. During the final five kilometers home, he drove very fast. The car passed along the main road below the church. I noticed he was driving well above the speed limit.
[1975-07-15 18:00:00] at home | That afternoon, I heard him tell Mom, 'He has hydrophobia.' I knew that wasn't true, but I said nothing—I wasn't stupid enough to speak up.
[1975-07-22 10:00:00] Tibaken | As far as I knew, my grandparents were coming to visit us at Tibaken a week later—it was their first time seeing us here.
[1975-07-22 10:00:10] Southberge Farm | I knew they had lived very comfortably on the farm at Southberge. Grandpa always wore overalls and tall boots, and liked to spit tobacco juice on the ground; Grandma wore clean old dresses, and her hands were always slightly trembling.
[1975-07-22 10:10:00] driveway | I saw my grandparents step out of the car, which had just pulled up onto the driveway in front of our house. I realized immediately that they looked completely out of place here.
locations: on the way back to the car

text:
[1975-07-22 10:15:00] garden | I showed them around the garden and saw Grandpa pointing here and there with the stem of his pipe. Grandpa was wearing a well-tailored gray suit and a gray hat, Grandma a light gray coat and carrying a handbag. I knew no one around here dressed like that.
[1975-07-22 10:20:00] room | I realized that even in the city, nobody dressed the way they did. I felt as if they had stepped out of another era. A sense of strangeness filled our room.
[1975-07-22 10:30:00] at home | I noticed that sometimes when Dad passed by me or my brother, he would rest a hand briefly on our shoulders. I found that my parents’ attitude had suddenly changed—Dad had actually become friendly, even saying things like 'Why not?' It felt as though we were celebrating Christmas.
[1975-07-22 10:40:00] at home | I observed that whenever Dad talked with Grandma, he would briefly look away. I sensed that Dad was actually uninterested—his eyes were dull and distant. Grandpa, though lively and animated, seemed less secure here, and didn’t notice Dad’s distraction.
[1975-07-23 19:00:00] dining room | I learned that one evening, Dad bought crabs to treat them. I knew it wasn’t even crab season, but for him this was a proper feast.
[1975-07-23 19:10:00] dining room | I heard Dad say it as a joke. He said that if Grandpa ever caught crabs, he’d throw them back into the sea. I knew my grandparents wouldn’t eat crabs because, according to their superstition, crabs weren’t clean—they believed this because crabs fed on dead things at the bottom of the sea. I wondered silently—had these crabs really been eating corpses at the bottom of the Skagerrak?
[1975-07-24 15:00:00] garden | I went back to my room and lay down reading comic books. I heard my grandparents walking onto the balcony; we had just finished drinking coffee in the garden.
[1975-07-24 15:10:00] living room/bedroom | I heard their heavy footsteps on the stairs, and then they walked into the living room. I saw the evening sun resting on the wall of the room, casting a golden glow. There was not a word spoken in the living room.
[1975-07-24 15:20:00] bedroom | I gazed through the window at the street, houses, and various objects outside. I saw the outdoor lawn covered in varying shades of brownish-tan. The entire residential area appeared profoundly quiet. To me, it all seemed as if everything was asleep.
[1975-07-24 15:30:00] living room | I stood up and walked into the living room, where I saw my grandparents each sitting in their chairs. I asked them, "Do you want to watch TV?" I felt my sweaty chest stick to the bedsheet, that sticky sensation making me uncomfortable.
[1975-07-24 15:30:10] living room | I heard my grandfather say happily, "Sure! Is the news about to start? You know, we’re interested in that."
[1975-07-24 15:31:00] living room | I walked over and turned on the television. Then I stepped back. I saw light appear on the screen, the news logo gradually enlarging. In my ears rang the monotonous xylophone music, starting softly and growing heavier.
[1975-07-24 15:31:10] living room | I saw my grandfather hunched forward in his chair, gripping the stem of his pipe. I said to them, "It's on."
[1975-07-24 15:31:20] living room | I knew I wasn't usually allowed to turn on the TV or radio by myself. But this time, since it was for my grandparents, I figured Dad wouldn’t have anything to say about it.
[1975-07-24 15:32:00] living room | I saw the images on the screen rapidly rolling and colors distorting, then a flash accompanied by a dull boom—the entire screen went black.
[1975-07-24 15:32:10] living room | I stood there, my eyes filled with tears. I heard my grandfather ask, "What's wrong with the TV?" I cried and answered, "It's broken." I thought: Oh no. No, no, no.
[1975-07-24 15:32:20] living room | I realized I was the one who had broken the TV.
[1975-07-24 15:33:00] living room | I saw Grandpa get up and shuffle slowly toward the radio. I heard Grandpa comfort me, saying, 'These things happen anytime. Actually, I prefer listening to the news on the radio.'
[1975-07-24 15:35:00] bedroom | I walked back to my room and lay down on the bed. I felt the cool bedsheet against my warm skin. I shivered with fear. I felt a churning in my stomach.
[1975-07-24 15:40:00] bedroom | I picked up a magazine from the floor. I couldn't focus on reading at all. I kept thinking about how Dad would soon come into the room to turn on the TV, and anxiety filled me.
[1975-07-24 15:45:00] bedroom | I wished no one had seen me—then I could pretend I knew nothing. But I knew Dad would sense the truth. And with Grandma and Grandpa here, they’d surely tell him. If I tried to hide it, it would only make things worse.
[1975-07-24 15:50:00] bedroom | I sat up on the bed. I felt something heavy pressing on my stomach, as if my whole body were soaked in cold and pain—a feeling that even tears couldn’t melt away.
[1975-07-24 16:00:00] bedroom | I sat there for a while and started crying. I learned my brother wasn’t home—he had gone swimming. I thought to myself: If only my brother were here, I could just stay in his room.
[1975-07-24 16:10:00] Henrik Inge's room | I opened the door, tiptoed carefully down the hallway, and entered my brother’s room. I felt that being in his room brought me closer to him—even though the room was empty, it gave me a little more courage.
[1975-07-24 16:10:10] Henrik Inge's room | I walked over and sat down on the bed. I saw that his bed and cabinet were blue, while mine were orange. I caught the scent that belonged uniquely to him.
[1975-07-24 16:11:00] Henrik Inge's room | I noticed the window was slightly ajar. I realized this way I could hear what was happening on the balcony without exposing myself—luckier than I dared hope.
[1975-07-24 16:15:00] Henrik Inge's room | I heard the sound of the radio from the living room in my ears. I heard my father’s calm and quiet voice, and I could tell he was in a good mood right now. I also heard my mother’s clearer, softer voice.
[1975-07-24 16:20:00] Henrik Inge's room | For some reason, I imagined in my mind that my grandparents might be sitting asleep in their chairs, just as they had been when we visited them in Sørbyvåg, with their mouths open and eyes closed.

[1975-07-24 16:31:00] Henrik Inge's room | I waited by the door, listening for the sound of the downstairs door opening. I thought I would see my mother soon—then I could tell her everything first!
[1975-07-24 16:35:00] hallway | I saw my mother walking up the stairs carrying a tray full of dishes and a coffee pot. I stepped out into the hallway. I heard my mother ask, 'Why are you standing here on such a nice day?' I answered, 'Yes.'
[1975-07-24 16:35:10] hallway | I saw my mother stop and ask me, 'What’s wrong? Has something happened?' I lowered my eyes and told her, 'The TV is broken.'
[1975-07-24 16:36:00] hallway | I nodded, watching as my mother prepared to call my grandparents. I heard my mother exclaim, 'Ah no, that’s terrible luck.' She told me the evening outside was beautiful and asked if I wanted to come out and have some juice too.
[1975-07-24 16:40:00] bedroom | I shook my head and walked back to my room. I stopped just after stepping inside. I thought it might be wiser to go out with them—if my grandparents were there, maybe my father wouldn’t do anything to me.
[1975-07-24 16:45:00] bedroom | I remembered the last time in Sørbyvåg, even though my father laughed in front of everyone, he later punished my brother fiercely for fighting. I realized that having outsiders present might only make him angrier.
[1975-07-24 16:50:00] bedroom | I decided to stay in my room. I lay down on the bed again. I thought if he found out about the broken TV while outside, he might get angry. I felt an uncontrollable shiver run through my chest, and tears welled up again.

[1975-07-24 17:10:00] bedroom | I covered my ears with my hands, closed my eyes, and tried to imagine that nothing had happened. Though the feeling of helplessness overwhelmed me, I still resisted inwardly, choosing not to give in.
[1975-07-24 17:20:00] bedroom | I knelt on the bed and looked out the window. What met my eyes was the intense sunlight spilling across the ground, roofs and windowpanes glittering in its glare.
[1975-07-24 17:30:00] bedroom | Hearing the door downstairs slam, I panicked and glanced around. I got off the bed and sat down on the chair in front of the desk. I heard the door bang shut, and a wave of fear surged through me.
[1975-07-24 17:35:00] bedroom | I stood up and sat on the edge of the bed. I heard heavy footsteps ascending the stairs. I realized it was him coming upstairs. I thought I couldn't sit with my back to the door.

[1975-07-24 17:37:00] bedroom | I felt him release my ear and instead grab both my arms with his hands, shaking me violently. I cried out, "I... I... I can't... turn on the TV by myself." Then I heard him bellow, "Now look at me!"

[1975-07-24 17:38:00] bedroom | I heard him order me to stay inside tonight and tomorrow, until he called for me. I whispered, 'Understood.'
[1975-07-24 17:40:00] bedroom | I burst into loud sobs. I felt my chest and hands trembling uncontrollably. I saw him leave. Because I was crying so loudly, I couldn’t tell where he’d gone. I felt my breath coming in gasps, like climbing stairs.

[1975-07-24 18:30:00] bedroom window | I remembered Dad often said sitting in the front garden was like being in a 'shop window display.' I noticed people nearby really did place their furniture and barbecue grills at the back of their houses.
[1975-07-24 18:40:00] road | I saw the door of the Karlsen house open, and Viktor Lunddal stepped out. I could only see the top of his head passing over car roofs, like a puppet in a puppet show.
[1975-07-24 18:41:00] road | I saw him reappear on his bicycle, speeding up the hill, then turning and disappearing.

[1975-07-24 18:42:00] Tiena Lake Road | I knew Viktor’s father had died two years ago. I recalled once meeting him on a cold, sunny day on the way to Tiena Lake, when I was holding orange-colored ice skates in my hand.

[1975-07-24 18:44:00] Karlsen's house | I knew his father had died after being overcome by natural gas while cleaning an oil tank and falling from a height. Everyone had stood looking at his house back then.
[1975-07-24 18:45:00] Tibaken | I knew we never talked about death or his father when Viktor was present. I also learned that a new neighbor with the same last name, Karlsen, had moved in.
[1975-07-24 18:46:00] Tibaken | I knew the age order among us children. Viktor was second, Toya third, and I was the youngest—the seventh.
[1975-07-24 18:50:00] Road | I saw Toya Moen get on her bicycle, and the two of them rode down the slope together. I heard Viktor shouting from in front of the house, 'Toya Moen, come out quickly!'
[1975-07-24 19:00:00] Hillside | I saw Presbakkmo’s cat lying completely still on the flat hillside between the two houses.
[1975-07-24 19:30:00] Bedroom | I went back to bed and lay there for a while. Then I got up, stepped off the bed, and pressed my ear against the door to listen. I sensed there was no sound outside and guessed they were still out there.
[1975-07-24 20:00:00] Bedroom | I wondered whether it was true that Grandma and Grandpa wouldn’t let me have dinner when they came to visit. It seemed unimaginable, yet I worried it might actually be true.
[1975-07-24 20:30:00] Bedroom | After hearing water running, I then heard heavy banging from the pipes. I heard someone go onto the balcony and enter the bathroom. From the footsteps, I realized it wasn’t Dad. I understood the loud clanging meant either Grandpa or Grandma was using the hot water.
[1975-07-24 20:40:00] bedroom | I feel that I am already ravenous.
[1975-07-24 21:00:00] bedroom window | I saw the shadows on the ground outside grow long and distorted, pausing in the deepening twilight. I feel as though these shadows are growing by themselves, as if there exists a parallel dark world—distorted and helpless.
[1975-07-24 21:05:00] bedroom window | An image of rocks exposed at low tide floated into my mind. I silently remarked within myself: the shadows lengthen with the deepening night, like a tide of darkness flooding across the land.
[1975-07-24 21:10:00] bedroom | I looked down at my watch; the hands pointed to nine-ten. I knew there were still twenty minutes until bedtime.
[1975-07-24 21:15:00] bedroom | I thought about how the worst part of being locked up in the afternoon was only being able to stand by the window and watch people outside. I also realized that the worst part of being confined at night is losing the familiar rhythm of time.
[1975-07-24 21:30:00] bedroom | After sitting for several hours, I undressed and lay down on the bed. I felt that the difference between sitting and lying here had been erased, which made me begin thinking about things I would normally never consider.
[1975-07-24 21:35:00] bedroom | I realized that in this state, the version of me sitting clothed was exactly the same as the one lying naked—there seemed to be no clear boundary.
[1975-07-24 21:40:00] bedroom | I silently sighed: this really is such an annoying feeling.
[1975-07-24 21:50:00] bedroom | I walked to the door and listened closely, then crawled under the covers and pulled them up to my chin. I took off my T-shirt and shorts. I heard some movement outside at first, then everything fell silent. I couldn't help crying for a little while.
