My mind was flooded with terrifying images of what would happen if he found out the truth.
[1975-08-18 15:55:00] edge of the hillside | I saw Karl approaching, carrying my plastic bag. Down below, a child was playing in the sand by the roadside. A car turned the corner and disappeared. I signaled Karl to evacuate quickly. I urgently told Karl, "We can't go down this way—if someone saw the smoke, they'll connect it to us. Let's get out of here now!" I kept asking myself over and over: Why did we do this? Why?
[1975-08-18 16:10:00] slope bottom woods | I stumbled through the woods about ten meters from the road, walking home. I stopped beside a huge spruce tree, reached into the stream to wash off any possible traces, and dried my hands on my pants. I saw the trunk covered in sticky, caramel-like resin and smelled a strong juniper scent. The stream before me was shallow and wide, muddy and murky, glowing with a dim greenish light. Through the slender trunks of rowan trees, I could see my own house. I carefully examined my hands, making sure there was no ash on them, but I still felt as if I could smell something burnt.
[1975-08-18 16:20:00] road intersection | Karl Larsdal returned the plastic bag to me, and together we walked toward the road. At the intersection, I watched him run up the slope. I asked Karl what he planned to do with the matchbox, warning him not to mention me if he got caught. I heard him reply that he would hide it, and then he said goodbye. I worried he might give in and light a fire again today, even take it to school—I thought he was completely crazy.
[1975-08-18 16:30:00] gravel path in yard | I passed my mother’s Volkswagen and stepped onto the gravel path in the yard. I lowered my head and came to the front steps, folding my hands and closing my eyes. I saw my father’s car shining with a brilliant red glow under the intense sunlight. A new fear welled up inside me, and I desperately prayed to God that nothing would happen. I swore to the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit that I would never do anything wrong again.
[1975-08-18 16:35:00] hallway at home | I walked into the hallway, bent down to untie my shoelaces, and carefully placed my shoes against the wall. I paused at the foot of the stairs, trying to make my expression look normal. The hallway was cooler than outside, dimly lit, and thick with the smell of stewed meat. I was torn—wondering whether I should go straight to my room or step into the kitchen to see about dinner.
[1975-08-18 16:35:10] hallway at home | I heard the clatter of dishes in the kitchen. I thought: Oh no, had they already eaten? I even considered fleeing back to the mountain and never returning—then they would surely regret it.
[1975-08-18 16:35:20] kitchen | I heard my father call from the kitchen: “Is that you, Grete Lundnes?”
[1975-08-18 16:35:30] hallway at home | I swallowed hard, gave a slight nod, and took a deep breath. I answered: “Yes.”
[1975-08-18 16:35:40] kitchen | I heard him shout: “We’re eating! Come in quickly!”
[1975-08-18 16:36:00] kitchen | I walked into the kitchen and saw my father sitting in his chair, legs stretched out, body leaning back, arms spread wide to both sides. I realized God had heard my prayer. Looking at my father’s shining eyes and the sly glint in them, I concluded he was in a good mood now.
[1975-08-18 16:36:10] kitchen | I heard my father ask: “What were you doing that made you forget to come home on time?”
[1975-08-18 16:37:00] kitchen | I sat down beside Henrik Inge. I looked at the plates on the table, the green glasses, and the large pot with a wooden spoon sticking out of it. Before me was a gray-and-white marble-patterned dining table; the bottom of the glass bore the engraving 'Dores.' A basket held crispbread.
[1975-08-18 16:37:10] kitchen | I leaned forward, staring at the chunks of meat in the pot. I told him, "I went out with Karl Larsdal."
[1975-08-18 16:37:20] kitchen | I heard my father press further: "Then where did you go?" I noticed a small piece of onion clinging to the beard on his chin. I saw him staring straight at me.
[1975-08-18 16:37:30] kitchen | I replied casually, "Straight into the woods."
[1975-08-18 16:37:40] kitchen | I heard him say while chewing, "Really? I thought I saw you heading up the mountain path?" I felt his gaze locked onto my face.
[1975-08-18 16:38:00] kitchen | I sat there, paralyzed, unable to move my body. Finally, with difficulty, I said, "We didn't go there." I was terribly frightened, thinking he suspected us after all.
[1975-08-18 16:38:10] kitchen | I heard my father snap, "Nonsense! You don't want to admit you went there—what were you two up to anyway?"
[1975-08-18 16:38:20] kitchen | I insisted, "But we didn't go up the mountain."
[1975-08-18 16:40:00] kitchen | I saw my mother and father exchange a glance. I started eating again and noticed my brother sitting beside me, staring blankly ahead. I felt my hands regain movement, and breathed a slight sigh of relief.
[1975-08-18 16:45:00] kitchen | I heard my father shift topics and ask, "Well then, what did the schoolchildren do today? Do you have homework?"
[1975-08-18 16:45:10] kitchen | I shook my head at Dad.
[1975-08-18 16:45:20] kitchen | I nodded at him. He asked how the teacher was, and I replied that the teacher's name was "Ciliavik Oscar".
[1975-08-18 16:45:30] kitchen | I told him the teacher lived in Sanddum.
[1975-08-18 16:46:00] kitchen | I heard Mom say the teacher was very young and quite nice. I mumbled in addition: "But we were late." After the conversation shifted direction, I felt completely relaxed.
[1975-08-18 16:46:10] kitchen | I heard Dad ask Mom in surprise: "Ah? You didn't tell me that?"
[1975-08-18 16:46:20] kitchen | I heard Mom explain that she had taken the wrong route, but they were only a few minutes late, and they hadn't missed anything important. She turned to me and asked: "That's right, isn't it, Grete Lundnes?" I answered: "Yes."
[1975-08-18 16:47:00] kitchen | I quickly swallowed my food. I heard Dad command: "Don't talk with your mouth full." I responded: "Yes."
[1975-08-18 16:48:00] kitchen | I watched Henrik Inge sit up straight in his chair. Dad asked him if anything surprising had happened today, and my brother answered "No".
[1975-08-18 16:49:00] kitchen | I heard Mom ask my brother if he was going to football practice, and he confirmed it.

[1975-08-18 16:49:10] Saltrode | I knew he had left the island team and joined the Saltrode club. I learned their sportswear looked great, and that he needed to ride his bike alone across the bridge to training, a distance of about five kilometers.
[1975-08-18 16:50:00] kitchen | I heard Dad continue to ask me, "So, nothing else happened at school, Grete Lundnes?"
[1975-08-18 16:50:10] kitchen | I nodded and swallowed my food. I told them, "We're having swimming lessons—six sessions—at another school."
[1975-08-18 16:50:20] kitchen | I watched Dad wipe his mouth with the back of his hand, but that piece of onion was still hanging there. I heard Dad say approvingly that people living on an island must know how to swim. Mom agreed it was a free class.
[1975-08-18 16:51:00] kitchen | I told them, "But I need a swimming cap—everyone does. Maybe a new swimsuit too?" Dad said the cap was fine, but a new pair of pants wasn't necessary.
[1975-08-18 16:51:10] kitchen | I kept asking for swimming goggles. Dad looked at me with a teasing expression and said, "We'll talk about that later."
[1975-08-18 16:55:00] kitchen | I saw Dad push his plate toward the center of the table and lean back in his chair. I heard him say loudly, "Thank you for the meal, Mom—it was great!"
[1975-08-18 16:55:10] kitchen | I watched my brother slip out of the kitchen. Five seconds later, I heard the sound of his bedroom door closing. I heard my brother say, "Thanks for the meal," as well.
[1975-08-18 17:00:00] kitchen / bedroom | I watched Dad get up, put his plate into the sink, grab an orange and the newspaper, and head downstairs to his office. I watched Mom clear the table, then walked into Henrik Inge's room myself. I was thinking Dad might want to talk to me again, and I felt a bit uneasy.
[1975-08-18 17:10:00] Henrik Inge's room | I sat on Henrik Inge's bed and watched him pack. I noticed his black football cleats and yellow-and-black striped socks. I couldn't help leaning in to smell the shiny, smooth jersey. I knew he had gotten new socks and given me the old ones. His jersey was Adidas, made of a fabric completely different from previous sportswear. The scent of that jersey felt utterly magical to me. I think because I longed so deeply to own something like it, its smell carried in my mind the hope of a future—something that seemed not of this ordinary world.
[1975-08-18 17:15:00] Henrik Inge's room | I watched him zip up his bag, sit down at his desk to look over his schedule, then stand up with a smile and walk out. I asked if he had any homework or book covers—he said no to both. I heard him joke, "If I don't come back by midnight, it means the headless man has eaten me!" I thought about how Mom would help me cover my books tonight, and I felt pretty good.
[1975-08-18 17:20:00] outside ramp | I watched him through the bathroom window. I saw him glide for a stretch, then swing onto the bike frame and pedal quickly up the steep slope, disappearing at the crossroads.
[1975-08-18 17:25:00] hallway at home | I stood quietly in the hallway, observing where Mom and Dad were. I whispered softly, “Mom?” But there was no response from anywhere.
[1975-08-18 17:30:00] kitchen / bedroom / garden | I searched the kitchen, living room, master bedroom, and garden one by one, but couldn’t find Mom anywhere.
[1975-08-18 17:35:00] bedroom | I confirmed that Mom’s car was still parked outside. I returned to my room and sat on the edge of the bed, reading a few magazines. I felt that without knowing where Mom was, the house seemed to lose a kind of cohesion. But then it suddenly occurred to me—she must be downstairs in Dad’s office.
[1975-08-18 17:40:00] Dad's office | I knew that the office was almost always off-limits, unless I had something important to ask. I was familiar with the old sink used specifically for washing stamps. As far as I knew, knocking on that door usually came with a heavy psychological cost. I remembered the times when I washed stamps, then dried them and placed them carefully into the stamp album.
[1975-08-18 17:45:00] Dad's office | I knew that when I was home alone, I once wanted to sneak in, but the risk was too great. I understood Dad’s astonishing perceptiveness—how he could instantly tell what wrong we’d done up in the mountains. I realized he could always sense anything unusual, no matter how hard I tried to hide it.
[1975-08-18 17:50:00] bedroom | I lay on the bed reading the magazine *Tintin* that my brother had lent me. I studied the illustrations of race car drivers and comic book heroes carefully. I had read these magazines countless times. To me, they belonged to a perfect world. Though I wasn’t picky about the content, I found myself drawn more to stories grounded in reality, because those cars and equipment could also be seen on television.
[1975-08-18 18:00:00] outside the office | I quickly put down the magazine and tied my shoes in the hallway. I knocked on the office door. I called out inside: “I’m going out! To Karl Larsdal’s!” Through the crack of the door, I recalled the space inside included a bathroom, office, and storage room. I knew this was a self-contained apartment, but our family had never rented it out. I felt restless. Even though it wasn’t quite five o’clock yet, I decided to go out for a walk.
[1975-08-18 18:00:10] outside the office | First I heard Dad impatiently shout, “Alright, alright!” Then I heard Mom’s gentle voice: “Okay, go ahead, Grete Lundnes!” I sensed that Mom’s voice served as a soothing counterbalance to Dad’s irritable tone.
[1975-08-18 18:05:00] outside Karl Larsdal's house | I slipped out the door and ran quickly toward Karl’s house. I called out a few times at the entrance, watching as his mother came around carrying a red garden spade. Karl’s mother said to me: “Hi, Grete Lundnes, Karl just went out with Tove.” I saw she was wearing khaki shorts and black clogs, with gardening gloves on.
[1975-08-18 18:05:10] Outside Karl Larsdal's house | I hurriedly asked, "Where did they go?" I heard Karl's mother reply, "I don't know. He didn't say." I then said, "OK. Goodbye!"
[1975-08-18 18:10:00] Driveway | I turned around and slowly walked up the driveway. I stood on the divider block between the two roads, standing quietly for a while, straining to listen for any sound of them. There was no sound at all around me. I felt sad, tears welling in my eyes. I couldn't understand why they had gone off to play without ringing my doorbell.
[1975-08-18 18:15:00] Roadside divider block | I sat down on one of the concrete divider blocks. I could feel the rough concrete pressing painfully against my thighs. I saw dandelions covered in dust growing from the cracks below, and beside them, a rusted, abandoned barbecue grill with a faded cigarette pack stuck in the wire mesh.
[1975-08-18 18:20:00] Roadside divider block | I stood up and started walking downward. I looked up ahead, but saw no trace of them. I mentally ran through the places they might have gone: Ullbukt, the dock, or the playground? I wondered if Karl might have taken Tove to our secret hill—the one that belonged only to us.
[1975-08-18 18:30:00] Path to the dock | I took the right-hand path, passed the gate, and followed the trail. I walked through flattened knee-high grass, past bare cliffs covered in gray lichen, and through the woods onto the road. I saw the massive oak canopy casting deep shade, with soil and branches partially covering the path. I knew there were three paths leading to the floating dock.
[1975-08-18 18:40:00] Small boat harbor | I crossed the street to the new small boat harbor. I noticed a boat had just docked—Kanestrøm’s boat—so I went over to see what was happening. I saw Kanestrøm standing alone on the deck. I heard Kanestrøm call out to me, "Is that you wandering around out there? See? I came out for a little stroll, doing some fishing." I saw three identical docks here, each with wooden walkways and bright orange pontoons. I realized they weren’t here either.
[1975-08-18 18:45:00] Kanestrøm's boat | I saw him lift a red bucket toward me, filled with long, slimy mackerel shimmering with blue iridescence. I noticed some of the fish were still twitching and jumping spasmodically. I heard him offer, "Want to take a look?" The sun glinted brightly off his glasses. I saw he had a mustache, a bald spot on top of his head, and was wearing a plaid shirt and denim shorts. I stared at the fish pressing against one another, feeling as though they formed one moving mass.
[1975-08-18 18:45:10] Kanestrøm's boat | I exclaimed, "Whoa! Did you catch all of those yourself?" I heard him confirm it with pride.
[1975-08-18 18:46:00] Kanestrøm's boat | I saw him place the fish bucket on the gangway and set an old gasoline can beside it. He kept humming an old tune. I heard him boast, "All within just a few minutes. A whole school of fish right along the shore. My dinners are set for the next few days!" Fishing reels and boxes filled with hooks and bait were scattered nearby.
[1975-08-18 18:47:00] Kanestrøm's boat | I asked, "Do you know where Dalson is?" I heard him apologize, saying he didn’t know, and asked if I was looking for him.
[1975-08-18 18:48:00] Kanestrøm's boat | I shook my head. I heard him invite me, “Perhaps you’d like to come up here and sit?” I refused, “I don’t want to. I’ve got so much to do.”

[1975-08-18 18:50:00] parking lot / forest path | I left as quickly as I could. I ran across the gravel parking lot, practiced balance on the stone curbs by the roadside, then ducked into a steep path leading into the woods. I heard him say, “Alright then.” I didn’t want to stay with him any longer—I just wanted to get away fast.
[1975-08-18 18:55:00] Nåben | I arrived at Nåben, where there were two-meter-high rocks to jump from into the water, and I could swim toward Yrsta island ten meters away. I knew this was a popular swimming spot for people in the residential area. As far as I knew, the water there was deep. Even though I couldn’t swim, I still liked going there occasionally because it was always lively.
[1975-08-18 19:00:00] forest path | I stopped on the forest path. I saw Dalson and Gretevik come into view, carrying towels, their hair wet. I heard two voices of different pitches from the woods, then heard Dalson call out, “Hey, Grete Lundnes! I saw a venomous snake at a place!” Sunlight cast dappled shadows between the tree trunks.
[1975-08-18 19:00:10] forest path | I watched Dalson and Gretevik stop in front of me. I noticed that Gretevik had long black hair and faint facial hair above his lips. I asked in surprise, “Really? Where? Here?” I heard him nod in confirmation. I knew Gretevik was in lower secondary school, played bass, and had his own room in the basement. I sensed that Gretevik seemed impatient, as if he didn’t want to waste time talking to me and just wanted to leave.
[1975-08-18 19:01:00] forest path | I heard Dalson describe, “I was running down when I turned the corner, and there was a venomous snake lying right in the middle of the path. I almost couldn’t stop in time!”
[1975-08-18 19:01:10] forest path | I asked nervously, “And then what?” I heard him say, “It darted into the bushes like a flash of lightning.”
[1975-08-18 19:01:20] forest path | I saw Dalson looking at me, a smile spreading across his face. I pressed on, “Are you sure it was a venomous snake?” I heard him answer firmly, “Absolutely, no doubt about it. It had zigzag markings on its head.” I noticed his face was triangular, with light-colored hair and gentle, eager blue eyes. I thought that in this world, snakes and insects were what I feared most.
[1975-08-18 19:02:00] forest path | I asked, “Can I come up with you?” I heard him say only Jon, his younger brother, and Marianne’s parents were down below.
[1975-08-18 19:05:00] forest path | I heard Dalson say cheerfully, “Of course, but I can’t play—I have to go home for dinner now.” I chimed in, “Same with me, I need to go home too. I have to cover my new schoolbag.”
[1975-08-18 19:15:00] path in front of the house | I saw them off and stood for a moment on the road outside my home, scanning around for Karl and Toya. I hesitated before moving forward. I felt the sun hanging above the ridge, burning my shoulders. I realized I couldn't see any trace of them anywhere.
[1975-08-18 19:20:00] path behind the house | I cast one final glance down toward the road, then ran into the path behind the house. I sprinted along my yard's fence and the neighbor's stone wall. I heard the aspen trees rustling softly in the afternoon sea breeze. I imagined they might suddenly appear at the crossroads.
[1975-08-18 19:25:00] marshland | I passed through dense deciduous forest and entered a marshy area. I saw a huge beech tree leaning out from a steep cliff, beneath which lay a small patch of grass shaded in green.
[1975-08-18 19:30:00] woods | I noticed the shadows growing slowly between the trees. I saw how the great trees stretched themselves in different styles, their trunks, roots, and bark each unique in the play of light and shadow. I felt as though these trees were speaking to me with their bodies—not through sound, but by simply revealing their presence.
[1975-08-18 19:35:00] woods | I saw the giant spruce beside the stream, its thick, tangled roots extending far out. I observed how the spruce’s branches covered the depths, nearly black in color. I smelled the rich scent of sap within the bark. I saw the branches forming a pyramid shape downward, densely covered with deep green, tightly packed needles. I found it incredible how massive that tree was.
[1975-08-18 19:40:00] woods | I saw pines rising like masts, their bark reddish. I noticed the oak behind the football field had a trunk as hard as stone, with a head-sized knothole in its center. I also saw thick, oil-green oak leaves hanging on the branches or piled on the ground like a russet-red carpet. I thought the canopy of oak leaves looked remarkably light and expansive. I realized that although the fallen leaves had softened on the ground, they were still beautiful.
[1975-08-18 19:45:00] steep slope by the marshland | I reached the slope before the marshland and climbed up onto the elevated ground beneath a nameless large tree. I grabbed the hanging branches with both hands, trying to swing myself up—attempting twice. I saw four equally thick trunks supporting a dense canopy, their gray-green bark deeply grooved. A rope hung tied to one of the branches. I knew that rope was probably put there by the children from the other side of the road. I felt this tree possessed a subtle and barely perceptible beauty.
[1975-08-18 19:50:00] steep slope by the marshland | I stood under the tree for a while, wondering what to do. I remained motionless there. I heard the owners of the house on the slope talking in their garden, the clinking of cutlery in my ears. In the distance, I also heard the drone of an airplane. I knew a couple and a child lived there. Though I could see nothing, I could sense the rhythm of my neighbors' lives.
[1975-08-18 19:55:00] shaded hillside | I moved across the dry muddy ground, looking up. After watching the plane disappear behind the hill, I began running, entering the other side of the slope. I saw a white seaplane flashing blindingly in the sunlight. I felt the air here was noticeably cooler.
[1975-08-18 20:00:00] path | I looked down at the path below. I ran along this trail. I proudly thought: No one could beat me in a race here. I could run this path blindfolded. I knew every stone, every depression, and every bush here. I found it deeply satisfying to precisely control where I placed my feet, and I tried to prolong this feeling of superiority.
[1975-08-18 20:10:00] football field clearing | I stopped at the open ground beside the football field. I saw many children of different ages on the field, all running back and forth chasing a ball. I heard screams, shouts, and laughter echoing through the trees. I felt like those sounds resembled monkeys playing.
[1975-08-18 20:15:00] football field | I saw the football field was a patch of dark, compacted earth. One side bordered a protruding cliff, the other side covered in stiff grass. At each end stood wooden goalposts without nets. I knew nearly all my dreams had originated here. I felt that running in circles on such a field was my greatest joy.
[1975-08-18 20:15:10] football field | I shouted, "Can I join?"
[1975-08-18 20:16:00] football field | I saw Helen Sengtong turn toward me. I heard Helen Stirling say, "If you want, you can stand here as goalkeeper." I noticed every kicked ball bounced back from the cliff side.
[1975-08-18 20:16:10] football field | I ran to the goal. I saw Helen Seng slowly walk away. I readily agreed, "Okay." I heard Helen Sterng announce loudly, "Grete Lundnes is our team's goalkeeper!"
[1975-08-18 20:20:00] football field | I positioned myself between the goalposts. I crouched down, caught the rolling ball, slapped it against the ground three times, then kicked it out. The ball struck my foot and arced in a parabola toward the right. I saw the ball was muddy-colored, worn thin with golden rubber showing through, large and soft to the touch. I found great joy in watching a group of children chase after the ball. I wasn't just following the players with my eyes—I was also silently distinguishing friend from foe in my heart.
[1975-08-18 20:25:00] football field | I was happy being the goalkeeper. I especially loved that instant rush of diving forward to grab the ball. But I realized I had a problem: I could only dive to the left. Diving to the right seemed to defy natural law for me.
[1975-08-18 20:30:00] football field | I noticed the players on the field began to slow down; some stopped and bent over, hands on their knees. I heard someone suggest, "Let's stop playing—I have to go home." I saw the trees casting long shadows across the field, darkness now chasing after the children. I reluctantly realized the game was coming to an end.
[1975-08-18 20:30:10] football field | My ears were filled with overlapping voices: "Me too." "I've got to go." "I'm leaving."
[1975-08-18 20:35:00] football field | I saw that within just a few minutes, the entire team had dispersed, leaving the field completely empty.
locations: path in front of the house

text:
[1975-08-18 20:45:00] kitchen | I sat in the kitchen with my mother. I cut a piece of paper and pressed it under a book, folded the cover neatly, and taped it down. I saw that the book-covering paper my mother bought was translucent blue. I noticed the edges of the paper I cut were crooked; in the end, my mother had to trim them straight for me.
[1975-08-18 21:00:00] kitchen | I sat there, watching my mother's knitting movements closely. I knew this was the Indian pattern I had chosen—white with dark brown edges. I also learned that the sweater would have side slits at the hem. I really liked the design of this sweater and followed its progress attentively. I realized my mother kept helping me adjust the book-covering paper throughout.
[1975-08-18 21:10:00] home | I looked at the reddish-brown patterned curtains in the room, handmade by my mother. I glanced around at the bookshelves filled with books. I knew my mother was skilled at crafts—sewing, mending, embroidery, she could do it all. As far as I knew, none of the neighbors had a large bookshelf like ours. I also knew she had many kind female friends. I thought my mother looked very peaceful when she read during her free time. I really liked her friends.
[1975-08-18 21:15:00] home / Zhens | I knew about Dagney’s friends, and Sven who drove the Citroën. I knew Marit and her children, Lars and Mariann. From what I understood, my father didn’t like their visits, so they rarely came over. I knew we would go to Zhens’ craft workshop to make Christmas gifts. I thought that whenever they did come, I’d get to enjoy being included and just sit with them.
[1975-08-18 21:20:00] kitchen | I saw my mother tuck a long strand of hair behind her ear; her face looked serious yet gentle.
[1975-08-18 21:20:10] kitchen | I told my mother, “Dalson saw a venomous snake somewhere! Right on the path down the cliff—he was running away! Luckily, the snake was scared too and crawled into the grass.” I heard my mother ask in surprise where exactly, then finally sigh, “That’s good.”
[1975-08-18 21:25:00] kitchen | I saw my mother give a soft smile. I asked curiously, “Were there venomous snakes when you were little?” She shook her head and said there weren’t any in the western region. When I asked why, she replied it was probably too cold there.
[1975-08-18 21:30:00] kitchen | I swung my legs back and forth, tapping my fingers on the table. I looked at my mother and brought up the mackerel. Humming a tune, I asked, “Kanestrøm caught so many mackerels today—I saw it myself. Do you think we’ll get a boat soon?”
[1975-08-18 21:35:00] kitchen | I heard my mother laugh and say, “You’re asking for too much—both a boat and a cat! It’s something we can consider. But not this year, maybe next year? It costs money, you know. But you can go ahead and ask your father.” As soon as I heard the suggestion to 'ask your father,' I felt uneasy inside and thought, 'Sure, like that’s going to help.' But I didn’t say anything out loud.
[1975-08-18 21:40:00] kitchen | I saw my mother hand me the scissors again. I tried to guide them forward smoothly, keeping them from veering downward. I was determined to cut it right this time, but the scissors jammed. I squeezed hard, and still, the edge came out crooked.
[1975-08-18 21:45:00] kitchen | I saw my mother gazing anxiously out the window. I heard my mother say, "Henrik Inge is late coming home again." I comforted her, saying, "Someone will take care of him."
[1975-08-18 21:50:00] kitchen | I watched my mother nod at me. I said to my mother, "That form—for swimming lessons. Can you sign it for me now?"
[1975-08-18 21:55:00] hallway / room | I stood up and ran through the hallway, dashed into my room, and rummaged around looking for that note. Just as I was about to run back, I heard the front door opening downstairs. Since I had just been running inside the house, the sound of the door made my heart suddenly sink.
[1975-08-18 21:55:10] staircase landing | I stood frozen outside the bathroom door, just in time to see my father's gaze rising from the lower landing, meeting my eyes directly. I heard heavy, firm footsteps on the stairs. I knew he was coming upstairs.
[1975-08-18 21:55:20] staircase landing | I saw him standing in front of me, staring at me. I heard him scold, "Don't run inside the house! How many times do I have to say this? The whole house shakes. Do you understand?"
[1975-08-18 21:55:25] staircase landing | I whispered, "Yes."
[1975-08-18 21:55:40] staircase landing / kitchen | I saw him walk past me into the kitchen, and I followed behind. I stared at his broad back beneath the white shirt, realizing all joy had vanished—but I knew I had to go in.
[1975-08-18 21:56:00] kitchen | I saw my mother still sitting in her place. I saw my father looking out the window. I stepped forward and carefully placed the school note on the table. I said to them, "Here it is."
[1975-08-18 21:57:00] kitchen | I sat down and continued wrapping the remaining book. I saw my father still staring out the window. I heard my father ask, "Henrik Inge hasn't come home yet?" My mother replied, "No, I'm starting to get a bit worried." I felt the silence all around, broken only by the movement of my hands.

[1975-09-06 11:15:00] landfill | I saw two men holding guns standing beside the garbage pile. They fired every few seconds, then stepped across the trash and walked away. [1975-09-06 11:20:00] landfill | We walked toward the spot where the two men had stood. I looked around and saw piles everywhere—junk cars, refrigerators, TVs, sofas, and all kinds of furniture. [1975-09-06 11:25:00] landfill | I saw one of them swing a dead rat by its tail in circles a few times, then toss it aside. The rat landed in a crevice between distant plastic bags. [1975-09-06 11:30:00] landfill | I saw the two men walking toward us, one wearing a blue sunhat and sporting a red mustache. I heard the red-bearded man greet us, 'Out for a stroll, kids?' [1975-09-06 11:40:00] junkyard | I saw the two men lying on the ground, motionless as they aimed. With the first gunshot, I saw a rat nearby torn open instantly, as if ripped apart. I felt as though a sudden gust of wind swept through the air. I tried hard to see what they were aiming at.
[1975-09-06 11:45:00] junkyard | I saw the rat was not yet dead, writhing in pain on the ground. text:
[1975-09-06 12:20:00] woods | We searched the woods for a suitable spot. I climbed onto a fallen pine trunk, pulled down my pants, gripped the log tightly, and stuck my butt out. I watched my poop fall straight down. I heard Karl point at the droppings hanging from the trunk and burst into laughter: 'See that!' I couldn’t help but laugh along with him. I thought of the poop falling like bombs dropped from an airplane, and found the whole thing incredibly fun. I realized that watching it hang there and then drop off gave me an oddly satisfying thrill.
[1975-09-06 12:30:00] woods | I was used to holding in my bowel movements for several days. I realized this built up the urge even more, and when I finally let go, my entire body would feel a wonderfully liberating pleasure. That sense of calm made me want to stay sitting there forever.
[1975-09-06 12:40:00] woods | I remembered the intense pain sometimes caused by overly hard stools—the bursting sensation scared me. I thought about how I’d once tried using my fingers to help push it out. Though it worked, the lingering stench on my fingertips annoyed me. I kept weighing the pros and cons of this method in my mind.
[1975-09-06 12:50:00] woods | I saw Karl stirring my poop with a stick. Immediately, several shiny green flies swirled over. I suggested we should leave. I heard Karl pinch his nose and shout in disgust, 'Ah, damn, that’s disgusting!' I shot back that his own shit smelled worse. Before leaving, I asked if he wanted to come back next week. He said he’d be going to Risør to see boats. I noticed my poop was mixed with green and somewhat soft. Karl’s looked drier and light brown.
[1975-09-06 13:10:00] on the way home | I carried the plastic bag full of magazines, watching Karl Larsdal hold a car wheel as we ran home together. I made Karl swear not to tell anyone where we’d been once we got home. I knew my family wouldn’t allow us to go there if they found out. I had already made up a story—if Dad asked about the magazines, I’d say I borrowed them from Jon who lived in another district.
[1975-09-06 13:30:00] hallway at home | I walked into the hallway and stood quietly for a moment, bent down to untie my shoelaces, and placed my shoes neatly against the wall. Dad appeared before me, pushing open the second door, so I showed him the bag. I watched him flip through it, take out a paperback copy of Tex Willer, and walk back into his office. I heard Dad ask, 'Where have you been?' I stared at the floor and answered, 'In the woods... then up on the high ridge.' Then I heard him ask what was in the bag, and I told him they were borrowed magazines. I suddenly remembered the excuse I had prepared earlier, mentally calculating how to make the lie sound more natural.
[1975-09-06 13:35:00] foot of the stairs | I was about to go upstairs when I heard Dad call me, so I turned and walked back down. I saw him standing in the open doorway, placing a five-kroner coin in my hand. I heard Dad say, 'You haven't taken your weekly allowance yet.' I said, 'Ah, thanks!' He also told me the supermarket was closed, and if I wanted sweets, I could go to the Finna gas station down below. I worried whether he had discovered something—maybe even that he could smell the landfill on the books. My legs felt weak and wobbly, as if I could barely stand.
[1975-09-06 14:00:00] path to the gas station | I headed toward the Finna gas station, walking the long downhill stretch, across grassy fields and forest paths, finally onto the gravel road leading to the highway. Houses surrounded me, with cars and pedestrians on both sides. Deep along the path, it was silent—only leaves, bushes, fallen wood, and occasional marshes. I found the gas station both wonderful and hateful. To me, the path was the worst place—once I stepped just a few meters into it, I vanished into the woods, completely cut off from any sign of people.
[1975-09-06 14:10:00] the path | I walked along the path, singing loudly. When I wasn’t singing, I talked to myself, muttering about the Knox and Fox candies I wanted to buy. I heard myself sing, 'A little blue bird is flying...' I also muttered to myself, 'Could someone be living on the other side?' I knew we lived on an island, so there must be ocean somewhere. I imagined perhaps Baywick’s ferry was crossing the sea right now. I felt that when I sang, I wasn’t alone anymore—the songs were like another boy keeping me company. In my mind, I kept repeating the names of the candies over and over.
[1975-09-06 14:20:00] the path | I noticed beneath the tall deciduous trees to the right, the dense canopy formed an open room-like space, leaving the understory vegetation very sparse.
[1975-09-06 14:30:00] Finna gas station | I walked up the gravel road, past the white old house and the red old grain silo. I stopped fifty meters from the gas station, looking at the four fuel pumps. I saw a truck parked there, the driver leaning out to talk to someone below. I heard the distant whoosh of cars passing on the main road. The gas station loomed ahead, impressive and grand, with a huge white plastic sign flashing the word 'Finna' in blue. Three mopeds were parked outside the convenience store. I felt as though the four fuel pumps were raising their hands, waving at me like greetings.
[1975-09-06 14:35:00] beside the gas pump at the gas station | I stopped in front of a man who was refueling. I stared at the rapidly changing numbers on the pump screen. I observed the man—he performed every movement without needing to look down. I heard the pump humming and roaring. The man pulled a thick wallet from his pocket and handled the nozzle with practiced ease. The numbers on the screen seemed like faces blinking wildly. I realized he was completely accustomed to this routine, and I was deeply impressed.
[1975-09-06 14:40:00] gas station convenience store | I walked toward the store and reached out to push the door open. My heart pounded—I didn’t know what awaited me behind that door. I was especially afraid someone might make fun of me or my dad, turning me into a laughingstock.
[1975-09-06 14:45:00] gas station convenience store | I noticed most of the customers were lower secondary school kids. Some wore leather jackets with Ferrari logos stitched on, their hair long enough to cover their eyes, flicking their heads sharply now and then. I saw some spitting, others drinking cola, smoke drifting through the air. I knew the younger ones rode bicycles, the older ones motorcycles. I learned some even poured peanuts into their cola bottles to eat. I watched the way they tied their bandanas and moved.
[1975-09-06 14:50:00] gas station convenience store | I kept my head low and darted like an arrow straight to the counter to buy my things. I imagined them shouting at me, 'Little Grete Lundnes is scared!' Everything here represented 'evil' to me. Their laughter was the most hateful thing in my nightmares—I couldn’t bear to stay here a single moment longer.
[1975-09-06 14:55:00] gas station convenience store | I used all my money to buy a huge pile of Fox and Knox candies, took the transparent bag from the cashier, and hurried out. I noticed a few girls sitting at the farthest table, giggling quietly. I saw three boys standing by the arcade machine, and four others sitting around a table drinking Coca-Cola. I was glad they hadn't picked on me this time.
[1975-09-06 15:10:00] path | I walked up the gravel road and re-entered the path. As I walked, I kept thinking about my candy-eating strategy. I heard myself say, 'This journey seems to be going smoothly enough.' I muttered indecisively, 'Should I eat one of each kind, or finish one type first?' I felt the sun no longer shining; the air had turned cool. I secretly celebrated how well my earlier adventure had gone.
[1975-09-06 15:15:00] path | I suddenly stopped dead in my tracks, staring fixedly at the bushes to my right. For safety, I stepped backward a few paces. I tried calling out, but no one answered. I asked cautiously, 'Hey? Is someone there?' A rustling sound reached my ears. My heart pounded: What could have made that noise?
[1975-09-06 15:20:00] path | I bent down, grabbed a stone, and hurled it hard into the bushes, then ran up the hill as fast as I could. I stopped to make sure nothing was following me. I shouted with a laugh, 'I'll beat you to death!' Seeing nothing behind me, I couldn't help laughing.
[1975-09-06 15:30:00] path | I pushed myself forward, feeling my heart pounding wildly beneath my chest. I thought the most important thing about dead people is not to think about them. I realized that once I started imagining ghosts, fear would swirl through my entire body, as if I could see them hiding behind the pine trees.
locations: beside the gas pump at the gas station

text:
[1975-09-06 15:40:00] construction area lawn | I stepped out of the path and saw the lawn of the construction area spread out before me. I felt only now did my mind finally relax completely.
[1975-09-06 15:45:00] construction area lawn | I began jogging across the field. Before me stretched a crystal-clear, bright sky, with a hint of gray smudged between the distant houses.
[1975-09-06 15:46:00] construction area lawn | Walking across the grass, I noticed two girls ahead staring at me, then they started running toward me. The two girls had originally been standing outside a house by the roadside.
[1975-09-06 15:46:10] construction area lawn | I looked at them but didn't stop walking forward, until they blocked my way. I wondered nervously what they were trying to do.
[1975-09-06 15:46:20] construction area lawn | I recognized one of them as Tom's younger sister; the other girl was someone I'd never seen before. I knew Tom was famous in this neighborhood—he owned a shiny red car.
[1975-09-06 15:47:00] lawn near the buildings | I prepared to walk around them and leave. I heard one of them ask, 'Where did you go?' I answered, 'To the Fina gas station.' The other pressed on, asking what for, and I said, 'Nothing.'
[1975-09-06 15:47:30] lawn near the buildings | I watched as they shifted positions, blocking my way out. I heard them demanding what was in my bag. I lied and said it was nothing. But they shouted, 'We saw—it's Fox and Knox.' In desperation, I said I'd bought them for my eleven-year-old brother, but then they actually told me to give them the candy. I felt tension rising involuntarily and quietly refused them.
[1975-09-06 15:48:00] lawn near the buildings | I saw Tom's sister grab the bag, and I quickly twisted it away. Another girl reached out and shoved me to the ground. I lay there clutching the bag tightly with both arms, struggling to get back up. I heard the girl who pushed me command, 'Give me the bag.' I shouted back, 'No.'
[1975-09-06 15:48:30] lawn near the buildings | She shoved me again, and I crashed hard onto the ground, helplessly watching as they snatched the bag and ran off toward the road, laughing. I sat there crying. I screamed hysterically, 'They're mine! You can't take them!' I heard one of them mock, 'So I guess it's not your brother's after all?'
[1975-09-06 15:49:00] lawn near the buildings | I yelled at their retreating backs as they fled. I shouted, 'They're mine! They're mine!'
[1975-09-06 15:55:00] on my way home | I sobbed as I walked home. I thought about how I had used the money Dad gave me to run so far just to buy that candy, and I felt utterly wronged. I kept asking myself over and over: How could this happen? How could they just take my things like that? I felt a despair born of being bullied.
[1975-09-06 15:58:00] in front of the house | As I neared home, I wiped my face fiercely with my sleeve, blinked rapidly several times, and shook my head. I thought this would hide the traces of my crying so my family wouldn’t notice.
[1975-09-06 15:58:10] in front of the house | I recalled the time when Wenke threw stones at me when I was five. As far as I knew, Dad didn’t help me then—he even said I couldn’t even fight off a little girl, which made me feel deeply ashamed. At the time, I completely didn’t understand why Dad wanted me to hit back. In my heart, I wondered—wasn’t fighting back something even worse?
[1975-09-06 15:58:20] by the yard fence | I remembered how Dad stood there with his arms crossed, his gaze extremely stern, only nodding for me to get out and play and stop bothering him. I knew Dad’s thinking was different from mine—he cared only that I didn’t act like a coward.
[1975-09-06 16:00:00] at home / Henrik Inge's room | I paused in the hallway, listening for sounds, then took off my shoes and placed them neatly. I tiptoed carefully upstairs and slipped into my brother’s room. Thinking of the lost candy, tears fell again. I realized it was girls who stole the candy—Dad definitely wouldn’t care. Just thinking about those Fox and Knox candies made me ache with sorrow.
[1975-09-06 16:05:00] Henrik Inge's room | I saw Henrik Inge lying face down on the bed with his legs crossed, a bag of candy piled beside him next to a magazine. I heard my brother ask, "Why are you crying?" He was reading a publication titled *The Nemesis*.
[1975-09-06 16:10:00] Henrik Inge's room | I sobbed as I recounted what had just happened. I heard my brother ask, "Well, couldn't you just run away?" I cried and explained that they had blocked my path. When he suggested I push back, I replied, "No, they're much older and stronger than me."
[1975-09-06 16:15:00] Henrik Inge's room | I wiped my tears and sat down, taking a few candies from his hand and putting them in my mouth. I heard my brother say, "You don't need to cry over this." He offered to share some candy with me. I nodded, and as he counted them out, he handed me a few pieces. I asked if I could stay here to eat them, and he agreed—but told me to leave once I was done. I felt much better and was grateful toward him.
[1975-09-06 17:00:00] Home | I washed my face with cold water. I stayed upstairs, making sure I didn't hear any sound from Dad. I heard the kitchen exhaust fan humming; Mom was busy working in there. I felt refreshed. I thought Dad must be in his office downstairs—that made me feel at ease.
[1975-09-06 17:05:00] Kitchen | I walked into the kitchen and took a seat on a chair, watching Mom standing by the stove stirring meat in a frying pan. I heard another pot bubbling nearby. I heard Mom ask, "Did you buy your Saturday candy?" The noise of the exhaust fan echoed in my ears, along with the sizzling from the frying pan.
[1975-09-06 17:10:00] Kitchen | I answered that I had. I heard her ask if I'd gone to 'Fina Service Station.' I casually asked what we were having for dinner. [1975-09-06 17:15:00] Kitchen | I watched Mom efficiently season the meat, measure water into a pot, and pour rice into the boiling water. I saw her sit down on the chair across from me and rub her lower back. I could sense that Mom was already tired after a long day's work.
[1975-09-06 17:20:00] Kitchen | I curiously asked, "What exactly do you do at the auxiliary therapy center?" Mom reminded me I'd actually been there several times. I asked her why she had to take care of those people, and why they couldn't live at home.
[1975-09-06 17:25:00] Kitchen | I watched Mom fall into thought, then shake her head. I heard her explain that the people there suffered from phobias. I heard Mom say, "A phobia is when you're afraid of something, but you don't even know what it is." I asked if they were afraid all the time. She nodded and said, "Yes, that's why I talk to them, so they won't be so afraid anymore." Actually, I was already thinking about something else by then and didn't really care about her silence.
[1975-09-06 17:30:00] Kitchen | I pressed on, "So they're just afraid?" Mom answered yes, and added that once they recovered, they could move back home.
[1975-09-06 17:35:00] kitchen | I explained that it was because the teacher had asked us to talk about our parents' jobs, so that's why I'd asked. I heard Mom ask if I'd been through something recently. I also repeated what Karl had said, about how his mom taught people to tie their shoes. Actually, I wasn't entirely clear on the specific details of my mom's job.
[1975-09-06 17:40:00] kitchen | I watched Mom get up and stir the vegetables in the pot. I heard Mom patiently explain that some people have difficulties with housework or dressing themselves, so Marthe helps them with those things.
[1975-09-06 17:41:00] kitchen | I asked if they were 'Mongos.' I heard Mom stare at me seriously and tell me it was called Down syndrome, and that 'Mongos' was an offensive term. I mumbled in response.

[1975-09-06 18:00:00] kitchen / hallway | I heard the front door open downstairs, immediately stood up, walked quickly down the hall, and slipped into Henrik Inge's room. I tried not to break into a run. I told Mom, 'I'm going over to Henrik Inge's for a bit.' I thought I absolutely had to hide in the room before Dad came upstairs, otherwise he'd start questioning me again.
[1975-09-06 18:01:00] Henrik Inge's room | I had just closed the door when I heard Dad step onto the first stair. I saw my brother lying on the bed reading a football magazine. I went over and sat down on the chair. My brother asked if dinner was almost ready. I nodded, then asked, 'Can I borrow one of your magazines?' He reminded me to take good care of it. I was glad I'd made it into the room ahead of Dad.
[1975-09-06 18:05:00] Henrik Inge's room | I bent down in front of the bookshelf, rummaging through a large stack of picture magazines. I wanted to borrow the whole folder, but was refused, so in the end I took just a single issue. I heard Dad's footsteps pass by. I heard my brother say firmly, 'Bring it back as soon as you're done!' I learned he was a member of the Phantom Club and liked keeping his Phantom comics neatly stored in folders, while I always tossed mine around carelessly.
[1975-09-06 19:00:00] dining room | The table was set with each person's napkin neatly in place. I saw Dad and Mom drinking wine, while we drank Blue Sky soda. I learned about the Saturday routine: cold rice porridge for breakfast, and a formal dinner in the dining room in the evening. I knew that after dinner usually meant watching TV together as a family.
[1975-09-06 20:00:00] living room | Broadway-style performances played on TV, with actors in tights and suits. I saw Solvi Wang, Mom's favorite, appear on stage. I knew that Saturday night TV typically featured variety sketches, the annual song contest, and sports events—these were highlights throughout the year. I also recognized regulars on the show like Leif, Alv, and others.
[1975-09-06 21:00:00] bedroom | I hummed 'Oul man rivå' all evening, whether brushing my teeth, undressing, or finally lying in bed. I heard a ragged man sitting on a rooftop on TV singing that song in an extremely deep voice. That melody kept circling in my mind.
[1975-09-06 22:00:00] living room / bedroom | I saw Mom and Dad close the sliding doors; they sat in the living room chatting, smoking, listening to music, and finishing the leftover wine from dinner. In between songs, I heard Dad mutter complaints under his breath, while Mom calmly responded—but I couldn't make out what they were saying.
[1975-09-07 02:00:00] bedroom | I fell asleep, and when I woke up again, I saw they were still talking inside. null null null I wondered to myself—were they planning to talk all night long?
[1975-09-10 12:00:00] in front of Helen Ster's house | At noon, I got off the bus and followed Helen Ster home with Karl Larsdal. We climbed up to his balcony and dropped our backpacks onto plastic chairs. I heard Helen invite us upstairs for juice. He opened the door and shouted into the house: 'Mom, we want juice! Some classmates from my class are here!' Before me stretched a bright blue sky and dry roads where dust swirled in the air. null null
[1975-09-10 12:10:00] Helen Ster's balcony | I saw his mother step out through the door and disappear into the living room, then behind another door. I heard her say: 'How lovely! I'll check and get you some juice.' I noticed his mother was wearing a white bikini, large sunglasses covering half her face, and deeply tanned skin. His living room looked somewhat empty, with no pictures on the walls. null null
[1975-09-10 12:15:00] Helen Ster's balcony | I saw two girls from our class passing below, and Helen Ster bent down and shouted at them. I noticed that Marianna was taller than all the boys. Karl and I burst out laughing. I heard Helen yelling after them, calling them a pair of monkeys. I noticed Marianna had a high forehead, high cheekbones, and long light hair falling like curtains on either side of her cheeks. null I saw the girls ignore him and keep walking. I liked watching the little wrinkles that appeared on Marianna’s forehead when she thought.
[1975-09-10 12:20:00] Helen Ster's balcony | I saw Helen Ster’s mother come out carrying a tray, pouring iced juice into each of our glasses. I heard Helen suddenly burst into loud laughter and say: 'Were you looking at my mom’s ass?' I saw the bright red juice, the ice cubes tightly packed and pressing against each other. null I noticed his mother’s skin was deeply tanned. I thought to myself that although she wasn’t beautiful, there was something undeniably striking about her.
[1975-09-10 12:20:10] Helen Ster's balcony | I saw Helen’s mother come over and slap him lightly on the cheek. I felt deeply embarrassed and shouted: 'No, I wasn't looking!' I heard Helen continue laughing and call his mother over. He said to her: 'Grete Lundnes was looking at your ass!' null null I didn’t understand why he would say that. I worried she might hear his shouting.
[1975-09-10 12:25:00] Helen Ster's balcony / room | I followed Helen through a dark hallway into his room. I saw motorcycle posters on the wall and a nearly nude woman on a poster. I heard Helen still laughing, introducing the poster: 'That’s a Kawasaki 750.' Then he asked if we wanted more juice. null null I saw Karl Larsdal whistling into the air, clearly embarrassed too.
[1975-09-10 12:30:00] Helen Ster's room / outside the door | We left the room and walked away amid the barking of the dog. I saw Helen waving to us from the balcony, and Karl waved back. I declined: 'I think not—I have to go home for lunch.' Karl echoed my words. null null I didn’t say a word as I walked down the stairs.
[1975-09-10 12:40:00] on the way home | null null null null I kept wondering: Why would I look at his mother’s ass? I felt uneasy—it wasn’t right, especially since she was almost naked, but I really hadn’t looked. And I kept thinking: how could he still laugh after she slapped him?
[1975-09-10 12:50:00] on the way home | null null null I knew this was the first and last time I’d visit Helen’s house. Though he was in my class, he wasn’t someone I could confide in. I knew he often hung out with older boys and even dared to challenge teachers. As far as I knew, Helen had more 'uncles' at home than anyone else. I realized that even though people said he only seemed tough, deep down I knew he truly was—and we were all a little afraid of him.
[1975-09-15 08:00:00] in front of the supermarket / bus | I saw Karl Larsdal come to ring my doorbell. We walked toward the supermarket and lined up our backpacks to claim seats on the bus. I love watching the children from old Tibaken and all over the hills gradually gather in small groups in front of the store.
[1975-09-15 08:00:00] Tibaken | I noticed that the warm days of September were summer’s final struggle, and the temperature would suddenly drop. I had to switch to sweaters and long pants, and wear a coat in the mornings. When the rainy season arrived, I could only wear rubber boots and a raincoat.
[1975-09-15 08:10:00] in front of the supermarket | Ingeborg had shiny black hair and sparkling dark eyes, with large, red lips. I especially enjoyed looking at Ingeborg. I felt she was always so joyful, as if her body was filled with endless happiness, which made me feel happy too.
[1975-09-15 08:10:00] Tibaken | I saw the stream overflowing with rainwater, and puddles of varying depths everywhere on the road. The rushing water swept away mud, sand, and pinecones, carrying everything far away. People at the dock were now busy fishing. I realized outdoor swimming was completely over; no one went out boating anymore.
[1975-09-15 08:15:00] in front of the supermarket | Lilund had a face full of freckles and pale skin. As far as I knew, Ingeborg’s close friend was Lilund, and they were always inseparable. I knew their family lived in the uppermost residential area of Tibaken, and I also heard that Ingeborg had a younger sister and a younger brother. I noticed that although Lilund didn’t talk much, her eyes were very gentle.
[1975-09-15 08:20:00] in front of the supermarket | I heard Vimd proudly say his father had hemophilia. He explained it meant that once bleeding started, it couldn’t be stopped, and he might die. I saw Vimd’s father was thin and pale, needing to walk with a cane. His mother, on the other hand, was large-built with a shrill voice. I knew Vimd was somewhat overweight, not good at reading but loved drawing. I learned his family lived at the very top. It was said his constitution was weak—even the way he threw things looked girlish.
locations: in front of Helen Ster's house
Helen Ster's room / outside the door
in front of the supermarket / bus

text:
[1975-09-15 08:20:00] outer side of the island | I saw Dad put on his dark green raincoat on weekends and drive off alone to the outer side of the island to fish. He would wait there for hours, hoping to catch a big cod. I knew winter was the season for cod fishing, and I also saw Dad pull out his full set of fishing gear.
[1975-09-15 08:30:00] various parts of Tibaken | From the top of the hill, I could see the lawn in Hagenlund’s garden, where a five-meter-high white wall and green hedges stood. I realized that with the start of school, many children who were once strangers suddenly entered my life. I learned where Karin Ingrid, Kristine Lof, and others lived, and discovered that the world wasn’t as closed off as I had imagined. I found it amazing that areas that once seemed independent suddenly became connected - this feeling struck me as truly wonderful.
[1975-09-15 08:30:00] school | I learned swimming lessons would take place every Tuesday evening. As far as I knew, everyone in the class had signed up, and we needed to go to the swimming pool on the other side of the bay for practice. I thought it felt a bit strange to go to an indoor pool when it was freezing cold outside.
[1975-09-15 08:40:00] school | Nilssen had tape covering his eyeglass lenses. Mariann was stronger than most boys. I learned Sølvi was so shy she barely spoke, Winnie’s whole family sold vegetables at the market, and Karl Larsdal had been thought unlikely to survive at birth. I knew Lilund was good at drawing, and Helen Ster had many uncles. I realized each person had their own world and unique story—these new details fascinated me deeply.
[1975-09-15 10:00:00] school | In class, I learned that it was true Jesus walked on water and that God appeared in a burning bush. I also learned that diseases are caused by tiny microorganisms. As far as I knew, everything in the world was made up of invisible particles too small for the eye to see. I felt school days were all the same. I gradually became convinced that school would never surprise me with anything new again.
[1975-09-15 10:00:00] school | I knew many teachers were my father’s colleagues, so they all recognized me. I realized they had initially been confused by my name because calling me was like calling him. I really enjoyed this feeling. I wanted to be the best in class, so my father would hear how outstanding I was.
[1975-09-15 10:05:00] school | I deeply loved going to school. In my heart, I marveled at how much I cherished everything that happened at school, and how each room carried its own stories.
[1975-09-15 10:10:00] school | I saw the teachers with their gray-streaked hair and neatly pressed suits. I knew many of them had been teaching for thirty or forty years. I realized they valued profound knowledge we could barely grasp, yet seemed indifferent to whether they got our names right.
[1975-09-15 10:10:00] classroom | I watched white chalk flow from the teacher's hand, forming various letters. I saw the wet sponge wipe the blackboard clean, which minutes later turned dark green again. I saw the old seats with iron pipe legs in the classroom, desks pockmarked and faded. I noticed the sponge bloating and changing color in the sink. Seeing a clean blackboard gave me a special kind of joy.
[1975-09-15 10:20:00] classroom | When the female teacher asked us something, I saw classmates raising their hands, and I vigorously waved my own back and forth, eager to get a chance to speak. I heard the woman teacher ask us questions in a Kamøy accent. I also heard classmates shouting 'Me, me, me!' in a rush. I knew we weren't allowed to speak freely in class—only when called upon by the teacher. I realized so many hands shot up because the question wasn’t difficult.
[1975-09-15 10:30:00] school playground / hallway | I saw children gathering and scattering during break time, one game after another unfolding. I smelled the green soap near the coat hooks, the urine odor in the toilets, and the scent rising from the milk cabinet. I noticed the classroom filled with the mixed smell of dozens of lunchboxes.
[1975-09-15 11:00:00] school hallway | I was on duty that week, walking alone into the empty corridor. I saw millions of dust particles shimmering in the light. Faint murmurs from classrooms on both sides reached my ears. Coats hung along both sides of the hallway, and the vinyl floor gave off a dull sheen. I knew that being on duty meant handing out materials, cleaning the blackboard, and collecting milk. At that moment, I sensed a unique atmosphere in the empty hallway, as if those dust particles formed a miniature galaxy.
[1975-09-15 11:05:00] school hallway | I felt the boy who burst out was like a comet, instantly transforming the hallway’s atmosphere, sweeping away all the smells and light. I realized he seemed to take all attention with him, becoming the center of this place.
[1975-09-15 12:00:00] school classroom | I watched Teacher Tormodsen stand hunched over the podium, clearing his throat and coughing up phlegm. I heard him read us a story about a wild woman in a muffled, nasal voice. I saw the teacher’s pale yellow face and lips tinged red with a hint of blue. I knew this was his lunchtime reading session. I found sitting quietly, listening to a story I couldn’t understand, an excruciating torment. I thought to myself: maybe this was his way of showing kindness.
[1975-09-15 12:00:00] front door | On a rainy day, I walked across the gravel in my rain boots and raincoat. I tightly gripped the key, trying to insert it into the lock, but couldn't turn it no matter what. I knew Mom had given me this key so I could enter the house by myself. As far as I was concerned, it was a proud symbol hanging around my neck, yet I was now running into trouble. I had originally felt very happy and proud that I could open the door by myself.
[1975-09-15 12:10:00] front door | I stood in the pouring rain for ten minutes. After trying with all my strength, I began to cry. I watched as other children quickly slipped into their homes. I felt my hands turn bright red and icy cold. I felt incredibly wronged and helpless.
[1975-09-15 12:15:00] front door | I saw an unfamiliar elderly neighbor woman walking down the slope. I hurried over to ask her for help, tears still streaming down my cheeks. I cried and asked her if she could help me unlock the door. I knew she didn’t have any connection with my parents, which made me less hesitant to ask her. At that moment, I just wanted to get inside as quickly as possible.
[1975-09-15 12:20:00] front door | I saw the old woman gently adjust the key, then smoothly turn the lock open. I thanked her and went inside. I marveled inwardly: Goodness, unlocking the door was so effortless for her!
[1975-09-15 13:00:00] school | I saw Teacher Mikkelbyst standing slowly beside the podium, eyeing us. He rose onto his toes and bowed to us. I heard him say seriously to us, 'Good morning, class.' We had to respond in unison, 'Good morning, teacher.' After the entire class marched into the classroom, we fell completely silent under the teacher’s gaze. I knew this teacher came from the west and enforced ironclad discipline. As far as I knew, his physical education classes were essentially drill exercises.
[1975-09-15 13:10:00] school | I saw the teacher yank disobedient students up by their hair or throw them out of the classroom. I knew that for rule-breakers, the teacher would slap them or write notes to their parents. I remembered once being pulled up by my hair by a female teacher for saying something wrong. As far as I knew, detention after school was hard to enforce since many of us relied on buses to get home. I felt both respect and deep fear toward these teachers.
[1975-09-15 14:00:00] school | I saw Teacher Ciliavik Oscar always maintaining calm and composure while in full control. I knew Ciliavik belonged to the younger generation of 'kind' teachers. As far as I knew, she never got angry or physically punished students, but instead resolved issues through dialogue. I realized her demeanor in class and outside class was almost identical. We all really liked teachers like her.
[1975-09-15 14:10:00] school | I knew Principal Osmundsen was strong-built and wore a mustache. As far as I knew, going to the principal’s office usually meant you’d committed a serious offense. I knew he rarely appeared during regular classes, like a ghost. Even though he wasn’t like my father, I instinctively felt afraid of him. I realized most students’ fear of the principal had never diminished.
[1975-09-15 14:20:00] school | I watched this bearded man display the ivory he had retrieved from a shipwreck. I knew the principal was a legendary diver who had discovered a slave ship from 1768. As far as I knew, newspapers and television had reported on his exploits. Among all professions, aside from sailors, I admired divers the most. Having a diver as our principal felt as thrilling as having an astronaut at school. I drew countless pictures of divers and sunken ships—these topics could excite me for weeks.

[1975-09-16 15:30:00] hallway at home | I heard my mom's car drive up the hill, so I immediately ran downstairs to wait for her in the hallway. I watched her walk in tiredly, a handbag slung over her shoulder. I noticed she wasn’t carrying the sports store bag, and my heart sank. I thought, did she really forget to buy the swimming cap?
[1975-09-16 15:31:00] hallway at home | I asked anxiously, "What about the swimming cap you were supposed to buy?" I heard my mother sigh regretfully, blaming herself for forgetting while thinking about other things on her way home from work. I reminded her that the swimming lesson started at six. I felt deeply disappointed because I had specifically reminded her the night before.
[1975-09-16 15:32:00] hallway at home | I watched as my mother glanced at her watch and said she could still make it if she went now, asking me to let Dad know. I nodded at her. I urged her, "Then go quickly!" I heard her say she'd be back in an hour.
[1975-09-16 15:40:00] kitchen | I saw Dad standing in the kitchen with his back turned, frying beef patties, one hand holding a spatula, the other braced against the countertop. I smelled the greasy fumes from cooking in the kitchen. I heard the radio playing and the lid of the pot rattling from steam pressure.
[1975-09-16 15:41:00] kitchen | Dad suddenly turned around and stared at me. I stood frozen on the grass. I called out timidly, "Dad." I heard him ask, "What do you want?" I truthfully relayed Mom's message that she'd be back in an hour. He then asked whether she had come back and left again.
[1975-09-16 15:42:00] kitchen / bedroom | I saw Dad nod toward the direction of my room, so I quickly walked in. I saw clear irritation in his eyes. With the situation uncertain, I didn't dare linger—relieved he let me off so easily.
[1975-09-16 16:40:00] kitchen | I slipped out of my room and sat down at the table. I saw Dad dividing beef patties, potatoes, and carrots onto our plates. We began eating in silence. I sat up straight, not daring to move carelessly, carefully observing all table manners.
[1975-09-16 17:00:00] kitchen / bedroom | After dinner, we said thank you and returned to our rooms. I heard the sound of Dad making coffee in the kitchen. Then I heard him walking downstairs to his office with his cup.
[1975-09-16 17:30:00] bedroom / stairway hallway | I lay in bed listening to sounds outside. I heard the familiar roar of an engine and immediately stood at the landing, waiting. I was absolutely certain that was Mom’s Beetle—I could never mistake that sound. I thought this was the best spot to wait for her, since Dad was in his office downstairs.
[1975-09-16 17:35:00] stairway hallway | I heard the door open, followed by the sounds of boots being removed and a coat hung up. I watched as Mom climbed the stairs. I asked impatiently, "Did you get it? Let me see?" I heard her say everything had gone smoothly.
[1975-09-16 17:36:00] stairway hallway | I saw Mom hand me a white Intersport bag. I opened it and pulled out the swimming cap inside. I protested, "Mom, there are flowers on it! I don’t want one with flowers! This won’t do! It’s a girl’s swimming cap! You bought me a girl’s swimming cap!"
[1975-09-16 17:36:30] stairwell | I stood there, staring down at the floor. I heard Mom ask, "Well, isn't that nice?" I saw it was a white cap with raised plastic embroidery, not printed patterns.
[1975-09-16 17:37:00] stairwell | I insisted to Mom, "You have to exchange it right away. I can't wear this to swimming class. I won't go. I'll stay home." I heard her ask helplessly, "Do you really think it's that bad?"
[1975-09-16 17:38:00] stairwell | I felt tears rolling down my cheeks. I heard Mom say, "You used to love going to swimming lessons. Does it really matter if there are some flowers on the hat? We'll buy a new one next time." I heard Mom say she needed a swim cap and thought the flowers looked nice.
[1975-09-16 17:38:30] stairwell | I almost shouted, "You don't understand anything—it's not okay! This is a girl's swim cap!" I heard Mom sigh, saying she thought I was being unreasonable.
[1975-09-16 17:39:00] stairwell | I saw the door to Dad's office open, and he stepped onto the landing halfway up the stairs. I quickly wiped my eyes and put the cap back into the bag. I heard Dad ask, "What's going on?" I realized Dad always knew exactly when something was wrong, especially at moments like this.
[1975-09-16 17:40:00] stairwell | I saw Dad walk up the stairs and lift my chin with his hand. I heard Mom explain that I didn't like the swim cap she'd bought, so I was throwing a tantrum and refusing to go swimming. I heard Dad snap, "Nonsense!"
[1975-09-16 17:41:00] stairwell | I wiped under my eyes with my hand. I heard Dad order, "Take the swim cap your mother bought and go to swimming class. Understand? Don't cry over something so trivial. You look pathetic. Go back to your room." I mumbled, "Understood," "Yes."
[1975-09-16 17:45:00] bedroom / kitchen | I did as he said, walked into my room and waited for departure. I heard Dad say to Mom, "You went all the way back into town just to buy this." Mom explained it was because I had been so excited about swimming, and she'd forgotten earlier.
[1975-09-16 18:30:00] hallway at home | I followed Mom downstairs, put on my boots and raincoat. In my hand I carried the plastic bag containing my swimsuit and that hat. I decided not to speak to her anymore—not a single word.
[1975-09-16 18:31:00] doorway | I opened the door and saw Karl Larsdal and Toya Moen standing outside, holding plastic bags. We hurried together along the gravel path. Before me lay the gloomy night, the air filled with fine misty rain. I saw their raincoats glistening under the porch light. I felt the outside world was eerie, somewhat frightening.
[1975-09-16 18:32:00] beside the car | I saw Mom and her companions greeting each other. Mom opened the car door, and we children climbed into the back seats. null null null null
[1975-09-16 18:33:00] inside the car | I saw Mom start the engine, and the car reversed uphill to turn around. I heard Toya Moen ask, 'Something wrong with the exhaust muffler?' Mom replied, 'Yes, it's an old car.' null null null
[1975-09-16 18:35:00] inside the car | I sat in the seat directly behind Dad. I said, 'Karl Larsdal can swim.' I heard Mom respond, 'How nice!' I saw the windshield wipers slowly moving across the front window. The headlights illuminated the dark pine trees along the roadside. null I suddenly realized I shouldn't have spoken to Mom. I noticed that unless I leaned sideways, Dad couldn't see me in the mirror.
[1975-09-16 18:36:00] inside the car | I saw Mom glance briefly to the right, then turn onto the main road, repeating the same motion at the next intersection. She raised the turn signal lever to indicate a left turn. I heard Mom ask, 'So, Toya Moen, have you learned swimming completely?' null null null
[1975-09-16 18:40:00] inside the car / on the bridge | I saw the red lights atop the bridge posts flashing in the night. The car was driving upward toward the bridge. I heard Toya Moen shake his head and say, 'Only a little.' A loud engine roar filled my ears, bouncing back from the cliff walls. null I thought those red lights looked like burning flames—someone unfamiliar would surely believe they were floating in midair.
[1975-09-16 18:41:00] inside the car | null null The car drove onto the bridge. I saw how the darkness of the heavy rain merged the coves and hills into one. Distant lights resembled stars scattered across the sky. null I noticed a unique reflection on the water’s surface, distinguishing it from the deep darkness of the land.
[1975-09-16 18:42:00] inside the car / on the bridge | null null I saw the car enter a fork—one side leading to a residential area, the other to factories. Under the headlights, the yellow factory buildings looked empty through the curtain of rain. null null
[1975-09-16 18:43:00] inside the car / on the road | null I heard Toya Moen say that Helen Sterne mentioned the teacher was very strict. The rain grew heavier; the windshield wipers worked busily. null I remembered Helen Stimson was a liar, and felt he was deliberately trying to scare Toya Moen.
[1975-09-16 18:45:00] inside the car | I saw Karl Larsdal showing me his blue-lensed Speedo goggles. I said although I didn’t have goggles, I could still see underwater. I heard Toya Moen ask, 'What about a swim cap?' Karl laughed and said he wore his dad’s, which was a bit too big. null null null
[1975-09-16 18:46:00] inside the car | I saw Mom lift her arm to check her watch. I heard Toya Moen ask if my dad had a swim cap. I answered, 'I don’t think so.' I also asked Mom if we were running late, and heard her reply, 'Five thirty-five—it's plenty of time.' null null null
[1975-09-16 18:47:00] in the car | I saw Karl Larsdal talking. I heard Karl say, "Next time I want a white swimming cap with the national flag on it—Dad promised me today." He also said he wanted to join the city's swimming club once he learned how. I curiously asked, "Then we won't be able to play football together anymore?"
[1975-09-16 18:48:00] in the car | I saw Mom drive the car onto a gravel road and stop in front of a dark building. I heard Mom point ahead and say, "I think it's just up there." Toya Moen also said that Thomas and Karlsen had already arrived.
[1975-09-16 18:49:00] in the car | I grabbed my bag and climbed out of the car, running toward the entrance. I heard Mom say she’d pick us up in an hour and wished us good luck. I heard the Beetle turn around and drive away.
locations: inside the car / on the bridge
inside the car / on the road

text:
[1975-09-16 18:50:00] outside the swimming hall | I saw five boys sitting in the changing room, taking off their clothes. They laughed and greeted us. I saw Karin Ingrid and her friends walking toward the showers. I heard Karin Ingrid say, "The water in the pool is so cold!" Toya Moen curiously asked if they had tried it already. Green floors, white walls, and harsh lighting from the ceiling met my eyes.
[1975-09-16 18:51:00] outside the swimming hall | I sat down on a bench and took off my sweater and pants. I caught a faint, pleasant smell of chlorine. I thought I really loved swimming pools.
[1975-09-16 19:00:00] changing room | I watched the other boys standing naked under the showers. I took out soap and a towel from my bag and got ready to go in. I knew there was a strict rule requiring everyone to shower before entering the pool.
[1975-09-16 19:05:00] changing room | I saw the boys carefully turning their shoulders toward the showerheads. I saw them standing with their backs against the wall, hair wet and clinging to their foreheads. I saw them cautiously feeling the water flow as if facing a wild beast.
[1975-09-16 19:06:00] changing room / shower room | I took off my underwear and folded my clothes neatly on the bench. I saw Helen Ster come in with a few others. I didn’t like standing naked while others were still dressed, so I quickly stepped into the shower. I was glad Karl and the others followed in right after me.
[1975-09-16 19:07:00] shower room | I turned off the faucet, dried myself, and walked back to the changing room to put on my swimsuit. I felt the warm mist from the showerheads fill the room. I noticed my buttocks had turned red like a monkey’s after the hot spray. I thought this cozy feeling could go on forever. But I realized the redness might easily invite mockery, so I had to get dressed quickly.
[1975-09-16 19:10:00] changing room / shower room | I sat on the bench for a while, watching as everyone gradually came out of the shower. I remembered Dad once joked that I had a 'sticking-out bottom.' I worried others might notice and talk about it—it mattered deeply to me.
[1975-09-16 19:15:00] shower room | I saw the group of boys, their damp hair making their skin look especially pale. I sat on the bench, rubbing hard at the goosebumps on my arms. The air was icy cold. I noticed the marks left by swimsuits standing out clearly on their pale skin. I tried to find the pleasure brought by chlorine, but it seemed to have vanished.
[1975-09-16 19:20:00] shower room / changing room | I saw the lights come on in the pool. The boys in the changing room hurriedly pulled on swim trunks and put on goggles. I heard someone shout: 'It's starting!' Through the crack in the door, I saw the swimming hall brightly lit up.
[1975-09-16 19:21:00] changing room | I crumpled my swimming cap into a ball and gripped it in my hand. I followed Karl Larsdal into the swimming hall and saw the girls emerging from the other side as well. I heard the teacher, a whistle hanging around her neck, wave to us.
[1975-09-16 19:25:00] changing room | I saw the teacher blow her whistle again. I watched the last few boys run out laughing. I heard the teacher shout: 'No running! Running is absolutely not allowed here. It's slippery, and the floor is hard.'
[1975-09-16 19:26:00] changing room | I saw the teacher holding a list inside a plastic folder. I heard her say: 'Welcome to swimming class! Since it's your first time today, we'll start with free play, then move over to the mats for basic drills.'
[1975-09-16 19:28:00] changing room / swimming hall | I heard Karin Ingrid ask: 'On these? Are we supposed to learn swimming on land?' I heard the teacher confirm yes, and then double-check whether everyone had taken a shower.
[1975-09-16 19:30:00] swimming hall | I heard the teacher restate the rules: caps must be worn, no diving, and no pushing others underwater. We could only enter the pool using the ladder over there. I heard her say: 'Every time I blow the whistle, you come straight to me. Understood?' Everyone answered in unison: 'Understood.'

text:

[1975-09-20 09:32:10] in front of the Jacobsen house | I heard his mother tell him, "Put on your raincoat."
[1975-09-20 09:33:00] in front of the Jacobsen house | I saw Thomas run back inside to get his raincoat, while Karl and I waited quietly outside. The rain had just stopped.
