[1975-09-20 09:38:20] outside Oskar Magnus's house | I heard all three of us shouting at the top of our lungs: "Toya Moen! Come out!"
[1975-09-20 09:39:00] Outside Oskar Magnus's house | I saw the kitchen window slide open, and his mother leaned out. I heard her say, 'He'll be right there. Coming just in a raincoat. Stop shouting now.'
[1975-09-20 09:39:10] Outside Oskar Magnus's house | I pictured the three-legged black iron pot in my mind, surely filled with gold and jewels. I thought that since the rainbow was fading fast, we had to act without delay. Remembering past failed treasure hunts, I felt determined to move quickly this time.
[1975-09-20 09:40:00] Outside Oskar Magnus's house | I saw a shadow pass behind the glass of the door, then it opened. I felt a wave of heat hit my face—he always kept his house so warm. text:

In the distance, the low concrete bridge and Ybe Bay were clearly visible. I thought there couldn't be a better viewing spot than this.
[1975-09-20 09:56:00] mountaintop | I noticed the sky above the residential area had almost turned blue, while the clouds toward the city were snow-white. But on the other side, the clouds behind Ybe Bay remained dark and heavy.
[1975-09-20 09:57:00] mountaintop | I saw my father below, now just a tiny black dot standing at the top rung of the ladder leaning against the roof. He looked no bigger than an ant to me.
[1975-09-20 09:57:10] mountaintop | I felt a wind blowing in from deep out at sea. I wondered in my mind whether he could see me up here on the mountaintop now.
[1975-09-20 10:00:00] mountaintop woods | I turned around looking for my friends. I saw two yellow patches and one blue patch moving among the trees. I noticed a log lying across the path that looked strangely shaped. The high ridge of the peak appeared blackish-gray with hints of yellow. A horizontal log was supported by slender branches, not touching the ground, seeming utterly still.
[1975-09-20 10:05:00] mountaintop woods | On the slope below, I saw nothing growing except heather; tall pines and spruces surrounded the place like walls, forming a room-like enclosure. I knew that before, I'd never gone farther than the uprooted tree. I remembered Karl Larsdal once saying he'd seen a fox. I realized I wasn't really brave enough to go deeper into these woods. I thought you shouldn't take foxes lightly, so I'd brought food with me when I left home.
[1975-09-20 10:06:00] mountaintop woods | I heard Toya Moen scream: "Here! My God! Treasure!" Then Karl shouted too: "My God!" I called back doubtfully: "Don't fool me!"
[1975-09-20 10:06:10] mountaintop woods | I heard Tova shout: "Haha! We're rich!" Thomas Linddal also exclaimed: "Good Lord!"
[1975-09-20 10:06:20] mountaintop woods | I suspected they were tricking me, but thinking about where the rainbow had touched down, I began wondering: what if the treasure pot hadn't vanished along with the rainbow?
[1975-09-20 10:07:00] mountaintop woods | I took a few steps forward, trying to peer through the juniper and cloudberry bushes to see what they were doing.
[1975-09-20 10:07:10] mountain-top woods | I heard Toya Moen shout at me, "Hey! Look at this!"
[1975-09-20 10:08:00] mountain-top woods | I rushed through the bushes toward them. I saw them burst into laughter as they looked at me. I heard them mock me: "You fell for it! Hahaha! You fell for it!"
[1975-09-20 10:08:10] mountain-top woods | I shouted defensively, "I knew all along you were tricking me—I just came to call you." Toya Moen laughed back, "No way. You totally fell for it." I urged them that if they didn't hurry up, the real rainbow would disappear.
[1975-09-20 10:10:00] cliff edge | I called on Karl to prepare to head down the mountain. I heard Toya Moen suggest having a pissing contest at the cliff's edge. I said to Karl, "Come on, let's go down there and find the treasure." I heard Toya say he needed to take a piss and wanted to see who could pee the farthest. I saw that Karl, though reluctant, still followed me. I thought he really was my best friend.
[1975-09-20 10:10:10] cliff edge | I saw my friends pulling down their rain pants to get ready for the contest. I stared at their wriggling buttocks. I remembered my father was still below—if he looked up and saw us peeing right now, it would be terrible.
[1975-09-20 10:10:20] cliff edge | I refused, "I don't have to pee—I just went."
[1975-09-20 10:10:30] cliff edge | I saw Karl Larsdal turn his head to stare at me, his penis still in hand. I heard Karl say suspiciously, "You didn't pee—we've been together all day." I insisted I had gone while looking for treasure.
[1975-09-20 10:11:00] cliff edge | I stepped forward a few paces to inspect the results of the contest. I watched Karl tuck his little 'elephant trunk' back into his pants. I heard Toya boast about his brother's pissing skills. Then I heard Karl say regretfully, "The rainbow's gone." I saw the urine they'd sprayed rising in steaming vapor in the cold air. I noticed Thomas Linddal had actually peed the farthest.
[1975-09-20 10:12:00] cliff edge | We all looked down the mountain together. I heard Thomas ask, "What should we do now?" Toya echoed him, equally lost.
[1975-09-20 10:12:10] cliff edge | I suggested, "Let's go to the boathouse down below? We can climb onto the roof." Toya Moen immediately chimed in excitedly.

[1975-09-29 08:13:10] Ingeborg Lofnes's front door | I heard her greet us, "Hi!"
[1975-09-29 08:13:20] Ingeborg Lofnes's front door | I told her, "We thought you were sick."
[1975-09-29 08:13:30] Ingeborg Lofnes's front door | I heard Karl add, "We brought your homework."
[1975-09-29 08:13:40] Ingeborg Lofnes's front door | I looked her over carefully. I saw she was wearing a white turtleneck sweater with red patterns and blue pants. I noticed a faint smear of white milk residue just above her lip.
[1975-09-29 08:14:00] Ingeborg Lofnes's front door | I heard her ask eagerly, "So, can you go out and play with me? I've been stuck at home all day!"
[1975-09-29 08:14:10] Ingeborg Lofnes's doorstep | I looked at Karl to ask for his opinion. I readily agreed, saying, "Sure, what do you say, Karl Larsdal?"
[1975-09-29 08:14:20] Ingeborg Lofnes's doorstep | I heard Karl reply firmly, "Yes."
locations: front door / outside Karl Larsdal's house
In front of Ingeborg Lofnes's house

text:
[1975-09-29 08:15:00] Football field / Wide path | Laughing and shouting, we crossed the muddy football field and stepped onto a broader dirt road. I saw the ground covered by a thick blanket of fallen leaves, with yellow, red, and brown hues woven together. Long, grayish-yellow grass lay limp on the soil. I noticed occasional faint green glimmers peeking through the leaves.
[1975-09-29 08:15:00] Ingeborg Lofnes's doorstep | I saw her putting on her white boots and red raincoat, and I saw her mother walking up the stairs.
[1975-09-29 08:15:10] Ingeborg Lofnes's doorstep | I saw her bounce out the door, and we started joyfully hopping around too. I heard her call out to her mom, "Bye!"
[1975-09-29 08:16:00] Gravel path | I saw her suddenly turn toward us at the end of the gravel path. I heard her ask, "What should we do? Shall we go down to Lilund's?"
[1975-09-29 08:20:00] Below the cliff | I saw old utility poles standing against the bare cliff face. Below was a quiet oak forest, and about a hundred meters deep into it, I spotted the wreckage of an old, battered car. As far as I knew, that car was in much worse condition than the ones we usually played with. I knew the place was so secluded that almost no one ever went there.
[1975-09-29 08:20:00] Outside Lilund's house | We went to Lilund's house. Karl and I held the rubber band while watching them skillfully jumping in the middle. I heard Ingeborg suggest playing rubber band jumping. I learned that their technique in rubber band jumping was flawless; their complex moves left me dazzled.
[1975-09-29 08:25:00] At the wrecked car | I smelled the musty odor of the old car wreckage in the damp woods. I saw the detached window frames hanging down like tentacles, and glass shards scattered across the rubber mat like tiny diamonds. I felt that although this stale smell was strong, compared to the scent of rotting leaves, it somehow seemed a bit 'fresh'.
[1975-09-29 08:26:00] At the wrecked car | I reached out and shook the black rubber mat, seeing a swarm of crawling insects scatter in panic. I saw spiders and woodlice fleeing in alarm. I noticed that all three pedals inside the driver’s cabin had completely failed.
[1975-09-29 08:27:00] wreckage of an abandoned car | I felt water droplets shaken loose by the wind pass through the broken window and strike my face. I thought these droplets were probably shaken from nearby leaves by the wind.
[1975-09-29 08:28:00] wreckage of an abandoned car | As far as I know, we once found beer bottles, pornographic magazines, and various discarded plastic barrels nearby. I clearly remember finding a pair of underwear covered in filth one time. Thinking about how someone would just throw soiled underwear there, my friends and I couldn't stop laughing back then.
[1975-09-29 08:29:00] woods | I saw that the feces in the woods were sometimes surrounded by beetles or flies. I know we often defecated during our hikes, choosing spots beneath trees, along cliffs, or beside streams. I learned it was merely to observe the changes and colors of our waste. I was curious about how the feces glistened among the heather, wondering what they might feel like.
[1975-09-29 08:30:00] woods | I know we occasionally returned to check old 'outposts.' Sometimes they were gone, sometimes dried up or softened. I learned that outdoor feces had an especially pungent smell. I noticed how those excretions spread out in the forest looked almost melted.
[1975-09-29 08:30:00] outside Lilund's house | I saw Ingeborg Lofnes walk toward me to demonstrate the movement, and I felt her hand rest on my shoulder. The moment she touched me, I felt a jolt like electricity ripple through my entire body.
[1975-09-29 08:35:00] playground hillside | We crossed the playground, climbed the steep slope, and stepped over the stone blocks. I saw the rusted swings and the rotting empty sandbox below the hill. Across the road, Rockhaug Supermarket came into view. I realized it was time for school—I didn’t have any more time to linger.
[1975-09-29 08:35:00] outside Lilund's house | When I did the movement wrong, I saw her burst into laughter at me, and I felt a strand of her hair brush past my face. I heard her clear, bright laughter. I gazed into her dark, shining eyes and caught the fresh scent of her hair. I was immersed in the sensory impact she created within me.
[1975-09-29 08:36:00] outside Lilund's house | I sincerely felt that everything was simply too wonderful. At that moment, everything around me seemed utterly perfect.
[1975-09-29 08:40:00] in front of Rockhaug Supermarket | I searched everywhere for Ingeborg’s figure. I saw the backpack line at the supermarket entrance stretching long, and several girls jumping rope under the eaves. A steady light rain was falling. Not finding her there, I couldn’t help but feel a deep sense of disappointment.
[1975-09-29 08:40:00] outside Lilund's house | I saw the sky above grow thick and dark, with a blackish-blue hue seeping through the gray clouds. The sky hanging over the woods resembled a wall, and then, I felt the first drops of rain fall.
[1975-09-29 08:45:00] bus | I saw the bus drive up the hill. I noticed Karl Larsdal and Toya Moen hopping across the street, arriving just in time at the meeting point. Finally, I boarded the bus with everyone else and sat in the very last seat. I watched as the vehicle turned into the asphalt square outside the supermarket.
[1975-09-29 08:45:00] outside Lilund's house | I pulled the hood of my raincoat over my head and continued jumping rope with my friends. I saw the light atop the post at the end of the driveway suddenly turn on. I felt raindrops hitting my hood and trickling down my cheeks. I heard the gravel beneath my feet crunching underfoot.
[1975-09-29 08:50:00] bus | I stepped inside and knelt on the seat, looking back toward the rear. I saw a thick layer of mist forming on the large glass windows. I realized Ingeborg wasn't there. I felt as though the world had become incomplete, as if everything had lost its meaning.
[1975-09-29 08:50:00] outside Lilund's house | I saw a car slowly drive up the hill. I heard Ingeborg Lofnes say, "That's Dad!"
[1975-09-29 08:51:00] Ingeborg Lofnes's driveway | I saw a Volvo station wagon come to a stop at the far end of the driveway. I noticed a tall, strong man with a black beard step out. I watched as Ingeborg ran toward him, and he bent down to embrace her before they both went inside the house.
[1975-09-29 08:52:00] Ingeborg Lofnes's front door | I heard her ask, "Now we're going to have dinner—what's the homework?"
[1975-09-29 08:53:00] Ingeborg Lofnes's front door | I saw her nod at me, then disappear into the house. I told her the homework assignment, and I heard her say goodbye to me.
[1975-09-29 08:54:00] outside Lilund's house | I saw Lilund standing there, gathering and coiling up the rubber rope. I heard Lilund say, "I have to go now too." I noticed a hint of disappointment in her eyes.
[1975-09-29 08:54:10] outside Lilund's house | I replied, "We're leaving too."
[1975-09-29 08:55:00] bus | I thought that now I would have to spend an entire day without seeing her—and the next day too. I realized that because I hadn't seen Lilund, I had no way of knowing how her illness was progressing.
[1975-09-29 08:56:00] crossroads / store | I ran to the store together with Karl Larsdal. When I arrived at the crossroads, I suggested, "Let's keep running all the way to the store."
[1975-09-29 09:00:00] school | I saw the car parked outside the school. I ran across the playground and waited under the shelter. After the class bell rang, I lined up and followed everyone into the classroom.
[1975-09-29 09:00:00] ring road | I followed Karl Larsdal along a path, over a small hill, and onto the ring road. I heard Karl suggest that instead of going home the same way we came or through the woods, we should walk down the main road to Holt and then follow the ring road back home.

[1975-09-29 09:05:00] school | I knew the students from the parallel class felt superior to us because they were locals who knew everything about the place. As far as I could tell, it was their school and their teachers. I realized that to them, we were just some kind of unauthorized immigrants. I felt I had already become fairly familiar with the appearance and rumors surrounding most people in the class.
[1975-09-29 09:05:00] ring road | I walked along the road, absentmindedly glanced back, and was startled to see Henrik Inge sitting in the window of a bus just a few meters behind me! I saw the bus driving downhill. I was full of suspicion: What on earth was he up to? Why was he going into town now? What was he doing there?
[1975-09-29 09:05:10] ring road | I kept turning it over in my mind—why was he going into town at this time, and what exactly was he planning to do?
[1975-09-29 09:05:20] ring road | I said to Karl Larsdal, "That's Henrik Inge—he's sitting in the bus."
[1975-09-29 09:06:00] main road | I crossed the lawn in front of a house and stepped onto the main road. I heard Karl Larsdal say, uninterested, "Oh, really."
[1975-09-29 09:07:00] main road | I heard Karl say, "It was really fun up there." I replied, "Yes, shall we go back up again sometime?"
[1975-09-29 09:08:00] main road | I heard Karl say, "Okay, but maybe we shouldn't tell anyone else about it? They're girls, after all." I responded, "No, no need to tell anyone now."
[1975-09-29 09:10:00] school | I learned that the boys living on the east side of the island were rougher and more prone to fighting than us. As far as I knew, apart from Asle Karl Larsdal and Helen Ster, the rest of us were often pushed and pulled around at their whim. I recalled the feeling of suddenly having an arm lock around my neck and being thrown to the ground, and I still felt a lingering fear.
[1975-09-29 09:10:00] top of the hill | I looked down from the top of the hill and saw my dad's car parked outside the house. I also noticed that Karl Larsdal's father had already come home. I knew they were both teachers, so they finished work earlier than most other parents.
[1975-09-29 09:10:10] top of the hill | I thought again about that plan to climb through the window using the trash can.
[1975-09-29 09:11:00] top of the hill | I suggested, "Should we find something else to do? Go somewhere else? Down to that shaky tree over there?"
[1975-09-29 09:12:00] top of the hill | I saw Karl Larsdal shake his head and heard him say, "It's raining. And I'm hungry. I'm going home." I politely replied, "OK, see you."
[1975-09-29 09:13:00] outside Karl Larsdal's house | I watched Karl Larsdal run toward his house. I heard him slam the door shut, making the glass in it tremble. I heard him say, "Bye."
[1975-09-29 09:14:00] on the road | I looked toward Oskar Magnus's house. I saw the light on in their kitchen. I wondered whether they had already come home or if only their father was there. I realized I couldn't tell by whether a car was parked outside, since they had a garage.
[1975-09-29 09:15:00] school | While playing football, I felt someone suddenly step hard on my toes—excruciating pain. I'd also seen Asle or Helen defend themselves by fighting back directly. I knew that people often faced rough treatment on the way to class. From what I'd heard, some liked pressing their fists into others' shoulders. I realized that Asle and Helen had already learned how not to be bullied anymore.
[1975-09-29 09:15:00] on the road | I turned and looked up the slope. I saw Marianne's father toss a tied plastic bag into the trash can. I saw he was wearing a knitted jacket and had an unshaven face. I knew he was a sailor who spent most of the year working away. From what I'd heard, once he returned home, he never left the house. I noticed he always seemed angry, but in truth, I didn't know anything about him.
[1975-09-29 09:15:10] on the road | I watched him close the door, completely unaware of my presence.
[1975-09-29 09:16:00] crossroads | I saw a massive yellow truck loaded with stones drive past the crossroads. I felt the ground tremble as the vehicle passed. I saw thick smoke billowing from its front exhaust pipe.
[1975-09-29 09:17:00] on the road | I heard Henrik Inge tell me this was a special vehicle from the Apollo space program used to transport rockets, moving extremely slowly, like a giant snail. I knew my brother had once shown me a photo of the world's largest heavy-duty truck. As far as I knew, this truck was specifically designed to carry rockets to the launch site.
[1975-09-29 09:18:00] on the road | I understood that during the initial phase of a rocket launch, it ascended extremely slowly. I knew that when flames and smoke burst out, a thunderous roar could be heard even kilometers away. I recalled countless photos I'd seen in a book about spaceflight. I had expected the rocket to shoot off at incredible speed, but in the actual images, it initially seemed to waver, almost resting in midair.
[1975-09-29 09:19:00] on the road | I knew the rocket would eventually surge toward the blue sky at an insane speed. A magnificent image flashed through my mind: it shot upward like an arrow or a beam of light, piercing the clouds.
[1975-09-29 09:20:00] school | I saw the boys from the east wearing clothes that looked like hand-me-downs passed down through several older brothers. I knew the boys from the east dressed differently from us. I was aware that Karl and I were both deeply worried our secret spot might be discovered by them. I thought that as long as we posted a lookout, there probably wouldn't be a serious problem. I kept observing those kids whose clothing was so different from ours.
[1975-09-29 09:20:00] on the road | I often pictured a scene in my mind: a rocket secretly launching from behind a mountain peak, slowly rising above the forest, and finally the roar of its engines echoing between our houses.
[1975-09-29 09:20:10] on the road | I silently judged it to be a rather good idea.
[1975-09-29 09:25:00] home | I jogged back home, walking across the gravel yard. I opened the door and, while taking off my shoes on the mat, saw Dad coming out from the office hallway.
[1975-09-29 09:25:10] home | I quickly glanced at him. I sensed he didn’t seem particularly angry at the moment.
[1975-09-29 09:26:00] home | I heard Dad ask, “Where have you been?” I replied, “Playing with Karl Larsdal.”
[1975-09-29 09:27:00] home | I kept my eyes fixed on the floor. I heard Dad correct me, 'That's not what I'm asking. Where did you go?' I explained, 'We were up at the Rockhaug supermarket, behind it.'
[1975-09-29 09:28:00] home | I heard him ask, 'Is that so? What were you doing there?' I answered vaguely, 'Nothing special, just playing.'
[1975-09-29 09:29:00] home | I heard Dad command, 'You go back there again. We need potatoes. Do you think you can go buy some potatoes?' I replied firmly, 'Yes.'
[1975-09-29 09:30:00] classroom | I heard the school bell ring, and we gathered into lines. I saw the female teacher walk stiffly to the top of the stairs. I marched into the classroom in line, hung my raincoat on the hook, and immediately sat down at my desk. I felt that the classroom was the safest place—only there could I feel that we were a close-knit group.
[1975-09-29 09:30:00] home | I saw Dad pull his wallet from his back pocket and take out a banknote. I heard Dad say, 'Let me see your pockets.'
[1975-09-29 09:31:00] home | I stood up and turned my hips toward him. I felt him slide the banknote into my pocket. I heard Dad instruct, 'Put it in your pants pocket and go quickly.' I responded, 'Okay.'
[1975-09-29 09:32:00] on the path | I saw him return to his office. I put my shoes back on, carefully closed the door, and started running uphill.

[1975-09-29 09:35:00] classroom | I heard someone in class discussing who was sick—mentioning Ingeborg, Lilund, and Vemund being absent today. I heard Karl Larsdal add, 'And Toya Moen too.'
[1975-09-29 09:35:10] classroom | Hearing Toya Moen's name, the events of the previous night immediately flashed through my mind.
[1975-09-29 09:36:00] classroom | I heard Kristine Lof mock, 'Vemund's got a screw loose!' Then came a burst of laughter around me.
[1975-09-29 09:37:00] classroom | I heard the teacher maintain order by saying, "Alright, alright, that's enough talking. In this classroom, we don't speak ill of others. At least not behind their backs!"
[1975-09-29 09:38:00] classroom | I loudly declared, "Toya Moen's father got drunk yesterday! My mom had to drive them over to relatives. That's why he's not here today!"
[1975-09-29 09:39:00] classroom | I saw the teacher put her finger to her lips and shake her head at me. Then I noticed she wrote something down in her notebook before turning her gaze back to the whole class. I heard the teacher shush me.
[1975-09-29 09:40:00] classroom | I heard her ask from up front, "Are there any other absences? None? Then let's begin."
[1975-09-29 09:45:00] classroom | I saw the teacher step forward and sit on the edge of the lectern. I heard her announce that this week we would be learning about farms, and she asked if any of us had ever been to one.
[1975-09-29 09:45:10] classroom | I raised my arm as high as possible, eager to the point of nearly standing up. I kept shouting, "Me, me, me! I've been to one!"
[1975-09-29 09:46:00] classroom | I realized I wasn't the only one eager to speak. I saw the teacher finally point to Karl Larsdal B., instead of calling my name.
[1975-09-29 09:46:10] classroom | I heard him answer, "I rode a horse at Legoland."
[1975-09-29 09:46:20] classroom | I protested, "That's not even a farm! I've been to real farms many times—my grandparents...
[1975-09-29 09:47:00] classroom | I lowered my head somewhat dejectedly. I heard the teacher ask sternly, "Was it your turn to speak, Grete Lundnes?" I quietly replied, "No."
[1975-09-29 09:48:00] classroom | I heard the teacher continue, "That's right, Legoland isn't a farm. And horses belong on farms—that's correct. Winnie?"
[1975-09-29 09:48:10] classroom | I turned around curiously to look for Winnie. Before me was a slightly plump girl with light hair, giggling softly. I wondered to myself: Winnie—who is that?
[1975-09-29 09:49:00] classroom | I heard her say, blushing, "I live on a farm, but we don't have animals. We grow vegetables. Then my dad sells them at the market in town."
[1975-09-29 09:50:00] classroom | I argued loudly, "I've been to a farm with animals!" Then I heard Karin Ingrid and Marivik·Kristian chime in too: "Me too!" "And me!"
[1975-09-29 09:51:00] classroom | I heard the teacher stop us, saying, "Wait until it's your turn to speak—everyone will get a chance."
[1975-09-29 10:00:00] classroom | Seeing that the teacher had finally called on me after five others, I lowered my hand. I began speaking excitedly, "My grandmother and grandfather have a farm. It's big, with two cows and a calf, and lots of chickens. I often go with them to collect eggs, and in the morning I watch my grandfather milk the cows. He first clears away the manure and gives them some hay. Sometimes the cows even lift their tails and pee or poop."
[1975-09-29 10:01:00] classroom | I sat in my seat, feeling my face grow hot and red. I continued, shocking everyone, "Once, a cow peed on me!" I felt waves of laughter crashing over me.
[1975-09-29 10:02:00] classroom | I looked around and saw my classmates burst into another round of loud laughter. I noticed the teacher remained silent, letting me keep talking, but I could keenly sense she didn't actually believe me.
[1975-09-29 11:50:00] classroom | I saw the teacher begin reading a story after everyone had spoken. I noticed she completely ignored me when asking questions, only calling me to stay behind after the bell rang.
[1975-09-29 11:51:00] classroom | I heard her say to me, "Grete Lundnes, wait here—I'd like to talk to you."
[1975-09-29 11:52:00] classroom | I watched as the other students ran out of the classroom, leaving me standing alone beside the teacher's desk. I saw the teacher sitting on the edge of the desk, staring at me.
[1975-09-29 11:53:00] classroom | I heard her teach me: "Just because we know everything about someone else doesn't mean we should go and tell it. For example, what you said about Toya Moen's father. Don't you think Toya Moen would feel sad about that?"
[1975-09-29 11:53:10] classroom | I lowered my head and replied: "He would."
[1975-09-29 11:54:00] classroom | I couldn't help but start crying. I heard her explain: "This is called personal privacy. You don't know what that is?" I sobbed and answered: "No."
[1975-09-29 11:55:00] classroom | I heard her continue explaining: "Privacy means everything that happens inside a home. If someone sees what happens in another person's house and then spreads it around, that's never quite right. Do you understand?"
[1975-09-29 11:55:10] classroom | I silently nodded my head.
[1975-09-29 11:56:00] classroom | I heard her comfort me: "There, there, Grete Lundnes. Don't be upset. You didn't know. Now you do! That's all. Go on now, go outside."
[1975-09-29 12:00:00] schoolyard | I quickly ran out through the corridor and into the schoolyard. I stopped and swept my eyes across every group gathered there. Before me lay the lively schoolyard; I saw girls jumping rope, playing elastic games, and chasing each other playfully.
[1975-09-29 12:05:00] school football field | I looked down at the football field and saw a group gathered near the goalposts playing ball. I noticed the center of the field was almost entirely filled with murky yellow puddles of mud.
[1975-09-29 12:10:00] schoolyard | I headed toward Karl Larsdal, Karlsen, and Kristine Lof by the bench. I noticed they were huddled together playing cards.
[1975-09-29 12:11:00] school playground | I shook my head at them. I heard Kristine Lof ask, "You've been crying, haven't you?" I brushed it off: "No, it was the wind." Then I asked what the teacher had said and suggested I could join their card game too.
[1975-09-29 12:11:10] school playground | I heard Kristine Lof repeat firmly: "You *have* been crying."
[1975-09-29 12:15:00] school | I knew that Karin, Kristine, and I were the top students in class. I understood that Kristine was strongest in math, while I excelled in reading and writing. As far as I knew, I ranked 7th in physical ability and 4th in football. I clearly remembered being nearly last in throwing the small ball—only Vemund was behind me. I mentally weighed everyone's strengths and weaknesses, musing that although I was tall and good at drawing, I truly wasn't as strong as most others.
[1975-09-29 12:20:00] school playground | I insisted, "Sand blew into my eye when I walked down the stairs—that's all. I didn't cry. Can I have a card, please?"
[1975-09-29 12:25:00] school playground | I reached out and drew the first card. I saw it was the French S/S—a real ocean liner. I thought with quiet delight: this is the largest passenger ship in the world; I knew this card would beat everyone else's.
[1975-09-29 13:00:00] classroom | I carefully wrote the letters over and over in my notebook. I knew today’s lesson focused on the 'u' in 'cow,' the 'a' in 'sheep,' and the 'å' in 'goose.' I learned that the homework was to copy these letters in our notebooks.
[1975-09-29 13:30:00] classroom | I heard the teacher ask if anyone lived near the homes of the classmates who were absent today.
[1975-09-29 14:00:00] indoor gym | I ran lap after lap around the indoor gym. It suddenly occurred to me—I could use this chance to go to Ingeborg Lofnes’s house and tell her the homework!
[1975-09-29 14:05:00] indoor gym | At the thought of going to see her, I felt warmth spreading through my whole body, a mix of joy and nervousness stirring in my chest.

[1975-09-29 14:50:00] school / meeting point | I quickly dressed and rushed out of the changing room. I headed toward the meeting point and told Karl Larsdal about my plan along the way. I heard Karl wrinkle his nose and question why we should go out of our way to visit girls whose homes we'd never been to. I shot back: "You don't understand anything—the whole point is that we go ourselves!" I was solely focused on seeing Ingeborg, completely dismissing Karl's concerns.
[1975-09-29 15:00:00] meeting point | I kept pleading with Karl. I noticed that in the end, he finally nodded and agreed to come with me. I saw that he held his ground at first, but eventually gave in to my persuasion.
[1975-09-29 15:15:00] bus / on the road | I stood on the sidewalk, watching the bus struggle up the hill. I noticed its exhaust fumes spreading across the asphalt. Before me was the sight of a large bus slowly winding through narrow streets, almost like a passenger vessel on a canal. The sound of its labored engine filled my ears. It felt a bit strange to me that the bus would drive directly into the residential area to drop us off.
[1975-09-29 15:20:00] driveway | I stepped onto my own driveway. I looked around and made sure no one was there. I asked Karl, 'Should I go up, or will you come down?' When he told me to go up, I cheerfully replied, 'OK.' I felt that this quiet environment came naturally to me.
[1975-09-29 15:21:00] front door | I walked up to my front door. I looked down at the shovel leaning against the wall, noticing droplets of water trembling on its handle. Before me was a damp scene. I saw the dark brown walls of the house streaked with black water stains, and puddles filling the uneven bricks in front of the door. Though the rain had stopped, the air remained heavy with moisture.
[1975-09-29 15:22:00] front door | I unzipped my coat and pulled out the key, trying to turn it. But I found that once inserted into the lock, it was completely stuck—immovable. I had hoped today might be the day it finally worked, but once again, I was disappointed.
[1975-09-29 15:23:00] by the yard fence | I glanced warily around to make sure no one was watching. I went to the trash can by the yard fence, took out the half-filled black garbage bag and placed it on the ground, then lifted the trash can high.
[1975-09-29 15:25:00] beside the house | I struggled to carry the trash can toward the house, setting it down several times along the way because it was so heavy. All the while, I kept my eyes fixed on the sloping road. I felt it was much heavier than I had imagined. I was relieved that no one was in sight.
[1975-09-29 15:26:00] on the lawn / under the window | I watched as an unfamiliar car drove past. I quickly moved the trash can beneath the window, climbed up, then pulled the glass window open and thrust my head and upper body inside.
[1975-09-29 15:27:00] basement window | I stared into the empty room, feeling a panicked sense of losing control. I felt the room I was in was dim and warm. Fear and unease filled my mind—I worried someone might be watching me break in through the window at that very moment.
[1975-09-29 15:28:00] basement window | I twisted my body forward until half of me was inside the window, then grabbed the metal pipe of the heater and pulled myself through for the final stretch.
[1975-09-29 15:29:00] hall / front door | My foot landed on the floor. I took off my boots, carried them across the entire hall to the front door, opened it, and stepped back outside.
[1975-09-29 15:30:00] in front of the house | I looked down toward the road below; there were no cars, no movement at all. I thought that as long as Dad didn't suddenly return in the next few minutes—whether because he'd forgotten something or fallen ill—even though he never got sick—as long as nothing unexpected happened, everything would be fine. I felt a hollow emptiness inside, filled with fear and tension.
[1975-09-29 15:32:00] in front of the house / beside the window | I let out a groan of relief, hurried over to the trash can in three quick steps, moved it back into place, stuffed the garbage bag inside, smoothed the opening, then ran back to the window. I silently rejoiced—if only he didn't appear during these few minutes, I’d succeed.
[1975-09-29 15:33:00] grass beneath the window | I reached out and tried to smooth the grass to cover the marks left by the trash can, and I turned over some of the soil mixed with fertilizer. To my horror, I noticed the trash can had left visible traces on the grass—some imprints looked quite deep.
[1975-09-29 15:34:00] grass beneath the window | I straightened up and carefully examined the patch of grass I had just worked on. I wanted to see how it looked, but I could still clearly spot the flaws.
[1975-09-29 15:34:10] grass beneath the window | I thought that if someone didn’t know what had happened, they might not notice it easily. But then I realized that with Dad’s sharp eyes—eyes that never missed a single detail—he would likely spot it.
[1975-09-29 15:35:00] grass beneath the window | I crouched down again and kept working at the grass, trying to flatten the marks. When I was done, I stood up. I figured it should be good enough now.
[1975-09-29 15:36:00] grass beneath the window | I decided that if he noticed, I would simply deny it. I thought he couldn’t possibly imagine me moving the trash can and climbing through the window. I told myself that as long as I kept a straight face, he wouldn’t press further.
[1975-09-29 15:38:00] room | I wiped my damp, dirty hands on my thighs, slung my backpack over my shoulder, and ran upstairs into my room.
[1975-09-29 15:40:00] room | I opened the wardrobe and looked at the white shirt. I had wanted to change into it, but in the end, I held myself back. I thought about how Ingeborg would find the shirt beautiful, but I was afraid Dad would question me if he noticed I’d changed clothes. I realized that once he became suspicious, I might very well be caught.
[1975-09-29 15:42:00] room / outside the window | I locked the door inside the room and climbed up onto the water heater pipes. I turned my body around with my feet facing outward, carefully lowered myself until I let go, and landed on the ground with a splash.
[1975-09-29 15:45:00] driveway | I quickened my pace onto the driveway, pretending to be nonchalant. I looked around and didn't see any vehicles.
[1975-09-29 15:46:00] intersection | I saw Fosson, Karlsen, Viktor, and Larssen standing at the intersection. I noticed they spotted me and started riding their bikes toward me. I stood quietly there, waiting for them to come closer.
[1975-09-29 15:47:00] intersection | I saw Karlsen hit the brakes in front of me. I heard Karlsen ask me, 'Did you hear about it?' I asked back, 'What?'
[1975-09-29 15:48:00] intersection | I heard Karlsen say nervously, 'Early this morning, a worker at Viddholmen was cut in half by a steel cable.'
[1975-09-29 15:49:00] intersection | I heard Fosson add, 'The cable snapped while it was being tightened—hit the guy with the flying end and sliced him clean in two. My dad said they sent everyone home today.' Hearing this horrifying news, I couldn't help but feel a chill run through me.
[1975-09-29 15:50:00] intersection | A terrifying image flashed in my mind: a man cut in half at the waist, his upper body still standing upright beside his lower half. The image made my skin crawl.
[1975-09-29 15:51:00] intersection | I saw Viktor Lunddal looking at me with concern. I heard Viktor ask me, 'Your bike with the flat tire still not fixed?' I nodded. Then he generously said, 'You can ride with me.'
[1975-09-29 15:52:00] intersection | I told them, 'I'm going up to Karl Larsdal's place.' I heard Karlsen shrug and say he might go down to the boat, then Viktor asked again where we were headed.
[1975-09-29 15:53:00] intersection | I explained, 'Up to a classmate’s place—to talk about homework.' I heard Karlsen ask who it was, and I replied, 'Vimund.'
[1975-09-29 15:54:00] crossroads | I waved and said, "No, just today. I have to go now." I heard Viktor ask, "Were you with him?"
locations: on the lawn / under the window
in front of the house / beside the window

text:
[1975-09-29 15:55:00] Karl Larsdal's uphill path | I ran up the slope shouting Karl's name, then saw him come running out holding a slice of bread. I shouted toward his house.
[1975-09-29 16:15:00] path leading to the highest point | Twenty minutes later, we passed the supermarket again, went around a patch of grass, and began climbing toward the highest part of the housing area. I noticed that from there, it led directly to the homes of Ingeborg, Lilund, and Vemd.
[1975-09-29 16:16:00] Rocky | As far as I knew, this path formed a loop, connecting all the side roads and houses in the housing area. I knew the main road outside also formed a circular roundabout. I thought to myself, marveling, that we actually lived in a circle inside a circle inside a circle.
[1975-09-29 16:20:00] beside the cliff | I saw that the two road surfaces outside the supermarket ran parallel, but were separated by a small cliff about ten meters high. A green wire-mesh fence stood on the cliff face, with an artificial sloped hill above it.
[1975-09-29 16:21:00] at the fence | Karl and I climbed down along the fence. Though I couldn't see the road, I could clearly hear the roar of cars rushing beneath my feet. The sound gave me a strange thrill.
[1975-09-29 16:22:00] at the fence | When cars came up from the direction of the gas station, I first heard a faint whooshing sound, which grew louder and louder until it echoed against the cliff wall and rushed past at high speed.
[1975-09-29 16:23:00] at the fence | Karl and I each held a stone, crouching beside the fence. We planned to throw stones at the cars. Since we couldn't see them, we had to focus completely and time our throws by sound alone.
[1975-09-29 16:24:00] at the fence | I saw that the stone was larger than my hand, heavy and solid. I looked down at the vertical roadway surface about ten meters below.
[1975-09-29 16:25:00] at the fence | I saw Karl launch the first attack—he threw his stone at the peak of the noise. Then I heard the hollow thud of the stone hitting the asphalt. I saw his stone miss, rolling off to the side.
[1975-09-29 16:26:00] fence | I quickly followed suit and threw the stone out, watching it hit the road and spark a small shower of sparks. I realized I had thrown too early—the car was probably still about fifty meters away.
[1975-09-29 16:28:00] sidewalk | I saw a woman carrying two plastic bags walking toward us along the sidewalk. She stopped in her tracks. I noticed this woman was a stranger we’d never seen before.
[1975-09-29 16:28:10] sidewalk | I heard the woman ask, “What are you doing down there?” Carl replied, “Nothing special.” She warned us again, “You’d better come up here—this place is steep and dangerous.”
[1975-09-29 16:30:00] sidewalk | I saw her watching us as she continued walking. Carl and I decided to follow her advice and climbed up to higher ground. I felt her eyes lingering on us, making me slightly uneasy.
[1975-09-29 16:35:00] outside Vemund's house | I walked along the narrow strip of stones by the roadside and saw Vemund’s little sister kneeling in the sandbox. I saw her wearing a yellow raincoat, busy with a green shovel inside a blue plastic bucket.
[1975-09-29 16:36:00] outside Vemund's house | I heard Carl ask, “Shall we go to Vemund’s first?” I immediately refused, “No, not yet—we’ll start at Ingeborg Lofnes’s house.”
[1975-09-29 16:36:10] outside Vemund's house | Ingeborg’s name seemed to carry an electric charge. Every time I whispered it softly, I could feel a warm current spreading through my body.
[1975-09-29 16:37:00] outside Vemund's house | I heard Carl mutter, “What’s wrong?” I shot back, “What?” He remarked, “You’re acting strange.” I quickly defended myself, “Strange? No, not at all—I’m exactly the same as always, me.”
[1975-09-29 17:00:00] home | Before dinner, I saw my brother return just in time. Then I heard Dad shouting from the kitchen that dinner was ready.
[1975-09-29 17:10:00] kitchen | I sat down at the table and saw Dad bring out grilled steaks and potatoes. Freshly cooked steak, fried onions, and boiled cauliflower came into view.
[1975-09-29 17:15:00] kitchen | I heard Mom say, "A housecleaner is coming to our house, Mrs. Jæren." She also said she had already called her at work. As far as I know, Mrs. Jæren is an elderly woman who is scheduled to come to our house once a week, and she was supposed to arrive that afternoon. I heard Mom comment that she sounded like a nice person.
[1975-09-29 17:20:00] at home | I clearly remember that Dad used to be firmly against hiring a cleaner. I noticed that Dad wasn’t saying anything now, and I realized he must have changed his mind. Though he might still be reluctant, this silent acceptance surprised me.
[1975-09-29 17:25:00] at home | I was happy that we were getting a housecleaner. I thought to myself how pleasant it always is when someone visits, and I imagined her arrival would bring a certain freshness to the house. I also looked forward to them noticing me, asking about school or soccer.
[1975-09-29 18:00:00] Henrik Inge's room | After dinner, I slipped into my brother’s room. I saw him take an album titled 'Pile Driver' from the tape shelf and put it into the player. The sound of Status Quo’s rock music filled my ears.
[1975-09-29 18:05:00] Henrik Inge's room | I said to my brother, "I saw you on a bus somewhere—where did you go?" I heard him reply briefly, "Into town."
[1975-09-29 18:10:00] Henrik Inge's room | I saw him lie down on the bed and start flipping through a magazine. I pressed on, "So, what did you go there for?" I heard him say somewhat impatiently, "Stop nagging me—I went to buy some bike parts."
[1975-09-29 18:11:00] Henrik Inge's room | I stared at him. I saw him turn his head and look at me seriously. I asked, "Is the bike broken?" I saw him shake his head, then I heard him say, "Don’t tell anyone. Not even Mom." I promised him, "I swear I won’t tell."
[1975-09-29 18:12:00] Henrik Inge's room | I heard my brother explain, "The bike’s at Frank’s place—the frame broke. But his dad says he can fix it, and I can pick it up tomorrow morning."
[1975-09-29 18:15:00] Henrik Inge's room | I saw my brother shrug again and go back to reading. I said to my brother, "Just think—if Dad or someone he knows had seen you in town?"
[1975-09-29 18:30:00] hallway at home | I returned to my own room. A little later, I heard someone ringing the doorbell. I waited until I noticed Mom going downstairs to the hallway before stepping out of my room.
[1975-09-29 18:31:00] stairs | I saw the large, elderly woman walking up the stairs. I noticed her hair was gray, she wore a pair of glasses, and her whole figure looked somewhat round.
[1975-09-29 18:32:00] stairs | I nodded at her and saw her smile back at me. I heard Mom introduce her: 'This is Grete Lundnes, the younger one.'
[1975-09-29 18:33:00] stairs | I felt her hand rest on my shoulder. I heard her say to me: 'I'm Mrs. Yhlen—we're going to be good friends.' I felt warmth spreading through my entire body.
[1975-09-29 18:34:00] stairs | I heard Mom say: 'The older one, Henrik Inge, is in his room.' I asked her, 'Shall I go call him?' Then I heard Mom shaking her head and telling me: 'You don't need to.'
[1975-09-29 18:40:00] bedroom | I saw Mom showing her around the house, then I returned to my own room.
[1975-09-29 19:00:00] bedroom | I saw the sky outside grow dark. I heard raindrops pattering against the roof and walls, heard the water trickling through the gutters. I saw large droplets strike the windowpane and run down in unpredictable, winding paths.
[1975-09-29 19:10:00] bedroom | I saw the headlights of a car sweeping across the spruce tree above the mailbox stand. I realized it was Jacobson coming home from work. I saw the green mailbox and the metal post supporting it gleam under the light. I felt as though those mailboxes were silently pleading in the stillness: No, no, don’t bring light.
[1975-09-29 19:20:00] bedroom | I lay down on my bed. I was thinking about Ingeborg Lofnes. I thought about how tomorrow we would go there again, but more than anything, I longed to see her at school first. I felt that just seeing her would be enough—the joy would spread through every cell in my body.
[1975-09-29 19:30:00] bedroom | I was thinking that one day I would ask her if we could be together. I wanted to go to her room, and I wanted her to come to mine. Even though I wasn’t allowed to invite people over, I thought that for her, I’d find a way—maybe even climb in through the window if I had to.
[1975-09-29 19:40:00] bedroom | I sat down at my desk, pulled out my books from my backpack, and began doing my homework.
[1975-09-29 20:00:00] at home | I noticed Mrs. Yellen had left, and then I heard Henrik Inge's footsteps disappear into the kitchen.
[1975-09-29 20:05:00] kitchen | I knew it was Monday today, and every Monday evening my brother would make pancakes or muffins in the kitchen.
[1975-09-29 20:10:00] kitchen | I felt the warmth in the kitchen, and I smelled the pleasant aroma of pancakes or muffins. I understood that when my brother was busy, I would usually sit there chatting with Mom.
[1975-09-29 20:15:00] kitchen | I learned that once my brother finished cooking, we would spread butter on the food, watch it melt, and eat it with cheese, sugar, tea, and milk.
[1975-09-29 20:20:00] kitchen | I realized that sometimes Dad would appear there too, but as far as I knew, he usually returned to his office quickly.
[1975-09-29 20:30:00] kitchen | I noticed homework didn't take long; after finishing my letters, I headed toward the kitchen.
[1975-09-29 20:35:00] kitchen | I saw Henrik Inge standing there with his sleeves rolled up and an apron on, watching him stir a bowl with a wooden spoon. I saw the light on inside the empty oven.
[1975-09-29 20:40:00] kitchen | I saw Mom tug at the yarn ball, a motion that made me feel as if she were sitting on a boat fishing. I sat down in my seat and asked Mom, "You'll be finishing soon, right?" I heard her reply, "Another day or two, depending on how fast I knit."
[1975-09-29 20:45:00] kitchen | I told Mom, "Today Karl and I went up to Ingeborg and Lilund's place." I heard her ask back, "Oh really? Who are they? From your class?" I nodded at her.
[1975-09-29 20:46:00] kitchen | I heard Henrik Inge tease, "So now you're starting to play with girls?" I replied, "Yeah?" Then I heard him ask, "Who've you fallen in love with, huh?"
[1975-09-29 20:47:00] kitchen | I looked at Mom hesitantly, then turned back to Henrik Inge. I admitted to him, 'I think so.'
[1975-09-29 20:48:00] kitchen | I saw Henrik Inge start laughing. I heard him mock me, 'You're only seven! You don't know what it means to fall in love!'
[1975-09-29 20:49:00] kitchen | I heard Mom say seriously to my brother, 'You shouldn't laugh at someone for something like this, Henrik Inge.'
[1975-09-29 20:50:00] kitchen | I saw Henrik Inge blush and suddenly bury his head in his bowl. I heard Mom continue, 'Feelings are feelings, whether you're seven or seventy. They’re equally important, do you understand?'
[1975-09-29 20:51:00] kitchen | The kitchen fell silent for a moment, then I heard Henrik Inge say, 'But it can’t possibly lead to anything!'
[1975-09-29 20:52:00] kitchen | I heard Mom say, 'Perhaps you're right about that, but can't a person still have feelings for someone else?' I retorted to my brother, 'You’re in love with Anne!' I heard him quickly deny it, but I insisted, 'You said you were in love with her.'
[1975-09-29 20:53:00] kitchen | I heard Mom intervene, 'Alright, alright, how’s the batter coming along? Is it ready?' I heard my brother reply, 'I think so.'
[1975-09-29 20:55:00] kitchen | I saw Mom put the fabric she was holding into the basket and stand up. I heard her ask, 'Let me see?' Then she asked me, 'Would you like to grease the baking pan, Grete Lundnes?'
[1975-09-29 20:56:00] kitchen | I saw Mom take out a small jar of melted butter, hand me a brush, and pull the baking pan from the bottom drawer of the stove.
[1975-09-29 20:57:00] kitchen | I observed the heated butter, noticing many small pits and some larger light brown spots within its thin yellow layer. I realized that if you heat the oil slowly, its color becomes richer and purer.
[1975-09-29 20:58:00] kitchen | I dipped the brush into the oil and spread it across the baking tray. I tried pulling the brush along rather than pushing it forward. I felt the melted oil making the brush stiff and resistant. I noticed the melted brown oil forming a thin layer on the baking tray.
[1975-09-29 20:59:00] kitchen | I finished greasing in just ten seconds. Then I sat back down, watching Henrik Inge begin shaping the pancakes.
[1975-09-29 21:00:00] kitchen | I immediately sat up straight in my chair. I heard the door downstairs creak open, followed by Dad’s heavy footsteps climbing the stairs.
[1975-09-29 21:01:00] kitchen | I saw Mom sit down again, placing the fabric on her lap and looking toward the doorway. That was when I saw Dad appear there.
[1975-09-29 21:02:00] kitchen | I saw Dad hook his thumbs into his belt loops and hoist his trousers upward. I heard Dad say, 'The whole family's here, I suppose dinner will be ready soon?' I heard Mom reply, 'Another fifteen minutes.'
[1975-09-29 21:03:00] kitchen | I noticed Henrik Inge simply lower his head slightly in response. I heard Dad ask, 'You're making pancakes, Henrik Inge?' Then I heard him murmur, 'Good, good.'
[1975-09-29 21:05:00] living room | I saw Dad turn and walk into the living room. He stopped in front of the television, turned on the switch, and sat down in the brown leather armchair. I heard the floorboards creak under his weight.
[1975-09-29 21:10:00] living room | I recognized the voice from the TV—the doctor from that medical show, his voice raspy like rusted metal. I noticed the man on screen always tilted his head back to speak toward the ceiling, yet his eyes remained fixed downward. It seemed to me as if he were directing the sound to land in exactly the right place.
[1975-09-29 21:15:00] living room | I stood up and walked into the living room.
[1975-09-29 21:20:00] living room | I asked Dad, 'Are they performing surgery?' I heard him answer, 'What else did you expect?' I pressed, 'Can I watch?' He agreed, 'Sure, it's not dangerous or anything.' I saw the TV screen showing incised skin, blue sheets filled with blood and flesh.
[1975-09-29 21:25:00] living room | I sat on the outermost edge of the sofa. I saw straight into the inside of a human body, the surgical site held open by metal clamps like a funnel. I noticed the freshly cut piece of flesh, its base a glistening membranous organ, smeared with dark blood—all clearly visible under the harsh glare of fluorescent lights.
[1975-09-29 21:30:00] living room | I saw a pair of hands wearing rubber gloves skillfully manipulating instruments. As the image zoomed in, I saw a person lying flat, covered entirely with blue plastic sheeting. I noticed five medical staff in green surgical gowns—two bent over beneath a lizard-shaped light, the other three holding trays filled with instruments.
[1975-09-29 21:35:00] living room | I saw Dad stand up. I heard him complain, "I'm not watching this anymore, this is unbearable—on Monday nights they only show this kind of thing!" I asked, "Can I keep watching?" He replied, "Sure, you can handle it."
[1975-09-29 21:40:00] living room | I saw one end of the membrane pulsating, expanding and contracting rhythmically. I noticed fresh blood welling up, while the membrane kept dilating to push the blood aside, then reemerging again from the pool of blood.
locations: path leading to the highest point

text:
[1975-09-29 21:41:00] living room | Suddenly I realized what I was seeing was a heart, and a terrible sadness welled up inside me.
[1975-09-29 21:42:00] living room | I thought to myself that the sorrow wasn't because the heart couldn't escape. I realized the heart should beat secretly, hidden from sight. It was like a blind little creature meant to throb and pulse beneath the chest, unseen.
[1975-09-29 21:45:00] living room | I continued staring at the screen. I felt that surgery programs were my favorite. I recalled how long ago I had already decided that when I grew up, I would become a surgeon.
[1975-09-29 21:50:00] living room | I knew my parents sometimes told others about this as a joke, because I was so young at the time. But deep down, I knew I was serious. I wanted to grow up and cut open wounds, to operate inside the human body.
[1975-09-29 21:55:00] living room | I remembered how I had always drawn pictures filled with bloodstains, knives, and surgical scenes. I realized Mom had often asked me, puzzled, why I insisted on drawing such gory images. I thought I could draw houses and suns if I wanted to, but that wasn’t what I truly desired. In my heart, I sighed—divers, rockets, and surgeries were the things I really wanted to draw.
[1975-09-29 21:56:00] Bærum | I knew Henrik Inge once wanted to be a janitor when he was a child. As far as I knew, Grandma would always bring it up and laugh, mentioning how Dad had wanted to be a handyman—she’d repeated these old stories hundreds of times.
[1975-09-29 21:57:00] living room | I realized my ambition to become a surgeon was serious, completely different from my brother’s childhood joke about wanting to be a janitor. I realized I was already much older than he was back then, and this fact was anything but funny to me.
[1975-09-29 22:00:00] living room | I heard the program host describing the surgery that had just been completed. I saw all the metal clamps and tubes being removed from the open wound.
[1975-09-29 22:10:00] kitchen | I stood up and walked into the kitchen, seeing the freshly baked pancakes sitting on a tray. I noticed Mom placing dinner plates and teacups on the dining table. I saw the tray cooling on the electric stove. I noticed the teakettle beside it steaming gently.
[1975-09-30 07:00:00] home | I saw Mom pull out a thick pair of socks and told me to put them on before slipping into my rubber boots. I felt the temperature drop, though the rain had stopped. I noticed last year’s mid-calf boots had shrunk and no longer fit.
[1975-09-30 07:10:00] home | I put on the blue down jacket I’d bought last winter and pulled the matching blue hat down over my forehead. I felt the hat block my vision, like a black awning.
[1975-09-30 08:00:00] school | I saw Ingeborg Lofnes wearing a smooth, shiny light-blue down jacket with a white hat, white scarf, and blue pants. I noticed she had on brand-new red half-boots, and her black hair curled out from under the brim of her hat.
[1975-09-30 08:05:00] school | I looked over toward the girls and saw Ingeborg standing among them. I noticed she didn’t see me.
[1975-09-30 08:05:10] school | I silently marveled at how strikingly beautiful the color of her down jacket was. I thought I wished I could have one just like it.
[1975-09-30 08:10:00] school gathering spot | I suggested to Karl Larsdal that we go together to snatch their hats—him taking Lilund’s, and me taking Ingeborg’s. I saw we had arrived at the school gathering spot, where everyone piled their backpacks together.
[1975-09-30 08:11:00] schoolyard | I lunged from behind Ingeborg, yanking off her hat, then turned and ran. I saw her spin around the moment I grabbed the hat, and I heard her let out a sharp scream. I waited until I was sure our eyes had met before I started running.
[1975-09-30 08:12:00] school playground | I ran across the playground, glancing back from time to time to see if she was chasing after me. I controlled my running speed—I wanted to make sure I wasn't too fast for her to catch up, but not so slow that others would notice I was deliberately waiting for her.
[1975-09-30 08:13:00] school playground | I felt her spread her arms and wrap them around me from behind. I heard her footsteps closely following mine on the asphalt path.
[1975-09-30 08:15:00] school playground | I held the hat high above her head. Finally, I gave it back to her and quietly watched as she put it on and walked away. I heard her laugh and call out to me: "Give it to me, give it to me!" I silently cheered inside—how wonderful that thick down jacket felt pressed together. My heart swelled with immense joy.
[1975-09-30 08:16:00] school playground | I saw her turn around and flash me a radiant smile. I gazed into her eyes, marveling inwardly: Ah, her eyes—so dark, so beautiful, still sparkling!
[1975-09-30 08:17:00] school playground | I felt as though I had entered a brilliantly shining realm. I thought: compared to this, everything else seemed dim and utterly meaningless.
[1975-09-30 08:30:00] classroom | I heard the bell ring, then lined up and walked into the classroom, taking my seat. I heard the class bell echoing through the schoolyard.
[1975-09-30 14:00:00] School / Bus / On the way | I sat in the classroom listening to lessons, speaking up, drawing, and playing football during breaks. I sang songs beside Karl on the bus ride home. Though I did everything I normally did, I felt a new sky rising within me. I realized that because of her, even the most familiar daily details had become completely renewed.
[1975-09-30 15:00:00] outside Ingeborg Lofnes's house | I saw Ingeborg Lofnes standing outside by the driveway, among a group of children.
[1975-09-30 15:05:00] outside Ingeborg Lofnes's house | I saw two girls swinging a long rope while the others took turns darting in to jump. I heard the mechanical whipping sound of the rope hitting the ground.
[1975-09-30 15:10:00] outside Ingeborg Lofnes's house | I saw Ingeborg smiling at us. I heard her say to us: "You come too!"
[1975-09-30 15:15:00] Outside Ingeborg Lofnes's house | I joined the line and jumped into the rope, but after just a couple of jumps, the rope whipped against my leg. I had to exit the game disheartened. I really wanted to perform well in front of Ingeborg, hoping to win her favor. But I found myself eliminated far too quickly.
[1975-09-30 15:20:00] Outside Ingeborg Lofnes's house | I saw Karl Larsdal jumping quite well, managing five jumps before being swung out. I watched him dash forward rapidly a few steps, using momentum to steady himself. I noticed how his wildly flailing arms and legs actually coordinated so well. His final sprinting motion seemed just like that of a professional runner.
[1975-09-30 15:20:10] Outside Ingeborg Lofnes's house | I secretly worried whether Ingeborg now thought Karl was better than me.
[1975-09-30 15:21:00] Outside Ingeborg Lofnes's house | I saw Ingeborg step lightly into the rope and begin dancing gracefully, swiftly shifting her center of gravity between her feet, her eyes calmly fixed ahead. After she jumped out, she glanced at me. I saw her smile so brightly—I felt her smile was saying to me, 'Now you see!'
[1975-09-30 15:22:00] Outside Ingeborg Lofnes's house | I saw Karl Larsdal try again but fail, and now he was staggering slowly toward me. I noticed he kept nodding in rhythm with the rope. I thought his last jump had truly been an earnest effort.
[1975-09-30 15:25:00] Outside Ingeborg Lofnes's house | I saw the pooled water in the large pit of the backfill area appeared a murky yellow. I also noticed that in the smaller puddles, the water was a gray-green close to the color of gravel, shimmering with light.
[1975-09-30 15:30:00] Outside Ingeborg Lofnes's house | I stood at the edge of the slope and looked down. I heard the gentle babbling of a stream coming from the woods below. A monotonous machine hum echoed in my ears. I realized I had never been to that place down there before.
[1975-09-30 15:35:00] Outside Ingeborg Lofnes's house | I saw how the foundation of the house near the woods turned into a steep stone cliff. Below lay a patch of withered, yellowish marsh. Between the trunks of pine trees, I spotted a green tool shed and a roaring yellow generator.
[1975-09-30 15:40:00] Outside Ingeborg Lofnes's house | I heard the sound of drilling—sharp, crisp metallic taps chiseling rock. Though I couldn't see anyone, I realized the sound seemed almost like singing—a sound I was very familiar with.
[1975-09-30 15:45:00] Outside Ingeborg Lofnes's house | I turned around and saw Karl Larsdal walking toward me.
[1975-09-30 15:50:00] Outside Ingeborg Lofnes's house | I saw Ingeborg easily jump under the rope, but she soon let it hit her arm and stepped out. She walked toward us with Lilund. I heard Ingeborg say, "Come with me, Lilund?" I thought she had deliberately let the rope touch her arm, just so she could stop playing sooner.
[1975-09-30 15:55:00] Outside Ingeborg Lofnes's house | I saw both of them come to a stop in front of us. I heard Ingeborg ask, "What should we do now?"
[1975-09-30 16:00:00] Outside Ingeborg Lofnes's house | I suggested, "Let's go look for empty bottles, okay?" I heard Karl immediately respond, "Yeah, find empty bottles!" Then I heard Ingeborg ask curiously where we might find them.
[1975-09-30 16:05:00] Outside Ingeborg Lofnes's house | I heard Karl list places like along the roadside, behind the playground, and around the workshop. I added, "At the bus stop, and under the bridge."
[1975-09-30 16:10:00] Outside Ingeborg Lofnes's house | I saw Lilund and Ingeborg looking at Karl with admiration. I heard Karl boast to them, "Once we found a whole bag full, down in the ditch below the shop. We got four kroner for it!"
[1975-09-30 16:10:10] Outside Ingeborg Lofnes's house | I felt a bit resentful inside: finding empty bottles was my idea, I came up with it first, yet Karl was taking all the credit.

[1975-09-30 16:15:00] On the path | We started walking downhill. I saw everyone moving forward along the roadside. Before me stretched a gray sky, dry and hard like dried cement. I noticed there was no wind, the treetops were motionless, the trees standing like silent, thoughtful sentinels.
[1975-09-30 16:20:00] On the path | I saw the pines pointing upward into the sky, as if resting. I noticed the spruce branches drawn inward, appearing heavy and solemn. The old oak by the roadside gave off an air of accustomed loneliness. I sensed that the slender deciduous trees seemed timid and sensitive. I silently marveled—these trees appeared to be showing themselves to me in different postures.
[1975-09-30 16:25:00] On the path | I heard Ingeborg Lofnes point to the slope and say, "There's a pipe running all along this road." I saw the pipe covered with freshly turned black soil, with no wildflowers yet growing on it.
[1975-09-30 16:30:00] Beside the pipe | We walked down toward it. I looked at the concrete pipe. I asked, "Has anyone here ever crawled through a pipe?" When they shook their heads, I suggested, "Let's crawl through it." I heard Karl immediately agree, "Yeah, let's crawl through it." I estimated the pipe's diameter to be just over half a meter.
[1975-09-30 16:35:00] beside the pipe | I saw Karl standing on a stool, peering into the pipe, then he began to crawl in with his upper body. I looked at Ingeborg and Lilund. I heard Lilund ask anxiously, 'What if we get stuck inside?' I reassured them, 'We can crawl through. You two go wait for us at the other end.' When Ingeborg asked if we dared, Karl turned back and asked me who should go first. I told him to go ahead.
[1975-09-30 16:40:00] inside the pipe | I watched Karl twist his body until he completely disappeared into the darkness of the pipe. I heard Karl call out, 'OK.' I noticed the pipe was so narrow that crawling on all fours was impossible. I realized we could only move forward by wriggling.
[1975-09-30 16:45:00] inside the pipe | I bent down like Karl did and pushed my head into the pipe. I used my elbows against the walls to inch forward. I smelled a thick, suffocating odor of cold dampness and mold filling my nostrils. I glanced at Ingeborg beside me, then plunged my head into that moist, musty air.
[1975-09-30 16:50:00] inside the pipe | I struggled to straighten my body slightly, using my forearms and knees to push against the walls as I twisted forward in the dark. I stared ahead, catching sight of Karl’s increasingly blurred silhouette. I felt my entire body enclosed by the cold concrete walls. At first, I could still see Karl’s shadow ahead, but as we went deeper, everything turned pitch black.
[1975-09-30 16:51:00] inside the pipe | I shouted loudly, 'Are you there?' I heard him answer, 'Yes.' Then I asked if he was afraid, and he admitted, 'A little.' I told him I felt the same way.
[1975-09-30 16:52:00] inside the pipe | I felt the entire pipe suddenly vibrate. I realized a heavy vehicle had driven past above us on the road. A terrifying thought surged through me: if the pipe collapsed, we’d be trapped inside, crushed. The image unsettled me deeply.
[1975-09-30 16:53:00] inside the pipe | I remained frozen in place, unable to move, feeling my fingers and toes tremble violently. A wave of panic hit me hard. Though I knew I had to move to get out, I found myself paralyzed. Desperately, I screamed inwardly: I can't make myself move.
[1975-09-30 16:54:00] inside the pipe | I heard my own voice trembling as I asked, 'Are you still scared?' I heard Karl reply that he was, just a little. Then I felt another slight vibration ripple through the pipe. I heard another car pass overhead.
[1975-09-30 16:55:00] inside the pipe | I remained frozen, not daring to move. I could feel the legs of my pants soaked by stagnant water inside the pipe. I heard Karl shout from ahead, 'I see light!'
[1975-09-30 16:56:00] inside the pipe | I imagined immense weight pressing down on the pipe, knowing it was only a few centimeters of concrete holding it up. My heart pounded wildly. A frantic urge to stand up surged through me, but I knew it was impossible in the narrow space. I felt my body tightly gripped, weighed down.
[1975-09-30 16:57:00] inside the pipe | I recalled how my brother Henrik Inge would sometimes ride on top of me, pressing the blanket tightly over me and pinning down my arms and legs. I knew he hated it when I struggled, so I did it deliberately. I remembered the terror of being trapped. I realized that whenever that suffocating sensation came over me, I would scream wildly out of sheer, inescapable fear.
[1975-09-30 16:58:00] inside the pipe | I shouted desperately, “Karl Larsdal!” I realized that familiar panic of being restrained was tightening around my heart again. I felt paralyzed, and the fear was growing stronger.
[1975-09-30 16:59:00] inside the pipe | I heard Karl Larsdal shout ahead, “I’ll help you! I have to crawl out first and then turn back!” Hearing his voice, I felt some of the panic inside me ease slightly.
[1975-09-30 17:00:00] inside the pipe | I tried moving my forearms forward, laboriously dragging my legs along. I felt the back of my down jacket scraping against the upper wall of the pipe. I thought about the tons of rock and soil pressing down from above, and suddenly I felt my arms and legs go completely limp. I could only lie flat where I was.
[1975-09-30 17:01:00] inside the pipe | I worried about what Ingeborg Lofnes and Lilund would think of me, and this thought made my panic surge again. I felt sealed in, utterly immobile.
[1975-09-30 17:02:00] inside the pipe | I noticed movement in the darkness ahead, heard the sound of clothes brushing against the concrete pipe wall. I clearly heard Karl’s distinctive open-mouthed breathing. I saw a pale face faintly emerge from the dark ahead—I realized it was Karl returning.
[1975-09-30 17:03:00] inside the pipe | I felt Karl grab the sleeve of my jacket and pull me toward him. I heard him ask, “Are you stuck?” I answered, “No.”
[1975-09-30 17:04:00] inside the pipe | I arched my back and inched forward step by step. I felt Karl constantly tugging at my sleeve as he backed up. Seeing Karl’s focused face, I stopped thinking about the pipe’s darkness and weight. I felt I could finally move again.
[1975-09-30 17:05:00] pipe exit | I saw Karl Larsdal’s feet emerge from the opening first, then my upper body was pulled out—I finally lifted my head back into the light. I heard Ingeborg Lofnes ask, “You were stuck, weren’t you?” I replied, “Yes, just for a moment. But Karl Larsdal helped me.”
[1975-09-30 17:06:00] pipe exit | I saw Karl Larsdal stand up and brush off his hands and pants. I stood up too. I heard Karl suggest, “Shall we go down to Little Hawaii?” I responded, “Good idea.” I stood beneath a gray sky, feeling the vast openness of space—everything seemed clear and distinct.
[1975-09-30 17:10:00] pipe outlet | I ran down the woodland and saw the black lake water before me. I saw everyone jump onto the two small islands covered by trees. I saw the trees on the islands standing quietly, and the surface of Little Hawaii was pitch black. I felt that running through the woods was truly exhilarating.
[1975-09-30 17:20:00] Little Hawaii | I watched Ingeborg Lofnes, seeing her soft red lips part to reveal white teeth. I noticed her mouth always carried a smile, her eyes sparkling with wonder and joy. I felt that all her movements followed the stirrings of her heart.
[1975-09-30 17:21:00] Little Hawaii | I watched two girls run toward the mainland. I nodded at them as well. I heard Ingeborg Lofnes suggest, 'You're sailors, just returning home... shall we play this?' Karl Larsdal also nodded in agreement.
[1975-09-30 17:25:00] Little Hawaii | I watched them walk deeper into the woods for a while. I heard Ingeborg Lofnes shout loudly, 'Now you can come back!'
[1975-09-30 17:30:00] Little Hawaii | I saw Ingeborg Lofnes impatiently stamping her feet, then sprinting toward me. As soon as she reached me, she stretched out her arms and tightly embraced me. I heard her exclaim, 'How I've missed you! Oh, my dear husband!' Then she asked me to do it again. I felt her face pressed against my cheek, and I felt somewhat flustered inside.
[1975-09-30 17:35:00] Little Hawaii | I ran back to the island, and after Karl took his position, I rushed toward them again. I felt her stretch out her arms and embrace me once more.
[1975-09-30 17:36:00] Little Hawaii | I gazed up at the deep, vast sky. I felt my heart pounding intensely. I wasn't only standing in the woods—I felt as though I stood at the base of my inner self, gazing upward at a future filled with light and joy.
[1975-09-30 17:40:00] Little Hawaii | I felt her body press close to mine. I smelled the apple-like fragrance from her hair. Through my thick down jacket, I could feel her body warmth. I noticed her cool skin pressing against my nearly scorching skin.
[1975-09-30 17:45:00] Little Hawaii | I saw us repeat this game three times. Then we walked deep into the woods, across a slope covered with fallen leaves. Before me lay a carpet of red, yellow, and brown leaves. I heard the gentle murmur of a stream flowing somewhere nearby.
[1975-09-30 17:46:00] Little Hawaii | I saw the land winding downward below the slope, the distant hazy bay lying there, while the sky above appeared clear and bright.
[1975-09-30 18:00:00] wooded path | We walked along the potholed roadside, dodging cars. I noticed that bottles found in the woods were always covered by leaves, possibly stuffed full of tiny insects.
[1975-09-30 18:05:00] wooded path | I followed my friends across the road, heading toward Old Tibaken. I passed the abandoned shed building belonging to the Larsen family. I knew the owner was a colleague of my father’s at school. As far as I knew, there were many rumors about him showing up drunk to class. I searched around for empty bottles, but found nothing.
[1975-09-30 18:10:00] by the highway | I entered a construction area. I walked along a path covered with red and yellow autumn leaves. I saw a white wooden cabin hidden deep within an old orchard. The sky was a cold, gray hue. I felt as if I were walking along the bottom of a vast bottle capped by the sky, with the surrounding hills forming its rim.

[1975-09-30 18:20:00] Old Tibaken | I stopped by a mailbox. I saw an elderly woman standing outside the upper house, trying to pull a tree out of the ground. I saw a wide stream flowing from the woods, beside which stood a small house.
[1975-09-30 18:30:00] Old Tibaken | I saw the old woman straighten up and wave at us, motioning for us to come over. I noticed the large tree had thick, sprawling branches, towering high above her.
[1975-09-30 18:40:00] Old Tibaken meadow | We ran up the slope, stepping on damp, soft grass, until we reached her. I heard the old woman say, 'You all look strong—can you help me? I want to pull this tree out from here.'
[1975-09-30 18:41:00] outside the old woman's house | I grabbed one of the branches and watched as we all pulled together. I saw the roots finally loosen from the soil, and we dragged the tree onto the bank. I heard Karl Larsdal leading the chant: 'Heave-ho! Heave-ho!' Hearing her say we were strong made me feel proud and pleased.
[1975-09-30 18:45:00] outside the old woman's house | I watched the old lady bow her head and walk back into the house. I heard her repeatedly saying thank you, praising how strong we were, and saying she’d bring something to reward us.
[1975-09-30 18:50:00] outside the old woman's house | I asked curiously, 'What do you think we’ll get?' I heard Karl guess cookies, Ingeborg guessed bread, and Lilund guessed apples. I remembered the apple trees growing along the roadside and thought Lilund’s guess made sense.
[1975-09-30 18:55:00] outside the old woman's house | I watched her step out again. I saw that she wasn’t holding any food in her hands. I heard her say, 'This is just a small token of my gratitude. Who would like to take it? It’s for all of you.' I saw her hold out a five-krone coin. I was somewhat surprised that she offered money instead.
[1975-09-30 19:00:00] outside the old woman's house | I took the five-kroner coin. I said loudly, "I can take it, thank you so much!" I also heard her saying goodbye to us. Getting the five kroner made me feel incredibly excited.
[1975-09-30 19:05:00] outside the old woman's house | We ran downhill, discussing how to spend the money. Karl and I wanted to buy something delicious. I heard Ingeborg and Lilund say they had to go home because it was time for dinner.
[1975-09-30 19:10:00] outside the old woman's house | I watched Ingeborg and Lilund walk up the path home. Karl and I continued toward the shop. I could feel the five-kroner coin burning in my pants pocket. Even though we'd said we'd wait until tomorrow, I realized I couldn't possibly do that. I decided to buy now and surprise them tomorrow.
[1975-09-30 19:15:00] on the road | Right after I bought the candy, I saw Karl Larsdal's father driving by. I heard Karl's father call us to get in the car.
[1975-09-30 19:20:00] at the shop | I saw Karl get into the car, and then it drove off. I heard Karl's father say they wouldn't take me this time because they were going into town. I heard Karl whisper to me as he left, "Don't eat it all yourself!"
[1975-09-30 19:30:00] outside the shop | I crossed the street, ran down the cliff, dashed across the football field alone, and went through the woods. I stood quietly in place until the car disappeared.
[1975-09-30 19:31:00] outside the shop | I stopped in front of my house. I divided the candy from the bag into the four pockets of my coat, then threw away the empty bag. I saw the living room light on inside the house.
[1975-09-30 19:35:00] on the road / in the woods | I saw my father's car and my brother's bicycle parked in the driveway. I noticed my brother's bike handlebars had been fixed. I saw the repaired parts gleaming, and thought to myself this would probably be hard to hide from my father's eyes.
[1975-09-30 19:45:00] at the front door | I opened the door and went in. I carefully took off my shoes and went upstairs into the bathroom. I planned that if my father asked about my coat, I’d say I’d rushed to the toilet. I silently prayed he was in his office or the living room and wouldn’t discover the candy I’d hidden.
[1975-09-30 19:46:00] driveway | I heard my father in the living room above, so I urinated in the bathroom and washed my hands. The soft sound of running water echoed in my ears. I felt a deep silence throughout the house.
[1975-09-30 19:50:00] home | I quickly slipped into the room and dumped the candy under the blanket, hiding it. Then I walked out into the hallway. I heard Dad call from the living room, 'Grete Lundnes, is that you?' I replied, 'Yes.'
[1975-09-30 19:55:00] home / bathroom | I went downstairs to take off my coat. I saw Dad come out as well. I heard him ask where I had been. I answered that I’d gone around old Tibåken with Karl. He asked why I was wearing my coat, and I explained it was because I’d rushed to the toilet. I felt his cold gaze fixed on me. I was very nervous and tried hard to make my voice sound normal.
[1975-09-30 20:00:00] hallway / bedroom | I hung up my coat and rushed back to my room, tucking the blanket tightly over the hidden candy. I turned on the small yellow lamp on my desk, and the light filled the room. I felt unsafe having the candy exposed like that.
[1975-09-30 20:05:00] hallway | I sat on the bed, guarding the blanket covering the candy. I felt extremely uneasy because I wasn’t sure what I should do next.
