[1975-09-30 20:06:00] hallway | I opened the borrowed space book. I knew it was a book from Dad’s childhood. Inside, I saw drawings of futuristic rockets, astronauts, and strange planetary landscapes. I wanted to read to hide my anxiety.
[1975-09-30 20:10:00] bedroom | I saw Dad open the door and stand motionless in the doorway, staring at me. I immediately snapped the book shut and sat up straight. I noticed he didn’t enter the room—just kept staring. I thought there was no way he could know something was hidden under the blanket.
[1975-09-30 20:15:00] bedroom | I heard Dad ask, 'What’s in there?' I replied, 'Where?' I insisted there was nothing under the blanket.
[1975-09-30 20:20:00] bedroom | I saw Dad stride over and yank the blanket off my bed. I felt him grab my ear and twist it hard. I heard him shout that I was a lying little brat. I cried and explained, 'An old lady gave me the money! I didn’t do anything wrong!' I was caught completely off guard, crying from the pain, and in my mind I wondered: How could he possibly know!
[1975-09-30 20:30:00] bedroom | I felt my ear twisted even tighter. I cried out and begged him to stop. I heard Dad order me to look at him, asking if I had lied. I also heard him demand to know why an old lady would give me money. I screamed, 'Ow! Ow!' I felt deeply wronged and couldn’t understand why he wouldn’t believe me.
[1975-09-30 20:31:00] bedroom | I saw Dad stare at me, then point toward my blanket. I heard Dad ask, 'What’s in there?' I nervously replied, 'Where?' I tried to argue, but he insisted it was under the blanket. I still refused, shouting, 'There’s nothing under the blanket!'
[1975-09-30 20:32:00] bedroom | I saw Dad staring at me, then he strode over to the bed and yanked the blanket off violently. He suddenly reached out, grabbed my ear, and twisted it hard. I heard him shout that I had lied to him, how dare I lie to my own father.
[1975-09-30 20:33:00] bedroom | I started crying from the pain and injustice. I protested, 'That's not what I meant!' I heard him demanding where the candy and money came from. Through tears, I answered, 'An old lady gave me the money! I didn't do anything wrong!'
[1975-09-30 20:34:00] bedroom | I felt him twist my ear even tighter, and I screamed in pain. I heard Dad repeat 'old lady' with deep suspicion, demanding why she would give me money. In agony, I cried 'Ow! Ow!' He ordered me to shut up and demanded whether I was lying.
[1975-09-30 20:35:00] bedroom | I was forced to lift my head and look at him. I saw flames of anger burning in his eyes, and I heard him command again for me to look at him when speaking. Finally, I admitted, 'Yes.'
[1975-09-30 20:36:00] bedroom | I saw Dad signal for me to follow him. I heard him press me on where the money really came from. I kept sobbing it was from an old lady. He cursed me as a 'lying brat' and ordered me to go with him.
locations: on the road / in the woods

text:
[1975-09-30 20:37:00] bedroom / office | I felt him gripping my ear tightly, forcing me to stand. I whimpered and sobbed as he dragged me toward the office. I cried in defense, 'I didn't... do... anything... wrong,' insisting the money was something we'd earned. He said coldly, 'Down to the office.' I felt my mind go completely blank.
[1975-09-30 20:38:00] office | I saw him shove open the first door, slamming it hard against the wall. Then he dragged me through the second door and threw me onto the office floor, finally letting go. I heard him demand once more where the money came from, warning me not to lie. I sobbed, 'We helped... an old lady... pull a tree out of the stream...'
[1975-09-30 20:39:00] office | I heard him ask suspiciously, 'She gave you money just for that?' I said yes. When he asked how much, I said five kroner. Then I heard him conclude that I was lying.
[1975-09-30 20:40:00] office | I felt overwhelming injustice welling up inside me, and I couldn't help shouting. I screamed desperately, 'I'm not lying!'
[1975-09-30 20:41:00] office | I felt his slap strike my cheek, silencing my shouts. I saw him straighten up and walk toward the desk. I heard him growl quietly, 'Don't yell!' Then he said, 'There's a way to check this. I'll call the old lady.'
[1975-09-30 20:42:00] office | I watched Dad walk over to the desk, pick up the receiver, and start dialing. He asked me where the old lady lived, and I whispered, "Old Tibaken."
[1975-09-30 20:43:00] office | I watched Dad press the receiver against his ear, waiting for the call to connect. I heard Dad say into the phone, "Yes, hello, this is Grete Lundnes. It's about my son. He says he got five kroner from you today. Is that true?" A deathly silence fell in the office.
[1975-09-30 20:44:00] office | I saw Dad put down the receiver. I heard him tell the person on the other end that he hadn't seen any boy, nor had he given anyone money. After apologizing, he hung up. He looked at me and said, "She didn't see any boy. At least, she didn't give anyone five kroner." Listening to him, I could hardly believe my ears.
[1975-09-30 20:45:00] office | I saw Dad shake his head at me. I pleaded desperately, "But it's absolutely true! We got five kroner." I heard him respond coldly, "That's not what she said."
[1975-09-30 20:46:00] office | I felt fresh tears welling up again, and I continued sobbing. I heard Dad declare that the lies had to stop, demanding to know where the money came from. Through sobs, I insisted, "From... that... old... lady!"
[1975-09-30 20:47:00] office | I saw Dad staring into my eyes. I heard him coldly decide to end the conversation, ordering me to throw away the candy and go straight to my room in confinement. He also mentioned he would talk to Presbakkmo.
[1975-09-30 20:48:00] office | I protested, "But this isn't mine! It belongs to Karl Larsdal too—I can't just throw the candy away." I heard him retort that if I'd been claiming all along it was mine, then how come now it wasn't?
[1975-09-30 20:49:00] office | I saw Dad glaring at me furiously, his gaze sending chills through me. I heard him command, "Do as I say. I don't want to hear another word from you. You steal, you lie, and you refuse to admit it! Upstairs—go to your room." I sensed he was on the verge of exploding.
[1975-09-30 20:50:00] kitchen / bedroom | I walked out of the office, feeling Dad right behind me. I went upstairs to my room, grabbed all the candy, threw it into a garbage bag in the kitchen, and finally returned to my room.
[1975-11-15 10:00:00] various places in Tibaken | That autumn and winter, I often went with Karl to visit Ingeborg and Lilund's house. I noticed we used flashlights to light our way through the woods in the dark. We also played around the shipyard dock and beneath the massive concrete pier. I saw the flashlight beams cutting through the trees. As far as I know, we even ventured into the backsides of hills we'd never explored before. I knew that autumn and winter were the times we visited them most frequently. In late 1975, we roamed across construction sites and forests.
[1975-12-06 14:00:00] junkyard | I remember that Saturday when Karl and I set up four chairs, a table, a lamp, and a cabinet in the woods. I saw furniture neatly arranged in the woods, like an outdoor living room. I noticed that Lilund and Ingeborg were with us too. As far as I know, it was Saturday, December 6, 1975. I thought it was absolutely wonderful—being under the sunlight in the forest, yet feeling just like we were sitting in a living room indoors.
[1975-12-06 14:10:00] junkyard | I gazed at Ingeborg Lofnes, watching her smooth, light-blue down jacket and white hat. I saw her knee-high boots and that radiant, diamond-bright smile. I felt a slight tremor inside every time I saw her. She seemed so beautiful it actually hurt. I realized even her stern, intense gaze sometimes held its own special charm.
[1975-12-15 14:00:00] stone island | When it snowed, I went skiing with Karl and two girls. I lay flat on the snow, feeling Ingeborg straddling my back as we slid down the long slope of Stone Island. I felt her legs tightly gripping my spine and her hands clutching my shoulders. I heard her shrieks ringing in my ears as we raced forward at full speed. I smelled the scent of snow everywhere in the air, changing with the temperature. I saw thick fog hanging still among the trees, and fine mist stinging my face. I knew winter had truly arrived in 1975. I learned we wore special raincoats that created almost no friction on the snow. I thought to myself: this is the most wonderful day I've ever experienced. The sensation of tumbling at the bottom of the slope, limbs tangled together, felt utterly intoxicating.
[1975-12-15 14:30:00] pine forest | I saw the dense fog still quietly suspended in the damp, dark-green pine forest. I felt a thin veil of mist constantly clinging to my face.
[1976-01-10 10:00:00] construction area | That winter, I noticed magical connections between areas that had once seemed separate. I saw how the Fina gas station and the football field in the woods were linked by the old gravel road. I learned that Ingeborg's house and Lilund's were actually quite close, only separated by a small patch of woods. I heard Marivik Christian point out Lilund’s neighbor to me. I knew it was January 1976. From what I understood, the entire construction area was interconnected—like all roads leading to Rome. I learned you could go from Tienna to Jelsta Lake via Sandum, even taking shortcuts to school. I felt amazed by these new geographical discoveries—places I’d thought were far apart turned out to be nearby. I realized this shattered my previous sense of isolated, closed-off spaces.
[1976-01-15 16:00:00] Mrs. Yellen's house | Sometimes I went alone or with my family to Mrs. Yellen’s house. I also often watched her clean at our home. I heard Mrs. Yellen teach me the trick for unlocking a door: insert the key, pull it out slightly, then turn. I would also tell her all kinds of personal thoughts. I knew Mrs. Yellen was our family’s cleaner. As far as I knew, she lived next door to Ingeborg’s house. I realized that although she had no children, she warmly welcomed me visiting her home.
[1976-01-15 16:15:00] by the roadside | I told Mrs. Yellen our secret about throwing stones at cars. I recalled that moment: I raised a stone larger than my hand, stared at the bend in the road, and saw a car roaring toward us. I saw the green fence lining the roadside where we stood, and that the area was situated high above the surroundings. As far as I knew, this was an event from the past. I remembered that Karl and I took turns throwing stones down. I said to myself in my mind: now!
[1976-01-15 16:15:05] by the roadside | I saw the stone arc through the air and strike the roof of the car precisely. I heard a loud crashing sound, followed by the scream of the engine and the tires screeching against the asphalt. My heart sank. Although I expected to hit it, I hadn’t anticipated such a violent reaction.

[1976-01-15 16:15:10] stone hill | I saw Karl Larsdal staring at me with terrified eyes. Then he scrambled up the stone hill, quickly crossed the road, and fled over the cliff. I heard him shout in panic: 'Run!'
[1976-01-15 16:15:30] by the roadside | I stood frozen in place. I heard a car door slam below, then the engine starting up. I saw the car accelerating toward me. I felt completely paralyzed. I realized I was terrified—so afraid I couldn't move at all.
[1976-01-15 16:16:00] slope | I saw the car stop about three meters away from me. I saw the driver not open the door, but instead push open the hatch and jump out, walking down the slope toward me with an angry look on his face. I felt my legs shaking violently, almost unable to stand. I felt warm tears rolling down my cheeks.
[1976-01-15 16:16:10] slope | I watched him storm angrily toward me. I heard him shout, 'It was you who threw that stone!'
[1976-01-15 16:16:12] slope | I silently nodded at him.
[1976-01-15 16:16:20] slope | I felt him grab my arms with both hands and shake me hard. I heard him yelling at me, demanding if I knew what I’d done could have killed him. He roared, 'Do you know how much it costs to fix this roof? This—you’re going to pay dearly for this!'
[1976-01-15 16:16:30] slope | I saw him let go of me. I felt myself crying so hard that my vision blurred, and I could barely see anything.
[1976-01-15 16:16:40] slope | I saw him straighten up and look down at me. I heard him demand my name. I answered, 'Grete Lundnes.' When he asked for my address, I said, 'North Mountain Loop.'
[1976-01-15 16:17:00] slope | I saw him stride back up the slope, get into the car, slam the door shut, and drive off with a lurch. I heard his final warning: 'You wait for my call—or rather, let your father wait for my call.'
[1976-01-15 16:17:30] slope | I collapsed helplessly onto the ground and let out a long breath. I felt all hope had been shattered.
[1976-01-15 16:18:00] slope | I saw Karl emerge from the field above. I saw him walk toward me. I wiped the tears from my face with my hand. I heard Karl rapidly firing questions at me about what had just happened. He asked why I hadn’t run. I replied, 'I don’t know, but I couldn’t. Suddenly, I couldn’t move.' He suggested I tell my family, but I whispered tremblingly, 'I can’t, I’m too afraid to say it out loud.' I realized he was relieved I hadn’t mentioned him, but I also noticed he was genuinely curious about why I had frozen up.
[1976-01-15 16:18:30] slope | I heard Karl ask if I had given my father’s name. I said I’d only given my own. He reassured me, 'Your name isn’t in the phone book! He won’t be able to reach your father. Maybe this will just fade away after all!' Hearing him say that, a small flicker of hope reignited inside me.
[1976-01-15 16:19:00] slope road | I thought about what Karl said, and I felt a little better.
[1976-01-15 16:20:00] slope road | I continued to dwell in the false sense of security that Karl had given me.

In the following days, every time I heard the phone ring, I shivered with fear. I heard Mrs. Yellen ask me what had happened. I begged her to swear secrecy, and I heard her agree. She suggested I tell my parents, but I refused. I felt these days were overshadowed. At first, I thought things would simply fade away with time—but I was wrong.
[1976-01-20 18:00:00] home | I heard the telephone ring, and Dad answered it downstairs. About three minutes later, I heard the extension click as it was hung up. I knew it had finally come—the moment I'd been dreading.

[1976-01-20 18:06:00] bedroom | I heard Mom add, 'If that rock had hit the front windshield, he might have swerved off the road or crashed into another car. He could have died.' I replied softly, 'Yes.'
[1976-01-20 18:07:00] bedroom | I saw Dad turn his head away. I heard Dad say furiously, 'Now I’ll have to pay for the repairs—thousands of kroner. We don’t have that kind of money! Where are we supposed to get it?' I whispered I didn’t know. I heard him exclaim in disgust, 'Oh, damn this child!'
[1976-01-20 18:08:00] bedroom | I quietly admitted, 'Yes, but I told Mrs. Yellen.' I heard Mom scold, 'And you’ve said nothing until now—this happened a week ago. You should have told us. You must promise to do so in the future.' Then I heard Dad shout in shock, 'You told Mrs. Yellen—but not us?'

[1976-01-20 18:15:00] bedroom | I knew that about a year ago, I had run away from home over a knife incident—it was another unfortunate event. I thought everything would pass. text:
[1976-04-15 21:31:40] my own room | I knew that those who walked on the seabed back then wore shoes made of lead, incredibly heavy, and their thick, bulky diving suits made them look as clumsy as elephants, with the oxygen tubes fastened to their heads swaying like trunks. In my mind, I am wearing the kind of iron helmet used by early divers.
[1976-04-15 21:31:50] my own room | I pant through my mouth, exhaling in small bursts, bringing my feet down heavily one after another, just like their slow, weighty movements on the seabed.
[1976-04-15 21:32:00] my own room | I kept walking in circles across the floor for a while... Until I felt my horrified imagination entering another stage, beginning to seep extremely slowly into that icy, bone-chilling water region.
[1976-04-15 21:32:15] my own room | I remember months ago I watched a TV adaptation of Jules Verne's novel *The Mysterious Island*, about several people who descend in a hot-air balloon onto a deserted island in the Atlantic Ocean. I was completely stunned the moment I saw the first scene.
[1976-04-15 21:32:25] my own room | I thought how this story contained wonders beyond imagination, encompassing everything—the hot-air balloon, violent storms, people dressed in 19th-century clothing, the barren, uninhabited island they landed on, which might not have been as terrible as they imagined, yet one bizarre, mysterious event after another unfolded around them... Who exactly were those people?
[1976-04-15 21:32:35] my own room | I recalled suddenly finding the answer near the end of that episode. There was movement in the underground water tunnels—creatures resembling humans... From the light of the lamps in their hands, a smooth, mask-covered head flashed past my eyes... I saw it clearly... It looked like a lizard, but walking upright on two limbs... And carrying several others on its back... One of them turned around—it had no eyes...
[1976-04-15 21:32:45] my own room | When I saw him, I didn’t scream, but I felt those terrifying images pierce through my entire body instantly, flooding my mind so completely that I couldn’t do anything. Even in the bright light of day, whenever I think of those frogmen in the underwater caves, fear utterly shatters me.
[1976-04-15 21:32:55] my own room | I feel now that the countless thoughts in my mind have transformed me into one of them—I mirror them, and they mirror me. Their steps are my steps, their arms are my arms. The moment I close my eyes, I see those eyeless faces.
[1976-04-15 21:33:05] my own room | I imagine the underground water caves... the dark, filthy water... the frogmen holding up lamps, marching in a long line... I feel myself sinking too deep, and opening my eyes won’t help. Even if I see myself sitting in my room, surrounded by familiar things, I remain gripped by fear.
[1976-04-15 21:33:15] my own room | I sat down on the bed, stiff-bodied, grabbing my schoolbag without looking, glancing at the timetable, finding Wednesday, reading the list below: arithmetic, general knowledge of natural geography, music. Once we even attended Karl Larsdal·B.'s birthday party. I had lost the ten-kroner note I meant to give him; when I arrived, the envelope was empty. Wearing my best clothes, I started crying. Fortunately, his father went with me to search. We walked back along the path I had taken, and there, on the black asphalt road shimmering with blue light, I saw the ten-kroner banknote lying on the ground. I knew halfway along the route I would pass, sheltered by cliffs and trees, lived Kristine Lof and Karl Larsdal·B.
[1976-04-26 10:20:00] roadside garden | I saw a boy standing on the lawn of a garden beside the road—long black hair and an Indian-like face—kicking a ball around with his feet. I heard him say: "Hi." I said: "Hi." He said: "How many can you do like that?" I said: "Four." He said: "Ha, what's that?" "Well, how many can you do?" "Sixteen." I said: "Then show me."
[1976-04-26 10:21:00] roadside garden | I saw him balance the ball motionless on the top of his foot. He pulled his foot back slightly, quickly tossed the ball into the air, and began kicking it with the instep—one, two, three—then the ball drifted too far away. For the last kick, he had to stretch his leg completely out just to reach it, and the ball flew toward the fence. I said: "That’s four." He said: "It’s because you’re standing here distracting me. One more time. Will you wait and watch?" I said: "Sure."
[1976-04-26 10:22:00] roadside garden | This time I saw him kick the ball up to about knee height, shifting it from one knee to the other five times before losing control again. I said: "Eight." He said: "Yeah, but now I’ll show you properly." I said: "I have to go." He said: "OK."
[1976-04-26 10:25:00] sidewalk | I saw his father—a fat man with glasses and thick gray hair—standing at the window watching us. I ran across the road to the sidewalk on the other side, immediately slowed down, and started walking with my head lowered again. I suddenly remembered I was wearing a hideous, sloppy outfit.
[1976-04-26 10:30:00] driveway at home | When I reached the bottom of the slope, I saw Dad backing the car out of the driveway. He waved at me and leaned over from his seat to open the door. I heard him say: "Get in, we're going into town." I said: "But I'm all dirty—can I change first?" He said: "Don't be silly, get in now!"
[1976-04-26 10:31:00] inside the car | I pulled up the small handle next to the seat so I could slide it forward. I heard him say: "Just sit in front." I said: "In the front seat?" He said: "Yes, we don’t have all day! Get in now!"
[1976-04-26 10:32:00] inside the car | I did as he said. When I closed the door, he shifted gears and the car began moving downward. I heard him say: "Yeah, you're a bit grubby, but we're only going for a short while. It doesn’t matter."
[1976-04-26 10:35:00] inside the car | I started fiddling with the seatbelt, not paying attention to the road, until the buckle clicked into place—I realized then we were heading up toward the bridge. I heard him say: "I want to check out the fish market and also Music Corner. Want to come along?" I said: "Yes."
[1976-04-26 10:40:00] inside the car | I saw him steering with one hand, the other resting on the gearshift, a lit cigarette between his fingers—driving fast, as he always did.
[1976-04-26 10:45:00] beside the Videsholmens Shipyard | I saw the Videsholmens Shipyard to my left, with its enormous lizard-shaped cranes and glass halls. The parking lot outside was mostly empty. I knew there was a huge oil platform here, and that a deep-water concrete structure would be launched next week.
[1976-04-26 10:50:00] Songe Road | After passing through a small passage, we drove onto the road toward Songe, when he glanced at me. "You were out with Karl Larsdal today?" he said. "No," I said, "they're in town." "Maybe we'll run into them—wait and see," he said.
[1976-04-26 10:55:00] inside the car | He looked at me. I heard him say: "We'll always find a place." Then silence again. It puzzled me—he was in such a good mood, I should say something. But what? After a while I got an idea. I said: "Where are you going to park the car?"
[1976-04-26 10:56:00] inside the car | I said: "Not on top of the skating rink, I hope? There's always space there on Saturdays." He said: "Only if there's no other choice. Understand?"
[1976-04-26 11:10:00] Tiholmen / Fish Market | I saw him find a spot at Tiholmen. He strode ahead with long legs between the tall wooden houses, and I had to jog to keep up. I watched carefully to see if they were staring at me or laughing. Inside the fish market, Dad scanned all the glass counters while waiting in line for his turn. I felt ashamed of my shabby clothes; among them, I looked like a fool.
[1976-04-26 11:20:00] Fish Market | I nodded. I stayed silent. He smiled, looking at me. I heard him say: "We'll take some shrimp, what do you say?" He added: "Maybe some cod too." He said: "I know you don't like cod. But it's good for you. When you grow up, you'll come to like it." I said: "I seriously doubt that."
[1976-04-26 11:25:00] Fish Market | I wanted so much to talk about everything related to me, the way I told Mom, but with him, I already backed down inside. Still, I was very happy he had brought me along—and more importantly, he knew I was happy.
[1976-04-26 11:30:00] Fish Market | It was his turn. I saw him point to what he wanted from the counter. One of the women behind the counter stared at him. When she noticed me watching her, she lowered her eyes and continued wrapping the fish lying on the wooden board before her. Back then, something about my father, something connected to him as he pointed at fish and spoke, made me think: he was trying to shake off, to get rid of, everything surrounding him. Not his appearance—the unshaven face, pale blue eyes, lips slightly twisted—but something else, something that radiated outward from him.
[1976-04-26 11:40:00] Mosgen (Pollen) | I saw him carrying the white bag with shrimp and fish. As we walked toward the music corner, beside him, I did little hurdle-like jumps to show I was happy. When he looked at me, I smiled. I heard him say, as he took the change: "Alright, now—we're off!"
[1976-04-26 11:50:00] Music Corner | I saw him smooth his hair back with his hand. I nodded and took the bag, while his fingers quickly flipped through the records. In the music corner, I heard him say: "Can you hold the bag for me?" I felt the wind coming from the bay, messing up his hair.
[1976-04-26 11:55:00] music corner | I knew that after we went to sleep, they usually played music, especially on Friday and Saturday nights. When he was alone in his office, he often put on records too. Gretevik once said that he brought a Pink Floyd record to class and played it for them. He spoke of it with reverence.
[1976-04-26 12:00:00] music corner | Dad suddenly said, "Don't you want to pick out a cassette for yourself?" I said, "But I don't have a tape player." He replied, "You can borrow Henrik Inge's, and besides, by Christmas you can have one of your own. So it's good to have some tapes ready. What use is an empty tape player!"
[1976-04-26 12:05:00] music corner | I hesitantly walked over to the cassette tapes. Unlike records, they weren’t kept in boxes; instead, they were hung on shelves mounted on the wall. One of them contained only Elvis songs. I could picture him on the cover, dressed in leather, guitar resting on his knee, smiling broadly.
[1976-04-26 12:10:00] music corner | Dad bought two records and carried them to the counter, telling the clerk I would also be picking out a cassette. I saw the clerk take a small key and walk over to the shelf. I pointed at the Elvis tape, and he unlocked it, took it down, placed it in a small bag, and set the little bag beside Dad’s larger one.
[1976-04-26 12:20:00] on the way | As we walked toward the car, I heard Dad say, "Good choice, Elvis—did you know he was my favorite singer when I was young? We used to call him Elleville Presseløs. I still have some of his old records at Grandma and Grandpa’s place. Maybe we’ll go get them sometime? Then you could listen to them."
[1976-04-26 12:25:00] on the way | I said, "Yeah, that would be great—maybe Henrik Inge would like to listen too." I glanced over toward Rocky, I heard him say, "These days, those old records are quite valuable." I saw the giant oil tankers moored in Galtisund. They were so massive they nearly touched the low dock, seeming as if they came from another world.
[1976-04-26 12:30:00] inside the car | Dad opened the door for me on my side. He placed the records on the back seat, lit a cigarette before fastening his seatbelt, while I had already buckled up. Then the car started moving. I said, "Can I still sit in front?" He said, "Yes. But just today. Understand?" I said, "Understood."
locations: near Kristine Lof and Karl Larsdal·B.'s house

text:
[1976-04-26 12:45:00] on the way home | On the way home, I sat there, sometimes looking at the cassette cover, sometimes gazing out the window. I saw the long pier jammed with traffic, only clearing up gradually as we reached the lower area on the other side... crossing the bay—the sea flecked with white foam... but on land, the road wound and twisted... everything trembling slightly in the wind coming from the south.
[1976-04-26 12:50:00] inside the car | Suddenly, thoughts of Ingeborg Lofnes flooded back, and my mood sank again. Maybe it was because of that deep-water concrete structure—if only I could have taken them both up to the bridge to see how they were dragged through the water. That won’t happen now. Or maybe it still could? She hasn’t been to my room yet. Every night before falling asleep, I imagine her sitting there, on my bed, surrounded by my things—this thought always sends fireworks exploding inside me—Ingeborg Lofnes, here, with me!
[1976-04-26 12:55:00] inside the car | I saw below us the bay connecting east and west. A small boat was heading toward land, nearing the shore—I spotted a figure at the stern, gripping the rudder. I wondered why Kristine Lof had replaced me, going to her instead. How happy we were together! Kristine Lof must disappear. The two of us must make up again. But how can we make that happen?
[1976-04-26 13:00:00] the driveway | Dad signaled a left turn, the blinker flashing as the car slowed. After two cars passed, he drove across the intersection and onto the final uphill stretch leading to the house. I saw Toya Moen, Helen Stergåsen, Karlsen, Thomas Linddal, Karl Larsdal·B., Karl Larsdal, and Viktor Lunddal playing football on the road. As we drove past, they looked our way while the car turned into the driveway. I stepped out of the car and raised my hand high in the air toward them.
[1976-04-26 13:01:00] the driveway | I shook my head. I heard Viktor Lunddal shout, “Aren’t you coming to play football?” I said, “No, it’s time for dinner.”
[1976-04-26 13:02:00] the driveway | Walking toward the house, just out of their sight, I felt Dad grab my hand. Then he let go. I heard him say, “Let me see, haven’t those warts gone away yet?” I said, “No.”
[1976-04-26 13:03:00] the driveway | I heard him say, “Do you know how to get rid of them?” I said, “No.” He said, “Let me tell you. I’ve got an old remedy. Come to the kitchen later, I’ll tell you all about it. You want to get rid of them, don’t you?” I said, “Yes.”
[1976-04-26 18:00:00] bedroom / kitchen | After going upstairs, the first thing I did was throw my dirty trousers and sweater into the laundry basket and change back into the clothes I’d worn that morning. Then I placed the cassette cover face-out against the wall on the top of my desk. After that, I went down to the kitchen, where Dad was sitting with a small plate of shrimp in front of him. Mom was outside in the living room watering the plants.
[1976-04-26 18:05:00] kitchen | I saw him stand up, open the fridge, take out a small white packet, place it on the table, and unwrap it. It was bacon. I heard Dad say, “We’ve just enough time to do this before you eat. It’s almost like some kind of magic trick. When I was little, my grandmother used to do this for me. It really works. Back then, I had warts all over my hands. A few days later, they were completely gone.” I asked, “What did she do?” He said, “Just wait and see.”
[1976-04-26 18:10:00] kitchen | I held out one hand. He took it in his, picked up a strip of bacon, and carefully rubbed it over all my fingers, the back of my hand, and my palm. I heard him say, “First I’ll rub the bacon over your fingers. Then we’ll go out to the garden and bury the bacon in the soil. Your warts will be gone in a few days.” I asked, “Really?” He said, “Yes! It’s truly amazing! The warts really disappear—just wait and see! Now hold out your paw.”
[1976-04-26 18:12:00] kitchen | I held out my other hand. He took another strip of bacon and repeated the process. I nodded. I heard him say, “That hand.” He asked, “Did I cover everywhere?”
[1976-04-26 18:15:00] kitchen / garden | I followed him downstairs, put on my boots without letting them touch my hands, and walked behind him—he carried a shovel—as we went around the house and into a vegetable patch beside the fence facing the woods. I heard him say, “Now we’ll go outside. You have to take the bacon out and bury it in the ground.”
[1976-04-26 18:20:00] garden | I saw him drive the shovel into the soil, press it down with his foot, and begin digging. A few minutes later, he stopped. I did as he told me, and then he dug a few more shovelfuls before we returned inside. I heard him say, “Now you can put the bacon in.”
[1976-04-26 18:25:00] kitchen | I asked, "Can I wash my hands now?" He said, "Yes, it's the bacon we buried that will get rid of the warts." I asked, "How long will this actually take?" He said, "Hmm... a week or two. It depends on how much you believe in it."
[1976-04-26 19:00:00] the road | After dinner I went back out onto the road. I saw that no one was playing football anymore, but Karlsen, Viktor Lunddal, and Toya Moen were still outside. They were running toward the wall by the roadside to see how far up they could climb before falling down. I thought that if they ran fast enough, maybe by the third or fourth step upward, gravity would take over and pull them down. If someone got higher up, he’d fall backward flat on his back—so this was a game that required caution.
[1976-04-26 19:10:00] the road | For the first time—and the only time—I proceeded very carefully, because just before me, Karlsen had fallen into the ditch by the roadside due to overconfidence. With a thud, all the air seemed to be knocked out of his chest. He let out a shrill, distorted cry to refill the empty space in his lungs, while fighting back tears, as if still wanting to carry on.
[1976-04-26 19:15:00] the road | I saw Karlsen get back on his feet, turn his body sideways with his back facing us, gasping for breath. When he turned around again, everyone could see that he had been crying, but no one said anything. I heard Viktor Lunddal ask, "So, what do we do now?" I wondered why no one spoke up. If it had been me crying, they surely would have said something.
[1976-04-26 19:20:00] the road | I saw Klepp ride up from down the slope on his bicycle. He wore a black coat and a black hat. His bike swayed slightly from side to side, and his loose, red cheeks jiggled back and forth just like the two Hagakollen grocery bags hanging from either end of his handlebars. Now he had turned onto the road where we were standing, so I had my chance. I ran alongside him for a bit, pretending to peer into the bags on his handlebars. I shouted to the others, "There are beer bottles in the bags!" I knew he was Håvard’s father. Håvard was a boy who lived in the house farthest from ours, already seventeen years old—an older figure we admired, though we rarely saw him. There were rumors that his father was an alcoholic.
[1976-04-26 19:25:00] the road | I saw that Klepp didn’t pay much attention to me. But the others laughed.
[1976-04-27 10:00:00] Karl Larsdal's house | I knew their house was identical to mine—same room layout, same orientation—but still vastly different. For them, the home was arranged purely for practicality: chairs needed to be comfortable to sit on, not merely pleasing to look at. Our house, by contrast, stood almost as a symbol of constant cleanliness, while their tables and floors were cluttered with things left wherever they’d been used. Their way of living had become part of the house itself, just as ours had—but we lived in completely different ways. The next day we sat in Karl Larsdal’s room, writing love letters to Ingeborg Lofnes.
[1976-04-27 10:10:00] Karl Larsdal's house | I knew it was nearly unimaginable for Karl Larsdal’s father to work alone with tools—he always involved Karl Larsdal and Gro as much as possible in whatever he was doing. Downstairs they had a carpentry workbench where nails could be hammered, wood planed, glue applied, and surfaces sanded smooth. If we wanted, say, to build a wheelbarrow or what we called a go-kart, we’d go to him first. Their garden wasn’t as neat, orderly, or symmetrical as ours—the result of my father dedicating all his time to perfection—but grew more naturally, organized entirely around utility. For example, an unsightly compost heap occupied a large portion of their yard. Similarly, behind their house grew a dense patch of bare, weed-like potato plants, whereas behind ours lay a lawn and a circular rhododendron bush.
[1976-04-27 10:20:00] Karl Larsdal's house | I knew that Karl Larsdal’s room was in the same position as mine, his sister Gro’s room corresponding exactly to Henrik Inge’s room, and his parents’ room located between them, just like in our house. Karl Larsdal could move freely between all the rooms, running up and down the stairs at will. If he wanted a piece of bread, he could take whatever toppings he liked from the fridge and spread them himself.
[1976-04-27 10:30:00] Karl Larsdal's house | I could do the same there—if I wanted, I could move freely between their rooms or make myself a piece of bread with Karl Larsdal. We often sat in the living room listening to his record of Knutsen & Ludvigsen, laughing frequently—at the record, or at Karl Larsdal, who not only knew every lyric by heart but could also imitate their tone and performance style perfectly. Karl Larsdal didn’t play football; he was poor at all ball games, partly due to lack of coordination, but also because of disinterest. I sensed he would never feel, as I did, that surge of excitement throughout my whole body when playing football. I often spent entire afternoons kicking a ball around on muddy ground, and when dusk fell and everyone left, I felt a deep sense of loss and longing—emotions completely foreign to him.
[1976-04-27 10:40:00] school / Karl Larsdal's house | At school, he wasn't doing well either. He had poor reading skills and was slow with numbers. It was hard for him to repeat or express anything he'd read or heard in class, but he managed to get by. For him, he didn't rely on football or school. Because he was good at imitation, a group of people began gathering around him—they would stand there listening to him talk about school. He enjoyed it; laughter made him lose himself, like pouring oil on fire, making his words grow more and more exaggerated. But even this wasn't something he truly depended on. It was as if he had a small world entirely his own.

[1976-04-27 10:50:00] Karl Larsdal's house | For example, drawing. He could sit in his room and draw all day long. Or build model airplanes—this was another thing he often did. He would let out loud, crude bursts of laughter, sometimes even hysterical fits that were impossible to control. He loved farting—maybe far more than others—and he’d experiment with it, even discussing it openly with people.
[1976-04-27 11:00:00] Karl Larsdal's house | I write this letter while he draws a picture. In the drawing, a boy is stepping on a heart, and two other boys are standing by watching. Beneath the drawing, I write in red ink: Kristine Lof broke our hearts. I know he has an older sister, Gro, which might be why he wasn’t shut out from the world of girls the way I was from the beginning. Still, the idea of love letters excited him.
[1976-04-27 11:05:00] Karl Larsdal's house | The letter itself has five lines: Dear Ingeborg Lofnes, we are heartbroken. Come back to us. Can you hear how much we love you?
[1976-04-27 11:30:00] below Ingeborg Lofnes's window | We held the letter and the drawing like two contracts, rolled them together, and went up toward her place. From the cliff above where Mrs. Jæren lived, we entered the area beneath her window. We tossed a small pebble at the window, and she appeared. First, we showed her the drawing. She smiled at us, so we tore both the letter and the drawing into pieces, stomped on them with our feet, then left. We couldn't give the drawing and the letter to Ingeborg Lofnes because, as far as we knew, she might show them to others—even people at school—and then everyone would laugh at us. So we decided to only show them to her.
[1976-04-27 11:40:00] near Ingeborg Lofnes's house | Now we know she at least understands our feelings. Now everything depends on her.
[1976-04-27 11:50:00] crossroads | Karl Larsdal stopped at the crossroads. I shook my head. I said, 'I'm going over to Vimd,' he said, 'Or do you want to come along?' As I walked down, I thought I should also go visit a new friend. Maybe Marivik Christian? But that seemed a bit strange, not quite natural, so I decided to go home instead.
[1976-04-27 14:00:00] bedroom | I was lying in bed reading for a while when Henrik Inge came in and asked if I wanted to go outside and kick a ball around. I wanted to. Nothing pleased me more than being with Henrik Inge. Most often, we played chess indoors or listened to music together, but once outside, we usually split up—he with his friends, me with mine—except during holidays, when we’d play football, table tennis, or badminton together. Situations like this one were purely accidental, happening only when he felt bored and had no other friends nearby except me.
[1976-04-27 14:30:00] on the road | We stayed there for over an hour, kicking the ball back and forth between us. At one point, Henrik Inge shot the ball toward me, and I practiced kicking it away. Then we continued passing it to each other.
[1976-05-15 10:00:00] at home | My warts are gone. They kept getting smaller, and after about three weeks, they disappeared completely. The skin on my hands became so smooth.
[1976-05-20 10:00:00] school / home | But Ingeborg Lofnes never came back. Before, when I took off her hat or tugged at her scarf, or suddenly covered her eyes from behind, she would let out frightened screams, but now she became annoyed, even angry. When I saw her walking toward the bus with Lilund, Kristine Lof, and Karl Larsdal·B., my heart ached. Every night before falling asleep, I imagined how I might save their souls, or make her understand everything in some other way—make her realize her mistakes and change her mind. Or else I imagined that if I were already dead and she realized she actually wanted to be with me, but it was too late—
[1976-05-20 22:00:00] in fantasy | Now I am already lying in a coffin surrounded by flowers. Great sorrow and regret will fill her completely. During that time, death was a sweet thought—not only because Ingeborg Lofnes would regret what she had done, but also because Dad surely would feel the same. They stand before my coffin, weeping for my early death. The entire housing estate gathers there, and everyone’s thoughts are about me. They will reassess who I was, and because I no longer exist, the person I actually was will become clearer and sharper in people’s memories than ever before. Yes, death is sweet and beautiful, a tremendous comfort.
[1976-05-25 10:00:00] school / home | Though I was sad about Ingeborg Lofnes, she was still there—I could see her at school every day. As long as she was there, there was hope, however slight. Thinking of her plunged me into a kind of darkness, entirely different from the waves of gloom that sometimes swept over me—this one brought complete dejection, making me lose interest in everything. Karl Larsdal noticed it too.
[1976-05-25 19:00:00] Karl Larsdal's house | One evening we sat in his room, and he asked me what was wrong. "Nothing special," I said. "You're completely silent," he said. "Am I?" I said, "I'm just very, very unhappy." "Why?" "I don't know. Nothing special. I just can't get myself together."
[1976-05-25 19:05:00] Karl Larsdal's house | "I feel like that sometimes too," he said. "You do?" "Yes." "You just feel bad inside, but don't know why?" "Yes, sometimes I feel exactly like that." "I don't understand," I said, "I didn't know other people felt that way too."
[1976-05-25 19:10:00] Karl Larsdal's house | "Let's call it that," he said, "'like that.' When we feel like that, we can just say it. 'Now I'm like that,' for example—and the other person immediately understands." "That's a good idea," I said.
[1976-05-26 10:00:00] the mountaintop | "This is called intercourse," I told him. "But you mustn't say you heard it from me! You have to swear!" He swore. Other new words appeared too, like the real name for mating, which Henrik Inge taught me—"intercourse." The word was so powerful that I didn’t dare tell Karl Larsdal until I’d taken him up to the top of the mountain.
[1976-05-28 16:00:00] Karl Larsdal's house / Vemund's house | I told him this. Why do you hang out with Vemund? He’s fat and stupid—the worst kid in class. He never answered me seriously, only saying he liked being there. Why? I asked again. What great things can you possibly do together? Nothing, Karl Larsdal said—we mostly just sit there drawing... Besides, he spent more time with Vemund upstairs, and sometimes Vemund came up to his place too. I didn’t understand it at all.
[1976-05-30 10:00:00] school / Vemund's house | Even in class, when the teacher asked us to work in pairs, sometimes he went to Vemund instead of me—he always used to choose me before. A few times I followed him up to Vemund’s place, just to get closer to Ingeborg Lofnes. But I found what they were doing utterly dull and boring. When I suggested doing something else, they insisted on continuing as they were. I didn’t care—if he wanted to hang out with the dumbest kid in class, let him.
[1976-06-01 10:00:00] on the road / Hovet | We were still neighbors, and he often came down to me in the afternoons. Also, when spring began, we started playing football together. Almost all the kids on our street played. Training was at Hovet, and my mother and Karl Larsdal’s mother took turns driving us there.
[1976-06-05 10:00:00] home | When I first started training, Mom bought me a jersey. This was my very first jersey. I had high hopes for it—imagining it might be a shiny blue Adidas, like Henrik Inge’s, or even better, a Puma, or at least something from Hummel or Admiral. But the one she brought home didn’t have any brand at all. It was a brown tracksuit with white stripes. Though I thought the color was ugly, that wasn’t even the worst part. The fabric had no shine—it was dull and coarse, poorly made. It wasn’t a comfortable fit; instead, it clung tightly to my body, making my hips stick out in an embarrassingly noticeable way.

[1976-06-05 16:00:00] the field | When I wore this training jersey, it was all I could think about. Even as I ran onto the field and began practice, it was still the only thing on my mind. My butt sticking out like a balloon, I thought, as I ran after the ball. My training jersey is brown and hideous, I thought. I must look like a fool wearing it, I thought. Fool, fool, fool.
[1976-06-05 18:00:00] home | So I said, 'Ah, this shirt is great. Really beautiful. Exactly what I wanted.' But I would never tell Mom how I really felt. When I received the jersey, I pretended to be happy because it must have cost her quite a bit, and she’d gone around town searching for it just for me. If I told her I didn’t like it, she’d feel unappreciated, and worse, she’d feel bad for failing to get it right. I didn’t want that to happen.
[1976-06-05 18:05:00] the field | There were many kids on the field, a swarm of arms, legs, and heads chasing the ball like mosquitoes. The coach could name only a few of them—mostly neighbors from his own district, probably his sons and their friends. One incredible thing about spring training was how vastly different my inner self was from the version of me on the field. My heart was packed full of thoughts and emotions—I wanted to score, to dribble past others, but also kept thinking how terrible my training jersey was, how prominent my big hips were, not to mention my protruding buckteeth—while out on the field, I ran around almost entirely unnoticed.
[1976-06-07 19:00:00] woods beside the field | My first moment of triumph happened one evening when someone kicked the ball into the woods behind the goal, and it disappeared. Everyone went into the woods to search. For two or perhaps three minutes, we all searched intently. No one found it. Then suddenly, there it was, right in front of me, glowing white under a bush in the twilight. All I did was kick it back onto the field. I walked out of the woods with everyone else, saying nothing. I knew this was my chance. I should have shouted, 'I found it!' and carried the ball proudly back to the field—then the honor would have been mine. But I couldn’t do it. And so it remained a mystery.
[1976-06-10 19:30:00] the field | About ten or twelve meters from the goal, I was running among a group of players. The ball was there, everyone crowded in, limbs crashing together, everything chaotic. Suddenly, the ball popped up just a meter away from me. I threw myself forward with all I had, and the ball flew straight off the post and into the net. I didn’t say anything, didn’t move—I just stood there quietly. 'Goal!' someone shouted. 'Who scored?' 'Whose goal was it? Nobody?' the coach called out. 'No! Then let’s keep going!' The second time was similar, though it felt more like a gift handed straight to me.
[1976-06-10 19:45:00] the field | Maybe they thought it was one of their own defenders who scored, so no one claimed it. Though I didn’t dare say it was me, it was my first-ever goal. For the rest of practice, and even on the car ride home, my heart was filled with light.
[1976-06-10 20:00:00] in the car | As we ran toward the car, Mom was already sitting inside waiting for me. The first thing I said was that I had scored. 'I scored a goal!' I said. 'That’s great!' Mom replied.
[1976-06-10 20:30:00] kitchen | After we got home, when I sat down at the kitchen table for dinner, I said it again. 'I scored today!' 'Were you playing a match?' Henrik Inge asked. 'No,' I said, 'we haven’t started matches yet. It was just training.' 'Then it doesn’t count,' he said.
[1976-06-10 20:35:00] kitchen | A few tears welled up and rolled down my cheeks. Dad stared at me with a stern, angry look. That’s when I truly began to cry. 'You can’t cry over something like this!' he said. 'You need to toughen up and endure such little things!'
[1976-06-10 21:00:00] home | I cry easily—that's a big problem. I always cry when someone scolds me, or treats me unfairly, or even when I think they might. Dad makes me cry most often. As soon as his voice rises, I start to cry, even though I know that’s probably what he hates most. But I can’t help it. The moment he raises his voice—which he usually does—I begin to tear up. I’ve never cried because of Mom. Throughout my entire childhood, it happened only twice. Both times were during the period when I started playing football.
[1976-06-12 20:00:00] the woods below | I went down to the woods below with a group of people. We gathered together, standing in a circle... For a long time, I just stood there listening... Then suddenly, a gap appeared—one I could step into. I heard seagulls shrieking from Yube Bay and saw that the sky still held some light, though darkness had begun creeping across the ground and beneath the trees in the lower woods.
[1976-06-12 20:10:00] the woods below | I said, 'I’m the smartest in my class, at least in reading and writing... I learned to read when I was five—earlier than anyone else in my class... Take Edmund, for example—he’s four years older than me, but he can’t read at all!... That’s not lying, is it?'
[1976-06-12 20:12:00] the woods below | I saw tears welling up in Edmund’s eyes. He stumbled slightly, turned around, and began walking uphill. I heard Henrik Inge say, 'Now you shut up, you show-off.' I said, 'But it’s true, isn’t it, Edmund?'
[1976-06-12 20:15:00] the woods below / on the path | I felt him place his hand on my arm and push me aside. I heard Henrik Inge whisper to me, 'What are you doing?' I said, 'But it’s true—I’m the best in my class, and he’s the worst in his.' Henrik Inge said, 'Go home now. You’re not allowed to stay here with us.' I said, 'You can’t decide that.' He said, 'Shut up and get back!'
[1976-06-12 20:20:00] home | I said, 'Fine, fine,' and started walking up the slope. After passing the crossroads, I dashed through the gate and took off my clothes. When I lay down in bed to read, my eyes filled with tears. I thought, what I said was true—why did he push me? It’s so unfair. I only told the truth. It’s not fair, not fair, not fair.
[1976-06-12 21:00:00] bedroom / kitchen | I showed her the letter I had written to Grandpa... Then she gave me an envelope, I put the letter inside, and she wrote the name and address. She asked if I had been crying. I said yes. She asked why, and I said Henrik Inge pushed me. She said she would talk to him about it. She said Grandpa would be happy to receive the letter and promised to mail it the next day.
[1976-06-12 21:30:00] bedroom | I left there and lay down on my bed. While I was reading, I heard Henrik Inge come home—his footsteps on the stairs, the sound of him entering the kitchen... Then voices, footsteps in the hallway, and the door opening. Lying there, I imagined how she would tell him he shouldn’t have pushed me, shouldn’t have blamed or scolded me. I could almost see Henrik Inge standing there with his head hanging low.
[1976-06-12 21:35:00] bedroom | I immediately saw Mom looking angry and sat up straight. I saw her take a few steps forward, nearly right in front of me. I saw Henrik Inge standing behind her, looking at me. I heard her say, 'Is what Henrik Inge said true? Did you mock Edmund because he can’t read the text?' I nodded. 'Sort of.' She said, 'Don’t you realize Edmund would feel hurt?... Grete Lundnes, don’t you understand?' I heard Henrik Inge say, 'He cried—you made him cry. Do you understand that?'
[1976-06-12 21:40:00] bedroom | I began to cry—a kind of crying I’d never experienced before. I felt Mom lean over me and gently stroke my cheek with one hand. I sobbed, 'Aaaaaa, waaahhh waaahhh waaahhh.' I choked out, 'I’m sorry, Mom. I’ll never do anything like that again. Never. I swear it with my whole heart.' Suddenly, I understood completely. Mom’s words were an unflinching summary of what had happened. It was Edmund who deserved sympathy—even though he was four years older than me. He was hurt—and I had caused that hurt.
[1976-06-12 21:50:00] bedroom | I realized I was crying out loud, those words of apology sounding more like shouts... Mom calmed down, but Henrik Inge didn't... Even though Edmund meant nothing to him... About this, I felt half-understanding, half-confusion.
locations: the woods below / on the path

text:
[1976-06-15 20:00:00] on the road | I held the flashlight... I shone its beam into the dark living room window of a house we were passing. I heard Mom suddenly whisper, “Don’t do that! People live in there! You can’t shine your light into someone’s living room!”
[1976-06-15 20:05:00] on the road | I quickly directed the light back onto the ground, desperately trying to hold back tears for a few seconds, but I completely failed—then came long sobs and whimpers. I heard Mom say, “Is it really that upsetting? If you see something, you have to speak up, understand? What you did wasn’t very polite.” I started crying not because I was scolded, but because it was she who scolded me. But at least she shouldn’t get angry just because I cried.
[1976-06-16 10:00:00] residential area | I know I almost never cry outside. Of course, falling down is an exception... The fact is, no one ever comes specifically to my house looking for me, and this precisely confirms other things beyond my control. I often argue with others, especially Toya Moen... Yet everyone still prefers playing with him rather than with me.
[1976-06-16 14:00:00] residential area | I follow Dalson, Karl Larsdal follows me, and Vemund follows Karl Larsdal. I saw his reluctance in his movements, and soon he disappeared. I said, “I’m supposed to command him! I decide what we do.” Karl Larsdal said, “But you can’t decide what I do.” I said, “What does that matter? Didn’t I just say Dalson commands me? You command Vemund? So what if I command you?”
[1976-06-18 15:00:00] roadside | A huge truck drove past, its trailer loaded with stones blasted and removed from farther up the mountain. I said, “You see? It’s a Mercedes!” I’m not interested in cars, boats, or motorcycles—I know nothing about them—but since everyone else likes them, I feel I must do something, just to show that I also know my way around.
[1976-06-18 15:05:00] roadside | Karl Larsdal said, “It isn’t. Mercedes doesn’t make trucks.” I said, “Well, didn’t you see the star?” He said, “Have you gone completely crazy or what? That’s not a Mercedes star.” I said, “Yes, it is.” Karl Larsdal whistled. He said, “Besides, Mercedes does make trucks. I’ve read it. It’s written in one of my books.” I saw Karlsen’s chubby face instantly grow even fatter than usual.
[1976-06-18 15:10:00] roadside | Karlsen said, “I’d really like to see that book—you lie so easily. You don’t know anything about trucks.” I said, “Can you just talk like that because your dad works with construction machinery?” He said, “Yes, actually, that’s exactly why.” I said, “Oh yeah? Then you think you know all about slalom skiing too... Look at how clumsy you are on skis. What good would another pair of ski gear do for you?... Everyone says you’re spoiled.” He said, “I’m not spoiled—you’re just jealous.”
[1976-06-18 15:15:00] roadside | I saw that Karlsen now not only turned his face away from me but turned his whole body away as well. I said, “Why should I be jealous of you?” Viktor Lunddal said, “Just drop it, Grete Lundnes.” I said, “Why should I drop it instead of Karlsen?” Viktor Lunddal said, “Because Karlsen is right—the truck isn’t a Mercedes. And it’s not only him who has slalom skis. I have them too.”
[1976-06-18 15:20:00] roadside | I said, “It’s only because your dad died—that’s why your mom buys you everything.” Viktor Lunddal said, “No, it’s because she wants to buy things for me.” I said, “Your mom works in a store—that doesn’t pay much.” Toya Moen said, “Then do teachers earn more money? Do you think we haven’t seen your house walls? They’re full of cracks, about to collapse because your dad didn’t know he needed steel reinforcement. He used only cement to plaster! What a blockhead!”
[1976-06-18 15:25:00] roadside | Then they all ran off. Viktor Lunddal said, "He thinks he's someone special just because he's on the city council. When he drove past, he raised one finger to greet us. So now you just shut your mouth." I said, "Why should I shut up?" He said, "No, right—you don't have to shut up... Anyway, we're not playing with you anymore."
[1976-06-18 18:00:00] residential area | I find myself increasingly often suddenly feeling cornered... When I arrive, the others turn away... Yes, sometimes I realize they are avoiding me... They say about me that I always know the most, that I'm always boasting. But the truth is, I do know more—much more than anyone else. Should I pretend not to know, like everyone else? When I know something, then I know it—because that's simply how things are.
[1976-06-18 19:00:00] ball field | I think everyone boasts—that's just what people do... So the problem isn't what I've done, but who I am. Otherwise, why would Helen Ster start calling me 'professional player' when I was just kicking a ball around?... All I did was explain how football should be played... We shouldn't run around in a swarm; we should spread out around the ball, or dribble past opponents instead of crowding together in chaos.
[1976-06-20 10:00:00] school | That spring, I also got the final important role. At the time, since the spring semester was ending and preparations were underway for the year-end celebration, the school rearranged class schedules, and the teacher handed out scripts for the play. Who else but me could possibly get this lead role?... It was me. Me, me, me. None of them could memorize so many lines... But in the end, the teacher chose me—it wasn't by chance.
[1976-06-25 14:00:00] school auditorium | During the final week, we practiced every day... The last day finally arrived, and all the parents came. I saw them dressed in their finest clothes, sitting on chairs along the wall, taking photos with their cameras. When we delivered our lines passionately, the audience fell completely silent, and at the end of the performance, thunderous applause filled the room. I saw the sun shining gloriously. When she gave me the role, I was so happy I didn’t know what to do—I felt almost flustered... Every day, I was the center of attention in class, and the person Ingeborg Lofnes focused on.
[1976-06-25 15:00:00] school playground | We played a tape, sang songs, then received our report cards... Then we ran out onto the playground and down further to where all the cars were parked, waiting for us. I stood somewhat impatiently beside Karl Larsdal by my mother’s Volkswagen Beetle, waiting for her. She walked over with Marta, both laughing and talking, not noticing Karl Larsdal and me until they were only a few meters away.
[1976-06-25 15:10:00] by the car | I saw my mother standing there for a long time, searching through her handbag for the car keys. She opened the door, and we got in—two adults in front, children in the back. Each lit a cigarette. Then we drove home into the sunlight. I heard my mother say, "Finally found it." I saw my mother wearing beige pants, a rust-red sweater with sleeves rolled up below her elbows. Her hair hung long down past her back. On her feet were light brown sandals. She had just turned thirty-two. Marta wore a brown dress and was two years older than my mother.
[1976-06-25 20:00:00] parents' bedroom | I stood in the open doorway, watching my mother dry her hair in their bedroom. Sometimes, when Dad wasn't around, I'd follow her around the house... But now I was quiet... I watched how she lowered her head... Occasionally she glanced at me and smiled. I stepped into the room. On a small table against the wall lay an envelope... I moved closer. It read "Solvevik·Grete Lundnes". I heard the sharp, shrill noise of the hair dryer making speech impossible. I didn't mean to snoop, but even from a distance I could see the name written there was Cecil—the name of my mother—but longer than her name... Something I knew without needing to read it.
[1976-06-25 20:05:00] parents' bedroom | I saw her lower the hand holding the hair dryer, as if to make my voice clearer, and she looked at me. I nodded toward the envelope. She leaned forward and picked it up. She switched off the hair dryer. I said, "Mom!" Then I said, "What's written on that envelope? What kind of name is that?" She asked, "What?" I said, "What's the name!" She said, "It's my name." I said, "But it says Norunn! You're not called Norunn!" She said, "Yes I am. That's my middle name. Solvevik." I said, "Have you always been called that?" She said, "Ye-es. I've been called that my whole life. Didn't you know?" I said, "No! Why have you never told me?" I thought, Norunn? Who is that? I felt my chest tighten with disappointment.
[1976-06-25 20:10:00] parents' bedroom | Tears ran down my cheeks. Mom said, "My dear sweet child, I don't think it matters? Cecil—that's the name I use. Norunn is just a middle name. An extra added name." A tremor passed through me. It wasn't really about the name itself, but that I had known nothing about it. My mother has things I don't know about. Are there even more things I don't know?

[1976-07-15 06:00:00] home | We drove to Sør-Aurdal in the outer Sogn region, to Sørbygda... The car’s trunk was packed full, Mom and Dad sat in front, Henrik Inge and I in the back seat. I had been longing for this day of departure so intensely that I woke up at first light, dazed and wrapped in a sense of unreality... Still, I sensed the difference. Now this journey no longer belonged to our house... Now it belonged to the long expedition we had begun, and I looked forward with anticipation to every cliff and crag, every island and reef.
[1976-07-15 07:00:00] intersection by the bridge | When we reached the intersection by the bridge, I instinctively crossed my hands and folded them together, offering a brief prayer as I always did. I prayed: Dear God. Please, please keep us from having an accident. Amen.
[1976-07-15 10:00:00] Setesdal Valley | We drove deep into the land, through vast, monotonous stretches of bare forest, past the long row of low military barracks at Evje and wide, sparse pine woodlands, then past Byglandsfjord and campgrounds, climbing upward through Setesdal Valley with its old farms and courtyards, and many signs advertising silversmith workshops. At some points along the road, we nearly drove onto private driveways. Gradually, the buildings disappeared, as if finally letting go of us, one after another, like children tied by ropes to a boat who fall off the big life ring one by one as the boat speeds up—until only the life ring remains.
[1976-07-15 12:00:00] Setesdal Valley | I looked toward the bright sandbanks along both sides of the river, and saw green-covered slopes rising ever more steeply into the sky. Occasionally, a bare, massive mountain peak emerged, everything veiled in dark gray tones, yet on some summits stood pines glowing red like flames. I saw rapids and waterfalls, rivers and open fields, all bathed in intense, clear sunlight, while our car climbed higher and higher, as if ascending into the clouds. The road was narrow, following gentle, almost imperceptible undulations of the earth, winding around bends—sometimes flanked by trees like walls, other times opening up to sudden, breathtaking views.
[1976-07-15 13:00:00] highway | "Are we going to stop soon?" I might ask when I spotted such rest areas... We also had a cooler in the trunk, a thermos, juice, a stack of plastic cups and plates. Dad would say: "Don't nag." Occasionally along the way there were places where we could pull over to eat—small gravel lots by the roadside where families could sit at rough wooden tables, park their cars nearby, open trunks and doors as widely as possible, usually in the shade of trees and often close to lakes or rivers. Everyone placed their thermoses on the table; many brought coolers, some even portable gas stoves. Because stopping to eat and taking ferries were both highlights of the journey. He was always busy calculating how many more kilometers we needed to drive before stopping... Then we’d have to search for just the right spot. Because the first place we saw wasn’t necessarily a good one—no; since we rarely stopped en route, when we did stop, it had to be somewhere truly special.
[1976-07-15 14:30:00] Haugastøl Mountain | Dad drove faster along this stretch because visibility was high... Without warning, Dad turned on the turn signal, slowed down, and pulled into a rest area. When Henrik Inge saw them, he said this. Up on the mountain, the terrain became quite flat. No trees or bushes were visible. The road stretched straight ahead like a rope. Some parts were strewn with stones... Other sections consisted of clean, level, water-smoothed rock. Between them shimmered patches of water, and dazzling brightness came from snowfields. Along both sides of the road stood tall icicles—so long they were characteristic of the place, since winter snow could remain unmelted atop them year-round. These icicles were several meters long! The sun shone brightly, and the mountain plateau unfolded in every direction as we rushed past.
[1976-07-15 14:45:00] lakeside rest stop | Dad opened the trunk, took out the cooler, and set it on a rough wooden table. Mom immediately began unpacking everything inside. Dad also brought over the bag containing cups and plates. Henrik Inge and I ran to the water’s edge, bent down, and dipped our hands into the lake. The rest stop sat directly to the right of the lake—an oval body of water, entirely black. On the opposite side, the mountains rose slightly higher, but on the lower side stood a huge snowdrift, almost blue in color, hollow beneath, where the water disappeared into an opening. Complete silence surrounded us. After so many hours accompanied by the constant roar of the engine, this silence felt false, as if it didn’t belong to the landscape but to us instead. Bone-chilling cold!
[1976-07-15 14:50:00] lakeside rest stop | Henrik Inge and I walked over to the snowdrift. It was so hard we couldn’t shape it into snowballs as we’d imagined. We weren’t allowed to step into the icy water beneath the ice cave while Mom and Dad were watching. I scooped up a piece of snow and threw it into the water. It floated and bobbed on the surface like a tiny iceberg. Dad said: "Kids, aren't we going for a swim here?" I said: "Ah, no, the water's freezing!" He said: "Are you all wimps?" I said: "But the water really is ice-cold!" He replied: "Alright, alright, I know. I was just joking. We don't have time to swim here." I thought that when we got home, at least I could say we threw snowballs in July.
[1976-07-15 15:00:00] lakeside rest stop | Mom called out: "Come, time to eat." We sat down. Each of us had our own lunchbox. At that moment, a car roared up behind me, the sound growing louder, beginning to vibrate, then fading with a rumble until it finally vanished completely. Our cups were filled with juice. The plastic gave it a different taste, but I liked it—it reminded me of our car trips to pick strawberries and of camping outings. Actually, we hadn’t taken many such trips; in fact, only once—last summer, when we traveled to Mochengdao with Grandma and Grandpa.
[1976-07-15 15:10:00] lakeside rest stop | I saw a car towing a trailer coming from the opposite side of the road. My eyes followed them as I poured the last drop of juice from the bottle. The turn signal began flashing. As the car turned into the rest area, Dad turned around. I saw the steam rising from Mom and Dad’s coffee cups.
[1976-07-15 15:12:00] lakeside rest stop | He pulled out a cigarette case decorated with a fox pattern from his shirt pocket. The car towing the caravan stopped just a few meters away from us. The door opened, and a fat man wearing beige shorts, a T-shirt, and a fisherman's hat stepped out. He opened the door of the caravan and disappeared inside, while at the same time a woman got out from the other side of the car. She was also fat, wearing light-blue elastic pants with pressed creases down the legs and a woolen sweater. A cigarette dangled unlit from her mouth; her hair was thick, a mix of yellow and gray, and she wore large glasses with thin black lenses over her eyes. She walked to the water’s edge and stood there, gazing ahead as she lit her cigarette. He said, "What’s this fool doing coming here? There’s only one table, didn’t he see it?"
[1976-07-15 15:15:00] lakeside rest stop | I started eating my last piece of bread. I saw the man come out holding a folding camping table. He unfolded it and set it up between his car and our table. I saw Dad drink the last sip of coffee from his cup and stand up. Dad turned around again. "Do they not understand how things are done here?" he said. "We’re sitting here eating. Does he just shove himself right in like that?" "It doesn’t matter," Mom said. "This place is nice enough." "It *was* nice enough," Dad said, "until this fool showed up." "He’ll hear you," Mom said. "They’re from Oswick," Dad said. "They can’t understand us. We can say whatever we want." "Well, now we should get going."
[1976-07-15 15:20:00] lakeside rest stop | I saw him toss away his still half-burning cigarette, pick up the coffee cup and drink cans, walk to the water, rinse them, then put them along with the plates and thermos into a bag. He closed the lid of the cooler and put everything into the car’s trunk. The man and the woman said something I couldn’t understand, looking toward the gentle slope on the far side of the water. He pointed. I saw something moving far off. Mom crumpled up the food wrapping paper, stuffed it into a bag, and stood up. "The kids haven’t finished eating yet," Mom said. "Do we really need to rush?" "Not really," Dad said. "Well then, finish up. But hurry." "Now we’re leaving," Mom said. "We’ll eat the biscuits at the next break."
[1976-07-15 15:25:00] inside the car | I saw Dad push the front seat forward for me, and I climbed in. Henrik Inge climbed in from the other door. He wrinkled his nose. Henrik Inge said, "I don’t think the motion sickness pills are working." "Then tell us if you feel sick," Mom said. "It won’t help if you keep smoking like this," he said. "Shut up, boy," Dad said. "Don’t complain. We’re on vacation now." This was exactly what I had feared would happen. After breathing fresh air outside, the heavy smoke smell inside the car felt especially unpleasant.
[1976-07-15 15:30:00] inside the car | The car slowly moved back onto the road. As we passed the lakeside, I looked into the distance, toward the direction the man had been pointing. I nudged Henrik Inge and pointed out the window to draw his attention outside. I said, "What is that?" He said, "Maybe reindeer—we saw them last year too, don’t you remember?" I said, "I remember, but they were so close then. This one’s tiny, like a mouse, over there!" There was definitely something out there. Against the green backdrop, a grayish shape was slowly moving. Who knows what it could be? Then we sank into the almost trance-like, dazed state that long car rides can bring.

[1976-07-15 17:00:00] Odda | We drove through... The car passed over the remaining mountains, descending into Nore village, then further into the town of Odda—a dirty little place at the very end of the Hardangerfjord, marked by decay and pollution... I realized that a person will sometimes encounter a towering peak rising abruptly before them, dominating everything with its purity and simplicity, making all other details of the landscape bow before it, vanish completely, utterly disappear... It was fundamentally, incomprehensibly different from the world we had left just hours earlier. The southern landscape was mostly made up of low rocky cliffs and scattered, uneven patches of woodland... On the island where I lived, the highest mountain was less than one hundred twenty meters tall... Who would care about a birch tree—even an unusually tall one—when standing beneath these magnificent, immovable mountains?
[1976-07-15 18:00:00] Hardangerfjord | I noticed the colors here seemed more intense, deeper—the green nowhere as rich, dense, vivid, and luminous as in this western region—not even the sky, which here appeared bluer and clearer than the sky back where I came from. The valley sides were lush and thick with trees; in spring and early summer, fruit trees bloomed with white cherry blossoms like snow, mountain peaks veiled in hazy blue, snow gleaming everywhere. And nestled among these mountains—between the peaks rising on either side of the valley—lay a fjord, its waters deep, just as the mountains beside it were high.
[1976-07-15 19:00:00] Hardangerfjord | Then we drove up along the northern side of the fjord... I saw that every detail was unfamiliar—the electric gate, the red barns, the old white wooden houses, cows grazing, long rows of hayracks standing upright, stretching up along both sides of the valley. Tractors, mowers, manure pits, brown rubber boots placed by the front doors, large shady trees in the yards, horses, ordinary homes with small shops run out of their basements. Children sold cherries and strawberries by the roadside, with handwritten signs on little tables. Driving through such scenery always makes a strong impression, because you can never predict, based on what you see one second, what you’ll see the next. Life here was unlike life back home: I could see an old woman bent over, wearing a dress with big flowers and a shawl—something you’d never see where we lived—or an old man, stooped and dressed in blue, wearing a black brimmed hat, standing in a field or walking along a gravel path—also unseen back home.
[1976-07-15 19:30:00] Hardangerfjord | Place names... Tyssedal, Eidfjord, Holme, Skei, Borgund, Uppstad, Ulvik, Lofthus, Kinsarvik. Among the many impressions this place left on me, the place names formed a significant part... Their strange sounds delighted me most. 'Vik' means bay, but what does 'Kinsar' truly mean? No matter how vivid the colors, no matter how varied the details, an overwhelming sense of vastness hung over this region—not merely surrounding the people and their activities, but enveloping their entire living space, as though the space itself were too immense for them... We didn’t stop anywhere, except when Henrik Inge wandered off at a bus station to vomit. We were strangers here, knew no one, so nothing we saw had any connection to us.
[1976-07-15 20:00:00] Kinsarvik dock | When we finally arrived at the Kinsarvik dock, Dad parked the car in line and we got out... Children carefully kicked a ball around beside the queue, or, like Henrik Inge and me, walked toward the little kiosk at the far end, wondering if we could spend some of our holiday pocket money there. By then, we no longer felt that earlier atmosphere. Quite the opposite—everything here felt pleasant, comfortable...
[1976-07-15 20:10:00] Kinsarvik Harbor | Henrik Inge bought a boat-shaped ice cream, and I bought a barrel-shaped one, complete with a little red shovel. We held them in our hands as we slowly walked toward the dock. We sat down on the stone edge, looking at the seawater below and a thick, wet cluster of seaweed clinging to the rocks. We saw the ferry entering the harbor from far across. I smelled the air filled with saltwater, seaweed, grass blades, and exhaust fumes, and felt the sun burning hotly on our faces.
[1976-11-01 11:30:00] Home / Basement | I know that when it comes to housework, they share responsibilities more equally than the parents of my friends; Dad takes care of cleaning and cooking. I remember hundreds of kilograms of various berries we picked along the roadside during our summer and autumn drives through the forests and fields of Leivik. I know they later turned those berries into juice and jam. I remember raspberries, blackberries, blueberries, cranberries, and yellowberries—Dad would let out joyful shouts whenever he found them.
[1976-11-01 11:40:00] Home / Swimming Spot | Everything we eat each day is planned in great detail, orderly and regulated. I know that before we go to school, we always already know how many classes there will be and what subjects they are. Evening activities follow a routine too: when it snows or freezes, yes, that means skiing and skating. And when the underwater temperature rises to fifteen degrees, yes, that’s when we go swimming—rain or shine, no exceptions.
[1976-11-01 11:50:00] Home | I listen to his footsteps on the stairs. I feel that the only truly unpredictable thing in life—from autumn to winter, spring to summer, one school year to the next—is Dad. I am so afraid of him... I’ve never once felt close to him. Is he on his way here now? I look at the savagery in his eyes. The drooping mouth, the unconscious parting of his lips. And his voice.
