[1977-09-25 16:00:00] Kitchen | I saw my mother sitting in the kitchen reading a book. She put down the book. She smiled. I nodded. "Hi," I said. "Hi," she said, "where have you been?" "Well," I said, "just wandered around a bit. We found some empty bottles and plan to exchange them for money on Monday." "Okay," she said. "Are you going to make pizza tonight?" I said. "I thought so." "That's great!" I said. "Have you read the book you got?" "I started reading it yesterday. It looks pretty good. Actually, I just want to go into the room and continue reading now." "Go ahead," she said, "there's still a quarter of an hour before dinner." I heard the radio was on, and saw that milk porridge was boiling on the stove. One side of the pot was already entirely covered with white milk residue, and there were traces of milk and rice grains on the stove plate, but they had mostly dried up, so I understood that the milk porridge had been cooked properly. Dad said that filling in five correct numbers is as difficult as filling in ten. But if you fill in ten correctly, you can collect money from the Leivik football lottery center, but those who fill in five correctly actually have to pay money, he said. After reading just the first few pages, I knew it was an excellent book. There were a total of twelve matches, with eight rows in each match. Henrik Inge got seven right, and my father got ten, but unfortunately, this time no one would pay the person who got ten right. Because my mother is at home, I am willing to spend as much time with her as possible. On the other hand, as long as she is at home, her presence itself makes my life completely different. At least when she is there, my father would never do anything bad. When she is around, he would never let his irritable and violent temper take over. He would control himself. Even if I am lying in bed and she is sitting in the kitchen, I am still safe. Because I know less than half, I have to decide what to fill in by rolling dice, and the final outcome would not be different anyway.

[1977-09-25 18:10:00] Boathouse Hillside | Karl Larsdal and I ran down the dirt slope and reached the path. We jumped over the stream and sprinted toward the lower incline, crossed a wild field, and passed over the gravel road. As we approached the grassy hillside, we slowed our pace—just then Magnus Nord appeared at the top of the slope, beside that old white house. The earth seemed to tremble beneath our feet. I knew Magnus Nord was two years older than us and often kept to himself—at least that’s how he appeared to us. His high cheekbones, narrow eyes, and slick black hair gave him an Indian-like look, which made him intriguing to the girls. This change had only recently begun. From one day to the next, Magnus Nord became the subject of their whispers and attention. What was strange wasn’t that he suddenly drew interest—he had always existed in some kind of shadow—but rather that the girls spoke about him almost proudly, as if by making such an unusual choice, they themselves had become noteworthy, even more so than him. Yet he continued living his own life, riding his bike aimlessly from place to place, always alone, yet always friendly toward us.

Maybe you could talk about homework. There was nothing else to say. Then suddenly I realized it: clothes—this was an interesting topic. You could talk endlessly about it.
[1978-08-20 19:30:00] Yenhaug Supermarket / playground / football field / Karl Larsdal's house | When I got near Yenhaug Supermarket, I said goodbye to them, ran down the cliff to the playground, where no one was, climbed the grassy slope to the shipwreck site, also empty, then walked to the football field, still deserted, so I climbed over Presbakkmo's yard fence and came to the front of their house, where I rang the doorbell. But Karl Larsdal was having dinner, and afterward he was going up to Vemd. Ah well.
locations: Yenhaug Supermarket / playground / football field / Karl Larsdal's house

text:
[1978-08-20 19:45:00] on the road / floating dock | I ran down the hill, but his bicycle was gone—they must have already left. I began slowly walking down toward the floating dock. The road was also completely empty. There were many clouds in the sky, not so hot anymore; surely no one would be at Naben. It was Sunday, dinnertime. Children were either eating, playing with friends outside, or out with their parents. Suddenly it flashed through my mind: Henrik Inge has visitors! Maybe I could sit in his room and stay with them? What else could I do? It would probably be empty there too, but if there was nowhere else to go, I could go look at the boats and breathe in that special smell of fiberglass, wood, gasoline, and saltwater.
[1978-08-20 20:00:00] floating dock | I quietly joined the group. The boat owners were sitting on their boat decks, spitting into the water while listening to those standing on shore—people without boats, but who were soon getting one. I stood among this crowd. There was a large gathering of people. No. But owning a boat wasn’t my dream—it was too unrealistic, just as unrealistic as waking up the next morning in the Viking Age, like the boy in a book I’d read. No, if I had any dream object, it would be a brand-new pair of white tennis shoes with a light blue Nike logo, like the ones Henrik Inge had, or a pair of light blue Levi’s jeans, or a light blue Catalina jacket. Or maybe a new pair of Puma sneakers, an Admiral tracksuit, an Umbro shorts, or a Speedo swimsuit. The black-and-white Adidas Olympia shoes were what I wanted most. I also wanted shin guards, a Puma bag, Atomic Atom alpine skis and slalom ski boots for winter, an alpine ski pants, and a real down jacket. Splitkein fiberglass skis with new bindings. Light-colored Sami boots, the kind with slightly upturned toes. A new white shirt, a red sweater. I’d rather have white rubber boots instead of the dark blue ones I was wearing now. I also wanted a pale red coral necklace I once saw, or white would do too. I wasn’t very interested in boats, motorcycles, or cars. But since I couldn’t tell anyone that, I still had some favorite brands. Boats: the ten-foot With Dromedille with a five-horsepower Yamaha engine. Motorcycles: Suzuki. Cars: BMW. These brands all started with unusual letters: Y, Z, W. For the same reason, I was also drawn to 'Wolverhampton,' my first supported team, even though Liverpool later replaced it. Wolves still thrilled me—their stadium called Molineux, their emblem a black wolf on an orange background. How could I not love them?
[1978-08-20 20:15:00] floating dock | In one of Henrik Inge's football magazines, I read a comparison between Kevin Keegan and Kenny Dalglish, who was his substitute. I constantly thought about trousers, jackets, sweaters, shoes, and sports gear because I wanted to look good, I wanted to win. When the tennis player Jenssen—who I thought was the best of them all—after a referee's call gave a fierce glare, angrily locking eyes with the referee while throwing the ball onto the grass, I desperately thought, no, don’t do it, don’t do this, it’ll be terrible, you can afford to lose this point, don’t do it! But he did—he launched into a furious tirade at the referee and even slammed his racket hard onto the ground, sending it flying several meters away. I could hardly bear such scenes. I loved him so much that every time he lost a match, I cried and couldn’t stay indoors—I had to go outside, onto the road, where I sat by the roadside, weeping bitterly over the loss. It was the same with Liverpool. If they lost the Football Cup final, I’d go outside, tears streaming down my face. My favorite player in that team was Emlyn Hughes—he was my man. Of course, I liked a few others too, especially Ray Clemence and Kevin Keegan, but only before Keegan moved to Hamburg and Newcastle. It was a very specific comparison—they were similar in many ways, yet each had their own personal style and shortcomings. The comparison was roughly fair. But one thing mentioned in the magazine unsettled me deeply: Kevin Keegan was extroverted, Kenny Dalglish introverted.
[1978-08-20 20:20:00] floating dock | Just seeing the word 'introverted' filled me with despair. Was I introverted? Wasn’t I? Didn’t I cry more often than laugh? Didn’t I always stay in my room reading? That must be introversion. Introverted, introverted—I didn’t want to be an introverted person. That was the last thing I wanted. It was the worst. But I was introverted—that idea spread rapidly through my mind like cancer cells. Kenny Dalglish also always stayed alone. Ah, so did I! But I didn’t want to! I wanted to be extroverted! Extroverted!
[1978-08-20 21:20:00] In the woods / At home door | An hour later, I returned to the path through the woods, wanting to climb a tree to see how far I could see. The moment I stepped onto the path, I saw Mom’s Volkswagen Beetle driving up the hill. I waved, but she didn’t see me. I ran after her car as fast as I could, up the slope, across the small lawn, and reached the house just as she was stepping out, slinging her handbag over her shoulder and opening the front door. "Hi," she said. "Would you like to help me bake bread?"
[1978-09-01 10:00:00] Baysang / Iceland (memory) | By chance, during a summer in the early nineties, I visited him. He was drunk, and I told him I would move to Iceland that winter. "Iceland," he said, "I've been there once—Reykjavik." "You haven't been there, have you?" I said. "When did you go?" "Back when I lived in Baysang, remember?" he said. "I had a girlfriend there—she was Icelandic—we went together." "While you were still with Mom?" "Yes. I was thirty-five, living in a student town." "You don’t need to justify yourself. You can do what you want." "Okay, thanks, son." This might have been the year he began escaping his father's control. Many years later, he would say he started drinking in Baysang. "I couldn't sleep," he said, "so every night before lying down, I'd have a little drink." Later he had a girlfriend in Baysang.
[1978-09-15 10:00:00] home | Of course, back then we didn't know anything, nor did we have enough experience to imagine such a scene. What mattered most to me was that he was no longer at home. Although the house was no longer a confined space and for the first time I could do as I pleased inside it, he still existed in some strange way. Whenever I walked into the hallway with muddy feet, spilled food on the dining table during meals, or let pear juice drip from my chin while eating, I would think of him—as if struck by lightning. 'Can't you eat a pear properly without making such a mess, boy?' I heard his voice speaking.
locations: In the woods / At home door

text:
[1978-10-01 10:00:00] school | That autumn, when I started fifth grade, I became deeply attracted to almost all the girls... This year a senior female teacher, Miss Horst, joined us and taught several subjects. She enjoyed having us do role-playing exercises. She often arranged short dramatic scenes, and I always volunteered—this was my favorite activity... I made Miss Horst laugh so hard that tears streamed down her face. If I did well on an exam, I wanted to share the good news with him rather than with Mom—that felt different. At the same time, everything happening outside was slowly changing in nature, becoming both better and worse. It was as if within that gentle, mild world of childhood, even the blows that came were soft and harmless... But now they were sharp and clear; doubts had vanished... Something else was unfolding before me, but this something else wasn’t personally related to me... It belonged to people of the outside world. Yet I didn’t feel much difference between them. Something inside me encouraged me, enabling me to approach them. I didn’t know then that this was a grave mistake—yes, perhaps the greatest mistake a boy could make. To be noticed by everyone, yet become someone else. I had a special talent: playing girls. I was good at it. Sweeping my hair behind my ears, pursing my lips into a cherry-like pout, swaying my hips when walking, speaking in a more sentimental tone than usual.
[1978-10-15 19:00:00] residential area | One evening, I stayed over with Karin Ingrid. I suggested we go to Miss Horst’s house. "Good idea," he said, "but my bike tire is flat. You can't walk that road." "Let's hitchhike," I said. "OK." He also liked performing and excelled academically; his appearance resembled mine somewhat—two substitute teachers couldn't tell us apart and thought we were twins. She lived about three kilometers east of the residential area.
[1978-10-15 19:15:00] intersection / inside car | We went down to the intersection and stood by the roadside. The first car passing that evening stopped. Two young men. We got in. We told them where we were going. He stepped on the gas, the car accelerated sharply, and our bodies pressed against the seats. At the intersection, the car suddenly braked hard. The driver turned toward us. "Where are you headed?" "Who lives up there anyway?" "Miss Horst," Karin Ingrid said, "she's our schoolteacher." "Ah-ha!" said the man sitting next to the driver. "You're going to play a prank? We used to do that when we were kids. Run over to the teacher's place and cause some trouble." "No, we're not causing trouble," I said. "We just want to visit her." He turned and looked at me. "Visit her? Why? To ask about homework or something?" "No… no," I said, "we just wanted to come." "Well then, get out, kid," said the driver. They had the music turned up loud—the bass made the windows vibrate. Over the past year, I had frequently hitchhiked here, usually with Marivik·Kristian, going to Hof or up to Roligheden or somewhere else, but never had it taken more than an hour before we found a ride. He turned his head back. For the rest of the ride, they didn't say another word.
[1978-10-15 19:30:00] outside Miss Horst's house | I sincerely thanked them, as compensation. Karin Ingrid and I stepped onto the gravel path. We had never been inside this house, but we clearly knew its location. I pressed the doorbell. "It's you?" she exclaimed in surprise when opening the door. They roared off into the darkness. Towering plane trees stood along both sides of the road, stretching out their branches. Two cars were parked outside the house, and every room was brightly lit. I felt a bit guilty—I realized I had disappointed them, but lying wasn't right either.
[1978-10-15 19:40:00] Miss Horst's living room | We went in. The living room was full of adults seated. Miss Horst introduced us, and we sat down on stools beside the table. She placed a plate with three cookies and a glass of juice in front of us. I tucked my hair behind my ears, pursed my lips, and began improvising. "We thought maybe we could come see you," I said. "Can we come in?" Karin Ingrid asked. She hesitated. "I'm sorry, I have guests, you understand. But you've come all this way just to see me?" "Yes." "Then come in! You can stay half an hour, if you'd like. I've got cakes too. You can try some. And some juice!" She said we were her star pupils, excellent at performing. "Could you give us a little performance right now?" one person asked. Miss Horst looked at us. "Sure," I said, "will you join me?" "Of course," said Karin Ingrid. But the performance went fairly well—the audience laughed.
[1978-12-20 19:00:00] carnival venue | When the performance ended, we bowed. Both Marivik·Kristian and I were dressed as women, fully made-up, wearing dresses and carrying handbags. My imitation was so convincing that no one recognized me—not even Dalson, who stood beside me for at least five minutes before suddenly realizing who this unfamiliar girl actually was. During the pre-Christmas carnival, I achieved another success. Our cheeks were slightly flushed, but we felt very pleased with ourselves because of the applause.
[1978-12-28 14:00:00] ice rink / Mariann's house / school | We went ice skating together; she would sit on my lap and kiss me. I was invited to her birthday party—the only boy there. She sat on my lap while chatting with her girlfriends, and I held her close, and then we kissed and hugged... Finally, I persuaded Marivik·Kristian to tell her that I had broken up with her. On that day, I made a terrible mistake—she ran after me, and instinctively, when she reached the shelter, I stuck my foot out. She tripped and fell to the ground, her face hitting the gravel, bleeding, and she started crying. The prettiest and most outstanding of them was Mariann—we were together for two weeks... Undoubtedly one of the most beautiful girls at school, though not *the* most beautiful... She lived with her mother and sister in quite poor conditions. She almost never wore new clothes; her mother always tried her best to mend and alter old clothes handed down from relatives, striving to keep them neat and presentable. I never felt ashamed of dressing as a girl, nor embarrassed talking about girls—I even became close with several of them. But later I simply couldn't bear it anymore—being in her room, I felt emptiness; kissing her gave me claustrophobia, I just wanted to escape from there as fast as possible... But that wasn't the worst part. The worst was that she unleashed all her anger on me, and all the girls took her side, siding against me. For the following weeks, I was extremely unpopular.
[1979-01-10 10:00:00] school | Sometimes the girls seemed to hate me—they thought I was no good—but at other times their attitude would do a complete turnaround, not only willing to talk to me, but even dancing with me during class parties—whether held at a student's home or at school. I explained that I hadn't meant any harm, that it was just for fun, but no one could understand.
[1979-01-10 10:10:00] school | My feelings toward them were also contradictory—at least toward the girls in my class. On one hand, nearly five years of school life had given me considerable understanding of them, so I felt somewhat indifferent. But on the other hand, they were beginning to change—their bodies developing beneath their sweaters, taking on curves, their hips becoming fuller, their gait different, and they started paying attention to boys two or three grades above us.
[1979-01-10 10:20:00] school | With our shrill, thin voices, we could only steal brief glances at them—girls whose qualities now filled us with awe, yet to whom we seemed like mere air. What was so special about girls that made them strut around so proudly? They knew so little about the world. How much did they really understand about men, women, and desire? Had they read Wilbur Smith’s books, where women are captured and raped beneath thunderous skies? Had they read Ken Follett, where a man shaves a woman's pubic hair while she lies with closed eyes in a foamy bathtub? Had they read Helen Sandnes’ *Insect Summer*? I can recite that scene word for word—him tearing off her panties in the hayloft. Had they ever looked at porn magazines? And what about music—what did they know? They only liked whatever everyone else liked—the Kids, those trashy top-ten hits. Music meant nothing to them; they had no idea what it truly was or what worlds it could build. They barely knew how to dress—otherwise they wouldn’t constantly show up at school in such bizarre outfits without even realizing it. So how dare they look down on me? I’ve read Wilbur Smith, Ken Follett, and Helen Sandnes. I’ve been looking at porn magazines for years. I listen to real bands and I know how to dress properly. How could I possibly be worse than them?

[1979-03-16 14:00:00] music classroom | Every Friday we held a class competition. Six students each brought a song, and everyone voted. I complained to Henrik Inge. To prove how knowledgeable and sophisticated I was about music, I tried to impress during music class. But my songs always came in last, no matter which band I played—Led Zeppelin, Queen, Wings, The Beatles, The Police, Jam, Skids—it was always the same: one or two votes, dead last. I knew they didn’t actually dislike the music—they were resisting me. In truth, they weren’t even listening. That infuriated me. He not only understood why I was angry—he also disliked the mainstream pop hits—but he came up with a plan to help me.
[1979-03-23 14:00:00] music classroom | One Friday, I brought Aller Værste!'s debut album *Tired*, which Henrik Inge had bought just days earlier. I told them I had gotten an advance copy of the upcoming album by The Kids. The music teacher didn't see through my trick and played the first track from the record, which was hidden inside a white paper bag. I claimed the disc was too new for the cover art to be ready yet. Then I stood up and revealed that they hadn't been voting for The Kids, but for Aller Værste!—my eyes gleaming with triumph. I said: "This proves they're not interested in music at all—other factors influenced their votes." The Kids' second album hadn’t even been released yet. To them, Aller Værste!'s music was unbearable—last time I played their single "Clean Hands" in class, they shouted "Clean hands! Clean hands!" and mocked me for days. But now, as the first notes rang out in the classroom, murmurs immediately spread through the room. Their excitement grew, peaking by the end of the song. It turned out that Aller Værste!, disguised as The Kids, had won. Ah, how furious they were! But they couldn’t say a thing. I’d really fooled them. Of course, I’d heard them say it—that I was arrogant, that I thought I was someone special, that I liked strange things no one else liked. But that wasn’t entirely true. I simply liked good music and disliked bad music—was that my fault?
[1979-05-01 10:00:00] at home | I went through them all, and Henrik Inge played music for me. He taught me more guitar chords, and when he wasn’t home, I would stand there with the black Gibson pick and the black guitar strap, playing for myself. Thanks to Henrik Inge and his music magazines, I learned more and more about music—Magazine, Cure, Killers, Simple Minds, Skids, Stiff Little Fingers, XTC, and Leivik’s rock bands like Meat, Bluebird, Aller Værste!, Cut, Stavanger Ensemble, News, Concrete Hysteria, Destruction, and so on.
[1979-06-01 10:00:00] at home / at Marivik Christian's house | Just to be safe, I bought a textbook on percussion, whittled two sticks with a knife, and arranged some books in a circle on the floor—one on cymbals to the left, another on snare drum beside it, and three more below on hand drums. The only person who joined me in these activities was Marivik Christian, with whom I spent more and more time. Most often, we sat at his place listening to records, trying to play his twelve-string guitar. He also came over to my house, where we would sit together reading our magazines—since my mom wasn’t so strict—and listen to my records, talking about girls or the band we were going to form, especially its name. He wanted to name the band "Marivik Christian's Nameless Disciples," but I wanted to call it "Clot." Actually, both names were equally good—we agreed on that point—and anyway, we didn’t need to decide now. We could wait until the time was right, until we actually had a chance to perform on stage, before settling the issue.
[1980-02-15 20:00:00] class party | Winter passed, and so did our first class party, where we played Postman’s Knock and slow-danced, holding the girls—whom we’d known for five years—close as we circled the floor. We knew these girls so well, perhaps even better than our own sisters. When Ingeborg Lofnes pressed so close to me, my head nearly exploded. The scent of her hair, her shining eyes, alive with energy. And ah, those small breasts beneath the thin white shirt. Wasn’t this an incredible feeling? It was something entirely new—I’d never experienced it before in all these years. Now that I knew what it tasted like, I wanted to feel it again.
[1980-03-27 07:00:00] kitchen | As usual, I walked into the kitchen in the dark and rain to prepare breakfast. Mom had already left for her early shift. I buttered a slice of bread, added a piece of sausage, and poured a glass of milk. Winter had passed and spring arrived, bringing light. Each day stretched a little longer toward night. Cold spring rains melted and sank the snow. One March morning... she forgot to turn off the radio. There had been an accident in the North Sea—a offshore oil rig had capsized and sunk. Even locked in my room, I could piece together what had happened overnight—the sound of the radio, though I couldn’t make out every word, carried an unusual dramatic intensity in its rising and falling tones.
[1980-03-27 07:10:00] kitchen / Rockhaug Supermarket | Half an hour later, I arrived at Rockhaug Supermarket, pants rolled above my rubber boots, hood pulled tight over my head. Everyone was talking about nothing else. I saw rain slowly streaming down the glass windows. It pattered softly on the roof like a steady drumbeat, wrapping the building in a thin film. Water flowed continuously through the gutters. Up above, Oskar Magnus started his car, and the headlights flickered on. It was a disaster—missing people uncountable, no one knew the exact number. Everyone had friends, or friends of friends, whose fathers or brothers had been working on that rig. A man named Alexander Schjølberg apparently broke a leg. Was it hundred-year waves? A bomb? Or a structural failure?
[1980-03-27 08:30:00] classroom | During the first lesson—though it was supposed to be math—the teacher spoke about the accident. He always urged us to pursue careers related to oil extraction. Oil was the future. Yet another voice emerged: the daily news predicted that oil reserves would soon run dry, consumed far faster than expected—within twenty-five years, all oil would be gone. I wondered what Granddad would say about this. I was fascinated by the number mentioned in the news—2004. It felt unreal, so distant, yet in the broadcast it was presented as serious reality, utterly unlike the years in sci-fi stories or magazines. It shocked me: would 2004 really come? Within our lifetimes?
[1980-03-27 08:45:00] classroom | At the same time, the gloomy tone in their voices unsettled me deeply—it hinted that something terrible was coming, that everything would end. I didn’t like that. I wanted everything to keep going on forever. All endings frightened me. That’s why I hoped Jimmy Carter would be re-elected, and that Odvar Nordli and his Labour Party would win the next election. I liked Jimmy Carter. I liked Odvar Nordli, even though he always looked so exhausted. I didn’t like Mogens Glistrup or Olof Palme—they had an unpleasant slickness and falseness that showed in our words and glances. Einar Førde and Reiulf Steen were similar, though less obvious. But I liked Brundtland. I didn’t like Golda Meir or Menachem Begin, even though he signed the Camp David Accords. It was hard to judge Anwar Sadat. Brezhnev too, though for different reasons. I saw him standing there in a thick fur coat and large fur hat, his bushy eyebrows shadowing narrow eyes, mechanically waving down at the parade below, where rockets mounted on platforms rolled past one after another, surrounded by thousands of soldiers marching in perfect unison. I didn’t think he belonged to humanity—he seemed like another kind of being, impossible to relate to. Did I like Knut Henrik? In a way, yes—at least I fervently hoped his "anti-inflation plan" would work. I liked Hans Hammond Rosbach, but found Trygve Bratteli odd—his voice soft, almost whispering, his strange rolling 'r', his thin shoulders and skull-like head, with thick, dark eyebrows.
[1980-03-27 09:00:00] classroom | The topic of the maritime disaster occupied us for a quarter of an hour, then class began as usual, which meant we started working on arithmetic problems from the textbook while the teacher walked between the desks, helping those who raised their hands with questions. Outdoors, the hand of darkness loosened its grip on the morning, and everything gradually became clearer. During break, someone said there might be air pockets beneath the oil drilling platform, allowing people inside to survive for several days.
[1980-03-27 10:00:00] classroom | The next lesson was Leivik. When the female teacher sat down behind her desk, I raised my hand. "Yes, Grete Lundnes?" "Have you graded our essays yet?" "You'll find out soon enough," she said. Others claimed that none of our schoolmates' parents were on that ship, but a boy from Roligheden had lost his father. It was hard to trace where all these rumors came from or how much truth they held.
[1980-03-27 10:10:00] classroom | She must have reviewed the notebooks already, because next she wrote some vocabulary and grammar rules on the blackboard—likely errors taken from our assignments handed in last Thursday. It was true—she pulled out a thick stack of corrected notebooks from her backpack. I stared at the small pile, trying to spot my own among them. "This time there were many well-written essays," she said, "I really wanted to read them all aloud. But unfortunately, time doesn't allow it. So I've selected four. That doesn't mean these are necessarily the best—you understand. Everyone in the class wrote very well." It's not the top one, at least I'm sure of that.
[1980-03-27 10:15:00] classroom | I saw Ingeborg Lofnes raise her hand. She was wearing a white knitted sweater. "Yes?" the teacher said. "Can we knit while you're reading the essays?" Ingeborg Lofnes asked. "Of course, I don't think that would be a problem," the teacher replied. I think that sweater suits her perfectly. Her jet-black hair and dark shining eyes go so well with the white, as do her red lips and the blush that appears on her face when she gets warm.
[1980-03-27 10:20:00] classroom | I saw four girls lean forward and pull out their knitting from their bags. I saw Karlsen smile, then flush slightly. "Can we do homework instead?" Karlsen said. Someone laughed. "You need to raise your hand like everyone else, Karlsen," the female teacher said, "but the answer is no, of course not." I don't think it was anger that made him react, but rather that he had spoken in front of everyone. He always blushes when he speaks in class.
[1980-03-27 10:30:00] classroom | The teacher began reading the essays. The first wasn't mine. I stretched my legs under the desk. The second wasn't mine either. Nor was the third. I looked up anxiously as she picked up the fourth notebook. Three more left, I thought. I love early classes, when it’s still pitch-dark outside and we sit like in a bright capsule, all of us with messy hair and sleepy eyes, a bit dazed, but as time passes, we slowly wake up until finally everyone is running around wide-eyed, flailing arms, shouting loudly. Still not mine? Ah. She won’t read mine after all. Something sank inside me—I felt disappointed. But another emotion began to grow. My essay was the best, I knew that. And so did she. Yet again, just like last time, she hadn’t chosen to read mine. What good was writing well then? Next time I’ll write the worst, most terrible essay possible.
[1980-03-27 10:50:00] classroom | Finally, she put down the poorly written essay. I raised my hand. She clapped her hands and nodded toward Karl Larsdal·B., who stood up and walked to the front. As the class monitor, he would distribute the notebooks. I quickly flipped through my essay from beginning to end. There was one mistake per page. "Why didn’t you read mine?" I said. "Is it really that bad?" For a moment, she narrowed her eyes, then opened them again and smiled. "I received twenty-five essays. I can’t possibly read every single one—you understand that. I often read yours. Now it’s time for others to be heard." "This time, they truly wrote quite well. How rich your imaginations are! I really enjoyed reading your work." In the end, she had written: "Imaginative and fluent writing, Grete Lundnes, though perhaps the ending feels a bit abrupt? Few errors, but you need to put more effort into handwriting!"
[1980-03-27 10:55:00] classroom | In my essay, I had written 'Hotel,' and she circled the word in red, adding an extra 'l' beside it. I raised my hand, and she came over. "There’s only one 'l' in this word. I know that. I’ve seen it in a book—I’m certain." We were supposed to write about the future. I wrote a story about space travel. I spent many pages describing the various training programs astronauts had to complete before launch. After ten pages, I still hadn’t reached the rocket launch. After some thought, I decided the mission would be canceled at the last moment due to some error, leaving the astronauts to return home empty-handed.
[1980-03-27 10:58:00] classroom | I saw her lean toward me. Then she straightened up and returned to her desk. "Ah, in a way, you’re right. But in English, 'Hotel' has only one 'l'. In Leivik, it should have two." "But Hotel Phønix has only one 'l'," I said, "and it’s in Leivik. Right in Aucity." "You’re correct." "So it’s not actually a mistake then?" "Then it’s not a mistake. That settles it. Your essay was very well written, Grete Lundnes." I caught the scent of soap from her hands, and a faint trace of perfume from her neck. Her words warmed me, even though they were meant only for me.
locations: at home / at Marivik Christian's house

text:
[1980-03-27 11:15:00] gym locker room | After break ended, as we entered the indoor gymnasium, the wind blowing against the high walls of the building was so strong... I sat on the bench in the locker room, thinking about this as I undressed. I stood up naked, took my towel, and walked into the shower, already filled with steam. I found a spot among the boys whose pale skin looked almost like marble. Warm water poured down, first onto my head, then flowing continuously down my face and chest, my neck and back. Wet hair clung to my forehead; I closed my eyes. Outside, rain continued to fall, driven by wind. Trees beyond the school swayed, creaking and groaning... It sounded just like waves crashing. The metal grates of the ventilation system roared and gasped, and the whole building seemed alive—a giant beast hidden within rooms, corridors, and passageways, crouching beside the school, singing a lonely, mournful song to itself in despair. The sounds rose and fell, sometimes lingering briefly, now here, now there, as if playing a game. Perhaps it is the sound that is alive.
[1980-03-27 11:20:00] shower room | I opened my eyes and saw Karin Ingrid pointing at Thor across from me. I saw Thor standing there laughing, his private part sticking straight up in the air. I heard someone shout, "Thor's thing down there is standing up!" I heard Karlsen exclaim in amazement. I knew Thor always liked wearing tight pants to show off his large member—it wasn't a secret in class.
[1980-03-27 11:25:00] shower room / gymnasium | I saw Miss Hensel cleaning up inside the gymnasium. I heard Karin Ingrid suggest taking Thor to physical education teacher Miss Hensel. [1980-03-27 20:40:00] bathroom / bedroom / living room | I turned off the player, changed into a light blue shirt and dark blue jeans. I walked up to Mom and stood before her. I asked Mom, "When exactly are we going to buy my clothes for May 17th?"
[1980-03-27 20:45:00] living room | I heard Mom say it was still early before the end of March, but I suggested it might be cheaper now. She smiled and told me I’d naturally have new clothes and shoes by May 17th. I knew money was tight at home because Dad was still in school.

[1980-05-17 08:00:00] Home / Tyholmen | I was wearing new jeans and crisp white tennis shoes. I felt the tense excitement in the air. I thought unhappily that the rain forced me to put on an ugly raincoat over my new clothes.

[1981-01-15 20:00:00] home | I learned that Dad once mentioned in conversation that it was Mom who saved us. I knew he lacked proper self-awareness. I pondered whether, despite Mom’s protection, our long exposure to fear of Father had left indelible scars. Doubt filled my heart.

text:
[1981-06-05 20:10:00] Forest Path | I jumped off my bike before the hill and pushed it up the ascending trail. Later, I climbed to the top of the slope and walked down the gentle incline, then got back on and rode onto the road. I saw dense broadleaf trees lush with green leaves and heard the chirping of birds. I saw the narrow path made of soil and bare rock, and massive tree roots and rotting fallen trunks stretching across the grassy banks of a stream. I felt the trees closing in behind me, as if entering a deep, mysterious world. I realized it wasn't the world that limited imagination, but imagination that limited the world. At that moment, I was immersed in the sense of freedom sparked by just one glance from Kaja.
[1981-06-05 20:20:00] Below the Chapel / On the Road | I pushed my bicycle uphill past the chapel. I saw people playing ball in front of Magnus's house and Tom washing his car. I rode over the crest of the hill, and strong winds blew sand into my eyes. I saw the distant blue bay behind the green trees and the white gas tank. I smelled barbecue smoke drifting from Magnus's house and heard the music of Dr. Hook coming from Tom's car radio.
[1981-06-05 20:30:00] Home | I saw two cars parked outside my house, went inside, and greeted relatives sitting in the living room. Anne handed me a bag of M&Ms, which I took as I headed toward the kitchen. I heard Anne laugh and say, 'I suppose you're too old for this kind of thing now?' I replied, 'People of any age can enjoy M&Ms.' I learned that the cars parked there belonged to Sven Nils’s Citroën and Dagney’s 2CV. I had completely forgotten they were coming, and seeing them filled me with a thrilling mix of joy and excitement.
[1981-06-05 20:40:00] Living Room / Bedroom | I took the candy bag into my room, lay on the bed reading, watching the last rays of sunset cast across the walls. I heard Anne laughing at the writing on my back, and Mom explained it was the name of a football team. I told them, 'The name comes from a Viking-era name.' I saw the final streaks of sunlight projected onto the ceiling.
[1981-06-15 10:00:00] Home | I knew that over the next two weeks, Kaja’s image would remain constantly in my mind. I could close my eyes and see her as she looked on May 17th, or lying naked on the grass. These images stirred a quiet ache inside me, and I fantasized about doing passionate things with her.
[1981-06-15 11:00:00] Home / Outdoors | I sat at the dining table peeling fish skin or chewing ox lung. I leaped my bike off a hilltop, felt my feet skim the water’s surface, then plunged into the sea. I swam slowly upward through the water toward the surface. I felt the sun beating directly on my face, tasted salty seawater on my lips, and felt my body wrapped in churning waves. I remembered that summer when we first moved here—I was thirteen, Dad planted potatoes and raised chickens. I felt a deep surge of ecstasy and trembling within. I realized Kaja was like a dream or a star to me—though not far away in distance, the gap between our worlds felt vast and nearly impossible to cross.
[1981-06-15 12:00:00] Tvet Old House (memory) | As far as I knew, Dad bought several chickens, but they all ran away within half a year. He enjoyed planting potatoes along the edge of the lawn and tending the compost pile—gardener was one of his dream jobs.
[1981-06-19 19:00:00] Sjøna Field | I was playing football at Sjøna field. From the corner of my eye, I saw three people walking along the sideline. I felt the warm sun and the flat grass beneath me, though the center of the field was slightly uneven. I immediately recognized that one of the three was Kaja. I found that during the rest of the game, I spent nearly as much time looking at the spectators as I did watching the ball.
[1981-06-19 19:30:00] Shena Court | After the match, I saw a girl walk up to me. I stared at the ground, blushing, unable to suppress a smile. I heard her ask, 'Do you know who Caesar is?' I replied, 'Yes.' She went on, 'Caesar wants to know if you'd like to be with her. Would you?' My heart racing, I answered, 'Yes.' I felt a wave of heat rush through my body; my longing was so intense it was as if my heart were on fire.
[1981-06-19 19:35:00] Shena Court | I watched her walk back. I began pacing nervously along the edge of the court. I asked her, 'Where is she?' She replied, 'She's waiting by the changing room. We'll meet there later?' I answered, 'Okay.' I could hardly believe it. I silently thanked God. Then I started worrying about what I should say or do next.
[1981-06-19 19:40:00] By the changing room | I saw Caesar standing by the roadside with two other girls, leaning on their bicycles. I walked toward her; when she smiled at me, I smiled back. I greeted her, 'Hi.' She said, 'Hi.' I told her, 'I'm going in to change clothes, then I'll come right out.' She nodded in agreement. I smelled the scent of fresh grass in the air and heard the pleasant chirping of birds. It was a warm, golden evening. I knew we had just won the match, and everyone inside the changing room was jubilant.
[1981-06-19 19:50:00] Inside the changing room | Slowly, inside the makeshift changing room, I unstrapped my knee pads and gazed out the window at the lake. I unwound my bandages and rolled them up. Then I stood and pulled on my light-colored jeans. I heard Helen Ster call Jostein an idiot. The changing room was a simple shed, very rudimentary. I anxiously searched for decent words. I had considered using 'homework' as an excuse, but feared it would make me look worse. I wanted to announce to everyone that I was with Caesar, but I knew I’d never actually do it.
[1981-06-19 19:55:00] Inside the changing room | I zipped up my Puma shoes, slung my bag over my shoulder, and walked out. I heard Jostein mock my pants and ask if my belt was designer. Helen Ster called me 'Fermi.' I shot back, 'What about you, damn daddy’s good boy.' Finally, I said goodbye to them. I knew my jeans were bought at the fashion store Interlude, and my belt was punk-style. I thought to myself that I was definitely not someone chasing trends. I felt irritated by Helen Ster’s provocation.
[1981-06-19 20:00:00] Outside the changing room | I stopped in front of them, my eyes meeting Caesar’s. I lifted my leg and swung it over my bicycle. I said to her, 'Hi.' She replied, 'You guys played well.' I asked, 'Can I see you tomorrow?' She said, 'Sure, I’ll come by after school.' I asked if she knew where I lived, and she said she did—Tibaken. Then we said our goodbyes. I saw she was wearing a white T-shirt, and from this close distance, I noticed her breasts clearly outlined. I nervously swallowed. I kept thinking I needed to find some busy excuse, so I wouldn’t be caught off guard now. Knowing she wanted to be with me filled me with overwhelming joy.
[1981-06-19 20:15:00] On the way home / Home balcony | I pedaled furiously until they were out of sight. When I got home, I saw my mother sitting at the camping table on the backyard balcony. I walked over and sat down. I asked my mom, 'Where’s Dad?' She said, 'He went fishing.' She asked how the game went, and I told her we won. I saw coffee on my mother’s table. I smelled a quiet, peaceful atmosphere around me. The joy of knowing she wanted to be with me felt absolutely incredible. But then anxiety crept in—I started wondering what I should do with her tomorrow.
[1981-06-19 20:20:00] Home balcony | I sat on the balcony, looked up, and saw Marta also sitting in a deck chair. I saw Presbakkmo working in the vegetable garden. I noticed a moving white figure on the path and realized it was Freddy. Mom asked, 'Did something happen?' I said, 'No.' She asked, 'Is there something you want to ask me?' I said no again. I heard the sound of a radio coming from Presbakkmo’s house. I caught a whiff of barbecue smoke drifting over. I knew Freddy had albinism and was hunchbacked.
[1981-06-19 20:30:00] Home balcony | I gasped, opened my eyes wide, rushed into the room and turned off the stereo. Then I went into the kitchen and ate a chocolate bar. I asked Mom, 'Do you know what exactly “Fermi” means?' Mom said it meant 'female.' Realizing my mistake, I quickly made an excuse: 'I almost came in with my training shoes on.' I heard Henrik Inge shouting from downstairs, asking what the hell I was doing. I felt the music vibrating through the walls, as if it had become part of the house itself. I was completely absorbed in the music, as if I had swallowed it whole. I’d mistaken the noise for Dad returning, which gave me a sudden fright.
[1981-06-19 21:00:00] Henrik Inge's room | I saw my brother come up the stairs, followed by Thomas. After he entered his room, he leaned close to the speaker to inspect it. Later, I went into his room to ask him for advice. I told my brother, 'Tonight I’m with Caesar.' He congratulated me. Awkwardly, I asked him what I should say to a girl. He laughed and reassured me, 'Don’t overthink it, and everything will be fine.' He introduced me to Thomas as 'the little idiot brother.' I had never seen the boy who followed my brother before. Thank goodness it wasn’t Dad who came back. I felt a helpless nervousness about the upcoming date.
[1981-06-19 21:30:00] bedroom | I walked into my room. I put on a record of McCartney II, lay face down on the bed and rubbed against the mattress, humming a tune. I asked my brother what he was doing, and he said he was working on chemistry and geography homework. He said high school required reading a lot. I knew my brother had to study natural sciences as Dad wanted. I imagined whether Caesar might also be lying in bed thinking of me right now. At the thought of our relationship, I felt shivers running through my body.
locations: Below the Chapel / On the Road
On the way home / Home balcony

text:
[1981-06-20 18:00:00] Home / On the way | I paced by the window watching the road, and saw her riding up the hill on her bike. I put on my shoes and jacket and went outside. I saw her talking with my friends. I pushed my bicycle over. Karlsen shouted, 'She wants to know where you live.' I said to Caesar, 'Hi, easy to find?' She said no problem. I said, 'Shall we go?' She said okay. I saw my friends standing there leaning on their bikes. When I saw Caesar appear, I felt a breathless shock, and at the same time an immense pride at having such a beautiful girl. I sensed my friends were filled with jealousy toward me.
[1981-06-20 18:10:00] On the way | I got on my bike, and she did too. On the uphill stretch, we both got off and walked. I waited for her to catch up, walking side by side on the gravel path. I heard the sound of my trouser legs rubbing together. I told her, 'Your jacket looks great—where did you buy it?' She thanked me and said it was from Bajazzo. I said goodbye to the four of them, 'See you!' I heard gusts of wind rustling through the trees. I saw her wearing low-heeled sandals and heard the sound of them tapping against the pavement.
[1981-06-20 18:30:00] On the road / outside the store | I got on the bike and pedaled downhill, holding the handlebars with one hand and tilting toward her. We rode down to the small shop at the bottom, where we saw nobody around. I asked her, 'Do you know Lars?' She said yes. I suggested, 'We could go over to the shop.' I felt a breeze rushing past my ears. The shop door was shut tight, looking very empty. I stole glances at her moving chest, wondering if she noticed my gaze. I kept agonizing over whether I should kiss her now, or hold her hand.
[1981-06-20 19:00:00] old gravel road / outside Caesar's house | We continued riding uphill until we reached the house where she lived. I stayed on my bike, ready to leave. I suggested riding in the direction of her house, and she agreed. She told me her parents were home, so I couldn't come in. I suggested meeting tomorrow, but she said she'd be going out on a boat, and we agreed to meet on Thursday. I felt the bike kept us apart, leaving no chance to kiss. I thought I must make a move next time somewhere no one could see—we couldn't just keep talking like this.
[1981-06-20 19:30:00] outside Caesar's house / on the way home | I got on my bike and said goodbye to her, then rode away as fast as I could. I stood on the pedals and accelerated wildly. I said to her, 'Well, I'm off then, bye!' She said goodbye too. I felt an incredible happiness, repeating in my mind over and over, 'I was with Caesar.' But then I fell into anxious planning for our next date, grateful that her two-day trip gave me time to prepare.
[1981-06-23 20:00:00] Fina gas station phone booth | I biked to the phone booth at the Fina gas station. I looked up the number in the phone book. I dialed slowly, pausing for a few seconds before the last digit, trying to steady my breathing. The phone booth was covered in dust. I saw that it was already dark outside. I knew the home phone wasn't convenient to use, and I had to be back before 8:30—it was an unbreakable rule. My heart kept pounding; I kept rehearsing in my mind how I should start speaking.
[1981-06-23 20:05:00] phone booth | I pressed the receiver tightly against my ear and heard the call connect. After hanging up, I felt a wave of relief. I heard a woman's voice. When Caesar answered, I told her I had training tomorrow and couldn't go to her place. She suggested coming down instead. I asked if a boat trip would be good, and she said yes. In the end, we agreed to meet tomorrow. I heard the rumble of a bus slowly pulling into the station.
[1981-06-23 20:15:00] Outside phone booth / on the way | I pushed open the door of the phone booth and stepped out. I saw an old teacher sitting on the bus staring at me. I cycled past the gas station and saw Helen Ster. I ran my hands through my hair, pushing it back, and realized it was all sweaty. I heard Helen Ster call my name. I shouted back. I heard the roar of a motorcycle engine starting. I felt the hot, thick air full of exhaust fumes. I saw Helen Ster wearing a black mask and bare-chested. I knew that the old teacher worked at Dad's school. I thought I must maintain a perfect appearance tomorrow—I was going to see Caesar again.
[1981-06-23 20:30:00] Rockehaug Supermarket bus stop | I stopped outside the supermarket bus stop, propping my foot on the curb stone. I remembered the scene when Tor performed a kissing act. I recalled Tor saying at the time, 'Let’s see how long we can kiss, shall we?' In the end, he announced ten minutes. I saw a thick glob of spit on the sidewalk. Melese was hugging Tor with her eyes closed. I remembered meeting Tor here with Marivik a few weeks ago. I knew Tor had a homemade bicycle with a motorcycle seat attached. I realized I could copy Tor’s method—use a watch to time how long I kiss Caesar, so I could naturally go ahead and kiss her.
[1981-06-23 20:45:00] on the way home / woods | I got on my bike and rode toward Holt. I was looking for a suitable place, and finally decided on the wooded path just above the gas station. I saw the light filtering gently through the deciduous trees. The ground there felt soft. I felt terrified and thought I had to find a place where no one could see us.
[1981-06-25 17:00:00] Sjøna field | I pushed my bicycle up the hill to Sjøna field. I saw two companions sitting on the fence, and I walked over and stood between them. I asked, 'Doesn't anyone have a ball?' Christian asked me, 'Is it true you're with Kaja?' I bit my lip to suppress a smile and answered, 'Yes.' He said, 'Nice, her.' I saw the sprinkler hissing out a curtain of water in all directions. The sunlight was blindingly bright. I knew Christian had never had a girlfriend before. I struggled not to laugh, but inside I was overjoyed.
[1981-06-25 17:10:00] Sjøna field | I saw everyone watching him. I casually replied, 'Yeah.' I remembered how last year during the Leivik Cup, Christian had been scolded by his father for buying a porn magazine. I knew he'd had to apologize and throw the magazine away.
[1981-06-25 19:00:00] Sjøna field | I saw Larssen come in with a ball. We ran through the sprinkler to take shots. Near the end of practice, I saw Kaja arrive with her friends, and I waved at her. I heard Larssen shout, 'Focus, Grete Lundnes! Training first, girls second!' I saw the sprinkler moving across the field.
[1981-06-25 19:30:00] Sjøna field / outside the changing room | After training, I dipped my head into a bucket of water. I saw Kaja walk down from the stands; she reached out her hand, and I grabbed it. I heard her ask, 'Are you going to change? I'll come with you. I have something to tell you.' I told her, 'Okay.' I felt nervous, wondering if she was going to break up with me. When her hand touched mine, I hesitated—was it accidental, or could I hold it? Finally, I decided to take the initiative and grab it.
[1981-06-25 19:40:00] path above the field / changing room | I held her hand tightly as we walked along the path above the field. We reached our destination, I went inside to the bench and leaned my head against the wall. After changing, I slung my bag over my shoulder and walked out. She said to me, 'Well, hurry up.' I replied, 'Okay.' I saw Lars and Helle whistling. I knew they were waiting for me, leaning on their bikes. I noticed Kaja's fingernails were painted pink. I felt an unbearable happiness. I thought she looked especially appealing right then.
[1981-06-25 19:45:00] outside the changing room | I heard her say, 'I’ll be home alone on Saturday. I told Mom that Suvi is coming. Do you want to come?'
[1981-06-25 19:45:05] outside the changing room | I nervously swallowed saliva. I said, 'Yes.'
[1981-06-25 19:45:15] outside the changing room | I heard shouts from the players inside the changing room. I saw Kaja standing there, holding her bicycle.
[1981-06-25 19:45:30] outside the changing room | I suggested, 'Shall we go? Downward?' She said yes.
locations: On the road / outside the store
old gravel road / outside Caesar's house
outside Caesar's house / on the way home
Outside phone booth / on the way
Sjøna field / outside the changing room
path above the field / changing room

text:
[1981-06-25 19:50:00] gravel road | We got on our bikes and raced down the shaded gravel road, me in front, her behind. We flew side by side down the slope. I saw sunlight shining on distant mountains. A shimmering swarm of insects gathered in the air.
[1981-06-25 19:55:00] forest path | As we rushed down the slope, I spotted a narrow forest path to the right. We turned and cycled up about ten meters before jumping off our bikes. I shouted to Kaisa over the wind, "Let's ride over there!" She nodded in agreement. I suddenly realized it might be a good spot for a rendezvous.
[1981-06-25 20:00:00] top of the slope | Without a word, I walked with her along the grassy path. We reached the top of the slope and looked out toward the woods; I surveyed the surroundings. I saw many broken branches and fallen logs lying across the ground. Tree stumps were everywhere, and spruce trees grew so densely they resembled a wall. I concluded this wasn't a suitable place.
[1981-06-25 20:01:00] top of the slope | I said to her, "No, this won't work. Let's keep going."
[1981-06-25 20:02:00] on the road | I saw her mount her bike and start pedaling hard—harder than I would have.
[1981-06-25 20:03:00] on the road | I glanced at her from the corner of my eye. I felt terrified, as if standing atop a high mountain looking down at water. I hesitated, wondering whether I should back out. I wondered what her serious expression meant now.
[1981-06-25 20:05:00] main road uphill | We got off our bikes and pushed them through the deep shade of deciduous trees. We hadn’t exchanged a single word since leaving the court. The treetops formed a high canopy above us. I thought that if I were to speak now, it would have to be something important.
[1981-06-25 20:05:10] main road uphill
[1981-06-25 20:10:00] main road | I followed her onto the main road. I imagined myself cycling around the world. Before us stretched a long downhill stretch. I felt an urge to escape, to leave everything behind. I fantasized about being known as "the cyclist from Leivik," exploring the world beneath ghostly lights.
[1981-06-25 20:15:00] downhill road | We swooshed swiftly down the hillside. I heard her ask, "Where exactly are we going?" I replied, "I know a good spot—not far."
[1981-06-25 20:20:00] Rocky path | I saw the car parked there. I locked up my bike, then started walking deeper into the woods, feeling her following behind me. I tried to find a suitable spot to lie down, whether on grass or moss. Deep in the woods, I heard our footsteps sounding unusually clear. I heard myself say to her: "We can leave the car here." I saw light seeping through the treetops, refracting like underwater rays, and shafts of sunlight slanting across the ground. The air was filled with birdsong. I felt unable to look at her, fighting back the urge to vomit.
[1981-06-25 20:25:00] deep in the woods | I sat down without looking at her. I noticed she hesitated before sitting beside me. I reached into my pocket, took out the watch, and held it in my open palm, offering it to her. I heard myself say: "We can lie down here."
[1981-06-25 20:27:00] deep in the woods | I placed the watch on the ground. I heard myself say to her: "I've got the watch—Thor kissed for ten minutes. We'll beat them by going longer." I noticed it was now seven forty-two.
[1981-06-25 20:27:30] deep in the woods | I heard her ask: "What?" I repeated what I'd said about Thor's kissing time.
[1981-06-25 20:28:00] deep in the woods | I felt my hand rest on her shoulder as I leaned toward her and pressed my lips to hers. After we both lay down, I slipped my tongue into her mouth. I felt her tongue—pointed and soft. I began moving mine inside, but kept my hands against my own body, not touching any other part of her. I felt as though we were two small boats moored beneath the canopy of trees. I tried to focus all my attention on the movement of the tongue. I could feel her breasts and thighs so close to me, my body burning, but I didn't dare touch her.
[1981-06-25 20:31:00] deep in the woods | I felt her lying there with her eyes closed. I opened my eyes searching for the watch and saw only three minutes had passed. I pressed my lower abdomen against the ground and continued moving my tongue. Nine minutes later, I saw her eyes open, but she stared straight up at the sky. I felt saliva running from the corner of her mouth, making me uncomfortable. I noticed she shifted slightly, as if something was wrong. I heard her make a sound—"Mmm... huh..."—but it didn't sound like pleasure. I saw a few dry leaves fall onto her head. I thought it wasn't as wonderful as I'd imagined—actually, it felt rather strenuous. I realized we'd already surpassed Thor's record, but I still wanted to last fifteen minutes. My tongue root began to ache, and the sensation of drool on my chin made me feel disgusted.
[1981-06-25 20:43:00] deep in the woods | At three minutes to eight, I pulled my head back. I saw her stand up and wipe her mouth, not looking at me at all. I stood up too. I excitedly said to her: "We did it—fifteen minutes! We beat them by five!"
[1981-06-25 20:45:00] end of the path | I saw the bicycle glinting at the end of the path. I walked toward it and saw her brushing leaves off her clothes. I stopped and reached out to remove a blade of grass stuck to her sweater. I heard myself say: "Wait, there's one more on your back." After that, I said: "Okay, done."
[1981-06-25 20:47:00] end of the path | I saw her mount her bike and pedal away down the path. I gripped my handlebars and began riding upward. I heard her say: "I should probably head home soon." I said: "Me too." I pointed ahead and said: "There's a shortcut through the woods." Then we said goodbye to each other.
[1981-06-25 22:00:00] Bedroom / On the way | I lay in bed. On Saturday, I waited until the last possible moment before biking down to the phone booth. I thought about her white, full breasts, imagining what we could have done in the woods. I realized I needed to call and confirm the exact time we'd meet on Saturday.
[1981-06-27 19:30:00] home | I heard my mom ask me what I was going to do. I told her I couldn't say. She said no then, I had to know where I was. In the end, I confessed to her about Kaja. As far as I knew, I had to be home by eight-thirty, and that conflicted a bit with going over to her place. I knew the house phone was in the hallway, where anyone could overhear. I thought I couldn't leave her place at eight—that's what she'd think of me? I realized I had to get in touch with Kaja first.
[1981-06-27 19:45:00] on the road / bus station | I cycled downhill, fastening the buttons on my coat. I saw two minivans parked at the station, and noticed the drivers chatting through their windows. Then the vehicles drove off in opposite directions. I saw many dark clouds in the sky, draining color from the earth. I felt the air grow cooler. The roads, stones, and leaves all looked gray. I felt my clothes puff out in the wind, like a balloon.
[1981-06-27 20:00:00] phone booth | I parked my bike behind the green shelter. I took coins from my pocket and inserted them into the slot. I flipped through the phone book searching for the number, my eyes glancing at the dusty window outside. Finally, I dialed. I saw a small stream flowing through the bushes. I saw trash everywhere—wrappers from Caramello and Hubba Bubba gum, some newspapers, and cardboard boxes. Some silly word games popped into my head. I felt myself gathering courage.
[1981-06-27 20:05:00] phone booth | I heard her say, 'Hello?' I quickly said, 'Hi, this is Grete Lundnes. Is this Kaja?' She answered yes. I told her I needed to confirm a suitable time. But she told me the date was canceled. I asked if it was because her parents weren't going out, and she replied, 'It's not because of that... I can't be with you anymore.' I felt a shock, thinking she was breaking up with me—we'd only been together for five days.
[1981-06-27 20:06:00] phone booth / bus station | I said nothing. I felt hot tears running down my cheeks. I hung up the receiver and walked over to the station. I asked her, 'Is it over?' She answered, 'Yes, it's over.' In the end, she said goodbye, and I said it back. I could hear her breathing on the other end of the line; I felt overwhelming pain inside.
[1981-06-27 20:10:00] on the road | I wiped away tears with the back of my hand and sobbed as I cycled back. I felt my vision blurred by tears, barely able to see the road. I kept wondering why she would do this—everything had just begun. I couldn't help shouting inwardly, 'Damn it!'

[1981-06-27 20:20:00] Yenhaug Supermarket / on the road | When I reached the supermarket, I dried my tears with my coat sleeve. I pedaled up that little hill, unable to stop sobbing. I saw the parking lot packed with cars and people carrying shopping bags, along with groups of children. The store was about to close. I worried people would notice I'd been crying, even though I was cycling. I felt a white, empty void opening inside me, and then Kaja's face appeared again, making me even sadder.
[1981-06-27 20:40:00] home / Henrik Inge's room | I locked my bike, slipped into the bathroom to wash my face thoroughly, then returned to my room and sat down. After a while, I went into my brother's room and saw him sitting on the bed playing guitar. He looked up at me. I heard Henrik Inge ask, 'What's wrong? Have you been crying? Is it Kaja? She's not with you anymore?' I paused inside the doorway when entering—I didn't want to run into any family members.
[1981-06-27 20:45:00] Henrik Inge's room | I nodded, and started tearing up again. I heard Henrik Inge tell me, 'It'll pass soon. There are plenty of girls out there.' I replied, 'This is serious. She was so great—I only wanted to be with her.'
[1981-06-27 20:50:00] Henrik Inge's room | I saw him stand up and rummage through his records, holding up one titled 'No Turning Back' in front of me. He placed the mat on the turntable, lowered the needle. I saw the turntable begin to spin with a soft crackle. He told me he was going to play a song that might help. He told me to listen to the lyrics.
[1981-06-27 21:00:00] Henrik Inge's room | I sat in the chair listening to music. I heard Henrik Inge shout, "Listen to this!" The lyrics from the speakers said: What I'm saying isn't exaggeration, our relationship isn't perfect, long-term plans wiped out in a minute, you can just put on your coat and walk away. I heard powerful drumming accompanied by bass, guitar, and electronic instruments. The singer sang with a Stavanger accent.
[1981-06-27 21:05:00] Henrik Inge's room | I heard the song say: We're one centimeter from mediocrity, we drink until we're drunk and sentimental, you shattered my heart and gave me pain, it will all pass, waking up to something entirely new.
[1981-06-27 21:10:00] Henrik Inge's room | I saw the needle lift automatically and return to its base. I heard him say, "It will all pass." I replied, "I know what you mean." He asked if it helped, and I said a little, and asked him to play it again.
[1981-06-27 21:30:00] floating dock | I walked down toward the floating dock. I saw a large group of people gathered around Jørn's new boat. As far as I knew, many people had gotten new boats this spring—mostly 10-footers with 5-horsepower Yamaha engines. I felt restless inside.
[1981-06-27 21:40:00] floating dock | I heard Jørn say, "Our Fermi is here too." Everyone laughed. I said, "Hi." Jørn called to me, "Come over here, I want to show you something." I answered that I didn't want to come. I felt uncomfortable again as that word was brought up once more.
[1981-06-27 21:45:00] floating dock | I hesitated and took a few steps forward. I felt him suddenly grab my legs. The boat began moving backward, forcing me to crouch and then fall to the ground, being dragged toward the edge of the dock. I clung tightly to the edge. I felt the motor speeding up, my body hanging over the water. I started crying. Finally, Jørn shouted, and he stopped. I heard him yell at his brother, "Back up!" I screamed for them to stop. Finally, Jørn shouted, "Enough!" I felt intense fear. I noticed the others standing there just laughing, watching it happen, not helping me at all.
[1981-06-27 22:00:00] cliff / bedroom | I saw Jørn release my legs. I scrambled up onto the dock and got away, sobbing the whole way. I sat on a rock to rest for a while. Eventually, I stood up and went home. I felt the warm air filled with the scent of sun-heated rocks, dry grass, and wildflowers. Night was falling. I felt physically weak. I thought about calling Kjell to ask why, but realized it was over anyway—asking wouldn’t change anything.
[1981-06-27 22:30:00] bathroom / bedroom | In the bathroom, I washed my face with cold water. I returned to my room, drew the curtains, and put on a McCartney single. I began reading Bagley's *The Golden Keel*. I knew the book was about South American pyramids and underground caves, a treasure-hunting story. I could still feel my body trembling. I wanted to hide in the world of the book so I wouldn’t have to face reality.
[1981-06-28 18:00:00] dining room | I sat down to eat dinner. I saw Mom looking at me and smiling. I heard her say, "Maybe it’s time you started using a male deodorant—you’re almost in junior high. I’ll buy you a tube tomorrow." I foolishly asked, "Deodorant?" She said, "You’re nearly in junior high." Henrik Inge chimed in, "Actually, you will start to smell, and no girl will like that."
[1981-06-28 20:00:00] bedroom | I heard Henrik Inge laugh and say he didn’t think it was that simple. I wondered silently—did Kjell leave me because I smelled bad?
[1981-06-29 09:00:00] Bedroom / on the way | I closed the book and walked out the door without looking at Dad. I sat by the roadside, throwing pebbles onto the path. Then I started walking toward the big cherry tree to see if the fruit had ripened yet. I heard Dad come in and say to me, 'You can't just lie around reading all summer. How about going swimming?' I said nothing. I didn't want to respond to him. I thought I couldn't just sit here like this—people might think I have no friends to play with.
[1981-06-29 09:30:00] big cherry tree | I climbed up the big tree, all the way to the highest branches. I picked cherries, bit off the skin, and spat the pits far away. I saw that the cherries weren't fully ripe yet—some green, some turning red, and the skins still hard. As far as I knew, no one had ever claimed ownership of this tree. We came to pick every year, and no one complained. I knew every branch of this tree.
[1981-06-29 10:00:00] big cherry tree | I saw Jøn arrive on his bike and stop beneath the tree. I quickly scrambled down, and the moment my feet touched the ground, he was standing right in front of me. I turned and ran toward the woods uphill. I heard him call my name. He said, 'I just wanted to say I'm sorry! Come here—I can shake your hand, show you my apology!' I saw he was holding a gasoline can in one hand and gripping the handlebars with the other. I sneered inwardly and had no interest in accepting his apology.
[1981-06-29 10:30:00] On the way | I stood on the hilltop after pushing through the bushes, watching him ride away. Then I walked back down the slope, then slowly back up again, glancing at the gardens on both sides. I saw the road was completely empty, everything quiet. I figured most people were probably out at sea or at work. I felt the sour cherries weren't interesting anymore. I hoped I'd run into someone on the main road, so I wouldn't look idle.
[1981-06-29 11:00:00] On the way | I saw Tove's husband lying on a lawn lounger. Through the fence, I saw Mrs. Jacobsen sitting under an umbrella on her balcony, smoking, with her little son beside her. Then I saw Karl running toward me. I heard someone calling my name. I asked Karl, 'Where's Vemd?' He said he was on vacation. He asked me, 'Want to go out rowing with me?' I said yes. He suggested we go to Ylsta Island, and I said OK. I saw the grass had turned yellowish. Mrs. Jacobsen was wearing a white fisherman's hat.
[1981-06-29 13:00:00] at sea | We got into the rowboat. I pushed off from shore and saw Karl sitting there rowing hard. I dipped my hands into the cool water. I heard him grunt 'Oof' with each stroke. I saw the sea was light blue, ripples forming whenever the wind blew. In the distance, waves crested with white foam. I knew Karl’s boat was a rowboat, so our range was limited. I gazed at the clear, cold water and felt a sense of clarity.
[1981-06-29 14:00:00] small island | We approached the island. I jumped ashore and pulled the boat into a small cove. I saw Karl tie the rope to an iron post. We climbed the cliff, dove into the water to swim, then lay on the rocks to dry off. I heard him ask, 'Shall we swim?' I said yes. I felt the wind in the air was cold, but the water was warm. I knew there were many iron posts along the rocky edges of this island.
[1981-06-29 15:00:00] small island | After dressing, I saw Karl squatting in the middle of the grass, lighting a patch of dry grass. I walked over and took the lighter from him. I asked him, 'Where did you get this?' He said he'd taken it from a holiday cabin. I suggested, 'Let's burn something.' I saw grass growing thick in the cracks. The bright flames were almost transparent.
[1981-06-29 15:10:00] small island | I lit the grass. I felt a strong gust of wind sweep past, and the flame shot upward rapidly. We jumped up immediately and stomped to put it out. I shouted, 'Hey! Watch out! The fire's spreading!' Karl laughed loudly. I said to him, 'Help me—this fire's getting too big.' I saw the flame rise like a small blanket.
[1981-06-29 15:20:00] small island | I took the lighter again. We lit fires in different spots. Where I set fire, the flames snaked outward like a serpent. Another gust of wind came, and I saw the flames leap as high as our knees. I heard him shout excitedly, 'Hear that? It's crackling!' I also heard him cry, 'Ouch, ouch!' I felt the fire grow fierce, the crackling sound right beside my ears.
[1981-06-29 15:30:00] the islet | I saw him stomping frantically. I sensed fear in his voice, and I started stomping too. We took off our sweaters and desperately beat at the fire on the ground. I shouted, "No! The fire's spreading over there too!" I suggested, "Take off your sweaters—we can use them to put out the fire!" I felt the wind constantly whipping the flames, and the fire was spreading outward. I felt that the situation had already spiraled out of control.
[1981-06-29 15:40:00] the islet | We kept beating at the fire, but it was no use. I stood a few meters away, watching the blaze. I heard Karl shout, "We can't put it out." I said it would only get worse. He asked what we should do; I suggested using a ladle, but he snapped back if I'd lost my mind. Finally he yelled, "Let's get out of here—go!" I felt intense heat hitting my face. I saw the flames roaring fiercely, making sharp, crackling sounds.
[1981-06-29 16:00:00] at sea | We pushed the boat away from shore. I saw Karl sitting there rowing hard. I looked back toward the shore. I heard him muttering over and over, "Damn it, look at that fire go!" I said who could have known. He reassured me it would be fine as long as no one saw us. I saw flames dancing across the grass, making terrifying noises.

[1981-06-29 17:00:00] shore / woods / home | We reached land and dragged the boat into the woods. We stripped off our clothes and scrubbed them in the water. To get rid of the smell of smoke, we jumped into the river and washed again. I sneaked into the basement to hang up the clothes, then went upstairs bare-chested, changed into clean clothes in my room. I thought that if anyone asked, we’d say our clothes had fallen into the water while swimming. I still felt somewhat shaken.
[1981-06-29 18:00:00] bedroom | I saw Dad lying on the sunbed. I heard the distant sound of a radio. The lawn had turned yellow under the sun. The sunlight remained strong. I was observing from the window of Henrik Inge's room. I remembered how Mom used to sit on the windowsill in the living room. I thought he could lie there motionless like a lizard, basking in the sun.
[1981-06-29 19:00:00] bedroom | I saw Mom walk into the room and hand me a bottle of MUM for Men. I looked at the little blue bottle and smelled its sweet scent. She explained that I should dab a bit under my arms after showering, and emphasized I must wash thoroughly first, or the smell would get worse. I knew I was about to start middle school. I noticed it was labeled for men only. I felt like I was truly becoming a man or a young adult.
[1981-06-29 19:30:00] bedroom | I followed her instructions and applied the deodorant, then sniffed the new scent on my body. I lay down and continued reading my book about vampires. I knew I had bought the book myself, that it was my favorite, and that this was already my second time reading it.
[1981-06-29 20:00:00] kitchen | I walked into the kitchen and sat down. I saw Dad’s skin deeply tanned, his eyes dark and heavy. I saw Mom brewing tea. I heard Mom say, "Marta invited us up to their summer cabin today." Dad coldly refused, "Don’t even think about it. Did she say anything else?" Mom replied nothing special. I ate as fast as I could without seeming eager to escape.
[1981-06-29 20:10:00] kitchen | I heard an engine starting up, accompanied by several groans. I saw Dad staring out the window, shaking his head. Dad asked, "Isn’t Oskar Magnus away on vacation?" I told him, "Yes, but Helen Sterli and Tova aren’t gone—they’re home alone."
[1981-06-29 20:15:00] kitchen | I heard the engine start again—this time with a loud roar. I couldn’t help wanting to stand up and see what was happening. I heard Dad command, "Sit down!" Mom asked what was going on. Dad sneered, "Some damn kids are sneaking around driving their parents’ car." He looked at Mom and said, "Unbelievable. Tova and Grete are in the same class—how could he steal a car like that?" After finishing my meal, I said thanks for the snack and got ready to go back to my room.
[1981-06-29 20:20:00] kitchen | I saw him turn and look at Mom. I sat there swallowing the last small piece of bread, finished the milk in my glass, then stood up. I heard Dad say, “It’s really unbelievable. Don’t they control their children at all? Toya Moen is in the same class as Grete Lundnes. He just took his parents’ car without permission?” I said to them, “Thanks for the snack. I think I’ll go to bed now.” Mom said to me, “Good night.” I heard the sound of the car rattling as it climbed up the hill.
[1981-06-29 21:00:00] bedroom | I saw him come in before I turned off the light. I sat up in bed. I quickly looked up and met his eyes. I heard Dad ask, “How many apples did you eat today?” I answered, “One.” He pressed on, “Are you sure? Grandmother said she gave you one apple.” I replied, “Really? Oh, my God! I completely forgot about it!”
[1981-06-29 21:05:00] bedroom | I felt his hand grab my ear and twist it hard. Then I saw his hand let go. I heard him demand, “You didn’t smoke, did you?” I shouted, “No!” He went on, “Helen Ster says you did. Are you saying Helen Ster is lying to me?” I answered, “Yes, he must be lying, because I never smoked.”
[1981-06-29 21:10:00] bedroom | I saw him turn and walk out of the room, his face still dark. I lay down and stared at the ceiling for a while. I heard him say finally, “Why are you crying? If you’ve done nothing wrong? I know you, Grete Lundnes. I know you smoked. But don’t do it again. This time, we’ll leave it at that.” I wiped my eyes with the bedsheet. I thought, although I absolutely hadn’t smoked, he must know what I’d done—but how could he possibly know?
[1981-06-30 14:00:00] the island | I saw Karl Larsdal put down his oars. We laughed in the boat until we almost fell into the water. I heard Karl Larsdal point at the island and say, “It’s all black up there!” I saw the island completely charred. I thought we couldn’t let go of this.
[1981-07-15 10:00:00] farm / Jestead Lake / tent hospital | I stood under the scorching sun picking strawberries, packing them, and tidying carrot vines. At noon, I sat beneath a cliff eating my lunch, then biked to Jestead Lake and jumped into the water to bathe. I saw myself taken to a tent hospital in the middle of a field, where I lay until evening. I felt the weather unbearably hot. I heard someone playing Roxy Music’s 'More Than This' from far away. [1984-09-01 10:00:10] Tvet old house (memory) | I saw a river in front of the house. The old house stood high up, with woods behind it. I knew we lived in Tvet back then. As far as I knew, the entire property also included a large grain barn and a storage shed.
[1984-09-15 10:00:00] Jimler Hall auditorium (memory) | I saw a teacher with wild white hair and a loose robe walking down the steps, reading poetry to us. I heard the teacher suddenly insert a line praising an erect private part in that poem. In the auditorium of Jimler Hall, surrounded by freshmen. I knew that teacher was a notorious nudist. I saw everyone in the room burst into laughter.
[1984-09-15 10:05:00] Jimler Hall auditorium (memory) | I sat there with my mouth open and eyes fixed blankly ahead. I didn't laugh. I thought to myself, are all erect things really bent? I was slowly beginning to grasp the meaning of that line of poetry.
[1984-11-15 18:00:00] Tvetold old house | I felt the chill in the house. I saw clumps of dried cat droppings curled up on the sofa upstairs, and an old dishwasher standing on the kitchen counter.
