All the heating was turned off. I knew my father mostly ate out, and the house was almost devoid of life. I sensed a deep silence enveloping the house. I realized my father was suffering inside.
[1984-12-02 19:38:00] Tvetold old house | I set down my handbag in the cold bedroom. I bumped into my dad just as he returned, in the hallway. I saw his hair was disheveled and his eyes dark and sunken.
[1984-12-02 19:38:10] Tvetold old house | I asked my dad, "Can't we light a fire? It's too cold here."
[1984-12-02 19:38:15] Tvetold old house | I heard my dad mockingly imitate my pronunciation: "Light a fire? We don't fucking light fires here."
[1984-12-02 19:38:25] Tvetold old house | I knew I couldn't pronounce the 'r' sound—it was my greatest childhood insecurity. As far as I knew, my father always mimicked me either to correct me, or simply because he disliked me and wanted to oppose me.
[1984-12-02 19:38:35] Tvetold old house | I turned and walked up the stairs. Back in my room, I grabbed a few new records and took out several sweaters from the closet. I dressed quickly, slung my travel bag over my shoulder, and walked out of the yard. I knew I was nearly sixteen years old. I was glad he didn’t see the tears in my eyes—I felt ashamed of them. I felt my father had placed an inescapable lid over my head, and I decided to defy him.
[1984-12-02 19:39:00] Tvetold old house | After going upstairs to my room, I grabbed a few new records and stuffed them into my handbag, then went downstairs to the room beside the front door where my wardrobe was. I took out several sweaters from the cabinet, put on clothes in the hallway, slung my travel bag over my shoulder, and walked out of the yard.
[1984-12-02 19:39:20] Outside Tvetold old house | I started walking downhill. I saw a sky full of stars and a high-hanging moon, with the hills bathed in moonlight. I heard my footsteps crackling on the icy ruts. I saw the thin-iced snow glittering under the lights, and the grass was brightly lit.
[1984-12-02 19:39:40] beside the roadside mailbox | I stopped beside the mailbox. I hesitated for a moment about whether to turn back and say goodbye. I thought it would mean more to leave without saying anything—it would make him reflect on what he'd done.
[1984-12-02 19:40:00] beside the roadside mailbox | I pulled off my glove and pushed up my sleeve to check my watch. As far as I knew, there would be a bus in half an hour. I thought it was 7:40 now—how great it would be if I could catch that bus home.
[1984-12-02 19:40:10] beside the roadside mailbox | I cursed inwardly—damn it, don’t let me miss the bus.
[1984-12-02 19:40:20] by the roadside | I slung my travel bag over my shoulder and kept walking, casting one last glance back at the house. I saw a thin wisp of white smoke curling up from the chimney on the roof. I figured he must have regretted it already, brought in firewood and lit the stove—he probably still thinks I’m lying upstairs in my room.
[1984-12-02 19:40:30] by the roadside | I heard the ice cracking on the river. The sound rushed up the valley with a loud boom.
[1984-12-02 19:40:40] by the roadside | I looked up at the starry sky and the moon. I saw headlights from cars on the opposite bank cutting through the darkness like cracks. I saw the water gauge on the ice glowing faintly with damp light. The air carried a chill. I felt a shiver run down my spine. That sound of ice breaking always fills me with immense joy.
[1984-12-02 19:41:00] by the roadside | I turned around and started walking back up again. I thought that since he had already lit the fire out of regret, leaving without a word had lost its meaning.
[1984-12-02 19:45:00] entrance of the old Tveted house | I came in and began untying the laces of my boots. I saw him open the door, standing there holding the doorknob, watching me. I heard his footsteps above me in the living room.
[1984-12-02 19:45:10] entrance of the old Tveted house | I heard Dad ask, "Are you going out?"
[1984-12-02 19:45:15] entrance of the old Tveted house | I nodded at him. I thought I’d already gone out and was now coming back—but there was no way I could explain all that.
[1984-12-02 19:45:20] Tvetold House foyer | I said to Dad, "That's right, we're starting early tomorrow."
[1984-12-02 19:45:25] Tvetold House foyer | I heard Dad say, "Alright, alright, I think I'll go out for a bit tomorrow afternoon. Just letting you know."
[1984-12-02 19:45:30] Tvetold House foyer | I saw him look at me for a few seconds, then close the door and walk into the living room. I replied to Dad, "Okay."
[1984-12-02 19:45:40] Tvetold House foyer | I opened the door again. I called out to Dad, "Dad?"
[1984-12-02 19:45:45] Tvetold House foyer | I saw him turn around and look at me. He didn't say a word.
[1984-12-02 19:45:50] Tvetold House foyer | I said to Dad, "There's a parent-teacher meeting tomorrow afternoon, remember? Six o'clock."
[1984-12-02 19:45:55] Tvetold House foyer | I heard Dad reply, "Is there? Alright, yes, I should go to that."
[1984-12-02 19:46:00] Tvetold House foyer | I saw him continue walking into the living room. I closed the door, tied my shoes, slung my travel bag over my shoulder, and walked to the bus stop.
locations: entrance of the old Tveted house

text:
[1984-12-02 19:56:00] Bus stop | I stood at the station. I saw the rolling hills behind me, and scattered glowing houses across the river valley. I saw the waterfall beneath my feet frozen into a massive ice dome, shining faintly in the dim light. I looked up at the stars. I thought the stars above looked like they were scattered across a frozen seabed.
[1984-12-02 20:10:00] On the bus | The bus arrived. I showed my pass to the driver and sat in the second-to-last seat on the left side of the bus—I always take that seat if it's free. I saw the headlights cut a beam through the dark. There was little traffic; we sped past Solsletta and Rynsletta, followed the banks of the Hamresanden River, entered the woods heading toward Timenes, turned onto the E18 highway, passed over the Varø Bridge, went by the high school, and entered the city center.
[1984-12-02 20:40:00] Grandparents' apartment | The apartment is located at the lowest point on this side of the river. To the left upon entering is my grandfather's office. On the right lies the living quarters—two living rooms, a kitchen, and a small bathroom. The second floor is also divided into two parts: to the right is an unfinished, extremely spacious attic; on the other side is a single room—that’s where I live. There I have a bed, a desk, a small sofa and coffee table, a record player, a shelf holding records, a stack of school textbooks, some magazines and music periodicals, and a wardrobe containing a pile of clothes.
[1984-12-02 20:40:10] Grandparents' apartment | The house is very old. It once belonged to my father's grandmother—my great-grandmother—who passed away here. I can somewhat understand my father now; during his upbringing, he was closest to his grandmother and spent much of his time here. To me, she is like a ghost from mythology—strong, authoritative, opinionated, mother of three sons, one of whom is my grandfather. In all the photographs I've seen of her, she always wears a black dress with buttons fastened tightly up to her neck. In the final years of her life, she suffered from senile dementia, which lasted nearly ten years beginning around 1870, and within the family they began calling her "the old fool."
[1984-12-02 20:40:20] Grandparents' apartment | I took off my boots and climbed the steep staircase that resembled a ladder, entered my room. I turned on the heater. Turned on the record player. I lay down on the bed and started reading. The book I was reading was Bram Stoker’s Dracula, which I had already read once the previous year, but this time it felt just as thrilling and intense. I felt a bit cold. Listening to Echo and the Bunnymen’s Heaven Up Here.
[1984-12-02 23:30:00] Grandparents' apartment | I lay quietly reading until half past eleven, then brushed my teeth, undressed, and went to bed. I heard the city outside my window accompanied by a steady, low hum from passing cars, fading out of consciousness and occasionally returning without awareness, as if I myself were in motion.
[1984-12-05 07:00:00] Grandparents' apartment | Until high school, I always woke up in such a house—my parents already up and rushing off to work, the air filled with the smell of tobacco, coffee brewing, radio playing, breakfast being eaten, car engines warming up in the darkness outside. Waking up there in the morning felt completely different—being alone in the apartment seemed not only to leave the surroundings empty, but also something inside me. It was an entirely different atmosphere, and I loved it.
[1984-12-05 07:30:00] On the way to school | Most high school students came from the city or surrounding areas; only a few of us, including myself, were from rural areas. So in October of that year, I started smoking. After school, walking back to where I stayed posed no problem. First because most days I either headed to training at Tvet or met up with Vallund, and second because no one saw me, so no one could know that I spent all those nights alone in the apartment. Walking less than a kilometer through the old residential neighborhood to high school was something I enjoyed too—my mind would fill with pleasant thoughts, as if I were someone important. But that was also a major disadvantage. This constant clustering together in groups made every break between classes problematic: Where should I stand? Where should I go? I could sit in the library reading or stay in the classroom pretending to look over homework, but both options sent a signal that I was an outsider. Not because I wanted to, nor because I wished to appear tough, but simply because I had somewhere to be. Being alone was the thing I feared most in the world.
[1984-12-05 08:30:00] Classroom | Our class had four boys and twenty-six girls. I sat in the back corner next to Baasen, with Moeller sitting in front of me, and Boer at the front of our row. The rest of the classroom was filled entirely with girls—twenty-six sixteen-year-old girls. But in class, things were different. In class, I had my role, my place. There I could speak, answer questions, join discussions, complete assignments—I existed. There I followed along with everyone else; we were all together. I didn’t draw attention to myself, so no one objected to my presence.
[1984-12-05 08:35:00] Classroom | Monica, whose parents are Hungarian Jews. Elsa Ingrid, a pretty girl from Vågå who sings in the choir, a Christian, rather childish. Siv, with light blonde hair and long brown legs. Benedikte, her face sharply defined, features almost reminiscent of women from the 1950s, curly hair, dressed in upper-class fashion. Tone, graceful in posture, dark-haired and somewhat serious, she paints. Anne, wearing braces. Hilde, pale yellow hair, rosy cheeks, bold and outspoken. Irene, the central figure among the girls, beautiful yet instantly forgettable. Nina, so strong and robust, with a physique almost masculine in its sturdiness, yet dressed in distinctly feminine skirts. I liked some of them, but not enough to say I was in love. Monica was intellectually sharp and well-read; when we discussed the conflict in Palestine, she always restrained herself, speaking moderately yet firmly in defense of Israel—something I couldn’t quite grasp, since clearly Israel was a military state and Palestine the victim. It was pleasant just to be in the same room as Elsa Ingrid. Early in the semester, Siv remarked that the area between the church school and the business school resembled an American campus, and that’s when I first noticed her—because she knew something I didn’t, and I wanted to belong to this world. Siv loved boasting, and her laugh was unusually loud. Tone seemed more independent than the others. At a class gathering that autumn, I fondled and kissed Anne on the barber chair belonging to Baasen’s mother. Hilde still sometimes hesitated, often turning toward me.
[1984-12-05 08:40:00] Classroom | Mette, short and slender, exceptionally intelligent. She loved Bruce Springsteen, always wore jeans, tiny in stature but constantly laughing, dressed provocatively and haphazardly, always smelling of cigarettes, showing her gums whenever she laughed—which aside from that flaw made her a pretty girl. But Mette’s laughter was peculiar—just after she finished speaking or was about to utter something silly, she’d let out a sharp consonant-like snicker. In fact, she was slightly tongue-tied, her speech a bit slurred, which naturally detracted from her beauty—in other words, she couldn’t truly be called beautiful. Around me swarmed a crowd of girls, a current of flesh, an ocean of breasts and thighs. Just watching their silhouettes behind the desks made me feel closer to them. In other words, my days gained meaning; I was happy to enter the classroom, to be among all these girls, sitting in the seat where I had the right to be.

[1984-12-05 09:00:00] School cafeteria/classroom | This morning I was the first to go downstairs to the cafeteria, bought a school-made sandwich and a bottle of cola, returned to my seat, chewing while flipping through a book. I watched students slowly trickle in, exchanging a few quiet words with Moeller. I saw them all moving sluggishly, faces still clouded with last night’s sleep, and soon the classroom filled up. Moeller lived in Hamresanden, and we had been classmates in middle school.
[1984-12-05 09:10:00] school classroom | Then the teacher arrived, his name was Berg, wearing a simple smock. This was our Leivik class, alongside history the subject I did best in, my grades always between five and five plus, never higher. I decided I would aim even higher on the exam.
[1984-12-05 10:00:00] school classroom | The teacher who taught us math and natural science was an old-fashioned figure. The math teacher was Vestby, whose entire body twitched; one arm constantly twisted and turned uncontrollably. During his lessons, I would put my legs up on the desk and chat with Båsen. At that, Vestby’s thick, fleshy face would instantly turn bright red, and he’d shriek my name in a sharp, grating voice. So I’d lower my legs—then as soon as he turned around, I’d start talking again. Natural science was my weak spot, and back then my math grades dropped as low as two. I never opened a book; the lectures were far beyond my comprehension.
[1984-12-05 11:00:00] school classroom | The natural science teacher, Nergaard, was short and thin, almost like a shrunken little old man, with a devilish grin, though his yawns looked oddly childlike. He was nearly at retirement age. He also had muscle tics—one eye constantly blinking, his shoulders jerking up and down, his neck suddenly snapping backward. I thought these movements made him look exactly like he was mimicking an unbearable teacher—very funny. In the summer term he wore a light-colored suit, in winter a dark one. Once I saw him use the large compass from class like a rifle: we were all bent over our tests when he loomed above us, clamping the two arms of the compass together and hoisting it onto his shoulder, then pacing slowly through the classroom, stopping now and then, wearing a sly, mischievous smile.
[1984-12-05 11:30:00] school classroom | I talked during his classes too, so often that eventually whenever he heard whispering somewhere in the room, no matter who it was, he’d snap, 'Grete Lundnes!' and raise his palm into the air—meaning I had to stand up from my seat and remain standing until the bell rang. I could hardly believe my eyes—was he out of his mind? But it actually pleased me, because inside me began to grow a rebellious urge to defy him: Screw it, that's how it is, what are you gonna do? I started planning to pierce my ear, shave my head completely. What did natural science have to do with me? Or math? I wanted to play in a band, to feel free, to live the life I wanted, not the life I was supposed to live.
[1984-12-05 12:00:00] school | No one shared this view with me; in this, I was utterly alone. So right now it seemed unreal, something belonging to the future—and everything about the future felt formless. Not doing homework, not paying attention in class—it all felt equally meaningless. Before, I’d always been among the top students in every subject, always eager to show off my achievements. But not anymore. Now I saw those good grades as almost shameful, signs that you stayed home all day buried in books, head down—a loser. Leivik was different; it connected to writers, to artists. And it wasn’t something you could get just from reading books—there was something else to it: emotion, intuition, personal style.
[1984-12-05 14:30:00] on the way home from school | For the entire class period I sat there scribbling aimlessly, smoked by the school gate during breaks, and when the final bell rang at half past two, I began walking home to my little dorm room. Within this routine, the sky and outdoor scenery slowly unfolded—the day passed. It was December 5th, the day before my birthday. I was turning sixteen, and Mom would be coming home from Baysang. Joy filled my heart. Living alone with Dad had been okay in some ways—he kept his distance as much as possible. He lived in Sandnes, I in town, going opposite directions. But that would end when Mom returned. Until New Year’s, we’d all live together again. With Mom around, the daily burden of facing Dad would be almost entirely compensated. I could talk to her. About anything. To Dad, I couldn’t say anything. It was impossible—we had nothing to talk about except practical matters, like where I was going or when I’d be back.
[1984-12-05 14:45:00] grandparents' apartment | When I walked back to the apartment, I saw his car parked outside. I went in. I smelled barbecue smoke throughout the hallway, heard the clatter of cutlery from the kitchen, and the sound of the radio.
[1984-12-05 14:45:10] grandparents' apartment | I poked my head in. I said, 'Hi.'
[1984-12-05 14:45:15] grandparents' apartment kitchen | I heard him say, 'Hi, are you hungry?'
[1984-12-05 14:45:20] grandparents' apartment kitchen | I said, 'Yes, very hungry. What did you make?'
[1984-12-05 14:45:25] Grandparents' apartment kitchen | I heard him say, "Grilled pork chops. You sit down, it'll be ready in a moment."
[1984-12-05 14:45:30] Grandparents' apartment kitchen | I walked into the room and sat down at the round dining table. The table was very old; I guessed it had once belonged to his grandmother.
[1984-12-05 14:46:00] Grandparents' apartment kitchen | I saw Dad put two pork chops, three potatoes, and a small pile of roasted onions onto my plate. He sat down and began eating.
[1984-12-05 14:46:10] Grandparents' apartment kitchen | I heard him say, "By the way, any news from school?"
[1984-12-05 14:46:15] Grandparents' apartment kitchen | I shook my head.
[1984-12-05 14:46:20] Grandparents' apartment kitchen | I heard him ask, "Didn't you learn anything today?"
[1984-12-05 14:46:25] Grandparents' apartment kitchen | I said, "No."
[1984-12-05 14:46:30] Grandparents' apartment kitchen | I heard him say, "Nothing at all."
[1984-12-05 14:47:00] Grandparents' apartment kitchen | We continued eating in silence. I didn't want to hurt him. I didn't want him to think this was unpleasant, that his relationship with his son was strained. So I sat there trying to think of something I could say. But nothing came to mind. I felt he wasn't in a bad mood—no anger—but distant, absent-minded.
[1984-12-05 14:48:00] Grandparents' apartment kitchen | I said, "Have you been to see Grandfather and Grandmother recently?"
[1984-12-05 14:48:10] Grandparents' apartment kitchen | I saw him staring at me. I heard him say, "Been there, stayed a short while yesterday afternoon. Why are you asking?"
[1984-12-05 14:48:20] Grandparents' apartment kitchen | I said, "Nothing, I just wanted to know." I felt a flush pass over my face.
[1984-12-05 14:50:00] Grandparents' apartment kitchen | I had already cut off all the meat with my knife as best as I could. Now I lifted a bone and brought it to my mouth, starting to gnaw on it. I saw Dad doing the same thing, beginning to chew on his bone. I put the bone down and drained the glass of water in one go.
[1984-12-05 14:50:10] Grandparents' apartment kitchen | Then I stood up. I said, "Thank you for dinner."
[1984-12-05 14:50:15] Grandparents' apartment kitchen | I heard him say, "The parent-teacher meeting starts at six, right?"
[1984-12-05 14:50:20] Grandparents' apartment kitchen | I said, "Yes."
[1984-12-05 14:50:25] Grandparents' apartment kitchen | I heard him ask, "You're staying here then, not leaving?"
[1984-12-05 14:50:30] Grandparents' apartment kitchen | I said, "That's the plan."
[1984-12-05 14:50:35] Grandparents' apartment kitchen | I heard him say, "Then I'll stop by after I'm done and pick you up, and we'll drive to Sannes together. Is that okay?"
[1984-12-05 14:50:40] Grandparents' apartment kitchen | I said, "Okay."
locations: on the way home from school

text:
[1984-12-05 19:30:00] my place in the city | I was sitting there writing a composition in the style of a sports drink advertisement when he came back. I saw the door push open, heard the city's clamor suddenly rise, and detected heavy footsteps and his voice echoing on the floor of the entryway.
[1984-12-05 19:30:10] my place in the city | I heard him say, "Grete Lundnes? Ready? We're leaving right away."
[1984-12-05 19:32:00] my place in the city | I packed all the things I needed into my travel bag and backpack, both bulging full. Since I’d be staying at home for the next month, it was hard to know exactly what I’d need.
[1984-12-05 19:33:00] the stairs of my place in the city | As I went down the stairs, I saw him staring at me. He shook his head. I didn't think he was angry. It was something else.
[1984-12-05 19:33:10] the stairs of my place in the city | I said, "What about the parent-teacher meeting?" It was as if he already knew the worst had happened, so I avoided looking at him while speaking.
[1984-12-05 19:33:20] the stairs of my place in the city | I heard him say, "What happened? Well, let me tell you. I got an earful from your math teacher. That’s what happened. Westby—was that his name?"
[1984-12-05 19:33:25] the stairs of my place in the city | I said, "Yes."
[1984-12-05 19:33:30] the stairs of my place in the city | I heard him say, "Why didn’t you tell me about this? I was left completely in the dark. Truly astonished, I was."
[1984-12-05 19:33:40] the stairs of my place in the city | At the same time, I began putting on my coat. I said, "Well, what did he say?" I was strangely relieved that Dad remained calm.
[1984-12-05 19:34:00] the stairs of my place in the city | I heard him say, "He said you put your legs up on the desk during class, showed no respect for discipline, acted outrageously, talked during lessons, neither read nor did your assignments. If this continues, he’s finished. That’s what he said. Is it true?"
[1984-12-05 19:34:10] the stairs of my apartment in town | I said as I straightened up, already dressed. I said, "Yes, partly that's true."
[1984-12-05 19:34:20] the stairs of my apartment in town | I heard him say, "He said it was my fault, you know. He scolded me for having a son like me."
[1984-12-05 19:34:30] the stairs of my apartment in town | I turned around where I was standing. I said, "So what did you say?"
[1984-12-05 19:34:45] the stairs of my apartment in town | I heard him say, "I talked back to him, gave him a piece of my mind too. Your performance at school is his responsibility, not mine. But of course it's unpleasant all the same. You understand that."
[1984-12-05 19:34:55] the stairs of my apartment in town | I said, "I understand. Sorry."
[1984-12-05 19:35:05] the stairs of my apartment in town | I heard him say, "It's no use. This was the last parent-teacher meeting I'm ever going to attend—period. Now, can we go?"
[1984-12-05 19:36:00] outside the apartment / by the car | We walked out through the front door and headed toward the car. I saw Dad get into the driver's seat and lean across to open my door from the inside.
[1984-12-05 19:36:10] by the car | I said, "Could you open the trunk too?"
[1984-12-05 19:37:00] by the car / inside the car | I saw that he didn't answer, but he did as I asked. I put my travel bag and backpack into the trunk, closed the lid carefully so as not to disturb him—he was turning the ignition key—and then I sat down in the front seat, pulled the seatbelt across my chest, and clicked it into place.
[1984-12-05 19:37:30] inside the moving car | I saw him start the engine. I heard Dad say, "Anyway, it's embarrassing. But what kind of teacher is this Westby, really?" The dashboard lit up. The car ahead of us had already moved off down toward the river.
[1984-12-05 19:38:00] Inside a moving car | I said, "Pretty bad. He can't maintain discipline. Nobody in class cares about what he says, so no one listens to him. He doesn't reflect on his own mistakes or learn from them either."
[1984-12-05 19:38:10] Inside a moving car | I heard Dad say, "Did you know that he ranked at the top of his class during university exams?"
[1984-12-05 19:38:15] Inside a moving car | I said, "I didn't know."
[1984-12-05 19:45:00] Inside a moving car | The car backed up a few meters, pulled onto the road, turned around, and began driving out of town. As usual, I saw that he was driving fast—his hand on the steering wheel, the other resting casually on the gearshift beside him. The overheated engine roared; small studs on the tires made a steady whooshing sound as they rolled over the pavement. My stomach churned, yet a small wave of joy spread through my body because this had never happened before. He had never defended me. He never showed leniency toward criticism about my behavior. Every summer and Christmas vacation, when I had to hand in my school report card, I would start feeling anxious a week in advance. Even the tiniest negative comment would make him blame me and fly into a rage. Parent-teacher meetings were the same. Afterward, he would vent his anger over even the smallest criticism—like talking too much in class or being forgetful. And it was even worse when I brought home official school notices. Those were judgment days. Days in hell.
[1984-12-05 19:50:00] Inside a moving car | I wondered—was it because I was nearly grown up now that he treated me this way? Were we finally becoming equals?
[1984-12-05 19:55:00] Inside a moving car | As he sat there staring ahead while our car rushed down the road, I really wanted to look at him. But I couldn't, because then I'd have to say something, and I had nothing to say.
[1984-12-05 20:15:00] Sannes' yard | Half an hour later, we drove up the final slope and entered the courtyard in front of the house. Dad didn’t turn off the engine—he got out to open the garage door. I walked toward the front door and unlocked it. Remembering the luggage, I turned back, just in time to see Dad switching off the engine. The red taillights flickered.
[1984-12-05 20:15:10] Sannes' yard | I said, "Open the trunk?"
[1984-12-05 20:16:00] Sannes' yard / inside the house | I saw him nod, insert the key again, and twist it. The hood rose like a whale’s tail and brushed against me. When I stepped into the house, I immediately noticed he had cleaned. I smelled the scent of green soap; the rooms were tidied, the floor gleamed. The dried cat droppings on the sofa upstairs were gone.
[1984-12-05 20:20:00] Sannes' house | A few weeks after Mom moved to Baysang for her studies, he invited several colleagues over to the house in Sannes for a small gathering. He asked me if I could stay in town that night. If I felt lonely, I could always go to Grandmother and Grandfather's, as long as I wanted. That morning, he stopped by and brought me a bag of food—baked pizza, cola, and french fries—that I could eat in front of the TV. Of course he cleaned—the reason being that Mom was coming home. He wouldn’t otherwise go to such lengths to clean for himself, since his place had always been messy and unpleasant. Now I felt much more at ease. The house was back in its former orderly state. It wasn’t just due to my personal inner turmoil or anything else—I was disturbed by multiple factors, especially because this disturbance wasn’t singular. Something had changed in him this autumn. Perhaps it was because of our lifestyle—just the two of us living together—but clearly, it wasn’t only that. He’d never had any friends, nor did anyone ever visit us except family. The only people he knew were colleagues and neighbors—which meant, at Rocky that was the case, but here, he didn’t even know his neighbors. Being alone is the thing I fear most in the world.
[1984-12-05 20:25:00] Sannes' house | The next morning I took the bus to Vallund, stayed there for a few hours, then continued back home by bus. The door was locked. I opened the garage to check whether he had gone for a walk or driven off. The garage was empty. I returned to the front of the house and unlocked the door. I squatted down beside the small pile of records—some leaning against a chair leg, others scattered on the floor nearby. I stood up and walked into the kitchen. There were unwashed cups and dishes in the sink. I opened the refrigerator; in the front row were several bottles of white wine and some beer, almost all empty. I went upstairs. Dad’s bedroom door was open, so I went in. I saw that Mom’s bed had also been moved in and placed right next to Dad’s. My room was untouched. I packed the things I wanted to take and headed back to town. On the living room table stood several wine bottles, the ashtray filled with cigarette butts. Though not cleaned up, it didn’t look too bad. The stereo system, which was usually stored in the attic, now sat on a small table beside the fireplace. Everything here bore some trace of unfamiliarity. I thought they must have had a little party. I remembered these records—he’d listened to them for many years: Pink Floyd, Joe Dassin, Arja Saijonmaa, Marie Hauken, Elvis, Bach, Vivaldi. Those last two tapes, he must have played either just before the party or earlier that morning. The other music wasn’t especially suited for such a gathering. Because of the drinking, the party must have lasted late into the night. The house is in a remote location, and taking a taxi into town or to Dad’s workplace in Vennesla isn’t cheap, so someone probably stayed over. Although I had planned to stay overnight myself.
[1984-12-05 20:30:00] Sannes' house | Another time I returned there unannounced. After training, I didn’t feel like going back to town, so my teammate Tom drove me home. In the light from the kitchen, I saw Dad sitting at the table, one hand propping up his head, a bottle of liquor in front of him. I didn’t want him to know I’d seen him, but I couldn’t turn back. So I deliberately stomped and kicked the snow off my boots loudly at the door, flung it open, then slammed it shut behind me, making it unmistakably clear that I had just arrived. I turned on both faucets in the bathroom and sat inside waiting for a few minutes. When I entered the kitchen, it was empty. An empty glass stood on the counter, an empty liquor bottle tucked into the cabinet beneath the sink. Dad had returned to the apartment underneath the granary where he lived. It was evening. This was new. He had never gotten drunk before—at least not while I was around, and certainly never alone. Now I had seen it.
[1984-12-05 20:35:00] Outside Solstua Shop / Sannes' house | One afternoon earlier that day, I saw him drive past the shop at Solstua. I had skipped the last three classes, and before heading to Rogaland for training that evening, I stopped by Vallund. As I sat smoking on the bench outside the shop, Dad’s snot-green Ascona drove past—I couldn’t have mistaken it. The car kept going. I tossed away my cigarette. There was no reason to hide, and as the car passed, I stared straight at it, even raised a hand in greeting. But he didn’t see me—he was talking to the person sitting beside him. When he came to my place the next day, I mentioned it. He said it was a colleague, and that they had been working together on a project at our house for a few hours after school. As if this weren’t mysterious enough.
[1984-12-05 20:40:00] Sannes' house | During this period, he had frequent contact with colleagues. One weekend they attended a lecture together in Hofden. He went to gatherings far more often than I could ever recall before. Certainly, it must be because he felt bored or disliked being alone for long stretches. I was glad about it. By then, I began to see him differently—not as a child sees a parent, but through the eyes of someone on the verge of adulthood. For a moment, I truly wished he had many friends and colleagues around him, just like anyone else. Yet at the same time, I disliked this change—it made him unpredictable. In fact, his unusually defending me at a parent-teacher meeting belonged precisely to this category of unpredictability. Yes, perhaps that was the most striking thing of all.
[1984-12-05 20:50:00] Second-floor room at Sannes' house | I took my clothes out of the suitcase and put them into the wardrobe, slid each record into the rack on the desk, and neatly stacked my school textbooks into a pile. The house was built in the mid-19th century, and all the floorboards creaked. These sounds ran through every wall, so I didn’t just know Dad was in the living room downstairs—I also knew he was sitting on the sofa. I had intended to finish reading Dracula, but I realized I couldn’t settle down to read until I’d clarified the situation between Dad and me. Naturally, he knew what I was doing, and I knew what he was doing.
locations: the stairs of my place in the city
the stairs of my apartment in town
outside the apartment / by the car
by the car / inside the car

text:
[1984-12-05 21:00:00] Stairs / Kitchen at Sannes' house | So I went downstairs and wandered into the kitchen—maybe there was something to eat? And why couldn’t I just go down and say directly, 'Hey Dad, I’m upstairs reading'? 'Why would you tell me that?' he’d ask—or at least think. But this awkward state of affairs needed to change.
[1984-12-05 21:02:00] Living room at Sannes' house | As I approached the final steps into the living room, I saw him sitting there, holding one of my old comic books.
[1984-12-05 21:02:10] Living room at Sannes' house | I said, 'Aren’t you going to eat anything tonight?'
[1984-12-05 21:02:15] Living room at Sannes' house | I saw him quickly raise his head and glance at me. I heard him say, 'You go ahead and eat.'
[1984-12-05 21:02:30] Living room at Sannes' house | I said, 'Okay, then I’ll be upstairs in my room afterwards.'
[1984-12-05 21:10:00] by Sannes' desk | He didn't answer, continuing to read his 'Secret Agent X9' in the light from a lamp beside the sofa. I cut myself a large piece of sausage and sat down at the desk to eat it. I remembered that he rarely ever bought me birthday presents; Mom must have bought something for me in Baysang. But surely he should have prepared a birthday cake? Had he even thought about that?
[1984-12-06 16:30:00] Sannes' kitchen | When I came home from school the next day, Mom was already home. Dad had picked her up from the airport, and when I walked into the house I saw them sitting at the kitchen table. At dinner I received a five-hundred-krone bill and a shirt Mom had bought me in Baysang. Meat roasting in the electric oven, candles lit on the table. She must have wandered through all the malls in Baysang trying to find something for me, finally settling on this shirt. Though she thought it looked nice and believed I’d like it, I knew I wouldn’t wear it—yet I couldn’t bring myself to say so.
[1984-12-06 18:00:00] Sannes' living room | I put on the shirt, and we ate cake and drank coffee in the living room. Then I went to training, and when I returned at nine o'clock that evening, they had already gone to the storage room. I heard Mom was in a good mood, saying more than once how wonderful it felt to be back home. Henrik Inge called to wish me a happy birthday, saying he probably wouldn’t return until Christmas Eve, but then I’d get my present.
[1984-12-06 21:30:00] Sannes' house | So I waited a while, then went to bed. I really wanted to talk with Mom alone, but it didn’t seem like there would be a chance.
[1984-12-07 08:00:00] school / town | During these last two weeks there were many exams. I handed in my tests early and went into town to browse record stores or visit cafés, sometimes with Båsen, sometimes with some girls from class. There’s an exam at school tomorrow. All of this was coincidence—it couldn’t be interpreted as me desperately trying to stay close to them. Being with Båsen was nice; we were starting to grow closer. One evening I stayed with him, just listening to records in his room, yet I was filled with joy. I had a new friend.
Båsen—or rather Lide, which was his real name—had chestnut hair, handsome features, and a strong appeal to girls. He wasn’t a country bumpkin, nor a heavy metal fan, but a music lover who liked Talk Talk, U2, the Waterboys, and Talking Heads. He never acted pretentious or self-important, because there was no showiness in his nature, no self-indulgence. He had never claimed the position he could have had.
But it wasn’t shyness either; rather, it was a kind of brooding introspection, a habit of stepping half a step back. He never fully let himself go or revealed his true self. Was it unwillingness, or inability? I didn’t know, though usually it was probably both.
I was proud to call Båsen my friend—not only because of his knowledge, or friendship itself (though that mattered too), but most importantly, because I imagined his good reputation might somehow benefit me. Not any concrete advantage, perhaps, but looking back now, it was clearly true: if someone is excluded, he must find someone who can bring him in—at least when he’s sixteen years old.
[1984-12-15 14:15:00] school | In this context, being excluded wasn’t an abstract metaphor, but a concrete, tangible act. There were hundreds of boys and girls my age around me, yet I couldn’t enter the circles they belonged to. Every Monday I dreaded the question everyone would ask: 'What did you do over the weekend?' You could say once, 'I stayed home watching TV,' or 'I listened to records with a friend in his room,' but naturally you wanted to give better answers, if you didn’t want to lose touch with others. Some people were shut out at first glance, and remained outside throughout high school. I absolutely refused to be like them. So much happened every day around us—I wanted to be one of them, to be invited to parties, to go into town together, to live their lives.
[1984-12-20 10:00:00] school | The biggest test—the year’s greatest celebration—was the New Year’s party. During these final weeks, that was all anyone talked about. Båsen was going to friends he knew from Jæren, and there was absolutely no way I could tag along. And so, until the end of term before Christmas, I hadn’t been invited anywhere.
[1984-12-27 15:00:00] Vallund's house | From Christmas to New Year's Eve, I sat together with Vallund, discussing what other possibilities we might have. He lives four kilometers below us at Sålesletta. This autumn he’s starting the pastry-making program at vocational high school. We wanted to go to parties and get completely drunk. As for getting drunk, that wasn’t really a problem. I played on the youth football team, and our goalkeeper, Tom, could handle buying alcohol for us—he wouldn’t object at all.
As for the party, though, it was a bit… The ninth-grade crowd was throwing gatherings in some nearby house—everyone knew those were wild, somewhat illicit events, absolutely unacceptable. Rather than that, I’d prefer staying home. There was also a group of people we knew well—some classmates, others from football—but that wasn’t an option either. The party was in Hamresanden, and we weren’t invited. Even if we could somehow sneak in, it still wouldn’t be ideal in our eyes. Then there were those living in Tvet, attending vocational school or already working—some of them had cars, seats covered in fur, and Oswick-scented air fresheners dangling from the front mirror, swaying as they drove. But we had no other choices. We had to be invited to a New Year’s party.
Besides, around midnight people would come out and gather in clearings or crossroads, setting off fireworks into the sky to celebrate the new year. That required no invitation—you could just join in. I knew many kids from school were having a party in the Sæm region. How could we possibly get there? Then Vallund remembered the drummer from our band—a boy in eighth grade who lived in Høynes. He’d mentioned going to a New Year’s party in Sæm. Clearly, this was our last resort.
[1984-12-31 14:00:00] Sannes' house | Later, two phone calls settled everything. That afternoon I returned home and, passing by my parents, said I’d been invited to a New Year’s party. I said, "It’s a gathering organized by some classmates in Sæm. Can I go there?" Tom would buy the beer for us. We’d sit with eighth and ninth graders in someone’s basement living room until midnight, then head outside to the crossroads where people gathered, find friends from our school, and spend the whole evening mingling with them. It was a solid plan.
[1984-12-31 14:05:00] Sannes' house | Neither Mom nor Dad objected to my going. I heard Mom say, "Oh, that’s nice!" Dad said, "Sure, but you must be back by one." I said, "But it’s New Year’s Eve—can’t it be two?" "Alright, two then, but not half past. Understood?" We were also having a family dinner at home—Grandma and Grandpa were coming, along with my dad’s brother Marivik and his family.

[1984-12-31 15:00:00] Raernesletta store / Sannes' house | On the afternoon before New Year’s, we biked to the Raernesletta store, where Tom was waiting for us. We handed him the money, then each carried back a bag with ten bottles of beer. Vallund hid them in the garden outside his house. I biked home. I stood for a while by the window in my room, watching snowflakes swirl past, the gray sky seeming to sink down among the dark trees in the woods. I put on a record, opened the book I was reading, and lay down on the bed. The wind was picking up outside. Mom and Dad were busy cleaning and preparing the house thoroughly so the evening family dinner would go smoothly.
[1984-12-31 15:30:00] Sannes' house room / hallway | A little later I heard Mom knocking. I went downstairs into the room, closed the door, and grabbed the phone receiver. I heard Mom say, "It’s Vallund on the phone." The phone was in the room downstairs near the coat closet. I said, "What’s up?"
[1984-12-31 15:31:00] Sannes' house hallway | I heard Vallund say, "Something huge happened—the damn Andersson·Helen Sterdal…"
Andersson·Helen Sterdal was his older brother. In his mid-twenties, he drove a souped-up Opel Ascona and worked at a solid wood composite flooring factory in Bøn. His life didn’t face southwest toward town like ours and most others’ did, but northeast toward Birkeland and Lillesand. I’d never interacted with people his age before. I knew of him, but didn’t really know who he was. He wore a small mustache and often sported aviator sunglasses. He didn’t look intimidating from top to bottom—his style was rather gentlemanly—but his behavior was the complete opposite.
[1984-12-31 15:32:00] Sannes' house hallway | I said, "What did he do?" I heard Vallund say, "He found the beer bag in the garden. Then the damn bastard started yelling at me. What a piece of crap. Total hypocrite—pretending to be decent but acting like a bully. He gave me a full lecture, saying I’m only sixteen, blabbing on and on. Then he demanded I tell him who bought the beer. Of course I refused. What the hell is it to him anyway? So he said if I didn’t give him the name, he’d tell my dad. A total fake, that bastard. So I had no choice but to tell him. You know what he’s going to do? You know what that asshole plans to do?"
[1984-12-31 15:33:00] Sannes' hallway | In the strong wind, I saw snow slanting down from the shed's roof like a light veil. Vaguely, I noticed a moving figure inside, and in the next second, his facial outline appeared before the window; he stared straight at me. I lowered my gaze and turned my head slightly aside. I said, "What are you doing?" Soft light spilled from the first-floor windows, almost mysteriously diffusing into the deepening dusk. It must be Dad, I thought, I was quite certain.
[1984-12-31 15:34:00] Sannes' hallway | I heard him say, "He forced me into the car, drove straight to Tom with those two beer bags." I said, "Really?" "Fuck him, he's just that kind of bastard. He was thrilled. I felt completely sold out. Absolutely brilliant—he won big time, goddamn it, in the blink of an eye. That man deserves to go to hell—I really wanted to curse him out."
[1984-12-31 15:35:00] Sannes' hallway | Then I glanced out the window again, but that face was gone. I said, "Well, what happened then?" I heard him say, "What do you think? He cursed Tom out too. Then told me to hand over the beer. I did. Tom paid me back. I was just like some little kid. Like he'd never done this himself when he was sixteen. Hey, he really enjoyed it, didn't he? He was happy cursing people out, happy driving me there, happy giving Tom a good scolding."
[1984-12-31 15:36:00] Sannes' hallway | "So, what now? We can't go empty-handed without beer. That won't work." I said. "Of course not. When I left, I winked at Tom. He understood. So after I got home, I called him to apologize. He hadn't done anything yet. So now he'll bring the beer over to you. He'll pick me up on the way, and I'll pay him." Vallund's voice came through the earpiece. "You're coming here?"
[1984-12-31 15:37:00] Sannes' hallway | At that moment I first noticed the cat lying on the chair beside the telephone table. I saw it staring at me, then start licking one of its paws. The cat quickly turned its head toward the direction of the sound, but in the next second it relaxed again. I leaned forward and stroked its chest and belly. "Yes, he's leaving in ten minutes. We'll probably arrive in about fifteen." Vallund said. "I need to think," I said. The sound of a vacuum cleaner came from the outer living room.
[1984-12-31 15:38:00] Sannes' hallway | "You can't drive directly up here. That won't work. But we can leave the bags somewhere by the roadside. Anyway, no one will find them here." I said. "Maybe at the bottom of the small hill?" "Down below the house?" "Yes." "Okay. Then tell Tom not to back up toward our place or go all the way down to the mailbox. A bit further up there's a turnaround spot. Can he go there?" "Alright. See you later."
[1984-12-31 15:40:00] Sannes' living room | I hung up the phone and walked into the living room to Mom. "I'm going over to Ciliavik's for a bit," I said, "just want to wish him a happy new year." I heard Mom say, "Go ahead, wish him a happy new year." As soon as she saw me, she turned off the vacuum cleaner.
[1984-12-31 15:41:00] Near Sannes' house / Ciliavik's house | Ciliavik was one year younger than me, living in a house a few hundred meters down the road. Over the years we'd lived here, he and I had spent a lot of time together. Whenever possible, we played football—after school, on Saturdays and Sundays, during holidays. Often we struggled to gather enough players for a proper match; if that failed, we'd play two-on-two for hours; if even that wasn't possible, it would just be me and Ciliavik. I'd shoot to him, he'd shoot to me, I'd pass, he'd pass. Or we'd play against each other—we called it 'two-man football.' Day after day passed like this until I started high school.
[1984-12-31 15:42:00] Ciliavik's house | We also swam together, sometimes under the waterfall where the pool was deep enough to dive from the cliffs, or downstream where the current was strong, then we'd float along with the water. On bad weather days when outdoor activities weren't suitable, we'd watch videos in the basement living room at his place, or hang out in the garage talking and joking around. I really liked going there. His family was warm, generous, and welcoming. Even though his father somewhat disliked me, I was still well-received in their home.
[1984-12-31 15:43:00] School / Town | Although among everyone Ciliavik and I spent the most time together, I never considered him a friend. I never mentioned him to friends from other circles—not only because he was one year younger, which wasn't something to boast about, but also because he was so unsophisticated. He had no interest in music and knew nothing about it; he showed no interest in girls or drinking. On weekends, he preferred staying at home with his family. He thought it perfectly fine to wear rubber boots to school, loved wearing hand-knitted sweaters and corduroy pants shorter than jeans, and T-shirts printed with the logo of Vesfjord Zoo. Before I moved there, he had never gone into town alone.
[1984-12-31 15:44:00] library/school | There were many books he had hardly read at all—mostly comic book series, the same ones I’d seen too—but for me it was more about that long list of MacLean, Bagley, Smith, Le Carré, and Follett novels I’d gulped down without much thought. Slowly, I began getting him to read some of them as well. Sometimes on Saturdays we went to the library together, or watched Stavanger football team’s home games on Sundays; twice a week we trained with our own team, and during the summer term we played a match each week. Besides that, we met daily riding the school bus to school. But we never sat together. We didn’t do that. The closer we got to school, the more connected to life there, the more distant Ciliavik and I became. As soon as we stepped onto campus, we had nothing to do with each other.

[1984-12-31 15:45:00] near Sannes' house | During the holiday between Christmas and New Year, I visited his house several times—we watched videos and skied on the hill behind our house. It was strange how little he cared about this. He was always so cheerful, open, full of humor, warm-hearted like his family. I never considered inviting him to my place on New Year's Eve—it wasn't even a possibility.
[1984-12-31 15:46:00] Rogaland/school | Vallund had no contact with Ciliavik, though they naturally knew each other—everyone here knew one another—but there had never been any private friendship between them, nor any reason for one. When I first moved here, Vallund was very close to Magnus Nord, a boy around his age who lived in Rogaland; back then, they were best friends, constantly going in and out of each other’s homes. Magnus Nord’s father was in the military, so they’d moved around a lot—I knew a bit about that. When Vallund started spending time with me, primarily because of our shared interest in music, Magnus tried hard to win him back, calling him repeatedly to invite him over. When the three of us were together at school, he made every effort to show that only the two of them were true friends.
[1984-12-31 15:47:00] airport café/Hammerfestanden | When that plan failed, he lowered his expectations and invited both of us to his house. We rode bikes around the airport area, hung out at the airport café, and called Rita, a girl from Hammerfestanden whom both Vallund and Magnus Nord liked. On the way up a gentle slope, Magnus Nord broke off half his chocolate bar and gave it to Vallund, not offering me any. But the gesture wasn’t appreciated—Vallund casually took half of his own piece and passed it to me. After that, Magnus gave up and turned to others, but throughout our entire time in lower secondary school, none of his friends ever came as close to him as Vallund had.
[1984-12-31 15:48:00] school | Everyone liked Magnus Nord, especially the girls, yet no one wanted to be with him. Rita spoke sharply and aggressively toward everyone, but she especially liked him. They often laughed together in a particular tone, though they never became anything more than friends. As for me, Rita was mercilessly harsh. I always approached her cautiously, never knowing when or how she might attack. I saw her as small and thin, with a narrow face, a small mouth, but perfectly shaped lips. Her eyes, always glinting with mockery, were almost sparkling. Rita was beautiful, but that beauty wasn’t obvious—her manner toward others always felt uncomfortable, so perhaps her beauty simply went unnoticed.
[1984-12-31 15:49:00] narrator's home (on phone) | I heard her say: 'Hi, Grete Lundnes, it’s Rita.' 'Rita?' I said. 'Yes, it’s me, Rita Lolita. You blockhead.' 'Oh,' I said. 'I’ve got a question for you,' she said. 'Oh?' 'Do you want to be with me?' 'What?' 'I said it once. Do you want to be with me? It’s a simple question. Just say yes or no.' 'I don’t know…' I said. 'Come on, just say it. If not, then say no.' 'I don’t think…' I said. 'Fine, no,' she said. 'See you at school tomorrow. Bye.' One evening she called me at home.
[1984-12-31 15:50:00] school | She put down the receiver. The next day at school, everything was as usual, and she seemed exactly the same as always. She never brought it up again, and neither did I. I never mentioned it to Vidal or Magnus Nord either. Maybe she just wanted to double her chances of attacking me, seizing any opportunity that arose. I didn’t want to appear superior to them.
[1984-12-31 15:55:00] Sannes' yard | After saying goodbye to Mom, she switched on the vacuum cleaner. I got dressed in the hallway and stepped outside, bending into the biting wind. I shouted, 'I’m going down to Ciliavik for a bit.' Dad had already opened one of the garage doors and was pulling out the snowblower. The gravel inside the garage was completely free of snow, while the same kind of gravel outdoors was covered in ice and snow. This imbalance between inside and outside stirred a familiar, faint discomfort deep within me. Once the yard gate closed behind me, I refused to think about it anymore—letting it vanish from my thoughts entirely—but whenever I saw it…
[1984-12-31 15:56:00] hillside outside Sannes' house | Dad sat on the snowblower and turned his head to nod at me. When I reached the mailbox, I heard the machine above starting up. I turned to check if he could see me. It didn’t seem likely, so I headed down the hill, taking the opposite path leading straight down the slope. I regretted suggesting we meet at the bottom of the hill—it was probably too close. My father usually had a sixth sense for anything unusual. Besides, he’d already been watching me for a while now. Better safe than sorry.
[1984-12-31 16:05:00] roadside at bottom of hill | At the very bottom of the hill, I stopped and looked across at the river while waiting. I heard a car turning somewhere a few hundred meters away. I glanced down the road, and when the car appeared around the bend, I raised my hand to wave. It pulled up beside me. Tom rolled down the window. Three cars drove past on the far side of the river, one after another. The beams from their headlights looked like yellow spots piercing the deep gray. The snow in the open fields reflected the color of the sky, and the light from the heavens seemed stitched together with the descending net of dusk. The water in the ice holes was pitch-black and glistened. The engine noise was dry and harsh—it must have been an old car. Tom’s, no doubt.
[1984-12-31 16:06:00] by the roadside below the hillside | I heard him say, "Hi, Grete Lundnes." "Hi," I said. He gave a little laugh. "Did you catch some hell?" I asked. "This goddamn mouth," Vallund sitting beside him chimed in. "It's nothing important," Tom said. "So you're going out tonight?" "Yes. What about you?" "Just a short round will do." "Anything else?" "No, all good."
[1984-12-31 16:08:00] by the roadside below the hillside | His kind eyes looked at me and he smiled. I walked to the back of the car, opened the hood, and from among the jumbled tools, toolbox, and a pile of perforated straps and hooks meant for repairing ceilings, I pulled out two red-and-white plastic bags. "Your stuff is in the back." "Is the trunk open?" "Of course it is."
[1984-12-31 16:09:00] by the roadside below the hillside | He exhaled sharply through his mouth, as if to say it was nothing. He nodded, Tom rolled up the window and casually raised his hand to his forehead in farewell, just as he usually did, then started the car and drove off up the slope. "I've got the stuff," I said, "Thanks, Tom. We won't forget this." "See you later," I said to Vallund.
[1984-12-31 16:10:00] in the bushes by the roadside | I stepped over the snowbank by the roadside and into the thicket, walking about twenty meters up along the snow-covered stream until I reached a fairly distinctive birch tree, where I left the bag with the alcohol. Now I heard the car had passed onto the main road and was driving away downhill.
[1984-12-31 16:15:00] outside the Sannes house | I stood at the edge of the woods for a few minutes, then walked up the slope. Dad was vigorously clearing snow from the driveway, widening the path. When I approached, I nodded to him; he glanced at me with an expressionless face. He wasn’t wearing a hat or gloves, walking behind the machine in an old lambskin jacket, a thick scarf loosely wrapped around his neck. The shoveled snow didn’t blow away in the wind but fell with a swish a few meters off to the side. So that this outing wouldn’t seem suspiciously brief.
[1984-12-31 16:30:00] Sannes' kitchen | After hanging my coat in the hallway, I went into the kitchen where Mom was sitting, smoking. The candle on the windowsill flickered in the dim light. The clock on the electric stove showed half past three.
[1984-12-31 16:31:00] Sannes' kitchen | "Everything’s fine, right?" I said. "Yes," she said, "It’ll definitely be a pleasant dinner. Won’t you eat something before heading out again?" "I’ll have a few slices of bread," I said. On the counter sat a large white bag containing lutefisk. In the sink nearby were piled dark, unwashed potatoes. In the corner, the coffee maker glowed, and the pot still held half a pot of coffee.
[1984-12-31 16:32:00] Sannes' kitchen/living room | I went into the living room and stood by the window, gazing out across the entire valley. "I think I'll wait a bit," I said. "I won't leave before seven. When are they arriving exactly?" "Dad’s going to pick up Grandma and Grandpa—I think he’ll leave soon. Marivik will arrive around seven." "Then I’ll make it in time to meet them," I said.
[1984-12-31 16:33:00] Sannes' living room | I walked over to the sofa table, picked up an orange, sat down on the couch, and began peeling it. The tiny lights on the Christmas tree twinkled, flames danced in the fireplace, and at the far end of the already-set table, light refracted dazzlingly off the crystal glasses.
locations: by the roadside below the hillside
in the bushes by the roadside

text:
[1984-12-31 16:35:00] Sannes' house | During the summer when Henrik Inge and I lived together, he was about to start his third year of high school, and he expressed a wish to finish school at the same place, staying with his friends there. Dad flew into a rage. But Henrik Inge didn’t give in—he didn’t move with us, and since Dad refused to give him a single krone, he applied for a student loan and rented a room not far from our hometown. I thought of Henrik Inge, wondering how he had experienced all this during Christmas back when he was in high school. At least now he has no issues. He’s at a cabin in Vetti, East Agder, with many of his friends. He returns here as late as possible—even on Christmas Eve—and leaves again as early as he can, departing on the third day of Christmas. He’s never actually lived here.
[1984-12-31 16:40:00] Sannes' house | During the weekends he came to us, Dad hardly spoke to him at all. Their relationship had frozen over. A year later, Henrik Inge went off for military service. I remember one weekend when he brought his girlfriend Alvhild home—it was the first time in his life he’d done such a thing. Naturally, Dad kept his distance; only Mom and I spent time with them. At the end of that weekend, as they walked down the hill toward the bus stop, Dad drove straight toward them.
[1984-12-31 16:41:00] the slope near Sannes' house | He stopped the car, rolled down the window, and smiled as he greeted Alvhild. There was something unusual in his eyes—something I had never seen before. His gaze was intense, filled with a kind of joy and excitement. He had never looked at any of us like that. Then he turned away, started the engine, and disappeared up the hill. We continued walking toward the station.
[1984-12-31 16:45:00] Sannes' house | That’s how things were during those weekends—every effort Mom made to make Henrik Inge feel welcome came to nothing. Was this our father? The warmth and care Mom showed Alvhild and Henrik Inge throughout that weekend suddenly felt diminished by Dad’s four-second stare. Perhaps this is also why Henrik Inge almost always came alone during those weekends—Dad stayed as much as possible in his cabin at the warehouse, appearing only at mealtimes, never asking him a single question, barely acknowledging him.
[1984-12-31 16:50:00] a room in Sannes' house | I stood up, holding the orange peel, walked into the kitchen where Mom was standing peeling potatoes, opened the cabinet beside her and tossed the peel into the trash, saw Dad walk past while running his hand through his hair and smoothing it back, stepped onto the stairs and went into my room, closed the door behind me, put on a record, and lay down on the bed. Outside, the sound of the snowblower abruptly stopped. It was Dad who set the tone in this house. Everyone remained silent, no one objected. That gesture was so uniquely his.
[1984-12-31 17:00:00] Sannes' house | We discussed for a while how we could get to Sæm. Vallund’s father and my mother were both willing to drive us there, as long as we told them our plans quickly. But then there were those two full bags of beer—so that option was out of the question. In the end, we came up with a solution: Vallund would go home saying my mother drove us, while I would say it was Vallund’s father. It was a bit risky, since our parents might meet later and expose the lie, but we decided to take the chance anyway. Once we’d agreed on that, the next issue was how to travel. On New Year’s Eve, the buses here stopped running, but we found a workaround—we could head to the Timenes crossroads, about ten kilometers from here. We’d hitchhike there—if we were lucky, catch one ride all the way; if not, transfer to a bus from there. To avoid questions or suspicion, it was best to wait until the guests arrived before making our move. That meant seven o’clock. The bus left at eight ten—that had to be the plan. Everything seemed fine, provided we had some luck.
[1984-12-31 19:15:00] the road near Sannes | I placed the bag I was carrying on the road, opened my jacket and pulled out my scarf, wrapped it around my face and tied it securely, then grabbed the bag again and continued forward. I began jogging downhill. The wind roared in my ears, whipping up swirling snowflakes that danced wildly in the air. The bags in my hands felt like lead weights. There are still four kilometers to Vallund’s place, so I need to pick up the pace.
[1984-12-31 19:20:00] roadside | I stopped, propped one foot on the edge of the roadside ditch, carefully placed the bag down on the bank below me, then continued walking. When a car passed me, I turned to look—a strange old man sat in the driver’s seat. On the other side of the road, around the bend, headlights appeared. The light cut through the trees. The tall trees standing there flashed into view, one after another.
[1984-12-31 19:25:00] roadside | I walked back about twenty meters, picked up the bag from the bank, and continued downward, rounded a bend, passed a house where an elderly person lived alone, crossed an open field, passed the abandoned little farm lying dark and silent in the night, and just before reaching the last house before the main road intersection, another car appeared on the road. There, I could see the faint glow of lights from the factory, blurred within the thick darkness of falling snow.
[1984-12-31 19:30:00] roadside | I took the same precaution as before, quickly placing the bag on the bank and continuing forward empty-handed. As soon as the car passed, I ran back, grabbed the bottle-filled bag, and quickened my pace even more; it was already half past seven. This one wasn’t Marivik either.
[1984-12-31 19:32:00] roadside | I hurried down the road, nearly reaching the main road, when three more cars approached. I once again set down the bag in my hands. Two cars followed each other across the bridge, while the third turned and drove past me. Let it be Marivik, I thought, because then he’d pass quickly, and I wouldn’t have to hide the beer bottles for every single car. But it wasn’t Marivik. Not him.
[1984-12-31 19:35:00] main road uphill | I picked up the bag and walked onto the main road, following the pavement past the bus stop, an old shop, the auto repair station, and those clusters of old-fashioned houses. Just as I was nearly reaching the top of this long, grueling hill, I saw headlights appear at the edge of the road. There was no ditch, so I placed the bag on the snowbank where it would be visible—there had to be several meters between it and me, at least. Everything was bathed in light, in the grip of a strong, biting wind, and the world seemed utterly empty.
[1984-12-31 19:36:00] main road uphill | As the car passed, I glanced into the window. This time it was Marivik sitting there. At the same moment, he turned his head and saw me; when he recognized me, he hit the brakes. The car slowed on the downhill stretch, finally stopping some twenty meters below, then immediately reversed back up. Snowmud sprayed from the rear tires, brake lights flashing red. The engine gave a low hum.
[1984-12-31 19:36:10] beside Marivik's car | The car stopped beside me, and he opened the door. I heard him say, "It's you out walking in this bloody weather!"
[1984-12-31 19:36:15] beside Marivik's car | "Oh, yes," I said. "So, where are you headed?" "To a party."
[1984-12-31 19:36:20] beside Marivik's car | I heard him say, "Come on, get in, I'll drive you there."
[1984-12-31 19:36:25] beside Marivik's car | "No, no need," I said, "It's not far now, I'm fine."
[1984-12-31 19:36:30] beside Marivik's car | I heard Marivik say, "No, that won't do—get in."
[1984-12-31 19:36:35] beside Marivik's car | I shook my head. "You're out late too," I said, "It's already past half past seven."
[1984-12-31 19:36:40] beside Marivik's car | I heard Marivik say, "Doesn't matter, no problem—get in, right now. It's New Year's Eve, you don't need to freeze out here, you know. We'll take you. End of discussion."
[1984-12-31 19:36:45] beside Marivik's car | "Well, okay," I said, "you're very kind." I couldn't keep refusing—he'd grow suspicious.
[1984-12-31 19:36:50] beside Marivik's car | I heard him chuckle. "You sit in the back," he said, "just guide me on the way."

[1984-12-31 19:37:00] inside Marivik's car | I opened the door and got into the back seat. It was warm and comfortable inside the car. Harald, their three-year-old son, sat silently in his child seat, following me with his eyes.
[1984-12-31 19:37:05] inside Marivik's car | I smiled at him. "Hi, Harald," I said.
[1984-12-31 19:37:10] inside Marivik's car | I saw Tove in the front passenger seat turn toward me. I heard her say, "Hi, Grete Lundnes, it's so good to see you."
[1984-12-31 19:37:15] inside Marivik's car | I said, "Hi, Merry Christmas."
[1984-12-31 19:37:20] inside Marivik's car | I nodded. I heard Marivik say, "So we're off then? I suppose we'll have to take another route?"
[1984-12-31 19:38:00] inside Marivik's car | We drove down to the bus stop below, turned around, and started driving back up the hill. I saw the bags lying there, and as we passed the spot where the beer bags had been, I leaned forward, searching for them. I couldn't help myself.
[1984-12-31 19:38:10] inside Marivik's car | I heard Marivik ask, "Where are you headed?"
[1984-12-31 19:38:15] inside Marivik's car | I said, "First down to a friend's place at Solsletta. Then we're going to Sem, there's a party there."
[1984-12-31 19:38:20] inside Marivik's car | I saw Tove look at him. I heard him say, "I can drive you all the way there, if you'd like."
[1984-12-31 19:38:25] inside Marivik's car | I said, "No, there's no need for that. Besides, we're supposed to meet the others on the bus."
[1984-12-31 19:38:30] inside Marivik's car | I knew Marivik was ten years younger than my father and worked as an accountant at a company in town. He was the only son who followed in his father’s footsteps; the other two became teachers—my dad at a high school in Vennesla, and Erling at a junior high in Thomas Linddalheim. Erling was the only one we called 'Uncle,' and he was more low-key, not drawn to status and recognition like the other brothers.
[1984-12-31 19:38:40] inside Marivik's car | We didn’t see much of my father’s two brothers while growing up, especially Erling. Marivik was different—he had long hair, played guitar, and most notably, owned a twenty-horsepower Mercury motorboat moored at a summer cabin outside Mandal, where he stayed for extended periods each summer during our childhood. But we liked them. They rarely said anything meaningless, and Henrik Inge and I were especially fond of him—perhaps because he was the relative closest to us in age.
[1984-12-31 19:38:50] inside Marivik's car | When he spoke about his companions there, it felt significant—not only because my father had no such friends, but also because we only knew them as people he met while out boating. Everything about them seemed almost mystical to me. We didn’t really know them at all, never having met them. I imagined scenes from their lives: endless boat trips weaving through skerries and islands by day, their long blond hair blowing in the sea wind, brown mustaches, smiling faces, playing cards and guitars in the evenings and at night, with girls always around.
[1984-12-31 19:39:00] inside Marivik's car | After he got married and had children, although he kept the boat, that wild, free spirit faded, along with his flowing long hair. His wife, Tove, came from a police officer’s family in Trøndelag and worked as a primary school teacher.
[1984-12-31 19:39:10] inside Marivik's car | I saw her turn her head toward me. I heard her say, "Did you have a nice Christmas?"
[1984-12-31 19:39:15] inside Marivik's car | I said, "Yes, it was good."
[1984-12-31 19:39:20] inside Marivik's car | I nodded. I heard Marivik say, "I heard Henrik Inge is home?"
[1984-12-31 19:39:25] inside Marivik's car | He loved Henrik Inge the most. I think this must have been because Henrik Inge was the eldest and had spent the longest time with grandmother and grandfather when Marivik still lived there. But it might also have been because, during our childhood, Henrik Inge wasn’t the sensitive type, unlike me who would cry at the slightest thing. Marivik was cheerful around Henrik Inge. That’s why, whenever I was with them, I tried to act tough against my nature, cracking jokes and saying funny things, trying to prove to them that I shared their temperament—that I had just as much humor and southern warmth as they did.
[1984-12-31 19:39:35] inside Marivik's car | I said, "He went back a few days ago—to go to a holiday cabin with some friends."
[1984-12-31 19:39:40] inside Marivik's car | I heard Marivik say, 'Yeah, he's become an Aucity person now, you know.'
[1984-12-31 19:40:00] inside Marivik's car | We passed the country church, made a wide circle around the canyon, and drove over the small bridge. I saw Harald’s eyelids drooping beside me. It was a place where the sun never reached. The windshield wipers tapped rhythmically against the glass. The fan hummed steadily.
[1984-12-31 19:40:10] inside Marivik's car | I heard Marivik ask, 'Who started the gathering? I suppose it’s someone from your class?'
[1984-12-31 19:40:15] inside Marivik's car | I said, 'Actually, it was a girl from our grade.'
[1984-12-31 19:40:20] inside Marivik's car | I heard him say, 'Yes, when one starts high school, everything changes.'
[1984-12-31 19:40:25] inside Marivik's car | I said, 'When you were studying at the church school, didn’t you change?'
[1984-12-31 19:40:30] inside Marivik's car | I saw him turn his head and meet my gaze directly, then shift his attention back to the road ahead. I heard him say, 'Yeah, same with me.'
[1984-12-31 19:42:00] clearing near Vallund's house | We drove into the clearing. The headlights cast beams of light onto trees and hillocks, the side walls of houses and the slopes, finally reaching the end surrounded by buildings.
[1984-12-31 19:42:10] clearing near Vallund's house | The car slowed down and stopped. I said, 'This is the end of the clearing—you can park the car beside that shop over there.' I heard Marivik say, 'Okay.'
[1984-12-31 19:42:20] clearing near Vallund's house | I said, 'Goodbye, happy new year!' I heard Marivik say, 'You too, happy new year.'
[1984-12-31 19:42:30] near Vallund's house | I closed the car door and started walking up toward the house where Vallund lived, while the car turned around and drove back along the road we had come. When the car disappeared from sight, I began to run. Now we don't have much time.
[1984-12-31 19:45:00] outside Vallund's house | I leapt down the steep slope onto their property, saw the light glowing from his room, and walked over to knock on his windowpane. A few seconds later I saw his face appear, squinting out into the darkness. I pointed toward the door. When he finally spotted me, he nodded, and I headed around the side of the house where the door was.
[1984-12-31 19:45:10] at Vallund's front door | I said, "Sorry, the beer is by Krag Bridge up there. Now we've got to hurry up and get it."
[1984-12-31 19:45:15] at Vallund's front door | I heard him say, "What the hell are the beers doing there? Why didn't you bring them with you?"
[1984-12-31 19:45:25] at Vallund's front door | I said, "I ran into my uncle on the way here. Just before his car stopped, I barely managed to toss the beer bag into the snowbank. Then he insisted—damn it—on giving me a ride. I couldn't refuse, or he'd get suspicious."
[1984-12-31 19:45:35] at Vallund's front door | I heard Vallund say, "Oh God, we're really fucking cursed."
[1984-12-31 19:45:40] at Vallund's front door | I said, "Yeah, damn it, but now we've got to start moving. We need to hurry."

[1984-12-31 19:50:00] on the way to Krag Bridge | A few minutes later we climbed up the hill and reached the road. I saw that Vallund had pulled his hat down over his forehead, wrapped his scarf tightly around his mouth, and raised the collar of his coat to cover his cheeks. The only part of his face visible was his eyes, and even those were barely seen—just a tiny point when our gazes met. The round John Lennon-style glasses he wore were fogged up.
[1984-12-31 19:50:10] on the way to Krag Bridge | I said, "We've just got to move fast."
[1984-12-31 19:50:15] on the way to Krag Bridge | I heard him say, "Then let's go."
[1984-12-31 19:55:00] on the way to Kråg Bridge | Taking slow steps, we began running along the path. Tears seeped from my nearly closed eyes. My weary legs couldn't instantly gather all their strength, and the biting wind hit us head-on as we crossed the open field. Swirling snowflakes danced and surrounded us. My feet started going numb, no longer obeying me—they stood stiff inside my boots, like pieces of wood.
[1984-12-31 19:56:00] on the way to Kråg Bridge | I saw a car drive past. But in an instant, the car disappeared around the bend at the edge of the clearing. The speed of people walking can never compare.
[1984-12-31 19:56:10] on the way to Kråg Bridge | I nodded. I heard Vallund shout, "Shall we walk for a bit?"
[1984-12-31 19:56:20] on the way to Kråg Bridge | I said, "Just hope the bags are still there!"
[1984-12-31 19:56:25] on the way to Kråg Bridge | I heard Vallund say, "What did you say?"
[1984-12-31 19:56:30] on the way to Kråg Bridge | I said, "The beer bags! Hope nobody's taken them yet!"
[1984-12-31 19:56:35] on the way to Kråg Bridge | I heard Vallund say, "Who the hell would be out here now anyway!"
[1984-12-31 20:00:00] on the way to Kråg Bridge | We laughed. Stepping beyond the edge of the clearing, we started running again. Finally, we reached the spot where I had left the two bags. Each of us grabbed one bag and began walking back. Up the hill, where a gravel road led down to the fertile land by the river, across the small bridge, past the gorge, the abandoned auto repair station, the country church, and the white-painted little houses from the 1950s lining the road.
[1984-12-31 20:15:00] near the country church | When we reached the church, we heard the sound of a car approaching from behind.
[1984-12-31 20:15:10] near the country church | I heard Vallund say, "Should we hitch a ride?"
[1984-12-31 20:15:15] near the small chapel | I said, "Why not?"
[1984-12-31 20:15:20] near the small chapel | I held the bag in my left hand and stuck out my right thumb toward the road, and we stood there smiling at passing cars. We kept moving forward slowly. The headlights of approaching cars showed no sign of slowing down or stopping.
[1984-12-31 20:20:00] on the road | I heard Vallund say after a while, "What if we don't manage to hitch a ride?"
[1984-12-31 20:20:05] on the road | I said, "We'll get a ride."
[1984-12-31 20:20:10] on the road | I heard him say, "Two cars have passed us in an hour."
[1984-12-31 20:20:15] on the road | I said, "Since you're asking, do you have a better suggestion?"
[1984-12-31 20:20:20] on the road | I heard him say, "I don't know, but there's a small group gathered at Rickard's."
[1984-12-31 20:20:25] on the road | I said, "You shut the hell up right now."
[1984-12-31 20:20:30] on the road | I heard him say, "Andersson and Olaf Olaf went with some friends to Rogulund—also an option."
[1984-12-31 20:20:35] on the road | I said, "We already agreed on going to Søm, didn't we? You can't suddenly suggest we go somewhere else for New Year's Eve! It's New Year's Eve!"
[1984-12-31 20:20:40] the road | I heard him say, "Yeah, we're standing here by the roadside. How happy we are?"
[1984-12-31 20:20:45] the road | Another car came from behind. It didn't stop. I said, "See that? Here comes another one!"
[1984-12-31 20:30:00] outside Vallund's house | When we stood outside Vallund's house again, it was already half past eight. When our eyes met, we kept walking forward. We left the residential area, passed the road leading down to the church below, turned a bend uphill, and walked past a small row of houses where a classmate of mine, Koller, lived. My feet were frozen. For a brief moment, I almost wanted to suggest forgetting about the beer, just follow him inside and spend New Year's Eve with his parents instead. Lutefisk and drinks, ice cream, cake, fireworks. That’s how we always spent New Year's Eve. I realized he had the same fleeting thought too.
[1984-12-31 20:35:00] the road (near Koller's house) | I said, "Do you think Koller went out tonight?"
