[1984-12-31 20:35:05] the road (near Koller's house) | I heard Vallund say, "I know—he’s at Rickard’s."
[1984-12-31 20:35:10] the road (near Koller's house) | I said, "That’s one more reason not to go there."
[1984-12-31 20:35:20] the road | There was nothing particularly wrong with Koller, but nothing quite right either. Koller had large protruding ears, thick lips, thin light-brown hair, and angry eyes. He was almost always furious, of course for reasons of his own. The summer I started school there, he lay in hospital with broken ribs and a fractured wrist. He’d been in town with his father to pick up building materials, including several wooden planks they’d placed on a trailer hitched to the back of the car, but hadn’t properly secured. When they reached Varo Bridge, his father told Koller to sit out on the trailer to keep the wood from shifting. Then the wind caught the planks, flipping him and the load off the trailer, tumbling them across the ground until he was nearly beaten to death. We laughed about that all autumn. Ever since, whenever Koller appeared, that incident was the first thing that came to mind.
[1984-12-31 20:35:30] the road | After he got his moped, he started hanging out with the others who had vehicles.
[1984-12-31 20:36:00] the road | On the other side of the bend lived Olaf Olaf, a girl Vallund had always liked. She had a good figure, yet her boyish sense of humor and manner somehow made her breasts and hips seem less noticeable. Once on the bus, I sat in front of her. She raised her arms wildly, flailing them around like crazy, shouting, "Oh, look at this hideous creature! Look at these long spindly arms! Can you see them?" But the girls she was yelling at just stared straight at me, completely silent. Then she turned and saw me too, blushing—I'd never seen her blush like that before—because in that moment it became unmistakably clear whose disgusting arms she had just pointed out. It didn't matter to me.
[1984-12-31 20:45:00] near the community hall | Below lay the community hall, then a short, steep slope leading down to the shop, beyond which stretched the long plain of Lein, extending all the way to the airport at its far end.
[1984-12-31 20:45:10] Community Hall Station | I nodded toward the bus stop beside the Community Hall across the street. I said, "I feel like having a cigarette. Can we stand here a while?"
[1984-12-31 20:45:15] Community Hall Station | I heard Vallund say, "Go ahead—you can do it, it's New Year's Eve after all."
[1984-12-31 20:45:20] Community Hall Station | I said, "Well, shall we have some beer too?"
[1984-12-31 20:45:25] Community Hall Station | I heard him say, "Here? What's there to celebrate anyway?"
[1984-12-31 20:45:30] Community Hall Station | I said, "Are you feeling a bit down?"
[1984-12-31 20:45:35] Community Hall Station | I heard him say, "What difference does it make whether I'm in a good mood or not?"
[1984-12-31 20:45:40] Community Hall Station | I took off my bag, pulled out a lighter and a pack of cigarettes, opened it, and used my hands to form a small windbreak as I lit a cigarette. I said, "Come on, just one sip—right now!"
[1984-12-31 20:45:50] Community Hall Station | I offered him the cigarette pack. He shook his head. I said, "Do you want one?"
[1984-12-31 20:46:00] Community Hall Station | I started coughing—the smoke felt stuck in the upper part of my throat, sending a burning wave piercing through my stomach. I said, "Ow, damn it."
[1984-12-31 20:46:10] Community Hall Station | I heard Vallund say, "Feeling good?"
[1984-12-31 20:46:15] Community Hall Station | I said, "I don't usually cough. The smoke just got stuck in my throat. I'm not coughing because I'm unaccustomed to smoking."
[1984-12-31 20:46:25] Community Hall Station | I heard Vallund say, "Really? All smokers get their smoke stuck in their throats and start coughing. That's nothing new. My mom smoked for thirty years—she always coughed when the smoke caught in her throat."
[1984-12-31 20:46:30] Community Hall Station | I said, "Ha, ha."
[1984-12-31 21:00:00] Community Hall Station | A car emerged from the darkness around the bend. Vallund stepped forward and raised his thumb. The car stopped! He walked toward it and opened the door. Then he turned back and waved at me. I tossed away my cigarette, swung my backpack onto my shoulder, grabbed the beer bag, and started moving. Susanna got out of the car. She leaned forward and pulled the lever to slide the seat forward. Then she saw me.
locations: on the way to Krag Bridge
on the way to Kråg Bridge

text:
[1984-12-31 21:00:10] By Torgeir's car | I heard her say, "Hi, Grete Lundnes."
[1984-12-31 21:00:15] By Torgeir's car | I said, "Hi, Susanna."
[1984-12-31 21:00:20] By Torgeir's car | Vallund was climbing into the dark car. I heard her ask, "Do you want to put the bag in the back?" The bottles in the bag clinked against each other.
[1984-12-31 21:00:25] By Torgeir's car | I said, "No, it's fine like this."
[1984-12-31 21:00:35] Inside Torgeir's car | I got into the car and shoved the bag between my legs. Susanna got in. Torgeir, sitting behind the wheel, turned his head to look at me. I heard him say, "You're hitchhiking on New Year's Eve?"
[1984-12-31 21:00:45] Inside Torgeir's car | I heard Vallund say, "Well... we've just had damn bad luck tonight."
[1984-12-31 21:01:00] inside Taiye's car | Taiye shifted gears, the wheels spun, and the engine roared as the car suddenly shot forward several meters. We rolled down the windows, and the car drove into an open field.
[1984-12-31 21:01:10] inside Taiye's car | I heard him say, "Where are you kids headed?"
[1984-12-31 21:01:15] inside Taiye's car | Kids. What a bloody idiot. How can he strut around thinking he looks great with that over-permed hair? Does he really think a mustache and curly locks make him look tough? Grow up. Lose twenty kilos. Shave. Get a haircut. Then maybe come back and show yourself. How can Susanna be with someone like this?
[1984-12-31 21:01:30] inside Taiye's car | I said, "We're going to Søm, there's a party there. How far are you driving?"
[1984-12-31 21:01:40] inside Taiye's car | I heard him say, "We are only going to Hamre, there is a gathering at Helge's place. But we can drop you off at the Timenes intersection if you like."
[1984-12-31 21:01:50] inside Taiye's car | I heard Vallund say, "That's great, thanks so much."
[1984-12-31 21:02:00] inside Taiye's car | I glanced at him. But he was staring out the window, and our eyes didn't meet. I heard him say, "So, who's going over to Helge's then?"
[1984-12-31 21:02:10] inside Taiye's car | I heard Taiye say, "The usual bunch—Ricard, Ekse, Moller, Yorg, Hebbe, Shedy. And Frode and Helen Ster, Jormos and Bjørn."
[1984-12-31 21:02:20] inside Taiye's car | I heard Vallund ask, "No girls?" Taiye replied, "Yes, yes, of course there are. You think we're all dorks or something?"
[1984-12-31 21:02:30] inside Taiye's car | I heard Vallund ask, "Who are they?" Taiye answered, "Kristin, Randi, Katarin, Hilde... Inge, Elin, Anne-Katrin, Rita, Vibeke... What, do you want to come along?"
[1984-12-31 21:02:40] in Tåje's car | I spoke before Vallund had time to say anything. I said, "We're on our way to another party."

Her face, which seconds earlier had been part of the surrounding joy, suddenly changed, her expression freezing.
[1985-01-01 00:10:00] Sem Crossroads | When she turned around, I got an erection. I finished off the rest of my beer. Only three bottles left in the plastic bag. I opened one, popped the cap with my teeth, and started pouring it down my throat. I lit a cigarette too. One hand held the smoke, the other gripped the bottle. Then I stood there lifting both to my mouth—first a puff, then a swig. Smoke, beer, smoke, beer. Ah, perfect timing. I need to save them, but I need something in my hands. This is my gear—this is how I stay ready.
[1985-01-01 00:20:00] Sem Crossroads | Ten minutes later, I tapped Vallund on the back. He nodded, and I began walking up the path toward Irene. She was standing with her back to me, talking to others. I had to tap her shoulder. I said I was going to someone I knew, would be back soon, told her to stay put. I said, "Hey, Irene!" At first she didn’t notice me—she didn’t turn around, maybe because my voice was drowned out by the surrounding noise. That’s bad—damn it, that’s just terrible. Touching someone’s shoulder isn’t a casual gesture; it’s deliberate. Now wait and see how they react.
[1985-01-01 00:21:00] Sem Crossroads | Anyway, she turned around. I heard her say, "Grete Lundnes, what are you doing here?" I said, "We’ve got a party nearby. So when I saw you up here, I wanted to wish you a Happy New Year. Happy New Year!" She said, "Happy New Year!" I said, "Having fun?" She said, "Absolutely! You?" I said, "Great." A brief silence.
[1985-01-01 00:22:00] Sem Crossroads | She gestured diagonally upward with her hand. She shook her head while humorously wrinkling her nose. I said, "You’re having a party, right?" She said, "Yeah." I said, "Nearby?" She said, "Yes, I live up there." I said, "That house over there?" Nodding in the same direction. She replied, "No, the one behind it. You can’t see it from this road." I said, "Hmm, could I join? Then we could talk a bit more? That’d be nice." She said, "I don’t think so—it’s not a class thing, you know."
[1985-01-01 00:23:00] Sem Crossroads | Then I turned and walked back. I said, "I know, just for a short while? Not longer. I’ve got a party not far from here myself." She said, "Then go there instead! We’ll see each other at school after New Year’s!" I said, "It’s good to see you—I’ve always liked you." She always shuts me down like that, leaving me clueless how to respond. Saying 'I’ve always liked you' felt awkward—it wasn’t true—but at least it shifted her attention away from my begging to join their party. Now she’d believe I only wanted in to get closer to her. That I wanted to get close because I was drunk. Who wouldn’t on New Year’s Eve? Bitch. Damn bitch.
[1985-01-01 00:30:00] Sem Crossroads | When I returned, Vallund looked up at me. Vallund exhaled sharply, looking dismissive. I stared blankly at him and yawned. I said, "No party—weren’t allowed in." He said, "Why not? You said you knew them." I said, "Only invited people. We weren’t included. Fuck it." He said, "Then we’ll just go back. It’s fine there anyway." Let him understand just how fine it really was. But we had no other choice. We wouldn’t call his father until before two. That’s why, on this windy New Year’s night from 1984 to 1985, we ended up once again mixed in with that group at Sem—those acne-faced high schoolers dressed in everyday clothes.
[1985-01-01 02:20:00] outside the Søm residential area | At two-twenty in the morning, Vallund's father parked his car outside this house. We had already been standing there waiting. I sat in the front seat, while Vallund sat in the back. I wasn't very drunk. Vallund—an hour earlier he'd been hopping around with a lampshade on his head—this was how we'd planned it. Fortunately, he'd already thrown up, then gulped down some water and rinsed his face under the tap, so he could manage to call his father and tell him where we were. He wasn't fully sober by any means—I stood beside him and heard how he shot out the first half of each word, because the second half always got swallowed—but at least he got the address across. On nights like this, parents probably don't expect us to stay completely sober anyway.

[1985-01-01 02:21:00] inside the car | As we got into the car, his father said. He rested his arm over the back of my seat, twisted halfway around, began reversing, then shifted gears and drove back along the same road he had come from. I heard him say, “Happy New Year, kids! Did you have fun?” I said, “Yeah, there were lots of people outside at midnight. It got pretty noisy. How was it at Tvet?” He said, “Peaceful and quiet. Who were you with, exactly?” I said, “Someone Larssen knows. You know—he plays drums in a band.” He said, “Ah yes, I know, I know.”
[1985-01-01 02:25:00] inside the car | The snow outside some gardens was scattered with leftover firework debris. A few couples walked along the road. Several taxis passed by. Otherwise, everywhere was quiet and still. I’ve always liked the scene of sitting in a car slowly emerging from darkness, with the instruments glowing, and the person beside me moving with steady, confident motions. Vallund’s father is a good man. He’s friendly and funny, and once he sees that look on Vallund’s face—the one that says enough is enough—he leaves us alone.
[1985-01-01 02:30:00] inside the car | He took us fishing, helped us out with all sorts of things—for instance, once when I biked down to their place and got a flat tire, he fixed it without saying a word; when I was ready to go home, the bike was already repaired and waiting for me. When they went on family trips, they invited me along. He asked my parents, and so did Vallund’s mother. In those days, he drove me home many times—if Mom or Dad was home, he’d always chat with them for a while, inviting them over to his place. They never came, but that wasn’t his fault. But I also know he has a temper, even though I’ve never seen him lose it. Vallund inherited all his emotions from his father—joy, sorrow, and even hatred.
[1985-01-01 02:35:00] inside the car | I turned in my seat to look at him. He sat there motionless, his gaze fixed on a point on the headrest of the front seat. I said, “So that means it’s 1985 now.” I heard Vallund’s father say, “Yes, that’s right. What about you back there?” The car was turning onto the E18 highway beside Vårholmen Bridge. Vallund didn’t say a word. He hadn’t spoken when his dad first stepped out of the car either.
[1985-01-01 02:36:00] inside the car | I saw him give me a small smile. I nodded back. I heard his father say, “Did you lose your ability to speak? Are your parents home tonight?” I said, “My grandparents and my uncle came over. Lutefisk and aquavit.” He said, “Glad you weren’t there, huh?” I said, “Yes.” Still no movement from the backseat.
[1985-01-01 02:45:00] inside the car / near the Sannes house | We drove onto the road toward Rogaland, past Hamresanden, reaching the top of Reinsjøtå. Passed by their house, turned onto a curve leading up to Kragbrua, crossed the bridge and climbed another slope on the other side. His father drove slowly during the last stretch. Passed the house where Susan and Elise lived—two sisters who moved here from Canada, nobody knew why—and William’s house at the bend, then downhill, and finally up the last stretch. There had been no snowplowing; the ground was covered with a soft layer of snow about five centimeters thick. Darkness, silence, warmth, comfort. I thought, I could sit like this forever.
[1985-01-01 02:46:00] near the Sannes house | Vallund blinked hard, suddenly opening his eyes wide. I slammed the car door shut, waved at them, and as I turned to walk up the sloping path toward my house, I heard the car reverse behind me. I heard him say, “I’ll leave you here, so you won’t wake them if they’re already asleep. OK?” I said, “OK, thanks for driving me home. See you later, Yev!” He said, “Alright, see you.” His father said, “Come sit up front.” He said, “No need.” “Yev”! Why did I call him that? Using a nickname means we’ve become real buddies. I don’t need to prove this bond, because we truly are friends—but I’ve never used that nickname before.
[1985-01-01 03:00:00] Sannes' living room | After hanging my coat in the hallway, I walked into the living room. I sat down on the sofa and started peeling an orange. The cat on the wicker chair over there lazily lifted its head. When our eyes met, it rose gracefully, padded across the floor, and jumped onto my lap. I tossed the orange peel—the thing it hates most—to the side. The house windows were dark. They were already asleep. Every trace of the New Year’s dinner had been cleaned away. The dishwasher in the kitchen emitted a low, monotonous hum. I’m glad about this—not because I have anything to hide, but because I don’t want anyone interrupting me. Though the fireplace had gone out, I could still feel its lingering warmth. Mom was right—it feels really good to be here.
[1985-01-01 03:05:00] Sannes' living room | I stroked it. It began to purr contentedly, curling itself into a ball on my lap. Its head slowly sank down, resting on one paw, closing its eyes with a satisfied expression, and fell asleep within seconds. I said, “You can lie here a while, you may. But not all night, understand? I’ll be going to bed soon.” I said, “You’re lucky.”
[1985-01-01 11:30:00] Sannes' kitchen | I woke up the next morning to the sound of the radio in the kitchen, and after a while I fell asleep again. When I woke up the second time, it was already half past eleven. I got dressed and came downstairs. Mom was sitting by the kitchen table reading something, and when I came in she looked up at me. I heard her say, "Hi, did you have fun last night?" I said, "Yeah, had a great time." She said, "When did you get home?" I said, "Around two thirty. Vallund's father drove us back." But I just wanted to lie there and rest. Besides, what's the point of getting up this early today?
[1985-01-01 11:40:00] Sannes' kitchen | I sat down and started spreading liver pâté on a slice of bread, tried several times and finally succeeded in spearing a pickle slice with my fork, placing it on top of the pâté, then picked up the teapot and shook it to see if it was empty. Mom stood up. She filled the pot with water and placed it on the electric stove burner. I heard Mom say, "Is there any left? I can make more." I said, "Just enough for a small cup, but maybe it's a bit cold." I said, "Sit down, I can manage myself." She said, "No, I'm right by the stove anyway." Immediately there was a hissing sputter of water hitting the hot plate.
[1985-01-01 11:45:00] Sannes' kitchen | I heard her say, "So, what did you all eat?" I said, "It was a cold buffet—I think her mom was going to a party, so she prepared that kind of food. You know, that kind... uh, shrimp and vegetable aspic, transparent...?" She said, "Cabaret?" I said, "Yeah, shrimp cabaret. And regular shrimp. Crab. Two lobsters—there wasn't enough to go around, but everyone got a taste. And, yeah, some ham and things like that." She said, "Sounds nice." I said, "Yeah, it was good. Then at midnight we went down to the crossroads below, where everyone gathered to set off some fireworks. Well, not us—we didn't set them off, other people did."
[1985-01-01 11:50:00] Sannes' kitchen | I hesitated, looking around the table for something to eat with my bread, and said, "Not yet, actually. Most of the time I stayed with people I already knew." I heard Mom ask, "Where's Dad?" I said, "Up in the loft. He's going to Grandma's today. Would you like to come along?" she asked. I said, "Nah, better not—too many people yesterday. Now I'd rather be alone. Maybe take a trip down to Ciliavik. That'll be enough. What are you doing?" She said, "Not quite sure. Maybe read a bit. Then start packing small things—I've got an early flight tomorrow morning." Dad is up in the loft. He's going to Grandma's today. Mom has an early flight tomorrow morning.
[1985-01-01 11:55:00] Sannes' kitchen | My eyes fell on the jam Grandma had made. I said, "Oh, when is Henrik Inge coming over?" She said, "I think in a few days. So it'll just be you and Dad here." I said, "Yeah."
locations: inside the car / near the Sannes house

text:
[1985-01-01 12:30:00] Outside Ciliavik's house | Half an hour later I was standing outside the house where Ciliavik lived, pressing the doorbell. I saw his father open the door. He looked like he was just about to go out, holding a dog leash in his hand. Their dog, a yellow old hunting dog, darted frantically between his legs. I heard him say, "Well, look who's here? Happy New Year!" I said, "Happy New Year."
[1985-01-01 12:32:00] Ciliavik's living room | I saw him whistle as he passed me and went out into the yard. I stamped my feet outside before stepping inside. As I passed through the kitchen I saw his mother turn her head, then I saw Ciliavik, his brother Tom, sister Marit, and his best friend Trygve sitting there. I heard his mother smile and say hi.
[1985-01-01 12:35:00] Ciliavik's living room | I saw Ciliavik walk over to the VCR and kneel down in front of it on one knee. I said, "What are you watching?" Ciliavik said, "The Guns of Navarone." I asked, "How long have you been watching?" He said, "Not long. Half an hour. We can rewind and start again, if you want." Trygve said, "Rewind? We don't feel like watching it all over again, do we?" Ciliavik said, "But Grete Lundnes hasn't seen it yet—it'll be over soon." Trygve said, "Soon? That'll take half an hour!" Tom said, "You can't decide everything yourself." Ciliavik said, "Can't I?"
[1985-01-01 12:40:00] Ciliavik's living room | I saw him press the stop button, then the rewind button. Marit stood up and walked toward the staircase leading upstairs. Ciliavik nodded. I heard Marit say, "Call me when you reach that part I wanted to see." I heard a series of clicking and tapping sounds from the VCR, along with small scraping noises, like sharp hydraulic whines, then everything settled, the tape began rewinding at increasing speed, suddenly paused near the end, and the final segment slowed down gradually. I felt it was somewhat like an airplane—you could imagine it slowing down after high-speed flight through the air, braking gently as it approached the ground and runway, gliding extremely calmly and carefully toward the airport terminal.
[1985-01-01 13:00:00] Ciliavik's living room | I looked at Trygve. I said, "You spent New Year's Eve at home with your parents, right?" He said, "Yeah. Were you out drinking last night?" I said, "Not really—I had a few drinks, but I would've much preferred staying home. We didn't have anywhere to go for a party, so we just wandered around in the blizzard, each carrying a beer bag, our feet heavy as lead, stumbling through the snow. Until finally we ended up at Sæm. Just wait. Soon it'll be your turn too—wandering uneasily through the night with a bag in hand." Ciliavik said, "Alright."
[1985-01-01 13:10:00] Ciliavik's living room | I heard Trygve say, 'This is so interesting.' I saw that the TV screen in front of us had already displayed the first few frames of the movie. Outside it was silent—this could only happen during those winter days. Although the weather was cloudy and the sky gray, the light in the landscape was entirely a shimmering white. I remember thinking at that moment that I wouldn't want to be anywhere else—I only wanted to sit there, in that newly built house, this bright spot in the woods, letting my mind go blank and happily being foolish.
[1985-01-02 09:00:00] Sannes' house / town | I saw Dad drive Mom to the airport. After he disappeared into his apartment in the barn, I went down to Vallund by car. We plugged into his amplifier and sat playing guitar for a while until we got bored, then trudged heavily to the store, where there was nothing much to do, before dragging our heavy feet back home, flipping idly between TV channels, listening to a few records, and talking about girls. When he came back, the buffer zone between us vanished, and our same life from the entire autumn returned.
[1985-01-02 17:00:00] Outside Sannes' house / inside car | At five o'clock I drove home again and met Dad at the door. I heard him ask if I wanted a ride into town. I said, 'That's fine.' On the way, I heard him suggest we could stop by Grandma and Grandpa’s place, since I was hungry—we could eat there.
[1985-01-02 17:30:00] Grandparents' front yard | When Dad parked the car outside the garage, I saw Grandma peek out from the window. A minute later she opened the front door. She looked at me. I heard her say, 'It's you two! Thanks for last time's dinner! So glad you came over!' She said, 'I heard you had a great time that day?' I said, 'Yes.' She said, 'Well then, give me a hug! Even though you're grown up now, you can still hug your grandmother!'
[1985-01-02 17:32:00] Grandparents' hallway / stairs | I leaned forward and felt her dry, wrinkled face press against my cheek. I heard Dad ask, 'Have you eaten yet?' Grandma said, 'Just finished, but no matter—I'll heat something up right away. Are you hungry?' Dad said, 'Are we hungry?' I saw him looking at me with a slight smile on his lips. I said, 'At least I am.' I thought she smelled nice—the scent of the perfume she always used. In my mind’s voice, I heard the r-less version of 'I am.'
[1985-01-02 17:35:00] Grandparents' hallway / stairs | We took off our coats in the hallway. I neatly placed my boots on the floor of the open closet and hung my jacket on one of the old coat hangers whose gold plating had cracked. I saw Grandma standing on the stairs watching us, in that usual state of impatience—her hand propped under her chin, head slightly tilted to one side, shifting her weight from one foot to the other. Yet all the while, she kept talking to Dad. I heard her ask whether the snow up there had been heavy this year, when Mom had left, and when she would come back next. I heard him say, 'Yes, that's right, exactly.'
[1985-01-02 17:36:00] Grandparents' stairs / kitchen | I heard her turn to me and say, 'And you, Grete Lundnes, when does school start again?' I said, 'In two days.' She asked, 'Everything going well there, isn't it?' I said, 'Yes, that's right.'
[1985-01-02 17:40:00] Grandparents' kitchen | As soon as we entered the kitchen, I saw him sitting by the kitchen table, legs spread wide, leaning far back, black braces over his white shirt, buttons fastened all the way up to below his neck. A strand of hair fell across his cheek, which he brushed upward with his hand. A burnt-out cigar dangled from his mouth. I heard Grandpa say, 'Here you are! How was the drive? Slippery roads?' Dad said, 'Not too bad—New Year's Eve was worse. Not to mention the traffic.'
[1985-01-02 17:45:00] Grandparents' kitchen | I saw Grandpa light the cigar with a lighter. Grandma turned on the electric stove, tapping her fingers on the kitchen counter as she always did, softly whistling a cheerful little tune. Dad sat at the kitchen table. I heard Grandma say, 'Sit down.' Dad said, 'No, then you won’t have a seat.' She said, 'I’ll stand. I’ve been sitting all day—you know that. Now sit down!' There were a few puffs, and smoke began to drift through the room. I felt that in some way Dad seemed too large—not physically; the chair was more than big enough for him. The issue was something within him, or perhaps the strength of his presence, making him seem better suited to sit at the dining table in the living room.
[1985-01-02 17:50:00] Grandparents' kitchen | After several seconds of silence, I said, 'It’s 1985 now.' Grandma said, 'Yes, yes, another year has come.' Grandpa said, 'So, where’s your brother? Did he go back to Baysang?' I said, 'No, he’s still in Aucity.'
[1985-01-02 17:55:00] Grandparents' kitchen | I heard Grandfather say, 'Yes, he's already an Aucity man, you know.' Grandmother said, 'Ah, he doesn't come to see us much anymore. How happy we were when he was little.' She looked at me and said, 'But you must come!' Grandfather said, 'What's he studying now? Not political science, is it, I think?' Dad glanced at me. I said, 'No, he's studying media now.'
[1985-01-02 18:00:00] Grandparents' kitchen | I saw Dad press out half a cigarette in the ashtray and turn toward Grandmother. Grandmother took two plates from the cupboard and placed them in front of us, then got cutlery from the drawer and set them beside the plates. She picked up Dad’s plate and filled it with potatoes, mashed peas, meat patties, and sauce. When she set the plate down in front of Dad, she picked up mine. I heard Grandfather laugh and say, 'You don’t even know what your own son is studying?' Dad said, 'I do. I know perfectly well. Mom, I think we can start eating now. It doesn’t need to be scalding hot, you know. It’s certainly warm enough by now, don’t you think?' Grandmother said, 'It’s definitely warm enough. This is all I made today.' Dad said, 'That’s fine. This is good.'
[1985-01-02 18:15:00] Grandparents' kitchen/living room | I saw that only minutes after Grandmother had placed the plates before us, everything was devoured. Dad leaned back, lit another cigarette, and Grandmother brought him a cup of coffee. I stood up and walked into the living room, gazing at the twinkling lights outside the town and the gray snow on the ground. The snow piled along the walls of the warehouses by the dock lay mostly under moonlight. The beams from the street lamps trembled on the dark, glossy water. I knew there were only two people who could eat as fast as I could: Henrik Inge and Dad.

[1985-01-02 18:20:00] Grandparents' living room | I felt how the whiteness erased so many details around mountain lakes or forest streams, making the contrast between landscape and water suddenly clear—the strange, unfathomable water lying there like a black hole in the world. For a moment, my heart was filled with the image of black water against snow.
[1985-01-02 18:25:00] Grandparents' living room | I turned around. Another living room was just two steps away from where I stood, separated by a sliding door that was now half-open. I climbed the two steps and went over. A piano stood against one wall, above it two early religious oil paintings. On the piano were photos from high school days of their three sons: Dad, Erling, Marivik. This was a beautiful room they only used on special occasions, and we were never allowed to stay in it alone. There was no particular reason—I was just restless. Every time I saw Dad without a beard, it felt strange. He smiled, his black student cap pushed to the back of his head, his eyes sparkling with joy.
[1985-01-02 18:30:00] Grandparents' living room | I quickly stepped back four paces into the everyday living room and answered. I heard Dad call from the kitchen, 'Grete Lundnes?' I said, 'Are we leaving?' He said, 'Yes.' In the center of the floor were two sofas with a table between them. In the far corner of the room was a white brick fireplace. Most prominent inside were two black leather sofas and an old corner cabinet with colorful floral patterns.
[1985-01-02 18:35:00] Grandparents' hallway | When I entered the kitchen, he had already stood up. Grandmother came downstairs with us as usual. Dad went out, opened the car door, closed it again, and when he returned, he held a package which he handed to her. I said, 'Well, goodbye then, see you next time.' Grandfather said, 'Alright, goodbye.' As we stood in the hallway below putting on our coats, Dad said, 'Oh, I have something for you. Happy birthday, Mother.' Grandmother said, 'No, you really shouldn’t have! Dear boy. What do I need gifts for?'
[1985-01-02 18:40:00] Grandparents' front door | I saw Grandmother standing there holding a tablecloth. I heard Dad say, 'Yes, you do—open it now!' Grandmother said, 'Ah, you’re too kind!' Dad said, 'I thought it would match the wallpaper upstairs, don’t you think?' Grandmother said, 'It’s so beautiful.' Dad said, 'Good. Well then, we’re off.' I didn’t know where to look. There was an intimacy revealed—something private I’d never seen before, never even known existed. His tone had reverted to how it used to be, yet he didn’t go any deeper.
[1985-01-02 18:45:00] Outside grandparents' house / in the car | We got into the car, Dad started the engine. As we backed up the small slope, I saw Grandmother waving to us from the steps. Just as always, the gate closed behind her as our car reversed, and by the time we drove on toward the main road, she was no longer there. The headlights shone on the garage door.
[1985-01-05 10:00:00] School | At the first class of the new semester, Siv had sent out invitations to everyone—for a class party next Saturday. Over the next few days, sometimes I’d recall that little scene in the hallway, and each time it felt the same: I had seen something I hadn’t seen before. But the thought passed quickly. My mind wasn’t occupied only with Dad and Grandmother—many other things had happened these past weeks. Still, this was good news: a class party was an event I had the right to attend, where no one could accuse me or pick a fight. There would be trust in others, allowing my behavior to closely resemble the real me from the classroom—and perhaps be accepted by this larger world.
[1985-01-09 16:00:00] supermarket | On Wednesday I walked into the supermarket, put twelve bottles of pilsner beer into my shopping basket, along with bread and tomatoes bought as cover. I stood in line, placed my items on the automatic conveyor belt, handed the money to the cashier who barely looked at me, then grabbed both grocery bags that clinked as I hurried home filled with excitement. In short, I could drink, dance, laugh, maybe even flirt and touch someone somewhere leaning against a wall. On the other hand, the low-key nature of class gatherings was precisely because of this—not being invited for who you are, but simply because you belong. That’s how it was with the 1B class reunion. But I wouldn’t let that spoil my mood. It wasn't just any party—it was the 1B class reunion. The problem was where to get alcohol, just like on New Year’s Eve. I briefly considered calling Tom again, but decided it was better to handle it myself. True, I was sixteen, but I looked older. If I just acted casual and confident, people usually didn’t think to refuse me.
[1985-01-11 17:00:00] the narrator's apartment in town | When I came home from school on Friday afternoon, Dad had already been by my place. There was a note left on the table. Grete Lundnes—the weekend seminar. Back Sunday evening. Fresh shrimp in the fridge, white bread in the bread basket. Enjoy yourself! Eat well, drink well! Dad. Under the note lay a 500-kroner bill.
[1985-01-11 19:00:00] the narrator's apartment in town / town | That evening I sat in front of the TV eating shrimp, then went out for a walk around town. First in my Walkman was Iggy Pop’s 'Lust for Life,' then a track from Roxy Music’s album. I saw the faces of all those drunken people gathered outside, the passing cars too, drivers getting out and back into their vehicles at the gas station, the shop assistant behind the counter with her tired smile and mechanical movements, and people walking dogs outside. Ah, this is simply fantastic! Shrimp are the most delicious food I know. At moments like this, a distance opens between the inner world and the external reality—and I love it; they seem to exist in a different dimension from me.
[1985-01-12 10:00:00] grandparents' house / town | The next morning I visited my grandmother and grandfather, ate freshly baked bread with them, then went into town, bought three records, a large bag of sweets and pastries, several music magazines, and a paperback copy of Jean Genet’s 'The Thief’s Journal.'
[1985-01-12 15:00:00] the narrator's apartment in town | I drank two beers while watching the football live broadcast, another one while showering and changing clothes, and one more before leaving, after finishing my last cigarette.
[1985-01-12 19:00:00] Lundingen | Båsen and I had agreed to meet at seven in Lundingen. When I approached him, staggering slightly with clinking bags in hand, he stood there smiling. He had a backpack full of beer on his back. The moment I saw it, I wanted to slap my forehead. Of course! That’s exactly how it should be.
[1985-01-12 19:15:00] Siv’s house | We walked up Kuholmsveien, passed my grandparents’ house, continued uphill into the residential area surrounding the stadium—where Siv lived. After a few minutes of wandering, we found the house number and rang the doorbell. Siv opened the door. I heard her let out a shriek when she opened the door.
[1985-01-13 10:00:00] the narrator's apartment in town | Before I fully regained consciousness, I knew something beautiful had happened. While lying in the abyss of unconsciousness, it felt as if a hand reached out to me, and then image after image floated before my eyes. I grasped that hand, slowly lifting myself upward, drawing closer and closer to myself until I opened my eyes. Where am I? Oh yes, the living room downstairs in the apartment. I was lying on the sofa, fully dressed.
[1985-01-13 10:05:00] the narrator's apartment in town | I sat up, holding my throbbing head. I got to my feet, walked into the kitchen, poured a glass of water, and drank it down in one go. My shirt smelled of perfume. A strong, foreign fragrance. I remembered touching and kissing Monica. We danced together, stepped aside, stopped under the stairs, and I kissed her. She kissed me back. No, not that! Not that! Something truly wonderful had happened, a light had been ignited—but it wasn’t Monica. It was something else. But what?
[1985-01-13 10:15:00] the narrator's apartment in town | I walked into the hallway, looked at myself in the mirror, and ran my hands through my hair, pushing it back. Alcohol always creates a physical deficit in the body. But you know what can restore it. Hamburgers, fries, sausages. Lots of cola. I need these things. I need them right now. I don’t look too bad—just some bloodshot eyes; I can show my face like this.
[1985-01-13 10:20:00] my place in town | I tied the laces on my boots and grabbed my coat, pulling it on. But what is this? A button? A button with a 'smiley face'? Ah, that's it! How wonderful! The last hour I spent chatting with Elsa Ingrid. That's exactly it! We talked for a long time. She led the conversation, full of enthusiasm. She didn't drink anything. But I did—I got tipsy, so I could follow her mood, floating in a light, cheerful atmosphere. Then we danced together.
[1985-01-13 10:25:00] my place in town | Ah, we danced to Frankie Goes to Hollywood’s 'The Power of Love.' Love—the power of love! But with Elsa Ingrid—yes, with Elsa Ingrid! I felt how close she was to me. Even when standing still, we were just as close, talking. Her laughter. Her green eyes. Her delicate little nose. Just before we left, on our way out, she stuck the smiley-face symbol onto my button. That was all. Nothing more than that—but that tiny moment was incredibly beautiful.
locations: Outside grandparents' house / in the car
the narrator's apartment in town / town

text:
[1985-01-13 11:00:00] street/restaurant | I buttoned up my coat and went out. I saw low clouds hanging over the city, and a biting wind sweeping through the streets toward the sea. Everything was gray and white—an icy, hostile day. But inside me, everything was bright and radiant. As I walked along the river toward the roadside restaurant, I kept replaying 'Love—the power of love!' over and over again. What had happened? Elsa Ingrid was still Elsa Ingrid—she hadn’t changed, still the same girl who’d been in class with me throughout autumn and winter. I’d liked her, but never thought of her differently from others. But now! Look at this!
[1985-01-13 12:00:00] restaurant | I bought a cheeseburger with bacon, fries, and a large Coke. It was like being struck by lightning. Waves of steady joy flowed into my nervous system. My heart trembled; my soul filled with light. Suddenly, I couldn’t wait until Monday—I couldn’t wait for school. Should I make a move? Should I ask her out? I didn’t hesitate. She told me she was with someone—a third-year student from Vågsbygd High. They’d been together a long time. But the way she looked at me—suddenly closing the distance—that couldn’t be meaningless, could it? It must mean something. She’s interested in me. She wants to get closer. It has to be true. On Monday—on Monday I’ll see her again. But how the hell am I supposed to pass the time until then? It’s almost a full day away!
[1985-01-14 08:00:00] school corridor | She smiled when she saw me. I smiled back. She lowered her eyes and fiddled with a button on her coat. I heard her say, 'You haven’t removed this sticker yet!' I said, 'No, every time I see it, I think of you.' She said, 'You were completely drunk.' Then she raised her eyes and looked at me. I said, 'I did drink a lot—honestly, I mostly don’t remember.' She asked, 'You don’t remember?' I said, 'Yes, yes, I do remember! For example, I remember Frankie Goes to Hollywood...'
[1985-01-14 08:05:00] outside classroom | I saw Tennesen, our young geography teacher with a mustache and a Mandal accent—he was our homeroom teacher—coming down the corridor. He opened the door we were standing outside of. Elsa Ingrid smiled at him. I heard him say, 'Hey kids, did you have a nice weekend?' Elsa Ingrid said, 'We had a class party.' He said, 'Oh, so I wasn’t invited then?' What a smile that was. He didn’t expect an explanation or anything—he wasn’t even looking at her, just walked straight through the classroom to the teacher’s desk at the far end, setting down a small stack of books he was carrying.
[1985-01-14 09:00:00] classroom | I couldn’t focus at all on what was happening in class. I only thought of Elsa Ingrid, even though she sat in the very same room as me. Or rather, I just kept thinking and thinking… My heart overflowed with boundless emotion, leaving no room for any other thoughts. This lasted throughout the winter and spring. I was in love—not one of those ordinary little crushes, but something huge, the kind of love that comes only three or four times in a lifetime. This was the first time—and because everything was so new, perhaps also the most intense.
[1985-01-19 18:28:00] Sannes’ house | So after that first joyful drunken night in Birre, I had only truly gotten drunk twice. This last time went wrong. Getting completely drunk requires careful planning. First, the alcohol must be absolutely secured. The location must be safe and reliable. Transportation there and back must be arranged in advance. And I had to avoid my parents when returning home.
[1985-01-19 18:30:00] Tvet (Olaf Olaf’s house) | Vallund’s sister Olaf Olaf had just become engaged to a soldier named Andersson whom she met in Rogaland. Vallund and Olaf Olaf’s father worked there too. She wanted to marry early, have children, and become a housewife—her dream of the future was unusual among girls our age. Though she was only a year older than us, she lived in a completely different world. One Saturday evening, she invited us both and some other friends to a small gathering. We had nothing else going on, so we happily agreed. A few days later, we went to a house somewhere, sat on the sofa drinking homemade wine and watching TV.
[1985-01-19 20:00:00] Olaf Olaf and Andersson's house | We ate lasagna. I drank—freely—and passed out completely after the fifth glass. Candles were lit on the table. The idea was to have a pleasant evening, and it might have been pleasant—if there hadn’t been alcohol. But there was alcohol—plenty of it, available for anyone to drink. I felt happy and carefree, just like the first time—but this time I got too drunk.
[1985-01-20 00:45:00] Olaf Olaf and Andersson's house (cellar) | The moment I woke up on the floor of the dark cellar... I swept my eyes around the room... I was wearing sweatpants and a sweatshirt for running—ones I had never seen before. A towel covered the blanket, and beside me lay a pile of my own clothes, soaked and soiled with vomit. Through bleary, drunken eyes, I saw the washing machine against the innermost wall, and next to it a basket filled with dirty laundry. Against another wall stood a freezer, with several raincoats and rain pants draped over its lid. There also lay a stack of crab traps, a fishing net, a fishing rod, and a shelf holding tools and various scraps. All these things surrounding me were completely new and unfamiliar. Now that I was sober, my mind was perfectly clear.
[1985-01-20 00:50:00] Olaf Olaf and Andersson's house | Lying on the floor, I got up, opened the door, and walked into the kitchen. I saw Andersson and Olaf Olaf sitting there, their hands interlaced together. My head was right up against the door crack, and outside I heard footsteps approaching. I felt they were radiating love and joy.
[1985-01-20 00:50:10] Olaf Olaf and Andersson's house | I said, "Hi."
[1985-01-20 00:50:15] Olaf Olaf and Andersson's house | I heard Andersson say, "Isn't that Garfield? How are you now?"
[1985-01-20 00:50:20] Olaf Olaf and Andersson's house | I said, "Alright—what exactly happened anyway?"
[1985-01-20 00:50:25] Olaf Olaf and Andersson's house | I shook my head. He laughed. I heard him say, "Don't remember? Not at all?"
[1985-01-20 00:50:35] Olaf Olaf and Andersson's house | Then I saw Vallund walk in from the living room. I heard him say, "Hi."
[1985-01-20 00:50:40] Olaf Olaf and Andersson's house | I saw him smile slightly. I said, "Hi." He said, "Hello, Garfield."
[1985-01-20 00:50:50] Olaf Olaf and Andersson's house | I said, "What the hell do I have to do with this Garfield?"
[1985-01-20 00:50:55] Olaf Olaf and Andersson's house | I heard them ask, "Don't remember?"
[1985-01-20 00:51:00] Olaf Olaf and Andersson's home | I said, "I don't remember. I don't remember anything. But I know I threw up."
[1985-01-20 00:51:10] Olaf Olaf and Andersson's home | I heard him say, "We were watching TV. A Garfield cartoon. You stood up, pounding your chest with both fists, shouting like crazy, 'I'm Garfield! I'm Garfield!' Then you vomited. All over the living room, on the carpet, everywhere—total mess—and then you just passed out, man... waaah... waaah! Just puked your guts out, completely impossible to talk to you."
[1985-01-20 00:51:20] Olaf Olaf and Andersson's home | I said, "Oh damn, I'm really sorry."
[1985-01-20 00:51:25] Olaf Olaf and Andersson's home | I heard Andersson say, "It's not a big deal, we can get the carpet cleaned. The real question is how you two are getting home." That immediately sent a wave of fear through me.
[1985-01-20 00:51:30] Olaf Olaf and Andersson's home | I said, "What time is it now?"
[1985-01-20 00:51:35] Olaf Olaf and Andersson's home | I heard the reply, "Almost one."
[1985-01-20 00:51:40] Olaf Olaf and Andersson's home | I said, "One o'clock already? Oh, okay then. I was supposed to be home at one. So we're only a few minutes late."
[1985-01-20 00:55:00] Andersson's car | Andersson hadn't been drinking, so we followed him down to his car, got in and sat down—Vallund in the front, me in the back.
[1985-01-20 01:00:00] Andersson's car | As the car started moving forward, I heard Vallund ask me, "You really don't remember anything at all?"
[1985-01-20 01:00:05] Andersson's car | I said, "No, damn it, I don't remember a thing."

[1985-01-20 01:00:10] In Andersson's car | I'm proud of this. The whole story—what I said, what I did, even the vomiting—makes me proud. It's close to the kind of person I want to be.
[1985-01-20 01:10:00] By the roadside at the Sannes' house | Andersson stopped the car by the mailbox, and I walked up the dark, shadowy uphill path, wearing someone else's clothes, carrying my own in a bag that swung back and forth in my hand. Now I was afraid.
[1985-01-20 01:12:00] Outside the Sannes' house | I hope they're asleep. Please, let them be asleep.
[1985-01-20 01:13:00] Inside the Sannes' house | I opened the door and slipped into the hallway. They seemed to be asleep after all. All the lights were off in the kitchen. But I heard their voices. They were sitting upstairs on the sofa in front of the TV, talking. This was the last thing they always did before going to bed each night. This has never happened before.
[1985-01-20 01:13:10] Inside the Sannes' house | This was something his parents had asked him to do before—his mom and dad had even laughed about it—but certainly not tonight. Are they waiting for me? Are they going to interrogate me? My father will probably make me breathe in his face.
[1985-01-20 01:13:20] Inside the Sannes' house | It would be impossible to sneak past them quietly—the stairs were right beside them. Better to just go for it.
[1985-01-20 01:13:30] Inside the Sannes' house | I said, "Hey? Are you up there?"
[1985-01-20 01:13:35] Inside the Sannes' house | I heard Mom say, "Oh, Grete Lundnes."
[1985-01-20 01:13:45] Upstairs at the Sannes' house | I slowly climbed the stairs, pausing when I came into their sight. I saw them sitting side by side on the sofa, Dad's arm resting on the back of the sofa.
[1985-01-20 01:13:50] Upstairs at the Sannes' house | I heard Mom say, "Did you have a nice time?"
[1985-01-20 01:13:55] second floor of the Sannes house | She didn't notice? I couldn't believe it.
[1985-01-20 01:14:00] second floor of the Sannes house | I walked a few steps. I said, "Not bad, we watched TV and ate lasagna."
[1985-01-20 01:14:05] second floor of the Sannes house | I heard Mom say, "Alright."
[1985-01-20 01:14:10] second floor of the Sannes house | I said, "I'm pretty tired. I think I'll go to bed right away."
[1985-01-20 01:14:15] second floor of the Sannes house | I heard her say, "Go ahead. We'll be going to sleep soon too."
[1985-01-20 01:14:20] second floor of the Sannes house | I stood on the floor four meters away from them. I was wearing someone else's running pants, someone else's sweater, and my clothes—soiled with my own vomit—were in a bag, reeking horribly. But they didn't actually notice at all.
[1985-01-20 01:14:30] second floor of the Sannes house | I said, "Well then, good night."
[1985-01-20 01:14:35] second floor of the Sannes house | I heard them say, "Good night."
[1985-01-20 01:15:00] my own room in the Sannes house | I hid the bag of dirty clothes in the closet. The next time I was alone at home, I would take them to the bathtub, rinse them out, hang them up in the closet to dry, and then toss them into the laundry basket like usual. I'd just made it through unscathed. But how had I pulled it off? I didn't understand—I only felt grateful and accepted the outcome.
[1985-01-20 01:15:10] my own room in the Sannes house | Not a single word came from their mouths.
[1985-01-20 01:15:20] Sannes' own room | Drinking is a great thing for me—it gives me drive. When I’m about to do something, I get this feeling… not limited at all, but one that transcends all boundaries, yes, an endless surge of energy. For whatever I intend to do, I’ll go deep, deeper still. My mind feels clear and sharp. Unstoppable. Once I’ve decided on something, nothing—not even three horses—can pull me back.
[1985-01-20 01:15:30] Sannes' own room | I’m glad about this. Although the last drunken episode was barely covered up, this time I’ve made several preparations. I’ll bring my toothbrush and toothpaste, bought eucalyptus lozenges, mints, and chewing gum. And I’ll take an extra shirt.
[1985-01-20 10:00:00] School | Elsa Ingrid has become the center of my entire existence. Every morning I wake up happy and go to school—that’s where she is. If she isn’t there, perhaps sick or away, everything instantly becomes dull and meaningless, and the rest of the day is just something to endure. For what? What am I waiting for, and how long? At least, it’s not about tight embraces or deep kisses—human relationships aren’t that simple. No, what I hope for and am ready to receive is merely a light touch of her hand on my shoulder, a radiant smile when she sees me or when I say something amusing, and a friendly hug when we meet outside school. Just those few seconds when I wrap my arms around her, feel her face close to mine, and catch the scent of her shampoo—a faint apple fragrance.
[1985-01-20 10:10:00] School/Residence | I know she’s moving closer to me, yet she maintains strict personal boundaries, knowing exactly what she can allow herself to do, never mentioning any possibility between us. Or maybe it’s I who am moving toward her—I’m not sure. Perhaps the explanation is simple: she’s spoiled by all the attention, praise, and flattery she receives and just wants to play. But in any case, when I return to my residence, I cling to hope, analyzing every word she said and every action she took during the day at school—this alone decides whether I plunge into the deepest despair or soar to the peak of joy. There is no third path.
[1985-01-25 10:00:00] School classroom | At school, I started passing her notes. Then she’d write replies, I’d read them and respond, tossing the note back. While she read, I carefully observed her every move. Gradually, notebooks replaced the scraps of paper, passing back and forth between us—not too frequently, as I didn’t want to annoy her; two or three times a day was enough. I wrote asking if she’d like to go see a movie or have coffee with me. Each time, she replied: 'You know I can't.' Simple comments, casual greetings, brief messages—these were usually things I had thought out the night before at home. If she closed the door I had opened for her, darkness fell before my eyes; if she kept walking forward, my heart trembled and raced as though I were a clock ticking wildly.
[1985-01-30 10:00:00] School | We would discuss things during breaks—some politics, mostly religious topics. She is a Christian, while I am a fervent anti-Christian. She passed my arguments on to a young leader in her parish, then brought back his response next time. The person she spent time with belonged to the same parish. Though I didn’t directly threaten their relationship, I served as a contrast to her life there. Still, having these brief, cautious encounters during breaks—though they didn’t happen every day—allowed me to carry this happiness discreetly beyond school grounds. We’re friends, classmates—can’t we occasionally grab a cup of coffee together? Can’t we sometimes walk to the bus stop side by side?
[1985-02-01 10:00:00] School | I live for these things—the fleeting glances, the faint smiles, the tiniest gestures. And oh, her laughter! When I make her laugh! That’s what I live for. But I need more—so much, so infinitely more. I want to see her all the time, be with her constantly, be invited to her home, meet her parents, go out with her friends, travel together, bring her to my place… You know I can't.
[1985-02-05 10:00:00] School | One morning I wrote to her, asking if she’d like to go with me. She read the note, then looked at me from afar, without smiling. Wrote something down. Passed the notebook back. I opened it and read her reply. It said 'Yes!' A cinema easily suggests romance, but there are other activities—like the invitation I made to Elsa Ingrid in early February. It was a youth political gathering in the city center, which I had seen announced at school. Yes! I thought. Yes! Yes! Yes!
locations: By the roadside at the Sannes' house
second floor of the Sannes house
my own room in the Sannes house

text:
[1985-02-05 18:00:00] Narrator's place in town | When she knocked on my door at six o’clock, I was sitting on the sofa waiting for her. I said, 'Hi! Would you like to come in? I’ll just change clothes.' She said, 'Sure.' She said, 'You live here!' Her cheeks were red from the cold. She wore a white hat pulled low over her eyes and a wide white scarf wrapped around her neck.
[1985-02-05 18:05:00] Narrator's place in town | I opened the door to the living room and nodded toward it with my chin. I said, 'Yeah. The living room’s there. Kitchen’s inside. Bedroom’s upstairs. Actually, it was my grandfather’s office. Right in there.' She asked, 'Isn’t it lonely living here alone?' I said, 'No, not at all. I like being by myself. Besides, I often go over to Tvet’s place.'
[1985-02-05 18:10:00] the bathroom of the narrator's apartment in town | I put on my coat, wrapped my scarf around my neck, and pulled on my boots. The toilet door closed behind me. I lifted the lid of the toilet bowl and pulled out my elephant trunk. Half a minute later I gave up, turned on the tap to let water run for a few seconds, then shut it off, opened the door, and walked out to meet her shy, downcast gaze. I said, "I'm just going to the toilet, then we'll leave right away." I heard her start softly singing outside. This place isn't soundproof. The smiley face was still there. Maybe she wanted to cover up the sounds coming from inside, or maybe she just felt like singing. At that very moment I realized I couldn't possibly pee with her out there. The hallway is small, completely unshielded. Even if I didn't manage to urinate, she'd still hear. Damn it. Shit. I strained with all my might. Not a single drop came out. She kept walking around, singing. What on earth would she think? At least something seemed to be happening in there.
[1985-02-05 18:15:00] the street | I said, "Now we can go." We didn't talk much along the way. A bit about school, people who went there—Båsen, Møller, Siv, Tone, Anne. For some reason she started talking about her father, what a great man he was. She told me he wasn't a Christian. She said I'd like her father. I said, "Yes, he sounds like a good guy. Concise." She asked, "What does concise mean?" I said, "It's hard to describe. Something like brief and to the point, maybe more focused on facts, understated. Is this it, right here?" The street was dark and windy, as this city usually is in winter. That surprised me. Was being Christian purely her own personal choice? Could it be? I wondered. She looked at me with those green eyes. Every time she did that, I felt electrified through my entire body. I could break every frame confining us, grab every passerby and throw them to the ground, leap high and stomp down hard until they were nearly dead—the green eyes filled me with such immense power. Or I could wrap my arm around her waist and waltz down the street, scattering flowers to everyone we met, singing at the top of my lungs.
[1985-02-05 18:30:00] AUF venue on Queen Street | We walked in. It should be somewhere on Queen Street. Yes, here—it, posters hanging on the door. The meeting room was upstairs, filled with chairs, a podium at the front, a projector beside it. A group of young people were gathered there, maybe ten, maybe twelve. Below the window stood a large thermos jug, next to it a small plate of little cakes and a stack of white plastic cups.
[1985-02-05 18:35:00] AUF venue on Queen Street | I poured myself a cup of coffee, took a few cakes, and returned to her side. We sat in the back row. Another five or six people arrived, and then the meeting began. I said, "Do you want coffee?" She shook her head and smiled slightly. "How about a cake then?" This was an event organized by AUF, promoting AUF's political views, then discussing general issues concerning youth politics.
[1985-02-05 19:00:00] AUF venue on Queen Street | If it weren't for Elsa Ingrid sitting beside me, one leg crossed over the other, so close that I burned, I would have stood up and left. In my imagination beforehand, this would be a crowded gathering, smoky air, witty and clever speeches, bursts of laughter shaking the room—exactly the kind of Mikkel-style event. Not this dull boy in boring sweaters and ugly trousers, gathering a small group of similar-looking boys and girls to discuss dull, lifeless matters. When your inner self is already blazing, who cares about politics? When you crave the burning of life, crave vibrant existence, who cares about politics? At least I don't.
[1985-02-05 19:30:00] AUF venue on Queen Street | During the break, I asked Elsa Ingrid if we could leave, and so we slipped away from the cold, dreary evening gathering. I said, "Can we get out of here?" She said, "Yeah." Announcements said there would be a short break after three speakers, followed by panel discussions and group talks. I noticed in the hall how she took off her coat and hung it over the back of her chair, revealing the sweater underneath—a thick woolen one, subtly outlining her curves, making me swallow repeatedly without realizing it. She was so close to me, the distance between us almost nonexistent.
[1985-02-05 20:00:00] the street | I said I'd rather know almost nothing. She said, "But you're an anarchist!" I replied, "Where did that idea come from? I hardly even know what anarchism really is. But you're a Christian—where did that come from? Your parents aren't Christians, nor is your sister. Only you. You're the one who believes it." She said, "Yes, you're right. But it seems you're too lost in thought. You should live more in life itself." I said, "I'm trying to do that." On the way home, I talked about my views on politics. She said I had opinions about everything and asked when I found time to study all this. She herself knew almost nothing about any of it, she said.
[1985-02-05 20:30:00] outside the narrator's apartment in town | We stopped outside my place. She shook her head. She smiled, rose onto her toes, and kissed my lips lightly. I pulled her close, holding her tightly against me; she hugged me back firmly, then let go. We exchanged a brief glance, and then she left. I said, "Where do you catch the bus?" She said, "Up there," nodding her head in that direction. I said, "Should I walk you there?" She said, "I'll go alone. I've got my Walkman." I said, "Okay." She said, "Thanks for tonight." I said, "There's nothing to thank for, really."
[1985-02-05 23:00:00] the narrator's apartment in town | I couldn't stay calm that evening, pacing around the apartment, walking back and forth through the rooms, up and down the stairs, in and out of the downstairs rooms. I felt as if I were larger than the world, as if I already contained everything within me, leaving no room for further expansion. Humanity was small, history was small, Earth was small, yes—even the universe, though said to be boundless, was small. I was greater than everything, incomparable. It felt incredible, yet it left me restless, above all with longing—for what was coming, for what I needed to do, what I didn't want to do, and what I'd already done.
[1985-02-05 23:30:00] the narrator's apartment in town | I forced myself into bed, forced myself to lie still, not moving a single muscle, no matter how long it took sleep to arrive. For some reason, suddenly one foot stumbled forward, triggering alertness deep inside me, plunging me entirely into a state of existential emptiness; I closed my eyes and started over again. How fiercely everything inside me is burning now? Strangest of all, only minutes passed before drowsiness crept up on me, like a hunter approaching an unaware prey—I didn't notice any bullet, because for some reason one foot suddenly stumbled forward; as if I were standing on a ship's deck while beside it a giant whale swiftly dove deep beneath the surface—I saw something, though its position couldn't be defined. At first it was a dream, I understood, yet it was dream-arms that yanked me in, and inside everything around me changed completely—this happened precisely when I stumbled. I became a dream, and the dream was me. Don't move, don't move, don't move…
locations: the bathroom of the narrator's apartment in town
outside the narrator's apartment in town

text:
[1985-02-06 09:00:00] football training field | The next day was Saturday, morning training for the youth team. I played with them, and many people couldn't understand it. On the day I joined the youth team's practice, the gravel path beside Søyeta was covered in snow, and I knew all I had to do was run. So I ran and ran. Every time I reached the end of the track, I came in first. Every single time, I gave it my all. When matches began, I did the same there—I ran and ran, desperately, endlessly, like a madman sprinting. After just three such training sessions, I knew it was working perfectly, and then I was informed that I’d been selected for the team. What I heard was, every time I received the ball it was terrible, every pass I made was a mistake—what the hell are you doing on this team? Why did they pick you? I wasn't good at football. In the youth team alone, there were at least six, maybe even seven or eight boys better than me. But only I and another one, Bjørn, were selected for the youth team that winter. Still, I understood. The youth team had a new coach who wanted to see all the boys, so each of us got a week to join their training—three chances to prove ourselves. I'd done a lot of running throughout the autumn, and my physical condition was excellent. I'd even been picked for the school's 1500-meter race, despite never having done track before. This was my only chance. I wasn't surprised by it. But for the others on the team, it was a different story. Ah, I know why—they picked me because I can run. Then I'll just keep running.
[1985-02-06 14:00:00] Sannes' house | After training, as usual, while we changed clothes, the others mocked my studded belt. I asked Tom to drive me to Sannes. He dropped me off at the post office, and I walked up toward the house. I pushed the door carefully. It was open. The sun hung low on the horizon, the sky clear and bright blue, surrounded by blinding white snow. Music poured from the living room. He had turned the volume way up—the whole house was filled with sound. I recognized it: Aga’s voice, singing 'Gracias a la vida' in Mochengdao. I hadn’t said I was coming home, and I didn’t know if Dad was even there.
[1985-02-06 14:05:00] Sannes' house living room | I took off my boots and coat. In the hallway outside the living room, I called out 'Hey!'—no answer. I stepped into the living room. He was sitting on the sofa with his eyes closed, his head swaying gently to the music. Tears streamed down his cheeks. I quietly backed away a few steps, and before the music paused, I quickly pulled on my clothes and rushed out the door. I said, 'Hey?' The music was too loud, I thought—he wouldn’t hear me calling. I didn’t want to appear suddenly in front of him.
[1985-02-06 15:00:00] Vallund's house | I ran to the bus stop carrying my backpack and everything. Luckily, the bus arrived within minutes. It only took four or five minutes to get to Sålesletta. I got off and went to Vallund’s place. He wasn’t home—he’d gone to Rogaland with his father—but they’d be back soon, his mother said, and asked if I’d like to wait for him in the living room upstairs? Yes, I would. I sat there with a newspaper spread out before me, a cup of coffee and a slice of bread on the table, until an hour later when Vallund and his father returned. I debated whether I should get off and go to Vallund’s or go straight into town. My answer came from deep inside—no, I didn’t want to be alone. I wanted to be with someone, to talk, to fill my mind completely with other things. With Vallund, whose parents always greeted me so kindly—I wanted to go to him.
[1985-02-06 19:00:00] Sannes' house | In the evening, I walked back up to the house again, but he wasn’t there. Several buckets stood in the bathroom, filled with slushy melted snow. But to Kjelltan, it was a matter of life and death, sharply divided. Even though back then I couldn’t articulate it clearly, I could sense the deep-rooted rift between them. That’s why my father’s voice carried irritation, and Kjelltan’s carried passion. Just as clearly—at least to me—my father’s words were grounded in the real world: what he said and thought belonged here, connected to us, to our student days, football matches, comic strips, fishing trips, snow shoveling, and Saturday porridge. He was talking precisely about concrete, material, physical, tangible reality! The irony of the situation was intense. He defended theories of unity and solidarity, yet he himself was the one excluded and isolated. He was the one who viewed the world through idealized and abstract lenses—the one whose soul was purer than everyone else’s, the one who bore burdens and carried loads, hammered and struck, welded and tightened screws, crawled and climbed across boat after boat, milked cows and fed them, shoveled manure into the pit and spread it on the fields in spring, harvested grass and made silage, repaired houses and cared for his mother, who needed more help each passing year. This became his life.

Below the sloping meadow stood a row of deciduous trees growing along the riverbank. Above, an old farmstead—an already dilapidated barn facing the road stood open. Its sound reached me first; I heard it before the vehicle appeared, as it shifted gears and slowly continued its climb upward. Then the trailer emerged. Above the treetops, against the overcast sky, two bats fluttered in flight. I felt joyful. I thought about the badger I often encountered on the last bus ride home. When I started climbing the hill, it usually darted down the stream toward the road. To be safe, I always kept a stone in my hand. Sometimes we met on the path, and then it would stop and stare at me before running back to its distinctive hiding spot.
