text:
[1985-07-25 22:48:00] hillside path | I saw a moving figure down on the ground below. I stepped over to the other side of the road, trying not to startle the passerby, but it spotted me and immediately stopped. I kept walking, stepped over the stone foundation, and stood quietly on the steep embankment below. When I returned to the road, I heard faint music. It was a badger. It hadn't noticed me yet, trotting across the asphalt. The badger hissed, continuing to stare at me. Suddenly it turned and lumbered away slowly, disappearing into the terrain above. The music had been there all along—I just hadn’t noticed it until now. Ah, that badger was so beautiful—the black-and-white striped snout so strikingly stylish! Its fur was gray, golden eyes gleaming with cunning. Clearly assessing the situation, because previously whenever I startled it, it would instantly turn and vanish without a trace. Now it did it again, disappearing into the landscape above, filling me with great delight.
[1985-07-25 22:50:00] outside Sannes' yard | I hurried down the final stretch of road, then climbed back up the slope. The house glowed brightly with electric lights. The music was coming from there—probably through the open door. On the upper level, several shifting silhouettes moved about the lawn, vague and indistinct in the dim, pale light of the summer night. Was that music coming from our house? I thought there was a party going on up there. Normally I’d approach the house from the west along the stream, but since there was a gathering, and strangers everywhere around front and back, I didn’t want to just step out of the woods directly into it, so I took a long detour along the road.
[1985-07-25 22:55:00] Sannes' yard / garden | When I reached the top, I paused briefly to compose myself. I saw a man in a white shirt walking toward the yard, unaware of me. I peered in through the window. The entire driveway was packed with cars, half of them parked on the lawn. More vehicles were lined up beside the barn and inside the yard. The garden behind the house buzzed with voices. In the kitchen, two women and a man stood by the table, each holding a drink, laughing as they sipped.
[1985-07-25 22:56:00] Sannes' garden long table | I took a deep breath and walked toward the front door. I set my backpack down beside the door and walked over to him. I heard him say, 'You're here, Grete Lundnes.' He placed his hand on my shoulder. 'We thought you'd come earlier. We're having a little party, as you see. But you can sit with us for a while, can't you? Sit here!' A long table stood in the garden leading into the woods. The white tablecloth spread over it gave off a faint glow in the shadowy darkness beneath the tree canopy. Six or seven people sat around the table, including Dad. When our eyes met, he stood up and waved to me. I’d never seen him like this before. He wore a loose white shirt with lace trim along the V-neck, blue jeans, and light brown leather shoes. His face, nearly sun-baked to dark brown, shone with a deep tan. His eyes sparkled.
[1985-07-25 22:58:00] Sannes' garden long table | I did as he said, sitting down at the table with my back to the house. I nodded to the other five people. He lit a cigarette, drew in some smoke, exhaled, wearing a look of deep contentment. I said, 'Hi, Winnie.' I heard Dad say, 'This is Grete Lundnes, my youngest son.' He said, 'And this is Bodil, Grete Lundnes, my cousin.' She smiled at me and said, 'We used to play together when we were kids, your father and I.' Dad said, 'Back in our youth.' Dad said, 'And here are Ragnvald, Ellen, Marthe, Erling, and Åge. These are my colleagues.' I said, 'Hi.' Of these people, Winnie was the only one I’d ever seen before. She was also wearing a white shirt or something like a knit sweater. I’d never heard him mention a cousin named Bodil before—perhaps my eyes showed a hint of question as I looked at her.
[1985-07-25 23:00:00] Sannes' garden long table | He put down his glass and said, 'Did you go to that training camp?' I nodded. 'In Baywick.' 'Which part of Baywick?' 'Nikben.' 'On Mossøya?' 'Yes, I think so. An island in the Lyngdalsfjord.' He laughed, looking around and said, 'That’s Axel Sandemose’s hometown!' Then he looked straight at me and asked, 'Do you know he created a law inspired by that very town you just visited?' I saw the table filled with glasses and bottles, trays and plates. Two large bowls overflowed with shrimp shells—clearly leftovers from their meal. The last person my father mentioned, Åge, was in his forties, wearing large glasses with thin, delicate frames. As he looked at me, he took a small sip of beer.
[1985-07-25 23:01:00] Sannes' garden long table | I said, 'Yes.' He said, 'And what was it?' I said, 'Jante Law.' He said, 'Exactly!' Dad asked, 'Did you have a good time there?' I said, 'Yes, great facilities. The town was nice too.' What on earth is this? Are we suddenly back in school class? I didn’t want to talk more, nor give him a chance to speak further. When I raised my eyes and met his gaze, I saw stubbornness mixed with shyness.
[1985-07-25 23:02:00] Nikkebin (memory) | Nikkebin: After spending the entire night and morning outside with a girl I'd just met, I walked back toward the school where I was staying. She was crazy about me. The other four from the team had left earlier, so it was only her and me. As I walked home, drunk more than usual, I stopped in front of a house in town. All the details have vanished. I don't remember how I left her, or how I got there. But standing there in front of that house, it was as if my senses suddenly returned. I took the cigarette glowing red from my mouth, opened the mailbox on the door, and tossed the cigarette inside so it fell onto the floor of the hallway. Then came another wave of dizziness—I had to somehow get myself back to the school dormitory, go inside, collapse into bed, and was woken up the next morning for breakfast, then trained for three hours. It wasn't until we were sitting together beneath a huge deciduous tree at the training ground that I suddenly remembered what I'd done. A chill ran through me. I stood up abruptly, kicked the ball away, and started running after it. What if it had caught fire? Could someone have died in the flames? What would I do then?
[1985-07-25 23:03:00] Sannes' garden long table | I had been happy throughout those training days, but now, on the first evening back home, as I sat beside the long dining table in the garden, fear crept over me again.
[1985-07-25 23:05:00] Sannes' garden long table | I heard one of them ask, 'Which team do you play for, Grete Lundnes?' I said, 'Tveit.' He said, 'Which division are you in?' I said, 'I'm in the youth team, but the senior team is in the fifth district.' He said, 'Not Stat Club, certainly not there.' I said, 'No, more like Vembjart Football Club.' Everyone laughed. From his accent, I realized he was from Vinne, so he enjoyed being precise. I lowered my eyes. I felt I was getting too much attention. But then, when my gaze briefly met my father's, he smiled at me. Truly, his eyes sparkled.
[1985-07-25 23:06:00] Sannes' garden long table | I nod. I heard him say, 'Don’t you want a beer, Grete Lundnes?' I said, 'Yes.' He said, 'Looks like the drinks here are finished, but there’s a case in the kitchen. You can go get a bottle.'

[1985-07-25 23:10:00] Sannes' hallway/kitchen | I stand up. As I walk toward the door, two more people come in—a man and a woman, their bodies entwined. They don’t move forward any further. I hear her say, 'Hey! You’re the son, right?' I say, 'Yes, hi.' She says, 'I work with your father.' I say, 'Nice to meet you.' She wears a white summer dress. Her bare arms and legs are brown. Her breasts are heavy, her belly and hips broad. Yet the eyes in her full face are gentle. The man, wearing a light blue shirt and white trousers, has a slight belly, but is otherwise well-built. Though he smiles, his drunken eyes wander restlessly, and I notice his facial expression is stiff. On that frozen face, only the lines in the skin are visible, like dried-up riverbeds.
[1985-07-25 23:12:00] Sannes' kitchen | When I reach the hallway, I see the bathroom door open. A short, stocky, bespectacled woman with black hair steps out. She glances at me, then lowers her eyes and walks past into the room. Carefully, I sniff the perfume drifting from her body, then follow behind him into the house. I enter the kitchen and see the three people I’d seen through the window sitting there. The man, around forty, whispers into the ear of the woman on his right. She laughs, but it’s a polite, perfunctory smile. The other woman sits with a handbag on her lap, rummaging through it. She looks up at me and places an unopened pack of cigarettes on the table. I say, 'Hi, I’m just here to grab a beer.' The scent of fresh flowers.
[1985-07-25 23:15:00] Sannes' kitchen | Two full cases of beer stand against the wall by the door. I take a bottle from the top case. The man stands up and slaps his thigh. He flicks his lower arm forward slowly—giving me time to prepare—but still, I stumble slightly forward. The lighter flies through the air, hits the doorframe with a clink, and drops to the floor. I say, 'Does anyone have a bottle opener?' He says, 'I’ve got a lighter.' I say, 'I don’t know how to open bottles with a lighter—maybe you could help me?' Had this scene not happened, I wouldn’t have known how to extricate myself—because then he would have opened the bottle for me in a paternal way, which I didn’t want. But now, since he offered first yet failed midway, the situation completely reversed itself.
[1985-07-25 23:16:00] Sannes' kitchen | I pick up the lighter from the floor and hand it to him along with the beer bottle. He holds the lighter, gives a soft 'pop,' and the cap flies off. He hands me the bottle. He says, 'There you go.' I notice he wears round glasses, half his head bald, while on the other side, the hair rises high at the edge of his scalp like the outermost wave at an endless beach—forever unable to climb higher, leaving him somehow discouraged, lacking confidence. At least, that’s the impression he leaves on me. His tense fingers are hairy. A silver watch chain circles his wrist.
[1985-07-25 23:20:00] Sannes' garden | I thank him, walk through the living room, see four or five people dancing, then step out into the garden. A small group gathers near the flagpole, each holding their drink, gazing out over the valley as they talk. The taste of the beer feels incredibly wonderful. In Baywick, I drank every night, all through the previous evening and night, so now I’d need a lot to actually get drunk. But I don’t want that either. If I get completely intoxicated, I’ll slip into their world, be fully absorbed and blended in, become no different from them—perhaps even start fantasizing about their women. That’s exactly what I most hope won’t happen.
[1985-07-25 23:25:00] Sannes' garden | I look outward. The river winds slowly around a narrow, grassy strip where a goal net stands upright, entering the channel bordered by two rows of tall trees. The dark trees face the leaden water shimmering with pale light. Across the river rise gently ascending hills, rolling and undulating until they reach the sea, also cloaked in darkness. A line of houses between the river and the hills spills out bright, clear lights. The stars near the horizon glow in a hazy hue; deep in the night sky, faint blue stars are barely visible.
[1985-07-25 23:30:00] deep in the Sannes family garden | The group near the flagpole were laughing about something. The man with a small belly came around the corner of the house, as if he were gliding along the ground. I took a sip of my drink and walked deeper into the far end of the garden, where it seemed no one else had yet discovered this path. There, I sat down close to a birch tree, crossing my legs. The music had grown distant, and so had the voices and laughter; their activities over there became more blurred. Their hazy silhouettes drifted like ghosts around the brightly lit house. They stood only a few meters away from me, yet their faces remained indistinct. My confirmation ceremony photo was taken there, in front of the flagpole, standing between Dad and Mom.
[1985-07-25 23:35:00] deep in the Sannes family garden | I thought of Elsa Ingrid. It was as if she truly occupied a specific place within me, somewhere in my heart, and that I was always with her. In truth, I could go there whenever I wanted, whenever I felt I absolutely had to. We sat outside the Svaberg campsite talking about the class gathering from the night before. Nothing happened—just being together. Svaberg, Elsa Ingrid, the bay with its low, shallow islets, the sea. We danced, played games, walked down the steps from the house, swam in the dark water. It was utterly exhilarating. That exhilaration never tired, it stayed alive inside me all day long, and it’s alive in me now. I am eternal. I stood up, aware that it was by the power of every single cell in my body. I wore a gray T-shirt, knee-length olive-green pants, and white Adidas basketball shoes—nothing more, but it was enough. I wouldn’t call myself strong, but I was slender, supple, agile, handsome like a god.
[1985-07-25 23:40:00] deep in the Sannes family garden | Could I call her? She should be home tonight. But it must be nearly midnight. Even if she wouldn’t mind being woken, disturbing the rest of her household would be hard to justify. What if the house caught fire? Could someone die in the flames? Ah, damn it, fucking damn it.
[1985-07-25 23:45:00] Sannes family garden/kitchen | I began walking across the lawn, trying to push all these thoughts aside, letting my gaze glide along the hedge fence, past the house and roof, all the way to a large cluster of lilac bushes at the far end of the grass. As I walked, I finished the last drops of beer in my bottle. I saw several flushed female faces, their legs bent as they sat on the steps, cigarettes dangling between their fingers. I recognized them as I passed the table, gave a small smile, went through the door into the living room, then the kitchen, which was now completely empty. I grabbed another beer, went upstairs to my own room, sat down in the chair by the window, tilted my head back, and closed my eyes. The heavy, purple blooms of the lilac bush filled the entire path downward with their rich fragrance.
[1985-07-25 23:50:00] a second-floor room in the Sannes house | Just like this. The speaker from the living room was right below me; the whole house was completely unshielded, and every single note came through clearly. What song are they playing? Anni-Frid Lyngstad. A summer hit from last year. What’s popular now, anyway?
[1985-07-25 23:55:00] a second-floor room in the Sannes house | In my memory, he always dressed simply, precisely, leaning toward conservative. His wardrobe consisted of shirts, suits, blazers—mostly patterned—with trousers made of polyester, corduroy, or cotton, and sweaters of wool or lambswool. Tonight, Dad’s clothes looked mismatched, almost absurd. A white shirt—or was it a blouse, or whatever the hell you’d call it? He belonged to the older generation of teachers, not the new kind who didn’t care about appearance, but neither was he from the old-fashioned era. The difference wasn’t really about that. It lay between softness and hardness, between trying to erase that distance and trying to maintain it. It was a matter of values. When he suddenly showed up wearing an embroidered artistic top or pleated shirt—the way I saw him this past spring—or casual leather shoes, looking just like everyone else enjoying themselves, the gap between the image he projected and who he actually was grew vast, and I knew him well enough to see that.
[1985-07-25 23:58:00] a second-floor room in the Sannes house | I myself stand on the side of the vulnerable. I oppose war and those in power, resist institutions of authority at every level and all forms of dominance. I don’t want to be crammed full at school, but I do wish my intelligence were better organized. Politically, I lean left; the unfair distribution of the world’s resources makes me want to curse aloud. I believe wealth in society should be shared equally, making capitalism and the ruling elite my sworn enemies. I mean, every person has equal value, and inner qualities matter far more than outward appearances. In other words, I favor depth over surface, praise beauty over evil, support the weak against the strong. So logically, shouldn’t I be happy that my father has moved toward the softer side? No—this is only the appearance of softness. Those round glasses, corduroy pants, snug shoes, knitted sweaters—I feel almost contempt for them, because alongside these political beliefs, I hold others too.
[1985-07-26 00:00:00] a second-floor room in the Sannes house | Ian McCulloch, lead singer of Echo & the Bunnymen, was a pioneer within this worldview. Coats, military jackets, basketball shoes, black sunglasses. Ideas tightly bound to music—in that world, quality and coolness are measured by an entirely different standard, one firmly tied to our present moment. It expresses the spirit of the age, not the part that chases the pop charts, not soft colors and hairspray charm, since those are tied to sales, to image-making and entertainment. No, it must express innovation rooted in tradition; deep feeling combined with nimble liveliness; sharp intelligence paired with simplicity and sincerity, free of pretense. Real music isn’t for everyone, isn’t the best-selling, yet it still captures an era—my era, my experiences and journey. Ah, a brand-new age. I stand on the side of the new age. This is far removed from my father’s embroidered shirt and Sami boots. On the other hand, it’s understandable—he belongs to a different generation. Imagining people from his time starting to dress like Ian McCulloch, listening to underground American bands like Husker Dü, obsessing over events on U.S. television, following debut albums by R.E.M. or Green on Red, or mixing cowboy fringes into their wardrobes—this feels almost like a nightmare. The point is, the embroidered shirt and Sami boots were never truly him. Yet he still quietly slips into this role, as if drifting into disorder and confusion, almost like a fragile woman, as if he’s completely lost himself. Even the hardness in his voice has disappeared.
[1985-07-26 00:05:00] a second-floor room in the Sannes house | I opened my eyes and turned around so I could see through the window to the table by the edge of the woods. I saw someone standing there urinating, gazing out toward the river. I saw Dad lift his head, his eyes staring straight toward the window. My heartbeat quickened, but I didn’t move—if he really saw me—I couldn’t be sure—but moving would have admitted I was spying. Instead, I waited a moment, until I was certain he saw me seeing him, if indeed he had seen me at all, and only then did I step back and sit down at my desk. Now there were only four people left. Dad, Winnie, the woman who called herself Bodil, and one other. Behind the lilac bushes, out of their line of sight, but I could see them clearly. Observing Dad was possible—he was always vigilant, sealed tight, nothing escaped his notice. He absorbed every detail, big or small.
[1985-07-26 00:10:00] a second-floor room in the Sannes house | I took a few sips of beer. Now a cigarette would feel incredibly good. He’s never seen me smoke—maybe if I did, it would become a topic between us. Then again, would he perhaps even encourage me to grab another beer?
locations: deep in the Sannes family garden
a second-floor room in the Sannes house

text:
[1985-07-26 00:15:00] Sannes' second-floor room | I set down the wine bottle, spun the record rack around a few times, and read the names written in my own childish handwriting along the spines of the record cases in capital letters: BOWIE—HUNKY DORY. LED ZEPPELIN—I. TALKING HEADS—77. THE CHAMELEONS—SCRIPT OF THE BRIDGE. THE THE—SOUL MINING. THE STRANGLERS—RATTUS NORVEGICUS. THE POLICE—OUTLANDOS D'AMOUR. TALKING HEADS—REMAIN IN LIGHT. BOWIE—SCARY MONSTERS (And super creeps). ENO BYRNE—MY LIFE IN THE BUSH OF GHOSTS. U2—OCTOBER. THE BEATLES—RUBBER SOUL. SIMPLE MINDS—NEW GOLD DREAM. The desk is the object I own with the longest memory; it's orange-red, the same color as my bed and the cabinet door from my old room. Now, except for the record shelf, the desk is completely empty. I had cleared everything out by the end of school, and aside from sleeping, this place serves almost no other function.
[1985-07-26 00:20:00] Sannes' second-floor room | I stood up, picked up the guitar near the small Roland Cube amplifier, strummed a few chords, then put it back in place and looked out toward the garden. This brother of my grandfather had long ago been excluded from the family. I myself first learned about him only a few years ago by chance, at a family wedding where he gave an impassioned speech. He was a lay preacher in the city’s Pentecostal church. A mechanic. He differed from his two other brothers in every way—even in name. Those three sons, persuaded and guided by their solemn and dignified mother, all decided to enter the academic world, beginning at university, and even changed their surname, replacing the rather ordinary Petersen with the more distinctive Grete Lundnes. He refused. They were still sitting there, in the dimness beneath the tree canopy, the two gas lamps now faint but still glowing, their faces slightly drained of color in the distant light. Dark, nearly copper-toned complexions. Bodil must be the daughter of my grandfather’s other brother—I’ve never seen her before. Could that be why he broke with the family?
[1985-07-26 00:25:00] Sannes' hallway | I walked out of the room and down the stairs. When I reached the hallway, I saw Dad standing in the room where the wardrobe was kept. The light wasn’t on, and he looked at me. He tilted his head slightly and smoothed his hair with his hand. I heard him say, “You’re here? Don’t you want to sit with us?” I said, “Yes, of course. Just walking around, looking.” He said, “A great party. You doing alright, Grete Lundnes?” I said, “Fine, nothing wrong. I’ll come out and sit down now.” He always had that gesture, but as for the jacket and trousers—they didn’t suit him at all, as if suddenly feminized. Conservative, traditional clothing, worn with meticulous care, had always been his style, just like that inherited gesture and his usual precision.
[1985-07-26 00:30:00] Sannes' garden | When I stepped outside. A gust of wind came through. The leaves at the edge of the woods stirred slightly, reluctantly, as if waking from a deep sleep. There was no other reason—he was simply drunk, I thought. Because this wasn’t how I knew him. My father never drank. The first time I’d ever seen him thoroughly intoxicated was two months earlier one evening when I visited him and Winnie at their apartment on Elve Street. They hosted me for fondue, something they’d never done before—a Friday night dinner at home like that had never happened. They’d already been drinking before I arrived. Though he was still friendly, there was a sense of threat—certainly not direct, because I didn’t feel afraid sitting there, but indirect, because I could no longer read him. It was as if all the knowledge I’d accumulated about him throughout childhood, the ability I’d developed to anticipate what would happen, had suddenly and completely failed. What was going on? Why couldn’t I read him anymore? What was this?
[1985-07-26 00:35:00] Sannes' garden long table | When I turned and continued walking toward the table, I met Winnie’s gaze. She smiled at me, and I returned the smile. When I reached them. I heard Winnie say, “You’re doing okay?” I said, “Yes, but I’m a bit tired—I think I’ll go to sleep soon.” She said, “Can you sleep with all this noise?” I said, “It’s not noisy at all!” Another gust of wind passed through, stronger this time. The leaves of the waist-high bushes in front of the barn steps rustled loudly. The lightest branches above the dining table swayed up and down.
[1985-07-26 00:40:00] Sannes' garden long table | I heard Bodil say, “Your father said many good things about you tonight—can you believe it?” I heard Bodil ask, “Isn’t that right, Winnie?” Winnie nodded. She said, “We read one of your essays here in the spring—you might not know? I hope you don’t mind that I read it? He’s really proud of you, you know?” Her long hair was completely gray, though she was barely over thirty. Dad had been her supervisor during her teaching practice at the teacher training college. She wore a loose green blouse similar in style to his. Around her neck hung a wooden bead necklace. She leaned forward across the table. I didn’t know what to say, so I smiled cautiously. Ah, I was utterly speechless. What the hell did my essay have to do with her? But clearly, it was meant as a compliment.
[1985-07-26 00:45:00] Sannes' garden long table | I heard Bodil say, “You look like your grandfather, Grete Lundnes. Same shape of the head. Same mouth.” I said, “Are you Dad’s cousin?” She said, “Yes, you should come visit us sometime. You know, we also live in Vesfjord!” I said I’d be happy to visit, asked about her job, and gradually started asking whether she had children or not. I don’t know. Before I came here, I didn’t even know she existed. I should have said that. But I didn’t.
[1985-07-26 00:50:00] Sannes' garden long table | While she was speaking, I saw Dad return. He sat down to listen, as if wanting to join the conversation, but then leaned back, placed one foot on the opposite knee, and lit a cigarette. I stood up, walked to the door, opened my backpack, took out cigarettes, put one in my mouth, and walked back. Halfway, I paused briefly to light it, so that when I sat down, I was already smoking. Dad said nothing. I heard him say, “Now that I’m back, you’re leaving?” I said, “No, I just went to get something.” I saw he wanted to say something—the hint of displeasure already visible at the corners of his mouth—but after that brief, dark glance, it all vanished completely, as if he had already told himself he was no longer that kind of person. At least, that’s what I thought.
[1985-07-26 00:55:00] Sannes' garden long table | They drank, looking into each other’s eyes. I shook my head. He raised a bottle of white wine across the table and filled their glasses. We clinked glasses again. I heard Dad say, “Well then, cheers, everyone.” Then he looked at Bodil and added, “To Helene.” Bodil said, “To Helene.” Dad said, “You haven’t toasted yet, Grete Lundnes.” He said, “Grab a glass over there—it’s clean. Right, Winnie?” She nodded. Who the hell is this Helene?
[1985-07-26 01:00:00] Sannes' garden long table | I looked at them and asked, “Who is Helene?” Bodil said, “Helene was my sister—she has passed away.” Dad said, “Helene was… yes, we were very close during my childhood. We spent all our time together until we were about ten. Then she got sick.” I took another sip. From behind the house emerged the two people I’d seen earlier—the sturdy woman in the white dress and the man with a small belly. Two others followed behind them; I recognized one of them, the man from the kitchen.
[1985-07-26 01:05:00] Sannes family garden long table | He put one hand on Dad's shoulder. I heard the man with a little belly say, 'So here you are sitting—we've been wondering about you. You're not taking good care of your guests, I must say that. We came up here first and foremost to see you.' Bodil whispered to me, 'That's my sister, Elisabeth, and her husband, Frank. They live down in Ryen, you know, by the riverbank. He's a real estate agent.' All these people Dad knows—have they always been living around us?
[1985-07-26 01:10:00] Sannes family garden long table | They sat down at the table and instantly came alive. When I arrived here, these faces were blank, meaningless and empty, so all I saw was their age and type, roughly like looking at animals—a herd of forty-year-olds, with dull eyes, stiff lips, sagging breasts, trembling bellies, wrinkles and flab. Now I see individuals, simple human beings, and I am one of their kin, blood flowing through their veins just as it does through mine. Who they are suddenly matters.
[1985-07-26 01:15:00] Sannes family garden long table | I heard Dad say, 'We were sitting here talking about Helene.' The man called Frank said, 'Helene, yes, I never met her. But I’ve heard a lot about her. It’s such a pity how things turned out.' Dad said, 'I was sitting by her bedside when she died. I valued her. Deeply valued her.' Bodil, still in that low voice, said to me, 'She was the most beautiful person you could ever imagine.' I stared at him. What’s happening now?
[1985-07-26 01:20:00] Sannes family garden long table | He sat there with his elbows on the table, hands folded across his chest, while tears streamed down his cheeks. Frank looked down, fiddling with his wine glass. Winnie placed her hand on Dad's arm. Bodil watched them. My father closed his eyes and covered his face with his hands. I heard Dad say, 'She just died like that, oh, ohhh.' Bodil said, 'You were closest to her. You were her dearest one.' My father said, 'Oh, oh.' He cried? Yes, he cried.
[1985-07-26 01:25:00] Sannes family garden long table | I raised my glass and drank. Another gust of wind swept over the yard. The hanging corners of the tablecloth fluttered upward. A napkin was blown away and landed on the lawn. The leafy trees above us rustled noisily. The sharp taste filled my mouth, sending shivers through me, immediately followed by that clear, pure sensation of nearing drunkenness—yet not quite reaching it—arousing a craving for the intoxicating euphoria that always follows close behind.

[1986-12-24 18:00:00] Yttersøndre Borg farm | Communism began to decline in the early eighties, and his passionate debates on various subjects gradually faded, until one day they disappeared completely. These facts may have changed the meaning of life, but not its content. Life continued as before, along the same course: rising at dawn to milk the cows, feeding the cattle, taking the bus to the shipyard, working all day, returning home to care for his parents—if his mother could walk, helping her take a few laps across the living room floor; otherwise, sitting down to massage her legs, assisting her to the toilet, perhaps preparing her clothes for the next day, doing all necessary outdoor chores, whether leading the cows or milking them, and then going back to his own house, eating dinner, sleeping until the next morning—unless Grandma fell seriously ill, forcing Grandpa to call him in the night. This was Kjertan’s life, as it appeared from the outside.
[1986-12-24 19:00:00] Yttersøndre Borg farm | His period as a Communist began when I was only two or three years old, and when it ended—at least the active, vibrant part of it—I had just finished primary school. So by the time I turned sixteen and started becoming interested in who people 'were,' that chapter of his life was merely a hazy backdrop within my impression of him. Far more significant was the fact that he wrote poetry. Not because I particularly liked poetry, but because the poems 'revealed' much more about him. You don’t write poetry unless you have to—that is, unless you are a poet. He didn’t talk to us about writing, but neither did he hide it. We knew, somehow. One year some of his poems were published in Tid og Sted, and another year Class Struggle published a few—poems about the everyday lives of industrial workers, small and simple impressions. Though they occupied little space, they earned him recognition among the book-loving Hartlev family. When one of his poems appeared on the back cover of the literary magazine Vinduet, accompanied by a small portrait of him, and then, years later, his poems filled two full pages in the same magazine, he had become, in our eyes, a poet in his prime.
[1986-12-24 20:00:00] Yttersøndre Borg farm | It was precisely at this time that he began reading philosophy. One night, sitting in the house high above the fjord, he opened Being and Time and began grappling with Heidegger’s extremely difficult German—perhaps word by word, since as far as I know, he hadn’t read or spoken German since leaving school—and also with the poets Heidegger mentioned, especially Hölderlin and the pre-Socratics, and Nietzsche, Nietzsche. He later described reading Heidegger as 'coming home.' Without exaggeration, he found immense fulfillment in it. It was a religious experience. An awakening. A conversion. The old world was infused with new meaning.
[1986-12-24 21:00:00] Yttersøndre Borg farm | By then my father had already left the family, so Henrik Inge, Mother, and I began spending Christmas Eve at my grandparents’ place. Kjertan, now thirty-five or thirty-six, still lived and worked there. Without a doubt, the four or five Christmas Eves we spent there were among the most memorable of my entire Christmas experience. Grandma was ill, sitting trembling at the table. Her hands shook, and so did her arms, head, and feet. She would occasionally convulse, at which point she had to be laid on a chair, her legs bent forcefully, then massaged. Yet her mind was clear, her eyes alert—she could see us, and was happy to do so. Grandpa was short and round, lively and humorous, always ready with a story, often laughing so hard at his own tales that tears streamed down his face. On the other hand, I'm not necessarily the most reliable judge when it comes to assessing anything. The stimulation of alcohol kept revealing more light, as if clearing up more and more questions in my mind. I began swallowing the wine almost as easily as juice, only to realize it was a bottomless pit.
[1998-07-19 23:34:55] Grandmother's kitchen | After I drank a glass of Sprite, I picked up the Absolut Vodka bottle and placed it on the windowsill, just blocking Grandmother’s line of sight. "What are you doing?!" Henrik Inge said. "You put the liquor bottle on the windowsill!" Grandmother said.
[1998-07-19 23:34:58] Grandmother's kitchen | I blushed, confused, grabbed the bottle, and put it back on the table. Grandmother began to laugh. Henrik Inge laughed too. "He put the hard liquor bottle on the windowsill!" "Obviously, the neighbors must have seen us sitting here drinking!" "Yes, yes," I said, "I didn't think about that at all." "No, one should say it that way!" Grandmother said, wiping away tears of laughter from her eyes. "Hehehe!"
[1998-07-19 23:34:59] Grandmother's kitchen | In this house, people had always been extremely careful to prevent others from looking inside, meticulously ensuring everything visible was blurred or concealed—clothing, gardens, exterior walls, cars, even children’s behavior. Placing a liquor bottle on the windowsill would expose everything happening indoors; anyone approaching could easily tell what we were up to. That’s why they, and later I as well, burst into laughter like that.
[1998-07-19 23:35:00] Grandmother's kitchen | I felt the light from the sky fall onto the small hill across the road, casting a dim glow through the dazzling kitchen lights onto the path, where our three submarine-like bluish-gray shadows stretched out. It was supposed to be a night exactly like this—one profoundly dark. I noticed Henrik Inge was beginning to slur his words—a sign invisible to someone who didn’t know him, but I caught it. When he got drunk, he always started this way: first mumbled speech, then increasingly nasal tones, until finally passing out completely and collapsing in an instant—something almost predictable. My own drunkenness was less obvious, mostly an internal shift. I usually remained articulate and precise in speech, which was problematic because people couldn’t tell how drunk I really was. Since I walked and spoke nearly as usual, there was never any excuse later for whatever reckless things I might have said or done. Instead, wildness and intensity grew stronger within me, unchecked by unconsciousness or social friction, continuing deeper into a state crystalline, empty, and primal. I loved it. I loved this feeling—it was the best I could feel. Yet it never brought me anything good. A day or days later, it would cling tightly to recklessness like stupidity, something I deeply despised inside myself. But when I was drunk, I couldn’t see the future or reflect on the past—I existed only in the present. That’s why I wanted to stay there, for my world to shine brilliantly amid the unbearable, torturous banality.
[1998-07-19 23:35:10] Grandmother's kitchen | I turned and glanced at the wall clock. Twenty-three thirty-five. Then I looked at Henrik Inge. I saw he looked tired. His eyes were smaller, with slight redness around the sockets. His glass was empty. Just don’t let him think about going to bed! I wouldn’t want to sit here alone with Grandmother.
[1998-07-19 23:35:20] Grandmother's kitchen | I said, "Another drink?" nodding toward the bottle on the table. He said, "Hmm, maybe just a little, but this is the last one. We have to get up early tomorrow." I said, "Oh? Why?" He said, "We’ve got an appointment at nine, don’t you remember?"
[1998-07-19 23:35:30] Grandmother's kitchen | I slapped my forehead—an old gesture I hadn’t done since high school. I said, "But that’s no problem, it’s just an appointment."
[1998-07-19 23:35:40] Grandmother's kitchen | I saw Grandmother watching us. I thought, please don’t ask where we’re going! The word 'funeral director' would surely break the spell and drive away this fragile joy. Then we’d be sitting here again—just a mother who lost her son and two children who lost their father.
[1998-07-19 23:36:00] Grandmother's kitchen | I picked up the bottle and poured Henrik Inge a drink, then refilled my own glass. As I poured, I met Grandmother’s gaze. I heard my own voice: "Would you like another?" She said, "Perhaps, just a small one. It’s getting late, you know." I said, "Yes, late on Earth." She said, "What did you say?" Henrik Inge said, "He said 'late on Earth.' It’s a famous line by Mochengdao, a renowned poet." I considered asking if she wanted more wine, but I didn’t dare. There was a limit here, tied to propriety—and we’d already crossed it long ago. Why did he say that? Was he trying to elevate me? Damn it, what a stupid thing to say. 'Late on Earth'...
[1998-07-19 23:37:00] Grandmother's kitchen | I nodded. Henrik Inge said, "Grete Lundnes is about to publish a book soon." Grandmother said, "Is that so?" "Yes, you said so yourself—I heard someone mention it. I think it was Marivik? You’re publishing a book."
[1998-07-19 23:37:10] Grandmother's kitchen | I saw her raise the wine glass to her lips and drink. I did the same. I wondered—was this merely imagination, or had darkness already filled her eyes again?
[1998-07-19 23:38:00] Grandmother's kitchen | I took another sip of wine. I said, 'So you didn't live here during the war then?' She pointed behind her and said, 'No, not right after the war ended. We moved here several years later. During the war we lived out there.'
[1998-07-19 23:40:00] Grandmother's kitchen | I said, 'But what exactly happened back then? I mean, during the war?' She said, 'Oh, it was almost like normal life, you know. A bit difficult to get food, but not much difference really. The Oswick people were ordinary folks, just like us. We even got to know some of them. After the war ended, we went down to visit them.' 'In Oswick?' 'Yes, yes. When they had to leave here in May 1945, they called and said we could come take all sorts of things they'd left behind if we wanted. They gave us their best wine. And a radio. And many other things.'
[1998-07-19 23:41:00] Grandmother's kitchen | I said, 'They left everything behind—where exactly?' Grandmother said, 'In a gravel pile up on the hillside. They called and told us precisely where to find it. That same night we went up there, and everything was there just as they described. They were friendly, yes, truly they were.' I'd never heard before about receiving gifts from the Oswick people before their surrender. But the Oswick people had actually been to their house.

[1998-07-19 23:41:10] Grandmother's kitchen | I imagined Grandmother and Grandfather climbing up to that hillside gravel pile one night in May 1945, searching around for Oswick people’s liquor?
[1998-07-19 23:45:00] Grandmother's kitchen | I saw Grandmother lean forward and peer out the window. She sighed and sat back in her chair, placing her hands on her knees, looking at us. She said, 'Who could that be at this hour? It's so good having you here, children.' A beam of car headlights swept across the garden, shining on the wall beneath the window for several seconds, until the car completed a full turn and slowly drove away down the narrow lane below.
[1998-07-19 23:46:00] Grandmother's kitchen | A long silence. I saw Grandmother take another sip of wine. She said suddenly, her eyes warm as she looked into Henrik Inge's, 'Do you remember when you used to stay here? When your father came to see you, he had a beard, and you ran up the stairs shouting, "That man isn't my dad!" Hahaha! "That's not Dad!"... You were such a funny little thing back then, you know?' Henrik Inge said, 'I remember it very clearly.'
[1998-07-19 23:47:00] Grandmother's kitchen | I saw her bend her head forward with laughter, wiping the corner of her eye with her index finger. She said, 'And then there was the time we listened to the "Nine Hours" program here, when they were talking to the owner of Leivik's oldest horse. Do you remember? You said, "Dad, you're as old as Leivik's oldest horse!"'
[1998-07-19 23:48:00] Grandmother's kitchen | She looked at me. I nodded. She said, 'And you—do you remember that time you stayed with us alone at the holiday cabin? One morning we found you sitting on the stairs crying. When we asked why, you said, "I'm so lonely." You were only eight, you know!'
[1998-07-19 23:49:00] Grandmother's kitchen | I remembered that summer when Mom and Dad went on vacation to Oswick. Henrik Inge was staying with his grandparents in Sørbygda, and I was here, in Vesfjord. What do I actually remember? A great distance from Grandfather and Grandmother, a rather distant relationship. Suddenly I became part of their daily lives. They seemed even stranger than before, because there was nothing or no one between us to carry communication. One morning I found a tiny insect in my milk and refused to drink it. Grandmother said I shouldn't be so picky—just fish it out. That's how it is in nature. Her voice sounded a bit sharp. I drank the milk anyway, feeling sick all day. Why did this particular memory surface now? Nothing else? There must have been more, surely?
[1998-07-19 23:50:00] Grandmother's kitchen | Oh, by the way, Mom and Dad sent me a postcard of Bayern Munich. When they finally came home, the gifts they brought were: a gold-and-red football for Henrik Inge, and a green-and-red one for me. How deeply I longed for such a postcard—and how overjoyed I was to finally have it in my hands! Those colors… ah, my heart feels as joyful as if newly born…
[1998-07-19 23:51:00] Grandmother's kitchen | I saw her looking at Henrik Inge. She smiled. Grandmother said, "Once you stood on these stairs and shouted up to me, 'Are you above or below?' I answered, 'Below,' and you yelled back, 'Why aren't you above?'"
[1998-07-19 23:52:00] Grandmother's kitchen | She said, "Yes, there were so many funny things… After you moved to Tybakken, you went straight to knock on your neighbor’s door asking if any children lived there. You asked, 'Do little kids live here?' Hahaha!"
[1998-07-19 23:55:00] Grandmother's kitchen | After the laughter had completely faded, I saw her sitting there quietly chuckling to herself for a while, then beginning to roll another cigarette in her rolling machine. The outer end of the rolled cigarette was empty. When she lit it with a lighter, the flame suddenly flared upward. A small flake of ash drifted down onto the floor. Once the tobacco caught fire, tiny dark red sparks appeared, glowing brighter each time she drew on the filter.
[1998-07-19 23:56:00] Grandmother's kitchen | She said, "But now you've both grown up—it's so strange. It feels like yesterday you were just little children here…"
[1998-07-20 15:00:00] Vesfjord Chapel | He lay on a table in the center of the room. The sky was overcast, casting gray light into the chapel. Outside the window, a lawn mower slowly circled across the grass. His eyes and mouth were closed. He wore a white shirt on top and black trousers below. I myself first saw a dead body when I was nearly thirty years old. It was a summer afternoon in July 1998, inside a small chapel in Vesfjord. My father had died. My brother and I were there together. The funeral attendant stepped out first, leaving us alone with the deceased. We stood several meters away from the body, staring at it. I thought this was the first time I could examine this face without difficulty—yet it felt almost unbearable. It felt like I was violating him. At the same time, I felt an intense hunger, a greedy need—I kept having to look again and again at this corpse, which only days ago had been my father. I knew this face well; I had grown up with it. Though in recent years I hadn’t seen it as often as before, hardly a night had passed without dreaming of it. I knew this face—but not like this. The dark, yellowish skin and the stiff expression made it look like a piece of wood carved from a tree. This tree-like face evoked no desire to come near. What I saw was no longer a person, but an object resembling one. And yet he came from among us—he had once been one of us—and now he still lingered within me, like a veil of life draped over death.
[1998-07-20 15:05:00] Vesfjord Chapel | I saw Henrik Inge slowly move toward the other end of the table. I didn’t look directly at him; I only noticed his movement when I raised my gaze outward. The gardener operating the lawn mower kept turning his head to check that the wheels followed the edge of the previously mowed strip. Grass clippings not collected into the bag swirled through the air above him. Some must have stuck beneath the machine, because damp clumps of grass were being squeezed out at regular intervals, appearing much darker green than the surrounding lawn. Further along the gravel path behind him came three people walking with their heads bowed, one wearing a red coat that stood out vividly against the green grass and gray sky. On the road beyond, cars glided steadily forward, heading toward the city center.
[1998-07-20 15:06:00] Vesfjord Chapel | I immediately took a step backward. Suddenly, outside the chapel wall, the roar of the lawn mower engine burst forth. I imagined whether this sudden loud noise might make Dad open his eyes—the image was so vivid and real that I immediately stepped backward.
[1998-07-20 15:06:10] Vesfjord Chapel | I saw Henrik Inge glance at me, a faint smile playing on his lips. Do I think the dead can come back to life? That this tree might turn back into a man?
[1998-07-20 15:07:00] Vesfjord Chapel | In the next moment, another sob welled up and escaped me. It was truly a shocking moment. But when my emotions settled, I realized clearly that he was truly gone—no matter how loud the sounds around me, no matter how wildly my mind conjured images, he remained motionless. Then a sudden surge of freedom rose in my chest, as uncontrollable as the waves of grief I’d felt earlier. And just as involuntarily, in the next moment, another sob welled up and escaped me.
[1998-07-20 15:08:00] Vesfjord Chapel | I met Henrik Inge's gaze and smiled. I saw him walk over and stand quietly beside me. The sensation of his closeness and nearness flooded through my entire body at once. How happy I was that he stood there—so happy that I had to struggle hard not to lose control again and ruin everything in this moment. That meant thinking about something else, forcing my mind to focus on things entirely unrelated to this.
[1998-07-20 15:09:00] Vesfjord Chapel | Someone was rummaging around in the next room. The sound was faint, but it broke the atmosphere we had been standing in—a hazy, dreamlike feeling, like those half-real, half-imagined sounds from the waking world that intrude into dreams when one is asleep. I felt as though those half-real, half-imagined sounds from the waking world were slipping into a dream while one sleeps.
[1998-07-20 15:10:00] Vesfjord Chapel | I looked down at Dad. I saw his fingers interlaced over his abdomen, the edges of the index fingers stained dark yellow with nicotine, just like old, discolored wallpaper. The skin over his knuckles was deeply and unnaturally wrinkled, now appearing artificial rather than natural. Then I looked at his face. It remained unreadable—though he lay there peaceful and still, it wasn’t blank; traces lingered that I could only describe as expressions of will. I realized I had always tried to determine what expression was on his face, always watching it while trying to interpret it.
[1998-07-20 15:11:00] Vesfjord Chapel | I turned toward Henrik Inge. I nodded. “Shall we go now?” I nodded. But now it’s closed.
[1998-07-20 15:12:00] Vesfjord Chapel | I saw the funeral director waiting for us in the outer room. After stepping out, I left the door open. Though I knew it was improper, I didn’t want to leave Dad alone inside.

[1998-07-20 15:20:00] Parking lot outside the chapel | We shook hands with the funeral director, discussed possible arrangements for the funeral in a few days, then stepped outside and walked toward the parking lot, each lighting a cigarette. Henrik Inge stood close to the car, while I sat down on the edge of a stone block. Rain drifted through the air. The trees behind the chapel bent under an increasingly strong wind. For several seconds, the deafening rustle of leaves drowned out the sound of traffic from the far end of the field. Then both fell silent.
[1998-07-20 15:21:00] Parking lot outside the chapel | He laughed. “Ah, kind of unbelievable,” said Henrik Inge. “Yeah,” I said, “but I’m glad we did it.” “Same here. I had to see it to believe it.” “Do you believe it now?” I asked. He laughed. “Don’t you?”
[1998-07-20 15:22:00] Parking lot outside the chapel | Instead of smiling back at him as I intended, I began to sob again. I pressed my hands hard against my face and lowered my head. Wave after wave of crying made my body tremble. When they finally subsided, I lifted my head and glanced at him, offering a faint smile. I said, “It’s just like when we were kids—me crying, and you watching.”
[1998-07-20 15:23:00] Parking lot outside the chapel | He searched for my eyes. “Are you sure…” he said, searching my gaze, “that you’ll be okay being alone now?” “Of course,” I said, “no problem.” “I can call home and say I won’t come back.” “You drive home. Everything’s already arranged.”
[1998-07-20 15:24:00] Parking lot outside the chapel | He dropped his cigarette, pulled out his car keys from his pocket. I stood up and took a few steps forward, but not close enough for a handshake or embrace. He opened the car door, got in, glanced upward as he inserted the key into the ignition, and the engine roared to life. “OK. I’m off now.”
[1998-07-20 15:24:30] Parking lot outside the small chapel | He said, "Well then, goodbye." "Goodbye. Drive carefully. Give my regards to the family!"
[1998-07-20 15:25:00] Parking lot outside the small chapel | He closed the car door, backed up slightly, paused, fastened his seatbelt, shifted gears, and slowly drove toward the main road. After that, I started walking forward. Suddenly his rear lights came on—he reversed back toward me. His hand reached out from the rolled-down window. He said, "You'd better take this."
[1998-07-20 15:25:30] Parking lot outside the small chapel | He said, "It makes no sense for me to carry it all the way to Zhenpine—better to leave it here. OK?" I said, "OK." This was the brown envelope handed to us by the funeral home attendant.
[1998-07-20 15:26:00] Parking lot outside the small chapel | The car window closed. I stood motionless until his car turned onto the main road and disappeared. Then I slipped the envelope into the inner pocket of my jacket and began walking toward town. He said, "See you next time." In the final seconds, soaring, stirring music rang out across the parking lot, sounding abruptly as if coming from beneath water. This was an impulse I’d had since childhood; if I didn’t do it, misfortune would befall me.
[1998-07-20 16:30:00] Vesfjord Street | After seeing Henrik Inge drive off toward Zhenpine, as I walked back to grandmother’s house, the first thing that came to mind was the blood. How could there possibly have been blood? Grandmother had said she found him dead in the chair—apart from that, the most believable explanation was that he’d suffered a heart attack while sitting there, perhaps even while asleep. Yet the funeral home didn’t just mention blood—they said there was a lot of blood. And the nose—his nasal bone was broken. So was his death at the scene something different in nature? Did he stand up, in agony, and crash into the brick fireplace? Fall onto the floor? But if so, why were there no traces of blood on the walls or floor? Why hadn’t grandmother mentioned any blood? Something must have happened—not just blood—that made it impossible for him to simply pass away quietly. Did she wipe away the blood and then forget all about it? Why would she do that? She didn’t wipe anything away or hide anything—I saw no sign that she felt the need to. Equally strange is how quickly I myself forgot about it. Ah, but maybe that isn’t so strange—there are many other things to deal with now. Still, once I returned to grandmother’s house, I’d have to call Henrik Inge immediately. We needed to contact the doctor responsible for transferring his body to the hospital. He might tell us exactly what had happened.
[1998-07-20 16:40:00] Vesfjord Street | I walked as fast as I could up the gentle slope ahead, as if rushing against time to arrive on schedule, alongside a lush green hedge growing densely within a yard fence. At the same time, another thought seemed to brew in my mind—the desire to prolong my time alone as much as possible, even considering stopping at a café to read a newspaper or something else. Being with Henrik Inge and staying with grandmother was one thing, but facing grandmother alone was quite another. Henrik Inge knew how to handle her. Their easy, humorous tone, similar to the approach used by Erling and Marivik, was—putting it mildly—a method I had never employed. During that year of gymnastics training, because I lived nearby, I spent a lot of time with them. It felt as though my attitude and behavior caused some unpleasantness, that I brought along ways they didn’t want, a suspicion later confirmed in some way months afterward when Mom told me grandmother had called saying I shouldn’t visit them so often. I could handle most accusations, but this one I couldn’t accept. Even if they didn’t welcome me, they were still my grandparents, and I was so shocked that I couldn’t hold back—I began sobbing right in front of Mom. From her perspective, she was also very upset, but what could she do? At the time, I couldn’t understand these things, thinking only that they simply didn’t like me. From then on, I began wondering what aspects of me might have made me unlikable. I couldn’t picture it, couldn’t step into their shoes. I carried my teenage habits into that house and stubbornly held on to them, assuming they’d eventually adapt. This created imbalance, since their habit was never to force me into anything, so ultimately they called my mother. My visits were always driven by need—either concrete, like going there to eat, since I arrived after school and before training, meaning I wouldn’t eat until eight or nine at night, or money-related, since only afternoon buses were free for students, and I couldn’t always afford tickets. Food and money—they didn’t object to providing these, but what angered them was probably my sense of entitlement. So they had no choice: meals and bus fare ceased being free gifts. But there were other factors too—the second reason was the issue of our relationship itself. They no longer wanted to maintain any connection between us. Back then I didn’t understand this. Now I do. My behavior there was to fully approach them with my entire life and thoughts—it was part of the same pattern. They couldn’t, perhaps wouldn’t, reciprocate that closeness, and I accepted some of it anyway. Ironically, during all those visits, I constantly thought of them, always saying what I believed they’d want to hear—even deeply personal, private matters, which I shared not because I needed to speak them, but because I thought it would benefit them to hear.
locations: Parking lot outside the small chapel

text:
[1998-07-20 16:50:00] Long Avenue | Now I was walking along Long Avenue, a long afternoon procession of cars passing beside me, driving past tree trunks darkened by dust and exhaust fumes. Compared to the thick canopy above, full of lush, delicate leaves, these trunks stood heavy as stone pillars. This is the most unpleasant thing, I thought, yet still I consider myself a good judge of people. All I can do is put myself in others’ places—that’s my strength. Understanding others. But myself remains more of a mystery. Ah, how foolish! I laughed. Immediately I looked up to check whether the people in the cars beside me could see me. But no one did. Everyone was absorbed in themselves.
[1998-07-20 16:55:00] Long Avenue | I stopped to light a cigarette. I can’t keep pretending ignorance. No lying, no acting. That’s why I was glad to let Henrik Inge deal with grandmother. But now I must face her personally. As I continued walking, for some reason I began to feel uplifted. Was it because of the brick facades to my left, originally white but blackened by exhaust? Or the trees along the avenue? These still, leaf-covered giants, carrying generation upon generation of endless foliage, these living beings bathed in air? Because whenever my eyes fell upon them, joy always welled up inside me.
[1998-07-20 17:00:00] Long Avenue | I took an especially deep inhale, flicked off the silvery-gray ash from the cigarette, and walked on. I thought of two earlier periods: first, visiting here as a child with grandmother and grandfather in Vesfjord, when every tiny detail of this cityscape appeared like scenes from a fairy tale; then, when I lived here at around ten years old. I saw the pharmacy and remembered once going there with Henrik Inge and grandmother; high snowbanks along the roadside outside, snow falling, her wearing a long coat and fur hat, standing in line at the window, the pharmacist in a white coat moving back and forth inside. Occasionally she turned to see what we were doing. Her gaze wasn’t cold, but at least emotionless—after the first glance, she smiled, her eyes suddenly warm. The change happened in an instant. When Henrik Inge and I drove to the small chapel, the surroundings hadn’t stirred any memories in me, but now they surged powerfully. I’d been here a few years ago, and since then I’ve observed how these impressions come flooding back, partly because they connect with certain fragments of my memory world, partly linked to others, simultaneously existing across three distinct, separate time periods.
[1998-07-20 17:05:00] Long Avenue | Even a rusty, crooked clothesline behind a garden, even the rotting apples on the ground beneath a tree, even the boat wrapped in tarpaulin with its damp support poles sticking out, and the yellowed, flattened grass underneath. I looked at the sloping road leading up to Long Bridge, remembering how grandfather usually cycled home along it in the afternoons. How different he looked outside! As if the slight swaying motion on the uphill ride was the reason—not only the bicycle he rode, but the man himself: for an instant he was just any elderly Vesfjord man in a coat and cap, and in the next moment he was grandfather again. I looked down at the rooftops spreading across the residential area below, recalling how, at sixteen, I had walked through them at night, filled with emotional turbulence. And so everything I saw now appeared splendidly beautiful.
[1998-07-20 17:10:00] Long Grove Avenue | I saw the grassy slope behind the buildings on the other side of the road, and I thought of a blue, biting winter day when we had sled down it with Grandmother. The snow in the sunlight was wet yet dazzlingly bright, like the intense light high in the mountains, so that the city below us looked strange, everything happening there laid completely bare—people walking along the streets beneath us, cars passing by, the man clearing snow from the driveway outside a local company on the other side of the road, other children playing with sleds, as if there were no other place to gather, just circling here under the sky. As I walked down, all of this came alive inside me, everything around me entered my awareness and made me reflect, but only superficially, only at the outermost layer of consciousness, because Dad is dead, and this fills me with sorrow deep within, an emotion that radiates through all my thoughts and feelings. He can be found in these memories too, but he is insignificant there, which is truly strange—there is no trace of any thought about him.
[1998-07-20 17:15:00] Long Grove Avenue | Back in the early 70s, Dad walked a few meters ahead of me along the sidewalk—we were going to the kiosk to buy a pipe cleaner, then on to Grandmother and Grandfather’s. He lifted his chin as if smiling quietly to himself; I knew that kind of joy of his. Or Dad at the bank, one hand holding his wallet, using the fingers of the other to push his hair back, looking at his gleaming reflection in the glass at the counter. Or Dad getting into the car and driving into town. In these memories, I didn’t feel him as someone significant. That is to say, I felt something at the time I remembered them, not now, as I think of them again. With the thought that he is dead, the relationship with him has changed. In this thought, he is everything—it feels natural—and the thought itself is everything. So when I go there, on a day with soft, misty rain, it’s as if I’ve entered another world. Nothing outside this world holds any meaning. I look, I think, and then what I see and what I think recedes: it has nothing to do with them. It has nothing to do with anything. Only Dad, that he is dead—that’s the only thing it’s connected to.
[1998-07-20 17:20:00] Across from Pharmacy Street | As I walked, the brown envelope—the one containing the items he had with him when he died—remained constantly in my mind. I stopped outside the general business company across from Pharmacy Street, leaning slightly toward the wall, and took out the envelope. I saw my father’s name written on it. I stepped a few paces closer to the wall, shaking the things in my hand. His ring, some jewelry, a few coins, a needle. That was all. An old woman pulling a wheeled shopping bag with one hand and leading a small white dog with the other glanced at me as she came out the door. I turned each item over in my palm, one by one. A strange feeling. I expected the surname Grete Lundnes. But unless there was a spelling error, the ridiculous and pretentious new name was the one used at his death. The objects themselves seemed utterly ordinary. Yet he carried them with him—his ring must have been on his finger, the jewelry a necklace around his neck—and after his death, they acquired a special aura. Death and gold. They filled me with a sense of dread. The fear I stood there with was the same fear of death I had as a child—not fear of dying myself, but fear of the dead.
[1998-07-20 17:25:00] Kiosk/Street | I put the items back into the envelope, slipped it into my pocket, ran across the street between two cars, went into the kiosk to buy a newspaper and a Lion chocolate bar, and ate the chocolate as I walked the last few hundred meters to the house.

[1998-07-20 17:30:00] Grandmother's Hallway | I smelled the familiar, nostalgic scent still lingering there, the same one I’d known since childhood. I remember Grandmother unexpectedly coming to our house—I had no idea she was visiting. When I came home from school and caught the scent in the hallway, I thought a burglar had broken in, because there were no signs of a guest: no car parked in the driveway, no coats or shoes in the hall. Only the smell. Our house never had its own distinct, personal scent. Even after everything that’s happened, even after twenty years, even after so much has changed, the smell in the house remains the same—it strikes me as so strange. You might suppose it has to do with habits: the same soap, the same detergent, the same perfume and aftershave, the same meals cooked the same way, the same daily routines... But when all former habits in a house have ceased... how can the scent remain unchanged? Is this smell I detect every time I enter—a smell infused and imprinted into the walls by forty years of life—exactly that?
[1998-07-20 17:35:00] Grandmother's Cellar | I didn’t go upstairs to her right away, but opened the door to the cellar and descended a few steps down the narrow staircase. I held onto the banister. I felt the cold, dark air rush toward me; the only light came from a small porthole-like window set into the wall below. It felt like condensed air, or perhaps the house itself concentrated—exactly how I remembered it.
