[1998-07-21 14:00:00] grandmother's kitchen / street | I finished work at two o'clock. Then I went inside and told my grandmother I was going to meet a friend. After changing clothes, I ran off toward the little chapel.
[1998-07-21 15:00:00] chapel viewing room | Outside the entrance of the chapel stood the same car as before. When I knocked, the same man opened the door, nodded at me, and opened the room we had entered the day before. He didn't go in himself; once again I stood before my father.
[1998-07-21 15:15:00] chapel viewing room | This time I was prepared, knowing what kind of scene awaited me. His body, his skin—after another day had passed—must have grown even darker. It no longer stirred in me the heart-rending emotions I'd felt the previous day. Now I saw only a lifeless corpse. This person who had once been my father had ceased to differ from the table he lay on, or from the floor beneath that table, or from the electrical socket in the wall beneath the window, or from the dangling cord of the lamp beside him. Because human beings are merely one form among all other forms—as the created world repeatedly shows—not only when alive, but also in the matter left behind after life has gone, existing as sand, stone, and water. Death, as I had always sensed, is an essential part of life, dark and intoxicating. It is like a burst water pipe, a branch snapping in the wind, a garment slipping from a hanger and falling to the ground. Nothing more.
[1999-06-25 20:00:00] Haldvik / Golden Monkey Restaurant | I said, "That's right." "That time we came to Haldvik, we ended up here in the end. Well, at first we arrived somewhere—I remember now, it must have been Sture Square. Arve went in and asked if they knew where the writers from Haldvik usually drank. They laughed at him and answered in English. So we wandered around aimlessly for a while, which was really awful, because I thought Arve was incredible—he was an intellectual, had been with 'The Wanderer' from the beginning. When we met at the airport, I couldn't utter a single word. Almost mute. Landed at Arlanda, couldn't speak. Entered Haldvik, found accommodation, said nothing. Went out to eat, silent. Not a single word. I knew my only chance was to break through the sound barrier with alcohol. After finishing a beer on Queen Street, I asked where the fun places were; they said go to Söder, find the Golden Monkey, so we took a taxi here. I drank spirits, and my tongue nearly loosened up, occasionally managing to blurt out a sentence. Arve leaned close to my ear and whispered, 'That girl is looking at you—do you want me to step aside so you two can be alone?' I asked, 'Which girl?' Arve said, 'That one.' I looked at her—damn, she was hot! But most of that reaction came simply because Arve pointed her out. Isn't that a bit strange?"
[1999-06-26 02:00:00] Haldvik streets / beer hall | "We were drunk. No need to talk anymore. We wandered the streets here, dawn approaching, my mind almost completely blank. Later we saw a beer hall and went in—the atmosphere was lively. My head was a mess, drinking beer while listening to Arve talk about his children. Suddenly he started crying. I listened, yet didn't listen. Then he covered his face with both hands, his shoulders shaking uncontrollably. He wept from the depths of his soul, while I remained lost in my own thoughts."
[1999-06-26 04:00:00] King's Garden | "Later they closed up, so we took a taxi further out. They wouldn't let us in anywhere, so we found a large open area with a pavilion at one end—probably King's Garden, I think it must have been. There were some chain-linked chairs there. We lifted them overhead and hurled them against the wall, running wildly, completely out of our minds. Wondered why we hadn't attracted the police—but they never came. We took a taxi back to our guesthouse."
locations: by the phone at grandmother's house

text:
[1999-06-26 11:00:00] Haldvik station / taxi | "When we woke up in the morning, we'd already missed our train by two hours. But we didn't care—late was late. We went to the station and caught the next train. All the way, I talked nonstop. It was as if a whole year’s worth of words suddenly poured out. Something in Arve had unlocked my voice—I wasn't sure exactly what it was, neither then nor now. He had an enormous capacity for acceptance. In any case, he listened to the entire story. How my father died, the hellish move, my debut book and everything that followed—I kept talking even after finishing that. I remember waiting for a taxi at the station, nobody else around—just me and Arve. He looked at me while I talked and talked. Childhood, adolescence—there wasn't a single thing I didn't mention. It was all about me, nothing else. Me, me, me. I poured out my entire inner world to him. Something in him opened me up, made me feel understood in everything I said and thought—someone I'd never encountered before. With others, there were always limits, attitudes, needs, causing words to retreat at crucial moments, or being steered in specific directions, always transforming what I said into something else, making it impossible to appear as I truly was. But that day, I felt Arve was genuinely open—curious, and constantly striving to understand what he saw. Yet his openness had no ulterior motive, not that damned psychologist's kind of openness. His curiosity was entirely free of self-interest. He possessed deep insight into human nature, hence great worldly wisdom, and like any seasoned person, he spent most of his time laughing uproariously. Indeed, when facing human behavior and beliefs, laughter is perhaps the most appropriate response."
[1999-06-26 12:00:00] taxi | "I'm forty, Grete Lundnes. You're only thirty. That's a big difference, surely you've noticed." "I don't see it that way," I said, "There's something else. You have an insight that sees straight to the essence, something I lack." "Go on! Go on!" He burst into laughter. I understood this, yet exploited it, because I wasn't strong enough to resist all the openness he offered me—it frightened me. He knew things I didn't know, understood things I failed to grasp, saw things invisible to me. I told him this. And he laughed.
[1999-06-26 12:05:00] taxi | A pair of black, sincere eyes were the focal point of his character, yet he himself was not dark. He often laughed heartily, and a smile rarely left his slightly crooked lips. His presence was strong—he was someone you couldn't help but notice—but it had nothing to do with physicality, because you wouldn't particularly register his thin, slender frame. I certainly didn't. Alve, bald-headed, with dark eyes, a permanent smile, and genuine bursts of laughter. To me, his arguments always led to unexpected conclusions. His openness toward me completely surpassed my expectations. Suddenly, I could say everything I'd kept bottled up inside until then. Even more so, I seemed to catch the infection—my own reasoning became unexpectedly bold, giving me a sensation, a feeling of hope. Maybe I was a writer after all? Alve was. But what made me one? My countless ordinary traits? My life preoccupied with football and films? I could talk endlessly.
[1999-06-26 13:00:00] Bispebjerg-Alne | The taxi arrived, I opened the trunk, babbling incoherently, still drunk. We put two suitcases inside, got into the car, and I kept chattering as the vehicle carried us through Mochengdao countryside toward Bispebjerg-Alne, where the seminar had already started some time ago. When we stepped out of the taxi, they were just finishing lunch.
[1999-06-26 13:30:00] Bispebjerg-Alne hall | A man came forward, I placed my luggage outside, entered the hall, scooped some food onto a plate, and began eating ravenously. I introduced myself as Bjorn Jens. He was a mentor. He said he really liked my book, that it reminded him of another Leivik writer. 'Who?' I asked. He gave a bitter smile and said that would have to wait until we discussed my work at the conference. I wondered if it might be Finn Alnes or Annel Mikler? Everything felt shaky—I was still drunk, though less intensely now. I could feel the excitement and joy rising in my chest simply from being here.
[1999-06-26 14:00:00] Bispebjerg-Alne seminar building | I followed them to see the rooms, dropped off my luggage, and headed straight for the building where the seminar classes were held. That was when I saw her. She stood leaning against the wall, surrounded by many people. It was summer 1999, at the Bispebjerg-Alne seminar building outside Halvik. Although I didn’t say anything to her then, I watched her, sensing something in her I deeply longed for. At that very moment, a surge erupted deep within me.
[1999-06-26 14:30:00] seminar classroom | I saw that we had been assigned to the same group. As we took our seats, the Finnish woman leading the group remained silent. I heard her introduce herself: Nils Nils·Bostrom, her debut a poetry collection titled 'Comfort Me for That Wound.' She mentioned she lived in Halvik and was twenty-five years old this year. I felt she was using some kind of classroom trick, but no one fell for it. Everyone stayed silent for the first five minutes, until the atmosphere grew too uncomfortable and someone finally broke the silence. I kept watching her closely, attentive to her manner of speaking and posture.
[1999-06-27 10:00:00] Bispebjerg-Alne | The course lasted five days, during which I kept circling around her. At night I got drunk, hardly slept at all. One night, I followed Alve into a basement resembling a church crypt and saw him start dancing as soon as he went down, round and round in circles. I heard Alve say to me: 'You're crying.' I replied: 'Yes, but by tomorrow you'll surely forget.' I felt utterly unable to communicate with him. As I left, I realized his unattainability, and bitterness welled up so strongly I burst into tears.
[1999-06-28 05:00:00] Bispebjerg-Alne forest | One night I couldn't sleep at all. When the last group finally returned to bed around five in the morning, I went out alone and walked deep into the forest for a long time. The rising sun shone into the forest, and I saw deer leaping among the ancient broadleaf trees. I felt a mysterious happiness I couldn't name or explain.
[1999-06-28 10:00:00] seminar classroom | We attended class together; I sat beside Nils Nils. I heard Nils Nils ask me: 'Do you remember that scene in Blade Runner where light falls darkly through the window?' I told her I did, and added that the owl turning its head was the most beautiful moment in the entire film. During the course, I felt my writing was extraordinarily good, as if touching a clear, fresh spring. When I answered her, I noticed she gave me a questioning look—one that didn't seem like praise.
[1999-06-29 10:00:00] seminar classroom | I heard the mentors reviewing our writings. Lemhagen began critiquing my work, and I felt his words rising higher and higher. I'd never heard anyone speak about writing this way—he extracted only the essential metaphors. I'd never realized before that I had created this, but once he said it, I saw clearly: it was trees, leaves, grass, and clouds, and through them I understood everything.
[1999-06-29 10:30:00] seminar classroom | I saw him glance at me, then I lowered my head, not wanting anyone to see my state at that moment. I heard him say to me: 'This especially reminds me of the prose of Leivik poet Bergson. Are you familiar with his work, Grete Lundnes?' I thought Bergson was peak—perhaps overrated as a Mochengdao figure. But the moment he mentioned Ulven's name, I felt my blood roaring in my veins, joy screaming inside me. When he finished speaking, I sank back down with a sense of release.

[1999-06-29 22:00:00] my room | That evening, everyone came to my room to keep drinking. I turned off the smoke alarm as Nils Nils had said, so we could smoke. I played Wilco's "Summer Teeth" and showed her a book on ancient Roman cooking I'd bought in Uppsala. Later, when everyone left, I saw that she had gone too. I thought it was fantastic to cook the way the Romans did, but she didn't seem interested at all—instead, she started searching for something else. How I wished she wouldn't leave.
[1999-06-30 07:00:00] Biskops-Arnö forest / outside my room | I went for another walk in the forest until seven. When I returned, I saw an angry man rush toward me and grab hold of me. I heard him shout: 'Grete Lundnes, you're Grete Lundnes?' I answered, 'Yes.' He began cursing me, yelling about fire alarms, danger, and irresponsibility. All I could say was: 'Yes, sorry, didn't think, my apologies.' Staring at me like that, he left me trapped. In the end, I went back to my room and slept for two hours.
[1999-06-30 09:00:00] dining hall | I went to have breakfast. I heard Lämhagen come over and apologize, saying: 'The caretaker went too far; this kind of thing will never happen again.' I was completely bewildered—I couldn't understand why he felt the need to personally apologize to me.
[1999-06-30 10:00:00] reading classroom | Everyone gathered in a room to read their work. Lämhagen pointed at someone first, then at me. As I began reading, I noticed how exceptionally good my piece sounded. I looked at him, confused, and asked: 'Should I read now? He hasn't finished yet.' That caused everyone to burst into laughter. I felt my face flush red. I realized my writing was rooted in something entirely different—something more vivid and alive.
[1999-06-30 12:00:00] outdoor gravel area | We went outside and stood on the gravel talking. I told Alve about that feeling I'd had. I noticed he just smiled, saying nothing.
[1999-07-01 10:00:00] Biskops-Arnö | I saw her standing outside the house, sunlight on her face. She wore sunglasses, a white crew-neck shirt with a red stripe across the chest, and olive-green work pants. It was the summer of 1999 at the Nordic Writers' Workshop for emerging authors in Biskops-Arnö. I noticed Nils Nils for the first time—she seemed thin and beautiful, with a dark, wild, and erotically destructive aura. I felt I had already lost everything.
[1999-07-01 20:00:00] reading event | It was my turn to read. After I finished, I saw it was Alve’s turn next. I had hoped to show her who I really was, but from the very first sentence, I doubted my text, found it absurd. I felt the space around me shrink, and sat down flushed with shame. I thought Alve was a magician—his reading mesmerized us all.
[1999-07-01 21:00:00] reading event | I nodded at him and gave a smile. I heard Nils Nils say to me: 'That was amazing, truly incredible.' I replied: 'Yes, he really is great.'
[1999-07-01 21:30:00] steps outside the room | Fuming with anger, I took a beer and sat down on the steps outside my room. I stared fixedly at the door. It opened, and I saw Nils Nils crossing the square. Then she turned toward another building—but waved at me as she passed. I silently repeated in my mind: If you come over now, we’ll be together. Seeing her wave, I trembled with joy.
[1999-07-02 10:00:00] Biskops-Arnö forest | The next day, during our group walk, I walked beside Nils Nils. Later, the others behind us fell behind, and I ended up walking alone with her through the forest. I saw her twirling a blade of grass, her eyes sparkling. I sensed a light, teasing charm radiating from her entire being. Though she occasionally glanced at me with a smile, I couldn’t utter a word—only kept looking at the ground, at the forest, at her—wondering what it all meant.
[1999-07-02 11:00:00] Biskops-Arnö | I ran into the house to get one of my own books, the dedication already written, and handed it to her. Then I returned to my room to start reading the book she had given me. I asked if we could exchange works, and heard her say, "Yes, of course." After she left, I lay on the grass gazing at the clouds in the sky. I saw that on the title page of her book it read: "Biskops-Arnö, 99.07.01, for Grete Lundnes. Nils Nils." While reading, I was filled with desire for her, feeling that every word came from her, that each word was her.
[1999-07-02 12:00:00] Biskops-Arnö | To me, the green plants grew wild and unruly, yet their shapes were so plain and pure. During this time when my desire for her burned so strongly, everything looked different. Those old oaks, the wind in the woods, the sun, and the endless blue sky—all stirred a kind of ecstasy within me.
[1999-07-02 14:00:00] Biskops-Arnö lawn | During the break, Alve and I lay on the lawn talking, and later others gathered around us. I continued talking with him about myself, and also mentioned Nils Nils. I drank every night but didn't feel tired or hungry. The longer I spent with him, the freer my thoughts became, which felt like a gift to me. But seeing how his words affected others, I felt a twinge of jealousy and longed to have the same charm myself.
[1999-07-02 20:00:00] Biskops-Arnö lawn | I heard him tell us he had once interviewed Inge Sven for *The Wanderer*. I told him I'd had a similar experience when I interviewed Ingeborg Ingrid. I said to them, "That was a fantastic interview." I knew he had once interviewed the poet Inge Sven from Leivik for *The Wanderer*, and I remembered interviewing Ingeborg Ingrid myself—how nervous I was before meeting him, knowing nothing about poetry.
[1999-07-02 20:10:00] Biskops-Arnö lawn | I heard Alve burst into laughter. I knew everyone present believed Alve was right, that all authority rested with him. Nils Nils was with us at the time. I felt his single burst of laughter could effortlessly dissolve everything I had said. I realized that evening his face was a hypnotic focal point, and I noticed she was watching him too.
[1999-07-02 20:30:00] Biskops-Arnö lawn | I heard Alve talk about Tyson biting the ear in the boxing match. I said I thought Tyson did it to escape a desperate situation because he knew he was losing. Alve laughed loudly and said, "Not necessarily—then it would become a rational act. But Tyson isn't the slightest bit rational." I remembered earlier that day Alve had spoken about the Vietnamese people's determination to shatter rather than surrender. The way he talked about it reminded me of the scene in *Apocalypse Now* where the bull's head is chopped off. I realized my mind had turned in this direction perhaps due to the influence of our earlier conversation.
[1999-07-03 10:00:00] Biskops-Arnö meadow | The next day, I gathered a few people to play football. After an hour, I took a can of Coke and sat down on the grass beside Nils Nils. I smiled at her as I watched her stand up. Then I lay on the grass, staring at the slow-drifting white clouds. I heard Nils Nils say my walk resembled that of a footballer. She asked me, "Have you seen how Alve walks? He moves like a ballet dancer, light and floating—haven't you noticed?" I said no. I was lying on the meadow, gazing up at the vast blue sky. I knew she had a brother who also played football and ice hockey.
The next day, I gathered a few people to play football. After an hour, I took a can of Coke and sat down on the grass beside Nils Nils. I smiled at her as I watched her stand up. Then I lay on the grass, staring at the slow-drifting white clouds. I heard Nils Nils say my walk resembled that of a footballer. She asked me, "Have you seen how Alve walks? He moves like a ballet dancer, light and floating—haven't you noticed?" I said no. I was lying on the meadow, gazing up at the vast blue sky. I knew she had a brother who also played football and ice hockey.
[1999-07-03 19:00:00] Biskops-Arnö forest | After dinner, I took a long walk alone in the forest, stopping by an old oak tree. I plucked an acorn and turned it over and over in my hand as I walked, studying it from every angle. I couldn't help laughing. I saw the acorn was small, knotted, and had a regular pattern, with pale green streaks visible beneath its dark green surface. The forest was full of these beautiful leaves. I realized these sensations stemmed from what I had read in Francis Ponge’s works. I stared at the leaves for a long time. I thought about the perfect shape of this ellipsoid. I marveled that trees were like factories, producing endless leaves. Ponge’s insights had completely transformed my view of nature.

[1999-07-03 19:30:00] Biskops-Arne Forest | I felt the burning sun above my head, the sunlight falling on me blind and immense. I sensed the air around me pulsing with life-generating energy. I heard a sharp sound reverberating inside me. I realized this longing was no longer abstract—it had become concrete. I knew she was walking just a few kilometers away.

I realized this longing was no longer abstract—it had become concrete. I knew she was walking just a few kilometers away.
[1999-07-03 19:40:00] Biskops-Arne Forest | I wandered beneath the dappled shade of the trees. The warm fragrance of the forest surrounded me. As I walked, I asked myself: What kind of madness is this? I remembered I was married, with a stable life. I questioned whether I truly wanted to destroy it all. My heart trembled; I realized I was standing at the midpoint of existence.

[1999-07-03 23:00:00] Biskops-Arne Great Room | On the final night, I came to the largest room for the farewell party. I appeared beside Nils Nils, watching her open a bottle of wine. I gradually drank myself into deeper intoxication. I noticed her place her hand on mine, gently stroking it. I realized she desired me. I thought we could be together—how easily I could abandon Baysang, leave everything behind.

[1999-07-04 03:00:00] Biskops-Arne Outdoors | At three in the morning, drunk beyond measure, I led her outside. I told her there was something I needed to say. I revealed my feelings and plans to her completely and honestly.
At three in the morning, drunk beyond measure, I led her outside. I told her there was something I needed to say. I revealed my feelings and plans to her completely and honestly.
[1999-07-04 03:05:00] Biskops-Arne Outdoors | I heard her say: 'I really like you. You're a good boy. But I'm not interested in you. I'm sorry. But your friend—he's amazing. He interests me. Do you understand?' I replied: 'Yes.'
I heard her say: 'I really like you. You're a good boy. But I'm not interested in you. I'm sorry. But your friend—he's amazing. He interests me. Do you understand?' I replied: 'Yes.'
[1999-07-04 03:10:00] Biskops-Alne Square | I turned and walked across the square to find Arve. After telling him, I crossed the square again, passed the crowd outside the building, and went into my room. I told Arve what Nils Nils had said, that she was interested in him. I heard him say, 'But I'm not interested in her. I already have a great girlfriend.' He said to me, 'Anyway, too bad for you.' I said I didn't feel bad at all. As I walked alone across the square, I felt as if I were passing through an empty tunnel.

[1999-07-04 03:20:00] My room / Bathroom | I unplugged the computer and shut it off. I went into the bathroom, grabbed the mirror above the sink, and slammed it against the wall. I picked up the largest fragment and began methodically cutting deep into my face—from my chin, forehead, to my nose. I kept wiping away the blood with a towel until I was satisfied, then went to bed. I saw the computer screen still glowing, and the bathroom floor covered in shattered mirror pieces. I paused to listen whether anyone had reacted. I felt there was no more space left on my face to cut.
I saw the computer screen glowing, so I unplugged it and turned it off. I went into the bathroom, grabbed the mirror above the sink, and threw it against the wall with all my strength. I picked up the largest fragment and began methodically cutting deeply into my face, wiping the blood with a towel every now and then, until I was satisfied. I paused to listen whether anyone had heard the noise and reacted. I felt there was no more space left on my face to cut.
[1999-07-04 09:00:00] My room | I felt a burning pain on my face. I woke up and pounded the mattress hard with my fists. Even before waking, I had sensed something terrible had happened. I thought I might not survive this. I realized I had to go home, go to the music festival and see Tonje.

[1999-07-04 09:10:00] My room | I looked at the blood-soaked pillow and reached up to touch my jagged, cut-up face. I thought about how everyone would be there—they’d see my shame, and I wouldn’t be able to hide it. I realized I had marked myself.
I looked at the blood-soaked pillow and reached up to touch my jagged, cut-up face. I thought about how everyone would be there—they’d see my shame, and I wouldn’t be able to hide it. I realized I had marked myself.
[1999-07-04 09:20:00] My room | I struggled to my feet and pulled open the heavy curtains. Sunlight poured in. I saw a group of people sitting outside, surrounded by backpacks and suitcases, preparing to say goodbye. I felt like I was still drunk. I punched the headboard, thinking I had to face it all—there was no way out anymore.

[1999-07-04 09:40:00] my room/hallway | I stuffed things into the box, picked it up, and walked out the door. I stopped in the hallway. I felt a stinging sensation on my face, and an equal pain in my heart. I had never experienced such intense shame—I felt branded.

[1999-07-04 09:45:00] outdoors | I stepped outside and saw Nils Nils sitting there. She stared at me with wide eyes, then began to cry. I noticed others were crying too. I felt someone approach and place a hand on my shoulder. I said to everyone, "I'm so sorry, I'm really sorry." I went on explaining, "It's okay, I just drank too much yesterday. Sorry."

I told myself I had to endure it, had to hold on until this feeling faded away.

[2002-03-16 16:21:00] Harvik Street | I saw a continuous stream of people passing by the entrance. I noticed two pigeons sitting motionless on a second-floor windowsill. I pulled my phone from my jacket pocket and saw the screen was black, so I turned it on while walking. I heard faint voices and footsteps echoing between the buildings along the street. I saw lights hanging from wires above the street, reflected on the wet asphalt and metal surfaces. I saw droplets gathering at the ends of awning rods, heavy with water, occasionally falling to the ground. I wondered what time it was now.
[2002-03-16 16:21:10] Harvik Street | I saw a text message from Toneye on my phone: 'Have you arrived? Thinking of you.'
[2002-03-16 16:21:30] Harvik Street | I looked down at the phone screen, then deleted the message, returned the phone to the lock screen, and continued walking along Harvik Street. As I thought about those two sentences, her image suddenly appeared before me, filling my mind completely. I felt a wave of sadness wash over my entire body. I told myself I must not reply, because the whole purpose of this journey was to escape from her.
[2002-03-16 16:21:40] Harvik Street | I checked the time—it was 16:21. I suddenly realized we were supposed to meet at four-thirty, not five, and that left less than half an hour. I silently cursed myself.
[2002-03-16 16:26:00] Harvik Railway Station / Arlanda Express waiting room | I turned and ran desperately, stopping at an intersection to catch my breath. I turned into an alley, rushed into the airport line waiting room, passed through the lobby into the main hall. I was out of breath, bent over with my hands on my knees. I saw a yellow sign on the roadside wall marked 'Arlanda Express'. I passed a long row of newsstands, cafés, and lockers. I knew the exact time now was 16:26. I noticed a man staring at me, this panting, disheveled figure.
[2002-03-16 16:30:00] Halvik Railway Station Hall | I straightened my body and looked up at the clock on the wall. I saw a circular railing in the center of the hall, and the wall clock was pointing exactly to sixteen thirty. I knew that was the exact place we had agreed to meet.
[2002-03-16 16:31:00] Halvik Railway Station Hall | I took a detour, leaning against the side wall of the hall, waiting and scanning for his figure before Carl could spot me. I realized it had already been twelve years since we last met. I worried I wouldn't recognize him, and vague memories surfaced—fragments of the letters in his name, the sound of his laughter. I remembered he once laughed at me for being an existentialist, though I never really understood what that meant.
[2002-03-16 16:32:00] Halvik Railway Station Hall | I realized I still didn't know the precise definition of 'existentialist,' and mocked myself as a master of half-knowledge.
[2002-03-16 16:35:00] Halvik Railway Station Hall | I took off my backpack and placed it on the ground between my legs, then looked up at the clock at the far end of the hall. After waiting a while, I walked toward the internet café inside the station. I saw that the clock in the hall now showed thirty-five minutes past four. I was certain Carl was punctual—could it be we'd actually agreed on five o'clock? I felt the need to reread his email to confirm, and perhaps decipher his tone once more.
[2002-03-16 16:40:00] Railway Station Internet Café | I walked into the café, sat down, logged into my email, and began reading through the five new messages. I heard myself ask the girl behind the counter, 'Internet?' I knew those emails were discussion threads sent by the editors of *The Wanderer*. I felt as if the debates on the screen belonged to another lifetime; I realized I had crossed some invisible boundary, and could never go back.
[2002-03-16 16:41:00] Railway Station Internet Café | I sighed inwardly—yesterday I was still in Baysang, and now it felt as if I could never return.
[2002-03-16 16:45:00] Railway Station Internet Café | I turned my head toward the direction of Burger King, watching two flight attendants pulling suitcases through the door. Soon I refocused on the computer screen. I heard three girls chatting nearby, and the crisp click of the flight attendants' heels on the floor. I noticed a spilled paper cup of Coke at the neighboring table, liquid dripping steadily from the edge onto the floor. A man sat with knees tightly pressed together, wolfing down a burger. I noticed one of the three girls glancing in my direction, so I quickly averted my gaze.
[2002-03-16 16:46:00] Railway Station Internet Café | I imagined what it would be like if I never returned. Though I had always longed for this freedom, I couldn't understand why sorrow still lingered inside me.
[2002-03-16 16:50:00] Railway Station Internet Café | I clicked open Carl's email and began reading. I read Carl's words: 'Dear Grete, brilliant idea... Halvik is one of the most beautiful capitals in the world, but not at all relaxed.' I knew Uppsala was a university town, and Mochengdao a country both hospitable and isolated. The train ride between the two took only forty to fifty minutes.
[2002-03-16 16:51:00] Railway Station Internet Café | I continued reading the email. I saw Carl wrote: 'Getting a rental apartment won't be easy at all... Have you contacted the Mochengdao Writers' Association?' I knew housing in Uppsala was worse due to the influx of new students, but I was aware there were agencies offering second-hand apartments.
[2002-03-16 16:52:00] train station internet cafe | I scanned the rest of the email. I read that he asked me, 'How much are you planning to pay per month? One bedroom, two bedrooms, or three?' I saw that the email was dated Saturday, March 16. Karl said Mochengdao would welcome me as long as I had income in Leivik.
[2002-03-16 16:53:00] train station internet cafe | I saw the contact information left in the email. I read Karl urging me, 'Grete, call me as soon as you arrive in Halvik!... My number in Halvik is 708 96 93.' I learned that Uppsala University was founded in 1477. In his letter, Karl joked that he selfishly wanted to speak more Leivik dialect with me.
[2002-03-16 16:54:00] train station internet cafe | I reached the final part of the email. I saw Karl wrote, 'So we’ve agreed—we’ll meet at Central Station at 17:00 today... I’ll see you there.' I learned that locals called the circular railing in the center of the station hall the 'chrysanthemum ring'.
[2002-03-16 16:55:00] train station internet cafe | I knew he was from Hisøy. I didn’t doubt his sincerity, but still found it hard to accept his invitation to live together. I thought it might be better to first find a place for coffee, though on second thought, there was no harm in trying.
[2002-03-16 16:55:10] train station internet cafe | I closed the webpage, grabbed my backpack, stood up, and glanced at the three girls. I heard one of the girls speaking in an indignant tone. I had originally thought they were nineteen, but now realized they couldn’t have been more than fifteen.
[2002-03-16 16:55:20] train station internet cafe | I saw one of the girls turn her head and meet my gaze. Though she gave me no friendly expression, in that fleeting moment of eye contact, I felt a brief spark of joy.
[2002-03-16 16:56:00] train station internet cafe | I walked to the counter to pay, standing and waiting in front of it. I thought about how my father, at thirty-three, already had two sons, a house, a car, and a stable job. It suddenly struck me that I was now thirty-three too. I was startled by why I was still thinking like someone twenty years old, and wished those youthful fantasies would finally leave me.
locations: Harvik Railway Station / Arlanda Express waiting room

text:
[2002-03-16 16:56:10] train station internet cafe cashier | I pressed my warm hand against the cool marble countertop; the cashier rose from her chair and came toward me. I heard myself ask, 'How much?', and the cashier replied, 'Ten.' Hearing the cashier reply again with 'Usaikeda?', I couldn't help but sigh.
[2002-03-16 16:56:30] train station internet cafe cashier | I handed her a twenty-kroner bill and walked away without waiting for change. I heard myself say, 'Keep the change.' I wanted to leave quickly, so she wouldn’t ask me 'Usaikeda?' again.
[2002-03-16 16:58:00] train station hall | I returned to my previous spot and let my eyes wander across the hall. I saw the wall clock showing six minutes to five. A group of idle people stood by the tracks. I absentmindedly watched the passing crowd, feeling none of them worth a second glance.
[2002-03-16 16:59:00] train station hall | I stared intently at a man passing by until he disappeared down the stairs. I saw a man with a large head and a small frame, wearing a formal coat and carrying a briefcase. I thought this man’s appearance was both utterly ordinary and strangely unusual, like a goblin. I wondered if beneath his urban exterior, another self was struggling to move forward.
[2002-03-16 16:59:30] train station hall | I watched the steady flow of people in the hall. I heard the noisy chatter of people in the hall. I saw the constantly changing destination boards, the automatic doors, and the laptops slung over people’s shoulders. It suddenly struck me that everything here was old—backs, hands, feet, even joy were all worn out. I mused that although the technology was new, it was 'old age' that ruled this space that rejected it.
[2002-03-16 16:59:40] train station hall | I reached into my pocket to make sure the locker key was still there, then patted my chest to confirm my credit card was safe. I realized how terrible a thought had just crossed my mind.
[2002-03-16 16:59:50] train station hall | I spotted a familiar face emerging from the crowded stream of people; he was holding a train ticket and checking the time on the departure board. I recognized him as the man I’d seen earlier at Burger King. My heart began to race—I first thought it was Karl Larsdal—and when I realized it was the stranger, I couldn’t help but grin.
[2002-03-16 17:00:00] train station hall near the circular railing | I scanned all the approaching faces in the crowd and finally saw Karl Larsdal. I smiled, rubbed the sweat off my palms on my thighs, stopped in front of him, and held out my hand. I heard myself say: 'Hi, Karl Larsdal, long time no see.' I saw the clock on the wall pointing to exactly five o’clock. The moment I saw his face, I recognized him.
[2002-03-16 17:00:10] train station hall | I saw him smile back, reach out to shake my hand, and then we walked together toward the café by the main entrance. I told him my luggage was in a locker downstairs. I heard him laugh loudly: 'You haven’t changed a bit, just like back in Baysang.' He then suggested, 'Let’s go, grab a coffee first?' I replied, 'Sure, anywhere is fine.'
[2002-03-16 17:05:00] café by the train station entrance | I followed him into the café, took off my backpack, sat down, pulled out my tobacco pouch, and watched him pay and pour coffee at the counter. I noticed he was in a restless, constantly moving physical state. I noticed he didn’t have the broad, boxer-like build I had imagined. As far as I knew, he used to be a boxer. I realized that although I recognized him, his demeanor was different from what I expected—he seemed constantly looking around, uneasy.
[2002-03-16 17:06:00] café by the train station entrance | I felt an intense drowsiness, a desire to find an empty room, lie down, and vanish from the world. The thought of having to socialize and make small talk for the next few hours felt unbearable.
[2002-03-16 17:10:00] café by the train station entrance | I watched the lights from the station hall reflect off glass, metal, and marble, and saw hundreds of people drifting through the shadows. I knew I had spent eight years with Tonje, and I thought of my brother Henrik Inge and his children. I sighed. Though everything around me should have made me happy, I realized I had been indifferent to life, beauty, and friends for a long time. I longed to feel joy again.
[2002-03-16 17:15:00] café by the train station entrance | I licked the edge of the rolling paper to seal the cigarette and lit it. I watched Karl standing there holding two coffee cups while the waitress called the next customer. I saw the next customer was a long-haired man in his fifties wearing a coat resembling a South American poncho. I noticed the café smelled of light brown tobacco and fresh coffee.
[2002-03-16 17:16:00] train station entrance café | I observed that Karl didn't look like a boxer at all; he avoided eye contact and seemed restless, as if wanting to keep moving without pause.
[2002-03-16 17:17:00] train station entrance café | I watched him approach with two cups of coffee, pull out a chair, and sit down. I heard him ask, 'So you're moving to Halvik then?' I replied, 'Looks that way.' Looking at him, I couldn't help but smile.
[2002-03-16 17:18:00] train station entrance café | I watched him grip the handle of his cup, blow on the coffee, and take a sip. I heard him exclaim, 'Thank goodness. I've always hoped someone from Leivik who cares about literature would move here.' I noticed that while speaking, his eyes remained fixed on the tabletop, never meeting mine.
[2002-03-16 17:20:00] train station entrance café | I told him, 'That summer you went to Uppsala, I wrote you a long letter but never sent it—it's still sealed to this day.' I heard him cry out in surprise, 'You're kidding! Don't open it—leave it as frozen time.' I knew that letter was written by me during the summer of 1989. I realized I no longer remembered what I had written in that letter.
[2002-03-16 17:21:00] train station entrance café | I nodded at him in response to his words. I told him, 'I burned all the diaries and manuscripts I wrote during that period.' I heard him ask in disbelief, 'Burned? Not just thrown away—but actually burned?' He then remarked that I was still very dramatic when I left for Baysang, but when I challenged him, he denied being that way himself. I realized I could no longer recall a single thing from that period.
[2002-03-16 17:25:00] train station entrance café | I tapped the ash from my cigarette into the ashtray, glancing at him roughly every now and then. I heard him laugh heartily and ask, 'Do you know Halvik at all?' I shook my head and told him, 'Not really—I've only been here a few hours.' I saw the door opening and closing, cigarette smoke gently swirling in the air currents. I noticed Karl’s gaze was dull and filled with sadness, yet his expression appeared cheerful and shy. I found that the impression he gave had nothing to do with his actual face.
[2002-03-16 17:30:00] train station entrance café | I heard Karl launch into a lengthy critique of Mochengdao, saying it was cold as ice and that there was an unbreakable 'yellow line' between people. He contrasted the sloppiness of Leivik scholars with the neatness of Mochengdao's academic circles, and complained that nobody here cared about Leivik. Following the direction of his nod, I saw orderly crowds standing on the escalator. I knew that in Mochengdao, people stand on the right side of the escalator while those walking use the left. I thought such an extremely rule-bound social environment could indeed drive a person mad.
[2002-03-16 17:35:00] train station entrance café | I watched Karl bring the coffee cup to his lips and take a small sip. I heard him continue talking about how everyone here lives neatly and publicly, mentioning that the poor, the rich, and the mentally ill are all assigned to specific zones. I didn’t know what to say. My intuition told me these smooth, fluent words were more like a prepared speech born of frustration. I felt he could say whatever he wanted—I didn’t really care.
[2002-03-16 17:40:00] train station entrance café | I heard Karl contrasting the cultural differences between the two places—he said Leivik undervalued intellect and prized sports, whereas Mochengdao revered intellect and strictly separated popular culture from elite culture. He brought up the example of the talkative Leivik bus driver to illustrate how strongly Mochengdao people identify with their social roles. I knew he was describing the vast gap between Leivik and Mochengdao in terms of social roles and cultural perception.
[2002-03-16 17:45:00] train station entrance café | I stubbed out my cigarette paper, finished the last sip of coffee, put on my coat, slung my backpack over my shoulder, and followed him into the station hall. I asked him, 'Then why do you live here?' I heard him answer with a wandering gaze, 'It's a perfect country—as long as you want to be left alone. I despise it, yet I benefit from it.' Then he suggested, 'Shall we go?' I responded, 'Yeah, let's go.'
[2002-03-16 17:46:00] train station hall | I walked around to his other side as he had suggested. I noticed that he walked with his feet slightly turned outward, like a duck's, which reminded me of a former ballet-dancing girlfriend. I heard him turn his head and say to me, "Could you walk on that side? I can't hear well with this ear." I realized this gait was just like that of a ballet dancer.
[2002-03-16 17:50:00] underground plaza of the train station | I pointed down to show him where the bag was, then followed him toward the stairs. I observed the behavior of the people around us, feeling it wasn't any different from those at Bergen Central Station. I heard him ask, "Where is your bag?" I replied, "Down there, then turn right." I thought that the subtle differences Karl mentioned were probably only noticeable after years of wandering.
[2002-03-16 17:51:00] underground plaza of the train station | I saw him glance at me and give that smug 'I-know-more-than-you' smirk. I said to him, "This place looks quite like Leivik—like encountering another version of Leivik." I heard him laugh in response, "We'll see." I realized how intolerable I found that kind of superior 'I-know-better' attitude.
[2002-03-16 17:52:00] underground plaza of the train station | I stopped and pointed up at the electronic bulletin board above us. I explained to Karl that seeing place names like Uppsala, Gothenburg, and Nynäshamn on the timetable filled me with an exotic charm. I told him, "This is why I came here. This is exactly why." I saw the signboard continuously flashing the names of various Mochengdao towns. I found the incredibly similar yet subtly different variations between Mochengdao and Leivik irresistibly fascinating.
[2002-03-16 17:53:00] underground plaza of the train station | I watched him stare at me in disbelief, then burst out laughing. We continued walking forward. I heard him laugh and say, "You're crazy." I kept explaining the cultural differences behind these similar landscapes, mentioning comparisons between rural Japan, rural Maine in the United States, and Leivik. I asked him, "Do you get what I mean?" He answered, "No, but I'm listening." I felt completely surprised by my own words, but I realized I needed to find a reason for myself to stay.
locations: train station hall near the circular railing
café by the train station entrance
underground plaza of the train station

text:
[2002-03-16 17:55:00] locker room / subway platform | We entered the underground plaza, I pulled two bags from the lockers, and Karl helped carry one. Then we walked together toward the subway platform a few hundred meters away. I saw the underground plaza still bustling with people.
[2002-03-16 18:25:00] Vestertorp Street | Half an hour later, we walked through the center of Vestertorp. I looked at the shops and buildings along the street, occasionally catching glimpses of distant mountains and lakes. I heard subway station announcements weaving through Karl's conversation. I heard Karl talk nonstop all along the way about everything we saw. Unfamiliar yet beautiful station names rang in my ears: Slussen, Liljeholmen, Telefonplan… I saw streetlights illuminating the March darkness, and the buildings were square brick structures from the 1950s. Many windows glowed with light. I knew this place was called Vestertorp, a well-preserved suburban town.
[2002-03-16 18:30:00] outside Karl Larsdal's door | I followed him through a gate and climbed the stairs into the apartment. I saw neat bookshelves on the wall and a row of tightly hung jackets. I heard him point at a house by the roadside and say, "Here we are." I smelled the scent of someone else’s life lived here.
[2002-03-16 18:31:00] Karl Larsdal's living room | I saw a woman sitting behind a desk in the room to the left look up, pencil in hand. I stepped forward. I heard Karl greet Kristina and introduce me. Kristina smiled and said, "So happy to meet you—I've heard so much about you!" I responded, "I'm actually embarrassed—I haven't really heard much about you, though I've seen a little in Karl's books."
[2002-03-16 18:35:00] Karl Larsdal's apartment | I followed Karl as he showed me around the apartment, watching him open a glass cabinet to display his book collection. Kristina brought us coffee. I saw the apartment had two rooms, each with floor-to-ceiling bookshelves. Karl's books were arranged with extreme precision, as if measured with a ruler, sorted by series and author. I learned that one room served as the living room and Kristina's workspace, while the other was both bedroom and Karl's study.
[2002-03-16 18:40:00] Karl Larsdal's bedroom | I looked at Karl, and he smiled back. I said to him, "You're very organized, I can see that." I heard him reply that everything in his life was planned. I remarked, "That sounds scary." He countered that meeting someone like me, who says something one day and moves in the next, was even scarier. I responded, "I had to."
[2002-03-16 18:45:00] Karl Larsdal's bedroom | I listened to Karl speaking and shook my head at him. I heard Karl quote lines from Ibsen’s plays, talking about hope and necessity. He mentioned Beckett’s opinion on that play and asked if I’d read it. I replied, "I haven’t read a single one of his historical dramas." I knew he was discussing Ibsen's *Emperor and Galilean*. I found myself drawn to the past era he described, one connected through ideas.
[2002-03-16 18:50:00] Karl Larsdal's bedroom | I saw him gesturing wildly as he spoke, and I shook my head at him. I heard him passionately argue how Ibsen rehabilitated Catiline and compared him to Quisling. He asked if I remembered Bjørnson’s *King Sigurd the Bad*, and I answered, "I don’t know anything about Bjørnson." I knew he was discussing the philosophical theme of actor versus observer, referencing works by Schiller, Kleist, and others.
[2002-03-16 18:55:00] Karl Larsdal's bedroom | I noticed that after this silence, he broke the stillness by speaking up. I heard him say he was probably more of an observer, and asked for my opinion. I answered simply, "Observer." Then I heard him say that I was in Baysang yesterday and here today—perhaps this was a way of deciding things by just letting them happen. The room fell into a silence. I realized that coming here hadn’t been the result of any deliberate action on my part, but rather felt like being driven by fate.
[2002-03-16 19:00:00] Karl Larsdal's bedroom | I heard him remark how strange it was, and mention that the boxer in his writing possessed astonishing presence, yet lost all memory because he refused to remember the pain of heavy blows. He pointed out that the life of reflection and the life of action were two different forms, calling it the old dilemma that haunts every observer.
[2002-03-16 19:05:00] Karl Larsdal's kitchen | I saw Kristina peek her head into the room. Then Karl and I walked into the kitchen and sat down at the table, looking out the window. I heard Kristina ask if we wanted coffee, and I said, "Yes." I asked what she had been drawing, and she told me she was sketching shoe designs for a small shoe factory in northern Mochengdao. I saw the empty road beneath the streetlights outside the window. The absurdity of sitting in the kitchen of a suburban town with two strangers suddenly struck me, and I silently asked myself: What am I doing here?
[2002-03-16 19:30:00] Karl Larsdal's living room | I sat in the living room, watching Kristina begin to prepare dinner. I heard myself telling Karl about Tonje and my life in Baysang. I also heard him summarize his experiences over the past thirteen years, especially his literary quarrels in the *Mochengdao Daily*, and even his joke about wanting to pee on the gates of Uppsala Castle. I learned that he had left Baysang thirteen years ago. I realized I loved hearing him talk about those rebellious episodes from the past most of all.
[2002-03-16 20:30:00] Karl Larsdal's kitchen | I wolfed down minced lamb burgers and fried potatoes like a starving animal; my plate emptied quickly. We drank some alcohol, and I nodded along at them. I heard Kristina apologize, and I responded with a counter-apology. We talked about the differences between Mochengdao and Leivik. I secretly thought that neither Mochengdao nor Leivik was really as they described, but I went along with them anyway. I realized Kristina and I were the same kind of person.
[2002-03-16 23:00:00] Karl Larsdal's living room | I smoothed out the sheet, preparing to sleep on the sofa in the living room, staring at Karl’s face. I tried hard to keep his features fixed in my sight. It was now around eleven at night, and I could feel my eyes struggling to stay open. I noticed his face suddenly looked completely different, then shifted back to normal—this confused me.
[2002-03-16 23:05:00] Karl Larsdal's living room | I tucked the last edge of the sheet under the mattress, then sat down on the sofa. I noticed my hands were trembling uncontrollably. I thought in alarm: What’s going on?
[2002-03-16 23:10:00] Karl Larsdal's living room | I watched him turn his head toward me and sit down on the other side of the table. I heard him say that my novel had left an unforgettable and shocking impression on him. Puzzled, I asked, "Why do you say that?" I noticed his face had changed back to the way it looked when I first saw him at the central station.
[2002-03-16 23:15:00] Karl Larsdal's living room | I heard him comment that I had gone too far—so far it was unbelievable. He remarked that only I had truly followed through on the idea of becoming a writer, but this extreme distance frightened him, and he said he would never go that far. I saw him sitting there with a smiling face.
[2002-03-16 23:16:00] Karl Larsdal's living room | I pressed on, "What do you mean? What do you mean I've gone too far?" I argued that it was just an ordinary novel. But I heard him insist that I had revealed horrifying things about myself—it wasn't just the story of that thirteen-year-old boy. I realized he was genuinely frightened by what I had written.
[2002-03-16 23:20:00] Karl Larsdal's living room | I stared into his eyes. I felt a chill inside and said, "I don't quite understand what you're talking about—I made it up." But then I heard him laugh and remind me that in Baysang, I had told him about that affair, comparing myself to Lieutenant Gran, and about my time as a teacher in North Leivik with a thirteen-year-old student. I knew he was referring to what happened after I returned from North Leivik the previous summer.
[2002-03-16 23:21:00] Karl Larsdal's living room | I forced a weak smile and said, "Well, that's not really funny either." I heard him drop his smile and ask if I didn't remember, pointing out that the party scene described in the novel was exactly as I had once described it to him, and he marveled that I had actually written it down.
[2002-03-16 23:25:00] Karl Larsdal's living room | I looked at him, feeling deeply shaken. I heard him ask what was wrong, saying I looked like I'd seen a ghost. I shot back, "You're not serious, are you? You actually believed what I said?" But he answered firmly, "Yes, I did. That's exactly how you put it. It's etched in my memory." Still, I insisted it wasn't true.
[2002-03-16 23:30:00] Karl Larsdal's living room | I felt a piercing pain, as if pierced by countless arrows. I couldn't understand why he would say such a thing. Inside, I frantically denied it, convinced I could never have buried and forgotten such a significant truth. It was utterly unimaginable to me.
[2002-03-16 23:31:00] Karl Larsdal's living room | I watched him stand up, look at me, and shake his head with a faint smile. I heard him say, "I'm sorry, Grete, but you really did say it." Dazed, I replied, "I don't understand, but you don't seem to be lying." Finally, I heard him wish me a good night’s sleep, and I responded, "You too."
[2002-03-16 23:40:00] Karl Larsdal's living room | I lay awake on the sofa, staring into the depths of the room. I heard the rustling sounds of the couple undressing and getting into bed in their bedroom. The room was filled with dim light seeping in from the streetlamps outside. Occasionally, I caught the low groan of a subway passing hundreds of meters away, and the distant highway roared like the ocean. His words had pierced me like a thousand arrows, leaving a dull ache throughout my body. I tried to find a solution, but intense emotions were accusing me from within.
[2002-03-17 01:00:00] Karl Larsdal's living room | I remembered waking up once in a shelter, with police suspecting me of breaking in and stealing money, and I insisted it wasn't me. I knew that during my time in the north, I often drank myself into oblivion, losing entire nights of memory. I learned I sometimes woke up wearing clothes that weren’t mine, or found myself sleeping on rooftops or under shrubs. Though I refused to accept Karl's accusation, I realized there were indeed huge black holes in my memory. I felt overwhelming guilt over my past recklessness, and this uncertainty made it impossible for me to deny his claims with a clear conscience.
[2002-03-17 02:00:00] Karl Larsdal's living room | I know I've been with Toneye for eight years now, married for six. Until yesterday, we still shared the same bed. I'm thinking about my relationship with Toneye, wondering whether our life together has truly ended or if it's just a temporary pause. I realize she's still the person closest to me, yet I have no idea what I truly want.
[2002-03-17 03:00:00] Karl Larsdal's living room | I lie on the sofa, closing and then opening my eyes again. I stare at that shifting face. I feel a face appear behind the glass door of the balcony, then vanish. Then more faces emerge in hallucination, noses turning into beaks, eyes becoming those of birds of prey. I am now in the suburbs of Hårvik, a place where I don't know a single soul. I feel inner chaos and unease. I sense this uncertainty is defining who I am. I notice an eagle perched inside my chest, glaring fiercely.

text:
I spent the entire summer with her in Halvik—swimming, wandering, reading. I became deeply absorbed in Hölderlin’s poems. There were no secrets between us. Sunlight bathed our entire holiday. I felt a resonance between the poetic realm and the joy within me. It was high summer in 2002. I knew this state might not last forever. I felt an absolute sensation in the core of my being—a fusion of fire and ice. Though I sensed potential threats from the future, I chose to pretend ignorance and savor the present.
[2002-07-20 08:00:00] Nils Nils's bedroom | One morning I was in the shower when I heard her calling me. I stepped out, entered the bedroom, and lay down beside her. We gazed at the sky together. I gripped her hand tightly. I heard her say, 'Look, can you see that cloud?' I answered that I could. She burst into laughter and said, 'Everything is perfect. I’m so happy to be with you!' I replied, 'Me too.' I saw a clear blue sky outside the window, with only one heart-shaped white cloud drifting slowly closer. The bed had been moved next to the window.
I came out of the bathroom dripping wet and entered the bedroom. She was lying naked on the bed by the window. I lay down beside her and took her hand. She laughed joyfully. She pointed at the single cloud in the sky and asked me about it. I confirmed what she saw. Then I heard her declare that everything felt perfectly complete. I echoed her happiness. Before my eyes stretched a vast, cloudless blue sky, with one solitary cloud shaped like a heart. Sunlight slanted across the bed.

I marveled at the pure joy we shared then, as if we had returned to childhood.

text:
[2002-08-20 22:00:00] Hårvik | I got into a black taxi and wandered through different bars and cafés across the city. I felt how bright and open the summer night was, as if sky and earth had merged into one. I noticed how the thick darkness eventually solidified into a wall, and morning rose. I realized the shifting light of the summer night was nearly indescribable in reality, like a dream impossible to retell. I knew the summer of 2002 was filled with endless drinking and late-night wanderings.
I rode the black taxi through Hårvik’s nightscape, sometimes alone, sometimes with friends. I let myself drown in waves of alcohol. Before my eyes lay Hårvik’s intensely bright summer nights, with light drifting everywhere. I felt the night shift from lightness to density, until finally it hardened. I knew it was the summer of 2002, and those daylight-bright nights left a deep impression on me. I inwardly lamented that once those radiant nights had passed, trying to recount them in words always felt so futile.
[2002-08-25 16:00:00] Mother's house in Årstad | I heard myself confessing to my mother about Nils Nils. I heard her say disapprovingly that I couldn’t date others because I only ever saw myself. She even compared me to my father, saying he could instantly see through people while I never could. I heard myself reply, 'Yes, maybe I can’t.' I knew it was August 2002, and I was visiting my mother in Årstad. I realized this was the first time my mother had ever gotten angry at me. Though her words surprised me, I didn’t think they mattered much.
[2002-08-25 16:30:00] Mother's house in Årstad | I was certain my mother was right, but I didn’t care. What surprised me was that she placed the detestable father above me—and was actually angry with me. I realized that back then, immersed in passionate love, I must have appeared to her utterly radiant.
[2002-09-10 10:00:00] Bastugatan apartment | I sat every day in the apartment writing, trying to introduce the theme of angels into the story about the maternity ward. I watched Nils Nils ride her bike to school each morning. I learned that in September 2002, Nils Nils began foundation courses at the drama school. I knew I was struggling with a novel about a maternity ward in 1944. I realized the text I was writing felt distant and false, but I didn’t mind—because the only focus in my life was Nils Nils.
I sat at the desk on Bastugatan, struggling page after page, though progress in my writing was poor, I kept going anyway. I knew Nils Nils was undergoing intense training at the drama school. At the time, I was developing the story of Lena Jorgensdatter’s ancestors. I found myself unable to grasp that story—the sense of falseness troubled me—but as long as I thought of Nils Nils, everything else became irrelevant.
[2002-09-22 12:00:00] Oscar Café | Nils Nils and I sat outside Oscar Café. I was eating a club sandwich while watching her eat chicken salad. I noticed several sparrows hopping and pecking at the still-untouched plates. I felt the Sunday quiet along the street. I heard church bells ringing below for worship. [2002-11-28 22:10:00] Vesder apartment | I hesitated in the darkness by the door, looking at her, then I turned around. I asked her if she thought she could do whatever she wanted. I heard her apologizing over and over, pleading for me to stay that night. Finally, I said, 'Alright, I'll stay tonight. But I'm still leaving.' I heard her whisper a quiet thank you.
[2002-11-29 07:00:00] Roof of old house on Bastugatan | Early the next morning, I returned to my old apartment without breakfast. I took a cup of coffee up to the rooftop terrace and sat smoking. I sat high up, overlooking the entire city. I sat on the terrace, deep in thought, convinced in my heart that I could no longer be with her—we were truly finished.
[2002-11-29 12:00:00] Bridge/Path outside Nordic Museum | I called Karl Larsdal and arranged to meet him on Djurgården, then we met up on the bridge outside the Nordic Museum. We walked along a path covered in fallen leaves. I heard Karl suggest that I follow my feelings. I told him I didn’t know what I was feeling. But he insisted, 'You must know.' I saw the brick-gray sky, the path beneath my feet littered with yellow, red, and brown leaves. I felt the desolation emanating from the leafless trees. I felt so ashamed about the argument that I didn’t mention the slap at all. I was deeply conflicted, unsure of what to do.
[2002-11-29 14:00:00] Halviken | I felt two powerful emotions warring inside me. One warned that if I didn’t leave, I would lose my freedom and independence as a writer; the other reminded me that she was the only one who truly knew who I was, the only one who gave me a sense of belonging. I realized these two forces were pulling me apart, but that day, the urge to leave prevailed.
[2002-11-29 18:30:00] Inside subway car / Outside Vesder apartment | I arrived at Nils Nils’s apartment. Though I had a key, I still rang the doorbell. I saw her open the door and look me over with a cautious smile. On the subway, I received her call and heard her ask if I wanted to come home for crab. I replied, 'Okay, we need to talk anyway.'
[2002-11-29 19:10:00] Dining table at Vesder apartment | I followed her to the table. I heard her ask if I was hungry. I told her I was starving. She said dinner would be ready soon. I saw the dining table below the window, covered with a white cloth, the flames of three candles flickering in the draft. On the table lay crabs, white bread, and butter.
[2002-11-29 19:20:00] Dining table at Vesder apartment | I began pulling off crab legs and cracking open shells. I saw her opening a bottle of wine. I passed her a plate of crab meat. I heard her admit she wasn’t very good with crabs and asked if I knew how to open them. I asked what she’d been doing today and heard her say she had visited Siv Inge and told her about hitting me.
[2002-11-29 19:40:00] Vesder apartment dining table | I heard her gaze at me and ask, 'Can you forgive me?' I replied that of course I could. But then I questioned her why she had lost control like that.
[2002-11-29 19:45:00] Vesder apartment dining table | I saw her pressing the crab shell onto a slice of bread, trying to pry out the meat with a knife. I noticed her eyes becoming moist. I heard her apologizing to me repeatedly. She explained that because it was I who first brought up having a child, when I later said we should put it on hold, it hit her too hard and made her completely lose control.
[2002-11-29 20:00:00] Vesder apartment dining table | I heard her ask if I understood how she felt, and I nodded and said yes. But I told her very seriously that I couldn't tolerate her lashing out at me and physically striking me. I heard her promise me she would learn to control herself from now on. I realized we couldn't become enemies—this kind of extreme conflict had drained all my energy.
[2002-11-29 20:30:00] Vesder apartment dining table | I paused mid-speech and lowered my head to eat. I heard her ask me with a smile if it tasted good. I replied that it really was delicious. I tasted the reddish-brown crab meat on the bread, feeling the sea saltiness, the sweetness of mayonnaise, and the tang of lemon blend together in my mouth. I fell into thought. Though I still wanted to have a child with her—and that desire had never felt more certain—I began asking myself whether this certainty was worth paying any price for.
locations: Roof of old house on Bastugatan
Inside subway car / Outside Vesder apartment

text:
[2002-12-05 19:00:00] restaurant | I introduced my mother to Nils Nils. I sat in the restaurant, watching their interaction. I saw Nils Nils shine brightly—cheerful and open—and this made me feel that everything was going smoothly.
[2002-12-05 22:00:00] Bastu Street apartment building entrance | I escorted my mother to the apartment building entrance. After watching her walk inside, I immediately turned and ran toward Nils Nils's apartment. I said goodnight to my mother.
[2002-12-06 09:00:00] cafe | The next morning, I picked up my mother for breakfast. I heard my mother complain that it took her an hour to get in last night because the hallway light kept turning off automatically. I told her it was Mochengdao’s energy-saving automatic timer switch. I laughed at her, saying she always did this—didn’t see the lit switch and mistook it for an alarm. She asked me about the lighter, and I smiled and asked her back.
[2002-12-06 09:30:00] cafe | I heard my mother remark that little details were always different in a foreign land. She asked what I thought of Nils Nils and praised her as a lovely girl. I casually responded, 'Yeah, sure.'
[2002-12-06 10:00:00] cafe | I knew Tonje had once been part of our family, and my family still held affection for her. I learned that my mother hadn’t hidden away those wedding photos and albums. I actually understood that my mother would surely like Nils Nils. But deep down, I sensed she and Henrik Inge probably still felt regret over Tonje’s departure.
[2002-12-20 20:00:00] Bastu Street / street | I heard her ask me about my Christmas plans. I told her I’d be returning to Ålhus to stay with my mother, and she offered to come along. I heard us then erupt into a heated argument. I insisted it was still too early to bring her back home. I saw snowflakes swirling through the city sky. I saw white streets and rooftops, and felt how every movement had softened.
[2002-12-20 22:00:00] Bishop's Crest Bar | I sat with her in the bar, silently drinking beer. Later, I handed her the plane ticket to Paris as a surprise. Then we went to the airport together. I learned that we were going to stay in Paris for a week. I wanted to use this trip to make up for our previous argument.
[2002-12-28 19:00:00] Paris restaurant | I noticed that during dinner in Paris, the male waiter’s every move flustered me, while Nils Nils merely cast a contemptuous glance. I heard her shouting at me incessantly, accusing me of not loving her, not wanting her, insisting that nothing would ever come of us. I felt utterly desperate, realizing her anxiety had flared up and turned irrational. I asked myself inwardly what kind of situation I had gotten myself into, and where my life was heading. I thought about going shopping, but then abandoned the idea, thinking of her hatred for it and her fear of being alone.
[2002-12-30 14:00:00] Eiffel Tower/Cemetery | I watched as we visited the Eiffel Tower together, then went to see one of Nils Nils’s girlfriends who lived in Paris. Afterward, we also paid our respects at the cemetery where Marcel Proust was buried. I sensed the Eiffel Tower exuding a strong nineteenth-century aura. I also noticed that although the day started well, Nils Nils’s mood would suddenly plunge into a black abyss.
[2002-12-31 23:00:00] Paris restaurant/Seine riverside | I saw us walking into an elegant and cozy restaurant on New Year’s Eve, receiving a string of compliments. An hour after the new year began, I held Nils Nils’s hand and walked back to the hotel along the Seine riverside. The atmosphere in the restaurant was elegant and warm; the night along the Seine gave me a long-missed sense of peace. I remembered this restaurant had been recommended by my good friend Helen Sterne from Baysang. I felt that in this moment, we were glowing, as if we had returned to the beautiful days of the past.
[2003-01-03 10:00:00] Paris airport | I realized that no matter how much stress the trip to Paris had caused her, as soon as we arrived at the airport to head home, the burden in my heart simply vanished.
[2003-01-10 10:00:00] Warehouse/New office space | In early January, I moved all my books to a warehouse outside the city, cleaned the apartment, and returned the keys. Following Cora’s advice, I secured a shared workspace in a castle-like building atop a hill on the Slussen side, and began going there to work every day. I am on the top floor of the workspace, situated so high that the view extends over the hills of Slussen. I knew my landlady was selling the house. I learned that Nils Nils was helping me look for office space.
[2003-01-15 09:00:00] Workspace | I tried writing over a hundred pages on a new document. I bought a cheap picture book and began writing a story about a shepherd boy secretly watching angels walk through the forest. I noticed three angels dressed in sixteenth-century clothing strolling through the Italian countryside in the picture book. I realized this was a new beginning—I had seized upon the theme of angels. Although I felt the story of angels living at the edge of human memory was traceable, I began to worry about where the story should go next.
[2003-01-15 17:00:00] Workspace | I realized this angel story had nothing to do with me—it contained no traces of my own life. I felt unable to enter into it, let alone control it. I even mocked myself inwardly—since that was the case, why not just write 'Ghost and the Skull Cave'? I kept asking myself: where is the story?
[2003-01-20 10:00:00] Workspace kitchen | I carried out meaningless work day after day in the workspace. I stood in the kitchen waiting for the coffee machine to finish. I noticed the man cleaning the toilet was a Black man. I heard myself accidentally use the word 'nigger,' and then heard one of my co-working partners immediately correct me on the spot. I learned that everyone in this shared writing space carried an overly abundant form of radical leftist kindness. I realized I had no choice but to continue this meaningless work. When I saw the janitor, I was so startled I couldn’t speak.
[2003-01-25 09:00:00] Workspace | One morning when I arrived at the workspace, I saw police questioning people inside the building. I watched as everyone sat down to discuss the break-in. I heard my companions speculate it must have been an inside job. When I mentioned it might have been those drug addicts downstairs who stole the keys, I heard one of them say sternly, 'You can't say that.' I learned that two break-ins had occurred here, and computers and camera equipment had been stolen. Looking at his self-righteous expression, I felt deeply shocked. I realized that due to political correctness in language, they would rather cover reality with a net than face possible injustice and prejudice.
[2003-01-25 10:00:00] office | I saw that group of drug users hanging around the stairwell all the time, and I was certain they'd do anything for money. I heard the other side argue that this was prejudice, insisting that drug users should be given a chance. I heard myself verbally admit uncertainty, yet inwardly I was deeply shocked. I knew those people indeed had criminal records. I realized this was exactly the Mochengdao society Karl Larsdal had once described to me. I felt this wasn't just prejudice—it was damn well the truth. Suddenly, I missed Karl in Baghdad terribly.
[2003-02-10 10:00:00] Halvik | I remembered Jorgensen once telling me he would never go back to Leivik. I learned that Jorgensen was coming over by car. I knew he had written a novel, *Zalup*, which meant a great deal to me. I recalled the radical, uncompromising ideas in that book, and its unique linguistic style. I realized I absolutely loved that kind of singular, self-contained originality.
[2003-02-15 00:00:00] Halvik | I knew that after living in Halvik for over half a year, everything had changed. I felt filled with resentment; the claustrophobia brought on by love made me long to leave. Yet I realized I was too weak—I couldn’t bear to leave her out of pity, and I knew deep down I still loved her.

[2003-02-20 13:00:00] Film Building/Café/Gnesta | I saw us sitting in the sunlight of the Film Building eating lunch, or talking endlessly in apartments and cafés. I followed her to her mother’s house in Gnesta, stepping into that quiet forest. I heard us discussing our lives, past and present, and the various people around us. I felt the sunlight in the Film Building was wonderfully warm. The forest exuded a hushed stillness. I felt Nils Nils pulling me out from my deeply buried inner world. I noticed that in the forest, she sometimes seemed like a fragile little girl. I realized all my feelings had become far more intense than before.
[2003-02-23 19:00:00] Siv Ingrid's apartment | I took Nils Nils to Siv Ingrid’s thirtieth birthday party. I found a corner to sit, chatting with a peace organization leader and her engineer husband. I drank several bottles of beer, then found a bottle of aquavit and started guzzling it. I saw the one-room apartment in South Malmo packed with people, and felt the air growing somewhat stale as night fell. I felt the alcohol making me feel stronger. I realized that as I got drunker, the figures around me began to blur.
[2003-02-23 23:00:00] Siv Ingrid's apartment/Street | I was very drunk, started crumpling napkins into balls and throwing them at people nearby. I rambled on incessantly, dumping every thought in my head. I watched as Nils Nils forcibly dragged me out. I tried to protest, but she pulled hard, and finally I stumbled outside, putting on my coat. I heard myself laughing uncontrollably, spouting what I thought were witty nonsense. I thought the atmosphere felt warm and cozy. I realized that although I’d tried hard to please everyone, I had clearly failed.
[2003-02-23 23:10:00] South Malmo street | I walked along the streets of South Malmo, watching Nils Nils raging at me. I noticed that all the other twenty-odd guests had left completely sober. I heard her scolding me for humiliating her in front of her best friend, accusing me of having lost all self-control. I also heard myself confusedly asking what was going on—after all, I thought, it was just a party. I learned that Mochengdao’s party culture demanded that everyone leave as dignified as they arrived. I realized I was utterly out of step with their customs. I felt her deep embarrassment and dissatisfaction toward me.
[2003-02-23 23:20:00] South Malmo street | I stared at Nils Nils, and my own temper exploded. I screamed at her and began cursing. I heard myself shrieking that she was utterly despicable, accusing her of trying to control me. I shouted, 'Now I’m leaving you, goddammit—you’ll never see me again!' I felt that due to drunkenness, I had no bottom line left inside. I just wanted to escape from this suffocating grip.
[2003-02-23 23:30:00] lawn near Vesder station | I yanked my hand free from hers and ran off. I strode across the street straight toward Vesder station. I charged forward without looking back. I heard her running after me, urging me to talk tomorrow. I shouted back, 'I never want to see you again!' Her voice calling my name from outside the apartment echoed in my ears. I felt an extreme sense of finality; the alcohol made this anger unstoppable.
[2003-02-24 04:00:00] Halvik Central Station | I crossed the old town, storming furiously toward the central station. I stared at the illegible letters on the bulletin board. I entered the station and found a bench deep inside, lying down on it. I felt snow falling outside, the cold biting through. I noticed the lights in the station wavering slightly in my vision. I learned there was a train to Bærleng around four in the morning. I knew it was now four o'clock. I told myself the plan was simple: take the train and leave, never come back. I felt the fire inside me even made me ignore the cold.
[2003-02-24 04:10:00] Halvik Central Station bench | I lay down on the bench and slowly drifted off to sleep. My last thought was: when I wake up, I must not hesitate—I have to follow through with this decision to leave Halvik, no matter how sober I am by then.
[2003-02-24 08:00:00] Halvik Central Station | I felt a security guard shaking my shoulder. I slowly sat up and finally got myself steady. I heard the guard say, 'You can't sleep here.' I replied that I was waiting for a train. Then I heard him suggest I go home, and I answered, 'Okay.' I noticed it was just past eight o'clock, and the station was already crowded with people.
[2003-02-24 08:10:00] Subway/Vesder apartment door | I staggered into the subway passage and climbed into the carriage. I got off at Vesder station, returned to the apartment, and knocked on the door. I felt extremely heavy-headed, and everything in front of me was swaying. I noticed that all around me were streams of commuters. I realized I hadn't sobered up yet. Right now, my only thought was to find a place to sleep—nothing else mattered.
[2003-02-24 08:30:00] Vesder apartment | Through the glass door, I saw Nils Nils running toward me. She opened her arms and hugged me. I pushed her aside and rushed into the room, stripped off my clothes, and crawled under the covers. I heard her say, 'Oh, you're back—I was so scared.' She asked me where I had gone. I answered that I went to the central station and had intended to take a train back to Leivik. I shouted at her, 'Leave me alone for a while—don't wake me up.' I could feel her fear inside, but right now I just wanted to escape reality and sleep.
[2003-02-24 18:00:00] Vesder apartment | I slept the entire day. When I woke up, I saw Nils Nils sitting in the kitchen chair reading a book. I heard her say, 'Okay,' and ask what I'd like to eat after waking up. I noticed it was already completely dark outside. The desk lamp in the room was tilted, casting a soft glow over her.
