[2003-02-24 18:10:00] Vesder apartment kitchen | I walked into the kitchen, poured myself a glass of water, and drank it all in one go. I saw her put the book on the armrest and stand up. I heard her ask, 'Hey, how are you?' I replied, 'Fine, as long as I'm not angry.' Then I heard her apologize for last night, and I responded, 'Me too.'
[2003-02-24 18:20:00] Vesder apartment living room | I refilled my cup with water and sat down at the table. I watched Nils Nils come over and turn on the ceiling light. I asked her if she remembered the first time we met in this room. I told her that when she said she 'liked' me, I felt offended because in Leivik language, 'like' sounds so weak. I explained that I really thought she only had slight feelings for me. I realized that the word 'like' in Mochengdao language means the same thing as 'love' in Leivik language.
[2003-02-24 18:30:00] Vesder apartment living room | I asked her if she remembered our first meeting in this room. I told her that when she said she 'liked' me, I felt offended because in Leivik language, 'like' sounds so weak. I explained that I truly believed she only had a little affection for me. I realized that the word 'like' in Mochengdao language carries the same weight as 'love' in Leivik language.
[2003-02-24 18:40:00] Vesder apartment living room | I saw her give me a faint smile, then lower her head and stare at the tabletop. I heard her tell me that she had summoned all her courage to confess to me, but my coldness afterward left her utterly disheartened when she walked away.
[2003-02-24 18:50:00] Vesder apartment living room | I said to her, 'But we're here now.' I sternly told her she couldn't command me what to do, or else I would leave her. I emphasized this applied to drinking and everything else. I heard her whisper, 'I know.'
[2003-02-24 19:00:00] Vesder apartment kitchen | I walked into the kitchen, poured the meatballs into the frying pan, and started boiling water for noodles. I noticed that Nils Nils had followed me into the kitchen. I asked her, "We still have meatballs in the fridge, right? I'm starving." I heard the sound of butter melting in the hot pan. I felt a momentary sense of peace.
[2003-02-24 19:10:00] Vesder apartment kitchen | I heard myself say, "There was nothing wrong with that summer. I mean, about drinking. You didn't mind back then, did you?" I also heard her reply, "No, it was wonderful. I'm afraid of going too far now, but I wasn't then—not with you. I felt completely safe. I'd never felt that kind of security before, and now we've moved past that stage."
[2003-02-24 19:20:00] Vesder apartment kitchen | I turned around as I spoke. I noticed the butter in the pan beginning to melt between the meatballs. I saw her shrug her shoulders. I heard myself ask, "So what stage are we in now?" I heard her respond that she didn't know either, only that it felt like something had been lost, that something had ended. She admitted she was afraid the rest might disappear too. I told her, "But you can't force me. That would be the best way to make it vanish." She murmured softly, "Of course. I know."
[2003-02-24 19:30:00] Vesder apartment kitchen | I sprinkled salt into the pot of water for the pasta. I watched her nod, then noticed she wiped tears from her face with both thumbs. I asked her, "Do you want to?"

[2003-02-25 10:00:00] Halvik | I know this man has a strong personality—stubborn yet generous, flexible yet unyielding. As far as I know, he is coming to Halvik now to visit Nils Nils and me.
[2003-02-25 14:00:00] Vesder apartment / antique bookshops / Pelican Restaurant | Around two o'clock the next day, I saw Jorgensen arrive. We browsed several antique bookshops together; I watched him examine old books on natural history. Then we went to the Pelican Restaurant for dinner and beer, staying until closing time. I felt his extraordinary presence fill the small apartment the moment he walked in.
[2003-02-25 21:00:00] Pelican Restaurant | I heard myself tell him about spending the night at the station and my decision to take the train back to Leivik. I heard him exclaim in surprise, "But I'm just arriving! Do I have to turn around and go back too?" I also said to him, "The moment I woke up, that's exactly what I thought: Jorgensen is coming. I can't fucking go home now."
[2003-02-25 23:00:00] Pelican Restaurant | I watched him burst into loud laughter. That night I drank twenty bottles of beer. I noticed an old drunk sat down at our table and seemed to get along well with Jorgensen. I felt Jorgensen laughing and occasionally nudging my shoulder. I heard him recount his bloody love affair. I heard the old drunk repeatedly complimenting me, calling me handsome, saying I was a good-looking young man. I heard Jorgensen keep trying to coax the man into telling more about his life. I thought to myself that compared to his story, mine with Nils Nils was nothing but a midsummer comedy.
[2003-02-26 02:00:00] Outside Vesder apartment | I remember us standing outside the apartment. I watched him climb into his little car and lie down on the back seat to sleep. I felt the gray, cold sky hanging over everything, saw light snowflakes swirling in the air.
[2003-03-01 10:00:00] Vesder apartment | I knew that if we wanted children, we would need a larger apartment. I learned that Nils Nils’s mother had an empty flat downtown. As far as I knew, rental agreements in Mochengdao were personal property and valid for life, but we could arrange a lease exchange. I thought this one-bedroom apartment was our arena, narrow but sufficient for now—but I realized we needed to plan for future changes.
[2003-03-15 14:00:00] Nils Nils's mother's apartment | One day, I watched as we went to see the apartment. Before me was the most bourgeois apartment I had ever seen. I saw a massive Russian marble fireplace at one end of the room, and the walls were adorned with intricately carved white paneling. I noticed the ceiling was over four meters high, and beneath my feet lay a beautiful herringbone parquet floor from the late nineteenth century. I also saw her mother’s heavy, aesthetically rich furniture from the late nineteenth century. I marveled inwardly—this was truly the most bourgeois apartment I had ever seen.
[2003-03-15 14:30:00] Nils Nils's mother's apartment | I watched us moving around the apartment. I heard myself ask, 'Can we live here?' I heard Nils Nils reply firmly, 'No, certainly not.' She remarked to me how lifeless the place felt and suggested somewhere like Sjølyst instead. I heard myself agree, 'I agree—we simply couldn't live in a place like this.' I knew that Sjølyst was a suburban satellite town populated largely by immigrants. I recalled the diversity of Sjølyst's market and felt it had far more vitality than this place.
[2003-03-15 15:00:00] Nils Nils's mother's apartment | I realized that the idea of moving in here was actually beginning to appeal to me. I remembered how I had always been drawn to the order and structure of middle-class life. Yet I also recalled that whenever I found myself in such environments, I would feel an inner resistance, as if the strange and distasteful parts of myself would be exposed.
[2003-03-15 16:00:00] Nils Nils's mother's apartment | I watched as we lay on the bed, propped up on pillows, smoking. I imagined starting a new life here with her and our child. I pictured a new happiness in a new neighborhood, and this thought overshadowed my initial impression of the apartment's lifelessness. I felt a sudden surge of enthusiasm and no doubt that our new life would begin right here.
[2003-04-25 19:00:00] Old Town American restaurant | In late April, I watched Karl Larsdal return from Iraq. We had dinner at an expensive American restaurant in the Old Town. I sensed he was extremely excited, radiating energy. I learned he spent weeks recounting his entire experience there, and gradually, even I became familiar with all the names he mentioned. I thought to myself, I had never seen him like this before.
[2003-05-05 23:00:00] Vesder apartment | In early May, I watched Nils Nils and me moving in with Anders’s help. I saw her suddenly squat down, leaning against the wall, tears welling up in her eyes. I heard her scream, 'I can't take it! I'm done!' I heard myself urge her, 'Just one more hour, at most an hour and a half. You can make it.' I also heard her suggest calling her mom, saying we didn’t need to finish everything, and that her mother could come tomorrow to help. I understood she didn’t think it would be a problem for her mother to come help.
[2003-05-05 23:10:00] Vesder apartment | I watched her grab a rag, stand up, and resume scrubbing the bathroom door frame. Then, I watched her get dressed and walk out into the night. I heard myself ask her, 'You're going to have someone else clean your house?' I scolded her, saying she couldn't call her mom every time something got tough. I heard myself say, 'I'll finish the rest—you go ahead. I'll come later.' I heard her ask in surprise, 'Really?' After I confirmed it, she said, 'Okay.'
[2003-05-06 01:00:00] Vesder apartment | I finished the remaining cleaning alone. The next day, I began moving all my books. As far as I knew, my book collection had now grown to twenty-five hundred volumes. I told myself that cleaning wasn't really such a big deal for me.
[2003-05-10 10:00:00] New apartment | I watched Anders and Karl Larsdal help me carry boxes into the elevator and the apartment. I started painting the walls. I heard them passionately cursing the moving task. I knew Nils Nils had gone to Leivik to do a radio program. As far as I knew, she would be staying with my mother, who they had only met once before. I thought about how Karl compared moving to unloading ammunition crates—a kind of physical labor that felt entirely unfamiliar to me.
[2003-05-15 20:00:00] New apartment | After she boarded the train, I watched myself call my mother. I heard myself mention taking down the wedding photo and that album. I heard my mother refuse to hide the album, saying it represented a period of her life, and she assured me Nils Nils wouldn't mind. I heard myself reply, 'Alright, you're right—it's your album. I just don't want to hurt her.' I also heard my mother reassure me that everything would be fine. I knew my mother had already taken down the wedding photo after the marriage ended. I felt uneasy about the traces left by Toneje, and inwardly worried they might hurt Nils Nils.
[2003-05-16 10:00:00] New apartment/Leivik Bålstad | I heard her describing the scenery of western Leivik over the phone, the sound of waves crashing. I heard myself tell her how cozy the big house felt now, how the rooms had been painted entirely white. I felt in my ears the dreamlike sensation of Leivik’s interwoven green, blue, and white that she described. I learned she had chosen to live with my mother, which I thought was a brave decision. I felt full of anticipation for the future. I imagined living together with her in our new home at the city center, and looked forward to the child we had decided to have.
locations: Vesder apartment / antique bookshops / Pelican Restaurant

text:
[2003-05-16 19:00:00] New apartment/Restaurant | After hanging up, I continued painting the walls. The next afternoon, I saw Olaf Ingva and Erik come by. I took everyone out to dinner and introduced them to Karl Larsdal. I sensed something strange in the atmosphere at the dinner table; I saw Karl Larsdal shut his mouth tight after being challenged by Olaf Ingva. I knew my friends were attending a seminar. As far as I knew, the two of them didn’t get along very well. I felt torn between my two friends. I realized this social performance I put on to keep things pleasant left me feeling somehow insincere inside.
[2003-05-17 10:00:00] Leivik Jølstadale Farm | I heard Nils Nils tell me she had gone with my mother to Dåle farm, where they met Sjøliug and Magne. She said the National Day celebration there felt exotic. I heard her mention seeing deer by the forest edge in the morning, and that my mother said the dolphins in the fjord were a lucky omen. I knew she had spent the whole day with my family.
[2003-05-17 15:00:00] Leivik Jølst | I heard Nils Nils say she really liked my grandmother’s sister and her husband Anfin. I heard her describe Anfin talking passionately about whaling, and how they made pancakes with penguin eggs. She also expressed concern to me about the poor audio quality of recordings of Anfin’s dialect. I recalled hearing the sound of dolphins breaking the water from a small boat in the fjord, seeing their sleek, shiny dark gray bodies. I knew dolphins weren’t commonly seen there. I learned Anfin was lively and remarkably charming. From what I understood, people from Mochengdao might have difficulty understanding him due to his heavy dialect.
[2003-05-18 20:00:00] New apartment | I watched Olaf Ingva leave. I shelved the last batch of books and threw away the remaining cardboard boxes. In the evening, Erik and I went out to eat, then came back and drank through the night. I read the text messages Nils Nils sent me. I read Nils Nils writing tenderly: 'Goodnight, my dear prince—maybe tomorrow will be a big day!' I knew Nils Nils was feeling unwell and exhausted. I understood she would be returning the next morning. As I read her increasingly passionate messages, I thought to myself that her feeling unwell might mean only one thing.
[2003-05-19 07:00:00] New apartment | At seven in the morning, I watched myself go to bed. Though dazed, I still set the alarm for nine. I prepared to go pick up Nils Nils at the station. I felt the sharp burn of alcohol blazing inside me, so intense it nearly blinded me to everything around. I realized that even though I was completely drunk, a faint awareness remained—to go meet her.
[2003-05-19 09:00:00] Street | At nine o’clock, I forced myself out of bed. I went into the bathroom and took a shower, changed into clean clothes. I shouted to Erik that I was leaving, then staggered down the stairs and out onto the street. I heard myself tell Erik we’d meet at the restaurant at twelve. I heard him reply with an acknowledgment. I felt the glaring sunlight, smelled the spring scent rising from the asphalt road. I felt drunk still—each step demanded all my willpower.
[2003-05-19 09:10:00] Store/Street | I stopped to buy a bottle of cola, drank it, then bought another. I used the store window to look at my own face. I saw how terrible I looked—puffy eyelids, bloodshot eyes. I knew her train would arrive in thirteen minutes. I inwardly lamented how exhausted I appeared. I thought, if only I could delay the pickup by three hours, I’d do anything—but I knew that was impossible.
[2003-05-19 09:20:00] Train station platform | I saw her appear on the platform, dragging her suitcase with one hand as she walked toward me. I waved and stepped forward to hug her, but I felt her pull away, then turn and walk off. I followed her silently down the platform. I heard myself say: 'Hey. I stayed up late yesterday, nothing serious.' I also heard her cold reply: 'You reek of alcohol. How could you do this to me? Did it have to be today?' I heard myself apologize, asking if it was really such a big deal, but got no answer. I saw her arrive radiant and light-footed. I felt how deeply repulsed she was by the smell of my hangover.
[2003-05-19 09:30:00] Clara Hill Viaduct/Pharmacy | On the escalator, I listened as she kept berating me. I followed her to the pharmacy. At the second pharmacy that was open, I watched her buy a pregnancy test. Then I walked beside her across the street. I heard her raging the whole way. Her voice of disgust echoed in my ears—she said she didn’t understand why she should stay with me, accused me of thinking only of myself. She shouted at me: 'Didn’t our words yesterday mean anything at all?' I felt passersby turning to stare because of her shouting. I knew it was Sunday, and many pharmacies were closed. I understood we were walking along Kabinettsgata. I felt like a dog walking beside her.
[2003-05-19 09:45:00] Cabinet Street | I walked beside her with my head down. I felt intense shame, guilt, and fear. I wanted to beg her to calm down, but realized she was justified, so I had to endure the scolding. I worried about being seen by someone I knew in this pitiful state, especially at the thought that Erik might be nearby.
[2003-05-19 10:00:00] New Apartment | I walked up the stairs and into the apartment, standing in the center of the freshly painted floor, watching her enter without even glancing at me. Before me were freshly painted walls; the whole apartment looked neat and orderly. I felt her earlier anger like a violent beating. I sensed myself as an empty shell, drifting through her life.
[2003-05-19 10:05:00] New Apartment | I was certain she was pregnant—I’d known it since the moment we made love. In my mind, I thought: Well, we’re going to have a child.
[2003-05-19 10:10:00] New Apartment | I stood in the center of the floor, turned my back so she wouldn’t see my expression, then covered my face with both hands and burst into uncontrollable sobs, crying as I moved toward the hallway. I felt the floodgates inside me suddenly open, my defenses collapsing instantly. I thought it was a profound humiliation, feeling neither like a person nor a man.
[2003-05-19 10:15:00] New Apartment | I heard her speaking behind me while I struggled to catch my breath between violent sobs. I heard her pleading behind me not to cry, saying she never meant it. I heard myself gasping out, 'Sorry, I didn't mean to.' Then I heard her say sorry too. The last thing I wanted was for her to see me cry, yet I couldn’t stop at all.
[2003-05-19 10:20:00] New Apartment Bathroom | I went into the bathroom, breathing deeply, then splashed cold water on my face several times. Through tears, I laughed and said, 'Alright, same old routine.' I heard her respond with a smile too. I felt the wave of sobbing finally recede within me.
[2003-05-19 10:30:00] New Apartment Kitchen | After leaving the bathroom, I saw her standing in the hallway and went forward to embrace her tightly. I watched her take the pregnancy test into the bathroom, and a while later, she came out and stood in the kitchen staring at the white stick. I heard her ask if I was feeling better, saying it was okay to cry. I heard myself ask if she wanted to do the test now, then pressed her in the kitchen whether anything had changed. I heard her tell me the result: 'It's positive.' I gazed into her wild, serious, dark eyes and realized our lives would change forever.
[2003-06-10 15:00:00] New Apartment Backyard | I sat in the backyard smoking and called my brother Henrik Inge. I heard Nils Nils announce the good news to her mother, and heard her burst into joyful tears. I heard my mother praise it as good news on the phone, yet mutter that we weren’t prepared. I told Henrik Inge the due date was January, and he congratulated me. I learned that after three weeks of pregnancy, we decided to share the news with our families. I thought Mom always needs time to adjust herself and adapt to such huge changes.
[2003-06-10 15:30:00] New Apartment Backyard | I lit a cigarette and sat in the backyard, gazing at the view before me, lost in thought. I found myself dissatisfied with how friends and family reacted. I realized that since moving to Mochengdao, I seemed to have grown distant from my family. I thought people often get trapped in mundane trivialities and struggle to immediately grasp life-changing events.

[2003-06-10 20:00:00] New Apartment | I crushed out the cigarette and went upstairs into the house. I watched Vidal installing the washing machine her mother had bought for us. I heard myself telling her that the family was actually very happy. I heard Henrik Inge promise over the phone to provide a stroller and all necessary baby clothes. I saw boxes of toys and bundles of baby clothes stacked around the house. I learned we could have everything we wanted for the baby. I knew her mother frequently visited, bringing meals and supplies. I saw her eyes glistening with tears of gratitude, and I felt comforted too.
[2003-06-20 10:00:00] office | I went to the communal office in the castle every day, piling my desk with massive volumes on theology, angels, and the history of science, and began taking notes on paper. I knew Nils Nils was attending classes at the drama academy. As far as I was aware, I was then immersed in biographies of Augustine, Hobbes, Spengler, and Newton, trying to piece together the logic for my novel. Though I didn't yet know what my exact goal was, I was striving to find a way out from within these vast and complex systems of thought.
[2003-06-25 00:00:00] new apartment | I realized that beneath Nils Nils's happiness lay a feeling as deep as an abyss. I thought she was both excited about the new life and deeply trapped in the fear of being unable to care for the child or possibly losing it. I felt that no matter what I did, I couldn't completely erase this inner unease from her heart.
[2003-06-28 10:00:00] Aucity street | I dragged two heavy suitcases and took Nils Nils across various modes of transportation toward Leivik for vacation. I saw Arvid meeting us in Aucity. I heard myself telling Arvid about her pregnancy right then, explaining why she needed rest. I knew that at the end of June we had begun this journey back home. Arvid had originally been Henrik's friend, but I had interacted with him frequently as well.
[2003-06-28 10:10:00] Aucity street/cabin | I watched Arvid drive us to our destination, then walked into the wooden cabin. I heard Arvid express joyful congratulations and suggest dropping us off to rest first, then coming back later by boat to pick us up. I heard myself thanking him. Before me stood a poorly conditioned log cabin. The moment I saw that shabby cabin, I regretted it. I had wanted to show her the beautiful side of my hometown, but the conditions here were truly unsatisfactory.
[2003-06-28 16:00:00] sea near Hisøy | I stepped out of the cabin onto the pier and saw Arvid approaching across the sea in his small boat; I then boarded the vessel. I saw rows of little white houses on the rocks bathed in the faint red glow of the setting sun, surrounded by blue sea and sky. Then, I felt strong gusts of wind rising across the water. Sitting on the boat, I marveled at the beauty of the scenery. Yet I also realized that under the force of the wind, these familiar landscapes seemed to be falling apart, becoming unfamiliar and alien.
[2003-06-28 18:00:00] garden on Hisøy | I accompanied her ashore and indoors, sitting down with relatives and friends around a garden table. Noticing Nils Nils seemed somewhat cold, I gently squeezed her forearm under the table and looked at her. Looking at her expressionless face, I was filled with anguish. I had hoped she would impress her friends with her brilliance, only to find her extremely silent and reserved, which left me deeply disappointed.
[2003-06-28 20:00:00] garden on Hisøy | I kept asking myself: What is she thinking? Who upset her? I wanted to figure out whether someone present had provoked her, or if I had said something wrong earlier.
[2003-06-28 20:30:00] at sea | I sat on the speeding boat, watching the bow violently crash into waves, sending up sprays of water. I saw Nils Nils beside me turn deathly pale. I heard her gritting her teeth and whispering fiercely at me: 'Tell him to slow down! This is too dangerous for me!' I felt the fresh sea breeze hitting my face, while noticing Arvid smiling as he sped forward full throttle. I knew she was only three months pregnant at this point. I realized she was in extreme fear and fury. Though I wanted to speak up, I worried that asking Arvid to slow down would make me look foolish.
[2003-06-28 20:40:00] at sea | I straightened up and moved close to Arvid behind the steering wheel, then returned to sit beside Nils Nils, watching him give me a smile. I heard Nils Nils angrily scold me for not understanding the danger. I heard myself weakly comforting her with 'It's okay.' I also heard Arvid casually ask how she was doing, and I nodded back with a smile. I saw Meldøya rapidly rushing toward us. I found that the words 'ask him to slow down' rose to my lips but were swallowed again—I ultimately didn't dare to speak them.
[2003-06-28 21:30:00] Meldøya/dock | After walking around the island, I returned to the dock and quietly approached Arvid. I whispered to Arvid, explaining that Nils Nils had been a bit frightened due to her pregnancy, and asked him, 'Could you go a bit easier on the way back?' We had coffee and pastries on a carpet in Meldøya.
[2003-06-28 22:00:00] at sea | I heard Arvid reply cheerfully, 'No problem.' Then I saw him steer the boat back to our destination at a snail's pace. I felt deeply embarrassed inside. I realized I had failed both to protect her feelings on the way there and then created this slightly ridiculous 'extra consideration' on the return—my handling of it all felt clumsy.
[2003-06-28 23:00:00] Leivik | I knew she had just come out of a psychiatric hospital three years ago. As far as I knew, her history of bipolar disorder made this pregnancy somewhat risky. I worried in my heart whether she might relapse, but looking at her now, I believed she was healthy. I told myself that as long as we got through this crisis, everything would gradually fall into place.
[2003-07-01 10:00:00] Moss Station / Rakolen | I took her by train to Moss, where Olaf Ingva picked us up and brought us home. I watched Nils Nils go off to rest first, then walked with Olaf Ingva to a nearby field to kick a ball around for a while.
[2003-07-02 10:00:00] Jeløy Island cabin | The next day, I watched Olaf Ingva drive us to a wooden cabin on Jeløy Island. I knew we planned to stay there for a week.
[2003-07-03 05:00:00] Jeløy Island cabin | I got up to write every day around five. Around ten, I watched her get up, and then we went swimming at the beach or shopping together. In the afternoons I went fishing alone, and in the evenings I lit a bonfire with her, chatting and reading. I noticed the novel about crab fishing was slowly taking shape. When I heard her praise what I'd just written as excellent, I felt deeply fulfilled inside.
[2003-07-09 10:00:00] Bergen / Flåm / Balestrand / Fjærland | I took her across various modes of transport, finally boarding a ferry to Fjærland, where I saw Mom standing on the dock waiting for us. Before me lay glaciers in shades of gray-white under a blue sky. I felt the heaviness of passing through long tunnels and dark valleys, until the gentle, fertile countryside of Jølster came into view. I learned that along the way we had unexpectedly met Thomas Bra, who was hiking. I felt incredibly excited seeing Thomas Bra after so many years. I thought he was one of the finest people I’d ever known.
[2003-07-10 10:00:00] Mother's house in Jølster | I sat in the garden, watching the interaction between Nils Nils and my mom. I heard Nils Nils initiate conversation with Mom, and saw Mom listening attentively to her. I knew this was their third meeting. I keenly sensed the distance between them. When I saw them begin to try communicating, a brief joy rose in my heart—only to be quickly replaced by worry over how it might end, hoping they would stop before things went too far.
[2003-07-12 10:00:00] Mother's house in Jølster | I stayed by her side as she consulted a midwife over the phone. I heard Nils Nils say in panic that she was bleeding and wanted to leave immediately. I heard myself keep telling her, 'It'll be fine, it will definitely be fine.' I could feel her inner panic, though I wasn't sure myself. I carried immense pressure in my heart, fearing that if we stayed and something really went wrong, it would all be my fault.
[2003-07-13 10:00:00] Mother's house in Jølster | I saw Nils Nils sink into silence all day, drifting like a ghost through the house. I went over and held her tightly, trying to calm her down. I sensed she was filled with fear, and that she felt I was indifferent to her pain—this had caused some resentment toward me. I could feel she didn’t want to stay here even a moment longer.

[2003-07-15 12:00:00] Florø Island restaurant | I accompanied her on a tour through the canyon, then sat with her at a table in the floating barge restaurant. I watched her remain nearly silent in response to my mother’s questions. I heard us shouting angrily at each other during the hike. I heard the waiter say the soup was fine—it was just supposed to taste that way. I smelled the spoiled flavor in the fish soup caused by too much butter. I was inside a restaurant on a barge at Florø Island. I felt this was truly an exhausting nightmare.
[2003-07-15 12:30:00] Florø Island Restaurant | I looked at the bowl of fish soup in front of me and couldn't bring myself to lift my spoon. I heard Nils Nils complain that he couldn't eat the soup. I heard myself say to the waitress, 'This doesn't taste very good—do you think we could order something else?' I felt it was extremely embarrassing to complain about food in such a public setting.
[2003-07-15 12:35:00] Florø Island Restaurant | I saw the strong middle-aged waitress shoot me an accusing glance, and then the three of us sat silently at the table, staring at our bowls of fish soup. I heard the waitress say, 'The food shouldn't be a problem, but since you've mentioned it, I'll go check with the cook.' I noticed the waitress had poorly dyed blonde hair.
[2003-07-15 12:40:00] Florø Island Restaurant/Kitchen | I got up and walked into the kitchen built on land, leaned over the counter and stretched my neck trying to get someone's attention, then walked back to the barge. I said to the cook, 'We ordered fish soup, but there's too much butter in it—it's practically inedible. Do you think we could get something else instead?' I heard the cook reply stiffly, 'That's just how it tastes. You ordered fish soup, and we served you fish soup. There's nothing we can do about it.' I saw the cook was a tall, burly man, about my age.
[2003-07-15 12:50:00] Florø Island Restaurant | I returned to our table and shook my head; then we stood up, left money on the table, and walked out the door. I heard myself say, 'No use.' I heard my mother suggest she try going in, but I stopped her. Finally, I heard myself say, 'Alright, alright, I'm hungry, but now this soup is completely impossible to eat.' I felt that complaining in a restaurant went against my nature and made me deeply embarrassed.
[2003-07-15 14:00:00] On the boat | I carried the luggage onto the boat, waved goodbye to my mother, then sat at the bow eating a poor-quality pizza and potato pancake. I saw Nils Nils lie down and fall asleep; when she woke up, I watched her sit beside me and chatter endlessly. I said to Nils Nils, 'Let's eat on the boat.' I heard her quietly nod. I heard the sound of the boat’s propeller still spinning, and I felt the soggy, mushy texture of the pizza and potato pancake. I looked in surprise at how cheerful and lively she became after waking up—could the earlier gloom have been because of my mother, the unfamiliar environment, or fear for the baby?
[2003-07-16 10:00:00] Halvik Hospital | I brought her home from Baysang by plane and accompanied her to the check-up the next day. I knew the test results showed everything was perfectly normal—the little heart was beating, everything was flawless.
[2003-08-15 10:00:00] Akselhof Office | After the check-up, we went to a cake shop, then I took the subway to Akselhof’s new office to work. I sat among concrete walls writing, reading, watching the subway pass through the forest. I heard us talking together about the details of the examination. I was in a modest room located in the basement of an apartment building. I saw the subway tilt through the woods every five minutes or so; in the afternoon, the cars looked like rows of lit rooms moving through the trees. I knew this office space was provided for me by Sofivik. I realized the discussion in the book I was reading, *The Decline of the West*, regarding theories of civilization and the Baroque period, was deeply inspiring to me. I realized this novel must center on the seventeenth century; whenever my hypothetical framework gained new supporting arguments, I felt an uncontrollable joy.
[2003-08-15 10:00:00] New Apartment | I watched Nils Nils’ belly grow larger each day, watched her busy herself organizing baby supplies. One morning I spilled water and left without cleaning it; when I came back, I found the carpet ruined, so we threw it away. I asked her what happened to the carpet. I heard her sheepishly explain that she’d been furious about the water stain I left, so she poured juice over it. I saw a large yellow stain on the kitchen carpet. I knew she now spent all day arranging baby clothes and studying pregnancy books. I was happy to see her enthusiasm for baby-related matters, but also realized I couldn’t fully share her feelings due to my need to write. I noticed anger flaring up between us from time to time.
[2003-11-05 20:00:00] New Apartment Dining Room | I saw her suddenly pick up a pen and forcefully stab it into the dining table, scratching and carving again and again. I asked her, 'What are you doing?' I heard her say sorrowfully, 'You don't care.' I snapped back angrily, 'Oh, for God’s sake! Of course I care. Now you’ve ruined the table.' I knew this dining set was a precious gift from her mother. I understood her anger stemmed from my lack of appreciation for the letter she had written to the maternity clinic.
[2003-11-10 21:00:00] New Apartment | I hurled a glass with all my strength against the stove. I felt furious at him. Seeing the glass didn’t break, I inwardly lamented how much of a failure I was—even failing at something as simple as smashing a glass.
[2003-11-15 10:00:00] New Apartment | I went with her to IKEA to buy a diaper changing table, stuffed it full of cloth and towels, and pasted a series of postcards on the wall above it. I saw postcards of seals, whales, monkeys, and the Beatles pinned to the wall. I hoped that when the baby was born, she would see herself in a wonderful world.
[2003-11-20 19:00:00] Prenatal Class Room | I accompanied her to the prenatal class, looked around the crowded classroom, and saw a woman crying on a bench. I heard the word 'instinct' from the podium, then heard angry murmurs from women in the room: 'No, no, no! How can you say such a thing!' I knew the crying woman was upset because her husband was late. I watched the woman's husband being beaten and felt inwardly that I wasn't alone—everyone was caught in this chaos caused by physical and psychological stress.
[2003-11-20 20:00:00] New Apartment | I accepted the baby supplies sent by Henrik Inge and Marivik Lund, then called Henrik to check on the progress of the stroller. I heard Henrik say the stroller was almost ready. I heard myself mumble an excuse about how pregnant women are irrational for pushing so hard. I learned that Nils Nils was deeply distressed because he hadn’t yet received the stroller promised by his brother. I hated myself for having to go against my nature and pressure someone, but I told myself I had to endure these petty matters to calm her down.
[2003-12-01 09:00:00] Prenatal Class Room / Subway / Aker Brygge | I saw the late man get punched in the stomach by his wife. Every morning I took the subway to Aker Brygge, walked to the office building to work, watching suburban houses and bridges flash by outside the train window. I smelled the distinctive air of the underground station. I saw the scenery rush past as the subway emerged from underground, and felt the view open up as the train crossed the bridge. I found that once I went underground, all the worries at home vanished. I deeply loved those little stops, enjoying the psychological isolation this commute brought.
locations: Prenatal Class Room / Subway / Aker Brygge

text:
[2003-12-01 10:00:00] New Apartment | I watched as the stroller still didn’t arrive. Later we bought a bath set, a onesie, and tiny shoes. I looked at the crib and down comforter lent to us by Helene. I learned that the delay with the stroller triggered another emotional outburst. I saw Nils Nils glisten with tears looking at the borrowed crib, sensing the waves of her emotions.
[2003-12-05 21:00:00] New Apartment | I heard Nils Nils suggest naming the girl Vanya. We agreed that if it was a boy, we’d name him Bjørn. I learned that 'Vanya' originated from 'Ivan,' and also corresponded to Nils Nils’s father’s name, 'Johannes'. I really liked the suggestion—I thought the name carried a strong, wild feeling.
[2003-12-10 08:30:00] Mochengdao Road Station | At Mochengdao Road Station, I saw two men fiercely arguing and throwing punches. I dropped my backpack, rushed over, and tightly grabbed one of them. Then I picked up my bag and sat on the train to Aker Brygge, feeling my knees trembling. I felt the subway station filled with terrifying aggression. I thought of previous conflicts where I had failed to act in time. I told myself today I had to take a stand—no more standing by. Though afterward my heart raced and I doubted whether it was wise, I was glad I proved I wasn’t a coward.
[2003-12-12 00:00:00] New Apartment | I realized we were both close and distant. I noticed I held grudges more than she did, remembering every single argument from the past year. I sensed she clung to me desperately out of fear of losing me, while my withdrawal deepened her anxiety. But I was certain that once the child was born, everything would be fine.
[2003-12-15 10:00:00] Aker Brygge / Maternity Care Center | I kept expanding the manuscript, passed by and visited a Russian Orthodox bookstore. I accompanied Nils Nils to the care center for her checkup, sitting in a chair watching her undergo various tests. I saw nurses measuring her blood pressure, drawing blood, listening to the heartbeat, and measuring her belly circumference. I learned the novel was turning toward theological theory. I knew the test results showed the fetus was developing perfectly normally. Whenever I found new arguments, I felt joyous. I felt concerns about physical strength were like passing clouds—utterly insignificant.
[2003-12-15 14:00:00] New Apartment | I watched Henrik Inge arrive with the children, bringing the stroller. I noticed Nils Nils looked terrible, so I stepped in, trying to calm both sides. I felt a hostile atmosphere spreading through the room. I felt this oppressive mood would drive me mad, and I didn’t want the guests to suffer along with us.
[2003-12-15 20:00:00] Harvik Bar | I sat silently across from him on the high stools at the bar. Two weeks later, I received a call from Kristina. I heard Kristina say he had gone to Turkey for field reporting and would be away for several months. I knew that the winter a year earlier, our atmosphere had been tense, and conversations often included sharp remarks about either him or my family. I felt somewhat offended that he hadn't mentioned a word to me before leaving.
[2003-12-17 10:00:00] New Apartment | I said nothing, swallowed my reproach, and suppressed my inner anger. I knew her due date was approaching and she wanted peace. I didn’t understand why she would provoke conflict in front of guests; I felt this coldness toward visitors was disrespectful to me. I lamented her inability to control her temper, while I had to endure it all in silence just to keep things together.
[2003-12-25 10:00:00] New Apartment | I watched Henrik and the children leave, and instead of punishing her with silent treatment, I let it go. I noticed she became cheerful and excited as soon as the guests left. I decided not to dwell on the earlier absurdity and let us have a pleasant time during Christmas.
[2003-12-31 20:00:00] Kitchen of the New Apartment | On the last day of 2003, I was busy moving around in the kitchen. I watched Karl Larsdal sit in his chair chatting with me. I knew my current life bore no trace of the Baysang period. I realized I had always been influenced by Karl, even easily swayed by him in changing my opinions. I remembered how my family once warned me not to pick up bad habits from him.
[2003-12-31 20:15:00] Kitchen of the New Apartment | I plated the lobster and wiped sweat from my forehead. I cut the lemon into four pieces and plucked some parsley leaves for garnish. I said to Karl, 'Done—just the side dishes left.' I heard Karl say, 'People know what you are, right? A writer’s life should be exciting, yet here you are scrubbing and cooking.' I replied, 'True, but look—it’s wonderful!'
[2003-12-31 20:25:00] Kitchen of the New Apartment | I burst out laughing at Karl’s words. I heard Karl mockingly say Bergson was the most depressing figure in Leivik literature because he not only never went out, but eventually killed himself. His infectious laughter rang in my ears.
[2003-12-31 20:35:00] Kitchen of the New Apartment | I heard Karl continue teasing, saying Ibsen was also a downer, even though he hid mirrors in his hat. He mentioned that Bjørnson and Hamsun weren’t depressing. He suggested classifying Leivik literature. I thought, if we really did this classification, the result might turn out unpleasant.
[2003-12-31 20:45:00] Kitchen of the New Apartment | I took bread from a paper bag, rinsed the knife under water, and began slicing it. I heard Karl suggest I write that article about Astridvik as soon as possible. I said I would write it later. I mentioned how he would destroy furniture when insane and lie naked in the coal cellar. I knew I had tentatively titled that article 'The Villain of Hardanger'.
[2003-12-31 20:55:00] Kitchen of the New Apartment | I heard Karl remind me that the writer had also written Hitler was a great man. I mentioned that the most meaningful entries in the diary were those written during his manic episodes, when his inhibitions vanished and he expressed genuine opinions about other writers. I remarked that no one had ever written about such a stark contrast.
[2003-12-31 21:05:00] Kitchen of the New Apartment | I placed the sliced bread into a small basket and started cutting another loaf. I heard Karl say no one dared write about those contrasts because everyone feared his reputation. I explained it was out of a certain tolerance and politeness. When I heard Karl ask if I didn’t understand the poet, I disagreed. I felt a twinge of guilt over having laughed at Bergson earlier.
[2003-12-31 21:15:00] kitchen of the new apartment | I heard Karl question my view of poets as wise men. I countered by asking him whether, if we only consider poetry itself, would a poet’s eccentric beliefs or crude remarks really affect his standing? I asked where exactly the boundary lies.
[2003-12-31 21:25:00] kitchen of the new apartment | I heard Karl Larsdal laughingly refute me, saying there was no way I could be that sensitive and cautious, especially since the writer was already dead. He mentioned that the image of Høygrd as the "Hardanger sage" must be questioned—if he had been mad throughout long cycles, then the so-called wisdom couldn't hold. I also heard myself explain that perhaps I felt a bit guilty inside because I had just made fun of Bergson. I realized I was caught in complex emotions—on one hand drawn to the tragic life of Høygrd, on the other hand reflecting on whether my judgment of him was fair.
[2003-12-31 21:35:00] kitchen of the new apartment | I finished slicing the last few pieces of bread and placed them into the small basket, then smiled at Karl Larsdal. I heard myself say to Karl, 'That's enough—help me carry the bread basket, butter, and mayonnaise; let's go join the others.' I heard Karl continue laughing and teasing that Bergson wasn't a party animal, just a crane operator. Though I was smiling, I still felt somewhat uneasy inside.

[2003-12-31 21:45:00] living room/dining area of the new apartment | I put the dishes on the table, emptied the remaining champagne, and opened another bottle of white wine. I sat down and used the seafood utensils gifted by Marivik and Tove to crack open the lobster claw. I heard Helene exclaim, 'Oh, wonderful!' and Nils Nils praise me for doing well. I responded, 'Please, help yourselves.' The lobster meat looked thick and delicious; when peeled, I noticed brine seeping from the gap between the meat and shell. Looking at the lobster in my hands, a strange thought crossed my mind: what must it have been like when this lobster wandered along the seabed?
[2003-12-31 21:55:00] dining area of the new apartment | I raised my glass and saw everyone follow suit, lifting their glasses together. I heard myself loudly say in the Leivik dialect, 'Gathered here together, everyone!' I heard Karl Larsdal quietly mutter 'Skål,' and Anders loudly thank me: 'Skål! Thank you for having us!' I noticed Karl’s reaction to my dialect, while the others clearly didn’t mind this small linguistic gap.
[2003-12-31 22:05:00] dining area/kitchen of the new apartment | I hid in the kitchen, peeking through the door crack to greet everyone before retreating back inside to keep busy. I began clearing the finished appetizers and preparing the next course. I realized that taking on the role of cook was actually my way of finding a refuge in this social gathering. I liked using the busyness of refilling glasses to hide my discomfort in conversation.
[2003-12-31 22:15:00] dining area of the new apartment | I watched my companions around the table: Karl was deep in animated conversation with Anders, Helene was laughing loudly, while Kristina remained in prolonged silence. I heard the laughter from Karl and Anders talking about their criminal acquaintances, and Helene’s breathy laughter triggered by Karl’s candor. I sensed a complex tension flowing through the table. I realized I couldn’t engage deeply with Anders or Helene, and I noticed Helene’s subtle disapproval of Anders’ remarks. Watching silent Kristina, I wondered if her unhappiness had anything to do with us or with Karl—this uncertainty in social dynamics made me feel increasingly pressured.
[2003-12-31 22:30:00] dining area of the new apartment | I speared a large bite of lobster meat, dipped it in mayonnaise, and put it into my mouth. I saw the windowpanes vibrate from sounds outside. I savored the thick, smooth texture of the lobster meat. Suddenly, a loud bang erupted outside, like an explosion, making the windowpanes rattle violently. I realized we were in a moment of delicate openness—as if on this New Year’s Eve, anyone could speak of any past without fear of losing anything.
[2003-12-31 22:35:00] dining area of the new apartment | I heard Anders say, 'That kind of thing isn’t legal.' I heard Karl mock him as an expert in such matters. I heard Helene describe the Chinese balloon they’d bought, saying it rose silently and beautifully. I also heard Nils Nils worry it might land on the roof and start a fire, while Anders casually replied, 'Anything can happen on New Year’s Eve.'
[2003-12-31 22:45:00] dining area of the new apartment | I got up and poured another round of drinks for everyone, exchanging a glance with Helene. I saw Karl Larsdal talking passionately. I sat in my chair watching Nils Nils. A brief silence fell over the room. Suddenly, a childhood memory flashed through my mind—the dangerous time when I and my friends secretly ignited powder from cartridge casings. I could even see Karlsen’s face blackened by smoke. But in the end, I decided not to tell that story. I saw Helene smiling warmly, while Karl began again on the differences between Mochengdao and Leivik.
[2003-12-31 22:55:00] new apartment dining room | I heard Anders complain that Mochengdao was lifeless, cold, and run-down, and demand to know what kept everyone here. I also heard Helena reveal Anders’s desire to return to Spain. I heard Nils Nils curiously ask about Spain.
[2003-12-31 23:05:00] new apartment dining room | I watched Anders spread his arms wide in gesture. He cast an expectant look toward me. I heard Anders passionately praise Spain's freedom and its enchanting cities, and suggest he'd take me to see Real Madrid and Barcelona matches. I heard myself reply, 'Sounds nice.' He grunted in dissatisfaction and shouted loudly, 'Let's go! Man!'
[2003-12-31 23:15:00] new apartment dining room | I saw Nils Nils give me an encouraging smile, but I could read the anxiety behind it. I realized her deep-seated desire to control everything. I thought of the child soon to be born, sensing a profound change taking place within her—a quietness and silence like roots growing downward into soil.
[2003-12-31 23:25:00] new apartment dining room | I leaned over to refill Anders’s glass with wine, then poured one for myself. I heard myself ask when exactly the matches would be, and heard Anders say we could attend any game. I heard someone suggest waiting a week after the baby is born before leaving; Anders joked that we weren't men from the 1950s pacing the hallway, and Karl laughed, jokingly calling himself just such an old-fashioned man.
[2003-12-31 23:35:00] new apartment dining room/kitchen | I gathered up the plates and walked into the kitchen. I heard Kristina follow me in. I turned on the tap to rinse the knives, then placed two cast-iron pots on the stove and cranked the burners to high. I pushed open the window and heard the noise of people passing below. I heard myself ask if everyone had eaten well. I heard Kristina kindly offer, 'Can I help you with anything?' I shook my head quietly and said no. I also heard bursts of laughter coming from the living room. Fireworks outside hissed and exploded one after another, flashes intermittently lighting up the night sky. I felt Kristina’s kindness, but I instinctively looked down and avoided meeting her eyes.
[2003-12-31 23:45:00] new apartment kitchen/living room | I poured white wine into the hot pan, sprinkled in parsley, then dumped the pasta into a colander. I walked into the living room and slipped a CD by the band Low into the player. I stepped behind Nils Nils and rested my hands on her shoulders. I heard Anders say he’d never ask me if I needed help. I also heard Helena ask with concern if I needed assistance, and I smiled and said no. I heard Nils Nils say gently to me, 'That’s nice.' Oil sizzled in the pans, and the air filled with the aroma of mussels and white wine. Music flowed through the room, mingling with the background hum of conversation and laughter.
[2003-12-31 23:55:00] new apartment living room | I stood in the living room listening to Nils Nils tell a story. I heard Nils Nils recount a strange tale about a woman who kept a red-tailed boa: one day, the snake stretched out straight and lay beside her on the bed. I heard her repeat what an expert at Skansen Park said—the snake was measuring its prey, assessing whether it could swallow the owner whole. As I listened, a chill ran through me.
[2004-01-01 00:05:00] new apartment living room/kitchen | I let out a startled cry and heard everyone burst into laughter. I saw Karl explaining regional dialect words for snakes to the others, and I took the chance to turn and head back to the kitchen. I heard myself exclaim, 'Oh God! That’s the most disgusting story I’ve ever heard!' I heard Nils Nils expose my secret fear of snakes and mimic my delirious midnight rambling about stepping on one. I heard myself retort, 'When you talk about bugs, as if they’re not dangerous or something!' I didn’t want to hear the Freudian psychological analysis that would surely follow—I just wanted to get out of the living room quickly.
locations: living room/dining area of the new apartment
dining area of the new apartment
dining area/kitchen of the new apartment

text:
[2004-01-01 00:15:00] new apartment kitchen | I dropped the pasta into boiling water and sliced garlic into the hot pans. I scooped mussels from the sink and tossed them into the pots, then covered them with lids. Next, I poured in white wine and sprinkled parsley on top. The crackling of oil in hot pans blended with the roaring of boiling water. I could feel the scent of garlic and herbs spreading through the kitchen.
[2004-01-01 00:25:00] new apartment dining room | I carried the plate into the dining room and saw everyone’s expectant expressions. I picked up a mussel shell, used my fork to dig out the meat with orange streaks, and took a bite. I heard Helena exclaim, 'Wow, amazing!' I heard Nils Nils praise me for doing well. I also heard Anders half-jokingly challenge, 'Is there anything you can’t do?' I heard myself explain it was just a simple recipe taken from Jamie Oliver. I heard the crunch of fine sand between my teeth as I chewed the mussel. I kept my head down, focusing on the food in my plate to avoid Anders’s teasing.
[2004-01-01 00:35:00] New Apartment Dining Room | I lifted my head from the plate and looked at Anders. I heard myself ask Nils Nils whether she had ever told about the salted mutton ribs feast. I explained to everyone this traditional Leivik Christmas dish, mentioning the lamb ribs my mother had sent. I recounted the awkward story of how I spent that afternoon steaming the meat, only for it to remain uncooked until late at night before finally being ready. I knew this salted mutton ribs required months of curing and air-drying, a specialty from my hometown. Remembering that Christmas Eve filled with the smell of mutton, yet ending with us going to bed without properly eating, I couldn't help but find it somewhat funny.
[2004-01-01 00:45:00] New Apartment Dining Room | I watched Nils Nils cheerfully adding details to the story for everyone. I heard Nils Nils laughingly complain that I woke her up at one in the morning to eat the meat. She sighed, 'It didn’t look like much, but it was actually pretty good.' I heard Anders comment that this was truly a 'pastoral' kind of story, unlike my usual tales of things going wrong. I felt a warm sense of camaraderie, even though it had been a less-than-successful dinner attempt.
[2004-01-01 00:55:00] New Apartment Dining Room | I looked at Anders, listening to him talk about his past life. I heard Anders jokingly refer to himself as 'a former rich man.' He described his extravagant past running a restaurant in Spain, owning luxury cars and fine horses, and then how he went bankrupt and ended up in prison due to fraud by a business partner, leaving him with massive debts. I heard him insist he hadn’t complained like we did. I was struck by Anders’ extreme experiences and his remarkably calm, accepting tone.
[2004-01-01 01:05:00] New Apartment Dining Room | I heard Helene challenge Anders, saying he simply didn’t want to understand where he was. Helene lamented that while she envied Anders’ 'not thinking,' she herself always struggled hard to figure out who she was and why she had gone through those experiences. Anders shot back, teasing that they were always sitting on the couch complaining about their feelings. I realized there was a fundamental difference in how the two approached life.
[2004-01-01 01:15:00] New Apartment Dining Room | I heard Karl Larsdal point out that Helene’s story wasn’t so different. Helene admitted that although she once starred at the Royal Theatre, leaving everything behind at her peak to move to Hawaii had not exactly been a wise career move. But I heard her say firmly, 'I followed my feelings—there’s nothing to regret.' I knew Helene had once married a New Age movement leader and moved to Hawaii.
[2004-01-01 01:25:00] New Apartment Dining Room | I looked at Kristina, listening as she began to share her story. I heard Anders encourage Kristina to speak. I heard Kristina describe how she was named best designer at a young age, exhibiting in Shannest and Paris. She regretfully mentioned that her success lacked foundation, which eventually led to bankruptcy. I sensed a quiet detachment in her voice toward that past glory.
[2004-01-01 01:35:00] New Apartment Dining Room | I heard Karl elaborate on Kristina’s former fame: TV crews coming to her home, her face displayed at the Cultural Palace, major newspapers dedicating six-page features to her. I heard Kristina shrug and calmly say she couldn’t earn money anymore and had already gone bankrupt. I could imagine the intense contrast of falling from such heights.
[2004-01-01 01:45:00] New Apartment Dining Room | I heard Karl vividly recount the disastrous final exhibition of Kristina’s: she rented a giant Sydney Opera House tent in Ladegårdsparken, had models ride into the show on guards’ horses. But just as everything reached its most spectacular moment, a heavy downpour began. I heard Kristina cover her mouth and burst into laughter. I too felt a sense of absurd humor rising from their storytelling.
[2004-01-01 01:55:00] New Apartment Dining Room | I heard Karl continue describing the models, drenched and disheveled, wolfing down food in the rain, calling it a 'glorious failure.' He explained that this was why, when I first met Kristina, she was designing shoes—the old-style pair she had worn during the exhibition, which later became popular, was her last small compensation for those lost dreams. I recalled the moment I first saw her, finally understanding the deeper meaning behind those details.
[2004-01-01 02:05:00] New Apartment Dining Room | I gazed at Nils Nils, listening as she shared her unremarkable path to modest success. I heard Nils Nils talk about the joy after her debut work was published, and the regret of missing a trip to Japan to receive an award due to illness. She mentioned writing several poetry collections, only to be accepted and then rejected by two publishers in turn. She said, 'I told everyone about it… then later he said it wouldn’t be published after all.' I felt the blow of that 'false hope' she’d experienced, yet also saw how she could now say lightly, 'It’s no big deal.'
[2004-01-01 02:15:00] New Apartment Restaurant | I heard Karl ask if he also counted as a 'beautiful failure.' He told how he had once been an academic prodigy, but his publication was blocked because he wrote his fieldwork on Mochengdao in Leivik and refused to provide sociological excuses for boxers' behavior. He joked that the book he self-published went unnoticed, except for one woman at the publisher who read it on a ferry and curiously studied the cover. He sighed, 'I don't think anyone would want to read the book I spent five years writing.'
[2004-01-01 02:25:00] New Apartment Restaurant | I heard Anders regretfully tell Karl he should have given him a heads-up so he could arrange a TV appearance for him. I overheard Helena asking Karl how he’d respond if he actually received such an irresistible invitation. I heard Karl reply that although Anders didn’t have strong connections, he still appreciated the offer.
[2004-01-01 02:35:00] New Apartment Restaurant | I saw Anders staring at me. I recalled my writing state over these past five years. I heard Anders say it was now my turn to speak. Karl remarked that I didn’t know how lucky I was. I told them I hadn’t achieved anything—I’d been writing for four years with no results. I heard myself mimic journalists’ tones, talking about writers with writer’s block or those who only ever wrote one book. I knew it had been nearly five years since I published my debut work.
[2004-01-01 02:45:00] New Apartment Restaurant | I saw Karl glance at me, then burst into laughter. I listened as he told stories about his friends. I heard Karl insist that I didn’t know how lucky I was. He began listing his failed friends: one who tried online dating but was too poor to do anything but roast sausages over a campfire; another who spent all his savings on breast implants for a prostitute; someone else who had been working on his doctoral thesis for fourteen years with no end in sight. I heard him mention an Aucity friend who got a thirteen-year-old girl pregnant.
[2004-01-01 02:55:00] New Apartment Restaurant | I saw Karl continuing to talk about his painter friend. I made eye contact with Nils Nils, and I smiled at her. I heard Karl make a point of clarifying that the man who got the girl pregnant wasn’t me. He sighed that we were all sitting on the same sinking, broken boat. I heard Nils Nils say Karl’s words were poetic, but that wasn’t how she felt right now. I saw Nils Nils sitting there with her arms wrapped around her swollen belly. I inwardly sighed—there would be a child in the house in just two weeks. I realized I was truly going to be a father.
[2004-01-01 03:05:00] New Apartment Restaurant | I saw the table fall into silence. I stood up, took the wine bottle, and poured drinks for everyone. I saw Anders leaning back in his chair, holding his glass. I heard Helena remark how unusually honest we all remained. I joked that this was turning into a misery contest. I heard Karl shout loudly that he was the most miserable of all.
[2004-01-01 03:15:00] New Apartment Restaurant | I saw Helen's face twitch slightly as she spoke, mimicking the mannerisms of her stepmother. I heard Helena say our parents could never talk as openly as we do. She described her father as the 'wig king,' and revealed that both her biological mother and stepmother were alcoholics. I knew Helena’s father made wigs. I understood her biological mother had become unbearable due to her drinking.
[2004-01-01 03:25:00] New Apartment Restaurant | I saw Helena looking at me. I listened as she recounted her absurd childhood experiences. I heard Helena describe how her parents used to pour hard liquor into juice boxes. She mentioned her mother once gave her sleeping pills so she could go out alone. She lamented that her mother had now become a selfish old hag. I heard her ask me whether my father also drank.
[2004-01-01 03:35:00] New Apartment Restaurant | I laughed along with everyone, listening to the laughter around the table. I told Helena my father also drank—and added that he died from it. I told them how after falling down the stairs, he refused an ambulance and simply lay on the floor for days, eating and drinking. I knew my father had been drinking heavily since I was sixteen, until his death when I was thirty. I knew he spent his final days at his mother’s house. I realized I no longer felt anything special about my father’s story.
[2004-01-01 03:45:00] New Apartment Restaurant | I laughed loudly, pushed my plate aside, lit a cigarette, and leaned back. I looked at Nils Nils. I told Anders about the fear my father caused me when he wasn’t drinking. I recalled losing my socks at the swimming pool as a child, being beaten by my father when I got home, and being banned from ever going swimming again. I heard Karl laugh and say we were kindred spirits. I knew my grandfather once shot a crow in the leg with a gun. I remembered the childhood lie about a 'little hawk snatching hair.' I thought to myself that it was a pity Nils Nils had never met my grandfather—she would have loved him.
[2004-01-01 03:55:00] New Apartment Dining Room | I saw Karl hesitate. I listened as he spoke about two entirely different parenting cultures. I heard Helena ask Karl whether his father had beaten him too. Karl explained that in Leivik’s tradition, spanking was seen as a duty, but his father had been very kind, and he bore no ill will. He believed it was a completely different culture from the unpredictable violence of my father. As far as I know, Karl's hometown indeed has this specific child-rearing tradition.
[2004-01-01 04:05:00] New Apartment Dining Room | I saw Anders laugh as he imitated his mother’s hoarse voice. I watched him closely. I heard Anders talk about how he had inherited massive debts due to his father’s financial fraud. I heard him say his father had fled and remained missing ever since. When Nils Nils asked about his mother, Anders described how she was now suffering in poverty. I mentioned I had met her twice and found her sarcastic and darkly humorous. I knew Anders had once been a partner in his father’s company and ended up taking responsibility for all the signed documents.
[2004-01-01 04:15:00] New Apartment Dining Room | I heard Karl describe how his mother controlled the family through guilt. He talked about her fear of space—using cushions to protect her head when entering tunnels, being unable to drive on highways or near water. Anders and Helena were deeply surprised. Karl sighed, saying he had paid a high price to escape that environment. I knew Karl had barely kept in touch with his mother for years in order to break free from her control.
[2004-01-01 04:25:00] New Apartment Dining Room | I heard Nils Nils describe her mother as utterly shameless and reckless. She told us how her mother would charge across roads, even sending her alone on vacation to Greece when she was just six. I heard Karl comment that it was the lawless seventies. I knew Nils Nils’s mother had once been an actress at the Royal Theatre.
[2004-01-01 04:35:00] New Apartment Dining Room | I looked at her and asked about her father. I watched Nils Nils speak calmly. I heard Nils Nils describe her father’s violent and unpredictable episodes, mentioning how they often had to flee from him. She said the hardest part was waiting for disaster to strike—when it actually happened, she felt strangely calm. I learned that during his episodes, her father would climb down drainpipes or jump out of windows. As far as I know, police intervention was always required to end such incidents.
[2004-01-01 04:45:00] New Apartment Dining Room | I saw Nils Nils smile slightly. I saw Anders turn to ask Kristina something. I heard Nils Nils recount the terrifying time when her father turned on the gas, and her mother escaped with the children only to return later and shut it off. Then I heard Anders begin questioning Kristina about her parents. I knew that during the gas incident, Nils Nils was only five years old.
[2004-01-01 04:55:00] New Apartment Dining Room | I saw Anders and Karl burst into laughter. I looked at Kristina. I heard Kristina say her parents lived in Uppsala and were Pentecostal believers. She mentioned they even returned sand collected after snow clearing back to the highway authority. I heard Karl joke that her parents were so good they must be the Devil’s test for him. I knew Kristina’s parents never drank alcohol due to their faith—even coffee was replaced with boiled water.
[2004-01-01 05:05:00] New Apartment Dining Room | I saw Kristina nod slightly at Anders, a faint smile on her lips. I heard Kristina talk about the loneliness she felt at age twelve when she broke away from her religious background and friends. Helena remarked how remarkably mature she must have been at such a young age. Anders joked and asked if she drank coffee now; she replied she did, except when visiting her hometown. I knew Kristina had left her original social circle at the age of twelve.
[2004-01-01 05:15:00] New Apartment Dining Room/Kitchen | I joined the group in laughter. I stood up and began collecting plates. I saw Karl pick up some plates and follow me into the kitchen. I dumped empty shells into the trash and loaded the dishes into the dishwasher. I turned around. I heard Anders shout behind me that Karl had ‘defected.’ I heard Karl call tonight’s conversation a ‘confession night,’ an evening of opening up. I said to Karl, ‘Go for a walk? I need a smoke.’ He agreed.
[2004-01-01 05:25:00] New Apartment Courtyard | I put on my coat, stood in the middle of the courtyard, and lit a cigarette. I saw both Karl and Anders with their hands tucked in their pockets. I heard Anders, braving the cold wind, talk about his free life running a restaurant in Spain—the best period of his life, he said. I felt the strong wind and bitter cold outside. I saw fireworks exploding above the courtyard.

[2004-01-01 05:35:00] new apartment courtyard | I saw Karl burst into laughter. I heard Andor confess that his business partnership had fallen apart after he was caught having an affair with his partner’s wife. He mentioned wanting to take Helena to rent a place in Granada, and I casually replied, 'Sounds nice.' I heard Karl complain that work left him almost no free time. I thought that kind of life might not be what Helena dreamed of.
[2004-01-01 05:45:00] new apartment courtyard/stairs | I flicked my cigarette butt to the ground and stomped on it hard a few times, then led the way toward the stairs. I said to them, 'Let's go up.'
[2004-01-08 10:53:00] Halvik Oksfjord | I saw the subway carriages approaching through the woods like a row of brightly lit rooms in the twilight. As far as I knew, I had spent several months in a basement in Oksfjord. I knew that at the end of 2003, I finally got an office in central Halvik.
[2004-01-08 10:53:00] central Halvik office | I knew this office was actually a furnished single-room apartment belonging to Nils Nils’s friend. I moved my books and computer there between Christmas and New Year. I understood that I began working here from the first day of the new year.
[2004-01-08 10:53:00] central Halvik office | As far as I knew, the novel had already reached one hundred and thirty pages. I knew the story began with crab fishing on a summer night, shifted into angel sketches, and ended with the life of a solitary man who writes and harms himself.
[2004-01-08 10:53:00] central Halvik office | I heard the publisher express interest in publishing it. I also heard Jorgensen, drunk late at night on the phone, repeat, 'Too simple... you need to tell a story, Grete Lundnes!' I felt deep uncertainty about whether this work could ever be published.
[2004-01-08 10:53:00] central Halvik office | I sat in front of my new desk, staring at the blank computer screen. I knew this was my first working day of 2004. I realized Jorgensen was right—I really did need to tell a real story.
[2004-01-08 11:23:00] central Halvik office | I leaned back and carefully studied the poster hanging behind my desk. I knew this poster was from years ago, when Tonje and I visited the Picasso exhibition in Barcelona. I recalled this episode from my past life.
[2004-01-08 11:23:10] central Halvik office | I saw four images on the poster: one looked like a little angel urinating, one showed bird wings, one was a photo of a 1920s pilot, and one depicted a corpse’s hand.
[2004-01-08 11:23:20] central Halvik office | I looked out the window. I noticed the sky above the hospital across the street. I watched the pedestrians on the sidewalk. Before me lay a clear, bright blue sky. I saw low sunlight glinting off windows and railings. The breath of passersby formed white plumes, making them look as if they were on fire. Everyone was wrapped in thick hats and scarves.
[2004-01-08 11:23:40] Håvik City Center Office | I let my gaze wander across the engineered hardwood floor. Suddenly, I fixed my eyes on a grain pattern two meters from my chair. I saw that on the reddish-brown floor, knots and wood grains had formed a clear image: Christ wearing a crown of thorns. I was captivated by this sudden discovery.
[2004-01-08 11:24:00] Håvik City Center Office | I noticed a damp stain on the ceiling that looked like a running dog, peeling paint on the stairs resembling snow-covered valleys, and clouds that seemed upside down. I realized I wasn't particularly moved by the image of Christ in the wood grain—I merely remembered it, since such images are common throughout buildings.
[2004-01-08 11:34:00] Håvik City Center Office | Ten minutes later, I stood up to refill the kettle with water. Suddenly, I recalled a long-ago evening from childhood. I remembered seeing a similar face on the water surface during a news report about a missing fishing boat.
[2004-01-08 11:34:05] Håvik City Center Office | An image of my childhood living room appeared in my mind—our teak-framed television, patches of snow on the dim hillside outside the window, and suddenly, a face emerging on the sea surface within the TV screen.
[2004-01-08 11:34:10] Håvik City Center Office | I recalled the atmosphere of life in the residential areas of the seventies—a mood that now felt almost nostalgically familiar.
[2004-01-08 11:34:15] Håvik City Center Office | The telephone rang suddenly, making me jump. A sudden telephone ring pierced my ears. I realized no one knew my number here, and I felt deeply puzzled.
[2004-01-08 11:34:30] Håvik City Center Office | After five rings, the phone finally stopped. The water in the kettle was nearly boiling, emitting a hissing sound. I felt as though the hissing sound resembled someone slowly approaching me.
[2004-01-08 11:36:00] Håvik City Center Office | I scooped two spoons of coffee into my cup, poured in hot water, put on my clothes, and prepared to leave. Before stepping out, I paused and turned back for one last look at the face in the wooden paneling. I watched the black coffee swirl in the cup, releasing rising steam.
[2004-01-08 11:36:10] Håvik City Center Office | That grain truly resembled Christ—his face half-turned, as if in pain, gazing toward a field, with a crown of thorns upon his head.
[2004-01-08 11:37:00] Håvik City Center Office | I realized it wasn't the faces themselves that mattered, but the fact that forgotten memories from childhood were resurfacing. I noticed I couldn't recall the sequence of events, yet I could vividly remember the furnishings of rooms and the places I'd been.
[2004-01-08 11:40:00] Harvik Street | I came out onto the street holding a coffee cup, crossing the road. I felt an awkward sense of exposure carrying an indoor coffee cup outside, and decided I'd get my morning coffee in those thick paper cups from 7-Eleven from now on.
[2004-01-08 11:45:00] Bench outside the hospital | I walked over to the bench outside the hospital, sat down on the icy seat, lit a cigarette, and looked down at the road below. I could feel the coffee in my hand turning lukewarm.
[2004-01-08 11:45:10] Bench outside the hospital | I could feel that although the sun was shining, the temperature might only be minus fifteen degrees. I learned that this morning the thermometer outside our kitchen showed minus twenty degrees.
[2004-01-08 11:46:00] Bench outside the hospital | I took out my phone from my pocket to check for any missed calls. I knew we were waiting for the baby due in a week. I realized I was fully prepared for Nils Nils to call at any moment saying the baby was coming.
[2004-01-08 11:47:00] Bench outside the hospital | I heard the pedestrian traffic light at the intersection start ticking, and saw the street below grow empty. Two middle-aged women in white coats walked close together, hugging their arms tightly under their armpits, stepping quickly out of the entrance. Looking at the way they walked, I silently remarked in my mind that they resembled some strange kind of duck.
[2004-01-08 11:47:30] Bench outside the hospital | The ticking of the traffic light stopped, and cars rushed out from the shadows up the slope like panting dogs, studded tires rolling over the asphalt.
[2004-01-08 11:48:00] Bench outside the hospital | I put the phone back in my pocket and gripped the coffee cup with both hands. I saw the steam rising slowly from the cup, mingling with the smoke drifting from my mouth.
[2004-01-08 11:50:00] Bench outside the hospital | I noticed the shouting and noise from the school suddenly fell silent, followed by the sound of the class bell ringing. I knew the school was just twenty meters up from my office.
[2004-01-08 11:51:00] Bench outside the hospital | I realized the sources of sound here were becoming familiar, yet would soon fade into subconsciousness. I thought that writing is about extracting real presence from the shadows of the known, but I was still pondering how to guide myself toward that direction of writing.
[2004-01-08 11:55:00] Bench outside the hospital | I sat in the Harvik district drinking coffee, my muscles tensing from the cold. I watched the smoke rise and disperse into the air above my head. I kept turning over in my mind the question of my writing goal.

[2004-01-08 11:55:00] Harvik Street | I noticed the morning street filled with congested vehicles. At six-thirty, laborers wearing safety boots and hands caked with grime gathered at the café for breakfast, their phones ringing incessantly. I learned this is the daily rhythm of an area situated along a major traffic route. I know workers are accustomed to keeping their tape measures tucked in their pockets.
[2004-01-08 11:55:00] Harvik Street | I saw the street filled with people dressed in soft, high-quality clothing. I understood these individuals were likely lawyers, journalists, architects, or project managers who would spend the day in offices.
[2004-01-08 11:55:00] Harvik Street | I saw nurses spilling out from buses. I learned from the caption that Constable painted this on an afternoon in Hampstead. Although some have questioned the accuracy of the date, weather records from that day support the cloud formations depicted in the painting. I found myself filled with tears—those beautiful, intimate emotions converging instantly. I recalled studying that green cloud before, the overwhelming intensity impossible to explain logically.

I feel I can find freedom in museums, yet also a certain indescribable greed for the infinite, leaving me unsettled even after I leave.
