[2004-01-09 04:35:00] Cabinet Street | I put on my coat in the hallway and grabbed my backpack with the computer before heading out. I saw a snowplow approaching down the street below. I felt the cold air hit my face as I stepped onto the snow-covered sidewalk. I heard the heavy iron blade of the snowplow rumbling against the asphalt.
[2004-01-09 04:36:00] Cabinet Street | I thought about how she always pulls me back. I couldn't help wondering—since she was already asleep, why did I have to stay there at all?
[2004-01-09 04:37:00] Cabinet Street | I started walking forward. I saw the sky above the rooftops, dark and heavy, and noticed the snow had stopped. The roar of the snowplow’s engine, the creaking hinges, and the scraping of metal on pavement reached my ears—I thought they sounded like noises from hell.
[2004-01-09 04:40:00] Baker David Street | I turned into the empty Baker David Street and stopped by the nursing home entrance. I saw the restaurant marked KGB by the roadside. Everything around was silent. I realized Nils Nils was right—the child could come at any time, and she didn’t like being alone. I asked myself why I was going to the office at this hour. I thought—if I hadn’t been ready these past five years, could I really write it today?
[2004-01-09 04:41:00] Baker David Street | I silently called myself a fool. She was waiting for our child—how could I leave her to face this alone?
[2004-01-09 04:45:00] Cabinet Street apartment bedroom | I walked back, dropped my backpack in the hallway and took off my coat. I heard her making sounds from the bedroom.
[2004-01-09 04:45:10] Cabinet Street apartment bedroom | I entered the bedroom and came to her side. I heard her ask, 'Is that you, Grete Lundnes?' I answered, 'It's me.' I saw the questioning look in her eyes.
[2004-01-09 04:45:20] Cabinet Street apartment bedroom | I said to her, 'You're right. I wasn't thinking. I'm sorry I just left like that.' I heard her generously apologize, saying I should go to work.
[2004-01-09 04:45:30] Cabinet Street apartment bedroom | I said, 'I'll work later.' I heard her assure me everything was fine at home, telling me to go ahead, and she'd call if anything happened.
[2004-01-09 04:45:40] Cabinet Street apartment bedroom | I lay down beside her. I briefly answered, "No." I heard her call my name, then laugh.
[2004-01-09 04:46:00] Cabinet Street apartment bedroom | I said to her, "Now you've taken on my earlier attitude, and I've taken on yours. But deep down, I know you're actually saying the opposite." I thought to myself, I've always loved how she calls me by my full name.
[2004-01-09 04:46:10] Cabinet Street apartment bedroom | I felt her moving closer toward me. I said to him wistfully, "This is all too complicated for me—can we just sleep here for now? And have breakfast together before I leave, would you like that?" I heard her reply, "I'd love to."
[2004-01-09 04:47:00] Cabinet Street apartment bedroom | I felt her body radiating warmth like a stove. I ran my fingers through her hair and gently kissed her lips. I saw her close her eyes and tilt her head back. I asked her, "What did you say?"
[2004-01-09 04:47:10] Cabinet Street apartment bedroom | I noticed she didn't answer me, but instead took my hand and placed it on her belly. I heard her say, "There!" Then her voice came again in my ear, "Can you feel it?"
[2004-01-09 04:47:20] Cabinet Street apartment bedroom | I felt a hard lump suddenly rise beneath my palm on her skin. I noticed myself lifting my hand to look at it. I couldn't help exclaiming, "Oh!"
[2004-01-09 04:48:00] Cabinet Street apartment bedroom | I heard Nils Nils say, "She's lost patience—I know it." I saw her belly being pushed upward from within, the skin bulging outward as if something were pressing against it, like ripples beneath calm water, then fading away.
[2004-01-09 04:48:10] Cabinet Street apartment bedroom | I asked her, "That's a foot, right?" I heard her softly confirm it. I added, "It seems like she's trying to come out this way." I noticed Nils Nils chuckled.
[2004-01-09 04:48:20] Cabinet Street apartment bedroom | I asked her, "Does it hurt?" I saw her shake her head at me. Her voice came again, "I can feel it, but it doesn't hurt—just strange, incredible." I replied, "Totally understand."
[2004-01-09 04:50:00] Cabinet Street apartment bedroom | I pressed myself tightly against her and placed my hand on her belly once more. Finally, I closed my eyes. I heard the mailbox flap in the hallway snap shut. A truck passed outside, its sound reaching my ears, and I felt the windowpanes vibrate.
[2004-01-09 05:00:00] Cabinet Street apartment bedroom | I felt the thoughts and images in my consciousness moving uncontrollably. I lay there like a lazy sheepdog of thought, aware that sleep was just within reach, so I let myself sink into the darkness.
[2004-01-09 10:55:00] Cabinet Street apartment bedroom | I woke up from my sleep. I noticed the clock on the mantelpiece showed five minutes to eleven, and inwardly grumbled that this was a damn weekday. I heard Nils Nils rummaging around in the kitchen.
locations: in front of the bedroom window in Cabinet Street apartment

text:
[2004-01-09 11:00:00] Cabinet Street apartment kitchen | I got dressed and walked into the kitchen. I noticed the toaster had just popped up two perfectly toasted slices of bread. Before me stood a small coffee pot hissing on the electric stove, juice and various spreads laid out on the table. I saw two crisp slices of toast already placed on a plate.
[2004-01-09 11:01:00] Cabinet Street apartment kitchen | I sat down at the table. I heard her ask me, 'Did you sleep well?' I replied, 'Yes, I did.'
[2004-01-09 11:02:00] Cabinet Street apartment kitchen | I buttered the toast, watching the fat instantly melt and fill the tiny pores in the bread. I noticed Nils Nils moved the coffee pot away and turned off the stove.
[2004-01-09 11:03:00] Cabinet Street apartment kitchen | To me, her huge belly made it seem as though she was always leaning backward. I noticed that when she worked, her hands appeared as if reaching out from an invisible wall.
[2004-01-09 11:04:00] Cabinet Street apartment kitchen | Outside, the sky was gray and overcast. I realized the light inside was brighter than usual, guessing the roof must have been covered with fresh snow again.
[2004-01-09 11:05:00] Cabinet Street apartment kitchen | I saw her bring over the coffee, pour it into cups, and place one in front of me. I noticed her face looked somewhat swollen, and saw her nod at me. I asked her, 'Are you feeling unwell?'
[2004-01-09 11:06:00] Cabinet Street apartment kitchen | I watched her lower her heavy body awkwardly into a chair and add a little milk to her coffee. I heard her complain, 'I feel awful—my whole body aches, and I think I have a fever.'
[2004-01-09 11:07:00] Cabinet Street apartment kitchen | I heard her sigh, 'Just my luck—I end up getting sick now, precisely when I need all my strength the most.'
[2004-01-09 11:08:00] Cabinet Street apartment kitchen | I comforted her, saying, "Labor might be delayed—it shouldn't come until you've recovered your health."
[2004-01-09 11:09:00] Cabinet Street apartment kitchen | I felt her gaze fall upon me. I swallowed the last bite of bread and drained the rest of the juice in my cup. I inwardly remarked that if there was one thing I'd learned over these past months, it was that the rumor about pregnant women's emotions being volatile and unpredictable was absolutely true.
[2004-01-09 11:10:00] Cabinet Street apartment kitchen | Our eyes met. I took a sip of juice. I heard her challenge me, "Don't you understand this is a disaster?"
[2004-01-09 11:11:00] Cabinet Street apartment kitchen | I nodded repeatedly and said, "I understand, I do, of course. But this will pass—everything will pass."
[2004-01-09 11:12:00] Cabinet Street apartment kitchen | I heard her say, "Of course it will pass, but that’s not the point. What I mean is, I don’t want to be sick or weak when I give birth."
[2004-01-09 11:13:00] Cabinet Street apartment kitchen | I saw us continuing our meal in silence. She said to me, "I know, but you won’t actually get sick—it’s still a few days away."
[2004-01-09 11:15:00] Cabinet Street apartment kitchen | I saw her look up at me again. Her beautiful gray-green eyes met mine, and I noticed that when tired, her eyes would slightly cross. I recalled her appearance in the poetry book photos, remembering the fragility in those crossed eyes. I thought about how that fragility clashed with the confidence she projected—an opposing tension that had once completely captivated me.
[2004-01-09 11:16:00] Cabinet Street apartment kitchen | I heard her apologize, "Sorry, I'm just so nervous." I replied, "You don't have to be. I know you're someone who always prepares thoroughly for everything."
[2004-01-09 11:17:00] Cabinet Street apartment kitchen | As far as I knew, she truly was someone who needed to have future events under control. I knew she had read extensively on the subject and listened every night to meditation tapes, where a lullaby-like voice endlessly repeated the idea that pain wasn't frightening and was even something positive.
[2004-01-09 11:18:00] Cabinet Street apartment kitchen | I remembered attending training sessions with her and visiting obstetrics demonstrations. From what I’d seen, she always wrote down prepared questions for the midwives and carefully recorded all charts and testing methods in her journal.
[2004-01-09 11:19:00] Cabinet Street apartment kitchen | I learned that she had sent a letter in advance to the maternity ward as requested. I knew she mentioned in the letter that she would feel uneasy there and needed encouragement, but she also expressed her wish to give birth on her own strength without anesthesia.
[2004-01-09 11:20:00] Cabinet Street apartment kitchen | I sensed the faint metallic smell of blood and entrails still hanging in the air in that room. I saw midwives constantly moving in and out of different rooms, and I kept hearing various cries, screams, and low moans from pregnant women. As far as I knew, although the maternity ward tried to create a homelike environment with sofas, carpets, and paintings, it was essentially a space reused by countless mothers. I understood that due to the endless cycle, even after cleaning, that unique odor still lingered. I felt both pained and moved. I thought about how, for the midwives working there, all of this was just an endless repetition, yet Nils Nils had expressed in that letter the most sincere hope and passion for this moment.
[2004-01-09 11:25:00] Cabinet Street apartment kitchen | I saw her gazing out the window, so I followed her gaze and looked out as well. Before me was the roof of the opposite building, where I saw a man tied around the waist with a rope standing there shoveling snow.
[2004-01-09 11:25:10] Cabinet Street apartment kitchen | I remarked, "People in this country are crazy." I heard Nils Nils ask me if Leivik was like that too, and I replied no, then asked her if she was crazy as well.
[2004-01-09 11:26:00] Cabinet Street apartment kitchen | I learned that a year before I arrived here, a boy had been killed by a falling ice block from a roof. I knew that ever since, all roof snow had to be cleared away. I knew that every warm season, sidewalks would be blocked off with red and white tape, turning everything into chaos.
[2004-01-09 11:27:00] Cabinet Street apartment kitchen | I quickly gulped down my bread and stood up to finish the last sip of coffee in my cup. I said, "But at least all these precautions have boosted employment. I'm off now."
[2004-01-09 11:28:00] Cabinet Street apartment kitchen | I heard Nils Nils say "Alright," and she asked me if I could rent a few movies on my way home. I replied of course, and asked if anything would do. She told me it didn't matter and told me to pick whatever I liked.
[2004-01-09 11:30:00] Cabinet Street apartment bathroom | I went to the bathroom to brush my teeth. As I walked down the hallway to get dressed, I noticed Nils Nils following behind me.
[2004-01-09 11:31:00] Cabinet Street apartment hallway | I took my coat from the closet with one hand while wrapping my scarf around my neck with the other. I asked her, "What are you going to do today?" I heard her reply, "Not sure, maybe go to the park, then take a shower."
[2004-01-09 11:31:10] Cabinet Street apartment hallway | I asked her worriedly, "Are you going to be okay?" I heard her answer confidently, "Yes, no problem."
[2004-01-09 11:31:20] Cabinet Street apartment hallway | I bent down to tie my shoelace. Her huge belly came into view; I noticed one of her hands propping up her waist, looming large above me.
[2004-01-09 11:32:00] Cabinet Street apartment hallway | I pushed my hat firmly onto my head and grabbed my laptop backpack. I said, 'OK, I'm off.' I heard her say 'OK' in reply, telling me to call if anything came up, and I promised I would.
[2004-01-09 11:32:10] Cabinet Street apartment hallway | I watched as we kissed goodbye, then I closed the door behind me and heard it shut at my back.

[2004-01-09 11:33:00] Cabinet Street apartment stairwell | I saw the elevator beside the corridor rising. As the neighbor from upstairs passed within my line of sight, I glanced briefly at her and saw her lower her face toward the mirror before her.
[2004-01-09 11:33:10] Cabinet Street apartment stairwell | As far as I know, she is a lawyer. I often see her wearing black trousers or black blouses reaching to her knees, and she always seems to greet people with a hostile expression.
[2004-01-09 11:34:00] Cabinet Street apartment stairwell | I learned that for a time her brother lived there—a man with dark, somewhat fierce eyes but strikingly handsome. I knew that one of Nils Nils’s girlfriends had fallen for him and become involved with him. From my observations, when I spoke with him in the hallway, his eyes seemed restless. Based on what I’ve gathered, he might be a drug user.
[2004-01-09 11:35:00] Cabinet Street apartment stairwell | I realized I actually know nothing about these complicated matters and hidden truths. I know that Karl Larsdal is truly the only friend I have in Halvik. I thought that in some ways I really am like what Karl Larsdal described. I realized I’m just like the deceived figure in Caravaggio’s painting *The Cardsharps*.
[2004-01-09 11:40:00] Cabinet Street apartment courtyard | I walked through the long corridor past the basement laundry room and out into the courtyard. I set my backpack on the ground and leaned against the wall, looking upward. Around me was the apartment courtyard.
[2004-01-09 11:41:00] Cabinet Street apartment courtyard | I felt the building's ventilation outlet directly above me, and smelled the warm, freshly-washed laundry scent in the air. [2004-01-09 11:45:00] Cabinet Street apartment courtyard | I walked to the far end of the courtyard near the fence bordering the kindergarten behind, leaned my elbows on the wall, and stood smoking. [2004-01-09 11:46:00] Cabinet Street Apartment Courtyard | To my knowledge, these towers were built in a neo-baroque style and stand as historical witnesses of the 1920s. I inwardly marvel that these buildings often fill me with a sense of nostalgia.
[2004-01-09 11:47:00] Cabinet Street Apartment Courtyard | I see the towers glowing brilliantly at night; I notice the different building materials on the walls and windows, and how the gilded statues shimmer against green patinated copper panels under artificial lighting. I feel as though the statues might begin to speak at night. I think their vividness may come from some assistance of artificial light. Their daytime indifference transforms into a strange liveliness after dark.
[2004-01-09 11:50:00] Cabinet Street Apartment Courtyard | I observe the street filled with passing cars, helicopters hovering in the sky like dragonflies. I see children climbing, riding bikes, sliding down slides on the playground, and hear their shouts and screams as they throw balls and run. I feel that daytime is full of distractions that make it hard to stay focused. I notice that by afternoon, the entire courtyard becomes noisy with shrill sounds like a flock of birds in the forest, but everything quiets down again at mealtime.
[2004-01-09 11:51:00] Cabinet Street Apartment Courtyard | I think it would be impossible to stay outside at other times—not because of the noise, but because I fear that group of children might swarm over to me all at once.
[2004-01-09 11:52:00] Cabinet Street Apartment Courtyard | I remember encountering this several times last autumn—four or five children hanging on the fence of the courtyard. I know that if they get bored, they’ll start talking to me and burst into loud laughter.
[2004-01-09 11:53:00] Cabinet Street Apartment Courtyard | I understand that the boy who climbs to the front often sits alone in the sandbox. [2004-01-09 11:54:00] Cabinet Street Apartment Courtyard | I often wonder how liberating it would be to cut away these inner feelings of sentimentality, pity, and compassion, as one might remove injured cartilage.
[2004-01-09 11:55:00] Cabinet Street Apartment Courtyard | A sudden, extremely piercing and prolonged scream erupts in my ears, sounding like: “Aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa.”
[2004-01-09 11:55:10] Cabinet Street Apartment Courtyard | I jump in fright from that scream. I know the scream comes from the apartment building opposite the kindergarten, which belongs to the nursing home. Although I’ve grown accustomed to it, I still find such sounds deeply unsettling.

[2004-01-09 11:57:00] Cabinet Street apartment courtyard | I walked toward the direction of the gate. I had learned that residents from the old people's home occasionally appeared on the street—sometimes brought back by police, sometimes lingering at the roadside. I realized I normally never think about what goes on inside the old people's home, just as I avoid thinking too much about that scream.
[2004-01-09 11:58:00] Cabinet Street apartment courtyard | I looked up for a while, then turned and walked toward the courtyard gate. I hung my coat and scarf on the wall hooks, took off my shoes on the mat, then made a cup of coffee and plugged in the computer. [2004-01-09 12:25:00] Holvik City Center Office | Before me was William Blake’s blurred painting of Newton hanging behind me, along with engravings from the eighteenth-century age of exploration I’d bought at Shannest: dead whales and dissected beetles. The bookshelves were piled high with books by Paracelsus, Augustine, the Bible, and works on Baroque style and atomic physics. I saw the title displayed on the screen was 'The American Soul.' I realized that every object in the room seemed focused on this theme. I thought that although the origins of this knowledge mostly lay outside the modern world, they still radiated an astonishing aura through the sheen of history.
[2004-01-09 12:30:00] Holvik City Center Office | I felt that in recent years, the world had somehow grown smaller, and the sense of having everything under control had become increasingly strong. Though rationally I understood the world was vast and unpredictable, sensorially, it felt already known—nothing truly new would ever happen again. I thought I understood myself and my surroundings, and even when encountering unclear phenomena, I knew how to figure them out.
[2004-01-09 12:35:00] Holvik City Center Office | I realized understanding should not be confused with knowledge; though I lacked knowledge in many fields, this didn’t prevent my mind from classifying the unfamiliar. I reflected that even children differ only in their degree of progress along the path of understanding the world. I thought that those who truly understand more often possess a heightened awareness of the boundaries of understanding—aware of a far greater, incomprehensible world beyond themselves.
[2004-01-09 12:40:00] Holvik City Center Office | I watched the pen in my hand, the sunlit windowpane, and students dressed for autumn standing at the courtyard crossroads. I sensed the smell of soil and leaves from her clothes sitting beside me. In my ears rang the sounds of road workers digging, the hum of a transformer, and the deep rumble beneath the entire city. I recalled that at nineteen, I encountered the assertion that 'the world is linguistic structure.' I pondered all that had happened, wondering whether for me this was merely a child’s world where I assumed I knew everything. I remembered rejecting back then the idea that the world was linguistic structure, considering it utter nonsense. I thought the world I touched, breathed, and encountered was real—calling it linguistic structure seemed absurd.
[2004-01-09 12:45:00] Holvik City Center Office | I learned that Nietzsche once wrote in a quotation that physics is merely an interpretation of the world, and that what we measure with our classifications is actually a purely fictional world. I thought the world is simply the world—I touch it, bleed, vomit. Years later, I began for the first time to see it differently. I came to grasp what Nietzsche meant—that the values we measure actually belong to a fictional world.
[2004-01-09 12:50:00] Holvik City Center Office | I reflected on this fictional mental world—abstract yet capable of movement within thought. I realized that in the history of natural science, everything has become transparent and explainable. I felt the entire material world being lifted into the realm of the fictional. I thought I tried to resist through fiction, yet in doing so only brought about my own failure. I recalled those fleeting moments when I seemed to glimpse an entirely different world—only for it to quickly withdraw, leaving everything as before.

[2004-01-09 12:55:00] Håvik city center office | I saw the landscape outside the window as a pure white expanse, with a gray, damp sky above. I saw the sun sinking in the west, a vivid red orb floating in the mist. I remember this was from an experience months earlier, riding the commuter train toward Håvik. I recalled the intense surge of joy striking my heart, a feeling so strong it was almost indistinguishable from pain. I realized this experience held profound significance for me. I thought about how, once that moment passed, the great meaning suddenly seemed out of place—why, I wondered, should such deep significance arise on a train journey through a factory district?

[2004-01-09 13:05:00] Håvik city center office | I realized I didn’t know the exact reason why these paintings made such a powerful impression on me. [2004-01-09 13:10:00] Håvik city center office | I thought about the strangeness and mystery that touches us, guiding my thoughts toward angels. I reflected on how modern art has become a self-contained world, where spirit has claimed everything. I realized that in our time, we understand everything because we do everything for ourselves, probing at the edges of language, yet finding no answers in the unfamiliar world outside.
[2004-01-09 13:15:00] Håvik city center office | I thought that in that beam of light, we must have seen the ambiguous and strange figure of death stepping in—and yet it had always already been within this world.
