[2004-01-30 19:05:00] hospital room | I saw Nils Nils nod at me. As soon as I lifted my hands from the massage, she roared. I pressed the button to call the previous nurse to take over. I stopped massaging, watched the nurse continue working, then seized those two minutes to quickly shovel noodles into my mouth with a fork before resuming the massage. I asked Nils Nils if I could eat. I heard her shout, 'No, don’t!' I heard the nurse say, 'Of course you can.' Then I heard Nils Nils scream, 'No, I want Grete Lundnes! I want Grete Lundnes! This is too light!' I saw Nils Nils regain her usual rhythm.
[2004-01-30 20:00:00] hospital room | I saw the midwife walk in, turn Nils Nils onto her side without hesitation, and check how many fingers dilated she was. I heard Nils Nils's scream—a full-force, uncompromising cry. All I saw was the cycle of contractions, nitrous oxide, massage, and rest—nothing else. I felt this was a different kind of scream.
[2004-01-30 20:30:00] hospital room | I watched her get up again. null null null I saw that she had found her own rhythm, as if detached from this world. I realized that several hours had just passed.
[2004-01-30 20:30:05] hospital room | I was startled by the sudden loud cry. I heard her suddenly shout: "Is it only us?" null null null
[2004-01-30 20:30:10] hospital room | null I heard myself reply: "Yes." null null null
[2004-01-30 20:30:15] hospital room | I looked at her, feeling my eyes fill with tears. I heard her cry out: "I love you, Grete Lundnes!" null null I thought how the words seemed to come from the deepest part of her being, a place she had never been to and I had never reached.
[2004-01-30 20:30:20] hospital room | I watched another contraction surge over her. null null I realized she hadn't heard me.
[2004-01-30 22:00:00] hospital room | I continued massaging her, my eyes fixed on the monitor. null null null I watched time pass—eight, nine, ten o'clock—my mind almost blank. Then suddenly a thought flashed through: a child is about to be born. I realized that in just a few hours, we would truly have a child.
[2004-01-30 22:05:00] hospital room | null null null null I thought that although the thought had flashed by, everything before me still returned to charts, numbers, touch, lower back, rhythm, and those cries.
[2004-01-30 23:00:00] hospital room | I saw the door open, and an elderly midwife walked in, followed by a young girl. I saw the woman lean close to Nils Nils's face and introduce herself. I saw Nils Nils nod and look for the intern's presence. I heard the midwife praise Nils Nils for doing well and ask if she could bring in an intern. I heard the midwife comfort her, saying it would soon be over, and say she wanted to examine her. I saw their faces extremely close, only two or three centimeters apart. null null
[2004-01-30 23:02:00] hospital room | I saw Nils Nils nod again. I heard the midwife whisper softly: "That's right, good girl." I watched the way she looked at the midwife, which seemed to me like a child looking at her mother. null null
[2004-01-30 23:05:00] hospital room | I saw her lying there, stroking her forehead. Then I saw the midwife take her hand away. I heard Nils Nils shout loudly: "Is it done?" I saw her staring blankly with those large, dark eyes, as if she didn't feel my presence at all. null I noticed she didn't scream this time.
[2004-01-30 23:05:05] hospital room | I saw Nils Nils patiently get back up and resume her original position. I heard the midwife reply, "Just a little while longer."
[2004-01-30 23:05:10] hospital room | I heard the midwife say to me, "An hour, maybe less."
[2004-01-30 23:05:15] hospital room | I looked down at my watch. I realized it was already eleven o'clock—Nils Nils had been enduring this for eight hours straight.
[2004-01-30 23:10:00] hospital room | I saw the midwife remove all the belts and wires. I heard the midwife say, "We can take these off now." I saw her sitting there, no longer bound by monitors. I realized she was suddenly free. Looking at her body lying on the bed, I thought how the pain she was battling was no longer just waveforms and numbers on a screen, but something real happening inside her.
[2004-01-30 23:10:05] hospital room | I remembered that I hadn't truly understood this before. Now I realized the pain was within her—she was fighting entirely on her own. I felt she was free.
[2004-01-30 23:10:10] hospital room | I pushed with all my strength, pressing both hands against her back. I heard her say, "It's coming." I realized that sensation was rising from within her. I thought in that moment there was only her and what was inside her—no hospital, no monitors, no books or corridors—only her and the being within.
[2004-01-30 23:15:00] hospital room | I saw the intern stay behind, wiping foreheads, handing water, offering chocolate bars. I saw Nils Nils grab the chocolate greedily. I heard the midwife say she'd be right back. I saw her white gown loosely wrapped around her, her hair disheveled, her body slick with sweat. I sensed she was nearing her breaking point. I noticed her impatience with rest—her contractions were coming much too close together now.
[2004-01-30 23:20:00] hospital room | I saw the midwife return. She dimmed the lights. I watched Nils Nils lie down as the midwife gently stroked her face. Then I walked over to the window, and turned once more to look at her. I heard the midwife say, "Lie down, rest a bit." I saw no cars on the road below, only heavy snow swirling around the streetlights. The room was silent. Looking at Nils Nils, I thought she seemed to have fallen asleep.
[2004-01-30 23:25:00] hospital room | I saw the midwife give me a small smile. I watched her take hold of one of Nils Nils’s arms and help her sit up. I saw Nils Nils groan, her eyes wide and dark like a forest at night.
[2004-01-30 23:25:05] hospital room | I heard the midwife command, "Push."

[2004-01-30 23:25:10] hospital ward | I moved behind her and started massaging her back again. I saw Nils Nils grab the nitrous oxide mask and greedily inhaling it. I heard that drawn-out, heart-wrenching cry, as if it would never subside. I realized something unusual was happening, different from before, but I couldn't pinpoint exactly what it was. I wondered if the nitrous oxide seemed to have lost its effect.
[2004-01-30 23:28:00] hospital ward | I saw the pain recede and Nils Nils collapse weakly. I noticed the midwife wiping the sweat from her forehead, praising her as a good girl. I heard the midwife ask, 'Do you want to touch your baby?'
[2004-01-30 23:28:10] hospital ward | I saw Nils Nils lift her face toward the midwife, slowly nodding, then kneel upright. I noticed the midwife take her hand and guide it between her legs. I heard the midwife say, 'That's the head—can you feel it?'
[2004-01-30 23:28:15] hospital ward | I heard Nils Nils reply, 'Yes!'
[2004-01-30 23:28:20] hospital ward | I heard the midwife instruct, 'Support it with your hand, then push hard. Can you do it?'
[2004-01-30 23:28:25] hospital ward | I heard Nils Nils say firmly, 'Yes!'
[2004-01-30 23:28:30] hospital ward | I saw the midwife help Nils Nils down to the floor; I noticed the intern pick up a stool that had been standing by the wall. I heard the midwife say, 'Come here, stand right here.'
[2004-01-30 23:30:00] hospital ward | I saw Nils Nils kneeling upright, and I moved behind her. I silently mused that somehow, massage no longer seemed to help.
[2004-01-30 23:30:10] hospital ward | I saw her gripping the baby’s head with one hand, her whole body shifting forward, and I heard her raw, guttural scream ringing in my ears.
[2004-01-30 23:30:15] hospital ward | I heard the midwife say, 'The head is out—just one more push. Push hard.'
[2004-01-30 23:30:20] hospital ward | I heard Nils Nils ask urgently, "The head's out?! You said the head's out?"
[2004-01-30 23:30:25] hospital ward | I heard the midwife encourage, "Yes, now push."
[2004-01-30 23:30:30] hospital ward | I heard her cry out again, a sound that seemed to pierce through everything.
[2004-01-30 23:30:35] hospital ward | I noticed the midwife was looking at me. I heard the midwife ask, "Will you hold her?"
[2004-01-30 23:30:40] hospital ward | I replied, "Okay."
[2004-01-30 23:30:45] hospital ward | I stepped around the stool and stood in front of Nils Nils, seeing her look at me with dazed eyes. I heard the midwife say, "Come over here, stand right here."
[2004-01-30 23:30:50] hospital ward | I heard the midwife say, "One more time. Push now, good girl. Push." I marveled inwardly—tears filled my eyes at that moment.
[2004-01-30 23:31:00] hospital ward | I saw the baby slide out of her body, like a little seal, plopping into my hands.
[2004-01-30 23:31:05] hospital ward | I screamed wildly, "Ohhhhhhhh! Ohhhhhhhhh!"
[2004-01-30 23:31:10] hospital ward | I felt the tiny body warm and slippery in my hands, nearly slipping away, but the young intern helped steady it. I lifted the small form and held it toward her as she pressed it against her chest. I noticed Nils Nils saw me for the first time in hours—she smiled. I wept aloud with joy. I heard Nils Nils ask, "She's out? She's out?" I answered, "Yes."
[2004-01-30 23:32:00] hospital ward | I opened my mouth and asked, "What is this?"
[2004-01-30 23:32:05] hospital ward | I heard Nils Nils say, "Girl, Grete Lundnes. It's a girl."
[2004-01-30 23:35:00] hospital ward | I saw her hair was long and black, stuck to her scalp, her skin pale gray as if waxed. A scream rang by my ear—it was my daughter’s voice. I felt everything around me had come to a standstill, and all was dark. I thought to myself, I had never heard such a sound before—like stepping onto the peak of the world. I thought, we’re all here, and this little baby is that beam of light.
[2004-01-30 23:40:00] hospital ward | I saw them help Nils Nils onto the bed, as she found a more comfortable position to lie down. I noticed the little girl lifting her head and looking at us. Before my eyes, the girl’s skin began to turn red.
[2004-01-30 23:41:00] hospital ward | Her eyes came into view—like two black lamps.
[2004-01-30 23:42:00] hospital ward | I heard Nils Nils murmur, "Hi... sweetie..."
[2004-01-30 23:43:00] hospital ward | I saw the baby lift one arm, then let it fall, then lift the other, stretch it out slightly, then let it drop again. I thought to myself, the movement was like that of a reptile—like a crocodile or a monitor lizard.
[2004-01-30 23:44:00] hospital ward | Those two black eyes were staring straight at Nils Nils.
[2004-01-30 23:45:00] hospital ward | I heard Nils Nils say tenderly, "Yes, I’m your mom. This is your dad! Can you see us?"
[2004-01-30 23:50:00] hospital ward | I gazed at this sudden new life, watching as the two women began tidying up around us. I noticed both Nils Nils and the baby were covered in blood. I smelled a sharp, metallic odor coming from both of them, making every breath feel unfamiliar.
[2004-01-31 00:00:00] hospital ward | I saw Nils Nils bring the girl close to her breast, and I noticed the little girl was straining to look at us. I saw the midwife walk in carrying a tray of food, a glass of apple juice, and a Mochengdao flag. I watched them take the baby to measure and weigh her; I heard the child's cries, but I saw she quieted as soon as she was placed back against her chest. I silently marveled—this flawless tenderness in every gesture of the child was a completely new experience for me.
[2004-01-31 00:10:00] hospital ward | Looking at the child before me, I asked, “Is this Vanja?”
[2004-01-31 00:10:05] hospital ward | I noticed Nils Nils was staring intently at me. I heard her reply, “Of course she is, can’t you tell?”
[2004-01-31 00:10:10] hospital ward | I turned to look at Nils Nils again. I whispered to the baby, “Hi, little Vanja.” I remarked that she resembled something we’d once found in the forest.
[2004-01-31 00:10:15] hospital ward | I saw Nils Nils nod at me. I heard her affectionately call her, “Our little monster.”
[2004-01-31 00:30:00] hospital ward | I saw the midwife approach the bedside. I heard the midwife tell us it was time to go to our own room, and suggest we might want to dress the baby.
[2004-01-31 00:30:05] hospital ward | I noticed Nils Nils was staring at me. I heard her ask me, “Will you come?”
[2004-01-31 00:35:00] hospital ward | I nodded, gently lifted the tiny, fragile body to the foot of the bed, took out her sleepwear from the bag, and began dressing her with infinite care. I heard her crying beside me in that strange little voice.
[2004-01-31 00:40:00] hospital ward | I heard the midwife compliment Nils Nils, saying she really knew how to give birth, and jokingly added she should have many more.
[2004-01-31 00:40:05] hospital ward | I heard Nils Nils thank her and respond that she thought it was the finest compliment she'd ever received.
[2004-01-31 00:40:10] hospital ward | I heard the midwife continue musing that when you think about how the child got such a start, it would benefit her for life.
[2004-01-31 00:40:15] hospital ward | I heard Nils Nils retort, 'Really?'
[2004-01-31 00:40:20] hospital ward | I heard the midwife affirm that it definitely mattered. She congratulated us and wished us good night, mentioning she’d probably stop by again tomorrow morning, though she couldn’t be sure.
[2004-01-31 00:40:25] hospital ward | I heard Nils Nils repeatedly thank her, exclaiming how wonderful they had been.
[2004-01-31 00:45:00] hospital corridor | I saw Nils Nils staggering down the corridor toward the room, and I followed closely beside her. I held Vanja tightly in my arms, noticing her eyes were wide open, staring at the ceiling.

[2004-01-31 00:50:00] new hospital room | I saw that as soon as we entered the room, we turned off the lights and went to bed. I noticed Nils Nils kept putting Vanja to her breast, but the baby didn't seem very interested. I heard the two of us talk for a long time, discussing everything that had just happened.
[2004-01-31 01:30:00] new hospital room | I reassured Nils Nils, saying, 'From now on, you'll never have to fear anything again.'
[2004-01-31 01:30:05] new hospital room | I heard Nils Nils respond that she felt the same way.
[2004-01-31 02:00:00] outdoors downstairs from hospital | I noticed they had both finally fallen asleep. I took the elevator downstairs, smoked a cigarette, and called Mom. I heard myself say to Mom, 'Hi, it's me, Grete Lundnes.' I felt still awake and restless, convinced I had to do something. Maybe it was because I hadn't done anything before—that must have been the reason.
[2004-01-31 02:01:00] outdoors downstairs from hospital | I heard Mom quickly ask how things were going and whether we were still at the hospital.
[2004-01-31 02:01:10] outdoor area downstairs at the hospital | I told my mother we had a girl. I noticed my voice cracking.
[2004-01-31 02:01:20] outdoor area downstairs at the hospital | I heard my mother exclaim, 'Oh my, oh my,' saying she couldn't believe it was a girl, and urgently asked about Nils Nils.
[2004-01-31 02:01:30] outdoor area downstairs at the hospital | I told her everything was fine, quite good indeed.
[2004-01-31 02:01:40] outdoor area downstairs at the hospital | I heard my mother congratulate me, marveling that this was truly wonderful.
[2004-01-31 02:01:50] outdoor area downstairs at the hospital | I agreed with her, but said I just wanted to let her know first, and we could talk more tomorrow. I admitted I probably couldn't say much now.
[2004-01-31 02:02:00] outdoor area downstairs at the hospital | I answered my mother with 'Of course.' After hanging up, I dialed the phone number of Nils Nils's mother. I heard my mother say she understood, and asked me to send her regards and congratulations to Nils Nils.
[2004-01-31 02:05:00] hospital parking lot downstairs | I noticed she cried when I told her the news. I lit another cigarette and said the same thing again. After hanging up, I called Henrik Inge, then lit another cigarette. I paced back and forth in the parking lot, holding the phone to my ear. I was in a parking lot bathed in dim yellow light. Even though I knew the temperature must have been below minus ten degrees, I was only wearing a shirt, yet felt warm all over. I thought talking to Henrik Inge would be easier, so I chatted with him for a few minutes.
[2004-01-31 02:15:00] hospital parking lot downstairs | I put away the phone and began walking up and down the corridor. I lit another cigarette, took two puffs, then threw it away, and ran toward the main entrance. I aimlessly stared at everything around me. I wanted to share my inner feelings with someone, but found no one. I kept thinking—they are upstairs right now, both of them!
[2004-01-31 02:30:00] new hospital ward | I saw Nils Nils sleeping soundly, the little one lying on her chest. I watched them for a while, then took out my notebook, turned on the lamp, and sat down in the chair. I had wanted to write something about all this, but realized it was a foolish idea—I simply couldn't put pen to paper.
[2004-01-31 02:45:00] hospital TV room | I went to the TV room and pinned a pink thumbtack onto the wall chart that recorded all the babies' birth dates. As far as I knew, girls were marked with pink on the chart, boys with blue. I remembered this, and felt that the pink thumbtack represented the lovely Vanja.
[2004-01-31 03:00:00] hospital/outdoor | After walking up and down the corridor for a while, I took the elevator downstairs and smoked two cigarettes before returning upstairs to lie on the bed. I felt as if my heart had suddenly opened completely, able to embrace everything. I realized the world I was in was full of meaning, and marveled at how anyone could possibly fall asleep in such a state.
[2004-01-31 04:00:00] new hospital ward | I felt myself finally drift off to sleep.
[2004-02-10 10:00:00] hospital/parking lot | I saw everything as so fresh and fragile that even dressing her became a major task. I noticed Helene waiting for us downstairs in her car, and watched as it took us half an hour just to get the baby ready, before I carried her out of the elevator. I heard Helene burst out laughing: "In this freezing cold, you're not seriously thinking of taking her out dressed like that?" I thought to myself, oh no, we hadn't thought of that at all.
[2004-02-10 10:30:00] parking lot | I saw Helene wrapped tightly in her down jacket, and noticed we hurried across the parking lot. I watched myself carrying the child seat in one hand. I saw Vanja swaying back and forth in the car seat.
[2004-02-10 11:00:00] new apartment | I saw Nils Nils sitting there holding Vanja, crying. I noticed myself constantly moving around the apartment, busy cooking, washing, or running errands, trying to keep myself in constant motion. I realized we were truly on our own now. I felt an uncontrollable restlessness and urgency, and found I couldn't sit still.
[2004-02-10 11:00:00] new apartment | I felt the light had not left us, nor had the silence vanished. I seemed to see a wall of peace rising up around us. I observed that Nils Nils simply wanted to sit quietly, holding the child against his chest. I thought to myself, this is truly extraordinary.
[2004-02-15 10:00:00] Håvik | I knew he had volunteered as a human shield in Baghdad, and returned to Håvik with tapes full of interviews. I understood he had been somewhat angry with me for some reason before, though I still don't know exactly why. I heard that Karl Larsdal had conducted interviews in Baghdad, and felt amused—yes, that's just like him. I realized we had reconciled our friendship.
[2004-02-20 10:00:00] new apartment/Oxhøg writing cabin | I watched myself spend ten days in calm and serenity. I noticed I had resumed writing, going to the Oxhøg writing cabin to work on 'Ezekiel'. I felt that inner, unstoppable restlessness. Looking at my little family, I thought: this is my little family—this feeling filled me with deep happiness.
[2004-03-01 09:00:00] new apartment | I noticed myself beginning to manage the new routines brought on by having a child. I learned that Nils Nils was anxious about being left alone with the child. I knew we needed money, and that the novel had to be published by autumn. I realized I must fully commit myself to writing.
[2004-03-01 10:00:00] Oxhøg writing cabin | I thought to myself, writing a novel about sandals and camels—this really won't work.
[2004-03-01 11:00:00] Oksfjord Office | I saw myself writing something down in my notebook. I recalled having written in my notes thoughts like 'the Bible reappears in Leivik.' I realized these ideas were difficult to handle for a novel, but I decided to start writing anyway.
[2004-03-05 15:00:00] New Apartment | I wrote about Cain hammering at the rocks in the twilight. I watched Nils Nils sitting in a chair listening as I read aloud, and I noticed the look of appreciation on her face. I heard myself ask Nils Nils if I could read it to her, and tell her I thought it was terribly silly. I heard her say to me, 'Oh come on, just read it!' After reading, I kept hearing her praise: 'Fantastic, absolutely fantastic—you must keep writing.'
[2004-03-15 10:00:00] Halvik | I recalled that spring when I moved to Halvik and met Nils Nils. I felt the world suddenly open up, overwhelmed by an intense sense of fullness. I remembered being deeply in love, ready to embrace everything.
[2004-04-01 10:00:00] Oksfjord Office | I watched myself keep writing in the Oksfjord office, continuing all the way to Vanya's baptism day.
locations: outdoor area downstairs at the hospital

text:
[2004-05-15 12:00:00] Jølster | I watched the baptism ceremony take place in May, then noticed we went to Vidal’s summer house on Idøy. I knew the baptism was held at my mother’s place in Jølster.
[2004-05-15 20:00:00] Halvik, Ridarøy | I saw futuristic trains passing through the Slussen district; I noticed the sun reddening the church steeple on Ridarøy. I smelled the fragrance of basil and the scent of freshly ripened tomatoes; I heard footsteps tapping on cobblestones in front of the Hilton Hotel. I recalled during those free days, I felt the surrounding world brimming with meaning. I remembered us sitting hand in hand on a bench, knowing only that our two-person world could last forever.
[2004-05-26 14:00:00] Jølster | I took Vanya for a walk in the valley. I saw that Nils Nils kept expressing dissatisfaction with the house. I saw that Mom had renovated the living room for the celebration, but it still looked like a construction site. I learned we hadn’t originally planned to hold the naming ceremony here. I knew I’d need at least three days to clean up the house. I observed that Nils Nils became furious after arriving a few days early. Though I understood her anger, I found myself unable to agree with her.
[2004-05-26 14:10:00] Valley Path | I heard Nils Nils shouting loudly in the valley: 'Sissel is narrow-minded, inhospitable, cold, and closed off. You don't understand your mother's true nature... you don't understand your mother at all.' I was in a sunlit green valley.
[2004-05-26 14:11:00] Valley Path | I felt a sharp cramp in my stomach from anger. I inwardly sighed—whenever she erupted into what I saw as utterly unreasonable and almost mad rage, I always felt this way.
[2004-05-26 14:12:00] Valley Path | I noticed we were pushing the stroller, nearly running along the valley path. I saw Vanya sleeping in the stroller.
[2004-05-26 14:13:00] valley path | I heard myself say loudly, "This is our daughter's naming ceremony—of course the house has to be cleaned!" I went on, "Mom has to work; she can't spend all her time on us."
[2004-05-26 14:14:00] valley path | I heard Nils Nils retort, "Can't you see? Every time we come back here, you have to work. She's taking advantage, and we never get to be alone together here."
[2004-05-26 14:15:00] valley path | I heard myself snap back, "We're alone together every day! We don't have anything except time alone together!"
[2004-05-26 14:15:30] valley path | I heard Nils Nils say coldly, "She gives us no space at all."
[2004-05-26 14:16:00] valley path | I heard myself challenge her, "What did you say? Space? If anyone gave us space, it was her. Your mother never gave us space." I mentioned how she had said, when Vanya was born, that she didn't want anyone coming over.
[2004-05-26 14:16:30] valley path | I saw Nils Nils fall silent, just gazing into the distance.
[2004-05-26 14:17:00] valley path | I heard myself say to her, "Of course Mom wants to come, Henrik Inge wants to come too... So what happened? Your mom came over when you invited her, and you actually said, 'Just Mom!'" I sighed, saying how she could come, but my mom couldn't.
[2004-05-26 14:18:00] valley path | I heard Nils Nils reply, "But your mom hasn't even visited Vanya. Months have passed."
[2004-05-26 14:18:10] valley path | I heard myself shout, "What did you expect? I told her not to come!"
[2004-05-26 14:18:20] valley path | I heard Nils Nils say to me, "Love, Grete Lundnes—love is something no refusal can stop."
[2004-05-26 14:18:30] valley path | I heard myself blurt out, "Oh my God!"
[2004-05-26 14:19:00] valley path | I saw that neither of us was speaking anymore.
[2004-05-26 14:20:00] valley path | I heard Nils Nils say to me, "Like yesterday, for instance. She stayed sitting with us the whole time, right up until we went to bed."
[2004-05-26 14:20:10] valley path | I replied, "So what?"
[2004-05-26 14:20:20] valley path | I heard her ask, "Is this how my mother lives?"
[2004-05-26 14:21:00] valley path | I shot back, "No, she goes to bed at eight if she thinks you want her to. She'll do anything for us when she's there, sure. But that goddamn doesn't mean it's some natural law. Ever since I left home, I've helped Mom with little things—painting the house, mowing the lawn, doing laundry. What's wrong with that now? What's wrong with helping out a bit? Huh? This time it's not even just for her—it's for us! It's our naming ceremony. Don't you get it?"
[2004-05-26 14:22:00] valley path | I heard Nils Nils say, "You don't understand what this is really about. We haven't come here because you had work and I had to take care of Vanja. That's where we're wrong. Your mother isn't as innocent as you think—she has intentions, calculations."
[2004-05-26 14:23:00] valley path | I thought, I've said everything I could, damn it. I feel like this whole situation is completely fucked up. I cursed inwardly—how the hell did I end up stepping in this giant pile of shit?
[2004-05-26 14:30:00] valley path | I saw that we were walking and arguing, pushing Vanja asleep in her stroller, while I was debating whether or not to spend a few days cleaning my mother's house. I looked up—the sky was clear blue, the sun blazing high. On either side of the river rose steep cliffs, the water swollen with melting snow. All around me lay green pastures dotted with sheep. At the top, the Jostedal Glacier's ice tongue shimmered, the mountain peaks above tinged pale blue, streaked with large patches of snow. The air felt crisp. I felt the beauty of the landscape ache in my chest.
[2004-05-26 14:35:00] valley path | I thought, her unreasonableness knows no bounds. Her ideas seem utterly meaningless to me. But then again, maybe I've gone too far now.
[2004-05-26 14:36:00] valley path | I couldn't help but wonder inwardly: what was she really thinking?
[2004-05-26 14:40:00] valley path | Oh, I realized it now—she had been alone with Vanya all day, from the moment I went to my study until I came home. I sensed how much she had longed for this small family gathering, this naming ceremony, out of her loneliness. And yet I only wanted to retreat into my study to write, especially since after six years of failure, I finally felt I was making progress and didn’t want to stop. I noticed how powerfully these feelings arose within me—they completely took hold of me.
[2004-05-28 10:00:00] Loen | I stayed up the entire night writing a speech for my mother's birthday. I drove through the countryside, passing fjords, mountains, rivers, and farms. When I arrived in Loen, I stayed in the room with Nils Nils and Vanya and took a short nap. Before my eyes lay a picturesque scene: such deep blues, vivid greens, and brilliant whites. I felt the vastness of the space so intensely it startled me. Friday had finally arrived, and I felt a wave of fatigue. I reflected inwardly that in the past, landscapes were merely passing images; now, I could truly experience their beauty.
[2004-05-28 15:00:00] Loen | I saw Nils Nils sleeping beside me, with Vanya resting on her chest. The sound of rushing river water reached my ears, along with the rising and falling noise of a tractor moving across a nearby field. Occasionally, I also heard faint sounds from the front of the house. Looking at Nils Nils asleep, I thought to myself that for her, the earlier quarrel had already vanished without a trace.
[2004-05-28 15:05:00] Loen | I knew I had been through three long emotional relationships and had learned how to respond to conflict with irony and silence. I recalled my childhood, when I had no choice at all. I realized that only I could sulk for weeks on end, harboring resentment solely toward Nils Nils. I regarded this as part of adult life. Being with her seemed to bring me back to that emotionally unstable past, and this tension made life feel unbearable—only in books could I find peace.
[2004-05-28 15:10:00] Loen | I thought: I'm thirty-five now, and I simply want as little inner turmoil and as little mental agitation as possible. I asked myself—surely I should be entitled to that? At the very least, shouldn't I have a chance?
[2004-05-28 15:11:00] Loen | But in my view, things weren't like that at all.

[2004-05-28 18:00:00] on a stone outside the house | I sat on a stone outside the house smoking, flipping through the speech I had already written. I thought about how giving speeches felt to me like a plague. The mere idea of standing on stage made me unbearably nervous—I would feel paralyzed, even unable to walk. I realized this anxiety was actually a phase of neurosis, one that caused me pain and was hard to escape.
[2004-05-28 18:30:00] on the road in Loen | I stood up and walked heavily down the road. The whole village lay before me. I saw fertile green fields, deciduous trees lining the riverbanks. The fjord lay calm, its waters a blend of blue and green. Across the water, farms perched high on the hillsides sparkled in the evening light. As the sun sank lower, the exposed mountain slopes turned dark blue, the sky remained clear. I noticed the first stars beginning to shimmer faintly in the night sky. Gazing at the landscape ahead, I thought to myself that all of this was beyond our comprehension.
[2004-05-28 18:40:00] on the road in Loen | I pondered how this scene transcended human understanding. Though we often deceive ourselves into believing our little world is everything, honestly I asked myself—what role do we slaves really play within such a sublime vision?
[2004-05-28 18:41:00] Lern Road | I thought, the answer is nothing.
[2004-05-28 18:45:00] Lern Road | The stars shimmered above me, and I saw grass growing. I noticed the earth swallowing and erupting new life. I remarked to myself that the cycle of the earth’s devouring and growing happens outside of us—we aren’t truly part of it. I felt as aimless as a wave in the sea, merely one fragment among countless lives that grow and die.
[2004-05-28 19:00:00] In front of the old house | I saw four cars emerge from the valley behind me—my mother’s guests had arrived. I walked toward the old house and watched them excitedly climb out of their vehicles. I observed as they went about arranging rooms. I could sense their excitement from having just seen the glacier. I knew the guests included my mother’s sisters, their husbands and children, as well as Inge and Vidar. From what I understood, the evening’s plan was to eat reindeer meat, drink, and listen to speeches.
[2004-05-28 20:30:00] Living room of the old house | I saw Henrik Inge step up to the stage first. I watched him present the single-lens reflex camera we had jointly purchased, then begin his speech. I heard Henrik deduce in his speech that my mother had always been confident about photography but never owned a camera herself, which was why we gave her this gift. I felt so tense that I didn’t absorb a word he said—I was completely shut down by nerves.
[2004-05-28 20:45:00] Living room of the old house | I saw it was my turn to go onstage. I sat there, unable to eat anything. I noticed that most people present were ones I’d known since childhood, watching me with kind expressions. I knew deep down that I couldn’t avoid this speech—after all, she was turning sixty today. I thought that as a son, I had to say something pleasant for her sake. Even though talking about love made me feel nauseous, I still had to stand up.
[2004-05-28 20:46:00] Living room of the old house | I stood up. I felt everyone’s eyes on me. I focused all my willpower into my hands, trying to steady the speech in my grip and keep them from trembling.
[2004-05-28 20:47:00] Living room of the old house | I looked at my mother and saw her giving me an encouraging smile. I began speaking: 'Dear Mom, I want to start by thanking you. I want to thank you because you’ve been such an incredible mother. And being such an incredible mother is just one of many things I know about you. But of course, expressing these things in the language we have isn’t always easy. It’s especially difficult here, because the qualities you possess aren’t always the kind that are easily seen.'
[2004-05-28 20:48:00] Living room of the old house | I swallowed hard, glanced down at my glass of water. I decided not to reach for it, then looked up again at the eyes watching me.
[2004-05-28 20:50:00] Living room of the old house | I continued my speech: 'There’s a Frank Capra film that hits the mark exactly. It’s called It’s a Wonderful Life, from 1946. It’s about a good man in a small American town who, at the beginning of the film, falls into crisis and wants to give up everything. Then an angel intervenes and shows him what the world would be like without him. I don’t think you need an angel to understand how important you are to us—but sometimes perhaps we do. You give everyone space to be themselves. Now, that might sound commonplace, but it’s not—in fact, it’s a very rare quality. And sometimes it’s hard to recognize. It’s not hard to see someone boasting about themselves, or judging others by their own standards. But you never boast, you never impose your standards: you accept people as they are, adapt to them. I think everyone here has experienced that firsthand.'
[2004-05-28 20:51:00] Living room of the old house | A low murmur rose from the table beside me.
[2004-05-28 20:55:00] living room of the old house | I went on, 'When I was sixteen or seventeen, that quality meant everything to me. We lived alone in Tvet, and though I think it was a tough time, I always felt you had faith in me—real confidence, not just a little bit. You trusted me. You allowed me to learn through my own experience. Of course, I didn't realize at the time what you were doing. I suppose I couldn't see you, or myself, clearly then. But now I can. And I want to thank you for that.' I recalled the days when I was sixteen or seventeen, living with my mother alone in Tvet.
[2004-05-28 20:56:00] living room of the old house | As I spoke these words, I caught my mother's gaze, and suddenly my voice turned hoarse. I picked up my glass of water and gulped down a large mouthful, struggling to keep a smile on my face. I found it wasn't easy to force that smile. I sensed a wave of sympathy spreading around the table, but I felt awkward about what to do with it. I realized I only wanted to make a speech—not plunge into a sentimental abyss.
[2004-05-28 21:00:00] living room of the old house | I heard myself continue at the table, 'Yes, now you're sixty. You haven't planned to retire—in fact, you've just finished your studies. These two things say something about who you are: first, that you're energetic, full of vitality, and curious about knowledge; second, that you never give up. This applies to your life as well, and to how you relate to others: things take time. Everything requires the time it needs. When I was seven and starting school, I didn't know how to understand that. On the first day, you drove me there—I remember it clearly—and you weren't quite sure of the way, but you were confident we'd manage. We drove through one residential area, then another. I sat in the car in my light-blue uniform, with my little backpack and combed hair. While we circled aimlessly around Rocky, my new classmates stood on the schoolyard and listened to the entire welcome speech. By the time we finally arrived, it was all over. I could tell countless similar stories. For instance, you once drove for kilometers completely lost—no exaggeration—through unfamiliar terrain, unaware you'd long left the roads near Bærum. Eventually you stopped on a narrow path fit only for tractors, at the dark, dead end of some remote valley. There are so many such incidents. Just recently, one week ago, on your sixtieth birthday, you invited colleagues over for coffee. They arrived, but you'd forgotten to buy coffee, so you all ended up sitting down to tea instead. Sometimes I think this absent-minded side of your personality is actually a prerequisite for your presence—during our conversations, and in your talks with others.'
[2004-05-28 21:05:00] living room of the old house | I met her eyes again. I saw her facing me, smiling. At that moment, I felt my own eyes grow moist, and then I saw her stand up, as if she wanted to give me a hug. I cursed myself inwardly for being so foolish as to meet her eyes again. Seeing her coming toward me, I silently screamed: No, God no, not this.
[2004-05-28 21:10:00] living room of the old house | I saw the guests applauding, and then I returned to my seat once more. I felt deep disgust toward myself. I thought that even if losing control created a good impression and strengthened the impact of my words, I still felt ashamed inside for showing such vulnerability.
[2004-05-28 21:15:00] living room of the old house | I saw my mother’s older sister, Grete Lundnes, rise from her seat a few places away. I heard her speak a few words about growing older, accompanied by some playful boos from around the table. I thought her speech was lovely, full of warmth. I reflected quietly: after all, sixty is no longer forty.
[2004-05-28 21:20:00] living room of the old house | As she was speaking, I saw Nils Nils walk in and sit beside me. I felt her hand rest gently on my arm. I nodded at her. I heard her whisper, 'Is everything still okay?' I leaned over and whispered back, 'Is she sleeping?' Then I saw Nils Nils nod and smile slightly.
[2004-05-28 22:00:00] living room of the old house | I saw Grete Lundnes sit down, and then the next speaker rose. I noticed that Vidar and Inge seemed very happy. I watched Vidar chatting animatedly, quickly responding with anecdotes and opinions. I also saw Inge laughing, but she seemed somehow stuck in place. I knew that Vidar sometimes displayed signs of elderly rigidity at home, but none of that was evident today. From what I observed, Inge either couldn’t easily connect with strangers, or her mental state was overly excited.
locations: on a stone outside the house
In front of the old house
Living room of the old house
living room of the old house

text:
[2004-05-29 10:00:00] Jølster | The next day, when we returned to prepare for the naming ceremony, I saw she was still carrying on as usual—preparing as much food as possible the night before. On the naming day itself, I watched her bustling about in the kitchen. From my observation, with more space around her, her behavior seemed less conspicuous. I knew she constantly worried there wouldn’t be enough food, feared the house door might be locked on the naming day leaving no time to host guests, or that she’d be alone in the kitchen unable to find the necessary tools.
[2004-05-30 11:00:00] church | I saw the priest was a young woman. We stood around her by the baptismal font, and I watched Nils Nils holding Vanja. Before me was the image of water wetting Vanja’s little head.
[2004-05-30 12:00:00] church | I saw that as soon as the ceremony ended, Inge left first, then I watched Berit Hansnes and her family rise and kneel at the communion rail. I also stood up and followed suit: I knelt before the rail, received a piece of bread on my tongue, drank the communion wine, accepted the blessing, then rose and returned to my seat. I felt the gaze of Mother, Sverre, Henrik Inge, and Karl Larsdal following me all the way. I realized their eyes held varying degrees of doubt.
[2004-05-30 12:05:00] church | I kept asking myself: why did I do this?
[2004-05-30 12:06:00] church | I secretly doubted myself: have I become a Christian?
[2004-05-30 12:10:00] church | I bowed my head, walked down the aisle, and finally knelt at the communion rail. I knew that ever since my teens I had strongly opposed Christianity, that I was a genuine materialist at heart. I realized my earlier action had been purely impulsive. I felt I couldn't defend it before everyone's eyes, let alone claim to be a Christian. I felt a slight shame.
[2004-05-30 12:15:00] church | I realized that so much had truly happened in recent years.
[2004-05-30 12:20:00] church | I remembered talking with a priest when my father died—it had felt like a confession, and I told him everything. I realized that at the time, the funeral ritual had almost become something tangible. Recalling that moment, I felt how tightly the ritual had gripped me. I thought: yes, it truly transformed my father’s bitter, broken life into a dignified one.
[2004-05-30 12:25:00] church | I realized that over the past year’s work, I had been reading the Pentateuch, the New Testament, and works by Rilke and others. I knew these texts carried a hymn-like solemnity. I knew the sacred had never been far away. I gradually came to understand that I wanted to explore the sacred. I realized this concerned flesh and blood, life and death. I felt these readings were leading me toward what has always been and will always remain.
[2004-05-30 12:30:00] church | I silently reckoned that I had already thought about these things for a long time.
[2004-05-30 12:35:00] church | I heard the priest asking questions about faith. At the time, I couldn’t tell her I was a Christian; I could only evade the question. I knew that because of my marital background, the priest had been somewhat reluctant when baptizing Vanya. I recalled the situation and felt a sense of hypocrisy, as if I were deceiving others to get my daughter baptized. I realized my act during communion might have been an attempt to redeem something, yet it ended up appearing even more insincere.
[2004-05-30 12:36:00] church | I sighed inwardly: But still, the sacred.
[2004-05-30 12:37:00] church | I silently recited in my heart: flesh and blood.
[2004-05-30 12:38:00] church | I felt inwardly: this is the one truth underlying all things, unchanging amidst every change.
[2004-05-30 12:40:00] church | I saw Berit Hansnes walk over and kneel down there. I also walked into the aisle and knelt on the ground. I felt he was a whole person, a good man. And deep inside, I longed: I want so badly to be a whole person, I want so badly to be a good man.
[2004-05-30 13:00:00] steps of Jølster Church | I saw us standing on the church steps, taking a group photo of parents, children, godparents, and godmothers. Before my eyes lay the ancient stone steps of the church.
[2004-05-30 13:00:30] steps of Jølster Church | To my knowledge, the baptismal dress Vanya is wearing today was also worn by her great-grandmother at her baptism—right here in Jølster.
[2004-05-30 13:01:00] steps of Jølster Church | I saw my mother’s sisters, all gathered together, along with their children and grandchildren. I spotted Alfdis, Aafne, as well as Karl Larsdal, Christina, and Vidar and Ingrid among the crowd. I know that Alfdis and Aafne are two elder relatives especially dear to Nils Nils.
[2004-05-30 13:05:00] outside Jølster Church | We were standing there when I saw Ingrid run up the hill. I watched her take the key from my mother, then turn and run back again. I realized my mother had been so distracted that the door indeed got locked. I knew Ingrid’s earlier worry hadn’t been unfounded.
[2004-05-30 13:35:00] Nils Nils's mother's garden | When we arrived home half an hour later, I saw her growing anxious because she couldn't find some plates. Then I watched everyone celebrate in the garden. I sensed the weather was wonderful. The lake spread out before me, with mountains mirrored in its waters. Around me rose voices praising the food.
[2004-05-30 17:00:00] Nils Nils's mother's house | But once all the meals were finished, I saw everyone take turns holding Vanya on their laps. I noticed Ingrid became idle, and then I saw her retreat to her room, staying inside without coming out. I wondered if perhaps this situation made her feel uncomfortable.
[2004-05-30 17:30:00] Nils Nils's mother's house | Not until around five or half past, after the first guests had left, did I see Nils Nils go inside to look for her. I found she was asleep, almost impossible to wake. I knew she had been like this recently. It suddenly struck me how long it had been since I last really saw her.
[2004-05-30 17:35:00] Nils Nils's mother's house | From what I understand, after she passes out completely, the first five to ten minutes upon waking she’s basically unable to communicate with anyone. I recalled how Nils Nils once told me how frightening this sight could be. I realized Nils Nils was suspecting this might have something to do with sleeping pills.
[2004-05-30 17:45:00] Garden of Nils Nils's mother's house | I watched her almost stumble across the lawn toward the outside of the house. I noticed that when she sat down at that table, her laughter seemed slightly out of context. In the surrounding atmosphere, I sensed her laughter was slightly disconnected compared to others.
[2004-05-30 22:00:00] Nils Nils's mother's house | After everyone had gone to sleep that night, I heard Nils Nils talk to me about it. Her voice, filled with worry, reached my ears as she said her mother seemed to be suffering but didn’t even know it herself—everything was suppressed, and though she wanted to communicate with her mother, she didn’t know where to begin. I learned that Ingeri’s condition was due to sleeping pills and the stress associated with the party. I knew she had cooked for twenty-five guests, and everything was new and unfamiliar to her. I thought she really looked worrying—clearly, something wasn’t right. I realized her mind seemed elsewhere; that overly excited voice and flushed face made me uneasy.
[2004-05-30 23:00:00] Nils Nils's mother's house | I saw that when I encountered them again, her panic and anxiety had completely vanished. I noticed Vidar had also returned to his usual self.
[2004-05-30 23:05:00] Outside Nils Nils's mother's house | I saw him standing there with his hands on his hips, gazing at the furnishings he had built himself. I noticed Nils Nils climbing up the hill, walking toward us. I heard the sound of a train coming from one side of the mountain, fading away, then rising again from the other side, growing louder and fuller.
[2004-05-30 23:05:10] Outside Nils Nils's mother's house | I heard her shout loudly as soon as she saw us: "Time for dinner!"
locations: Garden of Nils Nils's mother's house

text:
[2004-05-31 07:30:00] Train station | I saw Vidar drive us to the train station. Ingeri, Nils Nils, and I traveled together. We arrived just moments before the train departed, and I realized I didn’t have time to buy a ticket. I knew Ingeri had a monthly pass, and Nils Nils’s round-trip ticket was sufficient for returning to Håvik.
[2004-05-31 08:30:00] On the train | I sat by the window and took out a stack of newspapers to read. I saw Ingeri tending to Vanja, while Nils Nils sat beside her, looking out the window. I noticed the ticket inspector approaching us after several stops.
[2004-05-31 08:30:05] On the train | I heard Ingeri point at me and say to the ticket inspector: "He got on in Hønefoss."
[2004-05-31 08:30:10] On the train | I was astonished in my mind: What? I thought—she’s actually covering for me to evade a ticket? I realized she was doing something I never would have expected.
[2004-05-31 08:30:20] on the train | I locked eyes with the ticket inspector while speaking and fumbling in my pocket for change. I heard myself say to the ticket inspector, "To Halviken, getting on at Håninge. How much?"
[2004-05-31 08:30:40] on the train | As far as I knew, I had always stuck to the principle of never taking unfair advantage—even returning money when a shop gave me too much change. I knew that fare evasion was the last thing I'd ever want to do. I thought about how I couldn't bring myself to confront Ingrid directly and say I'd boarded in Gränna, because I was afraid it would embarrass her.
[2004-05-31 08:31:00] on the train | I took the ticket and change handed to me by the inspector and thanked him. I watched him disappear into the stream of morning commuters.
[2004-05-31 08:35:00] on the train | I kept my head down, reading the newspaper. I felt furious, yet sighed inwardly and ultimately said nothing.
[2004-05-31 09:15:00] Halviken Central Station | I saw that we had arrived at Halviken Central Station. I moved the stroller onto the platform and offered Ingrid to take her suitcase back to the office. I saw she seemed pleased, and I thought this would save her from dragging the suitcase around.
[2004-05-31 09:30:00] Halviken streets | I said goodbye to them in the hall. Pulling the suitcase with one hand and carrying my laptop bag with the other, I walked quickly toward Dalar Street. I unlocked the door to the office. Before me lay the square with the fortress-like building of the Trade Union Alliance.
[2004-05-31 09:35:00] the office | I knew the past from writing 'For Everything There Is a Season' was closing in on me from all sides. I silently marveled that this place had become so full of memories. I remembered how happy I had been back then.
[2004-05-31 09:40:00] the office | I saw myself clearing space for the suitcase in the cabinet under the sink, then walking into the bathroom to urinate. I thought it would be best not to see that suitcase while working.
[2004-05-31 09:42:00] office bathroom | I saw Ingrid's shampoo and conditioner in the bathroom. I noticed cotton swabs and dental floss in the trash bag. I grabbed the bottles and threw them into the kitchen trash can. I heard myself shout involuntarily, "What the hell is going on!"
[2004-05-31 09:43:00] the office | I grabbed the garbage bag from the wastebasket. I bent down and pulled a small clump of her hair from the drain. With all my strength, I threw the hair into the bag, crumpled it up, and shoved it into the kitchen cabinet's trash bin. I heard myself roar, "God damn it, will this never end?" I angrily thought to myself that this was my office, the one place that was entirely mine, and even here I had been invaded.
[2004-05-31 09:44:00] office | I silently made up my mind: then, go to hell.
[2004-05-31 09:45:00] office | I turned on the computer and sat down at the desk, waiting for it to boot. I stared at the mark on the wooden floor, then looked toward the wall behind the sofa. I noticed the photo taped above the desk, and the anatomical charts behind me. Before me was the image of Jesus Christ wearing a crown of thorns on the wooden floor. I saw the night poster of Per Bakke on the wall behind the sofa. I noticed two photographs of Thomas hanging above the desk, and behind me, whale anatomy diagrams and intricate insect illustrations.
[2004-05-31 09:50:00] office | I realized I couldn't write here anymore. I thought to myself that I wouldn't be able to produce anything new in this place.
[2004-05-31 09:55:00] office | As far as I knew, I had a lecture to give Saturday morning. I understood it was part of a tradition honoring writers nominated for the Nordic Council Literature Prize. I remembered that I had accepted the invitation at the last moment. I thought about how this week’s work would revolve entirely around that speech. I realized the next three days would be consumed by this meaningless task.
[2004-05-31 10:00:00] office | I sat there, filled with indifference toward the audience and the award—only wanting to write more books. I thought viciously that maybe I should publicly shit on the podium to humiliate the moment, then casually hand over the microphone to the next writer.
[2004-05-31 10:15:00] office kitchenette | I saw myself deleting those words from the screen. I walked into the kitchenette and started boiling water, scooped two spoons of instant coffee into a cup, and finally poured in the hot water.
[2004-05-31 10:30:00] bench outside office | I put on my coat, went out and crossed the street. I sat down on the bench across from the hospital and smoked three cigarettes in a row. I observed the passing people and vehicles. I saw the gloomy gray sky and felt the damp cold air. I noticed the snow along the roadside blackened by exhaust fumes.
[2004-05-31 10:45:00] bench outside office | I pulled out my phone, tapped around, wrote a short poem, and sent it to Karl Larsdal. I heard the lines I had written: 'Karl Larsdal Karl Larsdal, you're dead and gone... She has love, don’t miss the dawn.'
[2004-05-31 11:00:00] office | I walked back inside and sat down at the computer again. I noticed my phone vibrating in my pocket. I heard myself mentally rehearsing: I’ll talk about *Out of This World* and *Everything in Its Time*, and I’ll have to look happy and proud while doing it. I felt a deep disgust, thinking there were still five days before completion, and starting to write felt harder. I realized I had to finish this speech, yet inwardly I believed it was all nonsense.
[2004-05-31 11:05:00] office | I took out my phone and opened Karl Larsdal’s message. I read his text: 'You were right: died this morning in a traffic accident. My porn magazines are yours… Can you write something better?'
[2004-05-31 11:10:00] office | I replied to Karl with a text message. I read my own reply: "Of course I can—take a look at this. Karl Larsdal, young soul lost, lies beneath the sod. He drove a Saab, wheels flew free... only then did youth and death agree!"
[2004-05-31 12:00:00] supermarket / office | After sending the message, I went to the supermarket to buy some food. After eating, I fell asleep on the sofa for an hour. This kind of text exchange isn't particularly fun, but at least it passes the time. I can even imagine these verses earning Karl Larsdal a few cheap laughs in his university office.
[2004-05-31 18:00:00] office | I finished reading the first volume of The Brothers Karamazov and immediately started on the second. I noticed that it had grown completely dark outside when I finished the book. I felt the house fill with the various sounds of early evening. I was overcome by a feeling I used to have as a teenager—I remembered how I often lay in bed for hours on end, absorbed in books. My head felt a bit chilly; I realized I might have caught a cold while sleeping. The world around me, bathed in the afterglow of sunset, seemed hard and hostile.
[2004-05-31 18:15:00] office | I washed my hands with hot water and dried them carefully. I shut down the computer, packed it into my bag, wrapped my scarf around my neck, pulled my hat over my head, put on my coat and shoes. I walked out, locked the door behind me, put on my gloves, and stepped onto the street. I thought I still had just over half an hour before meeting Karl Larsdal at Pelican Restaurant—it was early enough.
[2004-05-31 18:30:00] Harvik Street | I walked up Sheriff Street toward the subway station where it intersects with Mochengdao Road. I saw the snow on the sidewalk had turned a yellowish brown, covered with a fine layer of granular particles like coarse flour. I realized walking on this kind of snow meant slipping was likely. I noticed it was now half past six.
[2004-05-31 18:32:00] Harvik Street | I walked briskly along the street. I saw the streets around me were nearly empty, filled with shapeless darkness. I noticed only the faint glow of electric lights reflected through every window and streetlamp, spreading across the snow, pavement, stairs, railings, cars, and building facades. As I walked, I thought it wouldn’t matter at all if I became someone else. I realized I didn’t feel any qualities uniquely my own at this moment.
[2004-05-31 18:35:00] Queen Street / subway station | I passed Queen Street, descended the steps beside Observatory Park, and finally went down the stairwell leading underground to the subway. At the lower end of the street, I saw a swarm of dark, beetle-like figures crowded together. I noticed a repulsive sign hanging outside one of the Chinese restaurants urging people to 'drink heavily.'
[2004-05-31 18:40:00] subway platform | I stood where the platform was least crowded, placed my bag between my feet, and leaned against the wall with one shoulder. I took out my phone and dialed Henrik Inge. I saw there were about thirty or forty people on both platforms. Judging by the bags people carried, I guessed most of them were on their way home from work.
[2004-05-31 18:40:10] subway platform | I heard Henrik say, "Hello?" I said, "Hi, it's Grete Lundnes." I heard him reply, "I know."
[2004-05-31 18:40:30] subway platform | I asked him, "Did you call me?" I heard him confirm he had called on Saturday. I explained I'd meant to call back, but got busy because someone came over for dinner, so I forgot. I heard Henrik Inge say, "No problem. It wasn't anything urgent."
[2004-05-31 18:41:00] subway platform | I asked him, "Did the kitchenware arrive?" I heard him reply that it had just arrived today, right beside him. He then told me he'd bought a new car, and I blurted out in surprise, "No way!" I heard him explain it was a Citroën XM, not too old, but originally a hearse.
[2004-05-31 18:41:30] subway platform | I exclaimed, "You're kidding!" I heard him say he wasn't kidding. I asked in disbelief if he really intended to drive a hearse around everywhere. I heard him explain that of course the car had been modified—there was no space for coffins anymore and it looked perfectly normal. I remarked to him that sounded easy enough, but still, dead bodies had definitely been carried inside it; I said I hadn't heard anything so creepy in a long time.
[2004-05-31 18:42:00] subway platform | I heard Henrik Inge snort and say to me, "You're too sensitive. It's a perfectly normal car. And I can afford it." I replied, "Yeah, yeah."
[2004-05-31 18:42:30] subway platform | After a brief silence, I asked, "Anything else new?" I heard him say there was nothing particularly worth mentioning, and then he asked how I was doing. I told him, "No, nothing much. I was at Nils Nils’s mother’s place yesterday." I heard him respond, "Oh, really." I answered, "Yes."

[2004-06-01 21:40:00] Pelikan Pub | I told myself not to believe I have any exceptional qualities or worth. I thought I should just keep my head down and work. I realized that the sum of a lifetime's experience amounts to this: I'm just a nobody—that's the only truth I've ever gained.
[2004-06-01 21:45:00] Pelikan Pub | I realized I've always focused on being likable, obsessively caring what others think. I thought media attention brings pleasure, but also pain—because I can't control how strangers perceive me. I sighed—when an interview's meaning gets twisted beyond correction, my self-image suffers unbearable shame.
[2004-06-01 21:50:00] Pelican Pub | I realized that the desire for praise had overwhelmed my fear and ideals of integrity, causing me to continue with the interview. I recalled how I had wanted to refuse interviews while writing the book, but changed my mind under Ingeborg's influence. I lamented that although I used promotion as an excuse, deep down I felt like a prostitute rather than a writer.
[2004-06-01 21:55:00] Pelican Pub | I reflected on my recent behavior and realized that I, too, had been talking about myself. Looking at writers like Tovevik or Flugstad, I found them upright and never self-referential, feeling they belonged to an exceedingly rare breed.
[2004-06-01 22:05:00] subway station | I saw myself handing the ticket to the window. I noticed him stamp it and push it back to me. I watched myself take the elevator down to the subway, walk through the tunnel to the platform. I checked the time for the next train. Finally, I sat down on a bench. A blank-faced staff member came into view. I was standing on a narrow platform.
[2004-06-01 22:06:00] subway station | I heard the journalist turn to me and ask, "Who exactly are you?" I remembered it was the late autumn when 'Out of This World' had just been published. I knew that NRK2's 'News' program wanted to interview me.
[2004-06-01 22:07:00] subway station | I asked in return, "What do you mean?" I heard his reply: "Bellson Hansen is a sage. Ciliavik Sand is a Labour Party writer. Sivvik is a drunken, promiscuous female writer. Who are you? I know nothing about you."
[2004-06-01 22:08:00] subway station | I said, "I don't know, I'm just an ordinary person." I heard him press me: "Come on! You have to give me something. What have you done?"
[2004-06-01 22:10:00] subway station | I told him, "Done a few odd jobs here and there. Went to school for a few days. You know..." I heard his final statement: "Ibsen said the strongest are those who stand alone. I think he was wrong." I learned that he used edited pauses and hesitations to portray my personality.
[2004-06-01 22:15:00] subway station | I watched myself sitting on the bench, raising my arms and taking a deep breath. I recalled what I had said then, feeling heavily oppressed. I reflected: How could I have said such things? Did I really believe in myself at that moment?
[2004-06-01 22:20:00] subway station | I realized that what I had expressed back then was actually my mother's belief. I thought that human relationships are in fact meant to erase individuality and suppress deviant behavior. I sighed—yes, Ibsen was right, and everything I see around me confirms it.
[2004-06-01 22:25:00] subway station | I recalled that my mother had never been as angry as when we discussed the concept of freedom. I remembered how she would always scoff at my opinions, calling them hollow, hypocritical American nonsense. I realized it was precisely this idea of 'living for others' that led to our today's institutionalized existence, making life feel like a tunnel already filtered on the very first day.
[2004-06-01 22:30:00] subway station | I thought about how some people are sent to do practical work while others rise to the top. I realized it's precisely this idea of equal education that gives us false expectations about life, making us quick to blame external factors when things don't go smoothly. I saw the anger people directed at the state when the tsunami came, and I sighed at how tragic it was. I realized that the kind of existence where one faces life-threatening emergencies directly no longer exists in our time.
[2004-06-01 22:35:00] subway station | I realized that such thinking has given rise to a culture where mediocrity can flourish through clichés. I thought of those revered writers who speak of writing tools as if they were Virgil reborn, and I felt disgusted by it all. Yet I blamed myself, remembering who it was that had talked to journalists about my own mediocre work as if I were truly a master—only to realize it was me.
[2004-06-01 22:40:00] subway station | I realized that once I knew I wasn't doing good enough work, I could no longer bear others' applause. I cried out inwardly that I must sever all ties with this corrupt, flattering cultural world—even if it meant locking myself in a room for twenty years to write. I wanted to cut myself off from that hollow media world and pursue literature at the highest level.
[2004-06-01 22:45:00] subway station | I realized I couldn't seize this opportunity because I had to remain present for my family and friends. I reflected on the weakness in my character—how I always say 'yes' to avoid hurting others, even abandoning principles to prevent conflict. In sorrow, I thought to myself that I was essentially a prostitute.
[2004-06-01 23:15:00] home | I walked through the door and, as soon as I shut it behind me, leaned forward to look into the living room. I saw Siv Ingrid together with Nils Nils. I heard their voices talking in the living room. Before me, each held a cup of tea, curled up on the sofa. I noticed a candelabra with three lit candles on the table, along with plates and baskets filled with cheese and biscuits.
[2004-06-01 23:16:00] living room at home | I shrugged and said. I heard Nils Nils ask me, 'Hey, Grete Lundnes, how’s it going?' I replied that it was okay, nothing worth mentioning. She asked if I wanted tea and cheese, and I answered, 'No, thank you.'
[2004-06-01 23:20:00] living room at home | I stood there untying my scarf, hung my jacket in the closet, and placed my shoes on the shoe rack. Then I walked into the living room. I saw the floor below covered in dirt and gravel. I thought I should sit with them for a while so as not to seem too cold or distant.
[2004-06-01 23:25:00] living room at home | I heard Siv Ingrid talking about her meeting with Culture Minister Olaflund. She told me the minister was an extremely small man sitting in a huge sofa, who even bit the cushion he held in his arms. I heard her genuine admiration for his sharp mind and strong work ability.
[2004-06-01 23:30:00] living room at home | As far as I knew, Siv Ingrid had secured one high-level position after another shortly after turning thirty. I learned she had a close relationship with her father, while her relationship with her mother—who lived in Gothenburg—was rather complicated. I wasn't quite sure about her qualifications, but I realized the positions suited her well. I observed that she, like many young women I'd met, was well-bred and carried herself with confidence.
[2004-06-01 23:35:00] living room at home | I heard Siv Ingrid recount a dream: she went to a party and left completely naked from the waist down, waddling like Donald Duck, and finally ended up lying across a table. She asked us what we thought the dream meant. I recalled this story that had clearly left a deep impression on her. I realized that although she frequently changed boyfriends, none of them measured up to her. I thought that the content of this dream—the fact she was willing to share it publicly—had a strangely charming awkwardness to it.
[2004-06-01 23:40:00] living room at home | I wondered about the meaning of that dream. I thought about why she would make such a private matter public. I realized that beneath her worldly demeanor, there were often traces of childishness. I wondered whether this display that caught my surprised gaze was intentional.
[2004-06-01 23:45:00] living room at home | I learned that Siv Ingrid was Vanja's godmother and had attended the child's naming ceremony. I knew she had made an excellent impression on my mother. I realized she held Nils Nils in high regard and sometimes even sought his advice. I felt she was very proactive within our small family, infecting us with joy and energy. I thought, from her perspective, this might be the only way to visit a vulnerable friend.
[2004-06-01 23:50:00] living room at home | I noticed that as the party was winding down, Siv Ingrid got up to help clear the plates. I realized this was exactly why we needed social norms—because they help us coexist peacefully. I observed that Siv Ingrid behaved sensibly, while Nils Nils never reached the same degree. I thought that despite Nils Nils not understanding these things, there was an unknown richness in her character.
[2004-06-01 23:55:00] living room at home | I felt sad inside because my mother preferred Siv Ingrid and failed to see the sudden dangers and resistance in Nils Nils’s character. I weighed in my mind how Nils Nils refused to serve others yet longed to be served. I wondered: should one choose the movement toward life, or the kind of death that resides in art?

[2004-06-01 23:58:00] living room at home / kitchen | I walked into the kitchen. I said, 'I'll have a cup of tea after all.' I heard Nils Nils say it was herbal tea, asked if I wanted some, and mentioned the water might still be warm. I replied, 'No, never mind.'
[2004-06-01 23:59:00] kitchen at home | Before the water boiled, I stepped onto the chair in front of the cupboard, took a pencil, and marked all the liquor bottles. I drew a tiny dot so small only I would know it was there.
[2004-06-02 00:01:00] kitchen at home | I realized I was behaving like a suspicious father and felt somewhat foolish. But I didn’t want the woman caring for my child to drink hard liquor while working, so I had to do it.
[2004-06-02 00:05:00] kitchen at home / at the computer | I put a tea bag into the cup and poured hot water. I left the kitchen to say goodbye to Siv Ingrid, who was leaving. Then I sat down at the computer. I looked down at Naren Restaurant and saw chefs washing the floor, steam rising from the dishwasher.
[2004-06-02 00:10:00] at the computer | I connected to the internet and checked my email, finding nothing. Then I visited several websites and searched for my own name on Google. I noticed the search results numbered over twenty-nine thousand, fluctuating like an exponential curve. I saw one online commenter say my book wasn't even good enough to wipe one's ass with.
[2004-06-02 00:15:00] at the computer | I accidentally opened a bunch of documents. I found a review about me on the website of a small publishing house. As far as I knew, one of my relatives had been involved in a neighborhood dispute over the length of a garage wall.
[2004-06-02 00:16:00] in front of the computer | I heard Nils Nils ask from behind me, "What are you doing?" I replied that I was googling myself. I exclaimed to her, "This is fucking Pandora's box. You wouldn't believe what these people have written."
[2004-06-02 00:17:00] in front of the computer | I heard her say, "You shouldn't do that—come over and sit down." I answered, "Coming, just two more things to check."
[2004-06-02 08:00:00] home / writing room | I left for the writing room at eight in the morning the next day and returned home at three thirty in the afternoon. I knew Inge would come to pick up Vannia. I realized I'd be writing my lecture in the writing room until three o'clock.
[2004-06-02 15:35:00] kitchen at home | I walked into the kitchen to inspect the wine bottles. I confirmed with certainty that someone had drunk from both bottles.
[2004-06-02 15:40:00] bathroom at home | I went to find Nils Nils and sat down on the toilet lid. I heard her smile and say to me, "Hi, I bought a bath bomb today." I saw the bathtub full of soap bubbles. I noticed Nils Nils raised one arm, and foam dripped down.
[2004-06-02 15:41:00] bathroom at home | I looked at her. I said to her, "I see that. There's something we need to talk about." I told her, "It was your mom. Remember how I mentioned lately that the wine in the bottles has clearly gone down?"
[2004-06-02 15:42:00] bathroom at home | I told her I had marked the bottles yesterday, so I could be sure the wine had gone down again. I said that since I hadn't drunk any, it must have been either her or her mother. I heard my own firm conclusion: "I know it wasn't you. That leaves only her—there's no other explanation."
[2004-06-02 15:43:00] bathroom at home | I heard her ask, somewhat surprised, "Mother?" She remarked that this must have been going on for years, as it would explain her mother’s long-standing, uncommunicative absentmindedness. I noticed Nils Nils fell into deep thought.
[2004-06-02 15:44:00] bathroom at home | I stood up. I told her it might stem from her mother's unhappiness due to problems with Vidar. I asked if she wanted to confront her now and settle it once and for all. I knew they would be home in half an hour.
[2004-06-02 15:46:00] bathroom at home | I heard Nils Nils murmur, "This must have been going on for years." Then she analyzed aloud that this actually explained many things, such as her mother’s persistent, unreachable absentmindedness. I noticed she fell silent. I looked at her, realizing she was lost in her own thoughts.
[2004-06-02 15:47:00] bathroom at home | I stood up. I tried to speculate, 'It's not certain—maybe she has something going on with Vidar, maybe she's gotten into trouble there, unhappy.'
[2004-06-02 15:48:00] bathroom at home | I heard Nils Nils retort, 'But you don't start drinking at sixty because you're unhappy.' She said it firmly to me, as if this were a well-established coping mechanism, one that had been used for a long time.
[2004-06-02 15:49:00] bathroom at home | I told Nils Nils, 'They'll be home in half an hour.' I asked her advice—should we stay quiet for now and talk later, or confront her immediately and settle things once and for all?
[2004-06-02 15:50:00] bathroom at home | I heard Nils Nils reply sharply, 'There's no point waiting.' Then she looked at me and asked, 'Can we do it together?'
[2004-06-02 15:51:00] bathroom at home | I saw Nils Nils shrug at me, spreading her hands beneath the bath foam. I shook my head and replied, 'It's too complicated—two against one, like a courtroom.' I heard her mutter, 'Hmm, I don't know either.'
[2004-06-02 15:52:00] bathroom at home | I volunteered, 'I'll do it. I'll go out and talk to her.' I heard her ask me, somewhat anxiously, whether I was really sure I wanted to do this.
[2004-06-02 15:53:00] bathroom at home | I raised my voice and said, 'Want to? Of all things in the world, this is what I want to do least!' I exclaimed—it was my mother-in-law, after all. I explained to Nils Nils that I just wanted to handle it decently, without losing face, calmly clarifying everything. I inwardly sighed—this situation truly gave me a massive headache.
[2004-06-02 15:54:00] bathroom at home | I heard Nils Nils say she was glad I was doing this, and guessed that in the end, her mother might admit it. I remarked to Nils Nils, 'I have to say, you're taking this remarkably calmly.'
[2004-06-02 15:56:00] bathroom at home
[2004-06-02 15:57:00] bathroom at home | I saw her smile at me, then shake her head. I repeated, somewhat sensitively, "The children?" I asked if there was something she knew that I didn't. I heard her reply that there wasn't, but that she could probably sense something.
[2004-06-02 16:00:00] living room at home | I walked out of the bathroom and closed the door. I watched Nils Nils walk into the hallway, saw the red towel wrapped around her head. Then I saw her disappear behind the open cabinet door. I stood by the living room window, hearing the sound of water draining from the bathtub. I saw the torch outside the café across the street swaying in the wind, silhouettes passing along the road. The faint strumming of a guitar from the upstairs neighbor reached my ears, and dim streetlight cast its glow upon the walls and floor. I wondered to myself whether Nils Nils would feel unsettled if she walked in and saw all this.
[2004-06-02 16:15:00] at computer at home / kitchen / hallway | I went to check my email, looked for a while, then turned off the computer. I went into the kitchen and turned on the coffee machine, then drank a glass of water. I noticed Nils Nils standing in front of the mirror in the hallway, putting on makeup.
[2004-06-02 16:20:00] hallway at home | I asked her, "When is Kristina arriving?" I heard her reply that it was at six, but she wanted to get things ready while we were still alone. She asked me in return whether I'd made any progress today, and I told her only a little—there was still more to do tomorrow night and Friday.
[2004-06-02 16:21:00] hallway at home | I saw her tilt her head back, brushing her lashes with a small brush. I heard her ask while brushing her lashes, "You're leaving Saturday?" I answered yes.
locations: kitchen at home / at the computer
at computer at home / kitchen / hallway

text:
[2004-06-02 16:30:00] at home | I noticed the elevator in the corridor starting up. After it stopped, I saw the door facing the corridor open, and then I saw the stroller being pulled outward. I heard the sound of the stroller's wheels turning in the corridor. I figured they must have returned.
[2004-06-02 16:31:00] hallway at home | I watched Ingeri open the door and step into the hallway inside the apartment. I heard Ingeri excitedly tell me that Vanya had fallen asleep on the way, poor little thing was completely worn out. She said they’d had a very rewarding day at June Mountain, and she’d bought an annual pass that allowed our whole family free entry. I felt the hallway instantly fill with her lively, vibrant energy.
[2004-06-02 16:32:00] hallway at home | I saw her put down the various bags she was carrying. I noticed her pull a yellow card from her wallet and hand it to Nils Nils. Then I saw her rummaging through one of the bags. I heard her ask whether buying that new jumpsuit was a good idea, saying the old one had become too small.
[2004-06-02 16:33:00] hallway at home | I saw her look at me, and I shook my head at her. I watched as she pulled out a pair of bright red new gloves from the bag and handed them to us. I heard her explain that these gloves had clips so they could be attached to sleeves—warm and spacious.
[2004-06-02 16:34:00] hallway at home | I saw her look at Nils Nils. I heard Ingeri ask Nils Nils if she was going out. Realizing there was an evening appointment, she turned to me and said that Karl and I should think hard about how to spend our time, and that she’d leave now not to disturb us.
[2004-06-02 16:35:00] hallway at home | I saw her turn toward Vanya. I noticed the little girl lying in the stroller, her hat covering her eyes. I heard her whisper that Vanya would probably sleep another hour, and she asked if I wanted to carry the child into the living room first.
[2004-06-02 16:36:00] hallway at home | I said, "Let me carry it." I asked Inge whether she was returning to Gnestad or had other plans. I heard her reply that she was going to the theater with Barbro and asked if she could stay another night in my study, wondering if I needed it.
[2004-06-02 16:37:00] hallway at home | I saw her large eyes behind thick lenses staring at me with suspicion and unease. I quickly said, "No, no, I was just asking. Actually, I wanted to talk to you. There's something I need to say."
[2004-06-02 16:38:00] hallway at home | I asked, "Can we go out for a walk?" I heard her answer, "Okay." I suggested, "Then let's go now. It won't take long."
[2004-06-02 16:40:00] home | I bent down, loosened the bolts, held both doors open, and pushed the stroller inside. I saw Inge go into the kitchen for water. I stood a few meters away waiting for her. I noticed Nils Nils had gone into the living room. I felt my mind racing with thoughts.
[2004-06-02 16:42:00] stairwell | I watched us step out of the apartment. I noticed her face turned pale as she spoke. I heard her nervously ask me, "You're not splitting up, are you? Don't tell me you're separating..."
