[2004-06-02 16:43:00] stairwell | I quickly reassured her, "No, oh no, we're not. There's something else I want to talk to you about." I heard her sigh with relief, saying, "Oh, then I'm relieved."
[2004-06-02 16:45:00] street | I watched us walk through the backyard and out the gate. She didn't say anything along the way. I noticed she glanced at me from time to time. I walked along the quiet David's Baker Street. I thought about the nursing home and noticed a look of expectation or surprise in her eyes.
[2004-06-02 16:47:00] street | I saw us walking toward St. Helen Ster Church. After a silence, I finally heard myself say, "I really don't know how to begin."
[2004-06-02 16:48:00] street | I confessed to Inge, "But this... well, I'd better be direct. I know you drank while watching Vanya today. You drank yesterday too. I... well, I simply can't allow that. It's not right. You mustn't do it." I reflected inwardly that I should just speak plainly.
[2004-06-02 16:49:00] street | I saw us continuing to walk, her eyes fixed on me. I went on, "I never want to control you—of course you can do as you please. But not when you're caring for Vanya. I have to draw a line. It's not acceptable, do you understand?"
[2004-06-02 16:50:00] street | I heard her say in surprise, "I don't understand. I have no idea what you're talking about. I've never drunk alcohol while taking care of Vanja. Never. And I never will. Where did you get such a conclusion?"
[2004-06-02 16:51:00] street | I felt a deep chill inside. I thought that whenever I find myself in a precarious or agonizing situation—like today, when forced into actions beyond my intentions—the way I observe the world around me (including myself) becomes unusually clear, almost surreal in its clarity.
[2004-06-02 16:52:00] street | I noticed my slightly hunched posture and Inge's lively gait beside me. I saw the way she tilted her face up toward mine—beyond confusion, there seemed to be a faint trace of barely perceptible reproach. Ahead, the green tin spire of the church came into view, surrounded by black, bare trees in the cemetery. I saw a shiny blue compact car gliding along the opposite side of the road.
[2004-06-02 16:53:00] street | I heard myself explain to her, "I noticed the wine level in the bottle had gone down. To check, I marked the label yesterday. When I got home, I saw it had decreased again. I haven't touched it at all. Besides me, only you and Nils Nils were home today. I know it wasn't Nils Nils. That leaves only one explanation—it must have been you."
[2004-06-02 16:54:00] street | I heard her say to me, "There must be another explanation, because it wasn't me. I'm truly sorry, Grete Lundnes, but I didn't drink your wine."
[2004-06-02 16:55:00] street | I said to her, "Listen, you're my mother-in-law, and I only want the best for you. I don't want this—I really don't. The last thing I want is to accuse you. But what else can I do? I already know the truth!" I felt a stabbing pain, as if stepping through the gates of hell.
[2004-06-02 16:56:00] street | I heard her say to me, "But you don't know—because it wasn't me." I sighed inwardly. This kind of pain was truly unbearable.
[2004-06-02 16:58:00] street | I said seriously to Inge, "You must understand—regardless of what you say, this has consequences. You're an excellent mother-in-law, and I know Vanja is deeply attached to you. But if you won't admit this, we can't trust you anymore. It doesn't mean we won't see you, but if you don't confess and promise not to repeat it, you can't be left alone with her. Do you understand what I'm saying?" I knew Vanja was closer to her than to anyone else, and that we had no other close family nearby. I thought how happy I would be if things could continue as they were.
[2004-06-02 16:59:00] street | I heard her say to me, "Yes, I understand. It's such a pity. But it can't be helped—I can't admit to something I didn't do. Even if I wanted to, I couldn't."
[2004-06-02 17:00:00] street | I suggested, "Alright then, let's not talk about this anymore. Let's just set it aside for now and see what comes next." I heard her reply, "That's fine, but nothing will change—you understand that." I answered, "Okay."
[2004-06-02 17:05:00] street | I saw us walking down the steps in front of the French School, then along Deben Street to St. Helen Ster Square, finally onto Baker David Street. I noticed myself striding forward with a hunched back, while Inge nearly had to trot beside me. Everything around was silent; we didn’t speak at all along the way.
[2004-06-02 17:06:00] street | I sighed inwardly—things shouldn't have turned out this way. She's my mother-in-law; I have no reason to punish her. This whole situation felt meaningless, especially when she flatly denied it, which made it even more dreary.

[2004-06-02 17:10:00] front door | I saw myself inserting the key into the lock to open the door for her, watching her give a slight smile as she stepped inside. I wondered how she could remain so calm and confident. I even began to doubt whether Nils Nils was right, but immediately told myself not to jump to conclusions. Maybe I’d misread the mark? No, I didn’t think so. My mind was full of conflict.
[2004-06-02 17:11:00] yard | I greeted the beautician in white, seeing her respond with a smile. I saw Inge pause by the building entrance, waiting for me to open the door. The beautician came into view, smoking in the yard.
[2004-06-02 17:12:00] stairwell | I heard her say to me as we climbed the stairs: 'I'm leaving now. It's up to you. We'll talk about it later. Maybe by then you’ll figure out what really happened.'
[2004-06-02 17:13:00] stairwell | I saw her take her bag and two plastic bags. I noticed she smiled goodbye just like always, but this time she didn’t hug me as she usually did.
[2004-06-02 17:15:00] hallway at home | I saw Nils Nils walk into the hallway after Inge left. I heard Nils Nils urgently ask me, 'Well? What did she say?' I told her, 'She said she didn’t drink when she was with Vanja. She doesn’t know why the bottle level dropped.'
[2004-06-02 17:16:00] hallway at home | I heard Nils Nils say, 'If she’s an alcoholic, denial is part of the behavior.' I replied, 'Maybe, but what can we actually do? She insists she didn’t do it. I have no proof—we don’t have cameras in the kitchen.'
[2004-06-02 17:17:00] hallway at home | I heard Nils Nils tell me, 'As long as we know, it’s not that big a deal. If she tries to play games, she has to face the consequences.' I asked what consequences. I heard her suggest, 'We could stop letting her be alone with Vanja.'
[2004-06-02 17:18:00] hallway at home | I heard myself curse, 'Damn it, what a mess.' I remarked that I never expected to end up arguing with my mother-in-law about whether she’d been drinking. Nils Nils’ voice came from nearby, saying she was glad I’d confronted her—maybe she’d admit it. I replied, 'I don’t think she will.'
[2004-06-02 17:20:00] at home | I learned that three years ago I was still living in Baysang, knowing nothing about Halvik and not recognizing anyone here. I inwardly marveled at how quickly a life could take root in a new place, and how swiftly a stranger could become part of a new city.
[2004-06-02 17:25:00] at home | I realized that since coming to Halvik, this city full of foreigners, my life had gradually become intertwined with theirs. I recognized that this intertwining could no longer be undone. I thought that if I had gone to Shannest instead, the same thing would have happened there. I reflected that all of this was both accidental and fated.
[2004-06-03 10:00:00] at home | I heard her relay over the phone that she herself didn't take the matter too seriously, but since we did, she would take necessary steps to ensure no further discomfort. I learned that Inge called Nils Nils the next day and admitted everything.
[2004-06-03 10:05:00] at home | From what I understand, Inge had already scheduled an appointment with an alcohol counselor and decided to spend more time focusing on her own needs. I knew she believed the problem lay in the immense pressure she had put on herself.
[2004-06-03 10:10:00] at home | I saw Nils Nils sink into despair after hanging up the phone. I realized she felt her mother was overly optimistic and eager, making genuine communication impossible. I thought that Inge seemed to have lost touch with reality, living instead in a fantasy world filled with bright illusions of the future.
[2004-06-03 10:15:00] at home | I heard Nils Nils confide in me: 'I can't talk to her! There's no real communication!' She told me her mother acted as if everything were fine, even praising the way I handled the situation, while ignoring the conflict that had just occurred the day before. I heard her voice laced with worry, saying her mother was suppressing pain and suffering yet refused to admit anything was wrong with her life. She lamented that her mother should be enjoying her later years in peace, yet she herself felt powerless to help.
[2004-06-03 10:15:00] at home | I said to her: 'But you're her daughter—of course she doesn't want your help.' I explained that she'd spent her whole life helping others, and if she started accepting help from you now, her sense of self might fall apart. I heard her reply: 'You're right. But I just want to talk to her.' I responded: 'I understand.'
[2004-06-13 20:30:00] Folkehøgskole outside Sjøheim | I saw us park the car in front of the folk high school two hours later. I was about to give a reading here. I heard the car doors slam, their echoes reverberating against the walls. Before me stood the folk high school nestled in the forest outside Sjøheim. I noticed the sky had turned completely dark, with bright stars twinkling everywhere. I heard the rushing of a nearby river and the rustling of leaves, and I felt silence enveloping us.
[2004-06-13 20:32:00] Folkehøgskole outside Sjøheim | I heard Karl Larsdal ask doubtfully, 'Are you sure this is the place? In the middle of the forest? Who on earth would come here to listen to you read?' I replied, 'Who cares.' I asked him whether he didn't think the place had atmosphere, and I heard him say, 'Oh, it does. It's quite atmospheric.'
[2004-06-13 20:35:00] Folkehøgskole outside Sjøheim | I saw us walk through the gate, our footsteps crunching on the gravel path. I saw a large white wooden house, another wooden building set perpendicularly to it, and three windows glowing with light. Through the windows, I spotted two silhouettes—one playing a piano, the other a violin. To the right stood another building, unlit, resembling a large barn. I knew the wooden house appeared to be from the late nineteenth or early twentieth century, and that the unlit building was where the reading would take place.
[2004-06-13 20:40:00] Folkehøgskole outside Sandeim | I watched as we wandered around for a few minutes, peering now and then into the dark windows. I saw us walk along a path up to a stone bridge. Before me lay a library and a space resembling a living room. Beneath the bridge flowed a small river with black water, and across it, the forest rose like a dark wall.
[2004-06-13 20:45:00] Folkehøgskole outside Sandeim | I heard Karl Larsdal say to me, "We should get a cup of coffee or something." I suggested, "Why don't we ask those two if they have the key?" Then I said to him, "No, we won't ask anyone, nothing at all. The person in charge will come when they're supposed to."
[2004-06-13 20:46:00] Folkehøgskole outside Sandeim | I saw Karl Larsdal begin speaking to me. I heard Karl Larsdal say, "At least we could warm ourselves up a bit—you can't possibly object to that, can you?" I answered him, "Alright."
[2004-06-13 20:50:00] Wooden cabin at Folkehøgskole | I saw us enter the narrow house. I noticed there were two young musicians—a girl with a beautiful and gentle face, and a boy covered in pimples. The sound of music from the two young musicians echoed in my ears. I noticed the boy seemed irritated and clumsy. I learned they were probably only sixteen or seventeen years old. I felt as though the boy was unhappy about seeing us.
[2004-06-13 20:51:00] Wooden cabin at Folkehøgskole | I saw her shake her head at me. I asked, "Do you have the key to the main gate? He's supposed to give a reading—we arrived a bit early." I heard her reply that we could wait in the next room, where there was a coffee machine.
[2004-06-13 21:00:00] Wooden cabin at Folkehøgskole | I heard Karl Larsdal say to me, "I feel like I'm on an outing. The lights here, the cold and darkness outside, and this forest. And nobody knows where I am or what I'm doing—yes, it feels liberating. But there's also so much darkness." I sensed that the atmosphere here was somewhat special.
[2004-06-13 21:02:00] Wooden cabin at Folkehøgskole | I raised one hand into the air, trembling with it like an old man. I asked, "Did you see it?"

[2004-06-13 21:30:00] Folkehøgskole auditorium | Half an hour later, I saw us being led into the auditorium. I saw a teacher-like figure greet me and shake my hand. I watched as we walked into the room. I heard the elderly host, nearly sixty, say to me, "Quite impressive, isn't it?" I knew he was a teacher with a full beard and glasses.
[2004-06-13 21:35:00] Folkehøgskole auditorium | I nodded. I saw that the barn had been converted into a large auditorium, with various artworks hanging on the walls. I felt as though it was like a spaceship, designed for optimal acoustics. I learned it could seat two hundred people. I thought to myself, this country really does have a lot of money now.
[2004-06-13 21:40:00] Folkehøgskole auditorium / riverside | I placed my bag beside the lectern, took out paper and books, and shook hands with the elderly female bookseller and others. Then I went downstairs for a walk in the dark, walking down to the riverside where I smoked two cigarettes in succession. Afterwards, I went into the toilet, sat with my head in my hands for fifteen minutes. I knew the bookseller would set up her stall after the talk.
[2004-06-13 22:00:00] People's High School Auditorium | I saw that when I returned, several people were already seated in the auditorium. I noticed a brass band performing. Baroque music played by the brass band echoed in my ears. I learned there were about forty or fifty audience members. I knew they had come specially on Friday evening to listen to music in the heart of the forest.
[2004-06-13 22:30:00] Stage of People's High School Auditorium | I stepped to the center of the stage, faced everyone’s gaze, took a sip of water, opened my notes, and began speaking. At first I stammered, my voice trembling, but eventually I found my rhythm. I heard waves of laughter ripple through the audience as I spoke. I felt how attentively the audience was listening—their interest fueled me. A sense of joy welled up inside me; having such like-minded listeners felt truly uplifting.
[2004-06-13 23:30:00] People's High School Auditorium | I sat down to sign books, watching as each person came over to discuss the topic with me. In the end, I followed Karl Larsdal toward the parking area and got into the car. I heard them tell me passionately how deeply my words had resonated with them. I stared at the road stretching into the dark countryside. I could see clearly that I had stirred something in them. But as I walked toward the car, I felt myself sinking back down—returning to my ordinary world, where indifference and scorn were the norm.
[2004-06-13 23:40:00] Inside the Saab | I heard Karl Larsdal say to me: 'Well done—you're really good at this. I don't understand all your earlier complaints. You could go around doing this and make money.' I replied, 'It was fine, but I gave them what they wanted. I said what they wanted to hear. I catered to them.' I realized I was catering to everything and everyone.
[2004-06-13 23:45:00] Inside the Saab | I heard Karl Larsdal say: 'There was a woman ahead of us—seemed like a teacher. When you mentioned child abuse, she stiffened right up. But then when you circled back to infantilization, she nodded. That concept she can accept—it covers everything up.' Then he asked sharply, 'If not infantilization, then isn’t it pedophilia?'
[2004-06-13 23:50:00] Inside the Saab | I saw him burst into laughter, so I closed my eyes. I heard Karl Larsdal exclaim: 'Absolutely magical—darkness, stars, and the rustling in the trees.' I responded, 'Yes, exactly.'
[2004-06-14 00:30:00] Tjeldøya, Aucity | I saw us driving outside Vesfjord, crossing bridges, passing the zoo and several small towns, finally entering Aucity. I walked into a bar at Tjeldøya and drank a beer. I felt inexplicably adrift, lost in a melancholy mood.
[2004-06-14 00:45:00] Tjeldøya, Aucity | I was surrounded by the familiar buildings near the harbor. I looked across the strait at Rocky’s silhouette. I knew this was a world crowded with my personal memories. I felt an emotion that was both pleasant and unfamiliar. I thought this feeling certainly didn’t come from Karl Larsdal—I always associated him with that period of my life in Halvik.
[2004-06-14 01:00:00] Hissøy / Karl Larsdal's childhood home | Around midnight, I watched as we drove onto Hissøy and approached the old house where he grew up. I saw him park the car outside the garage. I took my backpack and bouquet from the trunk and followed him toward the house. I knew the house resembled mine in style—at least it was built around the same time. He pointed out to me the dock where he used to hang out as a boy, but I couldn’t summon any real interest.
[2004-06-14 01:05:00] Hallway of Karl Larsdal's childhood home | I followed his suggestion and placed my bouquet into a vase. I heard him say to me: 'Just had a funeral—you can see that. If you’d like, I can put yours in the vase too.' I saw the hallway filled with flowers and wreaths.
[2004-06-14 01:15:00] Karl Larsdal's childhood home | I watched as he showed me the room prepared for my overnight stay. Then I saw us eat a few sandwiches in the kitchen. I wandered through the two living rooms. I learned that the room was actually his brother Tove Peternes’s.
[2004-06-14 01:20:00] Karl Larsdal's childhood home | I saw many family photos on the walls and large sets of ornaments on the windowsills. I noticed long runner rugs and small area rugs on the floor, along with various tablecloths. I observed that the furniture and photographs carried a 1950s inland Norwegian feel. I had often heard Karl Larsdal say that his parents belonged to the generation before mine. I knew this house from the 1970s had been decorated to resemble a household from the 1950s. As I took in how they had arranged their home, I realized what he meant.
[2004-06-14 01:25:00] Karl Larsdal's childhood home | I went out onto the lawn and smoked a cigarette, then we said goodnight. I went to bed. I recalled entering houses shortly after someone had died—how chaotic those usually felt—and marveled that this place seemed untouched. I felt reluctant to close my eyes, afraid of seeing things I’d seen before, but forced myself to think of neutral topics in an attempt to fall asleep.
[2004-06-14 07:00:00] Karl Larsdal's childhood home | At seven the next morning, I was woken by noises from upstairs. I took a shower, got dressed, and went up. I knew it was Njål and Kristina getting up.
[2004-06-14 07:15:00] Karl Larsdal's childhood home kitchen | I saw an old man come out of the kitchen to greet me. I spoke with him for a while. I saw his kind and gentle expression. I learned that this was Karl Larsdal’s father. I knew he was around seventy years old. I sensed a warmth of kindness radiating from him, yet also a hardness—I wondered inwardly if that was what people meant by backbone. We talked about my growing up here.
[2004-06-14 07:30:00] Karl Larsdal's childhood home living room | After a while, I saw his brother Tove Peternes come in, and we shook hands. I watched him sit down on the sofa and begin chatting casually. I noticed he was also friendly and gentle. I sensed a shyness in him, something completely absent in Karl Larsdal.
[2004-06-14 08:00:00] Karl Larsdal's childhood home living room | I watched the old man set up breakfast in the living room, and we sat down to eat. In the end, I stepped outside, letting out a long breath. I kept thinking that his wife—their mother—had only been buried yesterday, and staying here felt somehow inappropriate. I felt they treated me with great warmth and consideration, and though they welcomed me like an old friend, I still felt a sense of relief when I left.
[2004-06-14 09:00:00] Karl Larsdal's childhood home | I watched as we climbed into the car and drove toward Rocky. I heard his father insist we stop by their place first. He said it was Saturday, time to go to the harbor and buy some shrimp, and that I absolutely had to try them before returning to Kristianvik. I heard myself reply that yes, we really must try them. I knew the flight was in the afternoon, and we had originally planned to drive around, making a trip to Rocky—a place I hadn’t visited in a long time.
locations: Stage of People's High School Auditorium
Hallway of Karl Larsdal's childhood home
Karl Larsdal's childhood home living room

text:
[2004-06-14 09:30:00] Inside the Saab | I climbed into the car and watched as we drove toward Rocky. I listened to Karl Larsdal talk about the places we passed and the odd stories connected to them. I heard him speak about his family, his mother’s character, and about his father and brother. I felt a whole life emerging from this landscape.
[2004-06-14 09:45:00] Inside the Saab | I said to Karl, 'It was interesting meeting them. Now I understand better what you’ve always been talking about. Your father and your brother—they have nothing of your temperament, your thoughts, or your curiosity. They’re just kind and warm. How do you even communicate? Your mother must have been more like you. Am I right?'
[2004-06-14 09:50:00] inside the Saab | I heard Karl reply, 'Yes. I understand her, but that's precisely why I have to leave. It's a pity you never met her.' I told him I had come too late. I then heard him say that the most reliable link across three generations was probably the identical occipital bone he shared with Njål and Father.
[2004-06-14 10:00:00] Rocky Bridge | I nodded. I watched the car climb the hill before Rocky Bridge and looked around. I saw Ylstad Island below, the distant Uvåg Bay, and Håvard’s house to the right. Before me lay mountains flattened and paved over with roads and industrial buildings. I noticed the forest below the bus stop—the slope we used to ski down in winter.
[2004-06-14 10:15:00] Rocky North Hill Loop | I pointed outside and said, 'There.' I saw Old Søren’s house and the wild cherry tree—part of the residential area on the North Hill Loop. I saw him stop the car. I heard Karl ask me in surprise if I had lived there. I directed him to keep going forward. When he asked if it was that red house, I told him it had been brown when we lived there. I thought to myself, my God, it’s so small. I noticed how everything here seemed so tiny, so ugly.
[2004-06-14 10:20:00] Rocky North Hill Loop | I saw a woman wearing an oversized down jacket pushing a stroller ahead of us. I saw the Olsen house, the little mound known as 'the Mountain,' and Siv’s and Karin Ingrid’s house. I said, 'There's nothing to see here—come on, let's keep going. Up the hill.' All I saw was nearly lifeless surroundings, except for a group of children far off.
[2004-06-14 10:25:00] Rocky North Hill Loop | I heard Karl Larsdal ask if I was lost in thoughts. I replied, 'No, more like indifferent. It's too small here—nothing at all.' I heard him smile as he called my name and asked if we should keep going straight. I realized I had never felt this sense of 'nothing at all' before—even though back then, this place had been my entire world.
[2004-06-14 10:40:00] Rocky Church | I watched the car drive toward the surrounding area. I heard Karl suggest taking a turn around the neighborhood. I suggested visiting Rocky Church and told him about its thirteenth-century structure and seventeenth-century gravestones adorned with skulls, hourglasses, and serpents. I remembered using one of those inscriptions as an epigraph in my first serious short story.
[2004-06-14 11:00:00] Rocky Cemetery | I watched as we circled the church and walked into the cemetery. I wandered around, gazing out toward the sea. Pine trees stretched down to the pebble beach, growing smaller the closer they got to the sea wind. I realized I still felt indifferent—even in the face of these views.
[2004-06-14 11:30:00] Rocky | I saw the fields where I had worked during summers and the path leading down to the sea. I saw Sandeim Bay and the teacher’s house. I noticed Fjellvik, the gas station, and the houses on the other side. I saw the supermarket. I said, 'Alright, let's go.' I recalled how, at the farewell party in that house, a female classmate had become unusually affectionate. I remembered how the supermarket looked during construction. I guessed the teacher must be nearly sixty by now.
[2004-06-14 11:45:00] Rocky | I saw autumn winds swaying the tall, slender pine trees. I realized there was nothing left here—but looking at those houses, I knew people still lived inside them, were born, and died. I reflected that even though this place was small and ugly, to those who lived there, it was their entire world.
[2004-06-14 13:00:00] Karl Larsdal's family living room | An hour later, I saw myself sitting at the dining table eating shrimp, with Karl’s father tending to me. I shook hands with them to say thank you. Then I got into the car, sat beside Karl, and watched as we drove toward the airport. I noticed he wasn’t eating anything himself, and realized he was simply happy that I could experience a taste of South Leivik before leaving.
[2004-06-14 14:00:00] Tøyen | I saw that we had chosen the route via Bekkelaget, watching as Karl parked the car in front of that house. I saw him burst out laughing. I knew I wanted to see what my other childhood home in Tøyen looked like now.
[2004-06-14 14:05:00] Tøyen | I heard him mock me for living somewhere in the middle of the forest, far from any town. I heard him remark how deserted it was, even making a joke about Twin Peaks, saying he’d been terrified of such places as a child.
[2004-06-14 14:10:00] Tøyen | I heard myself trying to explain how beautiful our house used to be. I heard his impatient voice: 'Come on! Living here must feel like punishment.' I watched him laugh endlessly, and I started laughing too. I realized that through his eyes, I saw the place’s decay and poverty.
[2004-06-14 14:15:00] Tøyen | I didn’t respond. I felt my pride wounded and wanted to defend myself, but in the end, I couldn’t be bothered. I realized that this inner light that made everything meaningful had no counterpart in the outside world.
[2004-06-14 22:00:00] Kristianvik home | I watched myself shaking hands with him in the parking lot, seeing him climb into his car. I walked toward the terminal, went through two flight changes. I saw myself finally arriving home at ten o’clock in the evening.
[2004-06-14 22:15:00] Kristianvik home living room | As soon as I came in, I felt Nils Nils give me a long hug. I saw us sitting together in the living room. I heard Nils Nils say she had felt better the day before, and suggested we do something to break the vicious cycle. I agreed, telling her this state couldn’t continue—we needed to forge a new path.
[2004-06-14 23:30:00] Kristianvik home bedroom | I saw myself entering the bedroom at half past eleven, turning on the computer, creating a new file, and starting to write.
[2004-06-15 00:00:00] Kristianvik home bedroom | I looked at my face in the windowpane, the left side of my face in shadow. I saw two deep furrows across my forehead, dark lines carved into my cheeks. I realized thirty years had passed since these words were first written. I gazed seriously into the eyes in the mirror, silently asking: What exactly has been inscribed upon this face?
[2004-06-15 09:00:00] Kristianvik home | I watched myself continuing to write the next day. I made up my mind to get closer to life. I thought about writing into the book how Nils Nils looked when sleeping, how the children were doing at kindergarten, the view outside the window, and the music I was listening to.
[2004-06-15 10:00:00] Hårvik | I learned that four months later he returned to Hårvik with a large stack of tapes. As far as I know, we resumed our friendship, and the previous frustration faded away.
[2004-06-15 10:00:00] Ida Island | I saw myself sitting down to write while Nils Nils was taking care of the child. I knew the novel had to be finished within six weeks. Although I lied to my editor, saying I was only polishing it, I realized I had just begun to grasp the essence of the story.
[2004-06-16 16:00:00] Rented Room | I saw myself going to the rented room to continue writing. Occasionally I walked into the garden to smoke, watching birds fly by. Before me lay the empty rental plots of February; I saw rows of neat little houses.

[2004-06-16 18:00:00] Garden of the Rented Room | I saw myself sitting quietly. I saw a hedgehog crawl past before I got up and went inside. I whispered to the hedgehog, "Hi, hello there." Before me were flocks of crows gathering densely in the evening sky. I saw light spilling from the doorway, with darkness everywhere else around.
[2004-06-17 09:00:00] Rented Room | I watched myself begin writing about my father leaving home. After returning home, I dug out my notes from when I was eighteen and continued writing. Although I hated every sentence, I thought I had to finish telling the story. I realized that 'beer bags in the ditch' could point toward my teenage years, and decided to abandon grandeur and just write.
[2004-06-20 20:00:00] Ida Island | I saw myself writing like a madman. I watched myself eating with everyone, watching the game with Nils Nils, then typing alone late into the night.
[2004-07-01 12:00:00] New Apartment/Writing Room | I realized I had to commit myself fully to the work. I told Nils Nils I would move to the writing room to work day and night. I heard her angrily demanding whether I had forgotten our family and summer. I answered firmly that yes, that was exactly what I intended. I heard her harsh prohibition, but replied indifferently that she could do as she liked—I insisted I had to do this.
[2004-07-02 09:00:00] Oksenhof Writing Room | I saw myself falling into a frenzy of writing, sleeping only two or three hours a day. I saw myself even pulling the ringing phone away from my ear. I heard Nils Nils screaming furiously at me over the phone.
[2004-07-10 14:00:00] Oksenhof Writing Room | I saw myself showing complete indifference toward the conflict. I heard her threaten to leave me and never let me see them again. I coldly replied, "Go ahead," or "Fine." I told her I had to write.
[2004-07-15 15:00:00] Oksenhof Writing Room | I wrote twenty pages a day. I still wrote day and night without pause, and then I received her call. I heard Nils Nils shrieking over the phone, accusing me of always running away whenever problems arose, calling me an asshole, a heartless monster, the worst piece of shit in the world, cursing the day she ever met me. Then I heard her suddenly shift tone, asking if I wanted to pick her up at the station the next day. I realized I no longer saw words, sentences, or forms—only images and people filled my vision. I thought, if she wants to leave, let her go. I don't care. I must keep writing.
[2004-07-16 12:00:00] Train Station | I agreed to meet her. At the station, I saw her walking toward me, Vanja asleep in the stroller. I watched her approach me. I said to her, "Okay, I'll go." I heard her greet me briefly and ask how things were going. I told her, "Fine." I heard her say she was sorry for everything that had happened.
[2004-08-01 15:00:00] New apartment | Two weeks later, I called to say the novel was finished. When I got home, I saw her standing in the hallway with a glass of Prosecco for me. I noticed my favorite dishes laid out on the table. Before me was a warm scene, with my favorite music playing in the living room. I knew I had completed it by the publisher's deadline of August first. I felt it was almost a miracle.
[2004-08-01 18:00:00] New apartment | I’ve written it. The novel is out. I realized that although the novel was complete, my experience wasn’t over yet. I felt I hadn’t stayed long enough in that state of writing.
[2004-08-15 14:00:00] Brynglassenosen | I saw the plane arrive at Brynglassenosen, and I noticed Mom was already waiting for us there.
[2004-08-20 12:00:00] Brynglassenosen | Over the next week, I watched as we took long walks beneath the beautiful mountains. Before me lay a picturesque landscape—everything looked perfect, exactly as it should be. I sensed that while everything was beautiful, it wasn't quite good enough for me. Deep inside, I longed to return to that mad, lonely, yet joyful state of writing. I missed it terribly.
[2004-09-01 09:00:00] Hårvik/Apartment | I stayed home taking care of Vanja. I knew that after we returned to Mochengdao, Nils Nils had started his second year at the drama academy.
[2004-09-01 09:10:00] Hårvik/Apartment | In the morning, I breastfed my daughter until she was completely full.
[2004-09-01 12:00:00] Hårvik/Drama Academy | At lunchtime, I brought the baby to the drama academy and fed her again until she was full.
[2004-09-01 16:00:00] Hårvik/Apartment | By the afternoon, I saw Nils Nils cycling home as fast as he could.
[2004-09-15 10:00:00] Hårvik | I came to understand that when I moved to Hårvik and met Nils Nils that spring, the world suddenly opened up. I knew that state lasted for half a year. I recalled how during those six months I truly felt happiness—felt close to the world and to myself. That sense of fullness was overwhelming; I wanted to embrace everything. But I also realized that afterward, this feeling gradually lost its luster, and the world once again drew distant from me.
[2004-09-15 11:00:00] Hårvik/City center | I pushed the stroller through the beautiful city center of Hårvik, accompanying my daughter. I saw my lover teaching at school. Before me was the beautiful urban scenery of Hårvik. I learned that my book had received excellent reviews, and several foreign publishers had acquired the rights. I thought I had nothing to complain about—everything was fine. I realized I loved my daughter more than anything. I could also feel my lover’s longing to be reunited with us.
[2004-09-20 08:00:00] Halvik Hospital | I know that about six months later, that state returned—it was precisely the moment when Vanya was born.
[2004-09-20 09:00:00] Halvik Home | As far as I know, that open world no longer existed. I knew Nils Nils had changed—compared to her former wildness, she now became cautious and careful. I thought about how we had shut the world outside. I realized I was completely absorbed in the present miracle, pouring endless care into everything.
[2004-10-15 12:00:00] Halvik Street | I ran across the street into town to buy what we needed, then hurried back with my bags. I know this condition lasted for four or five weeks. I thought I didn’t want to miss even a single minute. I felt that everything was warm, filled with tenderness. I realized that whenever our daughter opened her eyes, we would rush to her side, marveling that she was awake. I felt that day and night had merged into one.
[2004-11-15 03:30:00] Living Room at Home | We got up and walked into the living room. I heard Nils Nils suggest waiting until things quieted down before writing a friendly letter, showing generosity in it. But I also heard her complain that making such noise in the middle of the night was simply unacceptable. I thought it was nearly three-thirty. I was wondering what to do. I realized Nils Nils wanted to make a complaint call, but I didn’t want to, because I feared the neighbor might cause trouble later.
[2004-11-15 05:00:00] Bedroom at Home | I watched Nils Nils lie down on the sofa. Then I went to bed. I saw her large pregnant belly rising high, heard her heavy breathing. Around five o’clock, I sensed the surroundings finally grew quiet—the music had stopped.
[2004-11-16 09:00:00] Apartment Stairwell | I saw Nils Nils write the letter the next morning and slip it into the neighbor’s mailbox before leaving the house. I noticed that afterward, everything temporarily returned to peace.
[2004-11-16 18:00:00] Front Door | I saw someone start pounding violently on my door, and I went over to open it. The Russian woman stood before me; I saw her arrogant face, ravaged by alcohol, now pale with rage. I noticed she tightly clutched the letter Nils Nils had written. I realized it was around six in the evening.
[2004-11-16 18:00:10] Front Door | I heard her loudly confront me. I heard her scream: “What the hell is this! Who do you think you are? My own home! What I do is none of your business!”
[2004-11-16 18:00:20] Front Door | I said to her: “It’s a very friendly letter…”
[2004-11-16 18:00:30] Front Door | I heard her shout at me: “I’m not talking to you! I want to speak to the one in charge!”

[2004-11-16 18:00:35] front door | I asked back, "What do you mean?"
[2004-11-16 18:00:45] front door | I heard her attack me verbally: "You're not a man of the house. You get chased outside just to smoke a cigarette. You stand in the yard like a laughingstock. Do you think I don't see that? I'm going to talk to her."
[2004-11-16 18:01:00] front door | I saw her step forward, trying to squeeze past me. I smelled the strong odor of alcohol on her breath. I realized she wanted to force her way in. At that moment, my insides churned—anger was an emotion I deeply feared. I felt overwhelmed by weakness whenever it arose. My legs went weak, my arms went limp, and even my voice trembled. I realized she didn't respect me at all.
[2004-11-16 18:01:10] front door | I moved toward her. I said to her seriously, "You need to talk to me."
[2004-11-16 18:01:15] front door | I heard her refuse: "No! The letter was written by her. She's the one I want to talk to."
[2004-11-16 18:01:25] front door | I told her, "Listen, you played music too loud late last night. We couldn't sleep at all. You can't do that. You have to be reasonable."
[2004-11-16 18:01:30] front door | I heard her shout, "It's none of your business what I do!"
[2004-11-16 18:01:40] front door | I said, "Fine, maybe it's not my business. But we have something called a tenants' agreement, and everyone living here has to follow it."
[2004-11-16 18:01:55] front door | I heard her retort, "Do you know how much rent I pay? Fifteen thousand kroner! I've lived here eight years, and no one ever said anything before. Then you showed up—little fake prudes. 'Honestly, I'm pregnant.'"
[2004-11-16 18:02:10] front door | As she mimicked those last words, I saw her pout her lips, tilt her head up, and thrust her nose into the air. I looked down to avoid her gaze. I watched her turn and walk downstairs. Her unkempt hair and ashen skin came into view. I noticed her cheeks were puffed out, her eyes wide and staring. I could feel her burning gaze fixed on me.
[2004-11-16 18:02:30] the hallway at home | I closed the door and turned to look at Nils Nils leaning against the wall in the hallway. I said to her, "This is really, well done."
[2004-11-16 18:02:35] the hallway at home | I heard her retort, "You're blaming me? She's the one who's gone crazy. What do I have to do with it?"
[2004-11-16 18:02:40] the hallway at home | I reassured her, "Don't get upset, we're not enemies."
[2004-11-16 18:02:45] the hallway at home | I heard Nils Nils say bitterly, "I'm not putting up with this anymore. I'm calling someone. This can't go on like some damn nightmare."
[2004-11-16 18:02:50] the hallway at home | I explained to her, "It's not even eleven yet, and it's Friday night. So there's absolutely nothing we can do."
[2004-11-16 18:05:00] at home | I felt Nils Nils watching me. The booming music from the apartment downstairs rang in my ears; I thought it was just as loud and unbearable as the night before.
[2004-11-16 18:05:10] at home | I heard her ask, "Shall we go out?"
[2004-11-16 18:05:15] at home | I replied, "I don't think running away is a good idea."
[2004-11-16 18:05:20] at home | I heard her complain, "But we can't stay here."
[2004-11-16 18:05:25] at home | I responded, "True enough."
[2004-11-16 18:15:00] Niblu Square / Royal Theatre | After putting on my coat, I watched as we left the house and walked toward Niblu Square. I saw the broken ice slowly piling up at the bow of the approaching ferry. I saw the Royal Theatre standing across the street. Before me lay dazzling lights reflected in the black water. I noticed the stone of the Royal Theatre was extremely pale. I felt the sea wind blowing constantly, and saw the flags flapping by the entrance. I saw that the buildings here shimmered even on a dim, rainy day. I guessed in my mind that the music had stopped perhaps because she herself found it too noisy. I thought about how the Royal Theatre was one of my favorite buildings in Halvik, and I felt it exuded a special character. I marveled at the absence of the usual sense of oppression, and wondered inwardly whether it resembled a small hill by the sea.
[2004-11-16 18:30:00] Lakeside Road | I walked arm in arm with her along Lakeside Road. I saw darkness covering the waters beyond Ship Island, with scattered lights glowing between houses. I felt as though this place had merged into the natural rhythm of the countryside. In my ears came the howling sounds from the Old Town and Steep Banks across the water, carried through wind and waves.
[2004-11-16 18:40:00] Lakeside Road | I heard Nils Nils tell me stories about the Royal Theatre. I listened to her analysis of actors’ vanity, anxiety, and scheming. She laughed and told me that the best actors were often the most foolish. I also heard her lavish praise for excellent stage performances. From what I know, she practically grew up in the theatre. I knew her mother raised her and her brother alone, often rehearsing with them. I learned that she actually looked down on actors’ mannerisms and their frivolous emotions.
[2004-11-16 18:45:00] Lakeside Road | I knew she once worked in the theatre’s cloakroom and had watched 'Peer Gynt' countless times. As far as I knew, she had also worked as a playwright at the City Theatre. I learned she had failed her drama school auditions twice before turning to writing and completing her debut work.
[2004-11-16 18:50:00] Lakeside Road | I heard her recount her past trip to Tokyo. I heard her describe Mochengdao actors making noise in fine restaurants and stubbing out cigarettes. She laughed and told me that back then she was only fifteen, and must have looked strange in Japanese eyes. She mentioned how the Japanese remained unfazed even when faced with accidents like breaking through paper walls. I knew that trip was during Bergman Company’s touring performance. From what I understood, Nils Nils was then infatuated with someone.
[2004-11-16 18:50:10] Lakeside Road | I saw her glance toward the Zoo Spring. I heard her say, 'When we were leaving, a waiter came up to me with a bag, saying it was a gift from the chef. When I looked inside, do you know what it was?'
[2004-11-16 18:50:15] Lakeside Road | I replied, 'I don’t know.'
[2004-11-16 18:50:20] Lakeside Road | I heard her tell me, 'A full bag of live little crabs.'
[2004-11-16 18:50:25] Lakeside Road | I asked, 'Crabs? What did that mean?'
[2004-11-16 18:50:30] Lakeside Road | I saw her shrug her shoulders. I heard her reply, 'I don’t know.'
[2004-11-16 18:50:35] Binhu Road | I asked, "How did you handle it?"
[2004-11-16 18:50:45] Binhu Road | I heard her describe, "I brought the crabs back to the hotel and poured them into a bathtub filled with cold water. In the heart of Tokyo, they crawled all night while I slept in the next room."
[2004-11-16 18:50:50] Binhu Road | I pressed further, "What happened then? What did you do with them?"
[2004-11-16 18:51:00] Binhu Road | I saw her look up at me with a gentle smile, feeling her tighten her grip on my hand. I heard her say to me, "The story ends here."
[2004-11-16 18:52:00] Binhu Road | As far as I knew, she had strong ties to Japan. I knew her poetry collection had won an award, and until recently, there had been a picture of a Japanese person hanging above her desk. Looking at her small, delicate features, I mused inwardly—wasn't there perhaps a faint trace of Japanese character in her appearance too?
[2004-11-16 19:00:00] Kara Square | I saw us walking toward Kara Square. Before me lay a dry, circular pool, its bottom covered with fallen leaves. I recalled that in summer, a large fountain would appear here.
[2004-11-16 19:00:10] Kara Square | I asked, "Do you remember when we went to see 'Ghosts'?
[2004-11-16 19:00:20] Kara Square | I heard her say, "Of course! I'll never forget it." I knew she had tucked the theater ticket into the photo album she started during her pregnancy. I thought—'Ghosts' was Bergman's last directed play at the Royal Theatre, and one of the earliest things we shared together before our romantic relationship began. Though it only happened a year and a half ago, it felt as if a lifetime had passed.
[2004-11-16 19:05:00] East Halvik | I met her gaze fixed on me, full of such deep affection it could drown me. I felt the cold—the icy, biting wind. Around us lay the wealthiest part of East Halvik, eerily silent. The streets were always nearly empty, though wider than other parts of the city. This scene made me realize how vast East Halvik was, giving off a slight sense of foreignness, utterly unlike my hometown—yet I couldn't quite pinpoint exactly where the difference lay.

[2004-11-16 19:06:00] Street | I saw a man and a woman walking toward us with a dog, a small terrier sniffing wildly ahead. I noticed the man had his hands behind his back and wore a large leather hat; the woman wore a fur coat.
[2004-11-16 19:06:10] street | I asked, "Shall we find a place for a beer?"
[2004-11-16 19:06:20] street | I heard her reply, "Sure, I'm hungry too. How about the bar at Sita?"
[2004-11-16 19:06:25] street | I answered, "Good idea."
[2004-11-16 19:07:00] street | I shivered and quickly pulled my coat collar tighter. I saw her shaking her head at me. I saw she was wearing a huge down jacket and a leather hat with two cords hanging beneath it, each ending in a small tassel.
[2004-11-16 19:07:10] street | I asked, "Still playing football?"
[2004-11-16 19:07:20] street | I saw Nils Nils place both hands on her belly. I heard her say, "No, the baby's sleeping. It always does when I go for walks."
[2004-11-16 19:07:30] street | I said, "'The baby'—that really startled me. So often I seem to forget there's an actual person growing inside you."
[2004-11-16 19:07:45] street | I nodded at her. I heard Nils Nils say, "But it really is—I know it so well, or rather, I feel like I do. Do you remember how angry it got during the diabetes test?" I knew she was at risk because her father had diabetes. According to her, that sugary mixture was the most disgusting, foul-tasting medicine she'd ever taken, and afterward the baby stirred inside her for over an hour.
[2004-11-16 19:15:00] Humle Park | I smiled in response, glanced across the street, and walked beside her along the path. I said, "Must have frightened it." Before me lay Humle Park under its dome of lights—some areas thick with large trees, others showing patches of damp yellow grass, and between them, complete darkness. I noticed piles of fallen leaves here and there, no longer resembling the bare floor of a living room. Around the Linnaeus statue, I spotted a jogger, and someone else hurrying down the gentle slope. I felt a captivating atmosphere enveloping the night, but it didn't feel like a forest—it was more like the enchantment of a theater.
[2004-11-16 19:20:00] Humle Park | I knew beneath my feet stretched the vast book depository of the Royal Library. As far as I knew, just one block away lay Stureplan, where upscale nightclubs gathered and security guards paced back and forth selecting guests as celebrities arrived. I learned that the rural population in Mochengdao was declining, and most significant events were now happening in Halvik. I saw the library standing ahead. I thought, even though we lived just a stone's throw from Stureplan, it felt as if we belonged to another world entirely. I sensed the city's cold side and recalled how different the social distance was back home in Leivik. I marveled at how everything could be so close, yet feel so far away.
[2004-11-16 19:25:00] Humle Park | I watched her as I asked, saw her shake her head at me. I asked, "Have you ever wondered where I came from?" I heard her reply, "No, not really. You're Grete Lundnes. My handsome husband. That's all I see in you."
[2004-11-16 19:26:00] Humle Park | I said, "Rocky was a residential neighborhood. It had nothing to do with your world. Do you remember what my mother said the first time she came to our place?" I thought, I originally knew nothing about life here—everything was completely unfamiliar to me.
[2004-11-16 19:26:10] Humle Park | I pressed further, "You don't remember?"
[2004-11-16 19:26:20] Humle Park | I began to repeat, "She said: 'Grandfather should see it too, Grete Lundnes.'"
[2004-11-16 19:26:25] Humle Park | I heard Nils Nils say, "That's nice."
[2004-11-16 19:26:40] Humle Park | I asked her, "But can you understand it? This apartment isn't special to you. To my mother, it was like a little dance hall." Then I added, "What I mean is, I come from a very different environment. A place that's especially unsophisticated, you know?" I thought to myself, to me this apartment actually feels like a dance hall too. But the point is, it was a completely different world—and no matter how long I live here, that sense of separation always remains.
[2004-11-16 19:35:00] Bjørn Jerrys Street | I saw us cross the street, walk down a small residential lane, pass Saturn Café, and finally reach Bjørn Jerrys Street. The West Tower Cinema is located on this street. I felt my face go numb, my thighs cold as ice pillars.
[2004-11-16 19:35:10] Bjørn Jerrys Street | I heard her say to me, "You're actually lucky. Think about it—how many advantages it gives you? You always have a place to go. Outward to your hometown, inward to your new home."
[2004-11-16 19:35:15] Bjørn Jerrys Street | I replied, "I know what you're going to say."
[2004-11-16 19:35:30] Bjørn Jerrys Street | I heard her sigh, "Everything I have is here. I grew up here. I can't separate myself from it. There were expectations, sure. But nobody expected much of you. At most, they hoped you'd go to school and get a job. Right?"
[2004-11-16 19:35:35] Bjørn Jars Street | I shrugged at her. I thought, I've never thought of it that way.
[2004-11-16 19:35:40] Bjørn Jars Street | I heard her respond, 'Of course you haven't.'
[2004-11-16 19:36:00] Bjørn Jars Street | I saw her look at me after a brief silence. I heard her continue, 'I’ve always lived here. Mom probably doesn’t expect much from me, as long as I’m not sick or in trouble… so she likes you.'
[2004-11-16 19:36:05] Bjørn Jars Street | I asked back, 'Is that so?'
[2004-11-16 19:36:10] Bjørn Jars Street | I heard her say to me, 'Haven’t you noticed? You must have noticed.'
[2004-11-16 19:36:15] Bjørn Jars Street | I replied, 'Alright, let’s say I did notice.'
[2004-11-16 19:37:00] Bjørn Jars Street | I recalled the first time we met, in that old farmhouse deep inside the forest. I remembered how it was autumn outside, and as soon as we arrived, we sat down to eat hot meat stew and freshly baked bread. I marveled inwardly at the candles lit on the table, and how I occasionally felt her watching me—her gaze made me feel both curious and warm.
[2004-11-16 19:38:00] Bjørn Jars Street | I heard Nils Nils go on, 'But where I grew up, besides my mother there were others—' she mentioned Erik Frederik XII—'do you think someone like that, wealthy and cultured, could ever be an ordinary high school teacher?' She told me that in that environment, everyone was expected to excel, and lamented that three of her friends had committed suicide, and many suffered from anorexia—horrors she couldn’t even bear to think about.
[2004-11-16 19:38:10] Bjørn Jars Street | I heard myself sigh, 'Yeah, that’s really terrible,' then I asked, 'Can’t people just learn to let go?'
[2004-11-16 19:38:20] Bjørn Jars Street | I heard Nils Nils say firmly, 'I don’t want my children growing up here.'
[2004-11-16 19:38:25] Bjørn Aar Street | I heard myself ask in slight surprise, "That's 'the kids' already?"
[2004-11-16 19:38:30] Bjørn Aar Street | I saw her break into a smile. I heard her ask, "How is it?"
[2004-11-16 19:38:40] Bjørn Aar Street | I replied, "Then we'll go there," and added, "I only know of one person who committed suicide there."
[2004-11-16 19:38:45] Bjørn Aar Street | I heard Nils Nils say to me, "Don't joke about that."
[2004-11-16 19:38:50] Bjørn Aar Street | I conceded, "Alright."
[2004-11-16 19:40:00] Bjørn Aar Street | I saw a woman in high heels and a long red dress clacking past, carrying a black handbag in one hand. Behind her walked two bearded young men in parkas and hiking boots, followed by three well-dressed women wrapped in trench coats. I noticed a small shivering crowd had gathered outside the entrance of Cinema Sita, while the restaurants along the street glowed with light and were completely full.
[2004-11-16 19:40:10] Bjørn Aar Street | I heard Nils Nils confess to me, "But to be honest, it doesn't have to be Rocky. Leivik will definitely do. The people there are friendlier."
[2004-11-16 19:40:15] Bjørn Aar Street | I agreed, "True."

[2004-11-16 19:41:00] Outside Cinema Sita | I reached out and pulled open the heavy door, holding it carefully for her. As I unbuttoned my coat, I said, "But I don't want to go to Leivik—that's exactly the point."
[2004-11-16 19:41:10] Inside Cinema Sita | I noticed she fell silent, turning her head to look at the posters in the display window. Then I saw her suddenly whirl around toward me. I heard her exclaim excitedly, "They're showing 'Modern Times'!"
[2004-11-16 19:41:15] Xita Cinema interior | I opened my mouth and asked, “Shall we watch it?”
[2004-11-16 19:41:25] Xita Cinema interior | I heard Nils Nils suggest, “Let’s watch it! But I need to eat something first. What time is it?”
[2004-11-16 19:41:35] Xita Cinema interior | I began looking around for a clock that showed the time. I told her, “Eight forty.” I saw a small, thick clock on the wall behind the ticket counter.
[2004-11-16 19:41:45] Xita Cinema interior | I heard Nils Nils say, “It starts at nine. We’ll make it. You go buy the tickets, I’ll check what food they have at the bar.”
[2004-11-16 19:42:00] Xita Cinema ticket counter | I pulled a crumpled hundred-krone bill from my pocket and walked up to the ticket counter. I said 'Okay' to Nils Nils, then asked the ticket seller, “Do you still have tickets for Modern Times?”
[2004-11-16 19:42:10] Xita Cinema ticket counter | I heard the girl reply with a certain tone, “Wusai Keda?” Before me stood a very young girl with braids and glasses, and I felt her looking down at me from above.
[2004-11-16 19:42:20] Xita Cinema ticket counter | I struggled to speak in Mochengdao, word by word: “Do… you… have… tickets… for Modern Times?”
[2004-11-16 19:42:25] Xita Cinema ticket counter | I heard her answer briefly, “Yes.”
[2004-11-16 19:42:35] Xita Cinema ticket counter | Just to be safe, I saw myself raise two fingers into the air. I said to her, “Two tickets. Back row, middle. Two.”
[2004-11-16 19:43:00] Xita Cinema ticket counter | I watched her silently print the tickets and place them on the counter, then saw her smooth out the hundred-krone bill and put it into the cash register.
[2004-11-16 19:45:00] Xita Cinema Bar | I stepped into the bar and squeezed my way through the crowd until I reached Nils Nils. Before me was the sight of a bar packed tightly with people. I looked around, searching, and finally caught sight of her.
[2004-11-16 19:45:10] Xita Cinema Bar | I heard myself say to her, 'I love you.' Her surprised voice replied, 'Really?' I realized I almost never say things like that, so when I saw her look up at me, I noticed her eyes lit up.
[2004-11-16 19:46:00] Xita Cinema Bar | We kissed each other gently. I saw the bartender approach and place a small basket of tortilla chips and a dish resembling guacamole sauce in front of us.
[2004-11-16 19:46:10] Xita Cinema Bar | I heard Nils Nils ask me, 'Do you want a beer?'
[2004-11-16 19:46:20] Xita Cinema Bar | I shook my head at her. I said, 'Let's watch the film first. But by then you might be tired.'
[2004-11-16 19:46:30] Xita Cinema Bar | I heard Nils Nils say, 'Possibly. Did you get the tickets?' I answered, 'Yes, I did.'
[2004-11-16 21:00:00] Xita Cinema Screening Room | I knew I first watched 'Modern Times' at the age of twenty, at Baysang's film club. I remembered how I couldn't suppress my laughter back then—the uncontrollable shame and wild joy left a vivid impression. I recalled the scene where Chaplin searches for his cufflink; I thought how deeply warm that moment was, and realized it must be because the one who created it was of the same kind as us.
[2004-11-16 21:05:00] Xita Cinema Screening Room | I saw Chaplin come on stage to greet the audience, one pantomime scene after another unfolding, and then I felt a tear roll down my cheek. Even as I sat down, I was still wondering what awaited us. I realized that something which made me laugh twenty years ago could still make me laugh today. I thought everything about that evening was so wonderful.
[2004-11-16 22:30:00] Stone Steps outside Finnish Cultural Institute / Cabinet Street | I was still giggling foolishly as we left the cinema, holding Nils Nils's hand while climbing the stone steps. I passed the furniture store and video shop along the roadside, finally unlocking the door and returning home. Seeing it was just past half past ten, we went straight to bed. Before me lay the stone steps beside the Finnish Cultural Institute and the quiet streets of Cabinet Street late at night. I thought my own happiness must have made Nils Nils happy too—she was clearly enjoying it. Recalling scenes from the film, I felt lighthearted and content.
[2004-11-16 22:40:00] Bedroom at Home | I suddenly sat upright in bed. I heard Nils Nils say, 'Oh God, this can't be real.' I had only lain down for ten minutes when the music downstairs roared up again, so loud that I could no longer hear what she was saying.
[2004-11-16 22:40:10] bedroom at home | I said, "It's not even eleven, and it's Friday night. So we're completely helpless."
[2004-11-16 22:40:20] bedroom at home | I saw Nils Nils just getting out of bed and about to leave the room when the music stopped, so we had to go back to bed. I heard Nils Nils say angrily, "I don't care anymore, I'm calling someone. This damn situation can't go on."
[2004-11-16 23:30:00] bedroom at home | I looked at the clock; it was half past eleven. I heard Nils Nils ask me, "Are you going to call? I haven't slept at all." The same shockingly loud music blared in my ears again, jolting me awake from sleep.
[2004-11-16 23:35:00] bedroom at home | I noticed that a few minutes later the woman turned off the music. Downstairs fell into complete silence.
[2004-11-16 23:40:00] living room at home | I heard Nils Nils say, "I'm sleeping in the living room." I realized she played music two more times that night, the last time lasting half an hour. I thought it was absurd and maddening—I felt she was insane and harbored hatred toward us. A sense of foreboding crept over me, as if anything could happen.
[2004-11-20 14:00:00] Halviken/Apartment | I saw autumn turning into winter, surrounded by baby food, clothes, crying, and vomit. I felt mornings and afternoons becoming wasted and empty, but I realized I couldn’t complain about anything—just shut up and do what I had to do.
[2004-11-23 10:00:00] stairwell | I saw that we had placed some potted plants on the windowsill outside our apartment door. Two days later, I found the plants were gone. Before me lay the cold, stark stairwell. I knew those flowerpots had been passed down from my great-grandmother, dating back to the years after 1900, among the few household items I’d inherited from my grandmother. I thought that although it was common space, we only wanted to add a bit of brightness. I realized how angry I was about losing the pots, and I suspected someone might be deliberately targeting us.
[2004-11-23 20:00:00] hallway bulletin board | I saw that we had posted a note on the hallway bulletin board asking about the flowerpots. That evening, I noticed new writing appeared on the note. I saw crude Mochengdao written in blue ink on the note, full of curses and accusations. I read that it questioned whether we were accusing all residents of stealing, and told us to move out.
[2004-12-01 19:00:00] at home/by the front door | I was assembling a changing table and needed to tap a few hammer strikes. A minute later, I heard a door slam downstairs and saw the Russian woman arrive at our door; I opened it. I saw her cheeks puffed and eyes glaring. I heard her shout at us for making constant banging noises and claim we had woken her up. I tried to explain it was still early, but she accused us of thinking we were superior. Right after my first few hammer taps, wild banging on pipes erupted from downstairs. I realized it was only seven in the evening—I thought it would be fine—but trouble came anyway.
locations: Stone Steps outside Finnish Cultural Institute / Cabinet Street

text:
[2004-12-01 10:00:00] at home | Whenever I stepped a little heavily, an extremely sharp, piercing sound of pipe-tapping rang in my ears. I realized she had discovered a new tactic. The noise filled me with inexplicable guilt inside my own room. I hated this sound and felt I couldn’t find peace even in my own home.
[2004-12-20 18:00:00] Humle Park/Home | I saw that we had bought a Christmas tree from Humle Park, and I hoisted it onto my shoulder to drag it back. Finally, I set it up in the living room. Before me lay snowy streets filled with hurried passersby. I saw a huge Christmas tree standing inside our home. I knew it was just before Christmas. I learned that the tree had cost us eight hundred kroner. I realized that it had seemed quite small when we bought it, but only after bringing it home did I see how enormous it actually was. Looking at this giant Christmas tree, I couldn't help but burst into laughter together with Nils Nils. I thought this might be the last Christmas we'd spend alone together—so buying a bigger tree perhaps wasn't so foolish after all.
[2004-12-24 20:00:00] Home | I saw that we ate the Christmas dinner brought by Nils Nils's mother, then opened presents. We also watched Chaplin's 'The Circus' together. Afterward, I noticed that we often took walks along empty streets and began preparing the New Year's Eve feast. I learned that Nils Nils's mother had prepared a Mochengdao Christmas dinner for us. I knew we had purchased Chaplin's complete film collection. I realized that during that holiday weekend, the Russian woman had completely slipped our minds—the outside world seemed to cease to exist.
[2004-12-31 10:00:00] Home | I cleaned the apartment and went out to shop for dinner. I saw myself ironing the white tablecloth, setting the table, and polishing the cutlery and candlesticks. I noticed Anders and Helena arriving first, bringing their daughter. Before me lay the dining room with its neatly laid tablecloth, fruit bowl, and the gleaming dignity of middle-class propriety. I knew Helena was an actress, and Anders was somewhat of a criminal. I learned that Helena was seven years older than Nils Nils.
[2004-12-31 19:00:00] Apartment Stairwell/Doorway | I opened the door and saw them standing in the stairwell. I saw Helena pushing a stroller and noticed the little girl studying me seriously. I heard Anders say, 'Hey, buddy!' and complain that it was freezing outside. Helena asked me, 'Can we bring the stroller in?' I saw Anders wearing a brown leather hat, and Helena in a white coat and black boots, looking very elegant.
[2004-12-31 19:00:10] Doorway | I stepped back a few paces to let them in. I said 'Hi' while looking into the little girl's eyes, then said, 'Come on in!' I heard Anders ask, 'Where's Nitulida?' I told him Nils Nils was resting. I heard Anders say, 'Great!'
[2004-12-31 19:00:20] Doorway | I saw Helena squeeze the stroller through the doorway. I noticed she released the brake, lifted her daughter out, removed the child's hat, and unzipped the snowsuit. I heard Helena ask, 'Do you think it'll fit? Should I open the other door?' I saw the child wearing a dark blue dress and white tights underneath.
[2004-12-31 19:01:00] Hallway | I saw Anders taking off his coat in the hallway, continuously rubbing his hands together. I heard Anders ask where Nils Nils was; I replied she was resting and confirmed everyone was fine.
[2004-12-31 19:02:00] Hallway | I saw Helena holding her daughter in her arms. I noticed the child’s elegant outfit for the New Year celebration.
[2004-12-31 19:03:00] Living Room | I saw Nils Nils walk out from the bedroom, smiling as she hugged Helena. I also saw her lean forward to embrace Anders. I heard Helena exclaim, 'Look how beautiful you are! What a big table! Wow!' I heard Nils Nils reply that it was just an old maternity dress. I noticed they hugged for a long time. I thought only I knew how fleeting her radiance was at this moment.
[2004-12-31 19:05:00] Kitchen/Doorway | I walked into the kitchen pretending to be busy. Then I heard the doorbell ring and opened the door to see Karl Larsdal and Christina. I heard Karl ask, 'Have you finished cleaning?' I responded with mild surprise, joking that I hadn’t expected them at this hour and worried there wouldn’t be space for them. I felt somewhat surprised seeing Karl—I remembered we had agreed on Monday.
[2004-12-31 19:06:00] living room at home | I saw Kristina give me a hug. I stepped back to make space for them. Then I noticed Anders’s daughter beginning to crawl around the living room, and things gradually settled down. I heard Kristina say, 'Hi, Grete Lundnes, are you all doing well?' I replied, 'We’re fine.' What caught my eye was the pile of shoes and coats stacked in the hallway.
[2004-12-31 19:10:00] living room at home | I saw Anders nod toward the Christmas tree in the corner. I smiled at him. I heard Anders tease us about keeping up traditions. I explained, 'It cost us eight hundred kroner—so as long as there's even a hint of green left, it stays right there. We don't just throw money away in this household.' I heard Anders laugh and call me 'boss.' I admit that huge Christmas tree is a bit embarrassing. I thought, Mochengdao people always fail to understand my Leivik jokes.
[2004-12-31 19:10:10] living room at home | I heard Anders say, 'Here comes the boss with his jokes again!' I responded, 'I'm always joking—only you Mochengdao people never get it. At least you didn’t get it at first.'
[2004-12-31 19:11:00] living room at home | I heard Karl Larsdal say, 'So you've bought yourselves a nouveau riche Christmas tree, then?' I heard Anders imitate that mixed Leivik accent blending kempe and gutt. I laughed and told them I thought it looked quite small when I bought it. I learned that Mochengdao people usually regard this kind of exaggerated tone as 'New Norwegian,' though it has nothing to do with my actual accent.
[2004-12-31 19:11:00] living room at home | I explained to them, 'It was an accident. I admit such a big tree is a bit awkward. But I’ve always had problems judging proportions.'
[2004-12-31 19:11:20] living room at home | I heard Nils Nils ask Anders if he knew what kempe meant. She explained, 'It’s the same as jätte. Jättestor means kempestor.' She also remarked how it took her a whole year to figure out the usage of certain words. I wondered whether Nils Nils thought I’d been offended, so she stepped in to explain.
[2004-12-31 19:11:30] living room at home | I heard Nils Nils burst into laughter recounting her blunder while translating Setebakken’s book. [2005-02-16 10:32:45] forest path | I said to him, 'I'm glad too.'
[2005-02-16 10:33:00] forest path | I saw him raise his hand to his forehead in a wave and then walk away. I watched as he lifted his ski poles high with each step.
[2005-02-16 10:33:15] forest path | His straight, watery eye came into view. I felt it resembled the eye of a mythical beast. Though the image didn't stay before my eyes continuously, I realized the feeling lingered throughout the entire day.
[2005-02-16 10:33:30] forest path | I watched him disappear around the bend, and we continued our walk. I said to Nils Nils, 'He doesn't seem like someone who's been broken down.'
[2005-02-16 10:33:40] forest path | I heard Nils Nils say, 'No, he doesn't. But it's hard to truly see what others are really like.'
[2005-02-16 10:35:00] beside the railway | I helped Vanya sit upright and turned her around so she could see. I saw her pointing at the train and shouting. The roar reached my ears again; I saw the train speeding through the woods. I felt a fine spray of snow blow against my face, melting instantly. I thought this time she definitely hadn't missed it.
[2005-02-16 10:50:00] end of the railway embankment | I watched as the path came to an end beside the railway embankment. I saw a white expanse of snow-covered fields across the way, like a tablecloth laid out in the forest. The beautiful manor house came into view, and beyond it I could see the lake and the center of Nyköping on the opposite shore. To my knowledge, the owner of the manor is the Prime Minister's brother. I recalled getting lost there one summer, remembering the group of people dressed in white dining outdoors. I inwardly remarked how Bergmanesque that party had been, surrounded by the greenery of southern Södermanland countryside.
[2005-02-16 11:00:00] return path | I walked back along the same route, lifting Vanya out of the stroller and into my arms.
[2005-02-16 11:30:00] slope in front of the house | Half an hour later, we reached the slope. Through the window, I saw Ingrid and Vidar standing at opposite ends of the table, shouting at each other. I heard shouts coming from inside the house. I realized the snow had muffled our return, masking any sound. I guessed we had come back earlier than they expected.
[2005-02-16 11:31:00] entrance hall | I stamped my boots a few times on the doorstep. I saw Nils Nils take Vanya from me, and I pushed the stroller into the garage. I saw Vidar standing in the hallway, putting on his coat. I knew this garage was something Vidar had built over the spring and summer seasons.
[2005-02-16 11:31:15] entrance hall | I heard him ask me with a smile, 'How was it? Did you walk far?'
[2005-02-16 11:31:20] entrance hall | I told him, 'No, just a short way. The weather outside was terrible!'
[2005-02-16 11:31:30] entrance hall | I watched him pull on a pair of brown rubber boots. I heard him reply, 'Yeah, sure was.' Then he said, 'I'm just heading out—got some things to fix.'
[2005-02-16 11:32:00] kitchen | I watched him slowly walk up the hill. I took off my coat, changed my shoes, and went into the kitchen. I saw Ingrid peeling potatoes; she had already placed Vanya in the high chair.
[2005-02-16 11:32:30] kitchen | I watched her place a bowl of water and a measuring spoon in front of Vanya. I shoved my coat into the pile of clothes and walked past them. I heard her gentle, kind voice. I knew this would keep the child occupied for hours. I noticed Ingrid looked sad, but I sensed her movements remained calm and deliberate.
[2005-02-16 11:32:45] kitchen | I asked her, 'What’s for dinner?'
[2005-02-16 11:32:50] kitchen | I heard her reply, "Lamb chops, potato wedges. And red wine sauce."
[2005-02-16 11:32:55] kitchen | I said to her, "Oh, wonderful! I love lamb the most."
[2005-02-16 11:33:00] kitchen | I watched her gazing at me with a smile, and I noticed her eyes looked unusually large behind her glasses. I heard her say to me, "I know."
[2005-02-16 11:33:10] kitchen | I noticed Vanya tapping the measuring spoon in the bowl of water.
[2005-02-16 11:33:20] kitchen | I ruffled Vanya's hair, then looked over at Inge. I said, "You're having such a good time here, Vanya." Then I asked, "Has Nils Nils gone to bed?"
[2005-02-16 11:33:30] kitchen | I saw Inge nod. I noticed something just outside my line of sight, no more than four meters away. I heard Nils Nils call out from the sleeping corner, "I'm right here!"
locations: slope in front of the house

text:
[2005-02-16 11:34:00] bedroom | I walked in and saw two beds placed at a ninety-degree angle, taking up nearly all the space in the room. I noticed she was lying on the inner bed, the duvet pulled up to her chin. I felt that although the curtains were open, it was still dim inside, almost dark. The dark, rough wooden walls came into view, as if absorbing all the light.
[2005-02-16 11:34:15] bedroom | I heard her hoarsely call out to me, "Are you going to take a little nap?"
[2005-02-16 11:34:20] bedroom | I shook my head.
[2005-02-16 11:34:25] bedroom | I said, "I'm going to read a bit. You go ahead and sleep."
[2005-02-16 11:35:00] bedroom | I sat down by the bed and stroked her hair. Before me was a wall with photos of Vidar's grandchildren, while the opposite wall held a bookshelf. On the windowsill stood an alarm clock and a photograph of Vidar's youngest daughter. I always feel uneasy in other people's bedrooms, afraid of seeing things I'd rather not, but here I found no such discomfort.
[2005-02-16 11:35:10] bedroom | I heard her say, "I love you."
[2005-02-16 11:35:15] bedroom | I leaned in to kiss her.
[2005-02-16 11:40:00] living room sofa | I stood up, left the room, found the book I had brought, picked up the biography of Rimbaud, and stretched out on the sofa beneath the window. I said, "Get some rest." I felt unable to face Dostoevsky, realizing it would be too strenuous to dive into him right now. I remembered this was one of those books I'd long thought I should read. What interested me most was his relationship with Africa and the time he spent living there. His poetry itself didn't attract me much, unless it revealed something unique and distinctive about his character.
[2005-02-16 12:00:00] living room sofa | I noticed Inge bustling about in the kitchen while talking to Vanja. I thought she was such a good mother, realizing how even the most tedious chores became lively under her hands. It wasn't just that she set aside her own needs when they were together, making everything revolve around Vanja and her feelings. I realized this wasn't sacrifice; the joy she derived from it was deep and genuine.
[2005-02-16 12:05:00] living room sofa | As far as I knew, our mother had always been like this when we were children. I couldn't imagine another woman like Inge being so utterly different from my mother. I realized that although my mother also set aside her own needs, the distance between her and her children was much greater. I recalled once going with them to a children's play area, seeing her look distracted, so I asked if she was bored, and she admitted she was.
[2005-02-16 12:10:00] living room sofa | I knew Inge had once been an actress at the country's largest theater, with a rich and active life. As far as I knew, my mother lived a contemplative life—always observing, analyzing, reading, writing, and reflecting. I thought that if Inge wanted to, she could capture any child's attention, realizing there was a natural ease in her nature. I marveled at her strong presence, how she could transform the atmosphere simply by entering a room. I saw that Inge loved cooking, whereas my mother only cooked because she had to.
[2005-02-16 12:30:00] hallway / chair by the wall | I saw Vidar walk past the bedroom window wearing blue overalls, noticing how he slightly hunched forward and stepped carefully. A moment later, I saw him appear again outside the living room window, heading toward the garage. I saw Vanja leaning against the kitchen cabinet while Inge lifted a frying pan off the stove. I stood up, went to the hallway, put on my jacket, hat, and boots, opened the door, and sat down on the chair by the wall to smoke. I watched Vidar carry a bucket out of the garage.
[2005-02-16 12:30:15] chair by the wall | I heard him ask me, "Could you give me a hand in a bit? About ten minutes?"
[2005-02-16 12:30:20] chair by the wall | I replied, "Of course."
[2005-02-16 12:40:00] outside | I watched him nod and go toward the corner of the house, so I turned my gaze to the distance. I felt the daylight fading, and before me spread the uneven, encroaching darkness of night. I noticed how the trunks and branches at the edge of the forest had already turned into a black mass. I observed the feeble February sunlight slowly diminishing, until everything was swallowed by blackness and night covered the earth and sky.
[2005-02-16 12:41:00] outside | I felt a sudden happiness seize me.
[2005-02-16 12:42:00] outside | I felt the light across the fields, the chill in the air, and the silence within the forest. Before me loomed the menacing darkness, and I felt it was like a breath being blown straight into my heart—an evening in February. I realized it awakened all my dead memories of February evenings. I marveled at how rich and full it felt, as if my entire life were gathered here. I thought time itself seemed pierced by it, and a different light unfolded across my memory.
[2005-02-16 12:45:00] storage room | I crushed my cigarette in the snow and tossed it into the large bin, then walked to the ground-level storage room behind the house. I saw Vidar inside, tightening screws onto the lid of the freezer. I felt the sense of happiness transform into an equally strong sadness. I silently told myself that before we left, I must clean up all these cigarette butts.
[2005-02-16 12:45:15] storage room | I heard him say to me: "We'll have to carry it over to the cabin. The ground's a bit slippery, but we should be fine if we're careful."
[2005-02-16 12:45:30] storage room | I nodded, turned around, and scanned the row of trees opposite, but found nothing. Behind me, I heard crows cawing noisily.
[2005-02-16 12:46:00] outside storage room | I noticed that every movement across the snow was clearly visible: the footprints on the path stood out distinctly, leading from the front door to each building. Where untouched, the rest lay white and pristine.
[2005-02-16 12:47:00] storage room | I watched Vidar begin tightening the third screw. I noticed his fingers were nimble and his movements coordinated. I thought he was perfectly suited for small repairs like this. I realized I had no patience for anything I couldn't handle with one hand—I even found assembling IKEA furniture enough to drive me mad.
[2005-02-16 12:47:30] storage room | I saw that when he worked, his lips parted slightly, revealing crooked teeth, along with his small eyes and triangular face accentuated by a protruding goatee. He looked to me exactly like a fox.
[2005-02-16 12:47:40] storage room | I saw the bucket he'd brought over, filled with sand, sitting beside him. The pale red sand contrasted against the gray concrete floor beneath.
