[2005-02-16 12:47:50] storage room | I asked, "Are you going to spread sand on the path?"
[2005-02-16 12:47:55] storage room | I heard him reply, "Yes, would you mind doing it?"
[2005-02-16 12:48:00] storage room | I replied, "No problem."
[2005-02-16 12:50:00] path outside | I picked up the bucket, grabbed a handful of sand, and scattered it around the footprints as I walked. I saw Inge walk out of the house wearing her green windbreaker, taking short, hurried steps toward the cellar. I remarked how even in such an insignificant moment, she carried herself with such strong presence. I thought Nils Nils must be awake by now—or perhaps Vanja had fallen asleep beside her.
[2005-02-16 12:51:00] path outside | I saw a few apples still hanging from two trees below the path. I noticed the skins were wrinkled and covered in black spots, yet their colors remained unchanged—soft shades of deep red and green. I felt that if placed against a colorless pasture or forest, they would appear strikingly vivid; but next to the red-painted cabin, their hues seemed dull and nearly invisible. I thought those apples looked even brighter because of the surrounding bare, dark branches.
[2005-02-16 12:53:00] path outside | I saw Inge emerge from the cellar, each hand holding a 1.5-liter bottle of mineral water, and three cans of beer tucked under one arm. I watched her set one bottle down on the snow. I saw her free her hands to use the hook to lock the door, then pick up the bottle again and shuffle back toward the house. I noticed the caps and labels appeared especially bright yellow against the white snow.
[2005-02-16 12:55:00] storage room | I had reached the storage room and scattered the remaining sand along the way back. I set the bucket down on the ground. It suddenly struck me who that man I'd seen at the café the previous day resembled—Frederik Lund, the novelist from Leivik! I realized they looked exactly alike: the same square jaw, the same gentle gaze, the same bald head. I noticed his skin tone was different, softer, almost baby-like. It felt as if Veslos’s skull had regenerated, or as if nature had reused the same code.
[2005-02-16 12:56:00] storage room | I saw Vidar place the small screwdriver onto the machine behind him. I heard Vidar say, "Alright." Then he said to me, "We can move it now. I'll lift this side a bit, and you lift the other—okay?"
[2005-02-16 13:00:00] storage room | I lifted my end, only to see the weight shift toward Vidar's side; I noticed him tense his body. I wanted to take more of the load, but I realized it was clearly impossible. I took small steps alongside him down the slope; we turned and walked side by side up the gentle incline toward the storage room. I watched as we first placed it in the center of the floor, then slowly shifted it into the corner. I wanted to carry more of the weight because I didn't think it was heavy at all.
[2005-02-16 13:00:15] storage room | I heard Vidar say, "Thank you." Then he sighed, "Great, finally finished."
[2005-02-16 13:00:20] storage room | I knew he usually had no helper at all, so I understood that for small tasks like this, he often waited until we came by and asked me to lend a hand.
[2005-02-16 13:00:25] storage room | I said to him, "Don't hesitate."
[2005-02-16 13:05:00] storage room | I saw him plug in the cord. I heard the freezer humming steadily in my ears. I knew there were two other freezers resembling this one, along with two large refrigerators. As far as I knew, they were all filled with various meats, fish, vegetables, and berries. I realized this way of managing food was unfamiliar to us. I learned that Inge always took advantage of sales, buying cheap goods and even picking up discarded fruit from supermarkets to make desserts. I noticed she often emphasized during meals how cooking skill could transform the value of meat. I knew she had attended home economics school and, after her acting career ended, returned to her former life.

[2005-02-16 13:10:00] storage room/cellar | I felt the room filled with the constant hum of refrigerators and freezers. I saw the cellar packed with vegetables, fruits, jars of jam, and pickled vegetables. I knew that every time we visited, we were treated to extraordinary meals. I realized most of the dishes were ones people in this country had commonly eaten one or two generations ago, and that those Italian, French, and Asian dishes were, in a sense, considered rustic fare.
[2005-02-16 13:15:00] Jølster | I heard Inge suggest preparing the food at home first and bringing it over, since she knew nothing about the local kitchen. I learned that when we were preparing the naming ceremony for Vannia, Inge wanted to help cook. I knew the ceremony was to be held at my mother’s place in Jølster. I understood that when Inge and Vidar arrived at the airport, they brought three bags of frozen food. I knew there would be two gatherings. I thought the idea sounded utterly absurd—carrying cooked food over a thousand kilometers. But I realized she was determined, so I thought, fine, let it be done.
[2005-02-18 16:00:00] Kristianvik Street | On Friday, I took Helen Ster to pick up the two girls from kindergarten. I pushed the stroller forward with my right hand. On the way back, I pulled Helen Ster behind me with my right hand, while using my left side to push the double stroller carrying Vannia and Lundlund. I saw people watching us as we moved forward. I felt pain surging from time to time, and I thought I had to be careful not to cry out. I realized it must have been a strange sight. I thought Nils Nils was too exhausted, so I had to go pick up the children.
[2005-02-20 10:00:00] at home | I sat quietly. I thought it was a peculiar experience for me. I felt that sitting down and standing up were both difficult, giving me a sense of helplessness. I discovered that the sense of control I once took for granted had vanished—did I always assume I was in command of my surroundings? I realized now that it was gone, and for the first time, I truly saw it.
[2005-02-25 09:00:00] rented room | I exerted my willpower and barely managed to meet my daily goal of writing five pages. I regained control over my will. It struck me as strange that my writing was affected by the broken collarbone. I lamented that the sense of mastery had disappeared; I felt the text was now controlling me. I thought I hated every word and sentence, but I realized that dislike didn’t mean I shouldn’t do it.
[2005-03-01 09:00:00] rented room | I flipped to a note I had made in a book. I knew I had kept that book with me for the past twenty years. I thought I’d be able to write something else in a year. I saw the page count rising. I recalled that summer when I had just turned sixteen, remembered the party my father held. I reflected that it was a moment where joy and my father’s tears became one. I realized everything converged there, and I thought now, finally, I was going to write about it.
[2005-03-10 16:00:00] kindergarten playground | I got up, turned off the computer, threw away the trash, and went to pick up the children. I saw them run toward me across the playground, racing each other. I felt their big hugs as they reached me. I heard them competing to see who could shout the loudest. I thought, once this is finished, only my father’s death remains. I realized it was a heavy door to open. I reflected that whenever I saw my children, the fear that had built up in my chest instantly dissolved.
[2005-03-10 16:10:00] kindergarten playground | I saw Helen Ster sitting there with a cheerful smile, watching him absorb everything his older sisters did and then imitate it. I noticed Lundlund developing intense jealousy toward him. I saw her scratch him, push him, hit him. I observed that he never looked at her with fear. I thought having two older sisters must be the greatest thing for Helen Ster. I realized we needed to remain constantly vigilant about Lundlund. I reflected: Has he forgotten? Or do I marvel at the immense kindness in his heart?
[2005-03-15 10:00:00] Halvick's home | I learned that novel writing had damaged our relationship. I knew I had slept in the study for six weeks, seeing my wife and daughter very rarely. I saw Nils Nils visibly relieved. I felt deeply indebted to her; I thought I should fully engage in life, yet I realized I hadn't. I lamented that for months I'd felt sorrowful, and I discovered that the desire to return to the study outweighed the joy of living.
[2005-03-15 10:00:00] rented room | One day in March, I was working. I heard the phone ring, saw an unfamiliar number, and answered it. I heard one of my mother’s colleagues tell me that Mom had suddenly collapsed in a store. I learned they were attending a seminar in Gothenburg, and Mom had been hospitalized, currently under intensive care.
[2005-03-15 11:00:00] rented room | I called them back. I learned she had suffered a heart attack and undergone surgery; I knew she was now out of danger.
[2005-03-15 23:00:00] home | That night, I heard my mother call personally. She told me the pain had been so severe she’d wished to die. I heard her say she lay there believing everything was over. She told me directly that she had lived a wonderful life. I knew she hadn’t lost consciousness—she had simply fallen onto the street. I could hear how weak she sounded, perhaps a bit confused. I was struck still when she said 'wonderful life.' I realized how beautiful life truly is.
[2005-03-15 23:10:00] home | I heard her tell me that as she lay there waiting to die, her childhood flashed before her eyes. I heard her say she’d had an absolutely splendid childhood, a time when she was free and happy. I realized it was like a sudden revelation to her. I marveled at how vivid life could be.
[2005-03-16 10:00:00] home | In the following days, I kept thinking about her words. I was profoundly shaken. I thought I could never think that way myself. I reflected: If I were to collapse, my thoughts would surely be the opposite. I realized I wanted to live—but I also questioned why sometimes death didn’t seem so terrible. I thought indifference must be the first among the seven deadly sins.
[2005-04-15 10:00:00] Halvick's home | I watched myself mark an X in the book, waiting for the next positive review or publishing offer. I knew the novel was receiving good responses. I learned it had been nominated for the Nordic Council Literature Prize. I felt whether the response was good or bad no longer mattered. I realized I no longer cared about the nomination. I understood one thing: the only meaning of writing lay in the act of writing itself. I marveled that all value was contained within it.
[2005-05-15 10:00:00] Halvick street | I pushed the stroller, circling endlessly around the zoo island in Halvick. I watched myself begin saying no to everyone and everything, resuming the daily grind. I knew public attention was like a drug. I realized I had once waited there for journalists’ questions and publishing offers. I wanted more of what came with it. I marveled how, once tasted, such attention became addictive. I realized the bitter aftermath this obsession left behind, and I noticed this fascination gradually fading.
[2005-05-20 10:00:00] Kristianvik's home | I was about to finish the story of Dad’s death. I saw Mom come to visit me. I knew she was attending another seminar in Gothenburg. I realized if she had collapsed at home, she probably wouldn’t have survived. I knew she had previously experienced intermittent severe pain but misinterpreted it, which led to the illness. I knew two months had passed since her episode. I thought about bidding farewell to those awful days in the old house.
[2005-05-20 14:00:00] Humle Park | I pushed the stroller through the city. I saw Vanja looking around or sitting in the sandbox holding a shovel. I watched her eating the food I fed her while she sat in the high chair. I heard those mothers constantly on their phones. Before me stood the tall, slender mothers of Harvik; I felt as if I were surrounded by an absurd fashion show. I knew that no matter how hard I tried, I could never truly become part of it. I knew that sandbox in Humle Park.
[2005-05-20 15:00:00] Harvik Home | I wandered around the house chatting idly with her. I took her on excursions into the city—to view paintings at the Modern Art Museum, to bookstores, or to see Karl Larsdal. I heard her cheerful babbling or unhappy crying. I had learned everything there was to know about small children. I knew the Modern Art Museum was on Ship Island, and that Karl Larsdal had an office at the university. I felt driven mad by how utterly weary all this made me. I felt foolish. I realized my tenderness was outweighed by growing indifference. I wanted to cross these days off the calendar.

[2005-05-21 09:00:00] Living Room, Kristianvik Home | One morning, I saw her knitting, while I was writing. I walked over to look at her. I saw her glance at me. I heard my mother bring up Dad on her own. She told me she'd been wondering why she hadn't left him back then. She said directly to me: 'I really loved him, Grete Lundnes. I loved him deeply.' I knew Nils Nils had not yet returned from taking his two daughters to kindergarten. I thought she must have been lost in reflection.
[2005-05-21 09:10:00] Living Room, Kristianvik Home | I was shocked, remembering she had never spoken like this before. I wondered: What is happening? I realized something was shifting, either around me or within me. Maybe it was because I’d talked so much with her about Dad. I felt that past once again drawing near.
[2005-05-21 09:20:00] Living Room, Kristianvik Home | I heard my mother recount how they first met. She said to me: 'I didn’t catch his last name properly— for a long time I actually thought it was Knudsen. At first, I liked the other one better, you know. But then I fell in love with your father… Such beautiful memories. The sunlight, the grass in the park, the trees, the shade, the people there… We were so young, you understand… Yes, it was an adventure. The beginning of an adventure. That’s exactly how it felt.' I knew she had worked that summer when she was sixteen at a hotel in Vesfjord. As far as I knew, they met on July 1st at an open-air beer garden in a large park.
[2005-05-21 14:00:00] Harvik Park | I walked through Harvik Park pushing the stroller, seeing myself sometimes holding a book in one hand while pushing the stroller with the other. I came to know the most secluded cafés in town, having sat on nearly every bench in the park. I realized I had brought Dostoevsky’s Demons and The Brothers Karamazov with me. I realized I had once again found light in books.
[2005-05-21 15:00:00] Harvik Park | I felt surrounded by the typical Dostoevskian atmosphere of misfortune, filth, and sickness—almost omnipresent. I knew this was not Hölderlin’s kind of light—sublime, clear, and pure. As far as I knew, in Dostoevsky there were no heights or sacred images; everything remained within the human realm. I thought this must be where light resides, where turbulent divinity dwells. But I questioned: Is this really where I want to go? Is it necessary to stoop down to meet it?
[2005-05-21 16:00:00] Harvik Park | I saw Vanja opening her eyes from deep inside the stroller; I held her gaze. As far as I knew, when I read I aimed for complete concentration, spending days to get through hundreds of pages. I thought that after reading hundreds of pages, clarity would suddenly emerge. I felt the details interacting, moving me so deeply that I became completely absorbed. I noticed even doubt in Vanja’s eyes, as if asking: Where have you taken me?
[2005-05-21 16:05:00] Harvik Park | I closed the book and picked up Vanja. I knew I had no other choice but this.
[2005-05-21 16:30:00] Harvik Café | I pushed the stroller searching for a high chair; I saw the staff reluctantly heating our food. I asked the staff to heat the food. Before me stretched Harvik’s streets full of babies; I saw countless women in their thirties now mothers. I noticed it was the peak of a baby boom, fashion magazines were emerging, and children had become accessories. I understood that if we were indoors, we’d bring out spoonable food; if outdoors, we’d head to the nearest café. I knew female celebrities had begun appearing in photos with their families and speaking publicly about home life.
[2005-05-21 16:40:00] Harvik Cafe | I learned that matters once belonging to the private sphere are now flooding into the public arena. I know prenatal contractions, breastfeeding, and vacation guides are being discussed everywhere. I learned that the authors of these books include stay-at-home husbands as well as exhausted mothers.
[2005-05-21 16:50:00] Harvik Cafe | As far as I know, it's better not to comment on topics that were once considered normal. I realize that child-rearing has now been thrust to the forefront of life’s great causes. I think it's filled with an alarming kind of zeal, but I wonder—what meaning could this possibly have?
[2005-05-21 17:00:00] Harvik Street | I pushed the stroller back and forth with my child. As far as I know, I’m complicit in this foolishness too. I think I’m no different from the many fathers who place fatherhood above all else.
[2005-05-21 17:10:00] Harvik Cafe | I sat in the cafe feeding Vanya. At least one other father caught my eye inside the shop. I noticed they were mostly around my age, about thirty-five or thirty-six, shaving their heads to conceal hair loss. As far as I know, receding hairlines and baldness have almost become a thing of the past.
[2005-05-21 17:15:00] Harvik Cafe | As far as I know, seeing these fathers always makes me feel slightly uncomfortable. I find it hard to accept their feminized mannerisms, and I realize my own gestures and posture have become just as feminized.
[2005-05-21 17:20:00] Harvik Street | I was pushing the stroller along the street. I know I harbor a slight contempt for men pushing baby strollers. I realize it's like a double-edged sword, because at the very moment I have this thought, I myself am pushing a stroller.
[2005-05-21 17:30:00] Children's Play Area | I know that in the children's play area, men often appear uneasy. I notice that when children are playing around them, those men's bodies show signs of restlessness. I don’t believe I’m the only one who feels this way—I see them practically itching to claw at the playground equipment.
[2005-05-21 17:40:00] Children's Play Area | I know spending hours each day in the play area is manageable enough. I realize there are worse things.
[2005-05-22 10:00:00] Home in Harvik | I learned that Nils Nils previously took Vanya to the children's dance class at Harvik Public Library. I know that since I’ve started taking care of the child, she wants Vanya to continue attending.
[2005-05-22 10:05:00] Home in Harvik | I refused the idea. I vaguely feel that disaster looms. I think since I’m the one caring for Vanya now, there’s no need to discuss it—the dance class simply won’t happen.
[2005-05-25 10:00:00] Harvik's home | In the end, I agreed, so we planned to go to the public library for class. As far as I know, Nils Nils brought this up every now and then. I realized that Vanja was growing fast, and the activities really needed more variety. I felt my resistance to taking on the soft male role had completely collapsed.
[2005-05-25 10:05:00] Harvik's home | I heard Nils Nils remind me, 'Remember to arrive early—it'll fill up quickly.'
[2005-05-26 13:30:00] Mochengdao Road / National Library | One afternoon, I pushed Vanja along Mochengdao Road early, crossed the street, and walked through the entrance of the National Library. I knew we were heading to the library near Udden Square.
[2005-05-26 13:35:00] National Library | I learned this was one of Harvik’s most beautiful buildings. I knew it had been designed by Asplund. I reflected on why I had never come here before. I thought the 1920s must have been the best decade of the last century.
[2005-05-26 13:45:00] Children's Section, National Library | I pushed the stroller into the circular space and inquired at the counter. I took her into a side room, parked the stroller beside three others, and noticed Vanja was wearing carefully chosen clean clothes. I asked a woman behind the counter how to find the children's section. Before me lay the library’s spacious interior and a children’s room lined with bookshelves. I saw three women, around thirty-five years old, sitting with tired expressions. I noticed children with runny noses crawling on the floor. I knew a poster on the door said class would start here at two o'clock in the afternoon.
[2005-05-26 13:50:00] Children's Section, National Library | I parked the stroller and lifted Vanja out. I sat down on a small bench, took off her coat and shoes, and placed her on the floor. I saw her stretch her arms toward me, asking to be picked up, so I lifted her back onto my lap. I had expected her to crawl around a bit. As far as I knew, she didn’t remember being here before and just wanted to stay close to me. I noticed she was watching the other children with curiosity.
[2005-05-26 13:55:00] Children's Section, National Library | I saw a young woman approaching, holding a guitar. A blonde woman came into view. I saw her walking toward me, wearing a knee-length coat and black boots. From what I could tell, she must have been only about twenty-five years old.
[2005-05-26 13:55:10] Children's Section, National Library | I heard her say to me, 'Hi! I haven't seen you before. Are you here for the children's dance class?'
[2005-05-26 13:55:20] Children's Section, National Library | I looked up at her. I replied, 'Yes.' I thought she was really beautiful.
[2005-05-26 13:55:30] Children's Section, National Library | I heard her ask me, 'Did you sign up?'

[2005-05-26 13:55:40] Children's Section of the National Library | I replied, "No, is registration required?"
[2005-05-26 13:55:50] Children's Section of the National Library | I heard her reply, "Yes, registration is mandatory. I'm afraid there are no spots left today."
[2005-05-26 13:55:55] Children's Section of the National Library | I sighed inwardly: What wonderful news.
[2005-05-26 13:56:05] Children's Section of the National Library | I said this to her and stood up. I said, "That's too bad."
[2005-05-26 13:56:15] Children's Section of the National Library | I heard her say, "Since you didn't know before, I suppose we can let you squeeze in this once—but don't make it a habit. After this, you'll need to register in advance for the next class." I knew that registering ahead of time was normally required to attend the class.
[2005-05-26 13:56:20] Children's Section of the National Library | I said to her, "Thank you." I realized I had now been granted an exception to join the class.
[2005-05-26 13:57:00] Children's Section of the National Library | I watched as she smiled, then opened the door and walked in. I craned my neck, watching her place the violin case on the floor, take off her coat, remove her scarf, and drape it over a chair toward the back of the room. I was observing this young woman who was about to teach the class. I thought her smile was truly beautiful. She seemed to have a fresh, light, spring-like quality about her.
[2005-05-26 13:58:00] Children's Section of the National Library | I crouched low, watching all this, and finally decided to settle down. As far as I knew, Vanya was already eight months old, and I knew she was utterly fascinated by any kind of performance. I thought to myself that I really should have gotten up and left, but I had come here for Vanya and Nils Nils. I realized that she, too, was part of this performance now.
[2005-05-26 13:59:00] Children's Section of the National Library | I saw two men walk in. I noticed one man with a large head, short stature, and glasses nodded at me. I watched as everyone took off their coats and hats, pulled out bottles and rattles, and sat down on the floor with their children. I saw more women arriving sporadically with baby strollers, and soon my ears were filled with voices, coughing, and laughter; I heard rustling clothes and bags opening and closing. From my observation, most mothers seemed to arrive in pairs or groups of three. I could tell the two newly arrived men knew each other. I remarked to myself that for a long time I appeared to be the only man here. When I saw that man nod at me, I thought, I almost wanted to kick him—angrily wondering in my mind if he assumed we belonged to the same club.
[2005-05-26 14:00:00] Dance Class Room | I saw the mothers had already gone inside. I waited until there was just one minute left before standing up and walking in, holding Vanya in one arm. I watched the instructor sitting on a chair at the front, a guitar resting on her lap, scanning the audience. I saw small mats laid out on the floor for us to sit on. I looked at her—she wore a beige cashmere sweater, her figure graceful, waist slender, long legs crossed, the top leg gently swinging, her foot clad in black boots. I knew this young woman was the instructor for today’s class.
[2005-05-26 14:01:00] dance class room | I sat down on the small mat and placed Vanja on my lap. I saw the woman with the guitar say a few words of welcome, and I noticed Vanja’s big eyes fixed intently on her. I was getting ready to start class with Vanja.
[2005-05-26 14:02:00] dance class room | I heard her say, 'We have a few new people today—maybe you’d like to introduce yourselves.' The teacher asked the new parents to introduce themselves.
[2005-05-26 14:02:10] dance class room | I heard one parent say, 'Monica.' Parents began taking turns introducing themselves.
[2005-05-26 14:02:15] dance class room | I heard another parent say, 'Christina.' The self-introductions continued.
[2005-05-26 14:02:20] dance class room | I heard a third parent say, 'Lur.' Another parent announced their name.
[2005-05-26 14:02:25] dance class room | I heard the name 'Lur'. I wondered inwardly: Lur? What kind of ridiculous name is that?
[2005-05-26 14:02:35] dance class room | I felt the room grow quiet. I saw the beautiful young woman looking at me, offering an encouraging smile. It was my turn to introduce myself.
[2005-05-26 14:02:45] dance class room | I said darkly, 'Grete Lundnes.' I announced my name to the group.
[2005-05-26 14:03:00] dance class room | I heard her say, 'Then let's start with a welcome song.' Then she explained that when she nodded at a parent, the parent should say their child's name while everyone sang together. I saw her play the first chord, and I felt the sound reverberate through the room. The teacher established the rules for singing and interaction.
[2005-05-26 14:15:00] dance class room | I saw her play a chord and everyone began singing. I watched parents grasp their children’s wrists to help them wave, and I mimicked the gesture. I saw myself forced to open my mouth and sing. I saw people touching parts of their bodies. I saw myself handed a rattle-like instrument. The song involved waving to friends and singing each child’s name, followed by a body-part recognition song, along with simple instruments. I felt that among the women’s high-pitched harmonies, my deep voice sounded as if tormented by illness. I thought to myself: I don’t feel embarrassed—it’s not embarrassment sitting here, but humiliation and loss of dignity. Everything feels gentle, friendly, and sweet, yet I feel myself shrinking on the little mat, squeezed in among them. I realize it’s a woman I want to sleep with who’s in charge. I feel angry—sitting here makes me appear utterly harmless, stripped of all dignity, leveled into complete self-effacement.
[2005-05-26 14:20:00] dance class room | I saw her put the guitar down on the floor and get up to walk toward the chair where the CD player was placed. I heard her say, 'Now it's time to let the babies dance!' The instructor was preparing to start the dance teaching segment.
[2005-05-26 14:20:00] Konsum Store | Vanya looked out from her stroller and pointed at a dog she had spotted. I watched Vanya pointing at the dog with her finger, and I couldn't help but wonder what she was seeing as she observed the world around her. I pondered what this endless stream of people meant to her. I was certain she wasn't taking everything in indiscriminately; I realized she had already formed a very clear hierarchy of the people around her.
[2005-05-26 14:21:00] dance class room | I saw her demonstrate by stomping her pretty foot. I heard her instruct, 'Everyone form a circle. We'll first walk in one direction, stomping as we go, like this—then turn around and come back the other way.' The teacher was demonstrating dance steps to parents and children.
[2005-05-26 14:22:00] dance class room | I straightened up, picked up Vanya, and stepped into the circle with the others. I glanced at the other two men and noticed they were both fully focused on caring for their own children. I joined the circle to prepare for dancing.
[2005-05-26 14:22:10] dance class room | I whispered close to Vanya, 'Yes, yes, Vanya, to each his own—your great-grandfather used to say that all the time.' I tried to communicate with Vanya through words while dancing.
[2005-05-26 14:22:20] dance class room | Vanya’s level of participation in the class was very low. I saw her tilt her face up to look at me. I realized she had shown no interest whatsoever in anything the children were supposed to do so far, and I noticed she didn’t even want to shake the rattle gourd.
[2005-05-26 14:23:00] dance class room | I saw the beautiful woman press the button on the CD player. I heard her say, 'Then we begin!' The dance session officially started with music.
locations: Children's Section of the National Library

text:
[2005-05-26 14:30:00] Konsum Store | I picked up a carton of milk and placed it in the stroller, then added pasta, Serrano ham, olives, cheese, basil, and tomatoes. I said to Vanya, 'Yes, look, a dog.' I was shopping for various imported ingredients at the supermarket in Halvik, deep in the heart of the middle class. I inwardly marveled that I would never have dreamed of buying such food before. I found this rejection of local things in favor of foreign ones foolish. I realized it was even repulsive. I remembered how I longed for the taste of 1970s pork chops, cabbage, and rice porridge. But then again, what I wanted to eat didn’t matter—I intended to cater to Nils Nils’s preferences.
[2005-05-26 14:35:00] newsstand | I paused briefly in front of the newsstand, looking at the newspapers. The stand displayed the two highest-circulation newspapers issued by Mochengdao. I considered whether to buy two evening papers. I felt that reading them would be like having a bag of garbage dumped over my head. I decided against it—for today, at least.
[2005-05-26 14:45:00] dance class room | I began following the others, moving to the music. I held Vanya in my hands, letting her sway against my chest. I watched myself stomping feet, spinning her around. I swayed left and right with Vanya in my arms. I saw everyone lifting and lowering a large blue canopy together, watching the children crawl wildly underneath. I heard a folk-like melody drifting through the room, along with constant laughter and shrieks. The dance class included walking to music, parent-child dancing, canopy games, and group singing. I thought to myself how ridiculous this all looked, feeling awkward pretending to be gentle and cute, uncomfortable being here among mothers I'd never met before.
[2005-05-26 14:45:00] Tennal Street secondhand bookstore | I paid and went out onto the street. To avoid the traffic, I turned onto Tennal Street. I turned the stroller around, propped the door of the secondhand bookstore open with my heel, and backed inside. I saw the warm winter sky, and ambiguous light reflecting off the pavement. I saw cars lined up at the intersection. As far as I know, Karl Larsdal once mentioned Malaparte's books. I spotted works by Galileo and Malaparte in the shop window.
[2005-05-26 14:45:10] secondhand bookstore | I said to the shopkeeper, "There are two books in the window I'd like—the one by Galileo and the one by Malaparte." I had noticed two books in the bookstore window and asked the shopkeeper about them.
[2005-05-26 14:45:20] secondhand bookstore | I heard the shopkeeper say to me, "Sorry, could you please repeat that?" I saw a man in his fifties, wearing a buttoned shirt, peering at me over the top of his square-framed glasses. The bookstore owner hadn't heard what I said clearly.
[2005-05-26 14:45:30] secondhand bookstore | I repeated in Mochengdao: "In the window—two books. Galileo, Malaparte." I clarified again to the shopkeeper which books I wanted.
[2005-05-26 14:45:40] secondhand bookstore | I saw the shop owner turn away to fetch the books for me. I heard the owner ask, "The one about the heavens and the one about war, right?"
[2005-05-26 14:50:00] outside the National Library | I watched as the teacher finally thanked everyone and said goodbye. I rushed out quickly, got Vanya dressed outside. I looked at no one, only stared at the ground. I placed Vanya into the stroller, fastened the seatbelt, and pushed her out the door—so fast that hardly anyone noticed. I heard the surrounding laughter and chatter, even more cheerful than before I’d gone in. As soon as I stepped onto the street outside, I felt an urge to scream wildly, to smash something into pieces. I realized I had to get myself away from this humiliating place as quickly as possible.
[2005-05-26 14:50:00] secondhand bookstore | I pulled the small handle beneath the headrest, gently lowering it toward me so Vanya could lie back in the stroller. I saw her hand twitch in her sleep, then clench tightly again. I knew this motion was innate, later gradually replaced by her own conscious actions, but it resurfaced whenever she fell asleep. I saw that Vanya had already fallen asleep, and wondered: Was children’s dance class really that tiring? Looking at her hand, I realized the movement was exactly the same as when she was first born.
[2005-05-26 14:55:00] Mochengdao Road | I jogged along Mochengdao Road while talking to Vanya. I said to her, "Vanya, Vanya, did you have fun, hmm? I certainly didn’t."
[2005-05-26 14:55:00] secondhand bookstore | I pushed the stroller to the side to let others pass, then turned toward the art bookshelf. I waited as the shop owner entered the prices of the two books into the old-fashioned cash register. My eyes immediately landed on Karinvik’s photography album—photos of cows, pigs, dogs, and seals. I knew he always had a way of capturing the soul of these animals. As far as I know, there’s no better way to understand the expressions of these animals in photographs. I thought, since Vanya was asleep, I had a few minutes to myself. How lucky! I’ve always loved his photographs.
[2005-05-26 14:55:10] Mochengdao Road | I heard Vanya say, "Da, da, da."
[2005-05-26 14:55:10] secondhand bookstore | I placed the books I had chosen on the counter.
[2005-05-26 14:55:20] Mochengdao Road | I watched Wanija extend her finger, and I noticed that although she wasn't smiling, her eyes sparkled with joy.
[2005-05-26 14:55:20] secondhand bookstore | I looked at the shopkeeper as he spoke to me. I heard the shopkeeper say: "This one just arrived—good book. Are you from Leivik?"
[2005-05-26 14:55:30] Mochengdao Road | I asked, "Oh, motorcycles—what's your connection to motorcycles, huh?"
[2005-05-26 14:55:30] secondhand bookstore | I replied, "Yes, I'll take a look at some others."
[2005-05-26 15:00:00] secondhand bookstore | I picked up Delacroix's diary, then a book about Turner. Right after, I took Gustav Daldal's treatise on Hammershøi, and another large volume on Orientalism in art. I thought that even though no paintings lose as much when photographed as Turner's do, I still decided to take it.
[2005-05-26 15:05:00] secondhand bookstore | I had just put these books on the counter when my phone rang. I heard the ringtone muffled from deep inside the pocket of my black snowsuit. As far as I knew, since Nils Nils had left for school that morning, I hadn't spoken to anyone except for a brief exchange with the woman from the dance class. I figured almost nobody knew my number, so the ringing didn't bother me.
[2005-05-26 15:05:10] secondhand bookstore | I heard Karl Larsdal say on the phone: "Hey? What are you up to?"
[2005-05-26 15:05:20] secondhand bookstore | I turned my face toward the wall as I answered the call. I said to him, "Busy being carried away—how about you?"
[2005-05-26 15:05:30] secondhand bookstore | I heard him reply, "I'm not busy with anything. Just sitting in the office, watching people come and go. Anything worth mentioning?"
[2005-05-26 15:05:40] secondhand bookstore | I told him, "I just met a very beautiful woman."
[2005-05-26 15:05:45] secondhand bookstore | I heard him respond doubtfully, "Oh?"
[2005-05-26 15:05:50] secondhand bookstore | I said to him, "We had a little chat."
[2005-05-26 15:05:55] secondhand bookstore | I heard him ask again, "Oh?"
[2005-05-26 15:06:00] secondhand bookstore | I told him, "She invited me into her house."
[2005-05-26 15:06:05] secondhand bookstore | I heard him follow up, "You went in?"
[2005-05-26 15:06:15] secondhand bookstore | I replied, "Of course. She even asked me my name."
[2005-05-26 15:06:20] secondhand bookstore | I heard him waiting for more: "But?"
[2005-05-26 15:06:35] secondhand bookstore | I explained, "She's a children's dance class teacher. So I had to sit down, clap my hands, sing children's songs—right in front of her. Vanja was on my lap. Sitting on a little cushion. Surrounded by a bunch of moms and kids."
[2005-05-26 15:06:45] secondhand bookstore | I heard Karl Larsdal burst out laughing on the other end of the phone.
[2005-05-26 15:06:55] secondhand bookstore | I added, "I even got a rattle to shake."
[2005-05-26 15:07:00] secondhand bookstore | I heard him burst out laughing: "Hahaha!"
[2005-05-26 15:07:15] secondhand bookstore | I told him, "When I came out from there, I was furious and didn't know what to do. I finally had a chance to show off my new waistline, but nobody cared about the rolls of fat around my belly."
[2005-05-26 15:07:30] secondhand bookstore | I noticed Karl Larsdal burst into laughter again as he spoke. I heard him say, "No, they're soft and nice, really." Then he invited me, "Grete Lundnes, let's get together tonight."
[2005-05-26 15:12:15] secondhand bookstore | I heard him say on the phone, "Nothing much. Ate some buns with a bunch of social anthropologists. Then the old department head showed up wanting to talk—his beard was covered in crumbs and his fly was open. I was the only one willing to pay attention to him, so he came over." As far as I knew, he had just been with a group of social anthropologists and had encountered the elderly, disheveled department head.
[2005-05-26 15:12:25] secondhand bookstore | I heard him ask at the other end of the line, "The particularly tough one?" I knew he was asking about the old department head.
[2005-05-26 15:12:40] secondhand bookstore | I heard Karl Larsdal reply on the phone, "Exactly. Now he's afraid of losing his position—after all, it's all he has left. So he's learned to behave. It's all about adaptation. Be tough when you can, and act properly when you must." I learned about the old department head's current situation and his changed attitude.
[2005-05-26 15:12:55] secondhand bookstore | I said to him on the phone, "Maybe I'll drop by tomorrow—do you have time?" I was planning a possible visit to see him tomorrow.
[2005-05-26 15:13:05] secondhand bookstore | I heard him respond generously, "Of course I do. Just one thing: don't bring Vanja along." I knew he would be free tomorrow, but he asked not to bring Vanja.
[2005-05-26 15:13:15] secondhand bookstore | I prepared to pay. I laughed and said to him, "Haha. Alright, I've got to go pay now. See you tomorrow." I was getting ready to end the call and head to the cashier.
[2005-05-26 15:13:20] secondhand bookstore | I heard him say on the phone, "Alright. Give my regards to Nils Nils and Vanja." Before ending the call, he sent greetings to my family.
[2005-05-26 15:13:25] secondhand bookstore | I responded to him, "Say hello to Christina too." I also sent greetings to his family.
[2005-05-26 15:13:30] secondhand bookstore | I heard him say on the phone, "Goodbye." We said goodbye on the phone.
[2005-05-26 15:13:35] secondhand bookstore | I replied on the phone, "Hmm, goodbye." We formally ended the call.
[2005-05-26 15:14:00] secondhand bookstore | I hung up the phone and put it in my pocket. I noticed that Vanja was still asleep.
[2005-05-26 15:40:00] secondhand bookstore | I stepped up to the counter and saw the bookstore owner studying a catalog; then he looked up.
[2005-05-26 15:40:05] secondhand bookstore | I heard the bookstore owner say to me, "That's a total of fifteen hundred thirty kroner."
[2005-05-26 15:40:30] secondhand bookstore | I handed my credit card to the owner, put the receipt into the back pocket of my trousers, placed the two bags of books into the lower compartment of the stroller, and pushed it out of the store. I heard the doorbell jingle beside my ear. I knew the receipt was my only proof for tax deduction.

[2005-05-26 15:41:00] outside the secondhand bookstore | I realized it was now three forty. I recalled getting up at four thirty in the morning and having to review a problematic manuscript for Damm Publishing by six thirty. I thought that job was tedious, but I realized it was a hundred times more interesting and worthwhile than changing diapers and entertaining a child all morning. I thought there was no longer any point in housework—it just wasted my time. These trivial chores depressed me, as if a ball had been punctured.
[2005-05-26 15:45:00] Dybens Street / St. Helen Ster Church / Ridge Street / Baker David Street | I walked to the intersection at Dybens Street, turned left up the hill beneath St. Helen Ster Church, walked along Ridge Street, turned into Baker David Street, and entered the gate to our backyard. The red brick wall and green metal roof of St. Helen Ster Church came into view. I found it very similar to Baysang's St. Helen Ster Church and Aucity's Trinity Church.
[2005-05-26 15:50:00] backyard | I saw two torches lit on the sidewalk outside the café across the way. I smelled the stench of a row of trash bins by the wall, along with a sharp odor of urine. I saw a pigeon in the corner of the wall. I know people often urinate behind the railings here at night. As far as I know, that pigeon has lived here for the past two years—originally it nested in a hole, but when the hole was sealed with bricks and cement, it had no choice but to move onto the ground.
[2005-05-26 15:52:00] backyard | I occasionally see rats. I saw a woman from the hair salon standing there, smoking while talking on her mobile phone. I saw her nod at me when she noticed me, and I nodded back. I heard her hoarse voice speaking with a distinct Scanian dialect. I saw the black back of a rat slipping through gaps in the shrubs, darting quickly across the patch of light. The woman’s all-white outfit caught my eye. I recalled stepping out for a cigarette at night. I guessed she must have been a small-town beauty in her youth. She reminded me of the kind of women I’d seen during summers at the Aucity restaurant. I liked her because she felt so different from the uniform crowd in Halvik.
[2005-05-26 15:53:00] backyard | Even though I’ve hardly spoken to her, I realized how much I liked her. I noticed she didn’t carry that same uniformity I see in people here—their clothes, thoughts, and attitudes all blending into one predictable style.
[2005-05-26 15:55:00] apartment lobby | I stopped at the door, took out my keys. I unlocked it and slipped into the lobby as quietly as possible. I saw that this time Vannia was awake, letting out a shriek. I smelled detergent and clean laundry wafting up from the basement vents. I heard noises coming from the basement. I knew Vannia was very familiar with these sequences of sounds. From what I understood, she would almost always wake up the moment we came through the door.
[2005-05-26 15:56:00] elevator | I ignored her shriek, opened the elevator door, pressed the button, and stared at my reflection in the mirror. I saw that Nils Nils was already waiting for us at the door. I realized Nils Nils must have heard the scream.
[2005-05-26 15:57:00] outside apartment door | I heard Nils Nils say: "Hey, did you have fun? Little one, just woke up, huh? Come here, let me..."
[2005-05-26 15:58:00] living room | I saw her unbuckle the seatbelt and pick up Vannia. I pushed the empty stroller inside. I watched Nils Nils walk into the living room and begin feeding Vannia. I said to Nils Nils: "We're fine."
[2005-05-26 15:58:10] living room | I emphasized: "But as long as I'm alive, I'll never set foot in a children's dance class again."
[2005-05-26 15:58:20] living room | I saw her glance at me, then quickly look down at Vannia. I heard her ask: "Was it really that bad?" I noticed a flicker of amusement in her eyes.
[2005-05-26 15:58:30] living room | I answered angrily: "Bad? That was possibly the worst experience of my life. When I walked out, I was so furious my lungs were about to burst."
[2005-05-26 15:58:35] living room at home | I heard her reply calmly, "I see." I noticed that she never brought up the subject again after that.
[2005-05-26 15:59:00] living room at home | I thought about how different Nils Nils was in caring for Vanja. I realized she was fully committed, and I could feel it was one hundred percent genuine.
[2005-05-26 16:05:00] kitchen / at the computer | I walked into the kitchen with the groceries, put the perishable food in the fridge, placed the basil on the windowsill and gave it some water. I put the books on the bookshelf. I sat down at the computer and opened my email. I realized I hadn't checked my emails since this morning.
[2005-05-26 16:06:00] at the computer at home | I received a message from Karl-Toya Ingrid, congratulating me on the nomination and suggesting we grab a beer sometime. I also remembered his previous opinion of *Out of This World*. I thought I truly liked Karl-Helen Ster, appreciated his carefree nature. But I realized I couldn't go out for beers with him, because I knew I'd just sit there in silence.
[2005-05-26 16:07:00] at the computer at home | I shut down the computer without replying. I learned there was an email from Bralund regarding an interview about the novel prize I'd received from Leivik Broadcasting's Second Channel. I also noticed a message from my uncle Marivik, thanking me for sending him the book, saying he'd gather the courage to read it, wishing me good luck in winning the Nordic literary crown. As far as I knew, he added a postscript expressing regret that Henrik Inge and Marivik Lund had divorced.
[2005-05-26 16:08:00] at home | I heard Nils Nils ask me, "Any good news?"
[2005-05-26 16:08:15] at home | I replied, "Well, Karl-Helen Ster sent his congratulations. NRK wants to do an interview in two weeks. And oddly enough, Marivik wrote too. He just thanked me for sending the book. Not so bad, considering how angry he was about *Out of This World* before."
[2005-05-26 16:08:25] at home | I heard Nils Nils say, "That's good. Why don't you call Karl-Helen Ster and invite him over for a visit, hmm?"
[2005-05-26 16:08:30] at home | I asked, "You're in such a good mood?"
[2005-05-26 16:08:40] at home | I saw her pout at me. I heard her say, "I just want to be nicer to you."
[2005-05-26 16:08:50] home | I replied, "I understand. I'm sorry. It wasn't intentional. Okay?"
[2005-05-26 16:08:55] home | I heard her reply, "It's okay."
[2005-05-26 16:10:00] living room at home | I walked past her and picked up the second volume of *The Brothers Karamazov*, which I noticed was lying on the sofa. I said, "Then I'm off. See you later."
[2005-05-26 16:10:05] living room at home | I heard her say, "Cheer up."
[2005-05-26 16:15:00] home | As far as I know, this was the only condition I set when I took over the daytime care of Vanya—having one hour to myself every afternoon. I understood that although Nils Nils thought it unfair, since she had never had an hour like that for herself, she still agreed to it. I thought now I have my own hour. In my view, the reason she’s never had such an hour is simply because she’s never thought about it. And I further believed the reason she’s never thought about it is that she’d rather stay with us than be alone. But I don’t want that.
locations: Dybens Street / St. Helen Ster Church / Ridge Street / Baker David Street

text:
[2005-05-26 16:16:00] Harvik Street | I saw the subway filled with all kinds of people, each with their own distinct characteristics. I found the same in squares, pedestrian streets, cafés, and large shopping malls. I thought thus every afternoon I could spend an hour sitting in a nearby café smoking. I realized I never went to the same café five or six times in a row. I thought if I did, they would make me into what Mochengdao calls a 'dead mister'—someone who gets greeted with smiles the moment he walks in, impressed by their knowledge of his preferences, and offered friendly remarks on whatever topic is currently popular. But I felt the only meaning of my life in a big city lay precisely in being able to remain utterly lonely even in the midst of a crowd. I marveled that I had never seen any of these faces before! I thought the true charm of a big city for me was the river of new faces endlessly flowing past, in which I could drift freely. I longed for distance, distance—I’ve never had enough distance.
[2005-05-26 16:17:00] Harvik Street | I knew we lived in the city center, within a ten-minute walking radius of hundreds of cafés. I thought therefore, when a barista began greeting me with a smile the moment he saw me, bringing me coffee without my asking, perhaps even offering a free croissant, that was the time to leave. I realized it wasn’t hard to find another place to replace it.
[2005-05-26 16:20:00] Cabinet Street | This time I walked along Cabinet Street toward the city center. I saw the street crowded with people. As I walked, I thought about the beautiful woman from the children’s dance class. I wondered what was going on. I thought I wanted to sleep with her, but didn’t believe I’d get the chance, and even if I did, I wouldn’t do it. Then I thought, so what if I acted like a woman in front of her? What would it matter?
[2005-05-26 16:25:00] Cabinet Street | I thought there are many things said about self-image, but it’s certainly not formed in the rational refrigerator. I realized thoughts might understand it, but lack the power to control it. I believed that one’s self-image includes not only who you are, but also who you want to be, who you can become, or who you once were. Regarding self-image, I found no distinction between the real and the imagined. I realized it encompasses all ages, all emotions, all drives. I lamented that when I push a stroller through the city, spending vast amounts of time caring for my child, I haven’t added anything to my life—life hasn’t become richer. On the contrary, I feel something has been lost: a part of myself, something connected to masculinity.
[2005-05-26 16:30:00] Cabinet Street | I realized this clarity didn’t come from my intellect, but from emotion, because rationally I knew I was doing this for a good reason—namely, that I must stand on equal footing with Nils Nils in raising our child. I realized that whenever I squeeze myself into a small, tight mold that leaves me unable to move, emotion fills me with frustration. I pondered which metric was truly valid. I thought that if equality and fairness are the measures, then there’s nothing to complain about men being constantly bound by tenderness and intimacy, let alone the fact that doing so earns round after round of applause. Because I believed if equality and fairness are the primary criteria, then the changes that arise represent an unquestionable improvement and progress.
[2005-05-26 16:35:00] Cabinet Street | I realized the indicators were more than just these. I thought happiness was one indicator, and vitality of life another. I wondered whether perhaps women could focus wholeheartedly on their careers, seizing the last chance to have a child almost after turning forty, letting the father care for the baby for a few months until daycare was found, so both parents could continue working—maybe they were happier than women of previous generations. I mused that perhaps men staying home for half a year to care for an infant might actually enhance their own vitality. I imagined women genuinely longing for those men at home—the ones with thin arms and big buttocks, shaved heads, wearing branded black-framed glasses—to gather together not only joyfully debating the pros and cons of Bear Brand baby carriers but equally excitedly discussing whether homemade baby food or store-bought organic fruit puree was better. I believed maybe they truly longed for exactly that, with full passion and complete engagement of body and soul. But I thought even if they didn't, it probably didn't matter much, because I realized equality and fairness were the real indicators, surpassing everything else in life and relationships between men and women.
[2005-05-26 16:40:00] Cabinet Street | I realized this was a choice, and that choice had already been made. I thought I was no different. I pondered that if I wanted a different arrangement, I should have told Nils Nils before she got pregnant: Listen, I want children, but I don’t want to stay home taking care of them—do you think that’s okay? I supposed that would naturally mean it fell entirely to her. Then I imagined she might say: No, I don’t think that works, or Yes, fine, and then we’d build our future around that. But I sighed—I hadn’t done that. I realized I hadn’t had enough foresight, and therefore I had to abide by the established rules.
[2005-05-26 16:45:00] Cabinet Street | I thought within our class and culture, this meant playing the same role, what used to be called the woman’s role. I realized I was bound to this role, like Odysseus tied to the mast: if I wanted release, I could achieve it, but I doubted I could do so without losing everything. I lamented that in the end I walked through the streets of Halvik looking both modern and feminine, while inside I was a nineteenth-century angry man. I felt that outwardly I had changed—as if with a wave of a magic wand I had instantly placed both hands on the stroller.
[2005-05-26 16:50:00] Cabinet Street | I looked at these eyes, these mouths, these chests and waists, legs and hips. I noticed sometimes I made eye contact too. I knew that gaze came from someone in the crowd, someone I knew nothing about—where she came from, how she lived. I thought I always walked around looking at women like a man does, and I found it truly mysterious behavior, because it triggered nothing, at most earning me a glance back. I realized that if I did see a truly beautiful woman, I might still turn to look, of course being careful not to attract attention—but I wondered why? What purpose did this serve? Why was looking at these things so important? And yet I thought that within seconds, occasionally minutes, I would forget them completely. I found that we simply saw each other—that was all—and then it ended, she became a passerby, and the event was erased forever from memory.
[2005-05-26 16:55:00] Cabinet Street | I noticed that when I passed by pushing the stroller, not a single woman looked at me, as if I didn’t exist. I realized someone might think it was because I sent such a clear signal that I belonged to someone, but I thought I sent just as clear a signal when walking hand-in-hand with Nils Nils, yet that never stopped anyone from looking at me. I sighed—good God, this must be my just punishment, I thought, perhaps just to give me a bit of self-awareness, because I reflected: wasn’t it true that when I wandered around leering at women, I left behind the one who gave birth to my child?
[2005-05-26 16:56:00] Cabinet Street | I thought yes, this is bad. I realized of course it was bad.
[2005-05-26 16:57:00] Cabinet Street | I heard him suggest they go back with him. As far as I knew, Tonje once told me she had met a man in a restaurant late at night; he approached their table, clearly drunk. I learned he told them he had come straight from the delivery room—his girlfriend had given birth to their first child that day, and now he was out celebrating. I imagined he then grew inappropriate, becoming increasingly insistent. I thought deep inside, Tonje was profoundly shaken, filled with disgust, though I suspected she was also drawn to him, because I wondered—how was that possible? What on earth was he thinking?
[2005-05-26 16:58:00] Cabinet Street | I thought I couldn’t imagine a greater betrayal than this. But I reflected—when I searched for women’s gazes, wasn’t I doing exactly the same thing?
[2005-05-26 17:00:00] Cabinet Street | I realized my thoughts inevitably returned to Nils Nils, and I remembered her at home keeping Vanja company. I recalled their eyes—Vanja’s eyes, alternately curious, excited, drowsy, and Nils Nils’s beautiful eyes. I sighed that back then I had wanted no one but her, and now I not only had her, but also her child. I wondered why this still wasn’t enough to satisfy me? Why couldn’t I stop writing for a year and fully become Vanja’s father, so Nils Nils could finish her studies? I knew I loved them, and they loved me. So why did everything else keep haunting me, tormenting me?
[2005-05-26 17:01:00] Cabinet Street | I thought I must concentrate harder. I realized that during the day, I should forget everything around me and focus entirely on Vanja. I wanted to give Nils Nils everything she needed. I resolved to be a good person. I sighed—good God, was it really so hard for me to be good?
[2005-05-26 17:05:00] in front of the Sony store / corner of Akademika bookstore street | I have arrived at the entrance of the newly opened Sony store. I see Marivik Knudt on the opposite side of the road. Before me, he is carrying a Nike shopping bag, and I see him walking toward me from across the street. I am pondering whether to go over to the Akademika bookstore at the corner and buy a few books, then sit for a while in its café.
[2005-05-26 17:06:00] Humle Park | In Humle Park, I see a thin mist floating above the trees. A man is approaching us. I notice he looks like a hobbit, dressed entirely in black. As far as I know, the first time I saw him was a few weeks after we moved into this apartment. Our eyes meet, and I feel his gaze as dark as night, sending chills down my spine. Who is this person? A wizard?
[2005-05-26 17:06:10] Humle Park | I ask Nils Nils, 'Did you see him?' I hear her say, 'That’s Marivik Knudt.' I respond, 'That’s Marivik Knudt?'
locations: in front of the Sony store / corner of Akademika bookstore street

text:
[2005-05-26 17:07:00] Harvik Street | I hear Nils Nils tell me that he once spoke with Helene, kindly advising her on how to deliver her lines in the play, helping them become part of the character she portrayed. I hear her say those two scripts are extraordinary. As far as I know, Nils Nils’s mother was an actress who once worked with him in a production at the Royal Theatre long ago. I understand that Nils Nils’s closest friend, Helene, is also an actress and collaborated with him too. I’ve also noticed that Nils Nils keeps urging me to read *Chaos and God Are Neighbors* and *Night Is Mother of Day*. But I haven’t read them—I think my reading list is already too long.
[2005-05-26 17:10:00] Harvik Street | I watch the street and see the writer Marivik Knudt walking past, carrying a shopping bag. As far as I know, I’ve encountered more than just this one writer. I know Astrid Peter has appeared at the bakery near our house; I’ve learned that Olasen and Marta Andersnes often talk at the Sports Café. I know Thomas Torstan was once seen reading on the terrace of Sturehof Restaurant, and I’ve also seen him at Pelikan Restaurant. I’ve also learned that writers like Eriksson, Torstan Lind, or Martavik can sometimes be found at parties in the Contemporary Culture Center or in Södermalm. I think I need to quickly make the most of this unexpected stroke of luck, because I know it’s not easy to run into him on the street. I recall how Thomas Torstan’s work once hit me like a punch to the gut, and when I saw him, my heart pounded as if I were looking at a corpse.
[2005-05-26 17:15:00] Harvik Street | I remember reading these writers in Baysang, where they were merely foreign names from distant lands. Now seeing them in person gives me a powerful sense of history—realizing they wrote in our time, and future generations will understand us through them. I feel that everything about that evening was so beautiful.
[2005-05-26 17:20:00] Harvik Street | I realize many of these writers are past their prime and now marginalized. Among the younger writers I read in Baysang, I only liked Magnus Moendal; I felt his *Black Crab* rose above the fog of morality and politics. I recognize this as literature’s unique duty, and I think if a writer remains indifferent to it, they deserve nothing but contempt.
[2005-05-26 17:21:00] Harvik Street | I inwardly groan with strong disgust—I truly hate their newspapers and articles. I think writers like Gacilevski, Ratama, and Halberg are utterly terrible.
[2005-05-26 17:22:00] small café opposite Nordiska Kompaniet | Instead of going into Akademika, I stop beside the crosswalk. I look at the sidewalk across the street leading to the old Nordiska Kompaniet building, then cross over. I think I won’t go into Akademika after all. I decide to go to the small café across the street instead. I realize that even though I go there often, the place is busy enough that I can easily remain unnoticed.
[2005-05-26 17:23:00] the small café | I see an empty table beside the railing of the stairs leading down to the underground hardware supermarket. I walk over, drape my jacket over the back of the chair, watch myself place the book on the table with the cover facing down and the spine turned inward, then head over to join the queue. This way, no one can see what I’m reading.
[2005-05-26 17:25:00] small café | I watched the three people working behind the counter. I observed the oldest woman moving back and forth behind the counter. I heard the coffee machine hissing. I felt that the three of them looked like siblings. I noticed that the woman had a face like a photograph, which almost canceled out any desire I might have felt. I realized that apart from our gaze, we shared nothing at all.
[2005-05-26 17:25:10] small café | I scolded myself inwardly in frustration: Damn it, here I go again. Can't I just stop these thoughts?
[2005-05-26 17:26:00] small café | I pulled a crumpled hundred-kroner bill from my pocket and smoothed it with my hand. I glanced around at the customers in the shop. Before me was a scene where nearly every chair was taken, though shiny shopping bags occupied empty seats. I noticed the customers wearing polished boots and formal attire, their aged skin and mascara-lined eyes, sipping coffee and eating muffins.
[2005-05-26 17:30:00] small café | I stared at the muffin’s coiled swirls, focusing on the island of cream at its center. I thought that if I were lucky, I’d really like to know what these people are thinking as they sit there. I wondered whether the world they see is entirely different from mine, whether the whole world might be singing inside them with some kind of joy.
[2005-05-26 17:35:00] small café | I watched the woman in the shop, middle-aged with dyed blonde hair. I saw a shopping bag with an elegant handle resting on her lap. I knew that those brand logos had taken designers weeks of painstaking work to perfect. I thought perhaps she wasn’t particularly joyful, but rather lost in contemplation. I realized that the anxiety of the designer now rested upon her knees, carried in these goods.
[2005-05-26 17:40:00] small café | I wondered whether she was filled with inner peace after a long life? I recalled foggy November nights, and in my mind’s eye, I saw dogs urinating on lampposts—I imagined whether she too had witnessed such moments that lend mystery to the city.
[2005-05-26 17:45:00] small café | I felt the air filled with fine particles of drizzle, coating skin and wood, reflecting light. I noticed the grooved glass salt and pepper shakers, their metal nozzles at the top. I smelled the aroma of barbecued pork, lamb leg, and fragrant fried omelets. I marveled at how everything in this gray world shimmered. I remembered seeing a man smash a window and crawl into a basement to steal. I thought that such rich smells and shapes themselves were life experiences, and I realized it was no wonder she sat there searching for peace.
[2005-05-26 17:46:00] small café | I saw the man ahead of me receive three lattes. I watched the female server with shoulder-length black hair and soft lips. Before I could even speak, I heard her ask me: 'A black coffee?' I noticed her eyes would instantly brighten when she saw someone familiar.
[2005-05-26 17:46:10] small café | I nodded, watching her turn away. I took the chance to sigh quietly. I figured she must have noticed me too—this tall, scruffy man with stained sweaters and unwashed hair who never seems to clean up.
[2005-05-26 17:46:30] small café | I watched her take a cup and fill it with coffee. I handed her a hundred-kroner note. I watched her give me change, then saw her smile shift toward my friend behind me. I heard her say to me: 'Here.' In those few seconds, I quickly scanned her from head to toe. I noticed she was wearing knee-high black boots—I wished this fashion would never go out of style. I saw that her nail polish was transparent.
[2005-05-26 17:47:00] small café | I looked at Dostoevsky's book lying on the table. Before leaning back on the sofa and opening it to read, I quickly glanced around the interior of the café. I felt this book didn't look particularly appealing to me. I realized I've been reading less and less because my threshold for reading has increased. I thought that although I deeply respect the author, immersing myself in the world he writes about makes me feel uneasy.
[2005-05-26 17:48:00] small café | I pondered how, before Dostoevsky, ideals were always part of a purely powerful heaven. I thought that in his books, everything becomes human, and I realized that if you relinquish will, ideals could be realized right now.
[2005-05-26 17:49:00] small café | I reflected that humility is the ideal in his most important novels. I realized Dostoevsky remains unidentifiable within his own fiction, and I thought that this is precisely where his greatness lies—because no moral truth is ever directly proclaimed.
[2005-05-26 17:50:00] small café | I considered how one might examine the concept of nihilism from this perspective. I believed that humanity flows abundantly through his works, and discussions concerning nihilism are therefore rich with meaning.
[2005-05-26 17:50:00] small café | I sensed fewer and fewer people around me. I watched as the street outside grew darker. I put the book down, stood up, and went to refill my coffee cup. It suddenly struck me in my mind that it was already 5:50. I remembered I should have been home by five. I couldn’t help cursing silently: Shit. Damn it.
[2005-05-26 17:51:00] small café | I thought about Tolstoy’s detailed descriptions of landscapes and hunting. I realized such objective depictions don’t exist in Dostoevsky’s work—there is always a drama of the soul hidden beneath.
[2005-05-26 17:51:00] outside the small café | I put on my jacket, stuffed the book into my pocket, and hurried out of the shop. I walked away without looking back. I heard the waitress say behind me, “Hei do!” I opened my mouth and replied, “Hei do.”

[2005-05-26 17:52:00] small café | I realized there is something else within a person besides the depths of the soul—I thought this was what the authors of the Old Testament understood. I sensed a shift in the relationship between humans and the world: once, people wandered through the world; now, the world wanders through people.
[2005-05-26 17:52:00] Systembolaget liquor store | I walked into the Systembolaget liquor store across the street, grabbed a red wine bottle with a bull’s head on the label from the shelf. Then I proceeded down the aisle into the shopping mall. I felt the inside of the mall was vast and luxurious. I knew I still needed to buy a few things before heading home. I thought I had just randomly grabbed that bottle of red wine. That kind of opulent environment always makes me feel shabby, like a homeless man.
[2005-05-26 17:53:00] small café | I reflected that when meaning changes, meaninglessness also shifts. I contemplated human value against the backdrop of the universe, imagining whether people are merely one among many insects. I realized meaning isn’t something we receive, but rather something that comes from our giving.
[2005-05-26 17:54:00] small café | I pondered how death renders life meaningless, yet at the same time gives it meaning. But I reflected that during my lifetime, death seems to have been removed by the media through daily, repetitive coverage.
[2005-05-26 17:55:00] small café | I realized that a plane crash is akin to a ritual, and I thought we participate in other people's lives by witnessing such events. I felt an inner tension rising, one that had nothing to do with me.
[2005-05-26 17:55:00] underground supermarket | I saw the meat counter, bought a steak from Gotland Pastures. I grabbed several jars of homemade sauce, then took potatoes and vegetables. I saw fresh raspberries and picked up a basket, then rushed to the freezer to pick out vanilla ice cream and French biscuits. I knew this steak, though shockingly expensive, tasted exceptionally good. Due to laziness and indifference toward money’s value, I always splurged recklessly whenever I had cash. I thought this was foolish and would leave me struggling financially for years afterward.
[2005-05-26 17:56:00] small café | I inwardly exclaimed, oh no, oh no, oh no—fifteen minutes had passed. I realized I’d been away more than an hour and a half longer than planned. I began to worry about Nils Nils’s mood; I thought this would make the evening too short.
[2005-05-26 17:57:00] small café | It was hard to say exactly how it happened, but I realized this outcome stemmed from a kind of neglect: unorthodox opinions simply don’t exist in the public sphere. I felt it would take some time before one could even notice this.
[2005-05-26 17:58:00] small café | I realized perhaps the worst thing was that Mochengdao was greatly celebrated in Leivik. I thought that since liberal democracy had triumphed, the establishment of a world government seemed inevitable, just as Jünger predicted in 1949. I found that even our dreams were becoming similar and commodified; I realized that emphasizing equality was merely another name for indifference, and I felt this was precisely where our night lay.
[2005-05-26 17:59:00] small café | I remembered Jünger wrote that the nihilistic world is essentially a steadily shrinking world. I thought of tendencies toward specialization and digitization. I realized all domains were being subsumed under a single commonality. I felt this process of continual reduction naturally and inevitably aligned with a movement toward zero.
[2005-05-26 18:00:00] underground supermarket | I tossed money at the meat counter. I grabbed several jars of homemade sauce, picked up a bag of potatoes, some tomatoes, broccoli, and mushrooms. I saw fresh raspberries on the shelf and quickly took a basket. I rushed to the freezer to select vanilla ice cream, then went to the other end of the store to get French biscuits, heading toward the checkout there. Before me were the excellent, mature, plump steaks from Gotland Pastures. I saw a 'new stock' label pasted on the freezer. I knew these steaks came from Gotland and tasted exceptionally good. I thought these meats were outrageously expensive by our standards. I realized I always splurged recklessly when I had money—a foolish habit that would leave me struggling later—but at that moment, I didn’t think of it at all.
[2005-05-26 18:01:00] underground supermarket | I inwardly exclaimed, oh no, oh no, oh no—fifteen minutes had passed. I realized I’d already been gone an hour and a half longer than I should have. I thought this would make the evening too short. What worried me was her—I felt this late return would leave her anxiously waiting.
[2005-05-26 18:02:00] underground supermarket | I knew I had recently returned from a three-day short trip to attend a reading. I learned I would have to give a lecture in Bergen next week. As far as I knew, my current schedule was extremely tight—the belt around my neck felt tighter than usual.
[2005-05-26 18:05:00] basement supermarket checkout counter | I watched the metal tray slowly move toward the cashier. I placed my items on the tray and observed as the cashier lifted each one, turning it in the air. I stared at her face. I heard a beep—the laser scanner reading the barcode. I felt the overhead light glaring down, harsh and bright. The cashier’s broad, fleshy face filled my view; I noticed her downturned mouth and the pores on her skin clearly visible. I saw her carefully styled hair, yet thought it resembled the top of a carrot sprouting green shoots. I thought her movements were like sleepwalking. I realized her facial appearance wasn't due to age, but rather to excessive plumpness.
[2005-05-26 18:06:00] basement supermarket checkout counter | I saw her glance at her fingernails for a moment. I took out my card, swiped it, and entered my PIN. I gazed at the displayed items. I heard her say, 'Five hundred twenty kroner.' While waiting for the transaction to complete, I suddenly remembered I had forgotten to buy a shopping bag. I wanted to pay properly so she wouldn’t think I was deliberately neglectful. I realized I had no change, and found it ridiculous to swipe my card again just for two kroner. I thought it didn’t matter what she thought of me anyway—after all, she was so fat.
[2005-05-26 18:06:10] basement supermarket checkout counter | I said, 'I forgot to take a bag.' I heard her reply, 'Two kroner.'
[2005-05-26 18:06:20] basement supermarket checkout counter | I took a bag from the box beneath the counter and pulled out my credit card again. I heard her ask, 'Don’t you have cash?' I replied, 'Afraid not.'
[2005-05-26 18:06:30] basement supermarket checkout counter | I watched her wave her hand dismissively. I packed up my things and walked toward the stairs. I saw that the staircase led into a passageway, noticing display cases from auction houses along both walls. I insisted, 'But I want to pay—it's not like that.' I heard her laugh impatiently and say to me, 'Just take it.' I responded, 'Then thank you.'
[2005-05-26 18:10:00] underground shopping street | I walked out through the main entrance. I passed Nordiska Kompaniet department store. I moved along the underground shopping street, going past Galerian mall, Kulturhuset, and Sergels Torg, all the way to the Central Station subway. I walked through the underground passage leading to the train station. The flickering lights of the underground shopping street came into view. I know that on rainy days I always take this route. I’m aware that this underground world connects with various shopping malls. I find the underground world fascinating, like an adventure into the unknown. I realize this preference stems from my childhood—I recall how even a single hole could once be the most thrilling discovery.
[2005-05-26 18:10:10] underground shopping street | I remember one winter, either 1976 or 1977, when more than two meters of snow fell. As far as I know, we dug several snow caves in our garden, connected by tunnels that even reached the neighbor’s yard. I know that when night fell, we would sit beneath the thick layer of snow and chat. Recalling that experience, I marvel at how enchanted we were by what we’d built that day.

[2005-05-26 18:12:00] outside American Bar | I passed the crowded American Bar. I saw people sitting on chairs draped with thick jackets, their faces flushed red. I noticed slender young men and women in black aprons moving back and forth. I watched five or six people waiting outside, rummaging for tobacco or using their phones. I saw someone pick out a passerby and offer them a smile. I heard the constant noisy chatter. I heard loud laughter burst out when the door opened. I sensed a warm, friendly atmosphere. I saw trays of beer and emptied glasses being collected. I noticed someone holding a phone to their ear, waiting expectantly. I know it’s Friday, and people come here after work to drink beer. I thought those people were simply looking for a kind smile.
[2005-05-26 18:13:00] street | I watched a line of cars slowly glide along the roadside. I observed the stream of people pouring out from Nordiska Kompaniet. I heard someone behind me say, 'Taxi, to Kabinetsgatan...' The faces inside the cars came into view, illuminated faintly by streetlights, covered in a mysterious glow. I saw the drivers’ faces lit by the pale blue dashboard lights. I felt some faces tremble slightly from the bass and drumbeats. I saw thick leather jackets, dark wool coats, and piles of shopping bags. I noticed occasional puffer jackets, low-rise pants, and knitted caps. I heard the loudspeaker announcement that the mall would close in fifteen minutes.
[2005-05-26 18:13:30] street | I saw a woman run past, clutching her hat, her coat flapping against her legs. I turned to stare after her. I watched her disappear around the corner leading to Kungsträdgården. I wondered why she was in such a hurry—this seemed urgent. But then I realized nothing significant had actually happened.
[2005-05-26 18:14:00] street | I saw three beggars sitting on a grating against the wall. When I passed by them, I deliberately looked away. I crossed the street and walked past the stiff facade of the College Bookstore. I saw a cardboard sign asking for money to get through the night, and beside it a hat containing coins. I saw the other two beggars drinking. I was thinking that Nils Nils might be getting angry, and that she perhaps felt this evening was ruined again. I realized I was worried she might think I didn't want to see her.
[2005-05-26 18:15:00] street/apartment entrance | I crossed the intersection and passed by the expensive Italian restaurant. I glanced at Glenn Miller Café and saw two people getting out of a car. I walked toward Nalen and saw a band tour bus with a trailer and a radio station bus. I stepped up three stairs and entered through the door after punching in the code. I saw a thick bundle of heavy cables running from the tour bus all the way onto the sidewalk. I knew Nalen was a venue for performances. I learned that a white bus belonging to Mochengdao Radio was parked there. I strained hard to recall who was supposed to perform here tonight, but realized my effort was ultimately futile.
[2005-05-26 18:16:00] apartment stairs | I started climbing the stairs. I met the Russian woman coming down. I greeted her: "Hi!"
