I heard a door open and shut above me, followed by the loud sound of a door being slammed. From that slamming sound alone, I could tell it was the Russian woman. I realized it was already too late to take the elevator. I noticed she pretended not to see me again.
[2005-05-26 18:16:10] apartment stairs | I watched her walk past me. I heard her mutter something only after she had passed. I thought this Russian woman was literally a neighbor from hell.
[2005-05-26 18:17:00] apartment stairs | I had heard her shouting and screaming from downstairs. I recalled how the bass and kick drum from Euro disco made the floor tremble and the windowpanes rattle. I felt the music was so loud we couldn't talk. I learned her apartment had been empty for seven months before we moved in. I remember being woken up at half past one in the morning in 2004 by the sound of her slamming doors. I know she then began playing extremely loud music nonstop. I thought about how even I, someone who usually sleeps soundly through noise, became completely sleepless. I remembered Nils Nils was eight months pregnant at the time and already suffered from insomnia.
[2005-05-26 18:18:00] living room at home | I recalled that we got up and went into the living room. I once went downstairs to ring her doorbell and knock on her door. I learned that ringing the bell and knocking received no response. I know we stayed in the living room for half an hour. I wondered whether I should call the duty phone, but I didn’t want to do that—I thought it would feel too Mochengdao. I hoped the music might just stop on its own.

text:

[2008-07-13 14:46:05] playground path | I heard her ask in confusion, "Why?"
[2008-07-13 14:46:10] playground path | I said, "How should I know?" Then I added, "I guess you wanted a toy."
[2008-07-13 14:46:15] playground path | I heard her ask eagerly, "So can we go now?"
[2008-07-13 14:46:20] playground path | I answered firmly, "Yes," and then said, "Let's go right over."
[2008-07-13 14:46:25] playground path | I pointed toward the asphalt path leading into the playground, thinking we could cut through the little woods.
[2008-07-13 14:46:30] playground path | I heard Vanja ask, "Does Lundlund have one too?"
[2008-07-13 14:46:35] playground path | I heard Nils Nils reply, "If she wants one, she can have it."
[2008-07-13 14:46:40] playground path | I saw Vanja lean down toward Lundlund in the stroller. I heard Vanja say, "She wants one," and then I heard her ask, "Do you want one, Lundlund?"
[2008-07-13 14:46:45] playground path | I heard Lundlund answer firmly, "Yes."
[2008-07-13 15:00:00] playground | I watched as we had to pay ninety kroner for tickets so each of them could hold a small cloth mouse. I felt the scorching sun; the air beneath the trees seemed motionless. The noisy clamor of the amusement park buzzed around me, mixed with eighties disco music from the stalls, making it feel like everything was closing in on us.
[2008-07-13 15:10:00] outside the snack stand | I noticed Vanja wanted cotton candy. Ten minutes later, I saw us sitting at a table outside the snack stand. I observed the children shouting angrily because the sugar stuck everywhere. I saw angry wasps stubbornly buzzing around us. I felt the searing sunlight making the sugar stick to everything it touched—tabletops, the back of the stroller, my arms and hands. I found my coffee too bitter to drink. I thought this wasn't at all what I'd imagined when the kids first saw the spiral candies in the big jars at the snack stand.
[2008-07-13 15:15:00] outside the snack stand | I saw a dirty little boy pedaling a tricycle straight toward us, crashing into Lundlund’s stroller. I noticed he pushed the stroller a few more times with his bike, blocking our way out, then just stood there, eyes fixed on the ground. I saw the boy had black hair and dark eyes. After he hit the stroller, I noticed he looked at us expectantly. I guessed he was probably Romanian or Albanian, maybe Greek.
[2008-07-13 15:16:00] outside the snack stand | I asked, "Shall we go?"
[2008-07-13 15:16:05] outside the snack stand | I heard Nils Nils say, "Lundlund wants to ride the horse," and then she asked, "Can’t we stay a bit longer?"
[2008-07-13 15:17:00] outside the snack stand | I saw a burly man with prominent ears and a dark complexion approach, lift the boy and his tricycle off to the side, give the boy a couple of pats on the head, and then walk over toward the mechanical octopus he operated. I saw the boy get back on his tricycle and ride across the entrance. I saw the mechanical octopus, its tentacles fitted with small baskets where people could sit, rising and falling as the machine turned. I saw a steady stream of visitors, all dressed in summer clothes.
[2008-07-13 15:18:00] outside the snack bar | I stood up as I spoke, watching myself toss the leftover cotton candy from Vennia and Lundlund into the trash, then push Helen Ster. I watched his head sway from side to side, catching sight of interesting things. I saw us cross the square and head toward the path leading to 'Cowboy Town'. I said to them, 'Of course.'
[2008-07-13 15:25:00] Cowboy Town | I saw the Eastern European woman sitting on a rock smoking inside the enclosure facing the mine. Before my eyes lay a pile of sand and three newly built sheds with signs reading 'Mine,' 'Sheriff's Office,' and 'Jail.' I noticed 'Wanted' posters posted on the latter two. On one side stood birch trees and a sloped ramp where some teenagers were skateboarding; on the other side, the horseback riding area was already closed.
[2008-07-13 15:26:00] Cowboy Town | I noticed Lundlund looking around as he spoke. I heard Lundlund shout, 'Horseback riding!'
[2008-07-13 15:26:05] Cowboy Town | I heard Nils Nils say to me, 'We have to go ride donkeys at the entrance.'
[2008-07-13 15:27:00] Cowboy Town | I saw Helen Ster drop his water bottle on the ground. I noticed Vennia crawl under the fence and run toward the mine; Lundlund saw it too and climbed out of the stroller to follow her. I spotted a red-and-white soda machine behind the sheriff’s office, so I fumbled through my shorts pocket—inside were two hair clips, a ladybug hairpin, a lighter, three stones, two white seashells Vennia had found on Sjøen Island, a twenty-kroner bill, two five-kroner coins, and nine one-kroner coins.
[2008-07-13 15:28:00] Cowboy Town | I pointed toward a log at the far end of the area. I saw Helen Ster raise both arms. I said, 'I'll have a cigarette now,' then added, 'Over there.'
[2008-07-13 15:28:10] Cowboy Town | I saw Nils Nils speaking while lifting Helen Ster up. I heard Nils Nils say, 'Go ahead.' Then she leaned down and asked Helen Ster, 'Are you hungry, Helen Ster?' Then she complained to me, 'It's so hot. Isn't there any shade where I can sit him down?'
[2008-07-13 15:28:20] Cowboy Town | I pointed toward the restaurant atop the hill. I told Nils Nils, 'Over there.' Before me rose the train-shaped restaurant on the hilltop—I noticed the counter was set up inside the locomotive, and tables filled the carriages. Not a soul was in sight; chairs were tucked tightly against the tables.
[2008-07-13 15:28:30] Cowboy Town | I heard Nils Nils say, 'I’ll go over now and feed him. Can you keep an eye on your daughter?'
[2008-07-13 15:29:00] Cowboy Town / beside the soda machine | I nodded and walked over to the soda machine to buy a can. I sat down on a tree stump, lit a cigarette, and looked up at the hastily built shacks. I noticed Vennia and Lundlund running in and out of the doorway.
[2008-07-13 15:30:00] Cowboy Town/shack front | I heard Vanya shouting, "It's pitch-black in here! Come take a look!"
[2008-07-13 15:30:10] Cowboy Town/tree stump | I raised my hand and waved toward Vanya. I saw she was still holding the mouse against her chest with one hand. I silently felt relieved that she seemed satisfied with this response. Then it suddenly struck me: Where had Lundlund’s mouse gone?
[2008-07-13 15:35:00] Cowboy Town/tree stump | I looked up toward the hill. I saw Nils Nils pull a chair over by the wall of the restaurant and begin nursing Helen Ster; I noticed the child first kicking its legs, then growing quiet. I saw the lady from the circus walking uphill. I felt a sting on my calf, slapped backward, and crushed a horsefly so thoroughly it burst. I kept drawing smoke into my lungs, eyes fixed on the spruce treetops. I felt another horsefly land on my leg and impatiently swatted it away. I stood up, tossed my cigarette to the ground, picked up the half-can of cold cola, and walked toward my two daughters. I spotted the mouse there, just outside the police station, headfirst in the sand. I smelled cigarettes baking in the heat. The spruce canopy caught sunlight, revealing an intensely vivid green. In my hand was the half-can of cola, still cold.
locations: Cowboy Town / beside the soda machine

text:
[2008-07-13 15:40:00] Cowboy Town/behind the shack | I saw Vanya look up at me, squinting, and say, "Dad, we're inside. Go around to the back and see if you can peek through a crack, okay?"
[2008-07-13 15:40:10] Cowboy Town/behind the shack | I walked around to the back of the shed. I bent down and brought my eye close to a crack to peer inside. I called out, "Okay." Then I heard them making clattering noises inside, giggling wildly. I felt the contrast between the bright sunlight outside and the darkness within was too extreme—I realized I couldn't see anything at all.
[2008-07-13 15:40:20] Cowboy Town/behind the shack | I heard Vanya shout from inside, "Dad, are you outside?"
[2008-07-13 15:40:25] Cowboy Town/behind the shack | I shouted back, "Yes."
[2008-07-13 15:40:30] Cowboy Town/behind the shack | I heard a voice from inside ask, "Can you see us?"
[2008-07-13 15:40:35] Cowboy Town/behind the shack | I called out, "No. Have you turned invisible?"
[2008-07-13 15:40:40] Cowboy Town/behind the shack | I heard them shout in unison, "Yes!"
[2008-07-13 15:41:00] Cowboy Town/Shack Front | I saw the two of them come out, but I deliberately pretended not to notice. I stared straight in the direction of Waneya. I shouted Waneya's name loudly.
[2008-07-13 15:41:10] Cowboy Town/Shack Front | I saw Waneya waving her arms at me. I heard her say: 'I'm here.'
[2008-07-13 15:41:15] Cowboy Town/Shack Front | I kept shouting toward her: 'Waneya? Where are you? Come out right now! This isn't a joke.'
[2008-07-13 15:41:20] Cowboy Town/Shack Front | Her voice came from nearby: 'I'm here! Right here!'
[2008-07-13 15:41:25] Cowboy Town/Shack Front | I shouted her name again loudly: 'Waneya?'
[2008-07-13 15:41:30] Cowboy Town/Shack Front | I heard Waneya ask with boundless joy: 'You really can't see me? Did I actually turn invisible?' I sensed she sounded extremely happy, yet I also keenly detected a hint of unease in her voice.
[2008-07-13 15:41:40] Cowboy Town | At that moment, I heard Helen Ster start screaming. I looked up and saw Nils Nils standing up, clutching her tightly in his arms. I realized Helen Ster’s usual crying didn’t sound like this.
[2008-07-13 15:41:50] Cowboy Town | I feigned surprise and said: 'Oh, there you are! Have you been here all along?'
[2008-07-13 15:41:55] Cowboy Town | I heard Waneya reply hesitantly: 'Y-yes... yes.'
[2008-07-13 15:42:00] Cowboy Town | I asked Waneya: 'Can you hear Helen Ster crying?'
[2008-07-13 15:42:05] Cowboy Town | I saw Vanya nod, then I watched her look toward the mountain restaurant.
[2008-07-13 15:42:10] Cowboy Town | I said, "We have to go, come on."
[2008-07-13 15:42:15] Cowboy Town | I reached out my hand, wanting to take Lundlund's hand.
[2008-07-13 15:42:20] Cowboy Town | I heard Lundlund say to me, "No, don't hold hands."
[2008-07-13 15:42:25] Cowboy Town | I said, "Alright then, jump into the stroller."
[2008-07-13 15:42:30] Cowboy Town | I heard her reply, "No stroller."
[2008-07-13 15:42:35] Cowboy Town | I asked, "Then should I carry you?"
[2008-07-13 15:42:40] Cowboy Town | I heard her sharply refuse, "Don't carry me."
[2008-07-13 15:43:00] Cowboy Town | I went down to get the stroller. When I came back, I saw she had already climbed onto the fence. I noticed Vanya was sitting on the ground. I looked up at the hilltop and saw Nils Nils had left the restaurant and was standing on the road looking down; I noticed she was waving one hand toward us. I noticed Helen Ster was still screaming.
[2008-07-13 15:43:10] Cowboy Town | I heard Vanya say to me, "I don't want to walk, my legs hurt."
[2008-07-13 15:43:15] Cowboy Town | I said to Vanya, "You haven't walked a single step all day—how can your legs hurt?"
[2008-07-13 15:43:20] Cowboy Town | I heard Vanya reply, "My legs are numb. You have to carry me."
[2008-07-13 15:43:25] Cowboy Town | I refused, "No, Vanya, you're being ridiculous. I can't carry you."
[2008-07-13 15:43:30] Cowboy Town | I heard her insist stubbornly, "You can."
[2008-07-13 15:43:35] Cowboy Town | I said to Lundlund, "Get in the stroller, Lundlund, then we'll go ride horses."
[2008-07-13 15:43:40] Cowboy Town | I heard her answer, "No stroller."
[2008-07-13 15:43:45] Cowboy Town | I heard Vanya shriek, "My legs are numb—!"
[2008-07-13 15:44:00] Cowboy Town | I think I felt my temper flaring, wanting to grab both of them and just storm off, one under each arm. I realized it wouldn’t be the first time I’d marched away with them kicking and screaming, and I noticed how I was now ignoring the onlookers’ stares. I thought to myself how they always watched our little scene with immense interest, as if I were wearing a monkey mask or something. But I told myself this time, I had to keep my temper in check.
[2008-07-13 15:44:10] Cowboy Town | I asked, "Can you get in the stroller, Vanya?"
[2008-07-13 15:44:15] Cowboy Town | I heard her reply, "Only if you pick me up."
[2008-07-13 15:44:20] Cowboy Town | I said to her, "No, you have to do it yourself."
[2008-07-13 15:44:25] Cowboy Town | I heard her still refuse, "No, my legs are numb."
[2008-07-13 15:44:30] Cowboy Town | I thought that if I didn't give in, we'd be standing here until tomorrow morning. I realized that although Vanya usually lacks patience and gives up easily when faced with obstacles, once she sets her mind on something, she becomes extremely stubborn.
[2008-07-13 15:45:00] Cowboy Town | I watched myself pick her up and place her into the stroller. I gave in and said, "Alright, you've won again."
[2008-07-13 15:45:10] Cowboy Town | I heard Vanya ask, "Won what again?"
[2008-07-13 15:45:15] Cowboy Town | I watched myself lift her down from the fence. After noticing a few half-hearted 'no, don't's, we started walking uphill. I carried Lundlund and pushed Vanya. I saw myself picking up Lundlund's cloth mouse halfway, brushing off the dirt, and stuffing it into the mesh bag. I said to them, "Nothing, come on, Lundlund, let's go."
[2008-07-13 15:50:00] Hilltop Restaurant | When we reached the hilltop, I heard Nils Nils say, "I don't know what's wrong with him—he suddenly started crying. Maybe he was stung by a wasp or something. Look here..."
[2008-07-13 15:50:10] Hilltop Restaurant | I watched her pull up Helen Ster's sweater to show me a small red spot. I saw Helen Ster squirming constantly in her arms. Helen Ster’s face, flushed red from constant crying, came into view; I noticed his hair was already soaked.
[2008-07-13 15:50:20] Hilltop Restaurant | I heard Nils Nils say sympathetically, "Poor little fellow."
[2008-07-13 15:50:25] Hilltop Restaurant | I said to her, "I got bitten by a horsefly too—maybe that's why. Let's put him in the stroller so we can move. Anyway, there's nothing we can do right now."
[2008-07-13 15:51:00] Hilltop Restaurant | I watched as we strapped him into the seat, noticing how he still wriggled from side to side, lowering his head in boredom. I heard him whining persistently.
[2008-07-13 15:51:10] Hilltop Restaurant | I suggested, 'Let's get in the car.'
[2008-07-13 15:51:15] Hilltop Restaurant | I heard Nils Nils reply, 'Alright, but I need to change his diaper first. There's a baby-changing cabin over there.'
[2008-07-13 15:52:00] Downhill Path | I nodded, then watched as we began walking downhill. I thought about how we'd already been here for several hours. I looked at the slanting sunlight in the sky and the light filtering through the trees, which inevitably reminded me of summer afternoons back home, when we would either drive off to swim or walk up the slopes by the bay. I realized these memories had flooded my mind within seconds, and I could sense their atmosphere, smells, and feelings.
[2008-07-13 15:52:10] Downhill Path | I saw how the clear, bright midday light had deepened in the afternoon, saturating everything with rich intensity. I saw sunlight glinting on smooth coastal rocks, almost turning them golden yellow, and noticed stiff, dry grass growing between the stones. I sensed the depth beneath the sea surface, saw how dark it became once shadowed by the mountain. I watched fish dart past. I saw slender branches of the treetop trembling in the wind, noticed the smooth trunks beneath the thin bark, like human legs. I looked at those green plants. I recalled a summer day in the seventies, remembering vividly the sensation of running along forest paths, plunging into the sea, and swimming across to the island of Ylsta.

[2008-07-13 15:55:00] In Front of the Octagonal Wooden Building | I saw Nils Nils gesture toward an octagonal wooden structure with a nod of his head. I heard Nils Nils say to me, 'It's right there—can you wait a moment?'
[2008-07-13 15:55:05] In Front of the Octagonal Wooden Building | I said, 'We'll take it slow.'
[2008-07-13 15:56:00] Fairy Tale World | I saw two wooden gnomes carved among the shrubs inside a fence, and realized this was precisely why the place could rightfully be called 'Fairy Tale World'.
[2008-07-13 15:56:10] Fairy Tale World | I heard Lundlund exclaim, 'Look, Tonttu!' I knew the correct pronunciation was actually 'Tonttu,' meaning gnome.
[2008-07-13 15:56:20] Fairy Tale World | I knew Lundlund had been obsessed with gnomes for quite some time. As far as I knew, she kept pointing at porches where gnomes appeared, saying 'Tonttu is coming,' even during gift-giving games always specifying their origins. I remembered finding gnome costumes in my wardrobe didn't surprise her at all; we said nothing, she simply shouted 'Tonttu' into the closet. I knew that whenever we encountered an old homeless man with a white beard, she would stand up in her stroller and shout loudly. I thought it was still hard to tell exactly what Tonttu meant to her, since she acted as if my wardrobe were the gnome’s dressing room.
[2008-07-13 15:57:00] Fairy Tale World | I leaned forward and kissed Lundlund's chubby little cheek.
[2008-07-13 15:57:05] Fairy Tale World | I heard Lundlund say to me, 'No kissing!'
[2008-07-13 15:57:10] Fairy Tale World | I heard my own loud laughter.
[2008-07-13 15:57:15] Fairy Tale World | I asked, 'Then can I kiss you, Waneya?'
[2008-07-13 15:57:20] Fairy Tale World | I heard Waneya reply firmly, 'No!'
[2008-07-13 15:58:00] Fairy Tale World | I saw a sparse but continuous stream of people passing by, most wearing shorts, T-shirts, and sandals. I was struck by the astonishing number of overweight people, noticing almost no one was well-dressed.
[2008-07-13 15:59:00] Fairy Tale World | I heard Lundlund shout joyfully, 'My dad went to jail!'
[2008-07-13 15:59:05] Fairy Tale World | I saw Waneya turn her head in the stroller.
[2008-07-13 15:59:10] Fairy Tale World | I heard Waneya correct him, 'No, Dad didn't go to jail!'
[2008-07-13 15:59:15] Fairy Tale World | I laughed again, then stopped walking.
[2008-07-13 15:59:20] Fairy Tale World | I said, "We'll have to wait here for Mom."
[2008-07-13 15:59:30] Fairy Tale World | As far as I know, 'Your dad's in prison' is something kids often say at kindergarten. I realize Lundlund took it as a great compliment and liked bragging about me. I remember Nils Nils saying she once told an old lady the same thing on a bus, and back then I couldn't respond in time because I was at the station with Helen Ster. I think Lundlund must have felt this was something truly impressive.
[2008-07-13 15:59:40] Fairy Tale World | I lowered my head and wiped the sweat from my forehead with the sleeve of my T-shirt.
[2008-07-13 15:59:45] Fairy Tale World | I heard Vanja ask, "Can I buy another ticket, Dad?"
[2008-07-13 15:59:50] Fairy Tale World | I replied, "No, you've already won a toy."
[2008-07-13 15:59:55] Fairy Tale World | I heard Vanja pleading with me, "Please, Daddy, just one more."
[2008-07-13 16:05:00] Fairy Tale World | I turned my head and saw Nils Nils approaching, noticing Helen Ster sitting properly in the stroller. I saw that Helen Ster was wearing a sun hat and looked quite happy.
[2008-07-13 16:05:10] Fairy Tale World | I asked, "Is everything okay?"
[2008-07-13 16:05:15] Fairy Tale World | I heard Nils Nils reply, "Hmm, I washed the sting with cold water. But he's tired."
[2008-07-13 16:05:20] Fairy Tale World | I comforted her, "He'll fall asleep once we're in the car."
[2008-07-13 16:05:25] Fairy Tale World | I heard Nils Nils ask me, "What time is it, do you think?"
[2008-07-13 16:05:30] Fairy Tale World | I replied, "Around four o'clock?"
[2008-07-13 16:05:35] Fairy Tale World | I heard Nils Nils musing, "Get home by eight?"
[2008-07-13 16:05:40] Fairy Tale World | I responded, "More or less."
[2008-07-29 11:30:00] Kristianvik Kindergarten | I saw three young female teachers trying every way to coax her, but she refused to get off my lap. So I watched myself sit down on a chair in the corner of the room, placing Vanja on my lap. I noticed the children playing around. When break time came, I saw the teachers set out snacks in the yard. I sat as instructed, ten meters away from everyone else, and I watched myself force an apologetic smile onto my face. In the end, I saw the teacher successfully lure her away from me. I rode home to write something, leaving her behind crying. It took a month before I could finally pick her up and drop her off normally again. I felt the dazzling sunlight outside. As the days passed, I sensed autumn drawing nearer. I thought it would be best to just throw her deep inside and walk away, leaving her to fend for herself—but I realized no one, neither the teachers nor Nils Nils, would tolerate such cruelty. I wasn't surprised by my own social behavior. I wondered, how had she, at only two and a half years old, already learned this kind of thing?
[2008-07-29 11:40:00] "Lynx" Kindergarten | I heard people say it was common for children to go home together. As far as I knew, sometimes in the mornings she still said she didn’t want to go, and occasionally still cried. I learned that when a spot opened up at another kindergarten nearby called "Lynx," we didn’t hesitate. I knew it operated as a parent cooperative, where parents took turns working and handling administration. I understood we didn’t know anyone at Kristianvik. I realized this was a shortcut to building relationships.
[2008-07-29 11:50:00] Home in Kristianvik | I heard Vanja ask two or three times every hour whether it was time yet, if we should leave. As far as I knew, we had received an invitation to Stella’s birthday party. I saw the invitation placed on the kindergarten bookshelf. I learned Vanja was genuinely looking forward to it, especially because she wanted to wear her golden party shoes. I sensed that although Vanja was excited, she also felt hesitant because she didn’t know the other children well—and didn’t really want to go. I realized it would be an unbearable morning.
[2008-07-29 12:00:00] Home in Kristianvik | I watched Vanja suddenly jump out of bed and rush to the small cabinet to put on her golden shoes. I saw Nils Nils take her to the bookstore to buy a gift, then sit at the kitchen table to make a greeting card. I watched myself bathe and comb the hair of both daughters, then dress them in white socks and party dresses. I heard us nod and say to her, "Yes, today we’re going to Stella’s house." As far as I knew, that morning had finally arrived.
[2008-07-29 12:10:00] Home in Kristianvik | I watched Vanja hurl both golden shoes against the wall. But I found we sat patiently, enduring her tantrum for several minutes, then carefully dressing her in all the necessary items. As far as I knew, the white knitted shawl had been given to her by Lundlund at her christening. I noticed Vanja’s mood had suddenly plummeted. I thought she no longer wanted to wear the socks or the dress—or even go to the party at all.
[2008-07-29 12:20:00] Kristianvik Street | I watched the two little girls climb into the child seats in front of me. I noticed Vanja holding her golden shoe in one hand and the gift in the other. I saw her turn back to speak to us. I saw Lundlund sitting beside her. I sensed their excitement once again. I noticed Vanja looked serious and quiet, yet her lips broke into a smile. I thought these preparations must have made Lundlund feel that something unusual was about to happen.
[2008-07-29 12:25:00] Kristianvik street | I pushed the stroller past. I saw family after family walking back and forth toward the multistorey car park. I was immersed in the bustling city noise. I saw shoppers carrying bags, and children loitering outside Burger King and McDonald's. I felt the vibration throughout the black car driven by a male immigrant in his twenties, and I heard the low rumble of the engine. I knew the apartment where the party was being held was on our street, just a few hundred meters away.
[2008-07-29 12:30:00] outside the supermarket | I watched myself pause briefly outside the supermarket. I saw a frail old woman in a wheelchair ringing a bell at my daughters and smiling. On the other side of the entrance, I saw a drug user sitting with a hat in his hand. I noticed there was a cat in his cage. I saw Vanja turn her head toward us. I felt the crowd outside the supermarket. I saw that the old woman was eager to show kindness. I knew this old woman often appeared here around this time. I realized the bell-ringing startled the two little girls.
[2008-07-29 12:30:10] outside the supermarket | I heard Vanja say: "When we move to the countryside, I want a cat."
[2008-07-29 12:30:15] outside the supermarket | I saw Lundlund pointing with his finger. I heard Lundlund shout loudly: "Cat!"
locations: In Front of the Octagonal Wooden Building

text:
[2008-07-29 12:31:00] road | I watched myself maneuver the stroller, crossing the curb onto the road, weaving around three slow pedestrians. I hurried forward a few meters, then turned back onto the pavement. I thought they probably believed the sidewalk belonged to them.
[2008-07-29 12:31:10] pavement | I said to her: "That might still be quite far off, you know, Vanja."
[2008-07-29 12:31:15] pavement | I heard Vanja say: "You can't have a cat in an apartment."
[2008-07-29 12:31:20] pavement | I heard Nils Nils chime in: "Exactly."
[2008-07-29 12:31:30] pavement | I saw her gripping the gift bag tightly with both hands. I realized Vanja was thinking about the future again.
[2008-07-29 12:32:00] pavement | I glanced at Nils Nils. I asked: "What was his name again, Stella's dad?"
[2008-07-29 12:32:05] sidewalk | I heard Nils Nils say, "Oh, my mind went blank... Right, Erik, wasn't it?"
[2008-07-29 12:32:10] sidewalk | I replied, "That's right." Then I asked, "What does he do?"
[2008-07-29 12:32:15] sidewalk | I heard Nils Nils answer, "I'm not sure, something to do with design, I think."
[2008-07-29 12:35:00] street | I watched as we passed Gottgruvan. I noticed that Vanja and Lundlund both stretched their necks to peer into the window.
[2008-07-29 12:35:15] street | I walked along the street. I saw the next shop was a pawnshop. I noticed the one after that sold various small statues and jewelry. The angels and Buddha figures inside caught my eye, and I smelled incense, tea, and soap. I saw posters in the window announcing dates for visiting yoga masters and spiritual mediums. I realized the shop had a 'New Age' vibe.
[2008-07-29 12:35:30] street | I looked across the street. I saw TABOO, a sex shop tucked into an alley. Dildos and dolls dressed in various casual clothes and lingerie were displayed in the window. I knew there was a clothing store selling budget brands nearby. I realized the sex shop was using its window displays to lure passersby.
[2008-07-29 12:35:45] street | I passed by that shop. Bergman's handbag and hat shop came into view. As far as I knew, the interior decor and product offerings had remained unchanged since the store opened in the 1940s.
[2008-07-29 12:36:00] street | I walked past it. The glowing TV screens of Radio City came into sight. I saw prices written on large orange and green cards. I knew this store had just gone bankrupt. I saw all kinds of electronic devices scattered around.
[2008-07-29 12:36:10] street | I recognized a pattern—the further into this street we went, the cheaper and more suspicious the shops became. I thought this same pattern probably applied to the people who hung around this area.
[2008-07-29 12:36:20] street | I understood that Halvik’s city center was different from this place. I realized that poverty and misery here were openly visible on the streets. I found that I liked it.
[2008-07-29 12:37:00] apartment building entrance | I saw Nils Nils stop in front of a door. I heard Nils Nils say, "This is it."
[2008-07-29 12:37:05] apartment building entrance | I passed by a bingo hall. I saw three pale women in their fifties standing at the entrance smoking.
[2008-07-29 12:37:15] apartment building entrance | I watched Nils Nils scan the list and press a number. I walked through the doorway. I heard two buses roar past. I was at the apartment building entrance. I felt the noise and vibration from the passing buses.

[2008-07-29 12:39:30] apartment hallway | I called out loudly: "Hello!"
[2008-07-29 12:39:40] apartment hallway | I saw that he didn't look back. I placed Lundlund's coat on top of another coat on the chair and then caught Nils Nils's gaze. I noticed she was looking for a place to hang Waninya's coat.
[2008-07-29 12:39:45] apartment hallway | I heard her ask me, "Shall we go in?"

[2008-07-29 12:40:00] apartment hallway | I heard him respond, "Hi."
[2008-07-29 12:40:02] apartment hallway | I also said back, "Hi."
[2008-07-29 12:40:05] apartment hallway | I heard him greet Waninya instead, "Hi, Waninya!"
[2008-07-29 12:40:08] apartment hallway | I saw Waninya turn her face away.
[2008-07-29 12:40:15] apartment hallway | I looked down and asked Waninya, "Aren't you going to give Stella your gift?"
[2008-07-29 12:40:20] apartment hallway | I heard Erik call out loudly, "Stella, Waninya is here!"
[2008-07-29 12:40:23] apartment hallway | I heard Waninya answer me, "You give it."

[2008-07-29 12:40:43] living room | I heard Vanja insist, "You give it."
[2008-07-29 12:40:45] living room | I took the gift and handed it to Stella.
[2008-07-29 12:40:50] living room | I explained to Stella, "This is from Vanja and Lundlund."
[2008-07-29 12:41:05] living room | I saw Stella tear off the wrapping paper, reveal a book, set it beside the other gifts on the table, then watched her return to the other children. I heard her say politely, "Thank you."
[2008-07-29 12:41:15] living room | I heard Erik chime in, "Well, everything okay?"
[2008-07-29 12:41:25] living room | I responded to him, "Fine, fine." I could feel my shirt sticking to my chest. I wondered if anyone would notice. I didn't know.
[2008-07-29 12:41:35] living room | I heard Nils Nils say, "Nice house—three rooms?"
[2008-07-29 12:41:40] living room | I heard Erik answer firmly, "Yes."
[2008-07-29 12:41:50] living room | He always seemed sharp, as if he had already gained something from whoever he was speaking to. I couldn't quite figure him out; I noticed his faint, tentative smile could be interpreted in three ways: mockery, camaraderie, or hesitation—and I felt any of them would make perfect sense.
[2008-07-29 12:42:00] living room | I thought that if he were more distinct or forceful in personality, it might have made me anxious. But I realized he was the hesitant type—weak-willed and indecisive—so no matter what he was thinking now, I didn't feel concerned at all.
[2008-07-29 12:42:10] living room | I saw Vanja standing close to Nils Nils, looking down at the floor. I realized my attention was entirely on Vanja now.
[2008-07-29 12:42:20] living room | I heard Erik say to me, "The others are in the kitchen. There's alcohol if you want some."
[2008-07-29 12:42:35] living room | I saw Lundlund had entered the room and was now standing by a shelf, holding a wooden snail. A wooden snail came into view—it had wheels and a string so it could be pulled along.
[2008-07-29 12:42:45] living room | I nodded toward the two parents in the hallway.
[2008-07-29 12:42:48] living room | I heard them say, "Hi."

[2008-07-29 12:43:05] living room | I said hello, "Hi."
[2008-07-29 12:43:10] living room | I heard him ask me, "How are you?"
[2008-07-29 12:43:15] living room | I replied to them, "Yes, and how are you?"
[2008-07-29 12:43:20] living room | I heard them politely respond, "All good, thank you."

[2008-07-29 12:43:45] living room | I watched her stand there for a moment. I thought she seemed about to take some decisive action.

[2008-07-29 12:44:05] living room | I saw her bend down, take off one shoe, lift it into the air, and finally put it back on her foot. I realized she had planned this to show everyone clearly, but I noticed no one was watching. I saw her notice it too, and then she simply put the shoe back on.
[2008-07-29 12:44:15] living room | I said to Vanja, "Don't you want to play with the kids over there? Did you see, they have a big dollhouse?"

[2008-07-29 12:47:55] kitchen | I saw Vanja enter the room. I observed how, upon seeing us, she walked over and stood very close by.

[2008-07-29 12:48:25] kitchen | I wondered—was she referring to the vegetables on the tray? I was certain she was. Inwardly, I thought this country had gone mad.
[2008-07-29 12:48:35] kitchen | I said to Vanja, "I'll go with you. Let's go."
[2008-07-29 12:48:40] kitchen | I heard Nils Nils ask me, "Can you take Lundlund along too?"

[2008-07-29 12:50:30] living room | I responded, 'That's great.'

[2008-07-29 12:51:13] the room where the children stayed | I heard Vanya reply firmly, "No."

[2008-07-29 12:51:50] the room where the children stayed | I wondered to myself why they couldn't just prepare sausages, ice cream, and soda for the kids? Or lollipops, jelly, chocolate pudding—something like that?
[2008-07-29 12:52:20] the room where the children stayed | I thought bitterly, damn it, what an ignorant and backward country! I noticed all the young women drinking large amounts of water—I suppose they believe it's healthy, but to me it only seems to be boosting incontinence statistics. I saw children eating hard-to-digest whole wheat pasta and brown rice, and realized they cared only about so-called 'hygiene.' I sighed at how they confused food with morality, believing that eating well makes one a better person, without understanding the difference between dietary ideals. I knew if I voiced such thoughts, I'd instantly be labeled a reactionary from ten years ago or just another Leivik fool.

[2008-07-29 12:56:15] living room | I saw Vanja staring at Achilles too, and thought that children are just like dogs—they always tend to stick together. I realized Achilles had become the playmate Vanja chose to replace Alexander, and her favorite one at that.

[2008-07-29 12:57:15] living room | I saw Lundlund standing by the yucca plant beneath the window, and I noticed she was pulling soil out of the pot, already making a small pile on the floor.

[2008-07-29 13:00:15] bathroom | I finished washing Lundlund's hands. I comforted Lundlund, saying, "There, there, good girl, all better now. Just a little bit left. Okay, all done!"
[2008-07-29 13:00:35] living room | I saw that she had stopped crying when we came out of the bathroom, but she didn't seem happy at all and refused to walk on her own. I realized she just wanted me to carry her now.
[2008-07-29 13:00:50] living room | I saw Robin standing in the living room with his arms crossed. I noticed Robin was watching his daughter Teresa's every move. I knew Teresa was only a few months older than Lundlund, but as far as I knew, she could already speak in long sentences.
[2008-07-29 13:01:00] living room | I heard Robin ask me, “Hmm, still writing then?”
[2008-07-29 13:01:05] living room | I replied to Robin, “Yes, a little bit.”
[2008-07-29 13:01:10] living room | I heard Robin ask, “You write at home?”
[2008-07-29 13:01:15] living room | I answered Robin, “Yes, I have my own room.”
[2008-07-29 13:01:30] living room | I heard Robin ask curiously, “Isn’t it hard? I mean, don’t you ever think about stopping for a while—watching TV, or doing some laundry or something?”
[2008-07-29 13:01:45] living room | I explained to Robin, “It’s actually good this way. If I had an office, I’d have less time, but…”
[2008-07-29 13:01:50] living room | I heard Robin respond, “Yeah, sure, of course.”
[2008-07-29 13:02:05] living room | Robin’s long, golden hair caught my eye, curling over the back of his neck. I saw his bright blue eyes, flat nose, and broad jaw. I noticed that Robin wasn’t particularly sturdy, nor was he slender.
[2008-07-29 13:02:20] living room | I looked at his appearance and thought he seemed about twenty-five or twenty-six, though I knew he was actually nearly forty. I realized I couldn't tell what he was thinking, but to me, he didn't seem mysterious.
[2008-07-29 13:02:35] living room | Although he gave me an impression of frankness, I sensed there was something else about him—something like a shadow.
[2008-07-29 13:03:00] living room | As far as I knew, his job involved helping refugees integrate into society—a fact he had mentioned to me before. I recalled asking him a few questions about how many refugees were granted permission to stay. I then dropped the subject, realizing my opinions and sympathies probably differed greatly from the standards I imagined he held, and that difference would eventually show. I knew I’d come across as either foolish or malicious, and I saw no reason to undermine myself.
[2008-07-29 13:03:15] living room | I saw Vanja sitting on the floor, looking in our direction. I noticed she was slightly apart from the other children.
[2008-07-29 13:03:45] living room | I put Lundlund down and saw Vanja get up, walk over, take Lundlund’s hand, lead her to the toy shelf, and hand her a wooden snail. I noticed that if you pulled the wooden snail along the floor, its two antennae would buzz and spin. I observed that Vanja seemed to have been waiting for me to do exactly that.
[2008-07-29 13:04:05] living room | I saw Vanja take the snail from Lundlund’s hands and place it on the floor. I heard Vanja say: "Look, Lundlund! You pull the string like this. Then it turns. See?"

[2008-07-29 13:04:15] living room | I heard Vanja say: "No, not like that—watch me."
[2008-07-29 13:04:25] living room | I saw Vanja right the snail and slowly pull it along for a few meters.
[2008-07-29 13:04:30] living room | I heard Vanja exclaim loudly: "I have a little sister!"
[2008-07-29 13:04:40] living room | I saw Robin had walked over to the window and was standing there looking out at the backyard.
[2008-07-29 13:04:50] living room | I thought Stella was full of energy, seemingly with extra vitality, because I knew this was her party.
[2008-07-29 13:05:15] living room | I saw Stella pointing at one of the two younger girls, asking her to hand over the doll she was holding, then pulling over a little wagon, placing the doll inside, and pushing it down the hallway. I heard Stella excitedly shouting something I couldn't understand.

[2008-07-29 13:06:00] living room | I saw Benjamin now sitting together with Achilles, building the railway track that Vanja and I had left behind. I thought he seemed imaginative, independent, and well-behaved.
[2008-07-29 13:06:15] living room | I saw the two younger girls chasing after Stella and heard Lundlund whimpering. I thought she was probably hungry.
[2008-07-29 13:06:30] kitchen | I walked into the kitchen and sat down beside Nils Nils.
[2008-07-29 13:06:40] kitchen | I said to Nils Nils, "Could you go check on them? I think Lundlund is hungry."

[2008-07-29 13:07:15] kitchen | I realized it took me several seconds to grasp the topics of the conversations going on at the table: one about a car cooperative, the other about cars. I guessed they had already started talking past each other.

[2008-07-29 13:07:50] kitchen | I saw Erik and Frida, and a woman standing by the workbench preparing food. Before me were their backs turned toward us. I realized I couldn't remember the woman's name.
[2008-07-29 13:08:00] kitchen | I felt my heart fill with tenderness for Vanja. But I realized there was nothing I could do.
[2008-07-29 13:08:20] kitchen | I watched the person speaking, offered a faint smile at each witty remark, and sipped the red wine someone had placed before me.
[2008-07-29 13:08:40] kitchen | Before me sat the man directly across the table. I saw he had a large face, scarred cheeks, rugged features, and piercing eyes. I noticed his two hands resting on the table were enormous. I felt he was the only one who made a striking impression.

[2008-07-29 13:09:10] kitchen | I felt it wasn't his appearance that set him apart, but his presence. I could sense this man's strong aura even though he hadn't spoken much.
[2008-07-29 13:09:20] kitchen | As far as I knew, I had attended a party in Halvik back in 2004. I recalled that a boxer had also been at that party.
[2008-07-29 13:15:00] kitchen | I felt the man sitting across from me radiated the same presence as the boxer from Halvik. [2008-07-29 13:15:30] kitchen | I sat there deep in thought, occasionally stealing glances at him, while half-listening to the others' endless conversation. I was sinking into deep thought.
[2008-07-29 13:16:00] kitchen | I heard the conversation had turned to various teaching methods and which schools people were considering for their children. I caught snippets of Linus talking about a school sports day he'd attended, and then the talk shifted to housing prices.
[2008-07-29 13:16:30] kitchen | I saw Linus turn his face toward me. I heard a general consensus that house prices had skyrocketed in recent years, but that Halvik had risen even more than here, and perhaps a price drop was only a matter of time.
[2008-07-29 13:16:35] kitchen | I heard Linus ask me, "How are house prices in Leivik?"
[2008-07-29 13:16:45] kitchen | I answered Linus, "About the same as here, roughly. Birren and Halvik are equally expensive. Other provinces are cheaper."
[2008-07-29 13:17:00] kitchen | I saw his gaze linger on my face for a moment, and I noticed that once he realized I had nothing more to say, he turned away and rejoined the conversation. I thought his pause just now was waiting for me to expand on the topic he’d handed me.

[2008-07-29 13:21:00] kitchen | I saw Linus fix us with his sharp, innocent gaze. I prayed silently that we wouldn't have to speak, and that the whole discussion would just end.
[2008-07-29 13:21:15] kitchen | I heard Lundlund crying from the living room.
[2008-07-29 13:21:30] kitchen | I thought of Vanya again. I remembered that her usual way in such situations was to do exactly what others did: if someone pulled out a chair or sat down, she would copy; if someone laughed, she would laugh too, even if she didn't understand why. I realized this was her method.
